column2: A fundamental question for the State Constitutional Convention will be whether the new Constitution should contain a Bill of Rights, similar to the one that is Article I of the present Constitution. We think the answer is an emphatic yes, despite the vigilance of the United States Supreme Court in protecting individual rights.

The Albert Ayler Octet indicated at a concert at the Village Theater on Saturday night that the jazz avant-garde really does have a song in its heart. However, the song turned out to be rather montonous--a singsong country jig that served as an ensemble theme on several occasions.
The nation's 6,200 savings and loan associations had a net inflow of $375-million in savings accounts during January, the United States Savings and Loan League said yesterday.
Production of William Manchester's controversial book, "The Death of a President," was temporarily halted for several days last week to correct an error.

The Tishman Realty Construction Company has been chosen to supervise construction of the mammoth World Trade Center--currently estimated at $575-million in cost with its twin 110-story world's tallest towers.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 26 --The engagement of Miss Nancy Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Martin, to Lieut. John J. Meyers. U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Meyers Jr. of Lynbrook and Southampton. L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents. A June wedding is planned.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 26 (AP)--Lake Placid Bobsled Club teams finished first and second today in the four-man competition of the National Diamond Trophy races.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26-- The Federal Government has decided to establish a dozen or more special centers for the study and treatment of the heart attack in an effort to fill important gaps in medical knowledge about this leading killer.

OTTAWA, Feb. 26--A Royal Commission proposed a taxreform program over the weekend that its chairman said would amount to a "revolution." The program would seek to eliminate inequities, close loopholes, and in general, redistribute income in favor of Canadians with lower earnings.

As New Yorkers bundled up and shivered yesterday in icy gusts and freezing temperatures, a Thalarctos maritimus slept serenely outdoors on a stone slab. "It's a nice comfortable day for him." said a zoo visitor, pointing to the ...

William Alfred, the Harvard University professor of English whose first play, "Hogan's Goat," is running in its second year here, will have another work presented off Broadway. The play, "The Conscience of the Queens," is a black-verse adaptation of the "Agamemnon" of Aeschylus. It was recently known as "A Pride of Lions" and as "Agamemnon" before that.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 26--Top-seeded Mrs. Newton Meade Jr., a 30-year-old Philadelphia housewife, retained the United States women's squashracquets singles championship today at the Vassar College courts.
The Baltimore Gas and Electric Company reported over the weekend 1966 operating revenues of $243,198,000, against $221,828,000 in 1965.
New Jersey disclosed yesterday that it was trying to get direct service into midtown Manhattan for Erie-Lackawanna Railroad commuters through the use of the Pennsylvania Railroad's tracks.

"JUNEBUG GRADUATES TONIGHT:," which opened a limited run last night at the Chelsea Theater Center, asks its viewers to consider what goes through the head of a sensitive young Negro when he thinks about the current state of race relations in America.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26-- Announcement of the engagement of Miss Susan Brady to Ricardo Joaquin Alfaro 2d, has been made here by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Everett Eynon of Honolulu.
Soldiers helped out with the chores at the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center yesterday, and the patients loved it.

A model of a 14th--century Japanese temple that Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving says provides a "tantalizing taste of Japan" will go on display tomorrow in Grand Army Plaza, at Fifth Avenue and Central Park South.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Feb. 26 (AP)--Thomas Morrow, a retired reporter and columnist for The Chicago Tribune, died last night in Cole Hospital. He was 63 years old, and had spent 35 years with The Tribune.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 26--Cutbacks of production by automobile manufacturers tended to offset gains in other Steel markets last week.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26--Mario Andretti of Nazareth, Pa., won the ninth and most exciting Daytona 500mile stock car race today in a 1967 Ford before a crowd of 94,255. He led an imposing array of 600 horsepower American cars on 112 of the 200 laps over the high-banked 2.5-mile course and averaged 146.926 miles an hour.

The revelation that Norman Thomas and others on the non-Communist left were unwittingly subsidized by the Central Intelligence Agency through its decoy foundations has brought an odd complaint from Barry Goldwater. The 1964 Republican Presidential candidate is outraged because conservative organizations like the Young Republicans were not cut in on the C.I.A.'s secret seductions.

TOKYO, Feb. 26--More than 40,000 local political offices from the governerships of 17 of Japan's 46 prefectures to the post or soncho, or headman, in 1,055 towns and villages will be filled in balloting on April 15 and 28.
James Farmer said yesterday that "the efforts of the civilrights movement in the past two years have won some little victories, but have not won victories for the little people."
The advertising business, the communicators say, is a people business. It is also a people-onthe-move business. This weekend was no exception.

Sales of new mutual-fund shares are running at a high rate, but they are well below the boom levels of a year ago. The managers of mutual-fund departments in Wall Street brokerage houses pinpoint two chief factors as a recent depressant on sales.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI)--Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that an antiballistic missile system would be well worth its cost to the United States despite Administration assertions to the contrary.
Investors who received cash distributions, such as cash dividends, on their corporate stocks last year must follow special Federal income-tax procedures.

Japan Air Lines will increase its New York-Tokyo schedule and begin operating daily flights between the two cities on Wednesday. On March 7, the airline will inaugurate flights twice weekly to London.

SHARON, Conn., Feb. 26-- Lewis A. De Blois, an early advocate of industrial safety and president of the National Safety Council in 1923, died of a heart attach this morning at his home here. He was 88 years old.

MANILA, Feb. 26 (UPI)-- Hsu Sheng-san, a 25-year-old amateur from Taiwan, shot a five-under-par 67 today for a 72-hole total of 283 and became the second amateur to win the Philippine open golf tournment.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26-- The United Arab Republic has failed to make two scheduled debt repayments of $4-million each in the last two months to the International Monetary Fund.

HIROSHIMA, Japan, Feb. 26 --Mayor Shinzo Hamai is having trouble raising funds from the public to preserve the ruin of the Hiroshima Industrial Promotion Hall, now renamed the Dome, as a reminder of the 1945 atomic holocaust here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26-- Barry Goldwater demanded today to know why the Central Intelligence Agency had been financing "left-wing" organizations but not conservative groups such as the Young Republicans.
Two of the chief combatants in the current fight over the State's abortion law stood jaw to jaw in an unscheduled debate in a corridor yesterday and traded loud and angry words.

Dr. Ralph H. McKee, discoverer of a variety of fast-growing poplar trees for the wood-pulp industry and the first man to get a patent for a plant, died at his home, 635 Riverside Drive, on Friday. He was 92 years old.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 27 (AP)--The Vietcong shelled the vast American air base at Danang with mortars and rockets before dawn today, killing 11 Americans and at least 30 Vietnamese, United States spokesmen said.
A record total of 23,795 abandoned automobiles were towed from the city's streets last year.

SOMERS,Conn., Feb. 26-- Frank Vita of Somers, Conn.-- one of five members of his family in the competition--won two horsemanship classes today, one championship and one reserve at the Shallow Brook horse show.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 26 (UPI)--Jim Clark, a former world driving champion, won his second Tasman series championship today with a runaway victory in the international cup race at the nearby Sandown track.

BOSTON, Feb. 26 (AP)--The attorney for Albet DeSalvo, who says he is the "Boston Strangler," said tonight that his client was happy it Walpole State Prison and that no immediate attempt would be made to have him moved.

MOSCOW, Feb. 26--The leaders of most European Communist parties plan to meet in Czechoslavakia April 24 to 27 in what the Soviet Union hopes will be the first step toward a world conference of Communist parties.
ALBANY, Feb. 26--Theodore C. Sorensen, former special counsel to President Kennedy, urged today that the State Constitutional Convention lower the voting age from 21 to 18.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 26 --The uniform time law that Congress passed last year has muffled the annual uproar over daylight saving time, but rumblings of discontent are still heard in the backlands.
MIKHAIL BOTVINNIK of the Soviet Union, former world champion, won the 1966-67 Hastings, England, Chess Congress, but came up against a stubborn first-round foe in W.R. Hartston of England.
Los Indios Tabajaras, two Brazilian brothers, presented a program of guitar and vocal works at Town Hall Saturday night for a highly enthusiastic audience of 1,250 persons.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Feb. 26--When he speaks of the Air Force Academy's current cheating scandal, Lieut, Gen. Thomas Samuel Moorman's eyes mist over and his voice softens. "These are only young men." he says. "We must remember that.

CHEVY CHASE, Md., Feb. 26 --Mr. and Mrs. Sol Schildhause have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Harriet Schildhause, to John Alexander Lack. He is the son of Mrs. Jerome Marrow of New York and the late Julius Lack.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within 12 months amount to $104,113,786,010. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
Tension between Mongolia and Communist China has risen sharply recently in the wake of what the Chinese Foreign Ministry has charged are deliberate Mongolian insults to Mao Tse-tung.

Regaining the lead in the final 600 yards, John Garlepp of the Millrose Athletic Association raced to a 70-yard victory yesterday in the ninth annual Cherry Tree Marathon, run along the Harlem River in the West Bronx.

Uto Ughi, an Italian violinist who was born in 1944, made his local debut Saturday night in a showy program at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Ughi has a past and undeniably a future, for he was a stirring performer, not without imperfections, but nonetheless communicative.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands" Feb. 26--The Dutch National Ballet is big in many respects, including its repertory, its subsidy and the number of its dancers, but its only claim to much attention artistically is in its permanent choreographer, Rudi van Dantzig, who has just mounted a new version of Prokofiey's "Romeo and Juliet" for the company.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 26--A Grand Opera Ball will be given on Saturday at the Carriage Trade here with Giorgi Tozzi, Metropolitan Opera bass, as guest of honor. The ball's sponsor is the Guild of Opera Theater of New Jersey, and the proceeds will benefit the theater's production fund.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP)-- Walter (Fats) Pichon, one of the last of the New Orleans riverboat jazz pianists, died today in a hospital after a heart attack. He was 60 years old. Mr. Pichon started his musical career at 14, in New Orleans, playing dances. Much of his career was spent on riverboats plying the Missisippi between New Orleans and St. Paul.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 26-- There is considerable Pretense, but little pretense about Mrs. Liz Whitney Tippett.
Top-seeded players took the finals in the New York tennis singles championships in both the boys and girls 18-year-andunder classes yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory.
Four members of the J.I. Kislak Organization, real estate, mortgage banking and insurance company with headquarters in Newark, have been appointed to vice presidencies.
PANAMA, Feb. 26 (UPI)-- Bert Weaver of Biloxi, Miss., shot a 71 today for a 14-underpar 72-hole total of 274 and a three-stroke victory in the Panama open.

LONDON, Feb. 26--As the curtaias leading onto the platform of the Festival Hall parted this evening and the tall, gaunt figure of otto Klemperer painfully made its way to the podium, a huge audience instinctively rose to its feet. The last time that can be recalled when London concert-goers stood for a conductor was when Toscanini made his only reappearance after World War II.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI)--The Council of State Chambers of Commerce said today that Congress should cut $5.4-billion out of President Johnson's budget for the fiscal year 1968 to avoid the proposed 6 per cent surcharge on income taxes.

The New York International Sport and Camping Show closed a nine-day run at the Celiseum yesterday with a flurry of awards and prizes and an appearance by Johnny Unitas, the Baltimore Colt quarterback. The show set records for exhibits, floor space occupied and total attendance.
George L. Fichtenbaum has been appointed executive director of the American Society of Travel Agents.
ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 25--The other day the Ghana State Fishing Corporation came in for incisive criticism from an economics professor at the University of Ghana.
James S. Thompson has been named financial vice president of Yardley of London, Inc. He was formerly controller of the Chun King Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI)--The Johnson Administration plans tomorrow to release a substantial part of the $1.1-billion in Federal highway construction funds frozen last fall.
TOKYO, Feb. 26 (Reuters)-- Some 1,500 demonstrators fought the police in a five-hour battle outside the United States air base at Tachikawa, near here, today.
ROME, Feb. 26--The massive migration by south Europeans to jobs in the north, a vital ingredient of Europe's economic well-being and social stability for a decade, has begun to move in reverse.
The Toronto Maple Leafs would have made Sisyphus give up.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26-- Samuel W. Yorty, Los Angeles self-styled maverick Mayor, is scheduled to report to the people tomorrow about his recent global junketing.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 26--What is it like to be 20 years old, handsome, carefree and the world's best pole vaulter?
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 26 (UPI)-- Sam Jones scored 39 points today to lead the Boston Celtics to a 130-119 victory over the St. Louis Hawks in a National Basketball Association game.
Max O. Urbahn, head of the New York architectural firm that bears his name, has been elected president of the New York Board of Trade.
The University of Texas defeated Mary Baldwin College by a score of 220 to 110 yesterday on the National Broadcasting Company's "College Bowl" television program. It was the third victory for Texas.
TORONTO--Two of the biggest mining and oil stock scandals in Canadian history return to public attention this week in Toronto courts.

JERUSALEM. Israel, Feb. 26 (UPI)--Nine American Roman Catholic leaders participated in an unusual interfaith prayer for peace today in the court below the room venerated as the site of the Last Supper on Mount Zion.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration has recalled 248,000 pounds of canned Alaska salmon after discovering that many cans were contaminated.
The credit markets appeared to have a split personality yes terday short-term interest rates declined and long-term rates went up.
ALBANY, Feb. 27 The bank-robbery trial of John (Sonny) Franzese was described by a defense lawyer today as "Peyton Place in Albany" a "Grade B movie" played by "four characters in search of a stage."
PORT HURON, Mich., Feb. 27 Dr. Clarence D. Selby, medical consultant to General Motors Corporation from 1935 to 1949, died yesterday at the age of 88.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Supreme Court agreed today to consider whether states can constitutionally prevent labor unions from employing salaried lawyers to provide free legal services for the unions' members.

LINCOLN, R.I., Feb. 27 (UPI) Hildy's Lou and Commogirl won the first two races at Lincoln Downs today and produced a $4,202.40 daily double, the largest in the track's history. Fifteen persons collected on $2 tickets.
An investigation of a Pennsylvania insurance company led to the recovery yesterday of more than $1-million in securities reported missing last August by Hayden, Stone, Inc., brokerage house here.
Steel production rose in the week ended Saturday to the highest level in four months, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 Miss Barbara M. Watson, a Negro lawyer from New York City, is expected to be promoted shortly to head the State Department's Bureau of Security and Consular Affairs, the highest post ever held by a woman in the department.

The Radio Corporation of America achieved new highs in 1966 sales and earnings, accord- ing to the annual report released yesterday.. The new fig- ures topped year-end estimates as sales ran 22 per cent higher than in 1965 and net income soared 29 per cent.
HONG KONG, Feb. 27 (Reuters) Communist China issued its 426th "serious warning" today on alleged United States violation of its air space. Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, said.

A brief sinking spell in the Canadian dollar, in response to the Royal Commission report on that country's tax system that was issued over the weekend, provided about the only interest yesterday in an otherwise dull foreign-exchange market.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--Exports rose sharply in January and the export surplus increased in the month, the Commerce Department reported today.
Labor Secretary W. Willard Wirtz criticized news media yesterday for "selective coverage" and for emphasizing negative rather than positive aspects of the news.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 The chairman of the Assembly's Codes Committee said today there was "a chance the vote would be delayed" on a bill to liberalize the abortion law if there were "difficult amendments that need study."
A flying jewelry exhibit valued at $2-million set up shop under heavy guard at the New York Hilton Hotel yesterday.
MONTGOMERY, Ala. It is almost a commonplace in the South that a city will boast one restaurant of singular distinction. In Montgomery it is the Blue Moon, otherwise known as Miss Leila Dowe's.

A spokesman for the Health Services Administration in New York said last night that city officials had recalled some salmon marketed under the brand names of Bernice, Three Castles and Lucky Boy. Another brand, Endico, marketed by Louis Ender, Inc., of Brooklyn, also was involved, according to the spokesman, Milton Levenson, director of public information for the Health Services Administration.
From all parts of the world top amateur and professional players were flocking into town yesterday for New York's biggest week of winter tennis.
WHEN Mrs. Chiyo Tanaka started her fashion career more than 30 years ago, her own countrymen sometimes mistook her for a spy.

AARHUS, Denmark, Tuesday, Feb. 28 (Reuters) The 2,435-ton Soviet ship Tukan sank in the Skagerrak strait early today, and between 20 and 30 lifeless bodies were sighted in the water, the Danish Naval Command reported.

George Rowen, a freelance photographer at the United Nations, known by many delegates and members of the secretariat, died of a heart attack yesterday in his apartment. He was 46 years old and lived at 311 East 72d Street. He had suffered two previous heart attacks, the first in 1963 and the second about a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) A House judiciary subcommittee approved today a comprehensive revision of the 58-year-old United States copyright law. The measure makes allowance for such "new devices" as jukeboxes, as well as newer ones yet to be known.

State Department support of a program to bring the most serious cases of war-maimed children from South Vietnam to this country for treatment was announced yesterday by the Committee of Responsibility to save War-Burned and WarInjured Vietnamese Children.
Legislation advancing the collection dates on real estate taxes by two months will be introduced in the City Council today by the Lindsay administration as a means of saving $14-million a year.

SEATTLE, Feb. 27 (AP) Attorneys for Paul Thiry, Seattle architect, filed a libel action against The Atantic Monthly in United States District Court here today asking $1-million in damages. The suit contends that an article in the

CLEVELAND, Feb. 27--H. James Rand 3d, president of the Rand Development Corporation, conceded here today that between June, 1966, and last Jan. 11 he transferred or sold more than 108,000 Class B shares in the company.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 27 Belgian law is to be poured into the memory of a computer so that when a judge or law yer wants to research a case all he would have to do, in effect, is press a button.

TOKYO, Feb. 27 (AP) Thirty-nine sopranos from 22 countries will compete here March 15 to 22 in the first Madama Butterfly Competition for singers of the title role in Puccini's opera, the Tamaka, Miuri Memorial Association announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Treasury announced today that it would deny all applications to send dollars to such organizations as the Canadian Friends Service Committee for the purchase of medical supplies to be shipped to North Vietnam.

Mr. and Mrs. Agelisao Dutra of Rio de Janeiro have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ina Dutra, to Peter Vandervoort Savage. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Chauncey Savage of Haverford, Pa., The wedding is planned for April 3 in Rio.
MIAMI, Feb. 27 Federal grand jury in Miami today indicted seven men, including a former Cuban Senator and an exiled Haitian priest, on charges of trying to invade Haiti from the United States.
MOSCOW, Feb. 27 President Nikolai V. Podgorny tonight condemned United States rejections of recent moves by North Vietnam to start peace talks and he strongly endorsed Hanoi's position.
DURHAM N.C., Feb. 27 Gradual, but substantial, progress in the survival of transplanted kidneys was reported here today.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 27 Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Isadore Fingeroth have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Louise Fingeroth, to Dr. Neal Lambert Kaplan, son of Mrs. Samuel Kaplan of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Kaplan.

Denis Stevens will make his debut here March 7, conducting Monteverdi's Vespers of 1610 in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. Mr. Stevens, conductor of the Ambrosian Singers of England, is a member of the Columbia music faculty. He will use his own edition of the Monteverdi for the performance, which will be sung by the University Chapel Choir accompanied by two organs and orchestra.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that he would have six bills introduced in the Legislature in Albany designed to give the city greater control of public utilities.
A Pan American World Airways jet with 98 passengers aboard landed at Kennedy International Airport last night without its pilot's hand on the controls.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) Justice Hugo L. Black, the sixth oldest man to sit on the Supreme Court of the United States, celebrated his 81st birthday today without fanfare.

TOKYO, Feb. 27 Arthur J. Goldberg, the United States' chief delegate to the United Nations, obtained an agreement today under which Tokyo will consult with Washington regularly, in advance, on questions likely to come before the General Assembly.

PARIS, Feb. 27 The funniest place here to pick out neckties on girls, since boys often don't wear them is at La Coupole, the huge cafe-restaurant in Montparnasse where a drifting cast of young Parisians put on a late, late fashion show almost every night.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 27 Casey Stengel, the boy philosopher, always studied the alternatives before writing out his batting order and he finally came to one inescapable conclusion.
A dispute arose yesterday between two major poll-taking organizations over how much television the more affluent, better-educated American is watching.

Stephen H. Larrabee, chief executive officer for South American operations of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, died Sunday in an automobile accident on a winding stretch of the Pan American Highway in Pasamayo, Peru. He was 59 years old and lived in Lima, Peru.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Feb. 27 (UPI) Two masked gunmen help up a branch office of the Main Savings and Loan Association here today, escaping with $8,000.

The nightclub that hired barebreasted waitresses, now fighting a 90-day suspension of its cabaret license, obtained an order in State Supreme Court yesterday requiring the State Liquor Authority to show cause why the nightclub's liquor license, which was canceled last Thursday, should not be renewed.
The range of Max Pollikoff's "Music in Our Time" series is astounding.

PEGGY FLEMING, a freshman at Colorado College, will begin defense of her world figure skating title in Vienna today. She is the fifth champion figure skater to attend the college at Colorado Springs in the last decade. But the college does not take credit for the champions just
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--A special study commission on the draft appointed by the House Armed Services Committee recommended today that the youngest men, rather than the oldest, be inducted first.

IN the torrent of last fall's books, one of the very good ones that almost got away is Hanson Baldwin's most recent volume. If it got away from you, too, now is the time to make up the deficiency. For Mr. Baldwin's chapters make up a series of heroic episodes heroically told. Eleven battles and campaigns of World War II are de

SARASOTA, Fla., Feb 27 (UPI) The Florida murder trial of Dr. Carl A. Coppolino was ordered today to be held in the small coastal town of Naples, about 100 miles south of Sarasota. It will begin April 3.
The Wholesale commodity price index fell to 101.4 on Friday from 101.8 on Thursday.
TORONTO, Feb. 27 (Canadian Press) Canada and the United States should establish their own free-trade area, David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank of New York, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) The medal of honor was presented today to a Marine Corps officer who braved heavy, Vietcong machine gun and mortar fire to lead a counterattack by an ambushed American patrol in December, 1966.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) The House Ways and Means Committee went along part way with President Johnson's request for stiffening the interest-equalization tax.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 President Johnson sought today to calm a growing political storm by releasing $175-million in highway funds and promising to release $225-million more by July 1.

GRENOBLE, France, Thursday, Feb. 28 The campaign for elections to the National Assembly reached a peak last night and early today at a noisy Gaullist rally where Premier Georges Pompidou defeated former Premier Pierre Mendes-France.

The State Harness Racing Commission heard more testimony yesterday, some of it conflicting sharply with previous reports, as hearings continued on Bud Gilmour's appeal to have his driver's license renewed.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 27--Foreign Minister Tran Van Do asserted today that North Vietnam had "rebuffed or ig- nored" every peace over- ture made by his Government.

NATCHEZ, Miss., Feb. 27 The treasurer of the Natchez branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was killed tonight when an explosion ripped through his truck and sent it crashing into a utility pole.
LONDON, Feb. 27 (AP) Gales gusting to 80 miles an hour swept much of Britain today, brining floods and blocking roads.
The American Stock Ex change declined yesterday along a broad front after a week of backing and filling.

MIDWINTER is the season when New York department store buyers, although up to their knees in boots, are up to their chins in spring summer merchandise. But recently coat and ensemble buyers at Bonwit Teller and Lord Taylor have taken a plunge into next fall.
ABOARD THE MARS, off North Vietnam There is no more impressive example of the logistic legerdemain of the American armed services than this modern supply ship.
WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 27 Angus B. Echols, a retired vice president of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., died today, at his home in nearby Greenville. He was 77 years old.
HENRY MOORE and his sculpture share one characteristic: neither looks like what the man in the street might expect.

In a report to the American Chemical Society in 1955, Dr. Martin held that the human body was continually being fomed and reformed and that all its elements were constantly engaged in a struggle for supremacy. If the balance of these elements were off, he said, disease or disorder might result.
Three men accused of having $1,580 in counterfeit $20 bills were arrested in the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Supreme Court declared today that the Justice Department had "knuckled under" to the El Paso Natural Gas Company by giving it favorable terms in an antitrust settlement.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 27 West German sources said here today that the resumption of relations between Bonn and the rest of the Arab states depended on how much aid West Germany was prepared to extend.
The Sunbeam Corporation, Chicago-based producer of home appliance, is negotiating to acquire NuTone, Inc., Cincin- nati makers of kitchen appliances, radios, lighting fixtures, stereos and lamps.

A drug that has been found to reduce cholesterol levels in the blood stream significantly and is already in widespread use in Europe will be marketed in the United States by May 1, its American distributor said yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27 (AP) The Bank of America reported today the loss of 5,000 blank money orders that pre- sumably disappeared while on the way to the bank's branch in Oakland.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 27 Has Frank Merriwell been turned on? Is the traditional boolaboola of Yale being replaced by plain boo, which, translated from the underground argot, means marijuana?
The commodities futures trade is marshalling opposition against plans by the Commodity Exchange Authority to require more information from brokers.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 Moses M. Weinstein of Queens, majority leader of the Assembly, pre dicted today that the Legislaure would not act this year on the compulsory health insurance plan advocated last week by Governor Rockefeller and the legislative leaders.

Increased charges for its new commercial jet transport programs, impact of program costs for massive expansion and commercial jet delivery delays held earnings of the Boeing Company last year 3 per cent below the record level of 1965.

MIAMI, Feb. 27 A close victory by Athen's Gem over Mandioca in the main race featured the program at Hialeah today. With Leroy Moyers riding, Athen's Gem made the lead stand up all the way in the sixfurlong sprint for fillies and mares, scoring by a neck. Foreign Fable was third in the field of 12.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 27 (Reuters) The motion picture "The Quiller Memorandum" has been changed in the West German version to eliminate all references to the villains as belonging to a neo-Nazi terror organization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 President Johnson told Congress today that he was going to seek to abolish the appointed District of Columbia city government as an interim step toward home rule. He also proposed a broad attack on crime in the capital.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI)--The Federal Aviation Agency said today it had banned pressurized flights in DC-6 and DC-7 airplanes because of a decompression explosion in a Northeast Airlines DC-6 over Holmdel, N.J., last Friday.
The Continental Oil Company, a leading independent marketer of oil products, announced yesterday that it would rescind a portion of its gasoline price rise initiated earlier this month.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) The Supreme Court today gave minority stockholders the opportunity to block the Missouri Pacific Railroad's planned consolidation with the Texas Pacific Railway.

Next Saturday's I.C. 4-A indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden have attracted entries from 60 colleges. But the one that will win the team title, everyone agrees, is Villanova.

MILL VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 27 The multiracial student body of Tamalpais High School skipped classes today with administration approval, aired complaints in discussion groups and sought solutions for racial disturbances.

An international manhunt has been started for an erstwhile foreign-exchange trader in the Beirut branch of the First Na- tional City Bank. Walter B. Wriston, executive vice president of the bank, said yesterday.
Norman Reid, director of the Tate Gallery, who is in New York on a brief visit, said yesterday that the British Government had allocated $2.1-million for the construction of a new wing.

"The total amount of new construction work being contracted has been slipping all too steadily since last spring," ac cording to George A. Christie, chief economist of the F.W. Dodge Company in his analysis of the country's construction activity in January. Dodge is the construction-research division of McGraw-Hill, Inc.
Potato futures "were pinned to the ceiling all day," according to one trader yesterday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Tuesday, Feb. 28 (AP) An earthquake blasted the East Java city of Malang Feb. 20, killing at least 51 people, injuring about 370 and demolishing more than 2,000 houses, the official news agency Antara reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27(AP) A House Republican leader, Melvin R. Laird, said today anything short of a free South Vietnam when peace came would not justify the sacrifice being made by United States servicemen.

Jacob B. Olstein, chairman of Riverdale Drapery Fabrics, 295 Fifth Avenue, a division of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 710 Park Avenue.

HAZLET, N.J., Feb. 27 Mr. and Mrs. Harold T. Byrne have announced the engagement or Mr. Byrne's daughter, Miss Lynn Harri Byrne, to John W. Beaudean Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Beaudean of Cape Girardeau, Mo. The wedding is planned for Aug. 26.

An Orthodox synagogue was broken into Sunday night for the third time in four weeks. Papers and books were scattered about and $500 as taken from a battered-in safe at the synagogue, Congregation Emu nath Israel at 236 West 23d Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 Demands for stiffer punishment of Representative Adam Clayton Powell than was recommended by a select committee have threatened the plan to seat and censure him.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 27 A Federal grand jury handed down new indictments today in two Mississippi civil, rights murder cases, but the identities of the persons charged were withheld pending arrests.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 27 Mrs. Elizabeth Hosford Cudmore, a former delegate and alternate delegate from New York City to Republican national and state conventions, died today at Bridgeport Hospital. She was 86 years old and lived on Fairfield Beach Road, Fairfield.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27--The American Medical Association gave cautious approval today to continued use of birth control pills.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 27--The City Council approved legislation today to ban discrimination in the sale or rental of all housing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--Treasury bill rates declined sharply at today's auction from the levels of a week ago, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 27--Members of the Jersey City Federation of Teachers, who began a walkout Feb. 15, returned to their classrooms today and all four public high schools operated normally.
Amos M. Kidder, a wellknown figure in Wall Street until his retirement four years ago, died on Sunday at the age of 75. He lived in Seabright, N.J.
Mrs. Marguerite Beatty Barber, widow of Dr. S. LeRoy Barber, and mother of the composer Samuel Barber, died yesterday in the Cotter Home North, Westchester, Pa. Her age was 85.

Miss Barbara Gail Reich and Simon B. Gluck were married yesterday evening at the Essex House. Rabbis Moses Feinstein, Emanuel Gettinger, Bernard Bergman, Ben Zion Frankel, Isaac Goodman and Baruch Rokeach officiated.

ADEN, Feb. 27 (Reuters) Six persons were killed today in a bomb attack on the home of Abdul Qawee Mackawee, secretary general of the Egyptian-backed Front for the Liberation of Occupied South Yemen, an anti-British group.
HONG KONG, Feb. 27 Army troops and civilians in two Chinese provinces have been warned to work hard to prevent famine.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The Supreme Court cleared the way today for the early imprisonment of James R. Hoffa by refusing to reconsider its decision upholding his eight-year sentence for jury tampering.
ROME, Feb. 27 Only one out of 10 Americans living abroad voted in the last Presidential election, Alfred E. Davidson, co-chairman of the Bipartisan Committee cf Absentee Voting, said here today.

A debut recital sponsored by Young Concert Artists, Inc., is something to be anticipated With interest, because this nonprofit organization has a remarkably good record for the spotting of genuine musical talents.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., Feb. 27 (UPI) A German freighter burst into flames in the Atlantic today, and one crewman was killed. The other 22 men aboard the ship were rescued.

ROCHESTER, Feb. 27 (AP) The Xerox Corporation said that it expected to hire about 150 additional disadvantaged Negroes and members of other minorities within the next year either through direct hiring or training programs.

Consolidated Edison, which has dug up most of New York's streets at one time or another, has turned its attention to the East River.
"Dundas and Son," a new musical, is to arrive here in midNovember at a cost of $550,000. It is a joint venture by the Los Angeles and San Francisco Civic Light Opera Associations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) Gov. Ronald Reagan of California has sent the Republican Senate and House campaign committees a personal check for $5,000 for seats at a party fund-raising dinner here Wednesday night.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 27 Eighty residents of Yonkers appeared at a meeting of the County Board of Supervisors today to protest the state's plan to open a narcotics center there, but the board voted not to oppose the plan.

LONDON, Feb. 27 Britain today threatened "massive withdrawals'" of troops from her Army on the Rhine if West Germany did not make "substantial" commitments by April 11 to meet the foreignexchange cost of keeping the troops there.
A. James Liguori, sergeant at arms of the City Council for the last 17 years, died Friday night at the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 385 Halsey Street, Brooklyn.

PENN VALLEY, Pa., Feb. 27 Mr. and Mrs. H. Russell Young have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Cornbrooks Young, to Richard A. Furniss Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Furniss, also of Penn Valley. A September wedding is planned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 President Johnson, appearing confident about the war and stoical about his critics, said today that he had ordered new types of military action in Vietnam in recent days to hasten the end of the fighting.
LONDON, Feb. 27 "We're being terribly chaotic," said the matronly looking British woman with evident delight as she sorted out a gaggle of actors and actresses waiting to meet Princess Margaret.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 27 Organized labor's high command delayed today taking a final position on Administration proposals to impose a 6 per cent income surtax and to create a department of economic affairs.

MADRID, Feb. 27 Spain's cardinals and bishops began today a week of meetings to try to settle a major problem posed by the Spanish Catholic Action movement, which has split churchmen and the laity.

LONDON, Feb. 27 (AP) British European Airways told its 1,300 hostesses and stewards today to quit draining the dregs ]eft by passengers.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Feb. 27 Four more cadets resigned from the Air Force Academy today, bringing the total to 40 who have quit in the continuing investigation of academic cheating.
WEEHAWKEN, N.J., Feb. 27 John F. Cahir, retired vice president of the Shamrock Towing Company in New York, died yesterday at his home. He was 80 years old and lived at 42 Cooper Place here.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 27--Twelve handicapped youngsters from Public School 129 in Harlem taught Cornell University students something about Negro history today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 A dispute developed here today over the toll-free status of a stretch of the Garden State Parkway in New Jersey.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 27--Roosevelt Raceway will offer four exactas, two more than last year, to its betting patrons when it opens a 70-night meeting on Saturday. HILLSBORO, N.M. Feb. 27 (AP) Mrs. Ginger Lamb, who with her husband, Dana, spent much of their 33-year marriage exploring Latin America, died of a heart ailment and pneumonia on Saturday. She was 53 years old.
LAWRENCE, Mass., Feb. 27 The Rev. Dr. Arthur Nelson Taft, a retired Episcopal priest who was the oldest living alumnus of Williams College, died today in a nursing home. He was 99 years old.
The Earl of Snowdon, husband of Princess Margaret, said here yesterday that rumors that they were on the verge of divorce were wholly unfounded.

Dr. Jacob M. Ravid, for 19 years chief of pathology at St. Clare's Hospital here, died Sunday night in Doctors Hospital after a heart attack. He was 69 years old and lived at 2796 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 27 The regime of President Humberto Castelo Branco announced today the suspension of the political rights of 44 labor leaders and local politicians.

STUART, Fla., Feb. 27--Scientists say the next ice age isn't due for at least a few thousand years yet, but to judge by the temperatures afflicting Florida they must be wrong. The leading edge of the ice cap must be at the Georgia state line and moving southward fast.
GENEVA, Feb. 27--South Africa denied today that she was holding any "political" prisoners and also denied charges that any said to be in this category had been brutally treated.

BONN, Feb. 27 Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger complained today that West Germany and the United States were accentuating the negative in their relations.
CAPETOWN, Feb. 27 The 1,388-ton oceanographic research vessel Robert D. Conrad, on loan from the Navy to Columbia University's Lamont Observatory, arrived at Capetown today.
PEORIA. Ill., Feb. 27 (UPI) A fourth juror was tentatively seated today just before the murder trial of Richard Franklin Speck, accused of slaying eight nurses in Chicago, was recessed for the day.
Villanova, which scored re- cent victories over three teams entered in the National Invita tion Tournament, accepted a bid to the N.I.T. yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 27 (Reuters) The executive board of the International Federation of Journalists said today it was convinced that the American Newspaper Guild had not knowingly accepted contributions from the Central Intelligence Agency.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) The American Federation of Teachers called today for a $5,000-a-year raise for each of the nation's 1.8 million public school teachers.
BRANCHBURG, N.J., Feb. 27 Thor Solberg, who in 1935 piloted the first northern-route flight to Europe, died yesterday in Somerset Hospital at Somerville. He was 73 years old and lived here.

NEWARK, Feb. 27 The Prudential Insurance Company of America, striving unstinting- ly to bump the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company from top place in the industry, posed the tentative claim today that its 1966 sales volume "once again led the industry."
The New York Yankees, whose main concern in 1967 is to escape the darkness of the American League cellar, also have plans to brighten the areas surrounding Yankee Stadium.

MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 27 (AP) James Clark, former Dallas County Sheriff, was held in civil contempt of a Federal court today in connection with the forced march of 200 Negroes during civil rights demonstrations in Selma, Ala., in 1964.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay are considering a longcontroversial plan to use the surplus revenue of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority to help avoid increasing the subway and bus fare in New York City.
New York Supreme Court Justice Vincent A. Lupiano re- served decision yesterday on the equity of a proposed settle- ment of five stockholder suits against the Dreyfus Corpora- tion.

Norman Tishman, chairman of the board of Tishman Realty and Construction Company, Inc., one of the country's leading developers of offices and apartments died yesterday at his home, 14 East 75th Street. His age was 65.

The scholarship fund of the Vassar Club of New York will receive the proceeds of the Metropolitan Opera Company's March 18 performance of Puccini's "La Boheme."

Miss Jennie Lee, Britain's uncrowned minister for the arts, would like to set up a National Film School in England, start what she calls an open university, and bring classical drama withing easy range of the TV dial.

ATHENS, Feb. 27 The Athens court-martial trying 28 Greek officers for an alleged plot against the Government reopened its doors tonight to the public and the press after a month-long ban for reasons of "public order."
Michael Stern, a stocky 21year-old Bronx student, walked out of Bronx Supreme Court a free man yesterday although he had confessed to raping a 75-year-old woman exactly two years before.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to review a Federal Communications Commission ruling against lower rates for some communications services.
The Board of Higher Educatior, approved last night a plan to establish "named" professorships in colleges of the City University.
A conflict within the Lindsay administration threatens to delay plans for the use of a 24block urban renewal site in lower Manhattan that will be vacated next week by the Washington Street Market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)--Stanford Smith, the general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, said today that freedom of speech, press and religion was everybody's business.
LONDON, Feb. 27 Poland's Foreign Minister, Adam Rapacki, returned home today from a week's talks in Britain that showed that the two countries had much in common but that they disagreed on Germany.

Space agency officials at yesterday's Congressional hearing acknowledged that inadequacies in standards and procedures contributed to last month's tragic deaths of astronauts Grissom, White and Chaffee. The nation will accept unquestioningly their assurances that they are doing all in their power to correct the errors that were exposed in such costly fashion.

Fredd Wayne's one-man show, "Benjamin Franklin, Citizen." will tour Western Europe and Scandinavia in the spring under the State Department's cultural exchange program. Prior to going overseas, it will be presented April 16 and 17 at Lincoln Center's Forum Theater before United Nations delegates.
Copper issues advanced in an otherwise mixed list on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 27 (AP) Friends and associates of Roy A. Roberts in his more than half a century as a newspaperman attended the funeral today for the retired board chairman of The Kansas city Star.
Oriental manuscripts from a world-famous collection will be on exhibition today at the Princeton University Library, on loan from Sir A. Chester Beatty of Dublin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 President Johnson said today that business spending for plant and equipment would be up this year by 6 or 7 per cent from 1966 levels.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 27 Mrs. Emilie B. Cole, a founder of the Elizabeth Symphony Orchestra and wife of Walter H. Cole St., former president of the Moore Brothers Foundry here, died last night at her home, 525 Irvington Avenue. She was 81 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The United States has offered to provide about a third of the $200-million in foreign aid that Indonesia says she needs in the current year to carry out an economic stabilization program, United States officials said today.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 27 A high-level North Vietnamese diplomatic mission is in Rangoon at a time when Secretary General Thant of the United Nations is vacationing in his homeland. The purpose of the North Vietnamese group is shrouded in secrecy.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27 To a rookie trying to win a job in baseball spring training is the road ahead. To an old-timer trying to win a job in baseball, it may be the road back to stardom or to Kansas.

Suffolk County Judge Floyd Sarisohn, facing trial on misconduct charges before the Appellate Division, filed suit yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn, seeking to restrain the appellate court from taking disciplinary action against him.

The women's division of the United Jewish Appeal will hold a rally to open its annual fund drive March 9 at 10 A.M. in the New York Hilton Hotel. Chairmen of the campaign are Mrs. Warren E. Abrams and Mrs. Chester M. Ross.
The maritime industry's reaction to proposals advanced over the weekend for a new five-year Federal shipping pol icy as sharply dividend yes terday.

A 20-point performance by Bruce Kaplan in a 5 -minute span in the second half erased a 7-point Long Island University lead and paced New York University to a 90-81 victory in a Metropolitan Conference basket ball game last night on the L.I.U. court.

New York City went into Small Claims Court yesterday to defend itself against the first damage suit brought by a motorist in the new program of towing away illegally parked vehicles in midtown Manhattan.

Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling of the Bahamas outlined plans here yesterday to make it "more difficult" to use the resort islands as a haven for illegal business and underworld gambling operations.

HOUSTON, Feb. 27 Securities and Exchange Commission lawyers will seek terms tomorrow under which the trustees of the Westec Corporation of Houston would be permitted to hire a financial adviser to guide in the company's reorganiza- tion.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The United States Supreme Court today admitted to practice the following New York lawyers: James B. Hurlock and Michael P. Oshatz.
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 27 John R. Clark, president of the Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Union from 1949 through 1963, died yesterday in a Tucson hospital. He was 78 years old.

TORONTO, Feb. 27 (Canad- ian Press) It was "hot un- usual" that shares of Consolid- ated Golden Arrow should al- most triple in price from 25 cents to 65 cents in an hour's trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange July 10, 1964, a Toronto broker testified today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) hTe Justice Department accused a North Carolina company of job discrimination today in ith first suit under the equal employment opportunity section of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

James Baldwin and Ossie Davis have severed connections with Liberator, the black nationalist magazine, in protest against the publication of articles described as anti-Sem itic.

GENEVA, Feb. 27 David A. Morse, a New Yorker who was Under Secretary of Labor during the Truman Administration, was re-elected today as director general of the International Labor Organization for five years.

THE Open Teams Championship at the George Washington Tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association ended on Sunday in a victory for the New York team of Frank Begley, Phil Goodman and Mr. and Mrs. Max Ritter.
ATCHISON, Kan., Feb. 27 Joe Vollmer, his eyes bright, leaned forward on the rickety bleacher bench and watched a buyer prod a snorting blackand-white sow toward the scales with wooden pole.
A 10-year-old Queens boy skating on a frozen creek yesterday fell through the ice and drowned despite efforts by his friends and the police to rescue him.
LONDON, Feb. 27--Henry Moore has offered to give the Tate Gallery 20 or 30 of his major sculptures, said to be worth 1-million ($2.8-million).
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The space agency conceded today that many of its standards and procedures were "inadequate" to have prevented the Apollo spacecraft fire in which three astronauts perished.
The scholarship fund of the Westchester Day School in Mamaroneck, N.Y., will benefit from the Fantasia Ball, a dinner dance March 12 at the Pierre.

Eugene Rodriguez, who lost his State Senate seat on being sentenced to prison for an attempted shakedown, pleaded guilty yesterday to a plot to murder the chief witness against him.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--Popular demand for higher and higher levels of excellence has created a new breed of humanity so superior at the skills that baffle the rest of us that they take much of the joy out of life. These are the superpeople.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Tarlowe of New York and Sag Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mr. Tarlowe's daughter, Miss Diana Ellen Tarlowe, to Allan Richard Strauss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond R. Strauss of Milwaukee.
AMITYVILLE, L.I., Feb. 27 Harry McNaughton, actor, died yesterday in Brunswick Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 4 Albert Road.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 27 Miss Helen Norris Lancaster, a reporter of social events here for The Newark News for 36 years, died yesterday at Clover Rest Nursing Home. She was 76 years old.
BONN, Feb. 28 West Germany and Jordan resumed diplomatic relations today after a break of nearly two years.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 28--The final prosecution witnesses at a military tribunal's hearing of treason charges against a former army brigadier general, Supardjo, testified today that they had sheltered the accused during the 14 months he was a fugitive because "he was a Sukarno man."

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 28-- Military patrols and helicopters today pursued a force of leftwing guerrillas that killed five policemen and wounded two others in a raid early yester day on a village on the Magdalena River.
City Councilman Edward I. Koch introduced a resolution yesterday urging the city to make unused city hospital beds available to wounded Vietnamese children.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- New York's multimillion-dollar Medicaid program--thought to be the target of a stringent Federal cutback--escapes unscathed in legislation that Congress will start to study tomorrow, according to state officials.
A United States Customs inspector called the Gallery of Modern Art yesterday to get some biographical data on an author whose works were being imported.

Mrs. Nina Lewton, a former story editor for Metro-GoldwynMayer and the sister of the late Alla Nazimova, the actress, died Sunday in Woodland Hills, Calif. She was 92 years old and lived in Canoga Park, Calif.

HARTFORD, Feb. 28--Supporters of Senator Thomas J. Dodd are asking hundreds of persons who attended testimonial dinners for him between 1961 and 1965 to sign affidavits swearing that they purchased the tickets not as a political contribution but as a personal gift to the Senator.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28-- The leaders of the General Labor Confederation, Argentina's central trade union organization with a membership of 2.5-million, have called a 24-hour strike tomorrow in defiance of the Government.

Harrison E. Salisbury of The New York Times, Ramparts magazine and Murray Kempton of The New York Post are among the winners of the annual George Polk Memorial Awards in journalism announced yesterday by Long Island University.
The boards of Trans World Airlines and Hilton International Company voted yesterday to approve the merger of Hilton International into T.W.A.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 28--When Tom Tresh was very young, his father would always beat him in fiercely competitive table tennis games that often left the boy in tears. Once, Tom complained to his mother, and his father overheard.
John R. Kimber, chief architect of a tough set of new securities laws for Ontario, will become president of the Toronto Stock Exchange on May 1, the exchange said yesterday.

An American swimming team composed of four girls, all national champions and world recholders, and two men, leave tonight for the 11th annual international "schwimfest" this weekend in Bremen, Germany.
Federal authorities are hoping to increase this country's participation in the growing Great Lakes overseas trade through the St. Lawrence Seaway.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee advanced the Administration's East-West bridge building program today by approving the United States-Soviet consular treaty by a vote of 15 to 4.
The All-State Credit Corporation, a Long Island finance company, has been sued by one of its principal creditors for making "untrue, misleading and deceptive" statements in order to obtain credit.
PARIS, Feb. 28--The campaign for the elections to the French National Assembly has become a shrill, bitter contest that is stirring more intense passions than had been expected.
OTTAWA, Feb. 28--Paul Hellyer, Canada's Minister of Defense, apologized today for having called a former admiral "disloyal" for opposing unification of the armed forces.

MIAMI, Feb. 28--For the first time in a week a hot morning sun knifed through the towering Australian pines, the palms and the eucalyptus trees that border the Hialeah barn area. The spirits of the horsemen brightened in the warming glow and even the thoroughbreds seemed a bit more frisky.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- Former Ambassador Edwin O. Reischauer said today he believed it was "very likely" that Communist China would moderate its foreign policy in the next two or three years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The outlook for Representative Adam Clayton Powell's Congressional future was confused today by House members who would deny him his seat and those who would let him off with censure alone.

Mrs. Cynthia Happ Laing, the widow of Chester W. Laing, chairman of the board of John Nuveen Co., Inc., investment bankers, died yesterday in her home at 870 United Nations Plaza. She was 42 years old. Her husband died on Feb. 13.
HOUSTON, Feb. 28--The Westec Corporation and the Securities and Exchange Commission have reached an agreement on the terms of a contract that permits Westec to hire a financial adviser.

VIENNA, Feb. 28 (AP)-- Peggy Fleming of Colorado Springs, the defending champion, took a strong lead in the women's division and American men placed third, fourth today in opening tests of the world figure skating championships.

Gerald W. Eskow, 44-year-old former president of Yale Express System, Inc., a major trucking and freight forwarding company in reorganization under the Bankruptcy Act, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on mail fraud charges.

Eddie Ellis, the young Harlem writer whose series of articles on Jewish "exploitation" of Negroes led to the protest resignations of James Baldwin and Ossie Davis as contributors to Liberator, the black nationalist magazine, said yesterday: "I am not a racist."

The former Commissioner of Baseball, Ford C. Frick, went on the city payrol yesterday as a $75-a-day consultant, assigned to work with business leaders "to open up opportunities and career lines for unemployed and underemployed New Yorkers."
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company lost its longstanding place last year as the world's richest life insurer to the Prudential Insurance Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28 (AP)--Since a user of narcotics could be simply one who administered them to animals, one portion of an 11-year-old Federal law has been declared unconstitutional by the United States Court of Appeals.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28--Allan Schnelz is a pitcher who used to be an infielder. Terry Christman is an infielder who used to be a pitcher. Tom Seaver's name was picked out of a hat. And Jerry Koosman was recommended by an usher at the Polo Grounds.
The Laird Company Corporation, an investment banking and brokerage concern, is moving its New York office into 40,000 square feet of space in the 52-story skyscraper at 140 Broadway.

Harold Konigsberg, who acted as his own lawyer in a trial in which he was found guilty of extortion, demanded in a speech that lasted four hours 10 minutes in State Supreme Court yesterday that his conviction be set aside.

A civil rights group filed yesterday a friend-of-court brief that seeks to establish the right of an indigent person accused of murder to a lawyer of his own choosing. Under New York law, a defendant may have a state-paid lawyer but must accept one selected by the judge.
ALBANY, Feb. 28--A showdown was postponed today on a bill to liberalize the state's abortion law after its sponsor filed amendments that he contended "met most of the substantive criticism."

STUART, Fla., Feb. 28-- "Great Scot!" said Jack Samson of New York, an exoutdoors writer who contends he turned honest and went to work for a living. He waved a hand in the air. The air was outrageously warm.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- President Johnson named Acting Attorney General Ramsey Clark today to become Attorney General.
DURHAM, N.C., Feb. 28--A woman near death from liver failure has been saved by prolonged cross-circulation of her blood directly with that of another person, a medical scientist said here today.

YONKERS, Feb. 28--Yonkers Raceway's stables and training facilities for standardbreds will remain open for the use of any owners who wish to keep horses here after the winter meeting ends Friday. It is expected that about 300 horses will be housed at Yorkers while the racing spotlight shifts to Roosevelt Raceway at Westbury, L.I.

BERLIN, Feb. 28 (AP)-- Cyrus S. Eaton Jr., the Cleveland industrialist, is in East Berlin for discussions about the development of economic ties, the official East German news agency, ADN, reported today.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 28--The Government decided today to cancel the "lame-duck" session of Parliament that was scheduled to meet March 13. Instead, the newly elected Parliament will meet about the middle of March to act on the budget and deal with other matter that would have been handled by the lame-duck session.
WASHINGTON, Feb.28--The Federal Reserve Board took another major step today in the direction of easier money.
VERDI's "Otello" received its first performance of the season on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera. Up to the end of the second act, it seemed as if the opera was going nowhere.
The Board of Education asked State Education Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. yesterday to lift his restraining order, which has held up the planned construction of seven schools in East Brooklyn.
TWO young women with virtually no tournament experience came within half a match-point of heading the New York field in the recent International Fund Pair game.
President Johnson said yesterday that Henry R. Luce was "a pioneer of American journalism" who had helped millions of readers "to understand the forces that shape the society in which they live."
Dresser Industries, Inc., the widely diversified industrial producer, is making a bid to buy about 45 per cent of the stock of the Link-Belt Company for $62.4-million.

Textile machinery manufacturers will need a quick reinstatement of the 7 per cent tax credit on new machinery and equipment if they are to maintain the 1966 pace of business, James H. Hunter, outgoing president of the American Textile Machinery Association, said yesterday.
Two maritime labor leaders expressed doubt yesterday over the soundness of Administration proposals for a new five-year Federal shipping policy.

HONG KONG, Feb. 28--Five cheerful Chinese from Hong Kong, ranging in age from 4 to 20, were guests today at a tea party given by Dr. Howard Rusk, director of rehabilitation services at New York University Medical Center and president of the World Rehabilitation Fund.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- On warm mornings in Washington, bystanders are occasionally intrigued to see a 1949 Oldsmobile convertible drive into the Justice Department parking area and occupy the position reserved for William Ramsey Clark.
LONDON, Feb. 28--The Government's expected majority in the House of Commons was cut dramatically tonight by a backbench revolt on defense policy.

SEIJI OZAWA, the young Japanese conductor, has directed concerts at Lewisohn Stadium, but, if memory serves, last night was the first time he has conducted a major orchestra in this city during the winter season.

Because of "an incorrect bracket on the steering mechanism," 1,498 recently manufactured Renault automobiles sold in the United States are to be recalled for inspection, a spokesman for Renault, Inc., the American outlet for the French-based company, announced here yesterday.
Gian Carlo Menotti's 10th annual Festival of Two Worlds at Spoleto, Italy, will begin June 23 and continue through July 16.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--In his news conference this week, President Johnson defined the main political issue before the American people. He said that everything he was doing in Vietnam was part of his "search for peace." He conceded that he was increasing the military pressure on the enemy by mining the rivers and shelling ports of North Vietnam.

It was Jean Martinon's turn last night to be the guest composer of the "Mostly Mozart" series of string quartet concerts at the Hunter College Playhouse. The Fine Arts Quartet flanked Mr. Martinon's Quartet No. 2, a New York premiere, with Mozart's E-flat Quartet (K.428) and the Quartet in D (Hoffmeister").

A NEW chapter is being written in the story of the late Cole Porter's bookshelves --bookshelves that dominated a trend-setting room of the nineteen-fifties and represented a high point in the decorative arts of recent times.

BONN, Feb. 28--Helmut Winter announced today that he had signed an armistice with the Luftwaffe after having forced the West German Air Force's noisy jet planes to keep a proper altitude above his Bavarian home by firing dumplings at them.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Following are excerpts from a message on education and health sent to Congress today by President Johnson:

SINGAPORE, Feb. 28--The Governments of Indonesia and Singapore have decided to set up a Joint Technical Commission to review means of resuming trade between the two coun tries, an informed source said here tonight.
New York City gained one corporate headquarters yesterday and lost another.
A giant dome of steel and transparent plastic tall enough to hold the Statue of Liberty without its pedestal will house the United States exhibition at Expo 67, the Montreal World's Fair.
Five years ago, Karl Weber, then a supporting actor on Broadway and television, chucked it for the wonderful world of commercials.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 28 (AP) --Vernon L. Pepersack was suspended as Maryland's Commissioner of Correction today on the recommendation of Attorney General Francis S. Burch. The suspension was ordered by Gov. Spiro T. Agnew.
A rally, which developed in afternoon trading, erased most of the early losses on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and the market closed slightly ahead on average in a moderately active session.
FOREIGN SECURITIES

ALBANY, Feb. 28--The Republican-controlled Senate passed a direct-primary election bill today, embarrassing its Democratic members and placing the controversial issue in the lap of the Democratic-controlled Assembly.

GENEVA--Geneva accustoms one to paradox. It is U.N.'s European capital although Switzerland isn't a U.N. member. This makes Switzerland the only nation to earn money from the world body, since it gets plenty of business and pays no dues. U.N. operates here from the old League of Nations headquarters--which the League never inhabited. It died too soon.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 28--Ralph J. Bunche announced today that he had bowed to Secretary General Thant's urging and would remain as United Nations Under Secretary for Special Political Affairs at the cost of "abandonment of plans and dreams" that he and his wife have "been contemplating for over the past six years."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)--Thirteen members of the House introduced a bill today to establish a select committee to learn how many civilian casualties and refugees there have been in Vietnam.
Stocks continued to lose ground yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, influenced in part by Wall Street's decline on Monday.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 28--The three British banks nationalized earlier this month--Barclays, Standard Bank Ltd. and Grindlay's--have decided to withdraw all nonTanzanian personnel over the next few weeks.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 28 (AP)--The Vietcong's supreme command charged today that the United States' "war policy" was the sole obstacle to peace in Vietnam.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 28 (Reuters)--Theophilus Ebenhaezer Donges was elected President of South Africa today for a seven-year term. He will succeed Charles R. Swart, who resigns May 31.
A plan to combat narcotics addiction first in the streets, then through the hospitals and later by the use of former addicts to aid in rehabilitation was unfolded last night by Mayor Lindsay.

Kendrick Pearson, since 1963 sales development manager of the Schenley Imports Company a sales unit of Schenley Industries, Inc., died of a heart attack Monday at his home. He was 59 years old, and lived at 40 West 67th Street.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 28 --Mrs. Barnet Gring Wallace has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helen Barnet Wallace, to Ens. Harry Strom Precourt, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Andrew Precourt of Dover.

VANCOUVER, B.C.--Like the early-blooming crocuses in local gardens, stock speculators have reappeared after a dull winter and are providing the Vancouver Stock Exchange with renewed excitement in penny mining issues.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28--Judge Herbert C. Paschen declared today that a suit charging him with illegally restricting news media in reporting the Richard Speck murder trial was "a thinly veiled attempt" to force him to "permit the press free reign at the trial."

GRENADA, Miss., Feb. 28 (UPI)--The newly acquired voting strength of Negroes here was not strong enough as a white conservative, Robert Alexander, swept to victory over his Negro opponent in a special election for a City Council post.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--A House subcommittee supported today a United States Government loan to an Italian credit institution to help finance the sale of $50-million worth of American machine tools to the Soviet Union.
BONN, Feb. 28--The West German Government is urging increased trade with East Germany as a means of keeping channels open between the two parts of the divided country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- Dr. Hornell Hart, a sociologist who also did parapsychological research, died yesterday at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 78 years old and a resident of Big Pine Key, Fla.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- President Johnson's demand for authority to send additional food aid to India backfired today in complaints against domestic farm policy and expressions of uncertainty about the effect of the recent Indian elections on United States aid policy.
The 55th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund closed yesterday with record contributions.
Stockholders of American and Foreign Power Co., Inc., approved at yesterday's special meeting at Augusta, Me., the merger of their company into its parent, the Electric Bond Share Company.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 (UPI)--A Federal appeals court ruled today that Girard College did not have to admit Negroes under the state's Public Accommodations Act.
The printers' union broke off contract negotiations yesterday with representatives of five major city newspapers.

To have laid up the Flying Cloud, pride of the clipper fleet, in her heyday in the mid-nineteenthcentury period of American maritime greatness would have been a major nautical heresy and a gross economic misjudgment.

The average cost of Sunday dinner at home for a family of four in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area last month was $5.19 if the housewife served rib roast and $3.72 if she served chicken, according to the regional office of the Labor Department.
The Communist party, U.S. A., said yesterday that "certain negative aspects" had arisen in internal party discussions on work among Jews and against anti-Semitism.

Henry R. Luce created an entirely new approach in magazine journalism and indirectly influenced the techniques of presenting the news in daily newspapers. He built a large, complex, highly successful publishing enterprise. For personal force, ambition, intelligence, calculated daring and sustained executive skill, he ranked among the most successful of contemporary American businessmen.
SEATTLE, Feb. 28 (AP)-- William K. Blethen, publisher of The Seattle Times, died of a heart attack at his home today. He was 53 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)--The Commerce Department recommended today the development of at least 54,411 miles of scenic roads and parkways throughout the nation at a minimum cost through 1976 of $4-billion.
HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Feb. 28 (AP)--Msgr. Joseph P. Sergel, pastor of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here since 1923, died yesterday at the rectory. He was 75 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI)--Fewer families are now planning to buy a new car, a house or a television set than were planning to do so a year ago, the Commerce Department reported today. But more expect to purchase a used car or an air-conditioner.

THE stark despair and monotony of life in a rundown Negro tenement in Chicago was presented almost without comment last night in Jay McMullen's documentary for the Columbia Broadcasting System's news division.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 28--Dr. Eugene D. Genovese, who triggered a political uproar when he told a Rutgers teach-in in 1965 that he would welcome a "Vietcong ascendency in Vietnam," is leaving Rutgers at the end of June.

Prices perked up yesterday on the American Stock Exchange after a weak opening. Although the improvement fell somewhat short of a fullfledged recovery from Monday's sharp decline, traders were satisfied to see the market turn firmer.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday 1966 revenues and other income of $327,645,968, against $310,456,650 a year earlier. Net income of $21,892,302, equal to $2.46 a share, compared with $17,833,353, or $2.30 a share, in 1965.
New Orleans--Herschel Jacobs, 175 pounds, White Plains, N.Y., outpointed Marion Connor, 176, Canton, Ohio, 10 rounds.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Top officials of the Commerce Department told businessmen today that the department would publish guidelines on "undue proliferation" of package sizes before July 1.

BABYLON, L.I., Feb. 28-- Suffolk County's proposed sewer system was rejected by almost 6 to 1 in a referendum today despite warnings that the county's drinking water was being dangerously polluted by cesspool water.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 28 (UPI)--Howard Keck's Saber Mountain, ridden by Bill Shoemaker, won the $20,000 Sierra Madre Handicap today in a sixhorse blanket finish at Santa Anita.
AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 28 (UPI) --Mrs. Patrick J. Nugent, who has never said publicly that she is pregnant, is making plans to go to a hospital sometime in June, a hospital administrator said today.

A FEW years ago, British mod fashion was moving across the Atlantic like a tidal wave and New York stores were opening Carnaby Street men's departments as fast as they could get hip-slung pants and flowered shirts.

Donald W. Douglas, chairman of the Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., and James S. McDonnell, chairman of the McDonnell Company, announced yesterday that the boards of the two companies had approved a definitive merger agreement.

Unilever, Ltd., and its sister company, Unilever, N.V., the British and Dutch partners in the worldwide soap, margarine, and foodstuff producers, reported yesterday a decline in 1966 consolidated net profits to $173billion from $178-billion the year before.

Francis Michael Freimann of New York and Mrs. Callagher Freimann of Palm Beach, Fla., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Francine Bonita Freimann, to Thomas Anthony Snyder. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Humphries Snyder of Oak Park, Ill.
ADEN, Feb. 28 (UPI)--At least five persons were killed today when violence broke out during a funeral procession for six victims of a terrorist bomb blast hours earlier.
The Earl of Snowdon denied again yesterday rumors that his marriage to Princess Margaret had foundered, and then he went about his work on a photography assignment for Vogue magazine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) --The Senate confirmed today the nomination of William B. Macomber Jr. of New York as an Assistant Secretary of State.

Just three weeks from its adjournment goal of March 23, the State Legislature has yet to pass its first major piece of legislation.

National Basketball Association players threatened yesterday to strike the championship playoffs and take steps to form a union by filing for certification with the National Labor Relations Board. The playoffs are scheduled to begin in about three weeks.

Barry White, named the most-valuable player in this traditional rivalry, paced all scorers with 19 points and hauled in 10 rebounds. When Dr. James B. Conant embarked on his mission of improving the nation's high schools ten years ago, he believed that reforms depended mainly on the quality of local school boards. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that total holdings of gold, dollar balances and other assets for foreign and international accounts rose to a record $29billion in June 1966, but ended the year at $28.4-billion, down $509-million from December, 1965.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 28 (AP)----District Attorney Jim Garrison's office today subpoenaed a "James Lewallen" to appear tomorrow in connection with Mr. Garrison's investigation of the assassination of President Kennedy.

The City Housing Authority has agreed to upgrade its apartment incinerators to cut down air pollution. Indications were that this would result in rent increases for its 143,000 tenant families in public housing.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Monday the level it reached on Friday, which was 101.4.
Last night President Johnson proclaimed March Red Cross month--the month that ...

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Feb. 28--The Rev. Bertram J. Mortlock, vicar of St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Yonkers, and of St. Barnabas, Ardsley, N.Y., from 1933 to 1954, died yesterday in the Good Shepherd Nursing Home. He was 89 years old and had lived in Pleasant Valley.

PEKING, Feb. 28--The Maoist communes of Shanghai and Peking, hailed at their birth this month as glorious successors of the short-lived Paris Commune of 1871, both seemed today to have been abandoned.

Judy Garland, who has not sung or acted in a film, since "I Could Go on Singing" in 1963, will return to the screen soon. She has been signed for one of the starring roles in the adaptation of "Valley of the Dolls," the best-selling novel by Jacqueline Susann.

Reuben Block, a vice president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and manager of the Eastern Pennsylvania and South Jersey joint boards of the union, died yesterday at Philadelphia Airport while en route to a board meeting in San Juan, P.R. He was 70 years old.
