GROWING confidence that American Telephone and Telegraph has made a good case to the Federal Communications Commission for an over-all 8 per cent return is helping bring renewed enthusiasm for shares of the world's richest corporation.
CHICAGO, March 1--More than two dozen hats--fedoras, tyroleans and homburgs--whirled onto the ice tonight in a spontaneous salute to Bobby Hull's artistry with a hockey stick.
WARSAW, March 1--Poland and Czechoslovakia signed a 20year treaty of friendship and military assistance today.

The New York-Harlem chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality proposed yesterday that jurisdiction of all Harlem schools be transferred from the city Board of Education to a completely independent school board in the area.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)--The Post Office Department said today that the new higher postal rates for overseas mail announced Jan. 14 could go into effect May 1.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- The Federal Reserve Board announced today an informationgathering study of "recent developments in the bank creditcard and check-credit field."

HATTIESBURG, Miss., March 1--The Imperial Wizard of a Mississippi Klan group and 11 alleged members of the organization were placed under new Federal indictments here today in the fire-bomb death of a Negro leader, Vernon Dahmer, in 1966.

BELLPORT, L.I., March 1-- John J. Roe Jr., president of the Roe Agency, Inc., real estate and insurance, of Bellport and Patchogue, died of a heart attack yesterday at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital, East Patchogue. He was 62 years old.
Cigarette smoke--long associated with respiratory ailments--has been shown in laboratory tests to inhibit the lungs' ability to fight disease bacteria.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- John W. Gardner, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, recommended today a broad program that would combine Government aid and Government influence to slow the rising cost of medical care.

CHICAGO, March 1 (AP)-- A magazine publisher said today the United States suffers from a serious "understanding gap," possibly because of overemphasis on how information is communicated rather than what information is transmitted.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- An influential Georgia Democrat has demanded the removal from office of a key Administration civil rights official for allegedly disrupting efforts to desegregate Southern schools.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)--The Treasury defined today the import regulations to be used in restricting trade with Rhodesia under United Nations sanctions and President Johnson's executive order of Jan. 5.
"Britain going into Europe may be the tide of history," grumbled Mr. Smith-Jones, an important official in London, "but it's not the tide of SmithJones."
THE decorous affection between Queen Victoria and Benjamin Disraeli, Earl of Beaconsfield, was invigorated by their selective passion for the British Empire.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)--Sen. Robert F. Kennedy is the United States Senate's largest employer of office help with 63 staff members, a report of the Secretary of the Senate disclosed today.
The News Division of the Columbia Broadcasting System has purchased a French-made documentary of American soldiers in battle in Vietnam.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 1--The great experiment began tentatively today as Mickey Mantle planted baseball's most expensive bad leg on the alien soil around first base.

WAYNE, N.J., March 1-- The voters of Wayne Township today again defeated proposed school budgets for 1967-68. The new budgets were recommended to the voters after proposed outlays of $8.5-million were rejected Feb. 14 in an election in which the religion of two Board of Education candidates was an issue.
David L. Luke 3d, president of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company, was elected yesterday to the board of the Irving Trust Company of New York.

Leading American health authorities, citing a steady increase in the incidence of venereal disease, particularly, among teen-agers, requested yesterday that Congress appropriate $17.5-million to combat this public health problem.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- The Administration, citing legal limitations, has partly reneged on President Johnson's support for international development of the Mekong River basin in Southeast Asia, United States officials acknowledged today.
The Xerox Corporation has adapted its xerographic office copying techniques to a machine that speeds duplication of printed data from a computer. The initial unit of the

WASHINGTON, March 1-- The following list of unusual job opportunities has been compiled for young persons who want to do something different from what their fathers have always done, yet still feel that they are contributing something to the society they live in:
The decision of the House of Representatives to exclude Adam Clayton Powell is more likely to lead to protracted litigation than to swift disposal of his case.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 1--The smallest nation in South America inaugurated Oscar Diego Gestido, a retired air force general, today for a five-year term as President.
A collection of modern paintings appraised at $2-million has been bequeathed to the Cincinnati Art Museum by Mary Johnston, a Procter Gamble heiress.
Negro leaders reacted angrily last night to the exclusion of Adam Clayton Powell from his seat in Congress.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1--The man who hit more home runs in one season than Babe Ruth pulled on uniform No. 9 today and became a full-fledged member of the St. Louis Cardinals.

SOMERS, N.Y., March 1-- March came in with coveys of kites skittering overhead here today in a brisk 20-milean-hour wind. Some were disguised as rockets, others as Superman, fish, elephants, birds, battleships, jet planes and astronaut's capsules.

WILL Willy Schaeffler's Denver ski team do it again? The nation's top collegians get together at Sugarloaf Mountain in Maine's high country today and, as usual, Denver's squad is being touted as the one to watch. Schaeffler has molded another strong unit and Den
Former Premier David BenGurion of Israel arrived here last night to begin a three-week tour of the United States.
A second newspaper union, Mailers Local 6, broke off negotiations yesterday with negotiators for five of the city's major newspapers.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 1--Howard B. Begg, retired president of Squier, Schilling Skiff, Newark distributors of tools and industrial equipment, died Monday at Hyannis, Mass., where he moved from East Orange after retiring four years ago.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 1 (AP)--Venezuela's constitutional guarantees, suspended in December as a precaution against terrorism, will be restored tomorrow, the Government announced tonight.

The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor has accepted a labor-inspired grammatical change in legislation designed to establish standards of physical and mental fitness for longshoremen and checkers in the port.

Every family here with infants three months old will receive an "alert" from the Health Department next week to begin the baby's immunizations against polio, diphtheria, tetanus, smallpox and whooping cough.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- The Treasury announced today that it would sell $2.7-billion of tax-anticipation bills next Tuesday.

ALBANY, March 1 (AP)-- Officials of commercial banks lined up solidly today against a proposed revision of the State Banking Law that would permit savings institutions to make personal loans to depositors.
BONN, March 1--The West German Government is weighing re-establishment of diplomatic ties with Yugoslavia as a priority in its drive to improve relations with Eastern Europe.

ALBANY, March 1--Governor Rockefeller and the private utilities in the state joined today in announcing an $8-billion spending and expansion program by the utilities. The plan, keyed to atomic energy, would double the availability of New York's electric power by 1977.

ATHENS, March 1--Two United States diplomats walked out of a foreign press luncheon here today minutes before Andreas Papandreou, Greece's most controversial leftist politician, made a sharp attack on the United States.
SYDNEY, Australia, March 1--The Government today commissioned into the Royal Australian Navy a freighter whose crew had refused to sail it to Vietnam.

The management of the Holly Sugar Corporation urged its shareholders yesterday to reject a tender offer by the Houston Oil Material Company to purchase 100,000 shares of Holly common stock at $24 a share.
HONG KONG, March 1-- The Peking radio announced to night that supporters of Mao Tse-tung had taken over Shan tung Province.

COMMERCIAL television is in the process of purging the evening game show because the format is wearing thin and purportedly appeals primarily to older viewers. Channel 13, the noncommercial station, elected last night to brave the electronic currents and introduce "Quote Unquote" under the moderating aegis of Bergen Evans, the durable quizmaster.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, March 1 (Reuters)--An international commission today advised the Canadian-owned Demerara Bauxite Company to abandon its rule of forbidding non-Guyanese staff members to carry local girls.
DETROIT, March 1--A leading unit of the United Automobile Workers warned management today that slumping car sales would not temper union demands in the forthcoming industrywide contract talks.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., March 1--George Meany was back in Washington today after a meeting of labor chieftains here that left his reputation as labor's leading politician greatly enchanted.

WASHINGTON, March 1--At 4:26 P.M., Speaker John W. McCormack announced the tally: 202 against permitting amendments to the resolution to censure Adam Clayton Powell; 222 for permitting amendments. The move to bar Mr. Powell was now in fullswing.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)--A film that the Pentagon purchased for $53,743 portrays President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam as a "kindly smiling grandfather" who plots war. It implies that the regime in Hanoi kidnaps soldiers to fight in South Vietnam.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 1--Arthur J. Goldberg arrived today on his first visit to Vietnam.

SOMEDAY someone is going to write a great role for Martha Raye. Just as Miss Raye's face at times suggests a haunting combination of the Greek masks of comedy and tragedy, so her force as a performer stems as much from her sense of pathos as from her rowdy, slapstick sense of fun.
Glen Donaldson, who had served for many years as chief of porters at The New York Times, died Tuesday at Knickerbocker Hospital on Convent Avenue. He was 84 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)--Public officials who serve as advisers to the Federal anti-poverty program called today for $35-million to be used to run special summer programs.
BALTIMORE, March 1 (AP) --James R. Hoffa affirmed today that his longtime friend, Frank E. Fitzsimmons, would run the teamsters union if Hoffa went to jail.
A scarcity of policemen in four sections of the Bronx has led to an increase in crime there that has brought about an "atmosphere of terror," Councilman Bertram R. Gelfand charged yesterday.
WHITE PLAINS, March 1-- Scores of Westchester welfare caseworkers, disputing pay and working conditions in the county, telephoned their offices today and reported they were too sick to work.

CONCORD, Mass., March 1 (AP)--Andrew H. Hepburn, whose architectural firm, Perry, Shaw Hepburn, took a major role in the restoration of Colovial Williamsburg, Va., died last night at his home. He was 86 years old.
DURHAM, N.H., March 1 (UPI)--A student publication at the University of New Hampshire displays a caricature of Cardinal Spellman of New York firing a machine gun at the base of a cross.

The Yankees would play ball in a massive Urban Sports Center on the lower West Side, tourists would dine at a Fisherman's Wharf overlooking the East River at Fulton Street and commuting brokers would ride New Haven Railroad coaches direct

Mayor Lindsay's pledge to fight for maintenance of the twenty-cent transit fare on a "permanent" basis derives partly, no doubt, from his sense of political realism, but also from a conviction that the question is primarily one of social and economic policy that rightfully should be under the city's control.

President Johnson's efforts to bring about a thaw in Soviet-American relations have received two powerful welcome boosts in Congress. The fifteen-to-four vote by which the Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved the consular treaty is an encouraging omen for its ratification by the entire Senate.

NATCHEZ, Miss., March 1-- Civil rights demonstrators massed near a gate at the Armstrong Rubber Company here today, and a Negro leader said eight members of the Ku Klux Klan had been noted leaving work there.

The Queens College swimming team completed its first undefeated season yesterday by scoring a 67-37 victory over Fordham. The Knights scored 11 triumphs while the Rams finished with a 6-5 won-lost mark.

NEW HAVEN, March 1-- Yale University officials revealed today that former Pennsylvania Gov. William W. Scranton has turned down an offer to become acting master of Saybrook College, one of Yale's 12 undergraduate residential communities.
The Textile Workers Union of America announced yesterday a 9-cent general wage increase for 800 employes of three New England woolen and worsted plants.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 1 --A nutrition expert said today that 300 million children, living in underdeveloped areas, suffered from malnutrition and their poor diet might permanently be stunting the growth of their brains, as well as of their bodies.
LONDON, March 1--Two new concert halls on the south bank of the Thames were opened tonight by Queen Elizabeth II.

AKRON, Ohio, March 1-- James S. Pedler, a World War I aviator, who retired 11 years ago as manager of the aeronautical sales division of the B.F. Goodrich Company, died here today in his home. His age was 75.
ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 28-- One year after Kwame Nkrumah's overthrow, Ghana's once tightly muzzled press is exercising its new freedom with restraint.
MOSCOW, March 1(UPI)-- Informed sources said today that Defense Minister Rodion Y. Malinovsky was gravely ill and probably would not be able to resume his duties.
PALM BEACH, Fla.--Life in this elegant, palm-fringed nomads' land has been any- thing but quiet this season, and for some unknown reason everyone who is anyone has suddenly become very musical.

The American Library Association has selected 60 books published in 1966 as particularly worthy of the attention of the American adult reader. The choices were made by the Notable Books Council of 11 members from nominations by 30 librarians. The library association's publishing department, at 50 East Huron Street, Chicago, distributes the list in leaflet form in batches of 50 to 5,000.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 1 --Mrs. Edythe Wisan McKenzie of 1341 North Avenue, secretary of the Visiting Nurse Association of Eastern Unions County, died last night at her home. Mrs. McKenzie, the wife of Arthur McKenzie, a Standard Oil Company (N.J.) executive, was 48 years old.

FORT LEE, N.J., March 1-- Burt S. Burke, vice president of the apparatus division of Federal Pacific Electric Company, died yesterday of a heart attack at the corporation's headquarters in Newark. He was 64 years old and lived here at the Horizon House.

The Metropolitan Opera is wealthy enough in vocal talent to have two casts functioning in its new production of "Die Zauberfl te." On Tuesday night, at the third performance of Mozart's work and only nine days

BONN, March 1--Apparently surprised by sharp American reactions, the West German Government sought today to soften the impression of Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger's criticisms Monday of relations with the United States.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 1 (AP)--Surgeons at University of Minnesota hospitals have transplanted two organs--kidney and pancreas--into the same patient.
GENEVA, March 1--The so-called International War Crimes Tribunal that Bertrand Russell, the left-wing British philosopher, proposes to have rule on events on Vietnam has been barred from Switzerland.
ONEONTA, N.Y., March 1 (AP)--Wagner overcame a halftime deficit to defeat Hartwick's basketball team, 89-86, today.

The Plaza's Grand Ballroom was transformed last night into a "Nippon teien" (Japanese garden) for the 28th annual White Elephant Ball, a benefit for the Child Adoption Service of the Children's Aid Society.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 1(AP)--A former sheriff's deputy accused of beating a Negro prisoner who was later found dead in jail was ordered today to face trial on a Federal civil rights charge.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP --President Johnson named today 10 members of the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)--If there has been any doubt about it, Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson confirmed today that her daughter, Mrs. Patrick J. Nugent, is expecting a baby.
The Federal Aviation Agency has partly lifted a ban on pressurizing the cabins of DC-6 and DC-7 airliners.
Local 1 of the Amalgamated Lithographers of America and the Metropolitan Lithographers Association have reached agreement on a new contract 14 months before the current one was due to expire.

MICHAEL COLGRASS is a musician from New York who first came into prominence as a percussion specialist. Then his music began to attract notice. He has been one of the group active at the Berkshire Music Center, under the auspices of the
Cowles Communications, Inc., announced yesterday that it would acquire the assets of the Cambridge Book Company and affiliated companies in the textbook publishing field.
A SURPRISING number of experienced players neg- lect safety plays, and this may be the effect of matchpoint duplicate contests in which safety plays are often losing propositions.

CLEVELAND, March 1--The defense rested today in the hearing on the Government's request for a permanent injunction against manufacture and distribution of the Rand Development Corporation's controversial cancer vaccine.

William D. Eberle, who has been president of the Amerscan Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation since last September, will become chairman and chief executive officer. The change was disclosed in an amendment to the company's bylaws filed yesterday.

Frances Kahn, 37-year-old lawyer, surrendered yesterday in Federal Court to begin a twoyear prison term for conspiring to obstruct justice. Miss Kahn, who lives at 913 Theriot Avenue, the Bronx, will be taken to the Federal women's institution at Alderson, W. Va.
MADISON, Wis., March 1-- The editor of the University of Wisconsin's Daily Cardinal, which has been subject to legislative attacks for weeks, resigned today on the ground of ill health.

Local governing units of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. have overwhelmingly approved a new creedal statement that recognizes for the first time the denomination's obligation to work for social justice.
Peter Bridge, one of the most prolific producers on the London stage, is planning to be represented here next season by two plays; "The Promise" and "Stephen D."
A strong Washingtons' Birthday shopping pace failed to offset the adverse effect that several days of heavy snow and cold weather inflicted on February retail business in New York City.

Columbia University scientists, working with 2,000 electric cels from the Amazon River, have made a major step toward elucidating the structure of a protein that is believed to play a crucial role in the transmission of nerve messages.
The New York State Banking Board approved yesterday the application of the Marine Midland National Bank of Troy to acquire the Unadilla National Bank, Unadilla, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)--Technical discussions on the direct air link between New York and Moscow will continue in Washington during the second half of this month, United States officials said today.

HANOI, North Vietnam, March 1--Premier Pham Van Dong said today that he did not think there was any present possibility of talks between the United States and North Vietnam for a peaceful solution of the war.
CHATTANOOGA, March 1-- A Federal judge today ordered James R. Hoffa, teamsters' union president, to report here by next Tuesday to begin an eight-year prison sentence for jury-tampering.
Even though Anna H. Albough goes shopping every day and spends huge sums, her husband never complains. In fact, he's quite proud of her.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 1--The success or failure of the United States and of white Americans will be, in large measure, "gauged by the success or failure of Negro Americans in their struggle for existence in the urban environment."
ALBANY, March 1--A Federal jury began deliberating today the fate of John (Sonny) Franzese and four other men charged with masterminding a series of nationwide bank robberies in 1965.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)--The national debt ceiling will rise to $336-billion as soon as President Johnson signs a bill passed by Congress today.

WHEN Mrs. Mignon Lieblong of New York was a professional handler and had to fill out any number of entry blanks for dogs in shows, she got tired of the complex names of many of her charges. They annoyed her.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI)--A civilian pilot was rescued today from a desolate icecap in Greenland where he was forced to land a private plane two days ago when he encountered a polar storm.
WICHITA, Kan., March 1 (AP)--William P. Lear Sr., founder of Lear Jet Industries, Inc., has officially moved back into the pilot's seat of the maker of business jets and electronics equipment.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which has picked up the Yankees, a toy company, a guitar firm, three other musical instrument companies and two film companies in three years of diversification, made a bid yesterday for a major publishing house.
LANSING, Mich., March 1-- The Oldsmobile Division of General Motors Corporation recalled 2,237 of its 1967 model 88 and 98 cars today to replace bolts in the steering assembly.
ALBANY, March 1--A State Senate committee chairman charged today that public-employe unions from New York City had sabotaged a bipartisan agreement on overhauling the Condon-Wadlin Law.
Prices firmed yesterday on the London Stock Exchange after a two-day easing trend.
MOSCOW, March 1 (UPI)-- Pierre Darmon and JeaneClaude Barclay of France moved into the semi-finals of the Moscow tennis tournament today with straight set victories.
THE Petroff Defense, sometimes called the Russian Game, was popular in the early decades of this century. The opening--1 P-K4, P-K4, 2 N-KB3, N-KB3--is hardly seen these days.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 1 --Suffolk County Executive H. Lee Dennison confirmed today that he would run for a third term. The 63-year-old Democrat has held the post since it was created seven years ago, twice defeating Republican candidates by narrow margins.

GENEVA, March 1--Over Soviet opposition, the United States won its fight in the United Nations Human Rights Commission today for an article recommending the prosecution of persons inciting religious hatred only if their acts were "likely to result" in violence.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- The Senate approved today a resolution pledging support for efforts by President Johnson and "other men of goodwill" to prevent the expansion of the Vietnam War and to reach a negotiated peace.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- Gov. George Romney said today he was keeping his peace on Vietnam to give President Johnson a free hand to end the war there.

WILLISTON PARK, L.I., March 1--The Rev. Ernest K. Scherer, pastor of St. John's Lutheran Church here for the last 32 years, died last night in Long Island Doctors Hospital, Roslyn Heights. He was 57 years old and had suffered a heart attack four weeks ago.
The hard-working movie photographer shown here is catching forever on film the struggle of a can of salmon going upstream to spawn. A what?

The American Association of Advertising Agencies, for almost a half-century the voice of the business, has just issued its first position paper on account conflicts. That may give you an idea of just how bad the problem is.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- The nation is near a "human breakthrough" in social development that may surpass the scope of the scientific and technical revolution of recent decades, Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today.

LONDON, March 1--An Armenian prelate charged today that a collection of valuable Armenian gospel manuscripts that are to be sold at Sotheby's had been illegally removed from the archives of the Armenian Cathedral in Jerusalem.
The Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, announced yesterday a reduction in the interest rate that it charges on home mortgage loans.
Reeves Brothers, Inc., a textiles producer, announced here yesterday the election of Jeremiah H. Wyatt, James R. Cooper and John W. Hardie as division heads.

George Marfeo, the lawyer representing William (Bud) Gilmour in Gilmour's bid for restoration of his harness racing driver's license, said yesterday that he had requested Governor Rockefeller to ask the chairman of the State Harness Racing Commission to disqualify himself from ruling on Gilmour's appeal.

PITTSBURGH, March 1-- Ground will be broken in midMarch for the world's secondlargest high-rise office building, a 64-story triangular steel tower that will serve as the new Pittsburgh headquarters of the United States Steel Corporation.

The Columbia University chapter of Students for a Democratic Society has called for a mass boycott of classes unless the university accedes to a demand to withhold class rank from Selective Service Boards. The tentative strike dates are March 15 and 16.

PARIS, March 1--The fifteen members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization began a study today of the "technology gap" between Western Europe and the United States. A special group formed recently will start by trying to establish what and where the gap is. What to do about it comes later.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- The House voted tonight to exclude Adam Clayton Powell from the 90th Congress and probably created ground for a historic test of its decision in the Supreme Court.

BEDFORD, N.Y., March 1-- The Rev. Dr. Arthur Willis Hargate, rector of St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, and Mrs. Hargate have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Lynne Hargate, to Frank William Tracy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Tracy of Ros Tanwara, Saudi Arabia.
Gil Radday scored 31 points to lead St. Francis to a 75-65 victory over Ions in a Metropolitan Conference game last night at Mt. St. Michael's High School in the Bronx.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Wednesday the level it reached on Monday, which was 101.4.

The Rockwell-Standard Corporation, a producer of automotive parts and business aircraft in Pittsburgh, made an offer yesterday to buy up to 1.05million shares of the Draper Corporation at $30 a share, or $31.5-million.
PARIS, March 1--President de Gaulle will not have the last word in the French election campaign after all.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara demonstrated agreement on military and diplomatic tactics in Vietnam today in a brief talk with newsmen in the White House lobby.

GUATEMALA, March 1-- The Guatemalan Government last night ended the state of siege that had ruled the country for three months and substituted a state of alarm, a milder gradation of the law of public order, which also calls for the suspension of rights.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 1 (AP)--After a second conviction on a charge of kidnaping and raping an 18-year-old Phoenix girl, Ernest A. Miranda, 26, was sentenced today to 20 to 30 years in prison.
Adrian F. Paradis, who retired in 1960 as president of George J. Wallau, Inc., importers of French pharmaceuticals, died on Tuesday in his home at 758 Westminster Road, Brooklyn. His age was 81.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 1--Charles Sweeney, a deputy chamberlain of New York City in the administrations of Mayors John F. Hylan, James J. Walker and John P. O'Brien, died yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Marguerite Gilligan, 60 Locust Avenue. He was 80 years old.

GARDEN CITY L.I., March 1--Sol Wachtler, Supervisor of the Town of North Hempstead, was unanimously named tonight at the Nassau County Republican Committee convention to be the party's candidate for County Executive in November.

ST. LOUIS, March 1 (AP)-- Bruce McArthy, president of Local 837 of the International Association of Machinists, was suspended today by the international along with all his officers, a spokesman for Mr. McArthy said.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 1 --In a last-minute scurry to avoid Congressional review of his actions, President Humberto Castelo Branco decreed 22 new laws yesterday to further his three-year-old Brazilian revolution.
F. Lee Bailey, the 33-year-old criminal lawyer from Boston, will make his motion picture debut in the role of a 33-yearold criminal lawyer from Boston.
Stocks rose yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in active trading.
The stockholders of the Meadow Brook National Bank approved the proposed acquisition of the Bank of North America yesterday at a special meeting.
BOSTON, March 1--The Massachusetts commissioner of banks took action today against three small-loan companies convicted of bribery and conspiracy charges.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- House and Senate hearings on President Johnson's plan to send more food aid to India erupted today in angry demands that the New Delhi government do more to help itself and that United States help be tailored to fit the contributions of other countries.

DARIEN, Conn., March 1-- Mr. and Mrs. Gunnar T. Hansson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Victoria Jane Hansson, to Lieut. (jg.) John R. Gallavan, U.S.N. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Gallavan of New Canaan, Conn.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 1--Gene Dressler's jump shot with four seconds remaining gave the Harvard's basketball team a 71-69 victory over Dartmouth tonight.
Motorola, Inc., a producer of television sets, radios and electropic components, announced yesterday in Chicago that it achieved record sales and earnings last year.
LINCOLN, Neb., March 1 (AP)--Nebraska celebrated its 100th birthday today and began a nine-month statewide centennial observance with formality and fun at the statehouse.

BUENOS AIRES, March 1-- The Government of Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania contended today that it had broken the 24-hour strike called by the defiant General Labor Confederation. Minister of the Interior Guillermo Borda said that "the discipline of the labor movement has been broken."

Leaders of labor and management will join with Congressional Democrats and Republicans in Washington today to mark the casting of the 25-millionth secret ballot in elections conducted by the National Labor Relations Board.

"FEWER and fewer ladies are interested in buying custom tailoring at custom prices," William Miller, director of the Elizabeth Arden salons, said yesterday. It was hardly a startling remark, but it served to introduce the fact that the fashion formula of the cosmetics empire has changed since Elizabeth Arden's death last fall.

BONN, March 1--The head of news services for the United States Army in Europe was relieved of his command after he had permitted publication of a dispatch about the son of the United States Ambassador to West Germany in the military newspaper Stars and Stripes.
CHICAGO, March 1--The Illinois Supreme Court ordered Judge Herbert C. Paschen today to modify his controversial restrictions on the press in the Richard F. Speck murder trial in Peoria.
The election of William A. Prior to the new post of vice president for corporate diversification was announced here yestreday by the Singer Company.
GENEVA, March 1--After nearly four years of negotiations, the sixth and by far the most important of the postwar series of tariff-cutting packages has begun to take shape.

MADRID, March 1--A message from King Hassan II of Moroco to Generalissimo Francisco Franco was brought from Rabat by the Moroccan Ambassador today as diplo matic reports circulated that Spain wishes to open negotia tions on the future of the territory of Ifni.
Walter P. Chrysler Jr., the art collector, horse owner and automobile heir, has sold his stamp collection, estimated to be worth about $100,000, to an auctioneer in Fort Washington, Pa.

MOSCOW, March 1--Pravda accused the Central Intelligence Agency today of having thrown a "sinister shadow" over a Soviet-United States student-exchange program by manipulating it to send spies to the Soviet Union.

WHILE their elders were having frown and laugh lines smoothed in the hushed, adult quarters of Georgette Klinger's salon the other day, a trio of longhaired girls giggled their way through facial treatments in the newly opened teen-age section down the hall.

John Newcombe of Australia defeated Manuel Santana of Spain, the Wimbledon titleholder, in the international indoor team tennis match at the Vanderbilt Athleic Club last night, repeating the victory he scored in the semi-finals of the United States championship last year.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 1--The man chosen yesterday as President, Dr. Theophilus Ebenhaeger Donges, has been the quiet man of South African politics--always more a diplomat that a fiery frontbencher.

NEW ORLEANS, March 1 (AP)--District Attorney Jim Garrison arrested today Clay Shaw, retired director of the New Orleans International Trade Mart, and accused him of having taken part "in a conspiracy to assassinate President John F. Kennedy."
CHICAGO, March 1 (UPI)-- "Events," a painting by Leanne Shreves, won the $1,500 second prize yesterday in the Chicago Art Institute's 70th annual exhibition of artists of Chicago and vicinity.
MONTGOMERY, Ala.--Mrs. Wiley Hill Jr. is a stately matron who lives alone in a stately mansion with black shutters and four immense Ionic columns.
A 20-year-old girl whose body was found Tuesday night in the Wall Street area was strangled after having left a nearby bank where she was working overtime, the police said yesterday.
The nonpartisan Committee on Constitutional Issues recommended yesterday that all state and local judges in New York be appointed rather than elected.
March came in like a bull in the stock market yesterday.

Detectives from the Brooklyn District Attorney's office and the Police Narcotics Bureau seized a Cleveland man and confiscated a suitcase containing 17.5 pounds of pure heroin at the Golden Gate Motor Inn in the Sheepshead Bay area early today.
E.F. Hutton Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the election of five vice presidents, four assistant vice presidents and four nonvoting stockholders.

Governor Rockefeller must first be notified officially by the Speaker of the House of Representatives that a vacancy exists in Adam Clayton Powell's 18th Congressional District before the Governor can call a special election.
Directors of The New York Times Company voted yesterday a regular quarterly dividend of $1.37 a share on the 5 per cent cumulative prior preference stock.
NEW DELHI, March 1-- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi appeared today to have gained the political support she needs to retain her job.
HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., March 1--John S. Hicok, a retired executive of the General Electric Company, died yesterday at his home, 45 Windsor Road. He was 61 years old.
ADEN, March 1 (Reuters) --An Arab boy and a man were shot and killed by British troops here today as the city continued paralyzed by demonstrations and a general strike called by Arab nationalists.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- The Federal Government will have to more than double its aid to airports each year if it wants to prevent air traffic strangulation, an airport executive warned today.
Frank B. Sheinberg, retired treasurer of the Bulova Watch Company, Inc., died yesterday in Miami. He was 71 years old and lived at 177 Hastings Street, Brooklyn.

Long Island University, bound for the national collegiate smallcollege division tournament, defeated St. Peter's College, headed for the National Invitational Tournament, 69-61, last night in a Metropolitan Conference game on the L.I.U. court.

The Public Education Association charged in a news conference yesterday that the Board of Education was "dragging its feet" on establishing a comprehensive high school in the city after having adopted a policy for such schools two years ago.
Someone asked Jack Magee, the Georgetown coach, if last night's game against Columbia here was the final one of the season. Magee answered, "Yeah, Thank God."
Bond prices rose and interest rates fell yesterday in a continued response to the Federal Reserve's move Tuesday to unfreeze about $850-million of reserves held against time and savings deposits.
The Philadolphia and Reading Corporation, a diversified manufacturing company, announced yesterday the election of Robert A. Kavesh as a director.

The largest industrial plant in Englewood, N.J., has been sold for $3.75-million to a Manhattan investment group. The building is the 263,000-squarefoot plant occupied by General Motors on Route 4 and South Van Brunt Street.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., March 1 (AP)--Six more cadets resigned from the Air Force Academy today, bringing to 46 the number leaving in the current cheating scandal.

Charles Guida, the 39-yearold driver of the car used in a $6,000 Yorkers bank robbery last July 27, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld to eight years in prison. Guida pleaded guilty to charges of conspiring to rob the First National Bank of Yonkers.
The Baroque Players, a civilized and tasteful group of New York musicians, last night reached the third of their modest series of four concerts this season at St. George's Episcopal Church.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI)--Here is a brief summary of punishments administered to House members:

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., March 1--Penn State's unbeaten wrestling team, ranked seventh nationally, defeated fourthranked Lehigh, 18-12, tonight before the largest wrestling crowd in Penn State history, 7,900.
The New York City Ballet will open its 1967 season at its permanent summer home, the Saratoga Performing Arts Center, on July 7.

DETROIT, March 1 (AP)-- Dave Bing scored 28 points and made seven assists in pacing the Detroit Pistons to a 118-101 victory over Ghe New York Knickerbockers tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)--Although the Treasury's sale next week of $2.7-billion in tax-anticipation bills is scheduled to be the last such sale on the open market this fiscal year, the Treasury will be forced to borrow up to $500million from the Federal Reserve System this month, officials said today.

S. Ray Kaplan who retired in 1959 as a mathematics teacher at James Madison High School, Bedford Avenue near Quentin Road, Brooklyn, died Tuesday at Kings Highway Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 76 years old and had lived recently in Miami Beach.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., March 1--The Villanova University basketball team defeated Seton Hall University, 83-65, tonight for its 17th victory in 25 starts. The Wildcats have won nine of the last 11 in a spurt that brought them a berth in the National Invitation Tournament.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 2--The American guided-missile cruiser Canberra was hit by enemy fire yesterday while engaged in a duel with shore batteries...
MOSCOW, March 1 (AP)-- The first model of the re-designed Soviet compact car Zaporozhets came off the assembly line today, Tass said.

WASHINGTON, March 1--A delay by the United States in selling a large amount of plutonium to the European Atomic Energy Community is compounding European fears of discrimination under a treaty to prohibit the spread of nuclear weapons.

VIENNA, March 1 (AP)-- Peggy Fleming of Colorado Springs took a virtually insurmountable lead today in her quest for a second straight women's title in the world figure skating championships. But the two-time men's winner, Emmerich Danzer of Austria, fell to second place, behind Wolfgang Schwarz, also of Austria.
They were a choir of the deaf, singing to a piano accompaniment they could not hear.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 1 --Princeton University, forced to play a waiting game by Pennsylvania's deliberate slowdown, overcame the Quakers, 25-16, in Dillon Gymnasium tonight, to clinch the Ivy League championship.
BIMINI, The Bahamas, March 1--Adam Clayton Powell was at The End of the World drinking and playing dominoes with friends today when the House voted to exclude him from membership.

THE HIRED KILLER" has one thing in its favor, not that adroit color photography ever sent anybody running to a theater. In any case, this limp little gangster thriller sneaked into circuit showcases yesterday, tucked under "Funeral in Berlin," which makes two funerals.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 1 (AP)--William Henry Whalen, a retired Army lieutenant colonel, was sentenced today to serve 15 years in prison on charges that he had passed military secrets to Russian agents.

FAIRFAX, Va., March 1 (AP)--A van transporting six race horses said to be valued at $300,000 overturned near Interstate 95 today. Some of the animals were treated for cuts at the scene and one was taken to a veterinary hospital in Manassas, the police said. Two persons on the truck were injured.

TOKYO, March 1--Garlanded by well-wishers with folded paper cranes, a Japanese symbol of peace, a group of American pacifists left Hiroshima today in a yacht loaded with medicines that they hope to deliver to North Vietnam in about three weeks.

MOSCOW, March 1 (UPI) --Valentin Christyakov, a 27year-old Moscow athlete, set a world indoor mark for the 50-meter high hurdles today with a time of 6.5 seconds in the Soviet winter track and field championships.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- Congress began today what promised to be an exhaustive and critical examination of the Administration's bill to raise benefits and otherwise liberalize the Social Security program.

ROME, March 1--A "substantial increase" in world food production from the current crop year will still leave the food situation in developing countries "precarious," the Food and Agriculture Organization said today.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 1-- The police said today that three men had witnessed a rape here last month and walked away, ignoring the vistim's please for help.

President Johnson's promotion of Ramsey Clark to the post of Attorney General is a reward for demonstrated merit. As an Assistant Attorney General in charge of the lands division and more recently as Deputy Attorney General, Mr. Clark has proved to be a skilled and energetic administrator. On difficult issues of civil rights, wiretapping and criminal law he has shown himself to be a man of conscience with an alert concern for individual liberties.

OTTAWA, March 1--Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson agreed today to try to find out whether the Central Intelligence Agency had spent money in Canada during a period in Which the Conservative Government lost influence and was finally overthrown by the present Liberal Administration.

MIAMI, March 1--In a stretch duel that was as stirring as that of any stakes performance this season, Mac's Sparkler of the Hobeau Farm beat Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Straight Deal in the $65,000 Black Helen Handicap today.

Edward Lesser, a confidence man who swindled businessmen and lawyers of $1-million in a mortgage financing racket and who "sold" air space rights over New York to a number of persons, was given a 10-year suspended sentence and placed on probation for five years yesterday in Federal Court. He had pleaded guilty to mail and wire fraud charges.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI)--President Johnson sampled today a creole dish prepared by Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana, at the Capitol and pronounced it "excellent."
The leaders of a national fair housing organization warned yesterday that racial tensions and alienation in the nation's Negro ghettos could lead to "unprecedented" explosions in 1967.
Hanna de pescado, or fish meal, is the newest futures contract.
SAM RYKIEL is the father of an 11-year-old daughter named Natalie, a 6-year-old son named Jean-Philippe and a 10-year-old boutique named Laura.
The color television wars shifted yesterday to the smallscreen portable.
YPSILANTI, Mich., March 1 (AP)--Two groups of Ypsilanti businessmen have agreed to try to save the Ypsilanti Greek Theater.

LONDON, March 1--Prince Charles of Luxembourg and Mrs. Joan Douglas Dillon, daughter of C. Douglas Dillon, former Secretary of the Treasury, and Mrs. Dillon, were married today in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Edward the Confessor in Guildford.
Whereas, the Select Committee appointed pursuant to H. Res. 1 (90th Congress) has reached the following conclusion:
A five-man commission in Washington moved a step closer yesterday to determining which of several American applicants will get the 2,000-year-old Egyptian Temple of Dendur.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., March 1 --The resignation of Dr. John King as president of the University of Wyoming was confirmed here tonight by Gov. Stanley Hathaway.

Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce returned to New York yesterday with the body of her husband, Henry R. Luce, the publisher, to prepare for the 3 P.M. funeral tomorrow at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at 73d Street.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., March 1--The opening of the Garden State Arts Center at Telegraph Hill Park near Holmdel, first set for August, has had to be postponed until the spring of 1968, the New Jersey Highway Authority announced today.

STUART, Fla., March 1-- The other afternoon three anglers who had fled the snow and ice of New York fished their way up the south fork of the St. Lucie River here in company of Sally Johns, the best woman fishing guide around.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1--Fifty New York Mets held their first full workout of spring training today and were told by their manager: "Don't forget--you're as good as the next team, or better."

Fees paid to Christian Science practitioners and chiropractors may be claimed as medical deductions by an income-tax payer. Under certain circumstances, he may deduct the cost of whisky-- in limited quantities--if the "medicine" had been ordered by his physician.
EDINBURGH, Scotland Mr. G.P. is younger and senior. Mr. A.P. is older and junior.

I have a brief announcement to make. I have received a reply from Chairman [Aleksei N.] Kosygin to my letter of January 27. This reply confirmed the willingness of the Soviet Government to discuss means of limiting the arms race in offensive and defensive nuclear missiles.

THE genius of the late Lorenz Hart was to write lyrics that had a point of view and something to say, With his collaborator, Richard Rodgers, he felt it was not enough to fashion a song that attracted the car only melodically. A number also had to have an attitude toward life, be it an outlook on the vagaries of romance or on the mores of the moment.

GENEVA Whether or not Washington and Moscow can convince their friends to sign a nuclear limitation treaty, negotiations seeking this goal mark dramatic switches in both American and Soviet policy. Each superpower is patently prepared to scrap past concepts.
Ten thousand miles from this chamber we are engaged in a violent conflict that has engulfed the land of Vietnam.
WHEN a 329,900-share block of Reynolds Metals Com pany punctuated the ticker tape yesterday at 48, a lot of work was completed to bring together one big seller and a number of buyers.

James (Lucky) Jordan, a Cleveland truckdriver who was arrested early yesterday on charges of possessing $3-million worth of heroin, was ordered held in $25,000 bail by Criminal Court Judge Royal S. Radin. The court set March 30 for a hearing.

FOR the last few years, everybody in music has been talking about the young British cellist Jacqueline du Pre, now 21 years old. She is the girl who is so talented that people rush to present her with Stradivari instruments; the girl who already has an imposing series of recordings (solo and concerto) to her credit. Last year, she made her New York debut, to considerable acclaim.

WASHINGTON , March 2 Senator Robert F. Kennedy proposed today a suspension of American bombing of North Vietnam to open the way for peace talks. His proposal immediately heightened the debate on the possibilities for peace.
LONDON, March 2 Prime Minister Wilson told rebellious Laborites tonight to support his Government loyally or get out of the party.
The National Broadcasting Company is planning to buy most of the business empire from here to Tokyo that is controlled by Arnold Palmer, the world's most successful golfer.
WASHINGTON, March 2 The United States Commissioner of Education, Harold Howe, 2d, told Congress today that he would not favor Federal legislation that required precise racial balance in the schools.
Nine writers, painters and composers have been elected to membership in the National Institute of Arts and Letters, the honor society in the arts.
The National Braille Press, Inc., of Boston announced yesterday that it was selling taped editions of The New York Times Sunday section, "News of the Week in Review," for use by the blind.

HONG KONG, March 2 The technique of political criticism in China today is illustrated by a veiled attack on the Chinese chief of state, Liu Shao-chi, that paints him as a capitalist in Communist clothing.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) The Pentagon today listed the following men from the New York area as killed in action in South Vietnam:

WASHINGTON March 2 Contract negotiations between the trucking industry and the Teamsters union came to a hall today as the union's president James R. Hoffa, pushed ahead with his private search for a way to stay out of jail.
Housing activity and the mortgage market are returning to normal faster than most observers had expected, a mortgage banking company that has started a new national survey has found.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 Without opposition from the floor, shareholders of Transamerica Corporation in a 22minute special meeting today authorized a doubling of the company's common shares to 50 million.

The Federal Reserve Board's reduction in commercial bank reserve requirements affirms its desire to make credit more readily available for loans and investments. Its action, though neither dramatic nor major, does provide welcome reassurance that the monetary authorities are continuing to unwind the extremely tight credit conditions that prevailed through most of last year.

A new city law will require that apartment house garbage be tightly compacted for cleaner disposal, but the Sanitation Department is ruefully discovering that its incinerators cannot burn the trash because it is too compacted.
TOKYO, March 2 (AP) Rene-Georges Inagaki, an Associated Press staff writer, died in a hospital here today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 39 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Intercity truck tonnage and revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the week ended Feb. 25, which included the Washington Birthday holiday, were both below the volume in the corresponding week of 1966.

Senator Robert Kennedy's speech yesterday calling for a halt in the bombing of North Vietnam comes at what is clearly a crucial moment either for peace negotiations or for an escalated war. Mr. Kennedy now openly joins a formidable list of Senators, world statesmen, the Pope and the Secretary General of the United Nations in calling for an end to the bombing as a necessary prelude to peace talks.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 2 Cuba has agreed to train guerrilla, fighters for an Eritrean secessionist movement, which has been waging a mounting campaign of terror and harassment against the Ethiopian central Government of Emperor Haile Selassie, informed sources reported yesterday.

The Defense Department vigorously attempts to foster competition among its suppliers, a defense official declared yesterday, but added that it would be impractical and foolish to tie procurement to antitrust considerations.

The gravest of the growing pains afflicting the resident professional theaters that have mushroomed across the land in recent years is the failure of communication and comprehension between artistic directors and governing boards of lay, public-spirited citizens.
The Board of Estimate approved an annual pension of $15,153 yesterday for former Corrections Commissioner Anna M. Kross.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Acting Attorney General Ramsey Clark said today that, on the basis of inquires by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, there appeared to be "no connection," between Clay L. Shaw and the assassination of President Kennedy.

THE difference between a double-dummy problem and a single-dummy problem is not always clearly understood. "Double-dummy" was an ancient form of whist for two players in which two dummies were exposed. Both players knew all about the deal, so the game was, like chess, one of pure technique: psychology, judgment and guesswork were not factors.

GENEVA, March 2 Czechoslovakia resumed today the attack by East European countries on West Germany for its "obstinate opposition to all steps that would prevent further proliferation of nuclear weapons."

HARTFORD, March 2 James Lippincott Goodwin of Hartford, a widely known conservationist who was a senior member of the Society of American Foresters, New England section, died today in Winter Park (Fla.) Memorial Hospital at the age of 85.

Becton, Dickinson Co. announced yesterday it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of 500,000 common shares, with 283,200 to be sold by the company and 216,800 by certain stockholders.
Gimbel Brothers plans to open an eight-story department store on the Upper East Side if the City Planning Commission authorizes a change in zoning in the area.

David Ben-Gurion, welcomed to New York as Israel's patriarchal statesman, recalled yesterday another visit 52 years ago when he was welcomed without passport or visa as a refugee from Turkish oppression.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Four Presidential relatives whose White House experiences spanned 62 years told tales on themselves upstairs at the Executive Mansion tonight before a fascinated audience of Congressional and Cabinet wives.

MIAMI, March 2 When the Baltimore Orioles opened spring-training camp last week for the pitchers and catchers, not all the uniforms had arrived. So the candidates merely grabbed whatever shirts and pantaloons they could dig out of the trunk.

Frank Sinatra's "Strangers in the Night" was declared the record of the year at the ninth anuual Grammy award presentations, made last night by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences at simultaneous banquets at the New York Hilton Hotel and in Los Angeles, Nashville and Chicago.

President Johnson has persuaded the Soviet Union at least to discuss the possibility of averting an appallingly dangerous and costly race by Moscow and Washington to deploy antiballistic missile systems. This news is especially welcome as an antidote to recent Soviet statements that discouraged hopes of negotiating a freeze on A.B.M. development.

MONTREAL, March 2 (Canadian Press) Bargainers for the 14,000-member Seafarers International Union and the Great Lakes shipping companies were deadlocked yesterday in their first hour of negotiations for a new contract and announced that they would apply for the help of a government conciliator.
WASHINGTON, March 2 The General Tire and Rubber Company and three subsidiary companies were charged by the Justice Department today with illegally coercing other companies to buy their products.

The honor that he coveted almost above any other of the many bestowed upon him in recognition of his distinguished service as a coach in college and professional football has finally been bestowed upon Earle (Greasy) Neale in his election to the college football hall of fame.
ALBANY, March 2 Albany Medical College announced today the election of three new members of its board of trustees.
WASHINGTON, March 2--The Senate ethics committee announced today that it would begin public hearings on the financial affairs of Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, on March 13.

BOSTON, March 2 (AP) Bobby Hull scored his 44th goal of the season and Stan Mikita contributed his 30th tonight in helping the Chicago Black Hawks, the National Hockey League's leading team, to a 5-2 victory over the Boston Bruins.
MAPLEWOOD, N.J., March 2 Miss Grace Anne Elders and William Tapley Gregor plan to marry in July.

Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., has named Dorothy Parisi as a vice president and general manager and Young Rubicam, Inc., has appointed two executive vice presidents, Stepen O. Frankfurt and Edward N. Ney.
A prowler and a detective were seriously wounded by the same shot, fired by a second detective, as the two policemen struggled with the prowler in a West Side patio apartment last night.
PERHAPS the special quality of the epic is its length. Please do not mistake me, for not all long theatrical events have epic quality not quite but almost the reverse.

OXFORD, England, March 2 (AP) About 500 of the 10,000 students at Oxford University regularly smoke marijuana, a committee of tutors reported today. It said investigations had shown that the same proportion of students at other British universities also use narcotics.

PARIS, March 2 A "little Courreges heaven" now exists just one flight below the designer's haute couture salon at 40 rue Francois Premier. But the coats and dresses downstairs, unlike the couture clothes hang ready for customers to wear except for the hems.
ALBANY, Friday, March 3 John (Sonny) Franzese and four other men were convicted today of masterminding a series of nationwide bank robberies in 1965.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 2 Staats D. Morrison, who retired in 1950 as a research engineer with the Bell Telephone Laboratories in Whippany, died today in his home at 181 South Street. His age was 73.

Ignazio Mellana, co-owner of the Famous Kitchen, a restaurant at 318 West 45th Street, died Tuesday at Polyclinic Hospital, shortly after he had collapsed in the Manufacturers Hanover Trust bank at 43d Street and Eighth Avenue.
The Manhattan Republican party plans an "intensive" campaign against Adam Clayton, Powell if the Harlem Democrat runs for Congress in a special election.
Details of the 1968 world's fair in San Antonio, Tex., were announced here yesterday by Gov. John Connally of Texas.
EAST LANSING, Mich., March 2 (AP)-Carl Robie of Michigan got the Big Ten swimming championships off to a fast start tonight with a record-setting victory in the 500-yard free-style.

ALBANY, March 2 The Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, threw out today most of the money damages against Adam Clayton Powell stemming from his seven-yearold legal battle with a Harlem widow he defamed.
MIAMI, March 2 Homero Blancas, who prefers to play golf in warm weather, led the opening round of the $100,000 Doral open tournament with a 65 today.

SYRACUSE, March 2 The 31-year-old wife of a man billed as a trick shooter remained in "very critical" condition today at Syracuse Memorial Hospital after her husband had shot her in the right eye during a performance last night.

Federal Judge John M. Cannella awarded the E.L. Bruce Company damages yesterday totaling $827,476 plus interest against Jacques Sarlie, Dutchborn financier. With interest over a four-year period the amount is expected to total more than $1-million.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 2 George W. Riley, a legal consultant for many years with the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, died here on Tuesday. His age was 71.

Michel Molese, singing his first Don Jose at the New York City Opera, and Huguette Tourangeau, making her debut with the company as "Carmen," enlivened a generally lackluster production of the Bizet classic last night at the State Theater.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 1 The leader of an oldline, right-of-center nationalist party diclosed today that he would run for President in the national elections this summer.

PARIS, March 2 The Communist party, which is likely to poll between one-fifth and one-fourth of the vote in Sunday's election for the National Assembly, may well have the power to decide whether the Gaullists will lose or win.
ROME, March 2 (UPI) The captain who voluntarily goes down with his sinking ship is not a hero, the Vatican radio said today, he is a suicide and a sinner.

ALBANY, March 2 (AP) The State Superintendent of Banks urged today that a legislative committee give favorable consideration to proposals which, he said, would create additional competition and provide better service in the state's banking facilities.

The Telephone Employes Organization broke off negotiations last night with the New York Telephone Company and announced that it would take a strike vote among the 3,600 accounting employes it represents.

A POPULAR and rather too easy theory of criticism holds that a reviewer should ideally approach each book cold, with as little intrusive knowledge as possible about peripheral matters the character of the author, his previous work, the circumstances of publication, thematic context and so on.
The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for banknotes of New York. These rates do not apply to regular exchange business transacted by banks.
HACKENSACK, N.J., March 2 (AP) John L. Ryan, assistant sports editor of The Record died of a heart attack today at West Hudson Hospital in Kearny. He was 34 yeas old.
JUNEAU, Alaska, March 2 (UPI) The Coast Guard reported today that the cutter Storis had seized a Russian fishing vessel, a stern-type trawler, for violating United States territorial waters.

SAN SALVADOR, March 2 President Julio Adalberto Rivera of El Salvador threatened today to boycott the projected meeting of American presidents if the international coffee agreement was not revised beforehand.
Scholars who hold their breath at the mention of the I.N. Phelps Stokes "Iconography of Manhattan Island" can exhale again.
This week's drive toward lower interest rates kept intact yesterday as the Federal Reserve injected more money into the banking system.

The City of New York has leased municipally owned Shea Stadium to Madison Square Garden Corporation for one year for the "booking, promotion and presentation" of a variety of cultural and sporting events.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) Wayne L. Randall, who retired last July as an assistant city editor of The Washington Post, died yesterday at the age of 83.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) Space engineers turned off the picture transmitting mechanism of the lunar Orbiter 3 spacecraft temporarily today so they could study and try to correct its faulty opearation.

Hunter College, as a good school should, is making a determined effort to see that the 400th anniversary of Claudio Monteverdi's birth the exact date is May 14 is properly observed in New York this season.
"The Birthday Party," Harold Pinter's first full-length play, will be presented on Broadway in October by Haila Stoddard. Alan Schneider will be the director.
ALGIERS, March 2 The official Algerian radio said tonight that Morocco had taken a step of "extreme gravity" in asking the United Nations to check a potential arms race in North Africa.
WASHINGTON, March 2 There are still three differences between the Administration and Senator Robert Kennedy about negotiating an end to the war in Vietnam.
February was a raw month for the nation's auto manufacturers.

BONN, March 2--After nearly two decades of intimate cooperation, relations between West Germany and the United States have deteriorated to the point where senior Bonn officials are talking about "a serious crisis."
ALBANY, March 2 Governor Rockefeller asked the Legislature today to create a Crime Control Council to coordinate the activities of the several state agencies that combat crime.

A landlord organization charged yesterday that more than 5 per cent of the apartments in the city were vacant. Since the law requires rent controls to be lifted if the vacancy rate exceeds 5 per cent, the landlords said that the continuation of controls was illegal.

City Council President Frank D. O'Connor urged yesterday that the newspaper unions and the publishers of five major newspapers in the city speed up their negotiations in an effort to avoid a work stoppage at the end of the month.
WASHINGTON, March 2 The Administration acknowledged today that enactment of its Social Security bill might be inflationary unless income taxes were raised.
SPOTTING Nicholas C. Giovan in a crowd is easy, a colleague explained recently, even if you have never met him.
TRENTON, Mich., March 2 A fire razed the Beth Isaac Synagogue here last night and the police said today it was the work of an arsonist. Citizens of various faiths voiced shock and offered help.
YONKERS, March 2 A state official called a temporary halt today to work on the controversial Bates Memorial Hospital, which is being prepared for use as a narcotics cure center.

CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) Dr. David D. Henry, president of Illinois University, made a 45-minute appeal today for clemency by the Big Ten faculty representatives in the case of the Illinois's athletic slush fund scandal.
BEVERLY HILLS, March 2 (UPI) Arthur Cameron, an oil man, was found dead in bed today in his mansion here. The cause of his death was not immediately determined. He was 66 years old.

BUDAPEST, March 2 (AP) A Hungarian reporter back from Peking says that Chu Teh, chairman of the Standing Committee of the Chinese National People's Congress, had told Mao Tse-tung, the party chairman, that his purge was wrecking the nation.
CALCUTTA, India, March 2 The first leftist Government of West Bengal State was installed today in the hall in which British governors once held their audiences.

DONGHA, South Vietnam, March 2 (Reuters) A Vietcong mortar attack forced the threenation International Control Commission to leave its compound in the demilitarized zone between North and South Vietnam and establish new quarters at Hue, American military sources said today.

Not content to play merely the extant cello literature in his eight-concert Carnegie Hall marathon, the Soviet cellist Mstislav Rostropovich offered last night the world premiere of a work he commissioned for the series, Walter Piston's Variations for Cello and Orchestra.

KANSAS CITY, March 2 (AP) The Big Eight issued a formal protest today and "denounced the Amateur Athletic Union for its discriminatory handling of a legitimate world track and field record" the 1:44.9 half-mile by Jim Ryun of Kansas last year.
The Anaconda Company, a large copper producer, announced here yesterday the election of John G. Hall as a vice president.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he favored a new regional agency to fight air pollution.
BOSTON, March 2 (AP) The Massachusetts Supreme Court, in a unanimous decision, ruled today that the state's teacher oath law was invalid.

WAYNE, N. J., March 2--The Wayne Township Council last night defeated a proposal to create a Human Relations Commission and instead turned the job of fostering brotherhood over to the Wayne Ministerial Fellowship.
BLOOMFIELD, Conn., March 2 Miss Linda Beth Bercowetz and Joel J. Einhorn have made plans to be married in April.
Carlos J. Routh was elected yesterday as president of the Pittston Company, a diversified holding company based in New York.

NGAPALI, Burma, March 2 (AP)--Secretary General Thant of the United Nations said today that it was too early for him to comment on the possibility of a "direct dialogue" with North Vietnamese representatives. He added that he would make a statement, if waranted, on his departure from Rangoon Saturday.
The Metropolitan Opera has started an emergency $3-million fund drive to meet what it calls its "most serious financial crisis in 35 years."
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 The big news in Florida this spring is that Wes Westrum is soft-pedalling his evangelical campaign to elevate the New York Mets.

Two foreign Davis Cup players, John Newcombe of Australia and Jose Edison Mandarino of Brazil, shared the lead last night after the opening session of the Vanderbilt Gold Cup amateur tennis round-robin tennis tournament.

LESLIE MORRIS, the publicity-shy designer who has been dressing the rich for 39 years, showed her last custom collection at Bergdorf Goodman yesterday. As usual, she hid in the fitting room instead of taking a bow.
It was on Feb. 22, 1964 that Simon Wiesenthal, the head of the Jewish Documentation Center in Vienna, learned that a man believed to be Franz Stangl was working in Sao Paulo.

The J.C. Penney Company registered new records in sales and earnings for its fiscal year ended Jan. 28, but the final quarter's profit was down 7.4 per cent, reflecting high operating costs and other factors, the unaudited, preliminary statement disclosed yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 2 The disclosure today by President Johnson that Premier Kosygin had agreed to discuss a moratorium on deployment of antimissile defenses was foreshadowed by a hint here two weeks ago that the Soviet Government was willing to hold such talks.
PARIS, March 2 (AP) A French authority on the Vietnamese war said today Washington could not expect Hanoi to reciprocate if United States bombings of the north were halted.
Eugene Rodriguez, deposed as a State Senator, disbarred as a lawyer and already sentenced for one crime, should not be punished further, a Bronx judge ruled yesterday.

CLEVELAND, March 2 A permanent injunction against the manufacture and distribution of the Rand Development Corporation's controversial cancer vaccine was granted by United States District Court Judge James C. Connell today.

Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of the City College, said yesterday that neither the World University Service nor the Foundation for Youth and Student Affairs had received funds from the Central Intelligence Agency during the periods he had been associated with them.

COBLESKILL, N.Y., March 2 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J. Lewis DuMond of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Diane DuMond, to Edward Martin Keech, son of Mrs. John S. Keech of Berkeley, Calif., and Northport, L.I., and the late Mr. Keech.
Prices ended up with investment-grade stocks and glamour issues showing the best gains in active trading; volume, 11.9 million shares.
March came in with a lambon Wednesday to the amazement of residents of Pennsylvania and Flatlands Avenues in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 2 If the people who pay $500 to go to a political dinner have much to say at their party's national convention, the next Republican candidate for President is likely to be Ronald Reagan.

HONG KONG, March 2 The Governor of Hong Kong, Sir David Trench, dedicated the John F. Kennedy Center for Spastic Children today. The center was built by the World Rehabilitation Fund, an American voluntary agency.
Widespread gains by industrials highlighted a firm trend on the London stock market yesterday.
FORT LAUDERDALE, March 2 Ray Barker is growing old, and the future he once thought he could snatch out of the air with his first baseman's mitt now rests precariously in the hands of Mickey Mantle.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 2 Iraqi oil began to flow again today through pipelines to Mediterranean ports in Syria and Lebanon after agreement had been reached between the Syrian Government and the Iraq Petroleum Company in a transit loyalties dispute that had halted the flow for three months.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Ramsey Clark, whose nomination as Attorney General was confirmed by the Senate today, plans an intensified antitrust drive and wants to use the 94 United States Attorneys' offices across the country to combat local and regional price fixing conspiracies.
MIAMI BEACH, March 2 Three thousand American and Canadian Jewish leaders were told today that stepped-up economic development of Israel would promote the establiment of peace in the Middle East.

NEW ORLEANS, March 2 The District Attorney's office contended, today that Lee Harvey Oswald, David W. Ferrie and Clay L. Shaw plotted the assassination of President Kennedy in a clandestine meeting here in September, 1963.
Little brown boxes smaller than bread boxes arrived the other day at newspaper, television and trade publication offices around town.
HE has said, "I will continue to the day I die." No one disputes him.

Directors of McKesson Robbins, Inc., and Foremost Dairies, Inc., approved yesterday in principle a merger of the two companies, it was announced yesterday by Herman C. Nolan, chairman of the worldwide pharmaceutical distributor, and Rudolph J. Drews, head of the San Francisco-based dairy producer.
Two leaders in their fields, Swift Co., the meat packer, and the American Home Products Corporation, a producer of pharmaceutical, cosmetic and food, proposed 2-for-1 stock splits yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Because of typographical and transmission errors, two points were stated erroneously in an article in today's editions of The New York Times dealing with a Government report on rising medical costs.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company realized a 12.6 per cent increase in earnings in the first fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31 on a sales gain of 9.5 per cent, with both setting new records for the period, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 2 Communist China has acknowledged a serious epidemic in some of its southern provinces.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 2 There was a run today in Beirut on the British Bank of the Middle East but the bank continued to meet all cash payments.
MUNICH, Germany, March 2 (Reuters 3 United States military officials, faced with the threat of antiaircraft dumplings, agreed today to negotiate with a Munich graphic artist, Helmut Winter.

The gradual trend of Federal Reserve policy toward easier money, which started to become apparent last November, was clearly evident yesterday in the weekly crop of banking statistics that the Reserve System releases every Thursday.
WASHINGTON, March 2 President Johnson revisited today the scene of one of his landmark civil rights speeches and recommitted his Administration to equal opportunity for Negroes.
The stock market continued to advance yesterday but with less vigor than Wednesday's rise.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 3 At least 94 South Vietnamese civilians were injured in northern South Vietnam last night when bombs fell on them from "an unidentified aircraft," a United States military spokesman said today.

Kidder, Peabody Co. Inc., the large New York investment banker and broker announced yesterday the acquisition of the investment banking and brokerage business of the Pacific Northwest Company, Seattle.

Carol, Elinor, Cathy and John are young people for whom the staff at the New York-New Jersey Red Cross Blood Program have a special feeling, mainly because we are watching them grow up, thanks to blood therapy.

Dave Dreyer, a popular pianist whose hit songs of more than two decades ago changed the tempo of the times, died yesterday in the Beth Israel Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 345 West 58th Street.
FRANKFURT, Germany, March 2 (Reuters) West Germany had a payments surplus on current account of 922 million marks ($230.5-million) in January, the Federal Bank announced today.
SAIGON, March 2 (UPI) United States Marines, who have been fighting North Vietnamese soldiers south of the Demilitarized Zone, captured an enemy stronghold on a hill today in hand-to-hand combat.

City antipoverty officials have asked the Federal Government for permission to add three months to their current program year. This would allow projects to end on Sept. 30 instead of at the end of the fiscal year on June 30.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2 (UPI) The Philadelphia 76ers rallied in the fourth quarter to defeat the San Francisco Warriors, 136-128 tonight in the second game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader. The Boston Celtics, led by its hot-shooting backcourt combination of Sam Jones and Larry Siegfried, defeated the Chicago Bulls in the opener, 114-108.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 2 King Hassan II of Morocco has appealed to Secretary General Thant to set up a commission of investigation to avert an arms race between Algeria and Morocco.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 2 Pictures of President Sukarno are disappearing from Government offices here, but not all at once. Some bureaucrats are keeping the official portrait handy for reinstallation if advisable.
Alf Olaussen, a former ship chandler at 11 State Street, died yesterday at the Silver Lake (S.I.) Nursing Home. He was 72 years old and lived at 100 Signal Hill Road in Grymes Hill, S.I.

A Brooklyn rackets grand jury indicted yesterday the International Longshoremen's Association, two I.L.A. locals, 10 union officials and 33 ship maintenance companies on charges of dealing with labor leaders who have criminal records.
CAPETOWN, March 2 The Government presented a bill to Parliament today that would make it harder for descendants of mixed marriages to claim classification as whites.
New York University's basketball team gave heavily favored St. John's a ferocious battle at Madison Square Garden last night before succumbing to a 55-51 defeat.
MIAMI, March 2 The glamour race of the Hialeah meeting, the 1 1/8-mile Flamingo for 3-year-olds, will have its 38th running tomorrow, with a field of 11 listed to compete.
PITTSBURGH, March 2 (UPI) Barry Goldwater said tonight that Senator Robert F. Kennedy had stuck his "foot in his mouth" when he called for a cessation of bombing in North Vietnam.

BIMINI, The Bahamas, March 2 Adam Clayton Powell, normally cool and unresponsive, broke into a broad smile today when he learned that an appeals court had handed down a ruling favorable to him in his bout with Mrs. Esther James, a Harlem widow.

WASHINGTON, March 2--A heavy build-up of inventories at the manufacturing level continued in January and new orders for durable goods fell even more than indicated by a preliminary report two weeks ago, the Commerce Department disclosed today.

VIENNA, March 2 (AP) Peggy Fleming of Colorado Springs gained an imposing 69.2-point lead in the compulsory figures today and virtually clinched her second straight women's crown in the world figure-skating championships.

WASHINGTON, March 2 The International Finance Corporation announced today that it was prepared to help finance larger private investment projects abroad in a broader field of activities than heretofore.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., March 2 Miss Althea Hungerford Nasmith and Floyd Liston Booth Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Booth of Guilford, N.C., have made plans to be married in the autumn. The engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Augustus Nasmith.

WHITE PLAINS, March 2 Welfare caseworkers from Westchester, who have seriously curtailed the county's relief services by staying out "sick" for a second day, arranged today to travel to New York City tomorrow to apply for caseworker jobs there.

Serving at 5-2 in the second set of his match with Pierre Barthes of France and with a 10-8, 6-2 victory apparently at hand, Richard (Pancho) Gonzalez of Los Angeles, the former world champion, went into a tailspin, and one of the most astonishing turnabouts on record followed in the pro tennis indoor tournament last night.
LONDON, March 21 The Bertrand Russell archives, a century-spanning accumulation of family papers of historical and literary interest, will be put up for private sale this summer.
