Samuel I. Newhouse purchased the 125-year-old Cleveland Plain Dealer yesterday, reportedly for $50-million.

CAMBRIDGE Mass., March 2 A South African physician reported to an international congress on nutrition today what was thought to be the first evidence ever collected that an improper diet does in fact cause brain damage in children.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 2-Tom Cahill, Army's head football coach, received a plaque today from the Football Writers Association of America honoring him as the organization's coach of the year. Cahill was selected two months ago as the writers' and the Football Coaches Association of America's coach of the year for 1966.

CHICAGO, March 2--A major meat packer and its packing house unions announced agreement today on a three-year contract. It calls for wage and fringe benefit increases totaling an average of 66 cents an hour for the period.
LONDON, March 2 (Reuters) Britain's reserves of gold and dollars increased by $39.2-million to $3,169,600,000 in February, the Finance Ministry announced today.
The following reports were provided yesterday by operators of the ski areas (messages were filed at the times listed in parentheses):

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) Soviet political analysts contend that wide resistance to Red Guard "outrages" and a threat of economic paralysis are primarily responsible for a slowdown in the Maoist upheaval that has shaken China since last summer.
A Northeast Airlines DC-6B that sustained a decompression explosion over New Jersey a week ago today was not structurally modified, as recommended by its manufacturer, the airline said yesterday.

The Democrats who control the State Assembly are now intimating that they may substitute their own version of a direct primary bill for the one approved by the Senate, 54 to 0. If they do, the result might well be a deadlock between the two houses that would prevent action on this long overdue reform.
VIENNA, March 2 Austria has taken up Soviet President Nikolai Podgorny on his suggestion to participate in building a natural-gas pipeline from Siberia to Italy and France through Austria.
Prices of fish meal futures advanced yesterday from their levels the day before when they were listed for the first time on the New York Produce Exchange.

GENEVA, March 2 The poorer countries have not been forgotten in the Kennedy round. As the final tradeliberalization package begins to take shape, there is almost universal agreement that they will be given the opportunity to increase their export earnings where it matters most for them in cotton textiles and tropical produce.

WASHINGTON, March 2 The House rejected today all attempts to attach a statement of policy on the Vietnam war to an Administration bill authorizing $4.5-billion in additional military spending for the current fiscal year.
CHICAGO, March 2 The legal dispute over restrictions on the press in the Richard F. Speck murder trial in Peoria, which was seemingly resolved yesterday, flared anew today.

MILAN, Italy, March 2 (AP)--Montgomery Hyde, British author, was convicted today of having defamed a dead Italian admiral by writing that the officer had given away military secrets to a lovely spy during World War II.

Announced at an impromptu news conference that Soviet Premier Kosygin had agreed to Soviet discussions with the U.S. on limiting the arms race in defensive as well as offensive nuclear missiles; spoke at ceremonies marking the 100th anniversary of Howard University.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2 The local team of William I. Forties Jr. and Jerry Bijur withstood the New York pair of A. Hadden Tomes and Col. James W. Gerard by 6-3, 2-6, 5-6, 6-4, 6-2 today in gaining the semifinal round of the United States court tennis doubles championship at the Racquet Club.
The Long Island Lighting Company reported yesterday that for the 14th consecutive year its earnings had shown an improvement.

WASHINGTON, March 2--Sam M. Lambert, who has been associated with the National Education Association for 17 years, was appointed today executive secretary, the top administrative post of the association.
The Chase Brass and Copper Company announced yesterday it was reducing surcharges applicable to free-cutting brass rods and shapes to 2 cents a pound from 4 cents, effective today.
The American Stock Exchange its third consecutive advance yesterday although some late profit taking reduced some of the gains.

PARIS, March 2 France's official reserves rose last month for the first time since July. The increase was small $5,5million. And it is improbable that France will present the dollars involved in the gain to the United States for conversion into gold.
A fiddle-leaf fig tree from the Philippines, trussed as tight as a mummy in yards of burlap, was hauled from the back of a moving-van yesterday at the Coliseum.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 2 The engagement of Miss Michelle Anne Malone to William Byrnes 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Byrnes Jr. of Scarsdale, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Michael J.P. Malone. A June wedding is planned.
Richard Elias, a violinist who made his New York solo debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, has a big tone, a decisive technique and a bold musical approach.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 2 A 60-year-old automobile mechanic identified by Brazilian and Austrian authorities as Franz Stangl, the commandant of the Treblinka and Sobibor concentration camps in Poland during World War II, has been arrested in Sao Paulo.
Jose Martinez Ruiz was the last survivor of a group of Spanish writers known as the Generation of '98, which emerged as Spain's colonial empire was vanishing.
The mines and shells that supplemented American bombs in Vietnam last week were intended to increase pressure in what the military call the "interdiction campaign against North Vietnam.
ADEN, March 2 (Reuters) Violence spread through this city today for the fifth successive day, keeping British troops in the streets.

ALBANY, March 2 (AP) The widow of a Syracuse automobile salesman who died of a heart attack after dancing the twist at a company party is entitled to workmen's compensation, the state's highest court decided today.
YONKERS, March 2 Yonkers Raceway will conclude its first of three 1967 meetings tomorrow night and attendance and mutuel-handle figures at the meeting are somewhat on the disappointing side.

NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., March 2 John Stokes Carswell, a marine engineer, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 431 Mountain Avenue. He would have been 73 years old tomorrow. He had a summer home at Point o' Woods, Fire Island, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) The Federal Reserve Board announced today its approval, in a 6-to-1 decision, of a new bank-holding company formed by four upstate New York banks.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 2 (AP) Albert A. Ridge, retired judge of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, Eighth District, died today. He was 68 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Secretary of State Dean Rusk rejected today on behalf of the Administration a proposal put forward by Senator Robert F. Kennedy for a suspension of the American bombing of North Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, March 2 The cut in budget funds for the Office of Economic Opportunity is imperiling family planning services for 30,000 to 40,000 women, a planned parenthood leader said today.

BIGELOW, Me., March 2 A late start, a change in programming and a strong showing by the University of Denver marked the opening today of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's four-event championships at Sugarloaf Mountain.
LEVITTOWN, L.I., March 2--A thief who walked off with a batch of film early this week is probably wondering what that movie of high school students kidnapping the Statue of Liberty is all about.

WASHINGTON, March 2 President Johnson announced today that Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin had agreed to discussions between the United States and the Soviet Union on limiting the arms race in both offensive and defensive nuclear missiles.
WASHINGTON, March 2 The leader of Adam Clayton Powell's legal team said tonight that no decision had been made yet on how to combat his exclusion from the House.

Edith Evans Asbury of The New York Times won a Page One Award from the Newspaper Guild of New York yesterday for local reporting on her series of stories about an upstate Italian-American couple's successful fight to adopt their blond foster child, Beth Liuni.

HOW to assess a musical like "Shoemakers' Holiday"? By Off Broadway standards, it is bouncy and good-looking and sometimes fun. Measured against the great Dekker play on which it is based, it's shoddy.
WASHINGTON, March 2 The House Agriculture Committee approved today a resolution authorizing the President to allocate three million more tons of food grain to India this year.
ALBANY, March 2 Democrats dropped their opposition to penalties against striking public employe unions today when they offered a plan to overhaul the Condon-Wadlin Law.
WASHINGTON, March 2 A noted aviation research pioneer, Dr. Antonio Ferri, urged today that the nation work toward a 5,000-mile-an-hour airliner and an 8,000-mile-an-hour bomber.
The Kips Bay Boys Club will benefit March 13 from a spring boutique to be held in the clubhouse auditorium at 301 East 52d Street from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.
The American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that it would aid any court test that Representative Adam Clayton Powell might bring to challenge the House decision to exclude him.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 2 Russell C. Clark of Long Ridge Road in Danbury, a retired executive in the nonferrous metals industry, died today at Bridgeport Hospital at the age of 66.
KEY LARGO, Fla., March 2 The simplest and easiest way to tell an angler other than if he has a fishing rod in his hand is if he has a fishing boat on the roof of his car.

PRICES are down in the newest couture import collection assembled in Europe by Hess's department store of Allentown, Pa. A crystalbeaded dinner gown by Antonio del Castillo is priced at $7,500--$1,500 less than last season's most expensive style, also a Castillo. But the reduction isn't significant, according to Gerard (Gerry) Golden, the store's fashion director.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 3 (AP)--President Johnson named today a commission of experts to recommend an overhaul of the Federal budget.

The last track meet scheduled for the present Madison Square Garden, where so many historic races and field events have taken place, will be tonight's 46th annual I.C.4-A, championships with a crowd of 10,000 to 12,000 expected.
TOKYO, March 3--Japan's political and economic leaders have warily chosen for the present a cautious, business-first policy in East and Southeast Asia.

Light snow and snow flurries are forecast today for northern New England, the lower lake region, the Northern Plains States and the rockies. Showers are expected in the Tennessee and mid-Mississippi Valleys. It will be colder in the northeast, the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys, the Central and Southern Plains States and plateau regions and warmer in the northern plateau region and the Carolinas.
This morning at the Central Synagogue, 55th Street and Lexington Avenue, 100
TUCKAHOE, N.Y., March 3-- The driver of a small car stopped outside the police station here this morning and asked the desk officer if he could borrow an electric extension cord.

NEW ORLEANS, March 3-- A man who declared "I don't know what this darn thing is all about" was subpoenaed today by District Attorney Jim Garrison's office in its investigation into an alleged plot that led to the assassination of President Kennedy.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., March 3--Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Farnsworth VanderPoel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Farnsworth VanderPoel, to James Mairs Duryea, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Mairs Duryea of Old Westbury.
NEW BRITAIN, Conn., March 3 (AP)--Senator Thomas J. Dodd said today he considered it "entirely sensible" to circulate in Connecticut affidavits concerning testimonial dinners in his behalf.
HONG KONG, March 3-- Overzealous supporters of Mao Tse-tung were warned today against promoting anarchy in China.

Quaker groups are continuing to send medical aid to North Vietnam through the Canadian Friends Service Committee despite the Treasury Department's ban this week on all applications to send money abroad for this purpose.

PEORIA, Ill., March 3 (UPI) --Acting over the objection of Circuit Court Judge Herbert C. Paschen, the Illinois Supreme Court dismissed today a suit challenging news coverage restrictions in the Richard Speck murder trial.
Eddie Neloy, a horse trainer who worries about taxation because of too much representation, will resume a familiar custom on today's racing program.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 3-- A University of Wisconsin, graduate student, studying in Taiwan on a United States Office of Education research grant, has been secretly tried and convicted on sedition charges by a Chinese Nationalist military court.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 3 --All was in readiness at Roosevelt Raceway today for tomorrow night's opening of the Nassau County harness racing plant. The first of 70 nights of trotting and pacing will follow immediately on the heels of tonight's closing at Yonkers Raceway. Tomorrow night's card is expected to attract at least 30,000 fans.

DETROIT, March 3--Mayor Jerome P. Cavanagh termed Detroit's finances "disastrous" today at a hearing on Gov. George Romney's fiscal reform program. There were indications that the Governor would obtain a bigger tax package than he had requested.

Almost 20 years ago, Roberta Peck, fresh out of high school in New Britain, Conn., and with ambitions to be a popular singer, made the decision that usually puts an end to such hopes--marriage and a family would come first, the career later. But Miss Peck is carrying through on the second part of her decision.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 3--Gen. William C. Westmoreland's drive against the main forces of the enemy has entered a new and critical phase.
BOSTON, March 3 (AP)-- The Philadelphia 76ers, led by Hal Green and Wilt Chamberlain, defeated Detroit tonight for the eighth straight time this season, 129-103.
MOSCOW March 3 (UPI)-- Two senior editors of the liberal Soviet magazine Novy Mir have been dismissed in an apparent blow at the country's liberal literary movement, it was learned today.
DUBLIN, March 3--The United States failed again today to gain permission for an American airline to land at Dublin Airport.
WASHINGTON, March 3--The United States issued tonight what appeared to be, a warning to the United Arab Republic and other outside powers not to attempt armed

Most of Westchester's 225 welfare caseworkers may take tests next week to join New York City's undermanned Welfare Department staff because of a deadlock in negotiations for higher salaries and other benefits.
The city is likely to be free this summer of most of the restrictions on the use of water that have prevailed for the last two years.
Interest rates again were nudged downward, moderately but firmly, yesterday by Federal Reserve purchases of Treasury bills and some issues with maturities up to five years.

A charge that Gerald Whitmore killed a man with a broken billiard cue during a brawl last Saturday was dismissed yesterday because, according to the prosecutor, "the cause of death appears not to have been the cue stick."

Mrs. Karen Bruce Hamburger, widow of Richard Hamburger, was married here yesterday afternoon to David Edward Ullman. The ceremony was performed by New York Supreme Court Justice Irwin D. Davidson in his chambers.
The dedication of the Maine Maritime Academy's new student center will be the highlight of the 25th anniversary celebration today of the school at Castine, Me.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 3 (AP)--The Arkansas House passed a bill today permitting casino gambling on a limited scale at Hot Springs, but Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller said he would not sign it under any circumstances.
The International Business Machines Corporation confirmed yesterday that the House antitrust subcommittee in Washington had asked for detailed information about the computer industry and markets.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP)--The Senate voted 51 to 25 today to raise the top salaries of its committee employes to $25,890 to equal the pay of their counterparts in the House.
Nearly 200 members of the faculty and staff of Teachers College, Columbia University, sent a letter to the White House yesterday protesting the war in Vietnam and asking for an end to the bombings.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., March 3--Msgr. Edward F. Glamkowski, pastor of St. Ladislaus Church, Hempstead, died yesterday at Mercy Hospital here. He was 77 years old.
New-car sales of the American Motors Corporation fell sharply in the final third of February and in the month as a whole, the company reported yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 3 (UPI)--The Maryland House of Delegates passed and sent to the Governor today a bill that would abolish the state's 306year-old law forbidding interracial marriages. The vote was 97 to 25.
Detroit is getting a resident theater company on March 17.
WASHINGTON, March 3-- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall, encouraged by the "steady erosion" of the gasoline price increase, said today he planned no action at present on the issue.
The Citizens Committee for Metropolitan Affairs, Inc., issued the first of a series of reports yesterday on the cost of drugs in the state.

The Associated Councils of the Arts, the organization of representatives of state and community arts councils, will hold a national seminar June 22-24 at the Airlie House Conference Center in Warrington, Va.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3 (AP)--Temple's zone press harried American University into numerous turnovers as the Owls won, 83-61, tonight and entered the final round of the Middle Atlantic Conference basketball tournament.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 3 --The Austrian Government began proceedings today for the extradition of Franz Stangl, identified by Brazilian and Austrian authorities as the cammandant of the Nazi concentration camps at Treblinka and Sobibor in Poland during World War II.
TRENTON, March 3 (AP)-- Legislation calling for $4-million in new exemptions to the state's 3 per cent sales tax will be introduced Monday, Assembly Speaker Robert J. Halpin said today.
ACCRA, Ghana Feb. 28--Ghana's year-old military government is faced with an increasing security problem.
The fact that a few large corporations are deserting New York does not mean that the city is finished, a leading authority on urban affairs said yesterday.

The manufacturer of a Northeast Airlines DC-6B that sustained an explosive decompression Feb. 24 over New Jersey said yesterday it had "highly recommended" in 1957 structurally reinforcing a door frame where the explosion occurred.

WASHINGTON, March 3-- State Department officials said today they had been informed by the Polish Embassy here that Mr. Nixon had been denied a visa for a planned visit to Poland. The reason given by the embassy, according to officials, was that Mr. Nixon's visit would be "inconvenient at this time."

YONKERS, March 3--The 51st and final card of the year's first of three meetings at Yonkers Raceway drew 24,267 harness racing buffs, who wagered $2,269,087 tonight. These figures brought the season's aggregate to 885,099 (average 17,354) in attendance and $85,842,475 in mutuel handle (average $1,683,185).

EIGHTH--The Flamingo; $100,000 added; 3YO; 1 1/8 M. Start good; won driving. Off 4:56. Winner. dk. b. or br. c. by Jester-Lysistrata, by Palestinian, Trainer, H. Jacobs, Value to winner, $93,990; second, $28,920; third, $14,460; fourth, $7,230. Times--0:22 3-5; 0:46; 1:09 4-5; 1:35 1-5; 1:48 3-5.
Adam Clayton Powell will fight the House vote excluding him as Harlem representative to the 90th Congress in Federal courts in Washington and in Manhattan.

PARIS, March 3 (Reuters)-- The French balance of payments surplus fell by 70 per cent from 1965 to 1966 to its lowest figure for seven years, the Finance Ministry announced today.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 9.5 per cent in production for the week ended Feb. 25, compared with the level in the corresponding 1966 week.
Three major brass mills announced yesterday they were reducing their prices for free-cutting brass rods and shapes.
TRENTON, March 3--Gov. Richard J. Hughes told cab drivers at Newark Airport today that "it's not nice for an old woman to get into a cab and be cursed for wanting to go to Newark."

CLEVELAND, March 3 (AP) --A terminal cancer patient from Nevada who came to Cleveland for treatment with the Rand Development Corporation's experimental cancer vaccine died yesterday at the Bay View Hospital in suburban Bay Village.

The State Department yesterday announced a major new approach designed to help solve the financial problems of maintaining American troops in West Germany. Under the new program, the United States and other Western allies would rely on monetary cooperation to prevent the cost of the troops from contributing to the balance of payments problem or causing a drain on gold reserves. MADISON, Wis., March 3 (UPI)--Wisconsin jumped off to a slim lead in the 57th annual Big Ten track championships tonight, and along with Michigan State, the defending champion, became the early favorites to win tomorrow's showdown.
James H. Beard of Monsey, N.Y., business products advertising manager of Newsweek magazine, died Thursday of a heart attack in Chicago, while on a business trip. His age was 53.

BREMEN, Germany, March 3 (AP)--Patty Caretto of Whittier, Calif., set an American women's indoor free-style record tonight as the United States scored a one-two 400-meter victory at the Bremen International swim festival.

The election of James J. Shea Jr. as president and general manager of the Milton Bradley Company was announced yesterday. He succeeds James J. Shea Sr., who was elected chairman and chief executive officer of the games and educational materials manufacturer.

LOS ANGELES, March 3-- In the public image the policeman's lot is still not a happy one, and therein, according to Los Angeles' new police chief, Thomas Reddin, lie both the problem of soaring crime rates and the task of averting more race riots.
Who's the man for all seasons, Alexander H. Cohen or David Merrick?

PRINCETON, N.J., March 3 (AP)--Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said today that Adam Clayton Powell "is wrecking the civil rights movement."

SYRACUSE, March 3--Overseas work by American scholars has been greatly handicapped by the recent disclosure of ties between the Central Intelligence Agency and student groups, Dr. Stephen K. Bailey of Syracuse University said today.
ATHENS, March 3--Former Premier George Papandreou, leader of the Center Union, defied an Athens court-matrial summons today by refusing to testify at treason trial of 28 military officers.
WASHINGTON, March 3-- James R. Hoffa lost two more legal points today in his lastditch efforts to avoid going to prison next Tuesday.
HAWTHORNE, N.Y., March 3--George H. Ogle Jr., an advertising executive, died at his home here yesterday. He was 44 years old and lived at 174 Belmont Road.
A bookkeeper was charged yesterday with having forged and cashed 760 payroll checks while working at a Bronx nursing home in the last four years.

MUNICH, Germany, March 3 (AP)--Hermann Winter claimed victory today in his dumpling war against lowflying aircraft. He said the offending United States Army helicopter unit had surrendered unconditionally.

Two Federal officials have denied that "political influence or pressure" affected the Government's approval of the controversial Chestnut Ridge path for an Armonk-Katonah segment of Interstate Highway 87 in Westchester County.

RABAT, Morocco, March 3-- King Hassan II of Morocco urged neighboring Algeria today to stop arming for a "violent show down" and to accept a negotiated settlement of the territorial dispute between the two countries.
The electric utility industry expects a full-size prototype of an electric battery for powering vehicles to be ready in 1968.

WASHINGTON, March 3-- The Congressional disagreement over the search for peace in Vietnam hardened today following Senator Robert F. Kennedy's proposal that the United States suspend the bombing of North Vietnam as an inducement to the Communists to enter into peace negotiations.
Representative Hugh L. Carey and other Brooklyn Democratic legislators met for two hours yesterday with city officials to complain about the antipoverty program here.
President Johnson has responded swiftly and constructively to the proposals of the Carnegie Commission and the Ford Foundation for Federal action to spur the growth of educational television.
WASHINGTON, March 3-- About one-fourth of the United States gold loss last year was to domestic users for such purposes as jewelry and filling teeth, the Treasury disclosed today.
The stock market closed mixed yesterday after undergoing a series of ups and downs in heavy trading.

LEVITTOWN, L.I., March 3 --The Motion Picture Cameramen's Union, Local 646, sent 10 rolls of color film to the Division Avenue High School senior class today, whose fundraising spy movie was stolen last Monday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 3 (AP)--A run against the British Bank of the Middle East here ended today and business was reported near normal.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)--A civilian advisory panel called today for a crackdown on draft evaders, draft card burners and men who join the Reserves to stay out of combat.
EAST LANSING, Mich., March 3 (AP)--Carl Robie of Michigan became the first double winner of the Big Ten swimming championships tonight by winning the 200-yard butterfly event.
MIAMI, March 3--There were some unusual happenings today during the second round of the $100,000 Doral open golf tourney as Homero Blancas and Tommy Aaron shared the lead at the halfway mark.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3--The New York Mets will head north five weeks from today with three catchers, 10 pitchers, seven infielders, seven outfielders and one jack-of-alltrades. Who will they be?

Puccini's "Madams Butterfly" fluttered uncertainly into the Metropolitan Opera last night for its first performance of the season. The chief problem was also the major novelty: the conductor, Francesco Molinari-Pradelli.
Spokesmen for fair housing committees in the metropolitan area urged Governor Rockefeller yesterday to abolish the State Commission for Human Rights.
For the third time in three weeks a labor dispute in Italy has halted the sailing of an Italian Line luxury liner here.

SAIGON, March 3--Capt. John J. Duffy, commander of a special forces detachment posted on a ridge just above Langvei, said today that "two dark gray or black delta-wing jets, which came in over the mountains from Laos," attacked at dusk last night.

ANCHORAGE, March 3 (UPI)--The United States Government decided today to prosecute the master of a Russian fishing vessel seized by the Coast Guard for violating United States territorial waters off Alaska.
The series of injuries on the New York Rangers extended yesterday to the general manager-coach, Emile Francis.
PHILADELPHIA, March 3-- District Attorney Arlen M. Specter, a former Democrat, was chosen today by the Philadelphia Republican organization as its candidate for Mayor.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 --Gov. Ronald Reagan of California was described today as "certainly a qualified person for higher office" by Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan.
An exhibition for the benefit of the Florentine Relief Fund, "400 Years of Italian Art," will open apt the Byron Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue, on March 15.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 101 on Thurs day from 101.3 on Wednesday.

There is only one reason why Ian Smith should need to appoint a commission to draft a new constitution for Rhodesia: He has no intention of implementing the constitutional proposals--including the guarantee of "unimpeded progress" toward African majority rule --that he insisted he was willing to accept in the abortive negotiations with Britain last December.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)--Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, proposed today the formation of an international force that would shoot down any missiles that cross the north polar icecap.

Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen, who had a hit record album, "Gallant Men," his first time out, is cutting a second album, "Man Is Not Alone." On "Gallant Men" the Republican orator from Illinois preached patriotism. On "Man Is Not Alone" he preaches religion.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., March 3--Top-ranked Anil Nayar, a 20-year-old Harvard sophomore from Bombay, India, reached the third round of the national intercollegiate squash racquets championship today at the Wesleyan University courts.
Chunky bars, a chocolate candy, had an energizing effect on cocoa futures yesterday.

Liza Minnelli daghter of Judy Garland and Vincente Minnelli, motion picture director, was married here last evening to Peter Woolnough Allen, a song writer and singer. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Woolnough Allen of Sydney, Australia.

STANFORD, Calif., March 3 (UPI)-Undefeated University of California, Los Angeles, sank 63 per cent of its floor shots in the first half and used a tough defense to coast to its 24th victory tonight, beating Stanford, 75-47, in a Pacific Eight Conference basketball game.

LIMA, Peru, March 3 (UPI) --Chief Justice Earl Warren said today that he knew of not one single fact that might change the conclusions of the Warren Commission report on the assasination of President Kennedy.
OAKLAND, Calif., March 3 (AP)--Bob Beamon of the Texas Western Track Club leaped 26 feet, 11 inches for an American indoor long jump record tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union championships.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 3-- Robert Ward, who won the 1962 Pulitzer Prize in music for his opera "The Crucible," based on Arthur Miller's play about the Salem witch hunt, was appointed today president of the North Carolina School of the Arts.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 4--Ninety-five South Vietnamese civilians are reported to have been killed and 200 wounded when two jet planes knifed in from Laotian territory Thursday night and bombed and strafed Langvei, a village near the border.

At Lincoln Center today: Little Orchestra Society Young People's Concerts, Philharmonic Hall, 11 A:M, and 3 P.M.; "Die Zauberflote," Metropolitan Opera, 2; "Tosca," New York City Opera, State Theater, 2:15; "II Trovatore," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "La Traviata," City Opera, State Theater, 8:15, and New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, March 3-- The Communist party won another round in the United States Court of Appeals today in its fight to avoid registering as a Soviet agent.

PARIS, March 3 (UPI)-- The Soviet rocket that put man into space for the first time will be shown at the Paris Air Show, aviation sources said today. It will be the first public showing of the rocket outside the Soviet Union.

UTICA, N.Y., March 3 (AP) --A Baptist minister has been dismissed from his job as a press operator at a sheet-metal plant here because, he says, of a placard he wore that paraphrased one of the Ten Commandments.

NATCHEZ, Miss., March 3 (AP)--In an unusual move, the Adams County sheriff and the Natchez mayor and police chief, all white, attended a Negro mass meeting last night and promised to work to solve the explosion death of a Negro civil rights leader.

IN this anthology of brief memoirs, biographical fragments, letters and confessionals, Lucy Dawidowicz has compiled an intellectual history of Eastern European Jewry in the century and one-half before 1939. Although we see history in outline, the emphasis is on the inner man, on the struggles that rent mind and spirit as the Eastern Jews tried to cope with the forces blowing in from the West and arising from their very own soil.

ROME, March 3 (UPI)--The European middleweight champion, Nino Benvenuti, in a tuneup for his Madison Square Garden title bout on April 17 for Emile Griffith's world crown, outpointed Milo Calhoun of Jamaica tonight.
Dennis Ralston was beaten last night in his first appearance in this country as a professional.
MADRID, March 3--Protestant and Jewish spokesmen expressed today deep disillusionment over the version of legislation on freedom of worship approved last Friday by the Spanish Council of Ministers.

Melina Mercouri, star of the musical "Illya, Darling," and its director, Jules Dassin, will be present to meet the guests at a Greek Supper Party March 22. The party will follow a preview of the musical at the Mark Hellinger Theater.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 3--Continental Air Lines will begin a free technical study of Indonesia's aviation facilities and requirements next month, Pierre Salinger, the airline's vice president for international affairs, announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP)--President Johnson's proposals for revising special tax treatment of the aged were denounced today by Representative Thomas B. Curtis, Republican of Missouri.

RANGOON, Burma, March 3 --Secretary General Thant of the United Nations had talks on the war in Vietnam with North Vietnamese envoys here, a Hanoi diplomat said tonight. The diplomat, Consul General Le Tung Son, said, "U Thant came here and I received him as an Asian and we exchanged views on the Vietnamese problem."

The president of Yale University said yesterday that the "overwhelming majority" of high school graduates admitted to colleges such as Yale would "benefit greatly" by postponing their entrance a year.
IN standard bidding methods any suit bid immediately following a take-out double by an opponent is not forcing: it implies a long suit with less than the 10 high-card points needed for a redouble.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 3 --Saboteurs blew up an Israeli tractor and injured the driver in the Jordan valley, approximately a mile from a Syrian border position, it was reported here today.

ROME, March 3--A heavily financed bid to get Italian teen-agers into British mod clothes is threatening the Bohemian character of Rome's via Margutta, historically an international center for artists and writers.
CARE, the international relief organization, said yesterday that a man who had been one of its seven field representatives in South Vietnam had been jailed in Saigon on black marketing charges.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on Colo nialism--Received draft resolution on five Caribbean territories.
FORT JACKSON, S.C., March 3 (UPI)--The 9rmy announced today that a young medical officer from New York would be court-martialed on charges of spreading disloyalty among troops bound for Vietnam.
In a predominantly man's world, Mrs. Julie C. Lauh of Francis I. du Pont Co., has found an unusual niche.
ALBANY, March 3--Records of the trial of John (Sonny) Franzese showed today that he was said to have murdered "30 or 40 or 50" people in his career as an "enforcer" for the Mafia.

PUERTO AZUL, Venezuela, March 3 (AP)--Germany's Lucky Liz, maneuvering through choppy seas and 30 mile an hour winds, won its third straight race today in the South American Star Class championship regatta.

BOSTON, March 3--A dispute between waterfront employers and longshoremen over what some employers consider featherbedding has been settled temporarily. It had threatened to shut down the Port of Boston tonight.

MADISON, Wis., March 3 (AP)--An organization whose members were involved in antiwar protests leading to 19 arrests last week has been suspended from activities on the University of Wisconsin campus by the student Senate.

John W. Celebre, supervising superintendent of the Department of Sanitation and bandmaster of the Sanitation Department Band, died, apparently of a heart attack, yesterday afternoon while conducting a band rehearsal at the departmental band room at 270 Union Avenue, Brooklyn.
Hourly and salaried employes of the iron and steel industries received a record $4,797,908,175 in 1966, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The total in 1965 was $4,687,609,774.

The spot rate on the British pound fell yesterday at the close in light dealings on foreign exchange markets here. The final quotation of $2.7942 was 14 points lower than the day before. Traders attributed the drop to weekend technical factors. Sterling for Monday delivery was quoted at $2.7944.

PALO ALTO, Calif., March 3 (AP)--John Wooden, the coach of the University of California, Los Angeles, basketball team was named the college basketball coach of the year in an Associated Press poll today.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 3--Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Linder have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Harriet Linder, to Frederick Kent Orkin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lazarus A. Orkin of New York.

CHOLON, South Vietnam, March 3--Behind a 15-foot- high wall in Cholon, Saigon's twin city and the home of 500,000 Chinese, lies a lot now occupied by nondescript Government offices but once the site of Grand Monde, Southeast Asia's largest gambling establishment. The club was officially closed...

REGAN CAMPKIN, 3 years old, who had just decided she would rather be a queen than a nurse, was darting around her parents' shop on a recent morning. That she was responsible for her parents new career as designers and purveyors of fashions for children was nowhere evi-...
A 21-year-old pre-medical student whose legs were crushed in a highway accident in 1963 received a $650,000 settlement yesterday in Federal Court.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP)--The Defense Department acknowledged today that United States Army headquarters in Europe had ordered Stars and Stripes to drop a dispatch reporting the arrest of the 19year-old son of the United States Ambassador to West Germany.
CARACUS, Venezuela, March 3 (UPI)--The brother of Venezuela's Foreign Minister was found murdered in a shack outside Caracus tonight. Communist propaganda leaflets were scattered around the body.

ST. LOUIS, March 3 (UPI)-- The St. Louis professional soccer Stars signed today four Jamaicans, including 20-yearold Allie McNab, a forward who played for the Jamaican national team. The other three players are Ernest Waugh, a halfback, Norman (Billy) Griffith, a forward, and Gauntlett Rowe, a goalie.

Ward Foods, Inc., made an exchange offer yesterday of $120 principal amount of 5 per cent convertible subordinated debentures due Jan. 1, 1987, in exchange for each outstanding share of $5.50 cumulative preferred stock, including dividends in arrears.
MIAMI, March 3 (AP)--John (Boog) Powell of the Baltimore Orioles signed a contracts today for a salary reported at $35,000.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 3 (Reuters)--President Sukarno has turned down a Government request that he leave the country despite the loss of his executive powers, a highranking army officer said today.
MIAMI BEACH, March 3-- The consolidation of Israel's economic framework was described here today as an "indispensable factor" in rehabilitating the surviving victims of the Hitler era.
Three companies announced yesterday the filing of registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission for common stock offerings.
A Regional Church Plan Commission was organized yesterday by representatives of 10 major Protestant denominations in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut area.
LONDON, March 3--It's almost as though Rice Krispies no longer snapped, crackled or popped.

LOS ANGELES, March 3 (AP)--Four consistent quarters of scoring by Los Angeles, led by Jerry West, gave the Lakers a 138-132 victory over the New York Knickerbockers tonight in a National Basketball Association game. The triumph gave the Lakers a tie with the St. Louis Hawks for second place in the Western Division.
The Chunky Corporation said last night that a milk chocolate supplier had caused its plant to be infected with a dangerous Salmonella bacteria forcing recall of 7.5 million Chunky candy bars.
THE girl in the purple dress swiveled on the piano stool, which was wearing red boots, and rested her elbow on the black and white piano keys, which were made of mattress ticking.

SOME of the best material in the Antiques Fair that open today at the New York Coliseum is in the art nouveau style. And just around Columbus Circle the work of Aubrey Beardsley, one of the progenitors of the style, is on display at the Gallery of Modern Art.

MIAMI, March 3--"The word for Figaro is go, go, go." That's what it said on a sheet of paper posted in the cabin today of William Snaith's 50-foot yawl as an admonition to the crew of the Stamford Yacht Club boat to try hard to regain the Southern Ocean Racing Conference championship she won two years ago.
PHILADELPHIA, March 3 --William T. Vogt of Philadelphia and E. Newbold Black 4th of New York reached the final of the United States court tennis doubles championship today at the Racquet Club.
IOWA CITY, March 3 (UPI) --Iowa broke a two-team monopoly in Big Ten gymnastics today to take its first conference gym title in 30 years.
WASHINGTON, March 3-- The United States outlined a new approach today to the financial problem of maintaining American forces in West Germany.
Two policemen credited with saving hundreds of lives by their quick action in a huge explosion and gas-fed fire in Jamaica, Queens, were promoted to detective yesterday.
While Leontyne Price was singing "Aida" at the Metropolitan Opera House Thursday night, two men forced their way into her home, bound her maid, and stole furs and jewelry valued at $75,000.

Lew Alcindor, the highly publicized sophomore from University of California, Los Angeles, who lived up to all his preseason billing, was named the college basketball player of the year for 1966-67 by United Press International yesterday.
Henry R. Luce, founder of the Time-Life-Fortune publishing enterprise, received memorial tribute here yesterday as a complicated and generous man who became "one of the decision makers of our time."

JERSEY CITY, March 3-- The Jersey City Federation of Teachers and the Board of Education here agreed today to accept the services of a mediator in their salary dispute. At the suggestion of Superior Court Judge Robert A. Matthews, the mediator will be the Rev. Victor R. Yanitelli, president of St. Peter's College.

Jacob E. Davis and John S. Fangboner have been elected directors of the Anchor Hocking Glass Corporation. Mr. Davis is president of the Kroger Company and Mr. Fangboner is chairman and chief executive officer of the National City Bank of Cleveland.
Next door to where Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary lives in Peter Cooper Village, some 100 or more housewives are afflicted with fear.
Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said here yesterday that he had been denied a visa by the Government of Poland to visit Warsaw March 20-21.
LONDON, March 3--Eileen Joyce, the pianist, returned to the concert platform here last night after an absence of six years and was warmly welcomed.

SAN DIEGO, March 3 (UPI) --Ogden Kellogg Jr., 21 years old, a member of the Scripps newspaper family, who was stranded for more than two weeks on 10,154-foot Mount Diablo in Baja California, Mexico, was rushed today to a hospital for treatment of frostbitten feet.

FORT LEE, N.J., March 3-- Frank Klein has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Susan Klein, to Mark N. Bloom. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron M. Bloom of Yorkers. A July wedding is planned.
Industrial issues closed with moderate gains on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

YONKERS, March 3--Dr. and Mrs. Harris Blinder have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phoebe Marlyn Blinder, to Paul Robert Weinstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mack Weinstein of Brooklyn, New York. The wedding is planned for March 25.

A class of eighth graders, most of whom said they expected to be making only $60 a week by the time they were 21 years old, was tempted by visions of $10,000-a-year positions this week by a group of professional people.
White Consolidated Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it is holding merger talks with Mack Trucks, Inc.

PARIS, March 3--Premier Georges Pompidou, in a final appeal to French voters tonight, denounced the "detestable war in Vietnam" and pointed to improved relations with the Soviet Union as an example of the success of France's foreign policy.

SANTA ANA, Calif., March 3 (UPI)--Judge Samuel Dreizen of Orange County Superior Court dismissed today contempt charges against a newspaper photographer accused of violating a ban on courtroom photography.
Stocks moved in a narrow range and prices were mixed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
Echo I tomorrow at 5:36 A.M., 26 above the southeastern horizon, moving S.W. to N.E.
Madison Square Garden Corporation's team in the North American Soccer League will play its home games in Yankee Stadium.

The Very Rev. Alfonso Parziale, former Minister Provincial of the Franciscan Province of the Immaculate Conception, covering the eastern United States, with headquarters here, died Thursday night in St. Francia Hospital, Poughkeepsie, N.Y. His age was 87.

Wholesale merchants moving from their congested Washington Street Market, founded in 1771, to a new site in the Bronx may continue to truck their fruits and vegetables through city traffic because of a dispute with the New Haven Railroad.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 3 (UPI)--President Johnson invoked the Taft-Hartley Law today in a preliminary step to halt a West Coast shipyard strike that the Pentagon says is hampering the Vietnam sealift.
A strike of boiler repairmen began yesterday after members of Local 32E of the Building Service Employes Union had rejected a package proposal.

The Rocketdyne division of North American Aviation, Inc., announced yesterday that it had received a $100-million order from the Pratt Whitney Aircraft division of the United Aircraft Corporation. Rocketdyne will produce afterburners for the turbofan engines of the F-111 military fighter, formerly the TFX. The engines are being built by Pratt Whitney under a subcontract from the General Dynamics Corporation.
In the New York City Opera season's last performance of "The Abduction from the Seraglio" at the State Theater last night, the casting of Nadja Witkowska as Constanza provided an element of novelty.

SWAN LAKE, N.Y., March 3--Mr. and Mrs. Herman Schop of Swan Lake and Miami Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sharlene Schop, to Daniel Paul Greenberg. He is the son of Mrs. Sarah Greenberg and Benjamin Greenberg, both of New York.

PARIS, March 3--The Guide Michelin, the most prestigious handbook of French restaurants, will drop one restaurant from its top, three-star category and add another when the 1967 edition appears March 15.

Unanimous passage by the State Assembly this week of a bill allowing policemen to hold other jobs is impossible to justify, or even to understand. The action comes when the crime rate here is steadily increasing, and when the Police Department is more than 300 men under strength and looking for a thousand additional officers.

BOYNTON BEACH, Fla., March 3--Frank W. Regan, a hotel manager who was president from 1945 to 1954 of Realty Hotels, Inc., which operated the Biltmore and other New York hotels, died today in the Bethesda Memorial Hospital here. He was 79 years old and had been living in Boca Raton.
The appointment of Donald L. Caldera as vice president and general manager has been announced by Flume Stabilization Systems, Inc.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 3--Having fixed his policy course in two months of intense domestic and diplomatic activity, President Johnson retreated briefly to his ranch near here today to prepare for the year's second major round of activity.

Edwin L. Thompson, a senior, securities analyst at Tucker, Anthony R. L. Day, 120 Broadway died yesterday at Beekman-Downtown Hospital after a brief illness. He was 70 years old. He lived at 3 Washington Square Village and had a summer home at Candlewood Isle, Conn.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 3 (AP)--Three of the New York Yankees' important pitchers--Whitey Ford, Mel Stottlemyre and Jim Bouton-- came in for special attention today during a 3 -hour workout.

Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, whose shareholders will vote on its liquidation at the annual meeting on April 24, suffered a net loss of $740,000 last year. This contrasted with the 1965 net income of $2,318,854 or $1.01 a share.

LONDON, March 3--An urgent effort to persuade the British Government to keep at least a token force in Aden after 1968 or to give the South Arabian Federation some kind of defense guarantee is being made here by Sheik Mohammed Farid, the federation's Foreign Minister.
WASHINGTON, March 3-- Additional evidence that consumers are buying less and saving more came today in two seperate Government reports.
MOSCOW, March 3 (AP)-- The Soviet Union has resumed sending weather information from an orbiting satellite to the United States after a fourmonth pause, informed sources said today.

LONDON, March 3--The Labor Government won a substantial victory last night when the National Union of Railwaymen agreed to lift its ban on the use of special "liner" trains and terminals by private highway transport concerns.

CHICAG0, March 3 (UPI)-- Big Ten faculty representatives upheld today a ruling by the athletic directors that the University of Illinois must dismiss three coaches involved in a "slush fund" scandal or show cause why it should not be expelled from the conference.
More of a general market than usual, the annual antiques fair that opens today at the Coliseum could have as its slogan "Something for Everyone."
SINGAPORE, March 3 (AP) --Mitsutaka Kono, a slender Japanese pro, tools a two-stroke lead with a three-under-par 68 for 137 today in the Singapore open golf tournament.
BONN--The new head of the Dusseldorf Stock Exchange is extending an invitation to major American companies: "Come and list your shares on the West German exchanges."

TOKYO, Saturday, March 4 --Chairman Mao Tse-tung has ordered all students in Communist China, down to the primary level, to undergo an annual 20-day period of "military-political" training, according to Japanese dispatches from Peking.

MOSCOW, March 3 (UPI)-- The Soviet Union said today that the Johnson Administration had no intention of ending the Vietnam war by peace talks. It accused the United States of seeking military victory in Southeast Asia.

John Newcombe of Australia, who likes the rubber indoor court because of the way "it takes the spin," and Jose Edison Mandarino of Brazil, who enjoys the "sound of my strokes" in the high-ceilinged Vanderbilt Athletic Club, continued on a collision course last night.

Stocks closed mixed with advances and declines just about even; leading averages showed irregular results; volume, 11.1 million shares. Corporate bonds were mixed in slow trading; transactions, $13.6 million.
Miss Craig Hill Marcus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Marcus Jr. of Dallas, will be married today to Thomas Yancy Hill Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hill, also of Dallas.

First Financial Corporation of the West, a comparatively small California savings and loan holding company, announced yesterday a complex transaction under which it will acquire from three of its directors 70 per cent of the common stock of a company that owns and operates the Stonewood Shopping Center in Downey, Calif.

The city's request for greater control over utilities comes too late in this legislative session for comprehensive consideration. But it will be unfortunate if it does not become the basis for a thorough study of the state's regulatory laws and of the operation of the Public Service Commission.

The president of a Wall Street bank-stock concern urged mutual savings bankers yesterday to begin immediately on a "substantial" program of mergers that would cut costs and allow the banks to pay a higher dividend rate to depositors.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 3 (AP)--Four Americans vowed today to continue their hunger strike in prison "until we die or get justice." They charged that the United States Embassy "threw us to the wolves," but Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge denied this.

CARSON CITY, Nev., March 3 (AP)--Warden Carl Hocker said yesterday that legal gambling at the Nevada State Prison would be replaced by a hobby program-- rawhide braiding, beadwork, knitting, crocheting and painting.

WASHINGTON, March 3-- Old buddies of Gen. Wil- liam Childs Westmoreland have long described him as a man with "the habit of command," which helps to explain his leadership in three wars, including his ascendancy to commander in South Vietnam. "Westy," as he is known...

KINGFIELD, Me., March 3-- A disastrous showing in crosscountry by Denver just when it seemed that it was highballing toward its seventh straight National Collegiate ski title sent the Pioneers skidding into a siding today.
A 21-year-old shipping clerk who was discharged a month ago from his job in a Brooklyn knitting mill for absenteeism was charged yesterday with the fatal stabbing of the mill's owner.

STOCKHOLM, March 3-- Britain's Foreign Secretary, George Brown, indicated today that Britain would take new steps to join the Common market after conclusion of the Kennedy round of trade negotiations.
The Court of Appeals decision in one basic phase of the Adam Clayton Powell case highlights the error that the House of Representatives made in its hasty decision to exclude him.
The Canadian Government is malting a pitch to attract feature film producers and to develop the country's young talent.

ROCKFORD, Ill., March 3 (UPI)--Investigators appealed to a woman with a Southern drawl today to identify herself and tell all she knows of the killer or killers who deliberately, and apparently without warning, shot two boys to death in a lonely park shelter house.
The opposite sides of the coin in labor-management relations have been vividly illustrated by developments in the last 48 hours.
Only one complaint in 25 concerning the conduct of policemen warranted a recommendation of charges, the Civilian Complaint Review Board said in a semi-annual report yesterday.

IT seems to happen every other day. An acquisi tion-minded company makes a tender offer and the object of its affection balks. Yesterday there were two such dissents, one of them tentative. For one, Link-Belt Company expressed opposition to a Dresser Industries, Inc., bid to acquire the capital-goods maker.

Hugo Klahre Sr., executive vice president in charge of operations for Conso Products Company, decorative trimmings, 27 West Second Street, died yesterday in Mexico, while on vacation. He was 72 years ald and lived at 255 East Saddle River Road, Saddle River, N.J.
Atheneum will publish in June "The War Years 1939-1945: Vollume II of the Diaries and Letters of Harold Nicolson." This will be the second of three vol-
THE PRESIDENT At his Texas ranch for weekend; appointed emergency board to help end fourmonths-old strike by electrical workers against 13 major West Coast shipyards.
A program to provide group homes for 25 to 30 per cent of the children in the state's mental hospitals was announced yesterday by the Manhattan Society for Mental Health.

CALCUTTA, India, March 3 --"I've just received a phone call from Mrs. Gandhi," Ajoy Mukherjee, the new Chief Minister of the state of West Bengal, announced this morning as he began his first full day on the job.

VIENNA, March 3 (AP)-- Emmerich Danzer of Austria won a dramatic duel with his compatriot, Wolfgang Schwarz, in the free skating competition today and gained his second straight men's world figure skating championship.

A work-stoppage at two television networks here by a dissident local of a technician's union was called off yesterday shortly before its scheduled start, 3 P.M., when the local's leadership decided that it was standing "on shaky legal ground."

LONDON, March 3--Eighty British engineers and technicians arrived in Moscow this week to work out final design details for the construction of the largest synthetic fiber plant complex in the Soviet Union.

BIMINI, the Bahamas, March 3--Adam Clayton Powell said today he would have accepted public censure in the House of Representatives "only if they had put me in chains and dragged me down the aisle of the house."
"The Hemingway Hero," by A.E. Hotchner, will close after tonight's performance at the Wilbur Theater in Boston. It had been scheduled to run through next Saturday.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 3 (UPI)--Manager Eddie Stanky of the Chicago White Sox named six pitchers today from a staff of 18 who already have clinched jobs for 1967.

MIAMI, March 3--Flying along the stretch with a late speed that increased with every stride, Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Reflected Glory raced to a convincing victory today in the $144,600 Flamingo Stakes.
ACHIEVING CHRISTIAN MATURITY, by Gerard Philips (Franciscan Herald Press, $4.95). Chronicle of the problems, tendencies and questions posed today.
SPRING is moving slowly northward in little rushes and pauses. Right now it is tarrying around Tryon, S.C., where bloodroot and hepaticas are reported to be opening and maples and scillas blooming.
BRUSSELS--An American film distributor has come up with a new idea to service the legions of traveling businessmen in Europe.

AUSTIN N. HELLER, New York's Air Pollution Control Commissioner, was on a tour not long ago of the General Motors laboratories in Pontiac, Mich., when a strange "popcorn" device caught his eyes. Exhaust gases from a diesel engine were being funneled into a small chamber in which catalytic balls, about the size of peas, bounced ...

GREENWICH, Conn., March 4--Top-seeded Stephen T. and Ramsey W. Vehslage reached the semi-final round of the Greenwich invitation squash racquets doubles championship today at the Greenwich Country and Field Club.
HAVERFORD, Pa., March 4 --Haverford College officials have removed all time restrictions governing the visit of women to dormitories.
Even though most consumers won't discover it until Christmas time, toy prices are going up.

Original illustrations for a 1966 edition of Dante's "Divine Comedy" in a new translation by Louis Biancolli will be exhibited, beginning Tuesday, at the Hudson Park Branch of the New York Public Library, 10 Seventh Avenue South.

The University of Texas defeated the University of Pennsylvania by a score of 255 to 230 yesterday on the National Broadcasting Company's "College Bowl", television program. It was the fourth straight victory for Texas.

WASHINGTON, March 5-- The Administration's safe streets and crime control bill has attracted wide bipartisan support in Congress, raising the prospect of favorable action with a minimum of controversy.
STOCKHOLM, March 5-- The Swedish Government plans to create by midyear a stateowned industrial credit institution of major proportions.
The Lindsay administration is taking a new direction in its efforts to provide decent housing in rundown neighborhoods.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 5--An almost daily series of street demonstrations outside the French Consulate is viewed by diplomatic observers as a warning by the Saigon Government against a United States "sellout" of South Vietnam in any peace negotiations.

Reducing the voting age from 21 to 18 years in New York State would mean a nearly 8 per cent increase in the potential electorate, the Temporary State Commission on the Constitutional Convention reported yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., March 5 --When the Federal District Court in Baltimore ruled last May that the Rescue Fire Company Arena here was a public accommodation, the Cambridge firemen locked its doors to the entire community rather than let Negroes in.
The New York Times began publishing a special weekly edition today designed for persons with impaired vision.

IF you come to Helen Hudson's second novel, "Meyer Meyer" with modest expectations, you will find it a bargain. It demands no great investment in time. Written in lucid prose, it purls along, with occasional flashbacks, in chronological order. Yet the return in pleasure, in insight into character is likely to be greater than from those books with more pretentious themes or complex structure or eyebrow-raising language.
The City Housing Authority said yesterday that it was look ing for a way to pay for new incinerator air pollution controls without raising rents for its 143,000 tenant families.

JERSEY CITY, March 5--Dr. Vincent P. Butler, chief medical examiner of Hudson County for the last 15 years, died last night at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York. He was 73 years old.
NEW DELHI, March 5--A coalition of Opposition parties took power today in the drought-stricken state of Bihar, in a move that could further complicate efforts to fend off famine there.

More than 800 former Peace Corps volunteers have signed a letter to President Johnson that is critical of United States policy in Vietnam as "seriously undermining" hopes for a "peaceful and bountiful world."
Dr. Murray L. Maurer, an allergist, died Saturday in University Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived at 123 Westwood Circle, Roslyn Height, L.I. His offices were in Manhattan and Jamaica, Queens.

FINDLAY, Ohio, Monday, March 6--A two-engine Lake Central Airlines plane crashed during stormy weather in westcentral Ohio last night, killing all 35 passengers and three crew members aboard.

Or perhaps it was only a collection of pieces rather than a program. Elthcr way, it made for fascinating listening.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 5 (AP)--Dingo, captained by Jim Schoonmaker of Biscayne Bay, Fla., won the South American Star Class sailing championship today without once finishing first in the five races. Dingo scored 72 points.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 5--The Hollywood gagmen once thought that they had hit on a hilarious description of the Dodger style of play. Maury Wills would walk, steal second, reach third on an infield out and beat the throw home after a dinky fly to the outfield. Then the heroes of never-never land would say to the pitcher, preferably Sandy Koufax, "There's your run. Now it's your fob to make it stand up."
