Locke of the English department of Madison College here and Mrs. Locke, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. Clark of Essex Conn., and the late Mrs. Jane Schley Clark of Sharon. A June wedding is planned.

Faulty printing on the credit cards issued by the New York Telephone company to approximately 130,000 persons in Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester, has caused the company to issue new ones to the recipients.
Toy manufacturers are gearing up for increased sales in 1967 and toy retailers are concerned about higher prices.
Steel production dropped 2.1 per cent last week from the unusually high level of the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Sidney Sezzen of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Phyllis Sezzen, to Donald Holt Levy, son of Mrs. Virginia P. Levy and George B. Levy of Manhattan. A summer wedding is planned.

The Downtown Community School is sponsoring a "Roaring 20's Cabaret Night" on March 19 at the Red Garter, 15 West 4th Street, as a benefit for its scholarship fund. The program will offer a floor show and a Charleston contest with an antique fur coat as the prize. Tickets at $5 each, are available at the school, at 235 East 11th Street.
Sales of several large chainstore organizations rose slightly in February from the level of the like 1966 month, their reports disclosed yesterday.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 6 (AP)--President Johnson disclosed today the assignment of Emory C. Swank, a 45-yearold Soviet specialist, as No. 2 man in the united States Embassy in Moscow. Mr. Johnson said he would nominate Albert Scheffer Lang as Federal Railroad. Administrator in the new Department of Transportation.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)--The Senate Preparedness Subcommittee will investigate the Defense Department procurement of rifles for the armed forces to determine whether United States servicemen are getting them fast enough, John Stennis, the chairman, said today.
The stock market went through a pattern yesterday that has become quite familiar in recent sessions: Up in the morning, down in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP)--Nevin M. Summers Jr., 17 years old, of Jacksonville, Fla., was named tonight as winner of the annual Westinghouse, science talent competition among the nation's high school science students.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 6-- Norman Lamont Macy, a retired vice president and director of the First Boston Corporation, investment bankers at 20 Exchange Place, New York, died today at Nassau Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 1 Shoreview Road, Port Washington.
Wearing a cream-colored cowboy hat, Cassius Clay glanced out of a window of a chartered limousine as it sped along the Long Island Expressway yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 6 (AP)-- The president of the American Federation of Teachers urged the National Education Association today to join with it in making public "the extent of C.I.A. activity in either organization."
The Chesapeake Ohio Railway was given the green light yesterday to take another carrier into its consolidated system.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 6--Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge has asked to be relieved of his duties in Saigon late in the spring or early in the summer, according to friends. Mr. Lodge has declined to discuss his plans publicly.

VIENTIANE, Laos, March 6 --Laotian military sources said today that Government troops killed 462 pro-Communist Pathet Lao and North Vietnamese soldiers and wounded 155 in January. The sources said 267 Government soldiers were killed and 352 wounded in the same period.

Maurice F. Granville was appointed yesterday by Texaco, Inc., as assistant to J. Howard Rambin Jr., chairman. Mr. Granville, who became a corporate vice president in 1960, will be in charge of strategic planning.
Prices drifted down yesterday in moderately active trading on the American Stock Exchange.
TRENTON, March 6 (AP)-- State Senate approved without dissent today the creation of a commission to study New Jersey's 44-year-old divorce laws.
Francis Cardinal Spellman will serve as honorary grand marshal of the St. Patrick's Day parade, the first person to hold that title in the 205year history of the event.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- Representative Wright Patman urged President Johnson today not to redesignate William McChesney Martin Jr. as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board when Mr. Martin's term runs out at the end of this month.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Vickers of Burlington and Gananoque, Ont., and of Del Ray Beach, Fla., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joanne Margaret Vickers, to Paul Douglas Peterson of Southborough, Mass. The wedding is planned for June 17.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- The trouble with the new plans for changing the draft law is that they do not take into account the changed nature of society and modern warfare. Both the President's plan and that of the House Committee on Armed Services cling to the out-of-date theory that an army has to be young.
Dorothy Parisi, girl general manager, has a green thumb. It does well by the flora flourishing in her office. It does well, too, by Doyle Dane Bernbach, flourishing in 43d Street.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP)--A decision by Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara to permit British shipyards to bid against United States yards on 16 prototype minesweepers was protested today by Representative John W. Byrnes, Republican of Wisconsin.
PINEHURST, N.C,, March 6 (AP)--The defending champions and the medalists led the way through the quarter-finals of the Pinehurst Country Club senior four-ball golf tournament today.
WASHINGTON, March 6-- Democratic leaders of the House Armed Services Committee said today they would attempt to block President Johnson's decision to create a lottery system for drafting young men.

Thomas Hoving's imminent departure as Parks Commissioner has caused no slow-up in the effervescence of his ideas for wider public use of the city's recreation areas. His latest proposal to use the Central Park reservoir for swimming and boating is an engaging addition to the list.

FLORENCE, Italy, March 6 --Florence, dried out, swept and garnished after her disastrous November flood, currently is celebrating her return to near normality with the most extensive review ever assembled of Italian art and sculpture in the years from 1915 to 1935.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, in closed session, inquired for three hours today into the relationship of the Central Intelligence Agency with the National Student Association.

Big Joe's Happiness Exchange Foundation, whose appeals in behalf of the needy and unfortunate have tugged at the hearts and the purse strings of millions of radio listeners, has a tax bill from the Government for $981,863.34.

The New York regional office of the National Labor Relations Board yesterday entered a dispute between two rival unions over representation of 1,800 employes at the American Broadcasting Company and the National Broadcasting Company.

Abraham H. Rachlin, a retired Newark real-estate executive and a former director of the Loft Candy Corporation, died Sunday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived on his estate, Hop Brook Farm, in Holmdel, N.J.
NEW ORLEANS, March 6 (AP)--Louisville, Ky., has been named the 11th member of the American Basketball Association, a new pro league which expects to begin action next season.
PHILADELPHIA March 6 (UP)--Gypsy Joe Harris, the fifth-ranked World Boxing Association welterweight, stopped Johnny Knight in the sixth round of their scheduled 10round bout at the Arena tonight.
LAUNCESTON, Tasmania, March 6 (AP)--Jack Brabham of Australia, driving a Repco-Brabham, won the South Pacific Trophy at Longford today, beating out Jim Clark of Scotland by more than a minute.
HONG KONG, March 6-- Mao Tse-tung's volunteer army of political supporters appears to be breaking up.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)--Mrs. John F. Kennedy is contemplating a vacation trip to Cambodia and has secured a visa for that country with the help of French officials, according to The Washington Post.

DUBLIN, March 6 (AP)-- The flow of cattle and fresh vegetables to Irish markets dropped abruptly today as farmers began a one-week strike to protest Government farm policies and the jailing of farmers who oppose them.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 6--Arthur J. Goldberg said tonight on his return from a brief visit to Southeast Asia that he saw little chance for an early peace in Vietnam.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 6 (UPI)--Indiana overcame a deficit in the final six minutes, then turned back another bid by Michigan and scored a 96-90 basketball victory tonight, retaining its share of first place in the Big Ten.
TOKYO, March 6--Top Government sources privately expressed hope today that Japanese industrialists and Moscow officials could make a deal, worth more than $300-million, to help develop Siberia.

MIAMI, Fla., March 6 (AP) --W. Arnold Hanger's Cleareye opened a lead going to the far turn and went on to score a three-length victory today in the feature race at Gulfstream Park before a crowd of 17,407.

TANINGES, France, March 6 (Reuters)--Eighteen children from 8 to 16 years old died early today when a fire swept through a 700-year-old orphanage in this mountain village near the Swiss bor der. Twenty-eight other children were hospitalized, four of them with serious injuries. Five members of the orphanage staff were also injured.
PARIS, March 6--French political parties started bargaining today behind closed doors on the deals they hope will decide the runoff elections for the National Assembly next Sunday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6-- Mr. Mary Ellen Miller Sullivan a registered nurse and the widow of Timothy Sullivan, a former New York Times reporter and rewrite man, died. Saturday in the Jefferson Hospital. She was 51 years old.
A change in senior management was announced yesterday in White Plains by the Nestle Company, a food producer.

MOSCOW, March 6--Nina Sergeyevna Isakova will not sing her accustomed role of Dorabella in the Sunday performance of Mozart's "Cosi Fan Tutti" a the Stanislavsky Musical Theater, but she has been singing Dorabella's arias at political meetings recently.

There will be two million people over 65 years old in New York State by 1985, twice as many as in 1965, according to the National Council on the Aging. California will also have two million over 65, it predicted.
The North American Trading and Production Corporation announced yesterday that it would spend $5-million to enlarge one of its tankers.
WASHINGTON, March 6-- The National Academy of Sciences urged today a United States policy and streamlined approaches to exploit the scientific treasures and practical uses of the seas.
Mayor Lindsay, New York's first Republican Mayor since 1945, received a standing ovation last night from the more than 350 guests attending the Reform Independent Democratic Club's annual dinner.
NEW ORLEANS, March 6 --Gary Cuozzo, considered the best backup quarterback in the National Football League, was traded to the New Orleans Saints today by the Baltimore Colts.
KEY LARGO, Fla., March 6 --Bless the Wright Brothers, not just because they invented the airplane, but because the device enables one to get to his hunting and fishing so quickly.

SAN SALVADOR, March 6-- Salvador has chosen a moderately liberal, semimilitary regime for the next five years as a result of a substantial victory for Col. Fidel Sanchez Hernandez in yesterday's presidential election.
MACAO, March 6 (AP)-- Macao newspapers reported today that Portguese officials had returned four more Chinese refugees to Communist China over the weekend.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- The Securities and Exchange Commission formally warned brokers and investors today that a British mutual fund is being sold in this country without fulfillment of American registration and disclosure requirements.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 7 (AP)--A fire spread rapidly through a slum area of Saigon along the city's riverfront today and destroyed more than 1,000 tin and wooden homes, killing three children and leaving thousands of Vietnamese homeless.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 6--Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller announced tonight that he would veto tomorrow a bill legalizing gambling at four private clubs at Hot Springs and that he would stamp out gambling in Arkansas.

Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin B. Braude of 201 East 28th Street have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Jane Claire Braude, to Dr. Donald Jerome Levine. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Levine of New York.
ROME, March 6--President Edward Ochab of Poland will pay an official visit to Italy from April 6 to 8 and will undoubtedly have an audience with Pope Paul VI.

PEORIA, Ill., March 6 (UPI) --Opposing lawyers reached tentative agreement today on a panel of four more jurors for the murder trial of Richard Speck. If their decision becomes firm, it would raise the total number of jurors selected to eight.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 6-- Governor Rockefeller said today that the state had asked the Federal Government for a $2.2-million demonstration grant to test methods of transporting low-income workers in Nassau and Suffolk Counties to jobs.

ONCE again, Ingmar Bergman is bringing us into contact with two strangely troubled women and exploring the sensitive movements of their minds in his new Swedish film, "Persona," which came to the Festival Theater yesterday. And once again he is inviting (or compelling) his public to engage in studious efforts at interpretation or simply outright involvement, of themselves, empathically and esthetically, and let the egos and ids fall where they may.

SEOUL, South Korea, March 6--The South Korean Government notified United States military authorities today of its intention to try in a Korean court an American airman accused of having set fire to a house and assaulted a taxi driver.

CHICAGO, March 6 (AP)-- Dr. David D. Henry, the spunky University of Illinois president, said today that he would fight to the end for retention of three coaches linked to illegal payments to athletes.

BETHESDA, Md., March 6-- Randolph L. Howard, an educator who retired in 1948 as foreign secretary of the American Baptist Mission Society in New York, died yesterday at Suburban Hospital. He was 83 years old and had formerly lived for 35 years in Rahway, N.J.

Reflecting the 17 per cent rise in earnings to a new high last year, directors of the CocaCola Company yesterday raised the quarterly dividend to 52 cents a share from 47 cents. COMPANIES ISSUE EARNINGS FIGURES
The Variety Merchandise Fair--an off-Broadway trade show in comparison with the Toy Show at the New Yorker and New York Hilton Hotels-- attracted several thousand buyers of its own yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- A citizens advisory group urged Congress today to strengthen the United States Information Agency for its task in a world that the group said had become "skeptical" on United States aims.

BAY HARBOR ISLAND, Fla.--Lucille Lortel, an Off Broadway producer who likes to be near the main stream but would rather not swim in it, preserves her customary way of life when she winters here. Her houseboat is anchored off Miami Beach.

WASHINGTON, March 6--James R. Hoffa today lost a crucial court appeal in his long battle to stay out of prison and was due to begin an eight-year sentence for jury tampering tomorrow. Imprisonment was assured for the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters after the Federal Court of Appeals here rejected his plea.

NEW ORLEANS, March 6-- District Attorney Jim Garrison came under sharp criticism from the American Civil Liberties Union of Louisiana today as his office subpoenaed a new "witness" in its investigation into the assassination of President Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- The State Department is expected to lift next week all restrictions on travel to Albania but to maintain controls over travel to Communist China and three other Communist nations.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- President Johnson's special representatives are studying the Central Intelligence Agency to see what changes, if any, should be made following the discovery that the agency had penetrated a number of private organizations while carrying out its work.
WASHINGTON, March 6-- The shortwave station that call itself Radio Free Harlem was on the air again today.

LAWRENCE, Kan., March 6 (UPI)--Kansas won its second consecutive Big Eight conference crown with a 66-59 victory over Colorado tonight and gained a berth in the National Collegiate regional tournament here.
ALBANY, March 6--Labor and business groups lined up today against the compulsory health insurance law proposed by Governor Rockefeller and the legislative leaders.

HAWTHORNE, N.Y., March 6--Patrick V. Ryan, former vice chairman of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors, died today of cancer at the Rosary Hill Home here. He was 62 years old and lived in Somers, N.Y.
GLASGOW, Scotland, March 3--The sound truck moves among the drab gray buildings of a public housing development, playing its resolute song:

BUDAPEST, March 6 (AP) --Zoltan Kodaly, one of the world's foremost composers, who incorporated Hungarian folk songs into his music, died in a hospital here today of a heart ailment. He was 84 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)--The Central Intelligence Agency is reported to be saying that the Soviet Union will fly a prototype of its supersonic passenger plane to they Paris International Air Show opening May 26.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy quickly declined yesterday the role of Democratic kingmaker in the state for 1968.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 6--"The creative part of baseball is improvising," says Ruben Amaro. "You must play the game as it happens, but you can prepare mentally for situations by thinking, and you can establish your rhythm by infield practice."

Despite a massive clearing of site and a wide variety of work already under way on $165million in contracts, the Lindsay administration contends that the $575-million World Trade Center project can still be halted --without Penalty to the city.
WORCESTER, Mass., March 6 (UPI)--Mel Massucco will resign as head football coach at Holy Cross on Wednesday to take a similar post at Worcester Polytechnic Institute, sources indicated today.

MINORITY stockholders of the South Shore Oil and Development Company are in open-rebellion over efforts by the Jim. Walter Corporation, the majority stockholder, to acquire the remaining 40 per cent of South Shore's common stock.
NEW DELHI, March 6 (AP)--Mobs hurled stones at policemen today in Jaipur, the capital of the state of Rajasthan, and were beaten back with tear gas and clubs.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, March 6 (AP)--The Supreme Court of Monaco today upheld Prince Rainer's moves to take control of the gambling casino and other tourist attractions of this Riviera principality.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 7--North Vietnamese forces staged two mortar attacks early today against longrange United States artillery that fires across the demilitarized zone into North Vietnam, the United States command reported.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 6--University and high school student groups opposed to President Sukarno rallied 15,000 supporters here today to repeat their denunciations of the President and demand that he be dismissed from his titular office and be tried on subversion and corruption charges.
ALBANY, March 6--Governor Rockefeller today called a special election for Tuesday, April 11, to fill the Congressional seat of Adam Clayton Powell.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 6 --Clarence C. Merritt, a retired real estate broker, architect and appraiser, died today in Suffolk County Hospital, He was 84 years old and lived at 52 Lilac Lane in Westhampton Beach.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 6 --Bobby Bragan is a compulsive conversationalist, but he found his powers of speech bumping into a rude wall of silence during his first four months as manager of the Atlanta Braves last season. A couple of his coaches were not on speaking terms with him during that period. Many of his players talked to him only when they had to and Eddie Mathews didn't talk to him at all.

Mr. and Mrs. Howard Wales Hiscock of Toronto have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Hiscock, to Robert Coleman Trump, son of Mrs. Harry William Trump of Circleville, Ohio, and the late Mr. Trump. A June 10 wedding is planned.

ATLANTA, March 6--Attornies for the American Liberties Union have filed suit here in United States District Court asking for a halt in the military draft in Georgia and South Carolina until Negroes are proportionately represented on draft boards.
BONN, March 6--A West German spokesman said today that the way had been cleared for a solution of problems related to meeting the foreign exchange costs of the 225,000 American troops in Germany.
A New Jersey trucker drove up to the main gate of the sparkling new New York City Terminal at Hunts Point, the Bronx, at 12:02 A.M. yesterday, with a 35-ton trailer jammed with sacks of onions.

WHITE PLAINS, March 6-- Westchester County welfare workers, who have been staying away from their jobs and calling in sick since Wednesday, ignored an ultimatum that they return today or face dismissal.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 (AP)--Manager Wes Westrum of the New York Mets said today he hoped to trade one of his surplus outfielders for a left-handed starting pitcher.
WASHINGTON, March 6--A new type of spacecraft has for the first time changed its plane of orbit and flown to the earth's surface like an airplane, the Air Force said today.
Gerald A. Hoyt was appointed yesterday as a vice president of the Western Union Telegraph Company and as a special assistant to Russell W. McFall, chairman and president.

Edward Albee is adapting a British satire for Broadway. "Everything in the Garden," by Giles Cooper, was the first experimental offering by the Royal Shakespeare Company in 1962. Later it ran in London's West End.

The engagement of Miss Carol Sue Bruland to Benjamin James Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Frederick Allen of Leicester, England, has been annnounced by the future bride's parents, Mr, and Mrs. John R. Bruland of Balboa, C.Z. A June 16 wedding in Wellesley, Mass., is planned.

A report by United States Government and academic experts has found that Communist China's economy has lost much ground in the nineteensixties, and that the prospects for substantial improvement in the years immediately ahead are poor.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- The Pentagon has decided to provide new planes armed with machine guns and rockets for the few hundred Air Force pilots in Vietnam who now fly reconnaissance missions over guerrilla positions in unarmed, single-engine Cessnas.
The University of California, Los Angeles, undefeated in 25 games, was voted the nation's top collegiate basketball team today in the final major polls.

PEKING, March 6--Informed East European sources said today that Premier Chou En-lai, assisted by a small "working group," had assumed control of China's governmental, Communist party and military affairs, as well as the guidance of the Cultural Revolution.

A physician who was dismissed Friday from his $22,500a-year post as chief of cardiology at the Brooklyn-Cumberland Medical Center after organizing a physicians' group to challenge hospital policies has filed charges of unfair labor practices with the State Labor Relations Board.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 6--President Johnson announced today in a special message to Congress that he intended to establish by Jan. 1, 1969, a kind of lottery that would determine which young men were drafted for military service.

ATHENS, March 6--An Athens court of appeals dismissed charges of subversion against Christopher Nikolopoulos, 47-year-old Greek-American today. Mr. Nikolopoulosis the New York correspondent of the Athens pro-Communist daily Avghi. His acquittal came after a summary trial.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6--Edward Emil Kranepool is the only licensed stockbroker and the only licensed first baseman with the New York Mets. So everybody in spring training naturally is besieging him for information about the state of the Mets' economy.

BALTIMORE, March 6 (UPI) Pimlico opened its winter meeting in the rain today with a crowd of 11,188 on hand to watch Misty's Baby draw off in the last sixteenth of a mile to win the $6,000 feature race by two lengths after a head-tohead battle with Garden Clubber.

MIAMI, Fla., March 6--Three old ladies of the offshore set were kicking their heels joyously today and faring well as 74 yachts began the annual MiamiNassau race, which is next to last on the Southern Ocean Racing Conference championship program.

BRUSSELS, March 6--Informed sources said today that American reviews of control procedures with the European Atomic Energy Comunnity were at the root of delays Euratom has faced in getting more plutonium from the United States.
WAYNE, N.J., March 6 (AP) --The Wayne Clergy Fellowship voted today to accept a Township Council request calling on it to act as a human relations commission.

The removal of a colonel as head of news services for the United States Army in Europe because he allowed publication in the service paper Stars and Stripes of a news item on the arrest of an Ambassador's son is a disheartening example of military obtuseness.

Gennadi Rozhdestvensky, the Soviet conductor who is in New York to conduct the London Symphony Orchestra for his compatriot Mstislav Rostropovich in a series of cello concerto programs, took on an extra assignment this week.
LONDON, March 6 (AP)--A prominent left-winger assailed Prime Minister Wilson and his policies tonight, adding to the strife in the Labor party.

WHITEHORSE, Yukon--The gold dredges on the Klondike River finally stopped last year, and the metal production that made the Yukon famous has fallen to its lowest level since the gold rush era of 1898.

The Synagogue Council of America and the Episcopal Church's Committee on JewishChristian Dialogue concluded a pioneering two-day conference here yesterday on mutual problems.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 6--A Vietcong mine exploded under a cross-country bus 42 miles northwest of Saigon today, killing 37 South Vietnamese civilians and wounding 15 others.
A husband hurled a gallon of gasoline at his wife yesterday, then threw a lighted match at her, setting her afire and burning her critically, the police said.

KENTON, Ohio, March 6 (AP) Thirty-eight bodies lined the gymnasium floor in an unused schoolhouse at nearby Marseilles today as investigators going over a snow-covered soybean field tried to determine the cause of Lake Central Airlines's first fatal crash.
WASHINGTON, March 6-- The Treasury bill rate dropped today to its lowest point since the move to higher interest rates began with Federal Reserve actions in early December, 1965.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- The Administration is hoping to send Congress its formal proposal for merger of the Commerce and Labor Departments within two weeks, but meanwhile it keeps getting suggestions for expanding the merged department to include more agencies and programs.

The New York Knickerbockers will play their last regularseason game against a Western Division team of the National Basketball Association tonight when they oppose the Los Angeles Lakers at Madison Square Garden.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 6--Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare John W. Gardner has told President Johnson that a major vaccination drive may eliminate common measles from the United States this year.
IN Helen Brooks's office at 100 West 42d Street is a baby-blue sign with black letters that says: "Marriages are made in Heaven. I am only His agent."

WASHINGTON, March 6-- Dr. James R. Killian Jr., Chairman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Corporation, gave strong support today to National Educational Television as the logical group to direct a national TV news service for noncommercial stations.
BRUSSELS, March 6--A subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) has become enmeshed, through no fault of its own, in the age-old Belgian linguistic controversy.

DETROIT, March 6--The nation's leading auto makers told the Federal Government today that its safety rule governing passenger protection from crash injury was impossible to meet in time to include on 1968 models.

STARKVILLE, Miss., March 6 (AP)--Tennessee won the Southeastern Conference basketball championship and a National Collegiate tournament berth tonight with a 78-76 triple-overtime victory over Mississippi State.

The Right Rev. James A. Pike urged the Episcopal Church yesterday to eliminate the requirement that either the Nicene Creed or the Apostles' Creed, the most universally accepted statements of Christian orthodoxy, be recited at all celebrations of the Holy Communion.

GENEVA, March 6--West Germany has offered conditionally to sign an international agreement under which it would remove any time limit on the prosecution for murder of war criminals and persons guilty of crimes against humanity.
PITTSBURGH, March 6 (AP) --The Philadelphia 76ers tied a National Basketball Association record tonight by gaining their 62d victory of the season, a 119-117 triumph over the Los Angeles Lakers.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Tuesday, March 7 (AP)--"We're on strike," a United Automobile Workers local officer said early today while a General Motors Corporation information source was saying that work was going on at the company's Fisher Body Division plant here.
ADEN, March 6 (UPI)--An explosion, apparently caused by saboteurs, ripped open an American-owned oil pipeline here today, spilling thousands of gallons of oil ito the sea.
The admission of Lloyd A. Doughty and Sheldon Fox as general partners of the architectural firm of Kahn Jacobs has been announced by Robert A. Jacobs, head of the firm.
LONDON, March 7 (Reuters) --Leaders of Britain's 200,000 Congregationalists and 70,000 Presbyterians unanimously proposed today a merger of the two churches.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 6 (UPI)--Hank Aaron, who has had difficulty getting his timing at the plate this spring, got in the groove today in a lengthy Atlanta Braves batting drill.

At 10 o'clock this morning, 19 men are scheduled to gather around a 30-foot mahogany table at the Federal Reserve Board in Washington.
