A statewide campaign to prevent any change in the New York State constitutional prohibition of public aid to parochial schools was opened yesterday by 15 major civic, educational and religious organizations.

A committee appointed by the president of St. John's University has recommended that the institution's entire Brooklyn center be phased out and that all future buildings be placed on the main campus in Jamaica, Queens.

Speaking in Fulton, Mo., where Winston Churchill fired some of the opening shots of the cold war 21 years ago, Vice President Humphrey now envisages "replacement of the Iron Curtain by the open door."

ST. LOUIS, March 6 (UPI)-- Buddy Campbell of Paramount, Calif., and Sallie Blatchford of Northbrook, Ill., were crowned new champions yesterday in the senior men and senior women divisions in the United States open ice-skating championships.

STANFORD, Calif., March 6 --John Ewart Wallace Sterling, president of Stanford University, and Mrs. Sterling have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Robinson Sterling, to Frank Patrick Morse, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Dayton Morse of Los Angeles. A June wedding at Stanford Memorial Church is planned.

William J. McDonald, senior vice president of the Wendell P. Colton division of Wesley Advertising, Inc., died yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 74 years old on Saturday and lived at 1045 Park Avenue.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 6--Gov. Ronald Reagan's administration is "not about to lie down and play dead" to pressures from Washington and from conservation groups for creation of a Redwoods National Park. This word is from the Governor's new director of resources.
"The Joey Bishop Show," the American Broadcasting Company's entry into the late-night, talk-show field, will be produced live in California, it was announced yesterday.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Friday the level it reached on Thursday, which was 101.

LONDON, March 6--Twentythree Armenian Gospel manuscripts, reported to be worth as much as $1.4-million, are to return to the Armenian cathedral in the Jordanian sector of Jerusalem instead of being put up for auction here next week.

MIAMI BEACH, March 6 (AP)--Eddie Gagnon of Somerset, Mass., rolled a 682 series in the American Bowling Congress tournament today and took first place in the regular singles. The 19-year-old Gagnon posted games of 225, 210 and 247. Yesterday's leader, Jack Engstrom of Rantoul, Ill., fell to second, Engstrom had 661.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 6 (UPI)--Bailey Howell scored 38 points tonight as the Boston Celtics routed the Detroit Pistons, 127-103, for their ninth victory in a row at Rhode Island Auditorium.
ROCKFORD, Ill., March 6-- A smirking, swaggering, 17year-old youth was charged today with the execution-style murders of two 14-year-old Rockford boys.

The spot rate on the British pound improved moderately in quiet dealings yesterday on foreign exchange markets here. The final spot quotation of $2,7946 was four points ahead of the closing rate on Friday.
The United States will open the 1967 Davis Cup tennis campaign against the British Caribbean in a match that must be completed by May 1.

Describing himself as "innocent as the babes in the woods," the ousted chief steward of the State Harness Racing Commission said yesterday that he would sign a waiver of immunity and testify before the Nassau County grand jury investigating the sport.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- Nations complaining of a "brain drain" need to improve their own political and economic conditions to keep their talent at home, Government witnesses told a Senate subcommittee today.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, March 6 (UPI)--The skipper of a Russian fishing vessel was found guilty today and was fined $5,000 for violating United States territorial waters off the Alaska coast.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 6--Britain took sharp exception today to a resolution offered by African and Arab countries criticizing the limited self-government granted six small British territories in the West Indies.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 6--The table below shows the order in which draft boards now summon men for induction from among eligible registrants and how the White House says the draft system would work after the President's new orders would go into effect Jan. 1, 1969:
Bert Lahr has resigned from The Lambs, the organization of people connected with the entertainment field, in a dispute over the club's annual show.

Ocean freight carriers will encounter a new challenge today when the United States Freight Company, the nation's biggest freight-forwarder system, inaugurates a "fishyback" rate designed to lower the transportation costs of small shippers to Europe.
LOS ANGELES, March 6-- Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation today was ordered to pay Shirley MacLaine $800,000 for a movie that was never made.
MOSCOW, March 6--Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin declared today that United States escalation of the Vietnamese war would bring retaliatory increases in Communist aid to North Vietnam.
Wheat futures went on a spree yesterday, increasing by as much as four cents a bushel during an active session. Prices were nipped later by profit taking, possibly from some surprised traders.
Mayor Lindsay reported yesterday that negotiations were under way to bring "a gigantic corporation" to the city. He said he expected to be able to announce the move within a few weeks.
New York's two United States Senators discussed the pressures on young people here yesterday in separate appearances before groups concerned with education.

The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation and the True Temper Corporation have held preliminary merger talks. The deal probably would be effected by issuing Allegheny stock to True Temper shareholders, the companies stated yesterday.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 6 (AP)--Oscar Robertson scored 12 points and made four assists in the final period tonight to lead the Cincinnati Royals to a 129-122 National Basketball Association victory over the St. Louis Hawks.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 6--The table below shows the kinds of draft deferments or exemptions available today and those that the White House says would be available after the President's new orders go into effect:

Henry T. Blair, a retired economist, stockbroker and business executive who was known for entertaining widely here, died Sunday night in the Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 79 years old and had lived at the New Weston Hotel.

A former firehouse in Queens and two parcels of vacant land on Water Street in lower Manhattan are among 131 surplus properties that will be offered at auction by the Department Real Estate on March 16 at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Norma Jones, a violinist born and educated in London, made her New York debut at, Carnegie Recital Hall last night. She is the wife of Ruben Varga, the violinist, and has lived in New York for three years.

The "extremely important peace initiative" mentioned by Premier Kosygin was, according to Johnson Administration sources, the offer to begin peace negotiations if the United States agreed to cease its bombing of North Vietnam permanently.
ROCKY HOLLOW, Ala., March 6 (UPI)--Tornadoes roared through a dozen mountain communities in Northern Alabama tonight, bowling over huge pine trees and killing at least two persons.

"OH, I have no hair myself," Alba Armellei said, pulling off a blond hairpiece in her room at the Pierre Hotel. "Solo tre peli--one, two, three hairs," she added, in virtually the only English she knows. She actually has a full head of short hair, to which she attaches a long...

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 (UPI)--Searchers found debris today in the Gulf of Mexico near where a Coast Guard plane was missing with six men aboard. The HU-1 6-E amphibian plane disappeared while on a rescue mission last night. Search operations were hampered by fog.

MIAMI BEACH, March 6 (AP)--Nelson Eddy, the deepthroated baritone who thrilled a generation of movie-goers 25 years ago singing the romantic songs of Sigmund Romberg and Victor Herbert with Jeanette MacDonald, died at Mount Sinai Hospital here today a few hours after being stricken during a nightclub show at the Sans Souci Hotel. He was 65 years old.
THE North American team for the World Champion ships to be played in Miami Beach in May is an unsatisfactory one for some bridge journalists.
ALBANY, March 6--The Republican majority in the State Senate passed a "no sock" bill today that would make it a misdemeanor for a citizen to resist an unlawful arrest.

SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY has 18,000 un- dergraduates at its Carbondale, Ill., campus. There are 7,000 more at the university's Edwardsvilie, Ill., campus 100 miles from Carbondale, S.I.U. ranked 20th in student body size among the nation's colleges last year.
NATCHEZ, Miss., March 6 (UPI)--Wharlest Jackson, civil rights worker, was buried during a rainstorm today, a week after he was killed by a bomb planted in his pickup truck.
LONDON, March 6 (AP)-- Richard M. Nixon discussed the European alliance in a half-hour meeting today with Prime Minister Wilson.
No strike is likely in the domestic copper industry when most labor contracts expire next June 30, according to Joseph Zimmerman, vice president of the Miles Metal Corporation.
American public schools have been found to rank low in an international comparison of pupils' achievements in mathematics, and Japan's schools to be doing "the best over-all job" in that field.
It's give-to-the-arts-time in 12 cities where the man who once gave for something separately now gives to everything at once, and gives more, too.
WASHINGTON, March 6-- More than $50-million that was appropriated last fall to put the hard core jobless of the big cities to work is still awaiting the completion of planning and other paper work.
Industrial issues closed mixed yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 (UPI)--David Ben-Gurion, first Prime Minister of Israel, laid a wreath today at the monument to six million Jewish victims of the Hitler regime before addressing the dinner opening the 1967 Allied Jewish Appeal campaign here.

No. 3 on the nonfiction bestseller list frowned across the elegant reception room at the Pierre Hotel yesterday evening, fixing his gaze on No. 1. "I Won't even go say hello to that lovely Cornelia Otis Skinner," George Plimpton said.
William H. Deacy, an architect who specialized in memorials, died Sunday at the Holly Well Nursing Home in Randolph, Mass. He was 77 years old and lived on Revolutionary Road in Scarborough, N.Y.
TRENTON, March 6--The State Supreme Court held today that a defective child's right to life was greater than the wish of his parents to employ an abortion to keep him from being born.

THE Manhattan Festival Ballet has this season established itself as a very real asset to the New York dance scene. Its regular Monday nights, at the excellent Theater 80 on St. Marks Place, have a spirit of their own that is both amiable and enthusiastic. Last night this chamber dance company offered its sixth program, which included a new production of John Taras's "Designs With Strings."

Converting the Central Park reservoir into a recreational facility for boating and swimming is a long way off, it was indicated yesterday by August Heckscher, who will become Parks Commissioner on March 15.

St. John's University proposed yesterday impartial arbitration to settle the 15-month-old controversy over its dismissal of 29 faculty members. The offer represented the university's first major effort to resolve the dispute, which has endangered the academic accreditations of the Roman Catholic institution.

WASHINGTON, March 7--A Senate subcommittee was told today that Soviet military technicians had "honeycombed" Cuba with underground sites for offensive missiles, aircraft hangars, ammunition dumps and even military hospitals.
Stocks turned around yesterday and rose moderately on the American Stock Exchange.
WOOSTER, Ohio, March 7-- Dr. Wilson Martindale Compton, former president of the State College of Washington now Washington State University, died today at his home here. He was 76 years old.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 7--The Government of Northern Ireland moved today to prevent new clashes between Irish Republicans and extreme Protestants led by the Rev. Ian Paisley.

ALBANY, March 7--The bill to liberalize the state's abortion law was killed today by a legislative committee. Thus ended the waiting over the fate of what was probably the most controversial and least-likely-to-pass measure of the 1967 session.

Negotiations are under way in London for Peter O'Toole and Zero Mostel to co-star on Broadway next season in "Staircase." Charles Dyer's play has been a success since it opened in London in November with Paul Scofield and Patrick Magee in the roles.
MAPLEWOOD, N.J., March 7--Carl William Barget Sr., former president of the New Jersey Retired Educators Association, died yesterday at his home, 15 Maple Terrace. He was 77 years old.
Geer, DuBois Co., has created a series of six ads for Argus Research Corporation, the investment advisory concern, all of which picture only hands.

YONKERS, March 7--Mr. and Mrs. E. Prescott Barker of Yonkers and East Orleans, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Barker, to Robert Allan Gibson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James O. Gibson of East Orleans.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., March 7 (AP)--Trenton State defeated the defending champion, Monmouth College, 63-60, tonight in the final of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics District 31 basketball playoffs.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- Democratic leaders have shelved a controversial proposal that would have established a quota system to insure Negro representation at the party's national convention in 1968.

PARIS--From the moment it became clear in early 1949 that Mao Tse-tung's armies would soon engulf all mainland China, U.S. policy was postulated on an inevitable dispute between Mao's regime and its ideological sponsor, Russia. State Department experts developed a theory that inherently nationalist forces would ultimately dominate the new China and create a movement regarded by Moscow as heretical and, therefore, quite as unfriendly to Russia as to America.

ONE of the finest collections of wine and food memorabilia ever displayed in the United States is the "Bread and Wine" exhibition that opens to the public today at the Hallmark Gallery, 56th Street and Fifth Avenue. It is an awesome grouping that emphasizes the almost spiritual exaltation and adoration accorded bread and wine since the innovation of vats and ovens.
Five young men, each clutching a handful of papers, sat nervously yesterday on wooden chairs in the reception room on the ninth floor of 321 West 44th Street.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 7--North Vietnamese gunners continued their mortar attacks today on an American artillery position near the demilitarized zone.
ROME, March 7--The Vatican explained today that a recent Roman Catholic Church document on sacred music limited the role of popular music in the mass.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- Senator Jacob K. Javits proposed today a broad program of Federal guarantees and tax incentives to turn ghetto tenements into livable housing.
WASHINGTON, March 7 --The Treasury Department auctioned $2.7-billion of June tax-anticipation bills today at an average discount rate of 4.295 per cent.

BIMINI, the Bahamas, March 7--Floyd McKissick, executive director of the Congress of Racial Equality, flew here today to confer with Adam Clayton Powell and lawyers representing the embattled Harlem leader.
NEW DELHI, March 7--At least six persons were killed today when the police opened fire on a crowd protesting alleged political discrimination in Jaipur, the capital of Rajasthan state.

WASHINGTON, March 7-- McGeorge Bundy, president of the Ford Foundation, asserted today that these were no seeds of "big brotherism" in the fund's plan to offer instructional TV programing on a nationwide network basis.
The Marine Midland Grace Trust Company of New York has elected Otmar George as a vice president of the International banking department, George C. Textor, chairman, announced yesterday.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7--The New York Mets suffered their first rainout of the season today, but Casey Stengel dropped out of the sky like Santa Claus just in time to take up the slack.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- North Vietnam is using a restricted zone about 25 miles deep along the Chinese border as a daytime sanctuary for truck convoys, informed military sources said today.

Republican leaders announced yesterday, that James H. Meredith, one of the most prominent Negro civil rights activists in the nation, would run against Democrat Adam Clayton Powell in a special Congressional election. The voting is scheduled for April 11.
HONG KONG, March 7-- Peking has signaled the end of an important phase of the Cultural Revolution by instructing the primary and secondary schools to reopen.
DETROIT, March 7--Under strong pressure from United Auto Workers headquarters here, wildcat strikers at a key Ohio plant of the General Motors Corporation trickled back to their jobs this afternoon.

The New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad Company has asked the United States District Court of New Jersey to award it damages of $4.8 million together with interests and costs against Seatrain Lines, Inc.

In the summer of 1961 the new Minnesota Vikings played a preseason game against the Baltimore Colts. The Viking quarterback was Francis Tarkenton, a skinny, 21-year-old son of a Methodist minister from Athens, Ga. He was just two months out of the University of Georgia, and his coach, Norm Van Brocklin, suspected Francis was "too nice."

BRUSSELS, March 7--The six Common Market countries will roughly double their import quotas for cotton textiles over the next three years in a move aimed at helping developing countries, such as India and Pakistan.
GREAT art, happily, makes hucksters of us all, which must be regarded as my contribution toward a thought for the month. Last night at the Mark Hellinger Theater...

THE SOLDIER'S ART. By Anthony Powell. 228 pages. Little, Brown, $4.95. A MODERN Chekhov would only need a scene in a wartime London cafe and one at a British junior officers' mess to turn "The Soldier's Art" into a superb play.

KINGSTON, N.J., March 7-- Mr. and Mrs. Peter Geoffrey Cook of Kingston and Wiscasset, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Paula Cook, to Frederick Jessup Kahrl, son of Prof. and Mrs. George Morrow Kahrl of Elmira, N.Y. and Georgetown, Me.

An ironworker wearing a welder's mask mounted a ladder at Bellevue Hospital yesterday and applied an acetylene torch to the top of an iron door frame in a surgical ward, showering silvery sparks like a Fourth of July sparkler.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 7--The United States and Britain protested today the "suppression" of private reports to the United Nations Special Committee on Colonialism accusing the United Arab Republic of gas warfare in Arabia.

A short, potent and lavishly pianistic program was played at Town Hall last night by Lucien Leinfelder, a member of the piano faculty of the University of Missouri. He began with Ravel's "Gaspard de la Nuit," followed it with Barber's Sonata, and ended with Chopin's Four Ballades.

For his sixth Carnegie Hall concert with the London Symphony Orchestra, Mstislav Rostropovich, the 39-year old Soviet cellist, invited 21-year-old Itzhak Perlman to join him in a performance of the Brahms Concerto in A minor for Violin and Cello.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 7--American officials are urging the South Vietnamese Government to use greater vigor in the investigation of charges that its special anticorruption court has been soliciting bribes.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 7-- Jacnot Stable's Sermon made a charge in the final strides to overtake Biggs and win the $29,700 San Bernardino Handicap today. The favored Saber Mountain ran a surprising last in the Santa Anita feature.

CHICAGO, March 7 (UPI)-- The Chicago Bulls, leading at every quarter, beat the Boston Celtics tonight for the first time since they joined the National Basketball Association, 117-114, and ended a nine-game Celtics' winning streak.
MOGADISCIO, Somalia, March 3--The Republic of Somalia, in trouble with her nieghbors and faced with the threat of war, is showing signs of trying to reduce the tensions in this part of Africa.

Mechanical trouble on a northbound subway train at the 14th Street station of the IND-Sixth Avenue line tied up operations on that line for more than an hour yesterday between the West Fourth Street station and the 50th Street station.

President Johnson has set forth with great clarity all the reasons why the military draft must be made more equitable, but his message to Congress shows a puzzling absence of insistence on swift action to get rid of the unfairness.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) --Senate and House conferees reached a compromise today on a bill that would authorize $4.5billion for more aircraft, missiles and related activities for the fighting forces in Vietnam.
Meyer Kupferman's "Infinuities 13" (1965) was given its first New York performance last night in the Aeolian Chamber Players' concert at Carnegie Recital Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 7-- The National Traffic Safety Agency was urged today to recommend that auto manufacturers voluntarily redesign the front ends of future models to provide greater protection for pedestrians.

WASHINGTON, March 7-- Nicholas Johnson, newest member of the Federal Communications Commission, accused the majority of the regulatory agency today of adopting a "complacent and comfortable hear-no-evil, see-no-evil slouch in front of the radio and television sets of America."

Bennett Cerf, chairman of Random House, raconteur and panelist on the "What's My Line?" television show, found himself yesterday under attack by a roomful of editors and critics when he pleaded for more newspaper space for books.
British Government bonds edged up slightly yesterday in an otherwise trendless session on the London Stock Exchange.

MADRID, March 7--Dr. John Corominas, professor of Romance languages at the University of Chicago, was released on parole early today after having spent three days in a Barcelona jail for his attendance at a Catalonian nationalists' meeting.
Time, Inc. announced yesterday that it would build an office skyscraper in Chicago for its subscription service division.

The snowstorm that hit the Eastern seaboard Monday night forced the cancellation yesterday of the National Collegiate college-divisional regional basketball playoffs at American International College in Springfield, Mass.
The National Broadcasting Company carried a radio report from a correspondent in Peking at noon yesterday.
WASHINGTON--Shopping on Capitol Hill is like shopping at the corner store in a small town. Greta Garbo wouldn't like it.
GRATANGEN, Norway, March 6--Pfc. Charles E. Carroll of Miami saw snow for the first time in his 20 years last month at the Marine Corps Mountain Warfare Training Center in California's Sierra Madre.

ROCKFORD, Ill., March 7-- The wife of a youth who was charged here yesterday with the execution-style murders of two boys said today that at the time of the crime the acused youth was having a hamburger with her.
CHICAGO, March 7 (AP)--A former convict who testified against his associates in two criminal trials was ambushed and slain today.

WASHINGTON, March 7-- Jimmy Hoffa's friends and enemies knew he soon would be sent to prison after the Supreme Court rejected his appeal last December from a jury tampering conviction of 1964. But many refused to...
ADEN, March 7--Sheikhan al Habshi, secretary general of the South Arabian League, escaped with minor injuries in two bomb attacks on him today in the back streets of the district of Maala.
Cooper Union announced plans yesterday for a new academic building on the south side of Astor Place, across Fourth Avenue from the landmark Foundation Building, the school's headquarters.

WASHINGTON, March 7 --A bill that would make the first significant reforms in Congressional procedures in 20 years was passed today by the Senate after more than six weeks of debate. The vote was 75 to 9.
LEWISBURG, Pa., March 7 --A shaken but defiant James R. Hoffa was hustled today into the snowswept Federal penitentiary here to begin an eight-year sentence for jury tampering.
Eight railroads serving the Great Lakes area were accused yesterday of attempting to capture a 55 million ton annual traffic market through illegal means from steamship carriers.

WASHINGTON, March 7-- The Administration pressed its case today for Senate consent to a space treaty, only to be confronted by suggestions that "reservations" be added to clarify "fuzzy" language, in the treaty.
For a while the Columbia Broadcasting System had Marshal Matt Dillon tied to a tree. But a cavalry troop of network officials saved him just in time.
At Lincoln Center tonight: Fortunato Arico, cellist, and John Atkins, pianist, LibraryMuseum, 6:30; "Die Zauberflote," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "Il Trittico," New York City Opera, State Theater, 8:15.

Last August, at the height of the Federal Reserve's credit squeeze, "an atmosphere of impending crisis" developed in the financial community, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday in its annual report for 1966. "Some observers," the bank said, "even saw the threat of financial panic."
Stock prices brightened yesterday afternoon and finished slightly up on balance.
Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., announced yesterday a new bid to increase its holdings in Austin, Nichols Co., the liquor importer and distributor.
The crusade to reform the state's cruel and archaic abortion law cannot be abandoned, despite the decision of the Assembly's Codes Committee--meeting behind closed doors--to abort the reform bill.

Returned from Texas ranch; made presentation of Federal Women's Awards; received the Alexander Graham Bell Award for distinguished service to the deaf; lunched with Secretary of State Rusk, Defense Secretary McNamara and special assistants Rostow and Christian.

ARNOLD SCAASI took his fashion show on the road before opening in New York yesterday. He gave women in San Francisco, Los Angeles, Dallas, Pittsburgh, Chicago and Palm Beach a chance to order his custom designs in hotel rooms in those cities before his local customers could see them in his beige salon on 56th Street.
New York City received permission yesterday to exempt 1.7-million residents and commuters from filing tax returns on their income or earnings.

BOSTON, March 7--Boston University overcame a firstperiod deficit to defeat Harvard 6-2, in the opening round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference hockey playoffs tonight before 3,000 fans at Boston Garden.
Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell announced last night that he was setting up 13 "community crime prevention offices" in the borough and a crime prevention bureau in his own office.

WASHINGTON, March 7-- Dr. Robert R. Wilson, professor of physics at Cornell University, has been appointed director of the national accelerator laboratory scheduled to be built at Weston, Ill., at a cost of $395-million.
ALBANY, March 7--A bill that would authorize New York City to develop a new uniform Housing Code was passed today in the State Senate.

GREAT NECK, L.I., March 7--Oscar Shaw, a musical comedy, screen and radio star of the nineteen-twenties and thirties, died yesterday at Deepdale Hospital, Little Neck, Queens. He was 76 years old and lived at 10 Welwyn Road here.
Three New York women will be honored by the national women's division of the American Jewish Cqngress on March 20 at a benefit luncheon in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom.

Precipitation in many forms--rain, snow, freezing rain and sleet--descended on the eastern third of the nation yesterday in a storm that created hazards, discomforts and quirks from Birmingham to Boston.

Although J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., has recently noted improved demand in some areas of its business, "it cannot be said at this time that there has been any general revival in market activity," Robert T. Stevens, president and chief executive officer, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
Soil blowing in windstorms is bad news for wheat growers at this time of year because it stems from too little moisture at a crucial period.
NEW DELHI, March 7--India is seeking joint action against aspects of the proposed treaty to ban the spread of nuclear weapons that she feels would discriminate against nonnuclear nations.
TOKYO, March 7--President Sukarno's wife Ratna Sari Dewi gave birth to a girl weighing about eight pounds at the Keio University Hospital today, a hospital spokesman announced.

HALLANDALE, Fla. March 7 (AP)--Jorge Velasquez, leading rider at Tropical Park this season and runner-up at Hialeah, rode four winners at Gulfstream Park today to take over first place with seven winners in three days.

Dave Stallworth, a 25-year old forward of the New York Knickerbockers, was hospitalized yesterday with a heart attack, first suffered last Saturday in Fresno, Calif. Whether he will be able to play basketball again remains in doubt, and in any case he won't play any more this season.

NASSAU, The Bahamas, March 7--Escapade, the big old blue sloop that finished first last year as a yawl before being converted, was first to finish again today in the race from Miami to this island. But that was where the similarity of her performances in 1966 and 1967 ended.
Successor, the colt voted most likely to succeed in this year's Triple Crown events, is due to arrive at Belmont Park today after a van ride from Florida. He left Miami early yesterday morning.

SPEONK, L.I,, March 7--A father whose 8-year-old son was nipped more than 300 times last week by three dogs has decided against subjecting the boy to the pain and possible danger of antirabies inoculations.

The City Investigation Department has completed an investigation of "special duty" payments to nurses at Coney Island Hospital and has found no evidence of fraud. However, the payments--$39 a shift, as against $26 for regular ward duty--were ordered discontinued as unwarranted.
Special Committee on Colonialism--Debated report by committee on petition rejecting circulation of South African petition.

WINCHESTER, Mass., March 7--Prof. and Mrs. Norman J. Padelford have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Padelford, to David A. Karns, son of Mr. and Mrs. Virgil P. Karns of Grand Rapids, Mich.
The spot rate on the British pound continued firm in moderate trading yesterday on foreign exchange markets here. The closing rate of $2,7947 was one point ahead of Monday's final spot quotation.

PARIS, March 7--The French Communist party and leaders of the non-Communist left forged a single slate of candidates today to oppose the Gaullists in Sunday's runoff election for the National Assembly.
FLORENCE, Italy, March 7 --There is nothing basically wrong with Florence today, four months after the city's disastrous flood, that a million and a half tourists could not fix.

BONN, March 7--The Fried. Krupp Company, one of West Germany's largest privately owned industrial complexes, agreed today to become a publicly held corporation in return for the Federal Government's underwriting of a $75-million export finance guarantee.

ANITA TAYLOR of London and Sierra (Smokey) Drolet of Miami, backed by an all-girl pit crew, will drive a car in the 12-hour international endurance contest at Sebring, Fla., on April 1. Miss Taylor, recently married to Jim Matthews, an English racing star, is England's leading...
Economists are calling on the Johnson Administration to change its current business forecast and the economic policies that are based on it.
Directors of Pan American World Airways decided yesterday to ask stockholders to authorize a 2-for-1 stock split.
Paramount Pictures' "Hurry Sundown," produced and directed by Otto Preminger, yesterday was given a condemned, or "C," rating by the National Catholic office for Motion Pictures.

HOLLYWOOD, March 7 (AP) --Kenneth Harlan, a screen actor of the silent era who worked with D.W. Griffith and other film pioneers, died last night at Sutter Memorial Hospital in Sacramento at the age of 71. He had entered the hospital Sunday for abdominal surgery and then suffered an aneurysm, or ballooning of a weakened blood vessel, friends said.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7--"The first thing I have to do this spring is revamp the bull pen," said Wes West- rum, the quiet-spoken manager of the New York Mets. "The Dodgers demonstrated last year how important relief pitching is. Phil Regan had a 14-and-1 record. If you take just a couple of victories away from him they couldn't have won despite Sandy Koufax. The importance of the bull pen is beyond estimation."
WASHINGTON, March 7-- The House Education Committee indicated today that it would look into the educational impact of proposed changes in the military draft.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- "I picked this out of the trashcan in the cellar of the Cannon House Office Building the other day," Representative Charles McC. Mathias Jr. told the House Rules Committee today as he held up a red, white and blue poster emblazoned with a...

The election, of Carlos L. Israels, a Manhattan lawyer, as president of United Hias Service took place yesterday at a meeting of the organization's board of directors at its world headquarters, 200 Park Avenue South.

Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz proposed here last night a two-year program of free public education for everybody 60 years old. The aim would be to make use of the experience that elderly citizens had accumulated and to equip them for service to their fellow men.

"GOOD evening, Mr. Smith. My name is Jack Riley. I'm a member of the sales staff of the Chicago district office of the Link-Belt Company, and I'd like to have a few minutes of your time to discuss our company."
WASHINGTON, March 7-- Congress was told today that many local school districts were more fearful of state control than of Federal control.
LONDON, March 7 (AP)-- The Soviet Union has bought its first British television program--a documentary about Wall Street.
The Carrier Corporation, a manufacturer of air conditioning equipment, announced yesterday in Syracuse the election of Walter Steitler and Ray A. Tritten as vice presidents.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- The Federal Government turned down today the controversial Brooklyn highway route that Mayor Lindsay said he envisioned as the base for a "linear city."
New Yorkers who buy soft drinks put out by Coca-Cola will have to pay higher prices for the beverages in the near future.
WHITEHORSE, Yukon-- Summer tourists to Alaska and the Yukon Territory are likely to regard the White Pass Yukon Railroad as a sort of Toonerville Trolley.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 7 --Theodore C. Sorensen, former special counsel to President Kennedy, declared here tonight that President Johnson would be following a "historical pattern" if he chose not to seek re-election next year.

WESTFIELD, N.J., March 7 --George J. Wilson Sr., legal counsel for the Continental Oil Company, New York, died today in Overlook Hospital, Summit, N.J. He was 44 years old and lived at 1716 Shackamaxon Drive.
No one has ever applied for a license to fire a cannon in New York City, so License Commissioner Joel J. Tyler has decided that cannon firing must not be a booming business.

Teachers and students at a Harlem school boycotted a morning performance of the New York Percussion Trio yesterday because the school principal said, "not enough attention is given in the schools to African culture."
Early last year, British Petroleum made a deal with the British Gas Council to bring ashore at least 50 million cubic feet of gas a day by July 1, 1967.
OTTAWA, March 7--The Canadian Government was advised today to enter the space race or risk closing it control over domestic communications to the United States.
The appointment of Paul H. Shapiro as a vice president and voting stockholder was announced yesterday by Hayden, Stone, Inc., members of the New York Stock Exchange.
PERSIAN ROOM, The Plaza, Fifth Avenue at 59th Street, Sergio Franchi, Italian tenor.

A selection of early Walt Disney short subjects will be shown today and next Wednesday as a special feature of the program of animated movies current at the Museum of Modern Art. Continuing through March 19, the program is the second international round-up of animation to be presented by the museum in cooperation with the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.
MIAMI BEACH, March 7 (UPI)--A Miami-Dade Junior College student jumped into a tie for second place in the allevents division today at the American Bowling Congress tournament.

LONGHUU ISLAND, South Vietnam, March 7--Two battalions of American and South Vietnamese troops invaded this Vietcong-held island today. They killed no enemy soldiers and did not fire a shot, but unlike many an operation that has turned out to be a long, hot walk in the sun, today's assault far exceeded its planners' hopes.

"C.B.S, REPORTS" finally unveiled its long-awaited study on homosexuals last night. It was not the program originally planned more than two and a half years ago, which was said to stress the more sensational aspects of the gay life. It was more a sober, intelligent discussion of a growing social problem that only recently has reached the public forum.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., March 7--Long Island University's basketball team snapped Rochester's 10-game winning streak with a 85-76 victory tonight and advanced to tomorrow's championship game in the National Collegiate small-college regional tournament at Central Connecticut State here.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 7--The young pitcher looked very sharp at breakfast this morning, a fresh shave, a clean sports shirt, an unaccountably jaunty bounce to his step. He left 50 cents, twice the minimum, for the team dining room waiters, and scrounged an early car ride to the ball park.
KEY LARGO, Fla., March 7 --A good number of fishermen fly kites in this part of Florida while offshore looking for sailfish and other billfish.

Two "Harpo" betting syndicate members, convicted of giving false information to the Internal Revenue Service to conceal $300,000 in twin-double winnings at Yonkers Raceway in 1964, were sentenced yesterday in Federal Court to a year and a day in prison.

Anyone acquainted with American teen-agers will not find surprising the report that they lag behind students of other leading countries in knowledge of mathematics. But the consequences of that lag are likely to prove severe.

The engagement of Miss Carole Smoler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Smoler of Belle Harbor, Queens, to War ren N. Rodnick, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Rodnick of New Rochelle, N.Y., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.
PARIS, March 7--France lobbed a monkey named Martine into space briefly today to test her reactions to weightlessness.
BOSTON, March 7--A crowded rapid transit train slammed into the rear of another crowded train today during a storm that pelted New England with a mixture of snow, sleet and rain.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 7--Arthur J. Goldberg and Secretary General Thant met privately last night for an hour and a half to exchange views on the outlook for peace in Vietnam.
The Federal National Mortage Association plans to sell $900-million of participation certificates on March 22.
In a move to improve the public image of reinsmen, the newly-formed National Association of Harness Drivers has retained F. Lee Bailey of Boston as their attorney.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 7--General Suharto the defacto chief executive of Indonesia, defended President Sukarno today before the opening session of the Provisional People's Consultative Congress, which is meeting here to act...
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)--A battle among the giant airlines for a share of future traffic across the Pacific enters a crucial phase tomorrow.

DARIEN, Conn., March 7-- Steve Orthwein and Sandy Carden scored nine goals each as Yale overwhelmed the University of Virginia, 22-8, tonight in the semi-final round of the national intercollegiate polo championship, at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

WASHINGTON, March 7-- The precipitous decline in new orders for freight cars and locomotives, largely a result of the suspension last year of the 7 per cent investment tax credit, has surprised and worried the Government.

DENVER, March 6--The wide disparity between appearance and reality in the impact of a state arts council was the impression that emerged most strongly from last weekend's Colorado Conference on the Arts and Humanities.
LOS ANGELES, March 7 (AP)--Brig. Gen. Reese M. Howell, a much decorated World War II field commander, died Sunday at his home. He was 77 years old.
The furrows in Boom Boom Geoffrion's face conceal the scars but betray his age.
Seventeen men arrived at Gracie Mansion yesterday morning before 8:30 and hurried to a basement conference room for the weekly meeting of Mayor Lindsay's new "supercabinet."
To commemorate the 100th anniversary of the birth of Lillian D. Wald, pioneer public health nurse, Mayor Lindsay has proclaimed Friday Visiting Nurse Day here.

PARIS, March 7--Alice B. Toklas, the longtime friend of Gertrude Stein, who helped the late writer preside over a celebrated literary salon, died here early today. She was 89 years old, and had been ill for several years.
DETROIT, March 7 (AP) --Dave DeBusschere asked tonight to be relieved as coach of the Detroit Pistons of the National Basketball Association. He would continue as a player.

KINSHASA, The Congo, March 7--The Congolese Government has asked the Spanish Government to try to persuade Moise Tshombe to accept the offer of a free airplane ticket so that he can stand trial for high treason.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 8 (AP)-- Cases of plague were reported today in the area of the big United States air base and harbor installation at Camranh Bay about 180 miles northeast of Saigon.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy declared yesterday that the Vietnam situation has "changed drastically and dramatically" within the last month.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7-- Mrs. Newton Meade of Cynwyd, Pa., and Mrs. W. Pepper Constable of Princeton, N.J., recovered from a two-game deficit today to reach the semifinal round of the United States women's squash-racquets doubles championship. They scored an 11-15, 16-17, 15-11, 15-11, 15-11, victory over the team of Mrs. Donald Manly-Power and Mrs. John Newlin, former titleholders, at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Louis C. Gerstein of 99 Central Park West have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Abigail Susan Gerstein, to Dan Samuel Chill, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Chill of Miami.

Stocks brightened in the afternoon and closed up on average with special situation and glamour issues strongest; volume, 9.81 million shares. Corporate bonds eased in less active trading; transactions, $14.2 million.

Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman has been appointed by the board of trustees of Columbia University as counselor to Jewish students, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. John D. Cannon, the university chaplain.

TORONTO, March 7--The future of the Mercantile Bank of Canada, wholly owned subsidiary of the First National City Bank, New York, is up in the air again as a result of a split within the Canadian Cabinet over the treatment of United States investments.

WAYNE, Pa., March 7--Mr. and Mrs. Walter Y. Howson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Meredith Howson, to John Lyman Cox 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Cox of Bethlehem.

SEVEN members of American international teams in recent years make their living primarily by teaching bridge. The number has recently been increased to eight, because Ira Rubin of Paramus, N.J., has embarked on a considerable program of bridge teaching in the North Jersey area.
ALBANY, March 7--The State Judicial Conference warned today that a breakdown in the administration of justice "will become inevitable" unless the Legislature creates enough new judgeships.

Telford Taylor, professor or law at Columbia University, United States Army intelligence officer in World War II and chief counsel for the prosecution at the Nuremberg war-crime trials, has continued his study of the German army, which led to the volumes "Sword and Swastika" in 1952 and "The March of Conquest" in 1958.

PEKING, March 7, (Agence France-Presse)--The Peking press announced today the reopening of primary schools here and in Shanghai, apparently delayed by the condition of the buildings, the disappearance of both teachers and students, and, especially, by confusion over the new curriculum.
ALBANY, March 7--Governor Rockefeller said today that New York State needed $6.4-biliion to pay for its mass transportation requirements over the next five years.

Milton I. Shubert, theatrical producer and a nephew of the late Shubert brothers--Sam, Lee and J.J.--founders of the theatrical dynasty, died yesterday morning at the Bethesda Hospital in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 66 years old. He had been admitted to the hospital just a week ago after being stricken with a ruptured aneurysm (a dilation of a weakened blood vessel) while visiting the Boca Raton Club.
Two million children 12 years old and under are incapacitated each year by accident.

There was an ad last week in The Long Island Press that was made up of a collection of newspaper headlines of this type-- "Gas Blast Sparks Mile-Wide Sea of Flames," "Gas Leak Drives 200 from Syosset Homes," "Cracked Pipe Repaired After Cove Gas Leak."

WASHINGTON, March 7-- The debate on Vietnam is getting noisier and sillier because almost all the principals keep arguing about mysterious proposals and "ultimatums" that have never been put on the public record.
Record revenue and earnings were achieved last year by the Sperry and Hutchinson Company although the final quarter results dipped from the 1965 fourth quarter, the report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 7 --The Johnson Administration will send Congress within a few days legislation that would free for sale in the market some of the 430 million ounces of silver now held as backing for currency (silver certificates).

SHREVEPORT, La., March 7 --Mr. and Mrs. Francis Cameron Payne have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elisabeth Platt Payne, to Martin Gerald Alexander Rosen of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Rosen of Van Nuys, Calif.

The walls of the Federal penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pa., swallowed up James R. Hoffa yesterday. The president of the giant International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the country's largest and strongest union, went to jail still insistent that he was the victim of a "conspiracy" by his foes in high Federal office.

ADEN, March 7--The South Arabian League, a nationalist group that eschews the backing of the United Arab Republic, threatened today to kill leaders of the Egyptian-backed nationalist Front for the Liberation of Occupied South Yemen,...

CHICAGO, March 7--Law agencies have failed utterly to penetrate the ruling councils of organized crime because of the Cosa Nostra's successful adaptation of big business methods to their operations, 750 crimefighting experts were told here today.
TRENTON, March 7--State Attorney General Arthur J. Sills said today that he had ordered a review of the administration and enforcement of New Jersey's 118-year-old abortion law.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI)--Congress was urged today to approve funds for the development of a "hybrid" electric car, a vehicle that could use conventional engines and batteries for long-distance travel and switch to electrical power in the cities.

PARIS, March 7 (Reuters)-- Mrs. Pegeen Guggenheim Rumney, an artist and the daughter of the American art collector Peggy Guggenheim, was found dead in her Paris apartment last week, the police said today.

A burglary suspect seized a patrolman's revolver while being fingerprinted in a Brooklyn police station yesterday, barricaded himself in a locker room and fired three wild shots before turning the gun on himself.

The Public Schools Athletic League playoff basketball tournament, which had already reached the semi-final stages for some teams, has been canceled because of a dispute involving two schools that had yet to play a game in it.

TOKYO, March 7--Echoes of the political quarrels in Communist China reverberated in Tokyo again today with the publication of a statement by a Peking trade representative attacking "Japanese revisionists" over a bloody clash between Chinese and Japanese Communist students here.
MOSCOW, March 7 (Reuers)--One of the five holes that the Soviet Union plans to drill into the earth's core has already reached a depth of four miles, it was reported here today.

Investigators of an airliner crash near Kenton, Ohio, Sunday night have determined that the airplane broke up in flight. They have also determined that one of the plane's two propellers came apart in the air.
A depressing day came to a dismal conclusion for the New York Knickerbockers last night when they lost to the Los Angeles Lakers, 131-119, before 5,627 spectators at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, March 7-- Another round in the perennial debate over where to put Washington's large number of foreign diplomats began today. As usual, Congress and the State Department were on opposite sides, with residents of the District of Columbia in the middle.

Cassius,Clay, who likes the gaiety and excitement of a big city, and Zora Folley, who prefers the warmer climate of his native Arizona, forsook the Catskill Mountains yesterday for the training ring in the basement of Madison Square Garden.
The waterborne commerce of the United States set a new record of 1.319 billion tons during 1966, according to preliminary estimates compiled by the Army Corps of Engineers.
"What would Alice have been without Gertrude?" a friend of Miss Toklas and Miss Stein once asked.

TORONTO, March 7--Noranda Mines, Ltd., a major Canadian copper producer, called off today its announced plan to seek a 51 per cent interest in the Essex Wire Corporation of Fort Wayne, Ind., for $122million in cash, debentures and shares.
EASINGTON, England, March 7 (AP)--Britain has received its first supplies of gas from the North Sea, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 7-- A 27-pound bundle of hairy winsomeness named Dennis, the only smuggled orangutan ever to be seized in the United States, held his first news conference today at the National Zoo.

WASHINGTON, March 7-- Supreme Court decisions restricting the use of confessions in criminal trials drew heavy fire from influential Senators today at the opening of hearings on crime control legislation.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., March 8--Harry A. Wilder, a lawyer, who was president of the W. Sales Co. of Newark, an automotive and industrial equipment dealer, died Monday of a heart attack. He was 60 years old and lived at 11 Elsway Road here.

The traditional Eastern rivals of the Giants were of one mind yesterday concerning New York's recent acquisition of Francis Tarkenton of the Minnesota Vikings. All agreed that Tarkenton was an outstanding quarterback, that the Giants had improved themselves considerably and that the trade was a good one for New York, no matter how costly.

Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steal Corporation, called yesterday for re-examination of this country's trade policies to check rising import competition and reduce nontariff barriers to American exports.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)--The National Aeronautics and Space Administration agreed for the first time today to sell a Delta rocket and the use of its satellite launching facilities to a foreign organization.

FORTY-ONE-YEAR-OLD MARK TAIMANOV, a veteran stalwart in the Soviet galaxy of grandmasters, scored nine straight wins to capture first prize in the recent international tournament at Helsinki, Finland.

TWO major sculpture exhibitions opened simultane ously but by coincidence yesterday--a Henry Moore retrospective at the Brooklyn Museum and a Louise Nevelson retrospective at the Whitney Museum. Although not intended as a pair, they set off each other's virtues so neatly that you could wish they were side by side.

Silver futures responded actively to news that the Government planned more sales of the metal to forestall a higher price for a while longer. By buying or selling silver at about $1.29 an ounce, the Treasury effectively pegs the current price at that level.

NEW HAVEN, March 8--A poll of 500 undergraduates at Yale University disclosed today that 71 per cent of the students favored Selective Service deferments for college students.

Julie Andrews has been signed to star in "Darling Lili, Or Where Were You the Night You Said You Shot Down Baron Von Richthofen?" The film farce will be produced and directed by Blake Edwards for Paramount Pictures from a script by Mr. Edawrds and William Peter Blatty.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Thursday, March 9 (Reuters)--Eighty Communists and their leader died in a nine-hour battle with army troops in the central Java oil town of Blora, 500 miles east of Jakarta, the army announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 8-- The chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit urged Congress today to legalize wiretapping and electronic eavesdropping in criminal investigations.
Mrs, Earle Ferris of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Glenna Ferris, to Robert B. Burekel, son of Mr. and Mrs, Arthur Burckel of Louisville, Ky.

DETROIT, March 8--Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers Union, ordered today the seizure of a rebel local in Mansfield, Ohio, where a car parts plant has twice been hit by wildcat strikes in the last three weeks.
The traditional Macy's-Gimbels rivalry, which has recently slowed to a gentle simmer, will flare up anew this fall when both stores will adopt the same theme on their annual import promotions.

A "basic improvement" in the British balance-of-payments position has enabled the Bank of England to repay entirely the loans granted by the United States last year to bolster the pound sterling, Charles A. Coombs, vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said yesterday.

Roswell G. Ham Jr., the author of four novels and the son of a former president of Mount Holyoke College, died Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived at 30 West 10th Street and at Watch Hill, R.I.

WASHINGTON, March 8--The House Administration Committee moved today to assume jurisdiction on ethics and assured Representatives that if it got the job it would not snoop into their afterhours morals.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor, and almost 600 of the city's more prominent and prosperous citizens, were on hand last night for the American premiere of the film version of "The Taming of the Shrew."

BONN, March 8--West Germany will equip its F-104 Starfighters with British-made Martin Baker ejection seats, the Defense Ministry announced today. They will replace the ejection seats supplied by Lockheed Aviation Company of the United, States, designer of the plane.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 8 (AP)--Harvard University said today that a new $6-million center for architecture and urban design would be named for George Gund, class of 1909, who died last Year.

James H. Meredith has proved the hard way that there is no limit to his courage. He proved it first by defying all the forces of bigotry and becoming the first Negro to enroll at the University of Mississippi in 1962. It took the combined efforts of the Army and the National Guard to get him in, but he stuck with it.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 100.8 on Tuesday from 101.1 on Monday.
Forty editors and publishers will meet at Columbia University today and tomorrow to examine 528 exhibits entered in support of journalism nominations for the 51st annual Pulitzer Prizes.

The National Book Awards, made last night at Philharmonic Hall, are among the best in the eighteen-year history of these prizes. The books are of striking seriousness and weight. Moreover, they make good reading--a quality too easily slighted in our time, when distinctions are drawn between lowand high-brow culture.

The Federal Aviation Agency has ordered suspended for six, months the pilot's license of a 21-year-old flier who landed his rented single-engine plane on the upper deck of the George Washington Bridge.

With Villanova facing Marshall University at 7 P.M. and Southern Illinois meeting St. Peter's in the second game of the double-header, the 30th annual National Invitation basketball tournament will get under way at Madison Square Garden tonight.

BERLIN, Mass., March 8-- John J. Pendergast, an expediter of Federal Housing on the Eastern seaboard after World War II, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Worcester. He was 61 years old and lived on Peach Hill Road here.
The American Stock Exchange made its second consecutive advance yesterday as the list managed to hold on to most of its earlier gains despite some late profit taking.
A news conference by President Johnson, scheduled for 3:30 P.M. today in Washington, wil be carried live on radio and television.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 9--Vietcong guerrillas badly mauled a platoon of American infantrymen early today in the rugged hills rising out of the coastal plain 250 miles northeast of Saigon.

ATHENS, March 8--Greek Orthodox leaders have launched a sharp attack on the Ecumenical Patriarch, Athenagoras, spiritual leader of the world's 200 million Orthodox Christians, for "planning to sell out Orthodoxy to the Vatican."

Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan announced a plan yesterday to prevent An drew Jackson High School in Queens from becoming a de facto segregated Negro school. The plan was immediately attacked by parents who want to insure racial balance.

Jackie Robinson, a prominent Negro Republican leader and a key assistant to Governor Rockefeller, castigated his party yesterday for offering to James H. Meredith the G.O.P. candidacy to oppose Adam Clayton Powell for Congress.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 8 (AP)--Complainants alleging that a Fairfax County, restaurant owner refused to serve Negroes have drawn severe criticism of a Federal judge.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange advanced on a broad front yesterday. Sentiment was helped by indications of an improvement in the economy and some encouraging earnings reports from key industrial groups.

ST. LOUIS, March 8 (AP)-- Federal marshals, after a day of legal maneuvering, escorted to city fail today eight persons convicted of contempt of court in connection with civil rights demonstrations at the Jefferson Bank and Trust Company here in 1963.

WASHINGTON, March 8-- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that a report indicating that North Vietnam was using a restricted zone along the Chinese border as a daytime sanctuary for truck convoys carrying supplies ...

SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 --California smog officials warned the automobile industry today that if fume-suppressing equipment on 1968 models was not substantially improved, the cars could be banned from sale in the state.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8--The New York Mets played their first intrasquad game of the spring today and, except for the palm trees and pelicans, it might have been Flushing in July.

WASHINGTON, March 8-- After all these years, the United States has at last succeeded in putting James Hoffa it prison. Who knows where this kind of thing could lead? If it keeps up, Mississippi might start putting people in jail for murdering civil-rights workers, and what sort of country would we have then?
TORONTO, March 8 (AP)-- The Toronto Maple Leafs gave a quick goal to the Canadiens tonight, then scored five times in the first period and went on to a 6-4 victory in a National Hockey League game.

Mayor Lindsay announced last night that he would set up a single planning body for a coordinated campaign against crime by the police, the courts, the district attorneys, the correctional system and other agencies.

More than 50 persons, including several well-known authors and publishers, walked out on a speech by Vice President Humphrey at the National Book Award ceremonies last night to protest the role of the United States in Vietnam.
The election of Gerald B. Block as president of the Republic Corporation was announced yesterday following the annual stockholder meeting in Beverly Hills, Calif.

WASHINGTON, March 8-- President Johnson appears to have decided against any side trips or major tours of Latin America in connection with his April journey to a meeting of American chiefs of state in Uruguay.
NEW DELHI, March 8--V. K. Krishna Menon, whose political career seemed over just two weeks ago, has received a sudden and dramatic reprieve.
"They're coming in steadily from all over and by Monday we'll have enough horses to assure full cards for the meeting," said Tommy Trotter at Aqueduct yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 8-- Nuclear proliferation is bad. Soviet-American detente is good. Therefore a Soviet-American treaty banning nuclear proliferation ought to make everybody happy. Right?

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 7-- A free-for-all scramble for trade has developed between capitalist and Communist nations. This is the clearest development emerging from the masses of men and machinery crowding this year's spring trade fair in Leipzig.
ALBANY, March 8--Governor Rockefeller gave details today of his plan to unify transportation in the metropolitan area and preserve the 20-cent New York City transit fare indefinitely.
WASHINGTON, March 8-- Congress appears ready to wash its hands of what some members say has become a politically thankless task--the selection of local postmasters.
HONG KONG, March 8-- Supporters of Mao Tse-tung, Chinese Communist party chairman, claimed a new success in Honan Province today.
The first all-aluminum containers for soft drinks to be marketed in this area were displayed yesterday by the Pepsi-Cola Company at a news conference in the Regency Hotel.

"NOTHING MORE TO DECLARE" is John Clellon Holmes's spiritual customs declaration, made at age 40, at the border of a country to which he will never return. "I have outlived myself," he says, "as I was in the years recorded here, and I am done--even with the celebrations of their end."

BOSTON, March 8 (AP)-- The Philadelphia 76ers clinched the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division title by edging the Boston Celtics, 115113, tonight on Hal Greer's 25foot jump shot with two seconds remainig in overtime.

WASHINGTON, March 8-- The policy-making committee of World University Service of the United States called on President Johnson tonight to release "from their oaths" student leaders and others who it said were "sworn to silence" about financial relationships with the Central Intelligence Agency.
OTTAWA, March 8--The state, church and military joined in a final tribute today to Maj. Gen. Georges P. Vanier, Governor General of Canada.
The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor made a last-minute appeal to the Assembly yesterday to pass legislation that it says will give it the power to control crime on the waterfront.

THE American Kennel Club received a rebuke yester day for what was termed its failure to spell out requirements for best-in-show judges. The criticism came from William H.A. Carr, a former dog columnist and now a freelance writer.

WATERFORD, Conn., March 8--It was clear and cold even in the morning's bright sun. Ralph White, wearing Hamlet's traditional stage garb--white shirt open at the throat, black breeches and boots--stepped onto the little outdoor amphitheater stage adjoining the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater.

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the State Liquor Authority had no right to suspend the liquor license of a bar on the basis of a single incident of alleged solicitation by a homosexual of a policeman who was in civilian clothes.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 8 (AP)--John F. Bothwell, who played Freckles in the "Our Gang" movie comedies from 1929 to 1931, died yesterday at Monmouth Medical Center. He was 46 years old and lived in Sea Bright.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 8--The Government announced that the first elections in a decade started this morning in three rebellious southern provinces.

THERE are several things about James Howard Mere dith that those who know him well are agreed on. One is that he is his own man. He does not hunger after consensus as a basis for his actions. He will listen patiently to advice.
The Hooker Chemical Company posted increased prices yesterday for three of its chemical products.

WINDSOR, Ont., March 8-- Four times tonight Stanley Dancer called upon Cardigan Bay to move and not once did the 11-year-old New Zealandbred gelding let down his master. The result was a two-length victory for the Down Under expatriate in the $25,500 Provincial Cup Pace, the richest purse in the history of Canadian harness racing.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 8-- Gary Player, the farmer, landowner and professional golfer extraordinary, who is here for the $115,000 Florida Citrus open that starts tomorrow, has a goal for 1967. He wants to win one of the four major championships again.

MANHASSET, L.I., March 8 --Mrs. Helene Hollander Flor sheim, president of the auxiliary of the North Shore Hospital here, died of a heart attack today, at her home, 126 Dover Road. She was 53 years old.
The election of two vice presidents has been announced by Frank H. Taylor Son, Inc., real-estate brokers and home builders of East Orange, N.J.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 8-- Suffolk County's five East End towns asked the State Legislature today to partition them from the rest of the county. The aim is for a bucolic county, free from the rule of the western suburbs.
LONDON, March 8 (UPI)-- A new team today directed the operations of Rootes Motors, Ltd., which recently was taken over by the Chrysler Corporation.
Newspapers from seven of the eight Ivy League colleges have split in formal joint statements defining their positions on the question of draft reform.
MADRID, March 8--The Spanish Government is disturbed by recent disclosures that the United States Central Intelligence Agency financed international organizations opposed to the Franco regime.
Newspapers from seven of the eight Ivy League colleges have split in formal joint statements defining their positions on the question of draft reform.
MADRID, March 8--The Spanish Government is disturbed by recent disclosures that the United States Central Intelligence Agency financed international organizations opposed to the Franco regime.
MOSCOW, March 8--Aleksandr T. Tvardovsky, editor of the controversial liberal literary journal Novy Mir, struck back at his conservative critics today.
LOS ANGELES, March 8 (AP)--Willie Smith, one of the outstanding saxophonists of the big band era of the nineteenthirties end forties, died here yesterday. He was 58 years old.

Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., achieved record sales and earnings in the three-month and six-month periods ended Jan. 31, the report of the widely diversified manufacturing and operating company disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON March 8-- Total world trade grew strongly again last year, with global exports of the non-Communist countries reaching $180 billion, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

Leonard G. Hanauer, a vice president and co-manager of the municipal revenue Bond department of Bache Co., Inc., 36 Wall Street, members of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 215 East 79th Street. He was 58 years old.
In the storefront of a former grocery, new, starched curtains were hung yesterday. Eight sewing machines began to whir and a Spanish record blared.

TRIVANDRUM, India, March 8 (Reuters)--A husband and wife who are ministers in Kerala's new Communist-led government will not be able to live together because they stand on opposite sides in the MoscowPeking ideological split.
WASHINGTON, March 8-- President Johnson requested the Senate's approval today for United States accession, to the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs of 1961.

ALBANY, March 8--The Democratic State Committee sought today to bounce the direct primary issue back to the Republicans by recommending three different proposals for nominating candidates for state offices.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange advanced on a broad front yesterday. Sentiment was helped by indications of an improvement in the economy and some encouraging earnings reports from key industrial groups.

After four years as the owner of two tenements on the Lower East Side, a leading civic group has decided that it is virtually impossible for a landlord to maintain decent living conditions in a slum area and make a fair profit.
The Studebaker Corporation expects another good year in 1967 but is not sure yet if it will surpass 1966, when the company netted $16,465,000, Byers A. Burlingame, president, said yesterday.
A part of 44th Street will get wall-to-wall carpeting on March 26, when the Tony Awards will be presented at the Shubert Theater to the best on Broadway.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 8-- John P. Allison, a partner in the law firm of Marshall, Bratter, Greene, Allison Tucker, 430 Park Avenue, New York, died yesterday at White Plains Hospital. He was 56 years old and livd at 10 Canterbury Road.
Persons who are over age 65 can enjoy many Federal income tax advantages that are not available to younger taxpayers.
Professional football teams no longer will draft the controversial "red-shirt" athlete, according to an announcement here yesterday by Commissioner Pete Rozelle.
WASHINGTON, March 8-- The Federal Government asked the Supreme Court today to extend the one-man, one-vote doctrine to county and city governments throughout the country.

PARIS, March 8--Le Nickel --the big French company whose interest in New Caledonia's vast nickel reserves is almost a monopoly--has changed presidents, evidently hoping to improve its strained relations with the New Caledonians.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 8--Saudi Arabia asked the Security Council today to circulate petitions from Southern Arabia denouncing Egyptian political intervention in the area.
BARCELONA, Spain, March 8 (AP)--Dr. John Corominas, a Spanish-born professor of Romance languages at the University of Chicago, was expelled from Spain tonight, his lawyer reported.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., March 8--Behind the all-around play of Barry Leibowitz, Long Island University's basketball team took a 65-30 half-time lead and went on to crush Central Connecticut State College 114-66 tonight and capture the National Collegiate Athletic Association small college regional tournament here on the loser's court.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 8--Four African nations suggested measures today to force South Africa to yield her powers to govern South-West Africa to a United Nations body.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 8--Gov. Ronald Reagan asked the Legislature today to place California in "a sound fiscal position" by approving a tax increase exceeding $800-million, one of the biggest ever sought in any state.

Edward P. Holden Jr., vice president and treasurer of Smith-Dietrich Corporation, manufacturers of movie camera equipment, died yesterday in Le Roy Hospital after a brief illness. He was 83 years old and lived at 275 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn.
ROCKFORD, Ill., March 8 The investigation into the execution-style murders of two 14year-old white boys here last Thursday night took on possible racial overtones today.

The New York grand masters --Bobby Fischer, the United States chess champion, and the Rev. William Lombardy--are scheduled to participate in the international tournament at Monte Carlo beginning March 24.

WESTON, Mass., March 8-- Mr. and Mrs. Homer Ray Oldfield Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Day Oldfield, to Frederic Jay Kahn. He is the son of Mrs. Louis Holtzman of New York and the late Nathan Kahn.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 9 (UPI)--Top-seeded North Carolina defeated North Carolina State, 56-53, and the defending champion, Duke, routed Virginia, 99-78, today to advance to the semi-finals of the 14th annual Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament.
Robert W. Sarnoff voiced strong support last night for the establishment of a noncommercial television service, but he proposed that it be financed by general government revenues.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 9--The Government began rationing rice today for the first time as retail prices continued to climb to crisis levels.

"KING AND COUNTRY" was a British war film that attracted handsome notices but few customers during a brief American run a couple of seasons back. Now the play that inspired the film is in town. If this, too, dies of neglect, there's something wrong with us.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 9 (AP)--A National Guardsman and three pro-Castro guerrillas were killed yesterday when a Government patrol was ambushed by insurgents 60 mils east of Caracas, a high military source announced today. One of the dead was described as a guerrilla commander. Two soldiers were reported wounded in the clash, which took place near the town of El Guapo.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9--Tommy Davis of the New York Mets was sidelined with a patch over his right eye today after undergoing a minor operation for an infection under the eyelid.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9--Why is a bull pen called a bull pen in baseball!
The spot rate on the British pound continued its firming trend in quiet dealings yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here.
GENEVA, March 8--After three years' study the United Nations Commission on Human Rights gave its unanimous approval today to a draft convention on the elimination of religious intolerance.

WASHINGTON, March 9-- President Johnson said today that the Government would seek a Taft-Hartley injunction to end temporarily a West Coast shipyard strike that has affected shipping to Vietnam.

LINCOLN, R.I., March 9 (UPI)--Jockeys at Lincoln Downs voted after the second race today not to ride because of an excessively muddy track and racing was suspended for the 10th time since Jan. 28. The jockeys scheduled a vote for 9 A.M. tomorrow on whether to resume riding.

RICHMOND, March 9--The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit expressed strong doubts today on the effectiveness of standards used by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare in reducing racial discrimination in publicly supported hospitals.
Seventy-eight per cent of the heroin addicts in the city's experimental maintenance program have been able to hold jobs, go to school, or do both, according to a project report released yesterday.

One of South America's most distinguished soccer clubs, Cerro of Montevideo, Uruguay, will represent New York in the United Soccer Association (formerly the North American Soccer League), officials said yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 9 (AP)-- Lev V. Nikulin, who won a Stalin Prize in 1950 for his novel about the Napoleonic wars, "Russia's Faithful Sons," is dead, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today. He was 75 years old.
The Brown University Club of New York will hold its 99th annual dinner March 18 at the Pierre. Alumnae of Pembroke College will also attend.
The Riegel Paper Corporation announced yesterday the election of William M. Riegel as executive vice president and a member of the finance committee.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 9--Mickey Mantle played four innings of smooth, flawless and busy baseball at first base and Fritz Peterson pitched three perfect innings as the Yankees' New Era dawned for the record today.
The junior stewardess aboard the jetliner that crashed in Ohio yesterday, Miss Carole Ann Andrews, had been flying with Trans World Airlines only since Jan. 13.
The Holland-America Line announced yesterday the cancellation of two cruises and an castbound trans-Atlantic sailing of the 36,982-ton liner Nieuw Amsterdam.

THE nylon jersey dresses Oscar de la Renta showed yesterday will be in Bonwit Teller, Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman and other stores in June, but they are not specifically for summer, the designer insists.

Two free throws by Bob Allen, aster the final buzzer had sounded in an overtime period, gave Marshall a 70-68 victory over Villanova at Madison Square Garden last night and got the 30th annual National Invitation Tournament off to a spectacular start.

The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Wednesday the level it reached on Tuesday, which was 100.8.

PRATO, Italy, March 9 (AP) --The Arno River, which flooded parts of Florence, and the Tuscan countryside last November, rose past the danger level today downstream from Florence and swept away part of a pontoon bridge. Heavy, rains have swollen the river.
TOKYO, Friday, March 10 (AP)--The original building of Tokyo's Imperial Hotel, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, will be pulled down late this year to make way for a modern multistory structure.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)--President Johnson proposed today to put executive and administrative functions of the Federal Trade Commission, now divided among its six commissioners, under the chairman.

It was an impressive homecoming for Stephen Bishop yesterday evening at Town Hall. The 26-year-old Los Angelesborn pianist has been living in England since 1959, when he went to study with Dame Myra Hess.
