BANGKOK, Thailand, March 9--Premier Thanom Kittikachorn's regime told the Thai people tonight for the first time that United States aircraft were bombing North Vietnam from bases in Thailand.

WASHINGTON, March 9-- Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd B. Wilson Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Wilson, to Gerald Nelson Van Atta Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Atta of Simsbury, Conn. A fall wedding is planned.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 9--A 23-acre section of the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center here will be enclosed by roofs over open malls and plazas under a $1.5-million project announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 9-- The Securities and Exchange Commission and a number of individuals in the mutual fund industry, contrary to earlier expectations, are actively attempting to work out a compromise plan for reform of certain industry practices.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 9 (AP)--Earl Elms of San Diego won the 30th annual Midwinter International snipe regatta by finishing first in the last two races today.
SAN JUAN, P.R., March 9 (AP)--Rod Laver of Australia scored an easy victory tonight over Dennis Ralston, of Bakersfield, Calif., 6-2, 6-2, in the opening match of a professional tennis tournament.
Earnings of the companies in the Royal Dutch-Shell group rose last year to $662.1-million, an increase of 5.4 per cent over the 1965 earnings of $628.4-million.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 9--American combat casualties were higher last week than those for any other week of the war, a United States military spokesman said tonight. The spokesman said 232 Americans were killed, 1,381 were wounded and 4 were reported missing in action, a total of 1,617 casualties.
MONTPELIER, Vt., March 9 (UPI)--The supversive activities clause of the Vermont teachers' loyalty oath was ruled unconstitutional today.

Arthur L. Strasser, a senior partner in the law firm of Strasser, Spielgelberg, Fried Frank and for more than half a century a leader in the settlement house work of the Hudson Guild, died of a heart ailment yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 86. He lived at 812 Park Avenue.

A young people's version of "Gammer Gurton's Needle," a robust, 16th-century farce, will be presented March 17, 18 and 19 in the educational auditorium of New York University. The play, for children 6 and older, will have period costumes and include Elizabethan madrigals and folk songs.

A committee of the Board of Higher Education recommended yesterday that City College's Baruch School of Business and Public Administration abandon its liberal-arts curriculum and become strictly an "upper division" business school. As such, it would serve only junior, senior and graduate students.
NEW HAVEN, March 9-- Don Schollander of Lake Oswego, Ore., sent the powerful Yale team off to a fast start tonight at the 27th annual Eastern Seaboard intercollegiate swimming championships.
The Griswold Hotel and Country Club, a 50-year-old resort at Eastern Point in Groton, Conn., has been sold by Milton Slosberg to an investing group headed by Richard M. Rahm for more than $1-million.
HONG KONG, March 9--The rehabilitation of a number of Chinese organizations that had been either in eclipse or under fire during the last year was made known in Peking today.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 9--Erica, Morini, the violinist, will be the soloist with the Philharmonic Orchestra of Westchester in its season's fourth concert at the Wood Auditorium on Saturday night. John Barnett, music director of the 90-member orchestra, will conduct.

THE HAGUE, March 9-- Queen Juliana tonight asked 46-year-old Barent Biesheuvel, leader of the Anti-Revolutionary party and Minister of Agriculture in the outgoing Cabinet, to try to form a new government.
The Delaware River Port Authority has called a meeting of general terminal and port operators today to study a complaint made by the BrazilUnited States--Canada Freight Conference.
MONTREAL, March 9 (AP) --Four men took from $95,000 to $100,000 from the Dominion Glass Company today. The men fired a machine gun over about 50 employes huddled on the floor and then escaped.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 9-- Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson proposed today that some homeowners and apartment-renters be allowed to subtract part of their local property taxes from Federal and state income tax payments.
LONDON March 9--The Government Intimated today that "Mafia money" had been backing the agmbling boom in Britain.
Forget that 1492, friends, 1967 is the year to Discover America. Wait, you'll see.

Clarence C. Pell Jr., former titleholder, and Robert Power won the opening match in the United States amateur racquets doubles championship last night. They defeated Edward Elliman and Dr. David Spear, 15-3, 15-7, 15-6, at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI)--The Defense Department today identified 32 United States servicemen killed in action in Vietnam. Among them were Lance Corporals Glenn A. Sheppard of White Plains, and John J. Clarke of Danbury, Conn., both marines.

Three officers of the Western Union Telegraph Corporation announced their resignations yesterday as directors of Microwave Associates, Inc., of Burlington, Mass. Western Union owns about 8.5 per cent of the 1,038,000 shares outstanding of Microwave.

COLOGNE, Germany, March 9 (Reuters)--Lufthansa, the West German airline, has taken an option on three Anglo-French Concorde supersonic airliners, the company said today. It added that firm orders would be placed after the aircraft had proved its airworthiness.

VITTORIO GIANNINI died Nov. 28 at the age of 63. He had just finished his new opera, "The Servant of Two Masters," commissioned by the New York City Opera Company. Last night, the work received its world premiere at the New York State Theater.

TRIVANDRUM, India, March 9--E.M.S. Namboodiripad, the Communist leader who took office this week as Kerala's Chief Minister, said today that the rout of the Congress party in the state cannot be considered a victory for the Communists.
President Johnson moved both correctly and decisively in requesting an immediate restoration of the 7 per cent tax credit for corporate investment in new plant and equipment.
TOKYO, March 9 (AP)-- Red Guards in Peking put a brake on wall posters today, Japanese press reports said.

BROCKPORT, N.Y,, March 9 --State University officials said today that they were studying charges that Federal agents had recruited or tried to recruit Brockport College faculty members to spy on other teachers and report on their political views.

NEW ORLEANS, March 9-- Joseph T. Lykes Sr., retired chairman of the board and president of the Lykes Brothers Steamship Company here, died today at his home on Moss Point in Clearwater, Fla. He was 78 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)--Aged and dependent persons in some nursing homes are apparently not getting all the physicians' services, medicines and skilled care for which governments are billed, a Cleveland Welfare Federation official testified today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 9--Foreign observers here are predicting widespread disillusionment among the followers of Mbah Suro, a Javanese soothsayer who was slain by Army troops Sunday.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI)--William Haddon Jr. administrator of the National Traffic Safety Agency, said today that he was looking for voluntary removal by auto makers of jutting hood ornaments and other front-end protrusions on cars.
DALLAS, March 9 (AP)-- Karl Hoblitzelle, theater executive, banker and a civic leader, died in his sleep at his home here yesterday. He was 87 years old.

"The Member of the Wedding," the Carson McCullers novel that has already been turned into a play--the Drama Critics Circle's best of the 1949-50 season--a film and a television program, is now headed for the musical stage.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 9--Eritreans are fleeing into the Sudan from their homeland, now part of Ethiopia, in such large numbers that the Sudanese Government may soon be unable to feed and house them, the Sudan's Interior Minister declared today.

GENEVA, March 9--The United States has suggested that an international organization, rather than individual nuclear powers, decide where and when nuclear explosions will be used to blow up mountains and dig canals for the benefit of the nonnuclear countries.
GENEVA, March 9--The Kennedy round negotiators agreed today that their bargaining for tariff cuts and other reductions in obstacles to world trade must be completed by April 30.
STOCKHOLM, March 9 (UPI) --Sweden's national ice hockey team defeated Canada, 4-2, tonight. A return game is scheduled for tomorrow.

The All-State Credit Corporation, the latest in a series of finance companies to find itself in financial trouble, had a net loss from operations last year of $7,031,449, a meeting of the company's creditors was told yesterday.

OTTAWA, March 9 (AP)-- Robert N. Thompson, one of the Social Credit party's five members of the Canadian Parliament, was reported today to have resigned as the party's national leader effective March 17.
Paul P. Johnson, 60 years old, will be elected president and chief executive officer of the Leesona Corporation following its annual meeting in Boston April 25, the company announced yesterday.

The Federal Reserve moved aggressively toward easier money during the week ended Wednesday, by adding more than $1.3-billion to its holdings of Government securities, the Reserve reported yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 9 --Lebanon's two national air carriers, Middle East Airlines and Lebanese International Airways, announced today that they would pool their services beginning April 3. The announcement said the agreement was first step toward a complete merger of the airlines.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI)--President Johnson said today that while he realizes there were "differing opinions in Congress" regarding his proposals for overhauling the draft he stood by his recommendations.
The Manhattan Junior League of the United Jewish Appeal will hold on April 5 its first luncheon for the support of the New York Association for New ...
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)--President Johnson's news conference today was the first to be televised live in color from the White House.

DETROIT, March 9--Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, won overwhelming support tonight from union delegates throughout the nation for his action to quell a rebellion in an Ohio local.
The dean of Harvard College announced yesterday that he would resign to devote full time to the education of struggling students at a small Negro college in Birmingham, Ala..

The Department of Licenses announced yesterday that it would amend its regulations to prevent used-car dealers from turning back mileages on their cars and to crack down on specialists who do the work for them.

The shipping industry is concerned about a legislative move in Albany that could limit the serving of liquor on foreignflag ocean liners at bon voyage parties and at special shipboard affairs at pierside.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 9-- Eddie Belmonte proved the delight of the long-shot players at Santa Anita today when he brought in two high-paying winners.

DARIEN, Conn., March 10 Pete and Steve Orthwein, 21year-old twins, have been playing polo together most of their lives, but they will line up on opposing sides tomorrow night when Cornell and Yale meet for the national intercollegiate indoor polo championship at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

Laurence Feldman, a 40-yearold trial lawyer and theatrical producer, was discovered murdered early yesterday morning fn the bedroom of his East Side penthouse apartment. Mr. Feldman had suffered multiple skull fractures in a bludgeoning attack.
Dollar stocks climbed as many as 3 points yesterday to highlight an otherwise quiet session on the London Stock Exchange.
WALDWICK, N.J., March 10 Don Rubell and Tony Vincent both of New York, advanced to the semi-final round of the eastern indoor tennis championships at the Bergen Tennis.

MAKING new seats for chairs is described in a series of four bulletins from Cornell University's extension service. Instructions are given for using splint (long, thin strips of wood that can be interwoven), rush, webbing, Hong Kong grass, rope or twine.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 10 (AP) Toshio Katsumata, a lightly-regarded Japanese, shot a par 72 today in the second round of the Malaysian open golf tournament and moved into the lead at the halfway point with 140.

A special commission of the Episcopal Church agreed yesterday that all baptized Christians in good standing whether they be Roman Catholic, Protestant or Eastern Orthodox may receive holy communion in Episcopal churches.
TRENTON, March 10 (AP) Gov. Richard J. Hughes signed a bill today changing the primary election day from the second Tuesday in September to the first Tuesday in
ESSEN, West Germany, March 10 (AP) Alfried Krupp, who received government assistance this week to ease his financial troubles, may sell some of his vast industrial assets, company sources said today.

HONG KONG, March 10 A Hsinhua report from Peking tonight depicted the Chinese Post Office as supporting Mao Tse-tung's Cultural Revolution. The Chinese Communist press agency said new stamps had been issued commemorating the revolution, Mr. Mao's attempt to promote a more austere form of Communism.

At Lincoln Center today: "Otello," Metropolitan Opera, 2; "La Traviata," New York City Opera, State Theater, 2:15; Nina Deutsch, pianist, LibraryMuseum, 2:30; "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "Madama Butterfly," City Opera, State Theater, 8:15, and New York Philharmonic, 8:30. At Carnegie Hall: Claudio Villa, Italian popular songs, 8:30.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 11 The 12-year-old revolt by warlike tribesmen in the southern Sudan is now "definitely militarily and politically defeated," Premier Sadig Elmahdi asserted today.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) The Justice Department said today it had filed a proposed consent judgment under which the National Steel Corporation, the nation's fifth largest steel producer, would have to sell its controlling interest in the Metallic Building Company of Houston.

FRANCONIA, N.H., March 10 Jean-Claude Killy, the French skiing sensation, made his 1967 American debut a noteworthy one today by winning the North American downhill title with an effortless performance on the sticky Cannon Mountain course.

Robert E. O'Connor has announced that he plans to resign as president of the American Paper Institute, top organization of paper trade groups to become active in the management of the Rising Paper Company, Housatonic, Mass., manufacturer of writing papers.

WASHINGTON, March 10 The Government's chief trade negotiators told the Senate Finance Committee today that Europeans would have a "rude shock" if they thought the United States would sign an agreement in the Kennedy Round just for the sake of getting an agreement and avoiding failure in the long tariff negotiations.

WHITE PLAINS, March 10 Harry B. Cohen, who headed an advertising agency before his retirement, died here today in White Plains Hospital. He was 70 years old.

THE FMC Corporation, which plans to merge with the Link-Belt Company, has placed orders on the New York Stock Exchange to purchase Link-Belt common shares for cash at up to $49 a share.

LONDON, March 10 (AP) Tony Vandervell, the millionaire industrialist who broke Italian and German domination of the European Grand Prix circuits, died today at the age of 68.

SAIGON, Saturday, March 11 (AP) A United States Navy C-47 transport plane crashed and exploded near Phanrang yesterday, killing a11 25 persons aboard, United States military headquarters reported today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 10 American warplanes struck a major industrial installation in North Vietnam today in the first such bombing of the Vietnam war.

The Southern California Edison Company reported yesterday that for the first time its revenues topped a half-billion dollars in a year. CHICAGO, March 10--Directors of the American Farm Bureau Federation expressed concern today over "the steady deterioration in farm prices."

CHICAGO, March 10 (AP) Newspaper and television cameras will be barred from all coroner's inquests in Cook County (Chicago), the state's attorney announced today.

Ruth M. Williams, secretary general of the International Council on Social Welfare at 345 East 46th Street, died of cancer yesterday in Trafalgar Hospital. Her age was 51, and she lived at 245 East 25th Street.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 10 (AP) Twelve candidates, especially invited for the race, were formally entered today in the $125,000 San Juan Capistrano Handicap at Santa Anita tomorrow.

MOBILE, Ala. The restaurant that is most cele brated and sans pareil in Mobile is Constantine's in The Ramada Inn, at 1500 Government Street. Its reputation is solidly built on the glory of freshly harvested sea food from the Gulf Coast. If the standards seem high, it is doubtless because the eating of shrimp, crab and random denizens of the deep is almost a way of life here.

WASHINGTON, March 10 The argument over whether the Johnson Administration has hardened its terms far peace negotiations in Vietnam over the last year refuses to be stilled. The President says No; his critics say Yes.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 (UPI) A Federal judge ordered striking West Coast shipyard electricians back to work today on grounds that their four month walkout was affecting the Vietnam war effort.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 10 (AP) A Louisiana official said today that a decision upholding Federal school integration guidelines would have a strong impact nationwide, not only in the South.
The stock market roared into high gear yesterday in response to President Johnson's request to Congress late Thursday afternoon to restore the 7 per cent investment-tax credit.
PARIS, March 10 Le Figaro voiced today "the most vigorous protest" against yesterday's expulsion from Spain of its Madrid correspondent, Jacques Guilleme-Brulon.
WASHINGTON, March 10 The Justice Department supported today the California Supreme Court's historic ruling that the state's fair housing law could not be repealed by a vote of the people.
CHICAGO, March 10 (AP)--Four new directors, representing the Missouri Pacific Railroad, were elected today to the board of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 The Right Rev. and Mrs. James A. Pike of San Francisco and Santa Barbara have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Hope Pike, to John C. Patterson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Patterson of West Burlington, Iowa.

Sanitation Commissioner Samuel J. Kearing Jr. said yesterday he would put through an order eliminating a paid day off for Department of Sanitation employes who march in the St. Patrick's Day parade and other parades. He said it would save the city more than $1million.
ARMONK, N.Y., March 10 Fordham University was given a 115-acre estate here today for its first academic center outside of New York City.
LIVERPOOL, England, March 10 (UPI) Everton paid $224,000 today for Preston's 20-year old halfback, Howard Kendall.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 10 (AP) A change of leadership in the National Liberation Front, the Vietcong's political arm, to smooth the way for direct peace talks with the United States was reported today by allied intelligence sources.
The spot rate on the British pound eased slightly in quiet trading yesterday on foreignexchange markets here.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 10 (AP) Earl Elms of San Diego, won the 30th annual midwinter international Snipe Class regatta today with a total of 7,921 points.

The principal of Intermediate School 201 resigned yesterday six months after East Harlem parents and others tried to force his ouster. The resignation takes effect April 1. Stanley R. Lisser, the 40year-old, prematurely grayhaired educator, told a surprised faculty meeting that he would

Three pupils were suspended after assaulting teachers in separate incidents yesterday at a Bronx junior high school where more than half the staff has threatened to resign Tuesday, partly over abuse by pupils.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 10 Leonard C. Wright, acting district supervisor in Newark of the Parole Department of the New Jersey Department of Insitutions and Agencies, died Wednesday at his home, 122 Willowdale Avenue here. His gage was 61.
WESTBURY, L.I., March 10 Orbiter N. ($6.20) and Direct Home ($27) were the winners of the first two preliminaries in the Early Bird Series for pacers tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. A crowd of 25,077
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 10 (UPI) Bill White, a first baseman, reinjured his right foot today as the Philadelphia Phillies lost their exhibition opener to the Cincinnati Reds, 7-0.
Arthur Susskind, who scored 44 first-round knockouts while boxing as Young Otto for two decades before 1923, died yesterday in Central Islip, L.I. He was 80 years old.

LeRoy E. Carter intergroup relations officer of the Housing and Urban Development Department of the Federal Housing Administration, Region 1 (Eastern seaboard), died Thursday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 59 years old and lived at 104-10 29th Avenue, East Elmhurst, Queens.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) Attorneys for Robert G. Baker contended today that the jury that convicted him had been selected improperly. They said he should have a new trial.
LONDON, March 10--Recommendations for higher fire-prevention standards in the construction of passenger ships were agreed upon by a 14-nation committee that ended two weeks of discussions here today.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) The United Federation of Postal Clerks sued Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien today for "arbitrary refusal" to enforce basic working conditions.
BOSTON, March 10 Boston University will clash with Cornell University in the Boston Garden tomorrow night to decide the Eastern College Athletic Conference hockey championship.
J. Raymond Jones resigned yesterday as the Manhattan Democratic leader. He cited a lack of support by Senator Robert F. Kennedy as one of the major reasons for his action.
A group of Harlem Negroes will circulate petitions in an attempt to give Adam Clayton Powell two lines on the ballot in a special Congressional election on April 11.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10 The defending champion, Lehigh, heads the pack at the halfway mark as the 63d annual Eastern intercollegiate wrestling championship moves into its final day. The Engineers, who had advanced all 10 wrestlers through the preliminary round, lost only one man in the quarter-finals at the Palestra tonight.

ADEN, March 10 British authorities and the Federal Government of South Arabia are preparing to move Arab troops of the federal Army into Aden, where the British Army has hitherto borne sole responsibility for security.
WASHINGTON, March 10 A Presidential emergency board recommended today basic changes in the Railway Labor Act in a bid to facilitate the settlement of labor disputes.
BALTIMORE, March 10 Port interests expressed hope today that the 150-day old tugboat strike, the longest in the history of this Maryland port, may be settled over the weekend.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 10 The Reserve Bank of Rhodesia conceded victory here today to the British Government is a dispute over 28 tons of Rhodesian banknotes, ordered by Ian Smith's breakaway government. Delivery of the notes has been blocked by sanctions.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 10 Willis L. Towne, the founder and former president of the W.L. Towne Company, a New York advertising and public relations agency, died today at his hime here at the age of 82.
The Brooklyn Urban League will hold a testimonial dinner April 11 in the grand ballroom of the St. George Hotel to honor two Brooklyn clergymen.
Ballots for a strike vote were mailed yesterday to 1,000 employes of United Press International at 90 bureaus across the nation.
Broadway is planning to pay tribute to a veteran showman who is virtually unknown to the public.

JERSEY CITY, March 10--About 450 pupils at Dickinson High School cut classes today and demonstrated to protest the cancellation of their Easter vacation to make up for time lost during a teachers' strike.

The stock market advanced over a broad front yesterday in the second heaviest trading of any day on the New York Stock Exchange in response to President Johnson's request that Congress reinstate the 7 per cent investment tax credit.
DETROIT, March 10 Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, said today he did not want "to divide the American labor movement, but to revitalize it."
NEW DELHI, March 10 Prospects brightened tonight for a compromise that would avoid a bitter contest for the Prime Ministership.

Stockholders of the Clinton Engine Corporation have approved the purchase by Lomart Perfected Devices, Inc., of 3 million common shares of the Clinton Engine Corporation, it was announced yesterday. This gives Lomart 53 per cent ownership of Clinton.
Mexico City is becoming one of the world's major office centers, according to an international study of the need for new office space.
ITS a long way from Tipperary to carnegie Hall but The Clancy Brothers and Tommy Makem have traveled the road a dozen times since 1962.
The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity fell to 313.5 from 313.7 in the preceding week. A year earlier it was 303.1.

WOODY ALLEN, the slight, bespectacled, 31-year-old writer-comedian, who jumped from gags to TV and from near rags to riches in sur prisingly short order, is preparing to enter another enclave of show business. Allen and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer are in the final stages of negotiations of a deal under which he would make his film directorial debut with "Don Quixote, U.S.A.," the adaptation by Cy Howard of the novel by Richard Powell published last year by Scribners.

The city will ask the Federal Government to grant funds to help rehabilitate sections of three badly deteriorated communities--Harlem, the South Bronx, and Central Brooklyn. The money would come from the Model Cities program established last year by Congress.

GREENVILLE, S.C., March 11 (AP) A Federal Court order today directed three South Carolina school districts to institute freedom-of-choice school enrollment and to desegregate faculties and staffs "from superintendent to custodial or janitorial positions."

LIEGE, Belgium An automobile ride along the banks of a river can prove as delightful a way as any to while away a day or two. And if the river is a beautiful one, like the Meuse, the trip can be all the more rewarding.

FLORENCE, Italy, March 7 The task of restoring Florence's flood-damaged art and library treasures, lagging behind the prompt recovery of the city at large, has barely begun and will go on for at least a decade.

TOKYO Official tourist organizations in eastern Asia are planning a joint campaign to bring down, the cost of air travel to this region. The ultimate goal is to lure more visitors from Europe, as well as from North America.
A spokesman for the Governor's office holds that Ohio is continuing to lead in economic growth among the 50 states.
The New York Civil Liberties Union urged delegates to the State Constitutional Convention yesterday to abolish the grand jury system.

ATHENS, March 11 The crown prosecutor asked an Athens court-martial today for sentences of seven to 20 years for 21 Greek officers accused of plotting to overthrow the Government in the Aspida (Shield) plot.

CHICAGO, March 11 Some way must be found to halt the "dollar drain" from the Middle West to other sections of the country if Chicago is to -develop its potential as a financial center, according to a business leader.

CHICAGO, March 11 (AP)--Senator Gaylord Nelson, urged the Governors of four states bordering Lake Michigan and Lake Superior tonight to get together and battle pollution of the lakes before they were destroyed.
MOST home swimming pools are equipped with automatic filtering and recirculating devices that do an excellent job of keeping the pool water clean with only occasional attention from the owner.

MOGADISCIO, Somalia, March 6 Famous as poets and storytellers, the Somalis like to relate to visitors a proverb that suggests it is their wish, but not their responsibility, to redraw the frontiers that have caused much trouble in the horn of Africa.

A plot of ground on the edge of the old Inclinberg farm that became Manhattan's fashionable Murray Hill residentail district is regaining in part the role envisioned for it by John Murray when he began selling his property off in 1847.
HONG KONG, March 11 The most prominent figure is Communist China in recent weeks has been Chou En-lai, the country's tough, flexible, 68-year-old Premier.

IN "Center of the Storm" John T. Scopes offers a quietly told account of his trial and conviction for having broken the laws of Tennessee by teaching the theory of evolution in a public-school biology course in 1925. The prominence of the special counsel brought into the so called "Monkey Trial" William Jennings Bryan for the prosecution, and Clarence Darrow,

ALTHOUGH most people have never seen one, there are actually two dozen $100,000 bills in existence. They are Federal Reserve Gold Certificates and a sample of one can be seen now in a special display at the Chase Manhattan Bank's Money Museum, 1254 Avenue of the Americas, in Rockefeller Center.

The Geneva disarmament conference opened three weeks ago amid intoxicating predictions that the long-dreamed-of treaty prohibiting the further spread of nuclear weapons would be signed almost immediately. Now it's the morning-after.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11 (AP) Tom Allen of Buffalo, a boat-builder, won both races today in the winter sailing championship of the Lightning Class.
BEAUTY IS EVERYONE'S BUSINESS, and it seems strange that we have to have our Government make us aware of it before we become concerned about it; however, "such is the nature of the beast."
OMAMA March 1 was Statehood Day in Ne braska and the beginning of a nine-monthlong series of celebrations to mark the 100th anniversary of the state's entry into the Union.

Stores are reordering spring and summer apparel for their sportswear and accessories departments, reports to resident buying offices indicate. Beachwear is in particular demand. Reports on various departments follow:
Teen-agers on the Fordham University campus in the Bronx will be going to school by 1969 in a low, circular building with a chapel at the top and a television studio below.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 (AP) Coach Bill Russell's 15foot field goal with two seconds to play carried the Boston Celtics to a 116-114 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers tonight and a 5-4 edge in games yon from the Eastern Division champions.

In the first international comparison of educational achievement, the United States carried off no Olympic medals. The subject was mathematics. The nations who voluntarily took part in the fiveyear study were Austrarlia, Belgium, England, Finland, France, Israel, Japan, the Netherlands, Scotland, Sweden, the United States and West Germany. Japan emerged as doing "the best overall job."
EL PASO, Tex., March 11 (AP) Texas Western College cannot repeat as National Collegiate basketball champion.

WASHINGTON, March 11 Few areas of medical research have received as much public notice in recent years as that of transplantation the art and science of giving a person a vital part from someone else.

VIKERSUND, Norway, March 11 (AP) Jiri Raska, a 26-yearold plumber from Czechoslovakia, dominated competition in an international ski soaring tournament today with leaps of 423, 449 and 354 feet. He scored 216.5 points.

NEW ORLEANS, March 11 A bitter legal battle between two corporations over the professional services of one of the South's most prestigious law firms was placed before the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit here yesterday.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 11 (AP) Gary Gubner of New York City set an American record in the standing press at the New York State Amateur Athletic Union weight lifting championship tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) Washington newspapermen poked fun tonight at big names of the political world and their would-be successors.
DULUTH, Minn., March 1l (AP) Bruce Cunningham, a 17-year-old skier from Mexico, Me., won the national Nordic combined championship today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 11 All this week, on the windswept central plateau of Brasilia, President Humberto de Alencar Castelo Branco and his tutorial regime have been closing the books on the first stage of the three-year-old Brazilian "revolution."

WASHINGTON, March 11 Lieut, Gen. Lewis B. Hershey is vigorously defending the concept of the neighborhood draft board, despite a unanimous recommendation by the President's Commission on the Draft that local boards be abolished. The general has been the director of Selective Service for a quarter of a century.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 11 Cornell University released a list of eight organizations that "have contributed funds to Cornell during the past 10 years [and] appear on the list of organizations reported in the press to have had C.I.A. support."

Students from high schools in in the city's underprivileged and upper-income neighborhoods, sat down together after school last week to discuss how the Australopithecus lost the battle of the trees to the apes in prehistoric times and descended to the forest floor to become an ancestor of man.

The quality of New England's labor force plays a vital role in the area's impact as an important economic force. Technical skills, both in manufacturing and service industries, make up for regional disadvantages that could relegate New England's economy to second-class status.
TOKYO Japan's two largest auto manufacturers, Toyota and Nissan, are trying to persuade consumers here that they won't lose face if they drive small, inexpensive "people's cars."

CINCINNATI, March 11. (AP) The Cincinnati Royals combined hot shooting and tight defense tonight for an 147-119 National Basketball Association victory over the Chicago Bulls. It was the Royals' highest score of the season.
It was winter yesterday and it will be winter until March 20, but the temperature climbed to 72 degrees at 2 P.M., five degrees above the high for the date set in 1955.
Cassius Clay boxed three fast rounds yesterday with Jimmy Ellis, a sparmate, in preparation for the heavyweight champion's title bout with Zora Folley on March 22.

BRANDS HATCH, England, March 11 (UPI) Dan Gurney, of Costa Mesa, Calif., posted the fastest time during trials today for tomorrow's "Race of Champions," the opening event for Grand Prix auto racing in England.

SALEM, Ore., March 11 A $20-million housing development for families with one member at least 50 years old and none under 18 will soon occupy a site three miles northwest of here, overlooking the Willamette River.
WASHINGTON, March 11 President Johnson will go to the island of Guam next weekend for strategy discussions on the war, Vice President Humphrey disclosed tonight.
Sales of soap and detergents rose to a new high in 1966, according to reports from 40 manufacturers to the Soap and Detergent Association.
Prices and volume both rose last week on the over-thecounter market and the American Stock Exchange.

WHEN Electra strides the stage of the Metropolitan Op era again on Fri day, in the person of Lavinia Mannon to the music of Marvin David Levy, a sevenyear-old project will reach fruiton. It would never have gotten under way, either, without the element of luck.

Arthur J. Goldberg, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, has been put forward by Assemblyman Stanley Steingut, Brooklyn Democratic chairman, as a "great candidate" for Senator next year.

WASHINGTON, March 11 A three-cornered poker game was going on this week between Bonn, London and Washington. On the outcome hung the future military strength of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. In a surprise move the United States threw in some new chips labeled "monetary cooperation," and seemed about to win the game.
PARIS, March 11 Britain lost 400 aerospace technicians to American industry last year.

Work is under way at West Virginia University here on a research project designed to determine some of the scientific secrets of acid minewater drainage.

Of all the words that might be used to describe Lyndon Johnson in his myriad moods, "serene" seems the most remote. Yet serenity is what Lyndon Johnson tried successfully to project in living television color last week just as more ordinary men were saying he had come face-to-face with disaster.

WASHINGTON, March 11 Mr. and Mrs. Secundino Robaina of this city, formerly of Havana, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elena Rabaina, to Frederic Koch Howard, son of John B. Howard of Scarsdale, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Howard.
It's spring again, and 15 million stockholders are stirring, The annual meeting season, otherwise known as corporate democracy in action, is shifting into high gear.
WASHINGTON, March 11 Poverty fighters are elated by hard, new evidence of cooperation by the medical and dental professions in providing complete, systematized services for the poor.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board, over the strong objections of both the Justice Department and one of its own members, sanctioned a proposal yesterday to charge airline passengers an extra $2 to watch in-flight movies. The board's action, however, was not final.

WASHINGTON-SALAM, N. C. March 11 Mr. and Mrs. P. H Latimer Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter Miss Elease Covington Latimer, to Peter Francis Kearns, son of Mr, and Mrs. Kenneth Kearn of Manchester, N. H.
MADISON, Wis., March 11 (UPI) Chuck Nagle set a Wisconsin record for scoring in one season as the Badgers downed Illinois, 102-92, today in the Big Ten finale for both teams.
NAPLES, Fla., March 11 "Wild Bob" West a man of considerable dignity and fishing skill tracked down this peripatetic angler the other day and asked: "How'd you like not to go fishing today?"
ALAN SEEGER died while storming a German-held town with his fellow American members of the French Foreign Legion, a year before America formally entered World War I.

WASHINGTON, March 11 Tomorrow is the 20th anniversary of the Truman Doctrine, the cornerstone of American postawar diplomatic strategy, but there is growing doubt in Congress about the doctrine's continued validity.

WINTER PARK, Fla., March 11 Mrs. Norman S. Buck of Winter Park and Jacksonville, Vt., formerly of New Haven, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alison Buck, to Philip Gerry Gallman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Waldemar J. Gallman of Washington.

Sandor Mark, a civil engineer who owned a real estate agency here bearing his name, died of a heart attack in his home yesterday. He was 46 years old and lived at 15 Haverford Avenue in Scarsdale, N.Y.

The South is still a tough nut for labor unions to crack. It is so tough, rapid industrial growth and lagging wage rates notwithstanding, that the Textile Workers Union of America last month urged the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations executive council to unite in a crusade against an alleged "South-wide anti-union conspiracy."
PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y. At 80 year of age, Mrs. Arthur O. Choate, widow of one of the Choates of Boston, still likes to attend Girl Scout functions, tell ghost stories and ride sidesaddle.
A new meat animal evaluation center, described by the State Department of Agriculture as the first in this country, has rune into operation at Pennsylvania State University.

Some tenants in Manhattan's first all-electric highrise apartment building received a shock when they opened their Consolidated Edison Company bills recently. One man, with a bill of $113 for six weeks, has refused to pay.
NEW YORK, (Madison Square Garden) Ismael Leguna, 134 pounds, Panama, outpointed Frankie Narvaez, 135 , Puerto Rico, 12 rounds.
ST. LOUIS, March 11 (AP) Professional soccer men may soon find out the problem is not whether Americans will understand soccer but whether soccer players will understand Americans.
Thoroughbred horse racing, the sport-industry that contributed more to the fisc at Albany last year than any other single enterprise, will begin the 1967 season at Aqueduct tomorrow.

BERLIN, March 11 A total of 1.73 million West Berliners are eligible to vote tomorrow in the quadrennial city elections, but only a relatively moderate turnout is expected following a quiet campaign devoid of controversy.

William B. Camp, the new Controller of the Currency, has appparently decided to take a less-liberal course in approving applications by banks for new branches than did James J. Saxon, his expansion-minded predecessor.
PITTSBURGH, March 11--Allegheny County Democrats, lacking the firm hand of former Gov. David L. Lawrence, who died last November, are experiencing their first major split since 1935.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)--Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall announced today that he had asked Congress to authorize a 43,434-acre redwood national park in California.

WASHINGTON, March 11 For more than a year the merits and the deficiencies of the draft have been debated in Congress, in the universities and in the columns of the nation's newspapers. The debate will undoubtedly continue, but the time is approaching when something must be done about the draft.

CALICUT, India, March 11 The Moslem League, the remnant of the movement that Created Pakistan 20 years ago, is making a political comeback as a member of the Communistdominated front that has taken power in the South Indian State of Kerala.

PASADENA, Calif., March 11 (AP) Discovery of a starlike object that one cosmic yardstick indicates may be the brightest, fastest and farthest yet found was disclosed this week by the California Institute of Technology.

QUITO, Ecuador The jetliner takes but three Hours to span the distance between the leg endary birthplace of the Inca, or Sun God, near La Paz, Bolivia, and the last capital of the once-mighty Inca Empire here at Quito. But in between, the visitor could spend a lifetime exploring the unforgettable sights in this living museum.

TOKYO, March 11 (AP) The first international pearl conference, aimed at promoting abroad the sale of Japanese cultured pearls, closed a two-day meeting here last week.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) Foreign-made television sets have been added to the gadgets in the limousines of three of President Johnson's Cabinet members.

Mr. and Mrs. Moses E. Ditchek of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lana Ditchek, to Dr. Lee Dresden Goldberg, son of Mrs. Milton J. Goldberg of Elizabeth, N. J., and Mr. Goldberg of Hillside, N. J.
ENUGU, Nigeria, March 8 The atmosphere in Nigeria's Eastern Region is like that of a nation on the brink of war.

Although the foundation is only a bit more than three years old, it already has achieved attention as a result of its annual summer playwrights' conferences held at its headquarters in Waterford, Conn.

WASHINGTON, March 11 The little noticed "fisherman's war" that has been going on sporadically between the United States and Ecuador and Peru for the past 15 years over the innocent but highly edible bluefin tuna was threatening this week to create a rift in the Alliance for Progress and jeopardizing attendance at next month's Latin-American heads-ofstate meeting.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 11 Francis U. got up in the last stride today to win by a neck in a four-horse photo finish in the $61,100 Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park.
DALLAS, March 11 (AP) Dundee United of Scotland will represent Dallas in the new United Soccer Association this year, the owner, Lamar Hunt, said today.

NEW HAVEN, March 11 Although the team's big star, Don Schollander, was beaten in one race, which is as rare as a summer's day in March, the Yale swimmers tonight again dominated the annual Eastern Seaboard Intercollegiate championships, which concluded after three evenings of record-breaking performances.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 11 (AP) The Minnesota Vikings said today they would use the New York Giants' first-round choice in Tuesday's National Football League-American Football League player draft. The Bureau of Federal Credit Unions reports that outstanding loans at the nation's credit unions increased $95-million, seasonally adjusted, in January. The December gain was $60-million.

Benefiting from the ball's proceeds will be the People-toPeople Sports Committee, which promotes world peacethrough-sports competitions around the world.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 11 (AP) Larry Miller's 32 points led North Carolina to an 82-73 victory over Duke in the final of the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament tonight. The Tar Heels rallied from a 9-point deficit.
NEW ORLEANS, March 11 (AP) Mrs. E.K. Thomas's Furl Sail gallaped to a fourlength triumph today in the $17,300 Oaks Stakes at the Fair Grounds, covering the mile and one-sixteenth in 1:45 1-5.

Leaders of the state's construction-trade unions announced their support yesterday of Governor Rockefeller's proposals for unifying transportation agencies in the metropolitan area. They represent 500,000 workers in the building industry.

This is not a book about the dress business but rather the undress about the rise of an unhappy, illiterate, nasty young immigrant, Jay Blackman, who becomes unhappier, a bit less illiterate and far nastier as he acquires money and power.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., March 11 Miss Evalyn Adlaide Washington and Arnold Humphrey plan to be married here in July. Mr. and Mrs. George Washington have announced their daughter's engagement. Mr. Humphrey is the son of Garth Humphrey and the late Mrs. Bertha Humphrey.
