EAST WILLISTON, L. I., March 11 The engagement of Miss Una M. Driscoll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Driscoll, to Richard A. Meyer of New York, son of Mrs. Irwin M. Rewer of Sheboygan, Wis., and the late Milton A. Meyer, has been announced by the future bride's parents.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 11 Army's caissons went rolling along tonight on a flat, flat, beige-colored synthetic surface in the 20th annual Heptagonal indoor track-and-field championships.

Each guest at a luncheon and fashion show to be held Thursday at the Plaza is to bring a salable item for the Ark, a preChristmas boutique operated by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. The shop is manned by volunteers and its proceeds support the society's Alteration Surgery Fund for adopted animals.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11 Tommy Davis listens to rock 'n' roll records in his room near the Gulf of Mexico. Terry Christman sits by the swimming pool and studies his correspondence course on the commodity markets. Jerry Koosman lives in a house trailer and commutes to work.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 11 Drought is threatening much of the nation's winter wheat crop.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., March 11 Geraldine Farrar, one of the most celebrated American singing stars of the Metropolitan Opera's "golden age," died of a heart attack today at her home on New Street here. She was 85 years old.

Mrs. Lucette Hyde of 400 East 59th Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Denise Hyde, to John Cotton Wood, son of Mrs. William Lawrence Wood of New York and the late Rev. Mr. Wood.

The race to capture a strong role in the massive revolution of the knowledge and education industry culminated recently in a prize offer to purchase a major text book publisher for about $280-million.

The New York Knickerbockers begin the final week of the National Basketball Association's regular season by playing host to the Philadelphia 76ers, the Eastern Division champions, at 2 P.M. today at Madison Square Garden. Manhattan Yeshiva meets the Hebrew Institute of Long Island at noon in a Talmudical High School League championship game.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11 Stan Musial and Red Schoendienst first roomed together in 1946 and they have remained the closest of friends ever since. Each has reached so lofty an estate that he is entitled to a separate suite whenever the St. Louis Cardinals are on the road. Stan is now the general manager of the team and the redhead is his chief lieutenant as field boss.
The four top-seeded teams moved into the semi-final round of the David J. Johnson memorial open doubles squash racquets tournament yesterday at the Heights Casino.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 12 (UPI)--Railroad switchmen staged a 14-hour strike against Southern Pacific today in a dispute over seniority rights, disrupting passenger and freight service in seven states.

LORIENT, France, March 12 --Pierre Messmer, the man in change of President de Gaulle's nuclear striking force, suffered a stunning defeat in the runoff vote today at the hands of a Socialist candidate who profited from the withdrawal of a Communist.
Verdi's "La Traviata," with Monsterrt Caballe in the title role, Richard Tacker as Alfredo and Cornell MacNen as Germont, will open the Metropolitan Opera's 83d season Sept. 18.
DETROIT, March 12--The automobile industry has begun to make tentative estimates of the cost of a guaranteed annual income for its workers, according to a management source.

PITTSBURGH, March 12-- The Pittsburgh Playhouse, beset by several crises over the last several years, announced over the weekend a new policy for the 1967-68 season. An eight-play repertory season will be held in the Craft Avenue Theater, and other productions will be performed in the Hamlet Street Theater.

John Harllee, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission, last week challenged a United Kingdom Chamber of Shipping report that accused the regulatory agency of generating "frustrations' in international shipping.
While studying a species of fly a geneticist at Rockefeller University has observed in the laboratory what he believes may be the first step in the formation of a new species.

IN the Adam and Eve scene of the Broadway musical "The Apple Tree," Adam (Alan Alda) builds a hut out of three boards and is joyously happy with it until Eve (Barbara Harris) decorates it with flowers and sea shells.

Samuel P. Howe 3d of Philadelphia and R. William Danforth of Pittsburgh justified their top seeding yesterday by winning the David C. Johnson Memorial open doubled squash racquets tournament at the Heights Casino Club, Brooklyn Heights.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay--By 1944, there was hardly a decent-size wood stove or boiler left in Uruguay. Thus it was that a Basque immigrant woodcutter named Ascencio Iturrya became technologically unemployed. So he opened a restaurant.
Nat Diamond, manager of the rubber department of the A.C. Israel Commodity Company, died of cancer yesterday in his home at 205 Third Avenue. He was 69 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 12-- In the Southwest Hebrew Congregation here today, Miss Miriam Sharon Betensky and Charles K. Marr, who are with the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, were married by Rabbi Richard G. Hirsch.
A Russian Orthodox priest who was a youth in the North Caucasus when the February Revolution broke out 50 years ago recalls it as "a moment of intoxication of the people."
OGDENSBURG, N.Y., March 12 (AP)--Two of four youths trapped in a dumbwaiter at the George Hall Trade School of Ogdensburg Free Academy here, died today, apparently of strangulation.

BOSTON, March 12 (AP)-- Bailey Howell's 30 points and John Havlicek's 21 points paced the Boston Celtics to a 123-118 National Basketball Association victory today over the Baltimore Bullets, the Celtics' eighth victory in nine meetings with the Bullets this season.
CHICAGO, March 12 (UPI) --The Chicago Black Hawks clinched their first National Hockey League title today with a 5-0 rout of the Tomato Maple Leafs in a nationally televised game.

FORSYTH, Ga., March 12-- Miss Joanlise Mucarzel Lins, daughter of Mrs. Joao Lagoeiro Lins of Belo Horizonte, Brazil, and the late Mr. Lins, was married today to Karl Bramblett Hill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charner Woodson Hill.

WASHINGTON, March 12-- Men and women who haven't forgotten how to dance in each others' arms were in luck at the third annual Bal du Futur in the Washington Hilton Hotel last night. Duke Ellington and his orchestra played nothing but their kind of music--no frugs, watusis or twists.

LONDON, March 12--Roman Catholicism is Britain, all but undisturbed by serious internal dissension for more than a century, is being buffeted by the winds of change stirred by the Ecumenical Council Vatican II.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)--Senator Joseph S. Clark said tonight the key point in an investigation of the antipoverty program would be to determine "what have been the concrete benefits" for the poor.

PEKING, March 12 (Reuters) --Anti-Soviet demonstrations flared up in Peking again today following Chinese charges that the Russians stopped a Chinese train at a Soviet border station last month, beat the crew and impounded the writings of Mao Tse-tung.
PARIS, March 12--Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville suffered a narrow and humiliating defeat today in his race for a seat in the National Assembly from Paris' Seventh Arrondissement.

Three maritime unions have warned President Johnson that they will refuse to sail ships to Vietnam if the Government does not stop the "practice" of employing foreign seamen on United States-flag ships.

The decision by Dean John U. Monro to give up his post at Harvard College to help boys and girls from the Negro schools in Birmingham make their way into, and through, Miles College is a poignant reminder that the essential battles for human and civil rights call for hard work every day in the year.

GENEVA, March 12 (AP)-- Airport sources said the charter fee of $2,000 for the Alitalia airliner that brought Svetlana Alliluyeva here yesterday from Rome was paid in the Italian capital by a man identified as Rayle. This appeared to be Robert F. Rayle, the Central Intelligence officer who accompanied her from New Delhi to Rome on Tuesday.

MILWAUKEE, March 12-- The Most Rev. William E. Cousins, Archbishop of Milwaukee, denounced today a group of Roman Catholic laymen who had questioned whether funds obtained in the archdiocesan charities drive were used to promote civil disobedience and civil rights demonstrations.

PARIS, Monday, March 13-- President de Gaulle's followers, in a stunning reversal of their political fortunes, are within a hair's breadth of losing control over the National Assembly after a runoff election yesterday.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 12 (UPI)--Florida East Coast Railway engineers threw up picket lines here and in Miami today to join 14 other unions in a strike that started four years ago.
Houston is likely to get a big infusion of investment capital soon, should Congress restore the 7 per cent investment tax credit.

Andres Segovia is now 74 years old, but his affection for the guitar and the music he finds to play on it seems to remain as constant as the public that flocks to hear him wherever and whenever he gives a concert. At Town Hall Saturday night, Mr. Segovia made his final appearance of the season and the house was sold out.

THE Saga Norwegian Blue Fox coat by Ritter Brothers was wrapped around Verushka, Countess Von Lehn dorff, one of the loftiest of the high fashion models. The background, in the words of Vogue magazine, was "the steams and mists, the sulphurous fumes of Jigokudani, the Valley of Hell," in Japan.
A mock session of the United Nations General Assembly, held here last week by 1,600 college students, sought to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.

Martin Liqouri, a senior from Essex Catholic High School in New Jersey, set a national interscholastic record for the onemile run on a 10-lap track at Queens College yesterday in the Irish Christian Brothers track and field meet.

GREAT NECK, L.I., March 12--Miss Rita Lee Shapiro, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Shapiro of Brooklyn, was married this evening to Mitchell Grossberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Grossberg of Jackson Heights, Queens. Cantor Arthur Savitt performed the ceremony at Leonard's here.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 12-- Dr. Ralph C. Kendall, a dean at the University of Toledo, who developed industrial education programs for labor and management groups, died today at his home. He was 48 years old.

MINERAL KING, Calif.-- The road to Mineral King is a tortuous, winding path clinging to a canyon wall. The first heavy rains and snow of the late fall close the partly paved, partly dirt road. It stays closed until late spying, sometimes as late as June.
THE Czarist regime, swept away 50 years ago, was a more complex system than is indicated by the predominantly negative image presented by some historians.

SEATTLE, March 12--West Coast players dominated the standing when the Men's Pair championship went into its final session in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring National Championships here tonight.
Mayor Lindsay said last night that the city might provide auxiliary policemen or volunteer youths to escort women and the elderly to and from church services and social gatherings at night.

The First Western Financial Corporation--a savings and loan holding company whose shares are traded on the New York Stock Exchange--announced yesterday it had sustained "substantial operating losses" during 1966, which may have wiped out its shareholders' equity.
Appointment, instead of election of judges, was recommended to the state constitutional convention yesterday by a special committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

Miss Lucy Elizabeth Simon, daughter of Mrs. Richard L. Simon of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Mr. Simon, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. David Y. Levine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Levine of Morris Plains, N.J. Dr. Matthew I. Spetter of the Ethical Culture Society performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

A woman who says she is the widow of the man who invented a game called "The Deadly Double" denied yesterday that advertisements for the game published in 1941 carried any warning of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

THE New York City Amateur Chess Championship, which attracted 149 players at the Henry Hudson Hotel recently, was won by Gilbert Goon, a 20-year-old Princeton senior. SWITKES 3-13-67 Position after 23... Q-B3

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., March 12--Dr. Walter A. Shewhart, an authority on applying statistical methods to quality control in industry, died yesterday is a nursing home in Troy Hills. He was 75 years old and lived at 158 Lake Drive.

NEW DELHI, March 12-- The Soviet Embassy here was reported today to have complained to the Indian Government over the manner in which Stalin's daughter, Svetlana, Alliluyeva, left the country Tuesday.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 12 (AP)--Ireneo Legaspi of the Philippines shot his third straight 71 and won the Malaysian open golf tournament by one stroke today with a 72hole score of 286.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 12-- The North Carolina General Assembly came face-to-face last week with one of its most controversial issues with introduction of legislation to make an independent university of growing East Carolina College at Greenville.
BONN, March 12--The ultrarightist National Democratic party apparently has rallied around its deputy chairman, Adolf von Thadden, in a dispute over the national leadership.

LONG BEACH, L.I., March 12--Noting that "juvenile delinquency is increasing in suburban neighborhoods where comforts of life abound," Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson announced a program today to put youths to work on public service projects.

WASHINGTON, March 12-- A leading private consulting concern reported yesterday that President Johnson's newest effort to improve urban life, the model cities program, had already achieved positive results though Congress had appropriated only token funds.
IF "The Natural Look" were about anything, it might be quite a pleasant casual entertainment. As things stand, it's fun only when it's faking.

Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving has backed down on his plan for an open-air horseback riding arena is Central Park which some critics have charged would mar the park to create a polo field for the rich.

Prolonged applause greeted George London at the start of his recital at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night--a heartwarming "welcome home" to the popular bass-baritone.
BASTIA, Corsica, March 12 (AP)--A ballot box was tossed into the sea today after a bitter argument in a polling place.
LONDON, March 12. (AP)-- The Maltese Government tonight accepted Britain's plan for a gradual withdrawal of her forces.

Everything was there for the Friday morning conference--the men in shirtsleeves around the big table, the containers of coffee. Typical agency scene, you say? Hardly. The conversation was Japanese. But so were the four men and so was the agency.
All the notice said the other day was that the Instrument Systems Corporation of Huntington, L.I., had acquired the Sekisui Plastics Corporation of Hazleton, Pa.

STUTTGART, West Germany, March 12 (UPI)--Dr. Wernher von Braun, director of the space flight center at Huntsville, Ala., said today that barring further accidents the United States could make a manned landing on the moon by 1970.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)--The tax increase asked by President Johnson will be needed to moderate an expected upswing in the economy later this year, the budget director Charles L. Schultze said today
DARIEN, Conn., March 12-- Sara King Carleton, who wrote two books of verse, died today at her home, 205 West Norwalk Road. She was 81 years old.

Jacob Goldenheim, president of the Goldenheim Corporation, 261 Fifth Avenue, converters of home-furnishing fabrics, died Saturday in French Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 430 West 24th Street.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI)--Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service director, said today that the first result of President Johnson's proposed draft reforms would be to induct all eligible 19-yearolds before anyone else.
LISBON, March 12--For the first time is the Salazar regime, a leader of international Socialism has come to Portugal to bring support to the clandestine Portuguese Socialist Movement.
About 150 people-dowagers, housewives, businessmen, medical students and beatniks-- marched through midtown yesterday, to protest the failure of the Legislature to liberalize the abortion law.
"Unless the head of a familyowned or closely held company takes the time to formally train his successor, his company's lawyer and banker may decide its future on the way home from his funeral."

The Soviet people are going through an "identity crisis" in this fiftieth year after the two revolutions of 1917. This is the hypothesis advanced recently by Princeton's Prof. James H. Billington after his return from a six-month stay in Moscow.
CHICAGO, March 12-- Through a long, arduous day, David Ben-Gurion, Israel's 80year-oid former Premier, played a favorite role today with particular relish, that of a missionary for the Hebrew Bible.
Forecasters of the gross national product generally miss the mark by an average of $10billion, the National Bureau of Economic Research points out in a report issued today.
Mayor Lindsay received on Saturday night the first award given by the Film Producers Association for "outstanding service to the motion picture and television industry."

MOSCOW, March 12--A bald man with a shuffling old man's gait took a walk through crowded Moscow streets today, his wife on his arm. Bystanders greeted him with affection, or at least with deference, and many walked with him.
The city hopes to reach agreement with Federal negotiators in two or three weeks on terms for buying the part of the old Brooklyn Navy Yard owned by the United States.

ST. LOUIS, March 12 (AP) --Three missed free throws by Flynn Robinson of Cincinnati after the final buzzer enabled the St. Louis Hawks to beat the Royals, 120-119, in a National Basketball Association game today.

Step by step greater personal and economic freedoms are emerging in the Soviet Union, Alexander Kerensky said in an interview here marking the 50th anniversary of the start of the revolution that overthrew the Czar in March, 1917.
A Survey on how Roman Catholics in this country look at their church discloses that the "most pressing" problem confronting them is birth control.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 12--After defeating the defending champions in the semi-final round, Oliver Kimberly of New Canaan, Conn., and David Jennings of Wilton, Conn., went on to win the national platform tennis men's doubles championship today at the Fox Meadow Club.
Sukarno brought nationhood to Indonesia and presided over the destiny of the nation for two decades, but his one-man rule ended in a swirl of national difficulties.
SPECULATOR, N.Y., March 12--An economic boom is puttputting into the remote fringes of the Adirondack Forest Preserve these days on the rubber tracks and diminutive skis of the snowmobile.
Five shows were announced yesterday for Broadway production next season. They are "Something Different," "If He Hollers Let Him Go," "A Garland of Figs," "She Haunts Me" and "The Wind Is Ninety."
To the head curator of the New York Botanical Garden, the American tropics is one big store badly in need of an inventory.
TEL AVIV, March 12--An empty freight train was mined near Beersheba this morning and railway service between the Negev and the north was dislocated.

Excitement and surprises, including victories by Rutgers, Virginia Tech and Dayton, highlighted major collegiate tournament basketball action Saturday, as the National Invitation Tournament completed its first round and the National Collegiate championship opened at four sites across the nation.

FRESNO, Calif., March 12-- The California Democratic Council, a federation of Democratic clubs throughout the state, threw its support today to proposals by Senator Robert F. Kennedy of New York for dealing with the war in Vietnam.
PARIS, March 12--Pierre Mends-France is known throughout the world as the Premier who tried to make Frenchmen drink milk.

Dianne and Bruce Tyler of the Princeton (N.J.) Skating Club scored a double victory yesterday in the concluding day's competition of the 45th annual Middle Atlantic figureskating championships at the Iceland Rink atop Madison Square Garden.
James Meredith, who said last week he would run for Congress against Adam Clayton Powell in Harlem, announced early today he was withdrawing from the race.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 12-- Julius Boros received a $23,000 check, the congratulations of Gov. Claude Kirk Jr. of Florida, a new jacket and a large drink of orange juice today for winning the $115,000 Florida Citrus open golf tournament.

The State University of New York, which is fast attracting top academic talent to its 57 campuses, announced yesterday the appointment of four distinguished educators to the new undergraduate college is Westchester and the university center at Stony Brook, L.I.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 12--President Sukarno of Indonesia was "replaced" today by General Suharto, who took the title Acting President and assumed all executive powers.

IN the days of the 10-inch screen almost 20 years ago, television had a program that will never be forgotten by pioneer viewers: the first live close up of the face of Arturo Toscanini as he conducted the N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra. For the mere thousands of set owners at that time it was the realization of the seemingly impossible: being an eyewitness to genius at work.
LONDON, March 12 (AP)-- Two children playing in the streets found 80 pages of confidential telephone numbers of of hundreds of British defense officials, the police reported...
DETROIT, March 12--Jim Ryun returned to the University of Kansas today, probably better off because he lost one of his two big weekend races than he would have been if he had won both.
MINERAL KING, Calif.--In the wilderness of the Sierra Nevada at more than 7,000 feet elevation, two young couples have been living as isolated but busy experience.

Joe Lapchick, the former Knickerbocker and St. John's University basketball coach, and Everett Dean, who coached Stanford in the days of Hank Luisetti, were inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame last night during the annual Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association dinner at the Downtown Athletic Club.
William Schuman, the president of Lincoln Center, received the annual Concert Artists Guild Award at the guild's annual benefit dinner concert last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza Hotel.

Edmund Astley Prentis, a founder and former chief engineer and secretary of Spencer, White Prentis, Inc., engineers and specialists in foundation and subsurface construction, died of a heart ailment yesterday in his home at 2 West 67th Street. His age was 83.
HANOI, North Vietnam, March 12--Midday raids shook windows and walls in the center of the North Vietnamese capital today.

MONTREAL, March 12--An $85-million bridge-tunnel across the St. Lawrence River just east of this city was opened today. The facility is a link between the north-south Route 15 and the east--west Trans-Canada Highway. The north-south highway becomes Interstate Route 87 in New York State.

IN THE early summer of 1966, Harrison E. Salisbury, an assistant managing editor of The New York Times and its for met Moscow correspondent, accompanied by his wife, traveled the perimeter of Communist China, looking for cracks and peepholes into the most populous and perhaps most dangerous nation on earth.
WEST POINT, N.Y., March 12--Newark College of Engineering defeated Army, 27-10, today in the final to win the team title in the sixth annual Eastern Collegiate Judo Association championships.

WHITE PLAINS, March 12-- Ch. Cragmount's Hi-Lo, the striking golden retriever who was this sporting breed's top representative in 1965 and 1966, showed today that he was going to be hard to beat again this year. Best of breed at Westminster, he repeated by taking a purple-and-gold rosette in an entry of 35 at the Saw Mill River Kennel Club fixture at the Westchester County Center.

WASHINGTON, March 12-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the United States Government, in considering the case of Svetlana Alliluyeva, "did'nt actually get to the question of whether she would be accorded political asylum in this country."

Mayor Lindsay proposed a novel solution yesterday to the city's problem of getting money out of the state government at Albany--invasion. A vice admiral of the Navy seconded the idea, and offered a fleet.
MOSCOW, March 12--The Soviet Union broke its silence tonight on the departure of Stalin"s daughter, Svetlana Al liluyeva, and said that the length of her stay abroad was her "private affair."
PITTSBURGH, March 12-- Steel shipments dropped to 6.5 million tons in February.
New York State's Health Commissioner called yesterday for stepped up research to make the cigarette habit "safe if we have to have it, and I believe we do."
President Johnson called upon organized labor yesterday to mobilize public support for his request to Congress for a 20 per cent over-all increase in Social Security benefits.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12--Dan Bosch is a 24year-old San Franciscan who had an ulcer even before he became the center fielder for the New York Mets. He also suffers from a sprained right wrist, has been to bat officially only twice in the big leagues and bears a startling resemblance to Willie Shoemaker.
IT started on a cold Thursday afternoon. The work ing-class women of the Russian capital were desperate for bread to feed their men, and the queues at the bakeries were long and slow.
About 10,000 postal employes gathered yesterday at Central Commercial High School, at 214 East 42d Street, to demand higher pay.

Quality fabrics with fine workmanship offer the American garment industry its "sharpest weapon" in combating foreign-made ready-to-wear apparel, Paul Honig, president of Anglo Fabrics, New York, said at the annual dinner of the Associated Piece Goods Buyers on Saturday.
Mrs. Gladys Garf Steinholz, the wife of Dr. Reuben Steinholz, a pediatrician, died Saturday in her home, 325 West End Avenue. She was 66 years old, and also had a home in Ridgefield, Conn.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 12--The United States lost four jet fighter bombers over North Vietnam yesterday, three of them in the raid on the iron and steel complex at Thainguyen, an American military spokesman said tonight.
Office leasing in Manhattan in February was markedly higher than in January, according to a compilation by Julein J. Studley, Inc., leasing brokers.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 12--Miss Dorothy Halstead, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul K. Halstead, was married this afternoon to Ronald B. Lepoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan S. Lepoff of Philadelphia by Rabbi Morris Kertzer in the Larchmont Temple.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, March 13--Thailand-based United States bombers pounded a North Vietnamese power plant 32 miles from Hanoi yesterday. Pilots reported a series of explosions and fires that sent smoke rising 3,000 feet.
CHICAGO, March 12--A group of Roman Catholic lay leaders plans to ask the hierarchy of the Chicago archdiocese to share with laymen its decision making role in church affairs.
CHILLICOTHE, Ohio, March 12--Charles Allen Smart, author of "RFD," a best-selling book about his life on an Ohio farm, died yesterday in Chillicothe Hospital. He was 62 years old.
Miss Barbara Ellen Newton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Newton of Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to William Franklin Rosenblum Jr., son of Rabbi and Mrs. Rosenblum of New York.

ALL the nymphs who hate been sneaking into barbershops to be shorn like Mia Farrow Sinatra can now bask in the official sanction of the master. Kenneth Battelle, who has often said that lots of hair makes a woman feel important, has taken to his shears. Hair is beginning to fly around his town house salon at 19 East 54th Street.
District Attorney Isidore Dollinger's campaign for election in the Bronx for a third time is expected to begin at a reception late this month being arranged by a group of top labor leaders.

The appointment of Dr. Hannah Arendt, political scientist and author, as University Professor of Philosophy at the New School of Social Research, 66 West 12th Street, was announced yesterday by Dr. John R. Everett, president.

Julius Katchen, the pianist who played all of Brahms's solo piano music at Town Hall last season, performed Brahms's two piano concertos yesterday afternoon with the Washington National Symphony at Philharmonic Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 12-- With the United States having embarked in recent days on an expansion of raids against North Vietnam, some high Defense Department officials are counseling the White House against bombing or mining Haiphong harbor, for the time being at least.
HUE, South Vietnam, March 12--The message came at 2:10 A.M. yesterday. It was three words long.
Geoffrey Atkins of Britain, the world open champion, and Stephen Cox of Chicago, a former United States amateur titleholder, won the national amateur doubles racquets championship yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 12 --Some of the world's leading businessmen arrived here today for the semiannual meeting of the Chase Manhattan Bank International Advisory Committee.

The corporate bond market begins today the biggest week is the biggest month on record. More than $700-million of new bond issues will be offered to investors this week--more than half the total of the previous record for a full month, set last August when interest rates reached a peak not seen in more than 40 years.

The frenzied demand for common stocks on Wall Street that followed President Johnson's request to restore the investment tax credit for business indicated that investors remain confident about the immediate future of the economy. But the President's action and the easing of credit undertaken by the Federal Reserve Board really have bearish rather than bullish implications.

WASHINGTON, March 12-- Attorney General Ramsey Clark said today that he was disturbed that District Attorney Jim Garrison of New Orleans had persisted in his investigation of the Kennedy assassination without turning any new evidence over to the Federal Government.

MIDDLE ISLAND, L.I., March 12--Childe Harold swept to victory in all four classes to win the open jumper championship at the Middle Island Arena horse show today, but it could have been his first and last triumph in the division.
MOSCOW, March 12--The Soviet Union noted quietly to day the 50th anniversary of the collapse of Czarist rule in Russia.

From a baby's cry to a poem written especially for him by Kay Boyle, the Rev. A.J. Muste received a broad spectrum of posthumous tributes yesterday before 700 people at the Village theater at Second Avenue and sixth Street.

The New York Knickerbockers, who could be deprived of playoff money if the National Basketball Association players go through with their threat to strike, continued yesterday on their treadmill toward the financial wasteland of fourth place.
TOKYO, March 12 (AP)-- North Vietnam said United States planes flew over Hanoi today and "rained bombs on the area bordering the Red River, inside the capital."
ALBANY, March 12-The Legislature will enter what could be its final three weeks tomorrow, with most of its work still unfinished.

TORONTO, March 12--The Canadian Government is giving the economy a gentle nudge upward with the weekend announcement that collection of an unusual refundable tax on corporate cash profits will be suspended after this month.

Mrs. Elizabeth Hofmann Dalmani, organist and choir teacher at St. Joseph Patron Roman Catholic Church, 181 Suydam Street, Brooklyn, for 38 years, died Friday in Wyckoff Heights Hospital, Brooklyn. She was 74 years old and lived at 165 Wilson Avenue, Brooklyn.

MIAMI, March 12--Driving to work last year from his home in New Jersey to Yankee Stadium, Jim Bouton would wonder how he was going to "get around" the hitters, how he was going to squeeze through a tough inning with change-up pitches.
Dresser Industries, Inc., which is competing with FMC Corporation for an interest in the Link-Belt Company, raised its bid yesterday.
FRANCONIA, N.H., March 12--Winter returned to the slopes of Cannon Mountain today to provide a frigid backdrop for another sizzling performance by Jean-Claude Killy.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 --Miss Helen Anne Palmatier, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Everett D. Palmatier of Chapel Hill, N.C., was married today to Dr. Theodore S. Tapper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham O. Tapper of Chicago. Rabbi Morris Goodblatt performed the ceremony at the Wynne.

Paul Salmony, a textile manufacturer, died on Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, at the Knollwood Golf Club in Southern Pines, N.C., where he was vacationing with his wife. He was 55 years old and lived at 200 East 57th Street.
Frederic Cohen, composer and former director of the Juilliard Opera Theater, died Friday at the New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 448 Riverside Drive

NEW HAVEN, March 12--In a tradition that he shares with William Howard Taft and Dean Acheson, Mayor Lindsay came back to his alma mater this weekend for a meeting of the Fellows of the Corporation of Yale University.
BOSTON, March 12 (UPI)-- The Boston Bruins got three goals in as many minutes in the first period tonight on the way to a 7-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.
PRAGUE, March 12 (UPI) --Eddy Ottoz of Italy equaled today the world indoor record he set yesterday when he ran the 50-meter high hurdles in 6.4 seconds at the second European indoor games.
TA KHLIT, Thailand, March 10--"You are with the first team today," Col. Robert R. Scott proudly told visitors to this busy air base 110 miles north of Bangkok.

PHILADELPHIA., March 12 Tom Heden of New York won the Middle Atlantic badminton championship today by defeating Colin Orton, an Englishman residing in New York, 15-5, 15-11, at the Wissahickon Badminton Club.
OKLAHOMA CITY, March 12 (AP)--Vice President Humphrey conceded today that the President's proposed Social Security increases were in trouble.
MIAMI BEACH, March 12 (AP)--Widman Harley Davidson of St. Louis, fired a 3,007 series last night to take first place in the regular team division at the American Bowling Congress tournament.

The horse is back in New York today--the thoroughbred race horse, that is. In the earliest opening of the thoroughbred activity in this state, the sport will begin a season that will run, under the supervision of the New York Racing Association, through 234 racing days.
Parents planning to begin a boycott of Public School 125 in Harlem this morning have set up special "liberation schools" nearby for the students.

WASHINGTON, March 12-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk, disagreeing with advocates of a new suspension of the American bombing of North Vietnam, asserted today that suspension would not shorten the war but would be "a way to prolong it indefinitely."
The Worker, the twice-a-week newspaper of the Communist party here, is seeking to raise $1-million in contributions in the hope of coming out five or six days a week.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., March 12--Two men and two women were presumed drowned today after a car in which they were riding plunged into the Passaic River at 1:16 A.M. Two men swam from the car and survived. Two bodies were recovered around noon.
BERNE, March 12--Well-informed sources predicted tonight that Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, would stay in Switzerland for a considerable time, perhaps as long as three months.

WALDWICK, N.J., March 12--Don Rubell of New York, the third-seeded player, swept to a straight-set victory over Tony Vincent, also of New York, in the final of the Eastern indoor tennis championships today at the Bergen Arena. Rubell downed the fourth-seeded Vincent, 6-3, 6-2, 6-4.

FREEPORT, L.I, March 12 --Charles Wald, who flew for the Wright brothers in 1911 and was an inspector of carrierbased Navy planes when he retired in 1949, died of a heart attack yesterday at South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside. He was 85 years old and lived here at 39 Raynor Street.

SLAUGHTER--hideous and horrible--of animals, hu man beings, political systems, social institutions and eventually, of all intelligence is visualized and pawed over beyond any possible theatrical validity, except that of shocking viewers and arousing them with anguish and disgust, in the two-hour color documentary, "Africa Addio" ("Good-bye, Africa"), which opened yesterday at the Forum and the 34th Street East.

"I wish that Good Pope John could see me now--a poor, defenseless Jesuit taking his life in his hands before thousands of Free and Accepted Masons. He would have loved it. This is the way he wanted things to happen.
BERLIN, March 12--The Social Democratic party received a minor setback in elections today in West Berlin but retained a majority of 56.9 pet cent.

"America and Americans," a recently published book by John Steinbeck, in which the author describes his country and his fellow Americans, is being adapted for television by the National Broadcasting Company.
WASHINGTON, March 12-- The Senate ethics committee will begin tomorrow its longawaited public hearings into the financial affairs of Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.
An enthusiastic, predominantly Italian-speaking audience filled Carnegie Hall on Saturday night to greet two popular Italian singers--Claudio Villa and Aura D'Angelo.

Five young composers presented a program of their works at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, and the results were gratifying. The five are William Karlins, Raoul Pleskow, Charles Wuorinen, Ursula Mamlok and Howard Rovics.

Mstislav Rostropovich last night ended his incredible 30-work, eight-concert series at Carnegie Hall with the London Symphony by playing Tchaikovsky's "Variations on a Rococo Theme." As the final note sounded, a tremendous standing ovation began.
The New York Central System will receive President Johnson's "E" Certificate of Export Service, according to an announcement by Alexander B. Trowbridge, acting Secretary of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, March 12-- Mr. and Mrs. Williams Swift Martin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Elizabeth Martin, to Donald Grant Calder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Calder of Garden City, L.I.
BRANDS HATCH, England, March 12 (AP)--Dan Gurney of Costa Mesa, Calif., bettered the track record twice today in winning the three-part Auto Race of Champions.

The New York Stock Exchange announced over the weekend that the volume of trading in individual stocks will no longer be printed on the quotation ticker when the tape runs more than two minutes late and also when it appears that tape lateness would otherwise increase. The change will be effective tomorrow.

Geraldine Farrar left the Metropolitan Opera in 1922. During the last generation she lived quietly in Ridgefield, Conn., virtually a recluse. Yet her fame was undimmed, and her death brought feelings of sorrow and nostalgia to opera lovers everywhere.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, March 12 (Reuters)--Frans Hals's "Flute Player" has disappeared, the painting's owner, Count Maurice de Bendern, reported here today.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 12--Gimbel Brothers and the J.C. Penney Company will occupy large new department stores along a proposed pedestrian mall in downtown Stamford.
Fears were expressed last week that one facet of the fiveyear Federal merchant marine policy program might force the tramp shipping segment of the United States Merchant Marine out of business.
BASEL, Switzerland, March 12 (Reuters)--Britain obtained an extension here today of present international financial arrangements for supporting sterling, informed sources said.

There was a time when all roads led to Rome; now they lead to Washington. In the case of the Cross Brooklyn Expressway, the route is a slow circle embracing the city, the state and the Federal governments. The Interstate Highway System is apparently constructed of miles and miles of tangled red tape.

Senator Jacob K. Javits dismissed as a "trial balloon" yesterday the suggestion that the Democrats name Arthur J. Goldberg, United States delegate to the United Nations, as the candidate to oppose his reelection next year.

NEW DELHI, March 12-- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that her new Government would continue to follow the policies of "democratic Socialism" at home and nonalignment abroad, but would try to improve their implementation.

Vladimir Golschmann, conductor of the Denver Symphony, who has appeared here in recent years only in the now-defunct Stadium Concerts, led the American Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 11 --"Charge it?" Yes, please." These words delight the advocates of a computer-based cashless economy. They vex the defenders of a cash-and-carry society. They interest anyone concerned with credit and inflation.
Players thudded into boards at Madison Square Garden last night, giving a strident leitmotif to the Rangers-Montreal Canadiens game.

It is obviously much too soon to be sure that Ambassador Arthur J. Goldberg will run for the United States Senate in the fall of next year. But he may well decide that he can make his greatest contribution to peace and the building of a secure world order by seeking a change of scene.

BOSTON, March 13--To someone who has always associated Boston with an adjacent and moderately ancient university, a historic tea party and somewhat frosty good manners, the Boston Ballet always comes as a very welcome surprise.

PARIS, March 13--If ever a teetotaler had an excuse to take a drink, Waldeck Emile Rochet, general secretary of the French Communist party, had one last night. On the boulevard outside the offices of the party daily, L'Humanite, the faithful were singing "The Internationale"

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation last year had the highest film rentals and net earnings in the company's history as it is now constituted or since 1952 when its theater business was divested from its film operations.
RADENTON, Fla., March 13--Alvin Dark gazed toward the outfield where Rick Monday was loping along in graceful pursuit of a fly ball. The manager of the Kansas City Athletics smiled contentendly.
FORT BRAGG, N.C., March 13 (UPI)--Groundbreaking ceremonies were held today for a $75,000 memorial to "green beret" soldiers who have been killed in combat.

James J. O'Leary, who has been economist for the Life Insurance Association of America for 20 years, has been chosen chairman and chief economist of Lionel D. Edie Co., Inc., it was learned yesterday.

Irene Hunt, author of "Up a Road Slowly" (Follett), and Evaline Ness, author and illustrator of "Sam, Bangs Moonshine" (Holt, Rinehart Winston), have won the Newbery and Caldecott Medals, given by the American Library Association for the most distinguished children's book published last year.

Arnold J. Toynbee, the 77year-old British historian, began a two-day visit to the State University Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn yesterday with a suggestion that mankind should slow down its social evolution "to a speed that human beings can cope with."
BERNE, March 13--The Swiss Government said today that it had assigned a high Foreign Ministry official to act as companion and consultant to Svetlana Stalin and a police guard "to protect her rest."

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--The Supreme Court ruled today that poor defendants must be provided with lawyers when they make appeals to higher state courts, even if they do not specifically request that aid.

ATLANTA, March 13--Dr. Jane Anne Russell, professor of biochemistry at the Emory University School of Medicine, died of cancer yesterday at Emory University Hospital, She was 56 years old and the wife of Prof. Alfred E. Wilhelmi, head of Emory's department of biochemistry.
ELKINS PARK, Pa., March 13--Miss Susan Sydney Weinberg and Lloyd Feller plan to marry in August.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- Some members of the North Vietnamese air force are training in southern China, well-placed military sources said today.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 13 (AP)--College students have already started streaming into Florida for their annual beach binge.
Investigators at New York Medical College have found that men produce the least amount of sex hormone at night and the most upon awakening in the morning.

The Rev. Brain T. Murphy, a Passionist Father, who was a Roman Catholic chaplain in the Army Air Forces in World War II, died Sunday in Baltimore, where he was stationed at St. Joseph's Monastery. He was 65 years old.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 13--Mis. F.M. Flynn, wife of the publisher of The Daily News in New York, died today in New Rochelle Hospital. Her age was 65 and she lived is Pelham Manor.
The General Motors Corporation asked yesterday for the consolidation of all suits involving Ralph Nader, the auto safety critic, and Vincent Gillen, the detective it hired to trail him.

JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia, March 13--Central Java, long a stronghold of supporters of former President Sukarno, reacted calmly today to the news that he had been formally divested of all powers and honors of the Presidency.
Bud Gilmour's psyche--as well as his veracity--was examined yesterday as the last witnesses testified on Gilmour's appeal to have his license as a harness racing driver renewed.
PARIS, March 13--The Government declared tonight that it had won a one-seat majority in the National Assembly after a recount in Corsica.
The Houston Oil Field Material Company announced last night it had received tenders on more than 100,000 common shares of the Holly Sugar Corporation at $24 a share.
A special meeting of Actors Equity next month will give members a chance to air grievances about the number of foreign performers working on Broadway.
EAST LONDON, South Africa, March 13 (UPI)--A South African Airways Viscount airliner crashed into the Indian Ocean near this port tonight, apparently killing all 25 persons aboard.
Industrial issues on the London Stock Exchange advanced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 13 --The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has proposed a simplification and slight liberalization of its rules setting minimum down payments on mortgage loans made by insured savings and loan associations.

Twenty-five sign-bearing actors and technicians will march silently in front of the White House today to call attention to the financial plight of small repertory companies throughout the country. The marchers will represent the Morris Repertory Company of Morristown, N.J., which must raise a total of $25,000 by Sunday or close.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- Robert C. Weaver, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, asserted today that Gov. George Romney of Michigan misunderstood the Administration's approach to slum problems.

WASHINGTON, March. 13 (AP)--President Johnson, an pounced today that Gen. Paul L. Freeman Jr. will retire July 1 as commanding general, United States Continental Army Command, Fort Monroe, Va., and will be replaced by Lieut. Gen. James K. Woolnough.

NEW DELHI, March 13--The central Government imposed Presidential rule on the troubled state of Rajasthan today, bringing it temporarily under direct rule from New Delhi.

BUFFALO, March 13 (AP) --Keith Lincoln, an outstanding fullback for the San Diego Chargers until last season, was traded today to the Buffalo Bills, the American Football League's Eastern champions. WASHINGTON, March 13-- High Administration officials said today it had been the intention all along to restore the 7 per cent tax subsidy for business investment ahead of the scheduled date of Jan. 1 next year.

The winner in the five-horse field that competed in the $27,200 Swift Stakes was Guy Burt's Solo Landing, who beat Allen Kennedy's Sun Gala, the runnerup by 5 lengths.

The La Guardia Terrace Restaurant at the La Guardia Airport is Flushing, Queens, will give a pre-Easter party at 1:30 P.M. Thursday for the benefit of the children at the La Guardia Memorial House, a community center here.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--Mrs. Georgia Neese Gray, the former Georgia Neese Clark, first woman Treasurer of the United States, today became the first woman chairman of the Small Business Administration's National Advisory Council. I

RYE, N.Y., March 13--Miss Penelope Dammann and William G. Swartchild 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Swartchild Jr. of Chicago, plan to marry in June.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)--The Supreme Court ruled today that the Interstate Commerce Commission had the authority to compel raliroads to establish equal rates to competing ports despite differences in distance.

KINSHASHA, the Congo, March 13--Former Premier Moise Tshombe was sentenced to death in absentia today by a three-man special military court. He was charged with high treason, subversive propaganda, inciting and organizing rebellion and recruiting foreign mercenaries for use against the Congo.
CHICAGO, March 13 (AP) --A major snow battered the Far West for the third straight day today.

A $200-million lease for office space--the largest such commitment ever made by a business concern in the city's history--was signed yesterday by the Chase Manhattan Bank for 22 floors in a 50-story skyscraper that will rise near the Battery.

The State Public Service Commission said here yesterday that a revised set of safety procedures submitted by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company following a Jamaica, Queens, gas explosion Jan. 13 were "not satisfactory."

The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers has announced an annual series of prizes for American writers on musical subjects. The prizes will be called the ASCAP-Deems Taylor Awards, in honor of Mr. Taylor, the composer, critic and commentator who died last year at the age of 81.

PITTSBURGH, March 13-- Peter Muller-Munk, 63 years old, one of the world's foremost designers of industrial products, was found dead in his car in the garage of his home today. His death was ruled a suicide caused by acute carbon monoxide poisoning.
Robert Wolbach, chairman of the art department at Lafayette High School in Brooklyn, died Friday in Roosevelt Hospital of a heart attack. He was 58 years old and lived at 30 West 48th Street.

The pro football draft, which is going to tell 445 college players what teams they can hope to play for next season, begins this morning at 10 o'clock in the Hotel Gotham, which will serve as headquarters. Ted Gilien, an artist and art teacher, died of a heart attack Saturday in Los Angeles, where he had lived since 1945. He would have been 53 years old Friday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13 (UPI)--Ralph Ginzburg, a New York publisher, lost another bid today for a hearing on the reconsideration or reduction of his five-year prison sentence for sending obscene material through the mails.
Alexander Aldrich, the executive director of the Hudson River Valley Commission, called on the state yesterday to acquire $10-million worth of unspecified property in the Hudson Valley.

A boycott by Negro and white parents kept most children out of Public School 125 in West Harlem yesterday. The parents, who are demanding a voice in the school's operation, said that the protest would continue for as long as is necessary.
BIMINI, the Bahamas, March 13--Adam Clayton Powell said today that he would return to New York on Sunday, despite the threat of arrest. He said he had been away from the city too long.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--The Supreme Court ruled today that savings obtained by natural gas companies through the filing of consolidated Federal income tax re-... turns must be passed on to consumers in the form of lower rates.

NORTHPORT, L.I., March 13--Ernest A. Oliver, a retired vice president of the George J. Meyer Manufacturing Company, maker of packaging equipment, died today in his home at 64 Mariners Lane. He was 83 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- House Republican leaders expressed concern today that threats of violence might have caused Mr. Meredith to withdraw from the Harlem Congressional race.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--Dr. Marshall L. Rosenbluth of the University of California, San Diego, one of the scientific who helped develop the hydrogen bomb, was named tonight as winner of the $5,000 Albert Einstein Award for 1967.

SEATTLE, March 13--Art Price and Richard Lawrence of Ann Arbor, Mich., were surprise winners of the Men's Pair event in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here last night. None of the other contending pairs was able to score well in the final session, and their total of 824 unexpectedly proved sufficient for victory.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 13 (AP)--Gov. George Romney of Michigan, a potential candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1968, said tonight that he believes a lottery system for drafting youths would be superior to the present system.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide the constitutionality of a controversial New York "stop and frisk" law that gives the police the right to search suspicious-looking persons in public places.
DETROIT, March 13--Supporters of Walter P. Reuther said today that Trotskyite influence was behind some recent opposition to him within the United Auto Workers of which he is president.
Sharply reduced annual sales and earnings were reported yesterday by the Lever Brothers Company, a major producer of soaps, detergents, household cleaners and food products.
JERSEY CITY, March 13-- Six hundred more students in three Jersey City high schools cut classes this morning and staged a citywide demonstration against curtailment of their Easter vacation.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--The Defense Department made public tonight a list of Vietnam casualties that included 52 men killed in action.

NEW ORLEANS, March 13-- The public could get its first look tomorrow at what District Attorney Jim Garrison says is a conspiracy case involving the assassination of President Kennedy.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 13 --Charges of employment discrimination against the Campbell Soup Company were filed today in the United States District Court by 24 Negroes. The company denied the accusation.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) Pentagon figures showed today that the number of soldiers going A.W.O.L.-- asbent without leave--has clmbed steadily in the mid1960's in the Army's buildup for Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, March 13The United States and Canada have agreed that there will be no increase in tolls on the St. Lawrence Seaway for at least four years, the State Department announced today.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 13 --The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors voted unanimously today against the establishment of a metropolitan-area jetport anywhere in the county.

LIBERTY, Miss., March 13 (UPI)--A bomb heavily damaged a local Head Start office early today and fires destroyed a Negro church and an antipoverty headquarters in Lownden County, Ala.

NORWALK, Conn., March 13 --Charles C. Haas, a former hat company executive and civic leader here, died yesterday. He was 75 years old and lived at 18 Pershing Street.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- The House Appropriations Committee, declaring that peace in Vietnam is not in sight, voted an extra $12.2-billion today to finance rising war costs between now and June 30.
Excavation work has begun for a 40-story skysraper that will be the first major building to be erected in the Herald Square area in many years.

LOS ANGELES, March 13--Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon has authorized the establishment of a national "Nixon for President Committee" with headquarters in Washington. The move, disclosed today while Mr. Nixon was traveling in Germany, was assessed in political circles here as a significant step in his putative bid for the Republican nomination in 1968.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- Arthur J. Goldberg declined to say "yes" and avoided saying "no" today to a proposal that he run for the Senate in New York.

The American Can Company, one of the big corporations that recently announced plans to move from the city, has bought a 140-acre tract in Greenwich, Conn., for a new international executive headquarters.

Harold Konigsberg, a convicted extortionist, went on trial in State Supreme Court yesterday to have a jury determine whether he had been convited of two earlier felonies.
John P. Schlick was elected yesterday as executive vice president in charge of administration for U.S. PlywoodChamnion Papers, Inc.
TRENTON, March 13 (AP) --The New Jersey Blue Shield was granted a 12 per cent rate increase today--half of what it had asked for.

OTTAWA, March 13--Senator Alexander Neil McLean of New Brunswick died last night at his home in Saint John. He was 81 years old.

BUENOS AIRES, March 13-- The Government devalued the Argentine peso today by 40 per cent, raising the official rate from the fornler level of 255 pesos to the dollar to a new level of 350 to the dollar.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 13--Prof. Albert J. Paquin Jr., chairman of the urology department at the University of Virginia Medical School, died of a heart, attack in his home here today. His age was 46.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Senators investigating the antipoverty drive found today that some persons with a desire to escape poverty would not settle for a guaranteed annual income paid by the Government.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 13--Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson began today a 1,500mile exploration of new avenues of learning.

The Columbia Broadcasting System said last night that it had suspended its free spot announcements for Radio Free Europe because the advertisements did not make it clear that the organization was an arm of the Central Intelligence Agency.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 13--The United States' attack on North Vietnam yesterday was the heaviest air raid in four months, an American military spokesman said tonight. The period he mentioned marked the duration so far of the monsoon rains in the north.

Ralph C. Gross, executive vice president of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., since 1961, was named president and a director of the group yesterday at the annual meeting of its board of directors. He will continue as administrative head of the association in charge of all staff operations.

No significant progress was made yesterday in settling they dispute that could cause cancellation of the National Basketball Association playoffs. The club owners had set noon today as the deadline for a guarantee that the players intended to participate in the competition scheduled to starts a week from today. Instead, in a series of meetings over the weekend, each team voted unanimously to stick by its strike threat.
ENUGU, Nigeria, March 13-- The military governor of Nigeria's Eastern Region warned today that his region would secede if invaded or blockaded by the Federal Government.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 14 (AP)-- Senator Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, said today that there was a possibilitly he could talk with representatives of the Vietcong and North Vietnam while he is visiting Cambodia.

LONDON, March 13--A $12-million contract to print and publish the world's largest book catalogue--in 600 volumes --has been given by a committee of the American Library Association to a British publishing company here.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 13--The unbeaten New York Mets knocked off the Boston Red Sox, 5-3, today for their third victory, and reached a pinnacle that no other Met team had scaled. Before last year, the club had never won any opening game. Last year it won twice before stumbling. And now three.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- The Administration apparently cleared the way today for Senate approval of the Outer Space Treaty by agreeing to language clarifying what some Senators found to be "fuzzy" provisions in the treaty.
HONG KONG, March 13-- China's peasants have been told not to participate in the present power struggle between rival factions during the period of spring cultivation.
A Bronx minister, handcuffed and wearing a fur-collared overcoat, was brought to the Bronx Court House yesterday and charged with stealing $7,760 in antipoverty funds.
MOSCOW, March 13 (AP) --The day after the revolution that overthrew Czarism in Russia, a newspaper appeared in the capital, Petrograd, called Izvestia of the Petrograd Soviet of Workers Deputies.

Bargaining in the Kennedy Round of negotiations to liberalize world trade promises to be extremely lively over the next few weeks. The 53 participating nations have agreed to complete their work by April 30 so the pacts can be put into required legal form before June 30, when the Trade Expansion Act giving tariff-cutting authority to the President runs out.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- The American Newspaper Guild announced today that it was completely severing its relationship with foundations believed to be conduits for funds from the Central Intelligence Agency.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 100.6 on Friday from 100.7.

NEW HAVEN, March 13-- Miss Margaret Arnstein, chief of nursing for the United States Public Health Service from 1960 to 1966, has been appointed dean of the Yale School of Nursing, Kingman Brewster Jr., president of Yale, announced today.

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, March 12--A new agreement to form an anti-Egyptian front between Yemeni royalists and dissident republicans is causing divisions in the royalist ranks although it has been approved by leading members of the royal family.
Led by George Stone's 46point performance, Marshall University of West Virginia set a National Invitation Tournament scoring record last night in beating Nebraska, 119-88.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 13--Secretary General Thant will visit five Asian countries, including India and Pakistan, next month, it was announced today.
The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for banknotes at New York. These rates do not apply to regular exchange business transacted by banks.

NORMAN, Okla., March 13 (AP)--Acknowledging "some difference" with President Johnson on Vietnam, Senator Robert F. Kennedy called again today for ending United States bombing of North Vietnam to encourage peace negotiations.
A statistical analysis of the health problems of men employed at sea shows that injuries and illnesses decline as jobs increase.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- The health gap between Negroes aad whites is widening despite increased Federal aid and steady advances in medical science; two New York public health officers reported today.
WASHINGTON, March 13--A recent study or television commercials indicates that one of the foremost physical problems confronting Americans these days is dry skin.
WASHINGTON, March 13Senator Thomas J. Dodd used $28,588 of the proceeds from a testimonial dinner in 1965 to repay money he had borrowed to pay his Federal income taxes.
LONDON, March 13--The Bank of England announced today the renewal of international stand-by credit arrangements to support the pound.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 13--"I still make jokes in the clubhouse, kid around with the fans, but I'm a more serious ballplayer now," said Joe Pepitone. "I know I'm of more value to the club, I'm in a position to make more money, and if I come up with a good year I can own New York."
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--President Johnson announced today the assignment of Aimy Lieut. Gen. Bruce Palmer Jr. as commanding general of the Second Field Force in South Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)--Secretary of State Dean Rusk urged the Senate today not to attach any strings to the Soviet-American consular treaty. If it is not approved as negotiated, he said Moscow may reject it.

ALBANY, March 13--The Assembly, many of its members groaning in boredom and others nodding at their desks, crawled through one of its heaviest calendars in recent years today and passed a number of relatively minor bills.

TEL AVIV, March 13--Prof. Moshe Stekelis, credited with the retrieval of 40,000 archeological items, including four stone-age skeletons, died in Jerusalem yesterday while making arrangements for another large-scale expedition. He was 69 years old.

THOSE two novels from abroad, one by a young English writer, the other by a Dutch painter and novelist, differ not only in theme and approach but also in surface texture and in the light and shadow in which their characters are revealed.
IRVINGTON, N.Y., March 13--Ellsworth R. Littler, a realestate man, died here yesterday of bronchial pneumonia. He was 66 years old.

Antiquarians, bibliophiles, museum curators, sponsors and directors of historic restorations were among nearly 100 guests honoring Mrs. Katharine Prentis Murphy, whore 85th birthday was celebrated last night at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel.

ALBANY, March 13--Democratic and Republican leaders said today that they were nearing agreement on a type of organization for the Constitutional Convention that could lead to the drafting of a simplified Constitution for the state.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 (UPI)--West Coast shipyard workers returned to work today, ending a 129-day work stoppage brought about by an electricians' strike.
The spot rate on the British pound renewed a firm trend yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.

Nerine Barrett, the 23-yearold Jamaican pianist who made her New York debut last night in the Young Concert Artists Series at Carnegie Recital Hall, played with a musical maturity that many pianists twice her age might envy.

The Monsanto Company announced yesterday price changes on several products. The company said that effective July 1, it was raising prices 25 cents per 100 pounds of sodium tripolyphosphate of light and medium density in granular grades.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 13 (AP)--Executives of the McDonnell Company were charged today with bad faith in a court suit that said they bought stock in the Douglas Aircraft Company while merger talks with Douglas were in progress.

CHICAGO, March 13 (AP)-- Oscar Robertson, hitting 14 of 18 field-goal attempts and 15 consecutive free throws, led the Cincinnati Royals to a 133117 victory over the Chicago Bulls tonight and a third-place tie with the New York knickerbockers in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association.
The credit markets exhibited yesterday--as they often do on Mondays--crosscurrents that made it difficult to discern any over-all trend for interest rates and prices of fixed-income securities.
James Meredith, the target of much abuse as a candidate, was hailed as a hero in Harlem yesterday after pulling out of the race against Adam Clayton Powell.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, New York's largest bank, warned yesterday that there might be a "marked increase" in the United States' international payments deficit during 1967. The bank said, however, that the higher deficit would probably not be accompanied by a corresponding increase in drains on the United States gold stock.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 13 (Reuters)--Sir Frank Worrell, former outstanding player and captain of the West Indies test cricket teams, died in University Hospital here today of leukemia. He was 42 years old.

Steel production dropped for the second week in a row in the seven days ended Saturday, and as a result cumulative 1967 output lagged further behind that of the comparable period last year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- Administration spokesmen went out of their way today to emphasize what they said was the routine nature of President Johnson's meeting with his advisers on Vietnam next week in Guam.
OKLAHOMA CITY, March 13 --Vice President Humphrey promised a skeptical farm audience here today that the Administration would eliminate the "prosperity gap."
Legislation designed to place the city's century-old Health Department under the jurisdiction of the state Health Department was protested yesterday by city officials.

NEW ORLEANS--A phenomenally successful restaurant in the vicinity of New Orleans is neither Freneh nor Creole but Italian. It is the Elmwood Plantation, about 18 miles from the heart of the city. The word phenomenal is used advisedly because, vast though the restaurant is, reservations must be made a day or so in advance.

In 1960, an expedition led by Professor Stekelis discovered the remains of a very early human creature. The find was on the west bank of the Jordan River at Afiqim, two miles south of the Sea of Galilee.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 13--Manager Bill Rigney feels that two more starting pitchers are all his California Angels need for a flight into the upper echelon of the American League.

MIAMI, March 13--There is little doubt Miami would rate high on a list of cities oriented to water recreation. Its boat facilities are superb. The city and its environs sit on some of the best fishing, boating and diving water to be found anywhere.
Mayor Lindsay's proposal to merge the City Housing Authority into the Housing and Development Administration came under fire yesterday from a Republican member of the authority. Francis V. Madigan.
Choong Hoon Park, South Korea's Minister of Commerce and Industry, likened his country yesterday to "a Vietnam" that had built with American help one of Asia's most rapidly developing economies.
ROSELAND, 239 West 52d Street. Raye and Roman, Cars and Desi, Allegro and Troy, dance acts, and Pedro and Olga, dance demonstration.

PALO ALTO, Calif., March 13--The Radio Corporation of America moved into computerbased education today in a major way with an announcement here by its president, Robert W. Samoff, of a program for individualized teaching in schools and colleges.

Henry James had an honor paid to him yesterday which he coveted in his lifetime. A plaque was placed on New York University's Brown Building in Washington Place, proclaiming that this was the site of the novelist's birth.

MANILA, March 12--The Philippine Government, prodded, coaxed and led by President Ferdinand E. Marcos, is fighting a critical battle to overcome the complex social and economic problems impeding the economic and political development of the republic.
MIAMI BEACH, March 13 (UPI)--A member of the record-breaking Pinky's Bowl team of Milwaukee jumped into first place in the regular all-events division today at the American Bowling Congress.
The Chappaqua-Mount KiscoPleasantvilie chapter of Hadassah will hold an art exhibition and sale on April 9 and 10 at Pace College's Westchester campus in Pleasantville, N.Y.
OTTAWA, March 13 (Canadian Press)--Canada's foreign aid program will be trimmed slightly, the Government forecast today in presenting spending estimates to the House of Commons.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- Events of the past few weeks leave little doubt that the Johnson Administration has set out upon a course of steadily increasing its military pressure on North Vietnam.

NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania, March 13--The drivers of nine sand yachts who have crossed the Sahara Desert sighted the Atlantic Ocean today for the first time, a month after setting sail from Colomb-Bechar, Algeria.
The Lillian R. Spector League of the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital will hold a 30th-anniversary dinner dance Saturday at the St. Regis Roof. The league will honor Mrs. Estelle Langs.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- The resumption of House hearings disclosed today a widening split among Westerners over plans to dam the Colorado River in the Grand Canyon.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 13--Algeria rejected today Morocco's request to Secretary General Thant that the United Nations investigate an alleged arms race between the two countries.

CAPETOWN, March 13-- South Africa signed a trade pact with Malawi here today, its first formal agreement with an independent black African state since the Nationalist Government came to power 19 years ago.
Mayor Lindsay put off a decision yesterday on whether to approve a series of five milkcontrol bills passed by the City Council with the objective of cutting retail prices 3 cents a quart.

The Police Department has expanded its force in the Bronx by 541 men, giving the borough more than double its normal share of new recruits because its felony cases have been rising faster than in any other borough.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- President Johnson urged Congress today to approve a commitment to increase aid to Latin America by $1.5-billion over the next five years, or by 30 per cent annually.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- Yields on the new issues of Treasury bills dropped somewhat further this week, following last week's large declines.
A spirited rise in prices of wheat futures yesterday indicated new bullish sentiment, and the upturn set off a general increase in prices of other major food commodities, such as corn and soybeans.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--The Supreme Court rejected today Louisiana's assertion that the state was exempt from key provisions of the 1965 voting rights law.

MADRID, March 13--Memsries of Guernica, the town whose destruction by Nazi fliers in the Spanish Civil War was immortalized by Pablo Picasso, were starkly revived today in a dark, crowded Madrid courtroom.

JACKSON, Miss., March 13 (UPI)--Leontyne Price, smiling and breathless after three encores before a packed house here, said she was overwhelmed by the response to her yesterday from an integrated audience.
The District Attorney's office charged in Criminal Court yesterday that some slogans on lapel buttons seen around town were "dirty" rather than "social comments."
Stokely Carmichael, an advocate of black power, was classified 4-F by his draft board last night.
A promising start gave way to losses yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 13--Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert H. Durbin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Ann Durbin, to Dr. Oliver Quentin Hyder, son of Dr. Aoland I. Hyder and Dr. Louise S. Hyder of Ipswich, England.
PALM SPRINGS, Calf., March 13 (AP)--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today Gov. Ronald Reagan would "make his own decision" about seeking the Republican nomination for President.
Braulio Baeza, a Band-Aid covering the incision on his recently broken collarbone, had returned in what the handicappers refer to as "the
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--The Treasury will seek Congressional permission soon to stop paying off silver-certificate paper money in actual silver.
Labor troubles, in the form of "quickie" crew strikes, continue to plague Italian Line passenger vessels.

New-car sales fell sharply in the first 10 days of March, but there is some indication that a little light may be creeping into the black picture that has characterized the automobile industry so far this year.

A spokesman for the McDonnell Company in St. Louis denied allegations made Yesterday in a suit by Gerda Bubolz alleging that directors had personally bought Douglas stock and made personal profits from it.
Two man were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of burning their draft cards in a cafeteria in protest of the Vietnam war.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- The Supreme Court ruled today that the right to a speedy trial, as guaranteed in Federal courts by the Sixth Amendment to the United State Constitution, is also binding on state courts.
TRENTON, March 13--Any chance for a study of New Jersey's century-old abortion law was killed today at the request of Gov. Richard J. Hughes and the Democratic legislative leadership.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 13--Russell Rash, a 29-yearold driver from Felton, Del., was thrown over the head of the 6-year-old pacer he was driving Crescent Chief, when the horse stumbled near the end of Roosevelt Raceway's third race tonight.
President Johnson warned Senator Robert F. Kennedy last month that his political career would end rapidly if he maintained his stance on Vietnam, the magazine Time reported yesterday.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 13 (AP)--Brooks Robinson, the Baltimore Orioles' all-star third baseman, was beaned tonight in the fourth inning of an exhibition baseball game between the Orioles and the Atlanta Braves. He appeared to have escaped serious injury.
While thousands of persons bustled ground the New York Hilton Hotel yesterday morning, a well-dressed young gunman quietly staged a robbery and got away with $20,000 cash and $80,000 in checks.
Vincent M. Petrilli named research director for Young Rubicam, Inc. branch offices

J. Raymond Jones was reported yesterday to have reigned as Manhattan Democratic leader because Reformers aligned with Senator Robert F. Kennedy had seriously undermined his leadership and because the Senator had been "waging continuous war" against him.
CANADA TOWNSHIP, N.C., March 14--Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson saw today how a new Federal program, the National Teacher Corps, is reaching into a remote hamlet of mountainous western North Carolina.

WASHINGTON, March 14 --Mrs. Marjorie Merri weather Post's 80th birthday isn't until tomorrow, but some of the Postum heiress's best friends decided not to wait. They gave an elegant little reception for her today at the Sulgrave Club.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)--About 20 costumed ac tors and actresses from New Jersey picketed the White House today to appeal for a Government subsidy to keep their theater alive.

LONDON, March 14--Ballet Rambert introduced something new to the British dance world tonight. Not just a dance workshop--we have had those before --but a full scale collaboration between young choreographers and designers to help develop their skills.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 14--Favorite-fanciers among the 15,964 harness racing buffs at Roosevelt Raceway tonight probably had visions of every chalk-player's dream--a sweep of the card--after the first three choices had sped home in the first three races.
THERE appears to be no question but that Federal authorities are looking askance at the proposed merger between Bendix Corporation and Corporation.
The appointment of Alfred Maskin as director of the legislative, research and public relations activities of the American Maritime Association in Washington was announced here yesterday.
BREMEN, Germany, March 14 (AP)--A former Nazi guard, Philipp Mensinger, was sentenced to life imprisonment today for the murder of Jews in World War II.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- That private confrontation on Vietnam between President Johnson and Robert F. Kennedy on Feb. 6 was portrayed today as not exactly friendly but as less than a profane shouting match.

Bullish sentiment pushed up wheat futures yesterday by as much as 2 cents a bushel during the session. But by the end of the day, the fervor abated enough to trim prices to a range of only 1/8 to cents a bushel ahead of Monday.
LAGOS, Nigeria, March 14 --Nigeria's supreme commander, Lieut. Col. Yabuku Gowon, warned today that he would deal severely with the Eastern "butcher the Constitution."
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)--The larger-than-lifesize shadow of the Surveyor 1 spacecraft, sitting on the moon, has been photographed by Lunar Orbiter 3.
LONDON, March 14--Britain's trading deficit was cut in February to 3-million ($8.4million).
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 14 (AP)--Harvard University will hold a seminar April 4 on how to make a good cup of coffee.
