BASTIA, Corsica, March 14 --An epidemic of sickness that strikes many Corsicans at election time may cost the de Gaulle regime its majority in the National Assembly.

A STRONG team of Mustang drivers, headed by Jerry Titus of Sherman Oaks, Calif., has been entered in the four-hour Trans-American sedan race to be run at Sebring, Fla., on March 31. This contest, the second in a series of 11 for the Sports Car Club of America's manu-...

As part of New York's campaign to increase film production here, Mayor Lindsay and the city's Office of Cultural Affairs are sponsoring a festival of New York films at the Regency Theater, Broadway at 67th Street, April 2-5.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 14--The engagement of Princess Benedikte to Prince Richard Casimir Karl August Robert Zu Sayn Wittgenstein Berleburg of Germany was made known today.
Louis R. Harolds, an admiralty lawyer who was active in the American Trial Lawyers Association, died of cancer yesterday in University Hospital, His age was 54.

The National and American Football Leagues conducted their first common draft yesterday at the Gotham Hotel, a staid, high-ceilinged landmark off Fifth Avenue where the room clerk wears a dinner jacket before dark.

The city's first billion-dollar capital budget was approved yesterday, but not before Mayor Lindsay had accused the Board of Estimate of having met in a rump session to vote an "unjustified" $750,000 planning fund for the Borough Presidents.

LYNCHBURG, Va., March 14 --Negroes filled a city courtroom and overflowed in a noisy crowd on Court Street today as Lynchburg, for the third time since 1963, began an effort to impose the death penalty against a 21-year-old Negro dishwasher accused of raping a white spinster and a Japanese housewife.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- The State Department acknowledged today that Stalin's daughter, Svetlana, had requested political asylum in the United States before taking refuge in Switzerland.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 14--John Bayley O'Brien, who retired in 1944 as a staff writer for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died yesterday at Lawrence Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 25 Parkview Avenue.
Films made by painters and sculptors will be presented on six Sunday afternoons starting next Sunday in the Warburg Auditorium of the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue.

LONDON--Britain is not offering its nuclear deterrent for admission to the Common Market nor is France, which collects the tickets, any longer interested in British atomic weapons as a price. This is a basic difference between current negotiations and those conducted with de Gaulle five years ago by Prime Minister Macmillan.

SAN DIEGO--Almost every morning at 9:50, just as the employes of the Walker Scott Company, a department store here, are making their final preparations before the doors are opened to customers, a recorded hymn is played over the loudspeaker system for a few minutes.
OAKLAND, Calif., March 14 (AP)--Alice Tisdale Hobart, the author, died at her home today after a long illness. She was 85 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- The first nationwide effort to bring together Federal, state and local governments in a broad search for jobs for minority groups was announced today by the Equal Employment Opportunities Commission.

ST.-GERMAIN-EN-LAYE, France, March 14--American and French flags were lowered at the United States' European Command headquarters today, formally marking the departure of United States troops from France, as ordered by President de Gaulle.

NEWARK, March 14--The utility that supplies power to 80 per cent of New Jersey customers announced today a program for "substantially" reducing air pollution from its fuel burning operations.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 14--"Spring training games mean nothing at all," Ralph Houk says. "You don't play to win, you play to see what your players can do, to get your club into condition. It's just that you hate to lose them."

After nearly two months of debate, the 12 New York motion picture production unions have agreed to support Mayor Lindsay's one-year experiment designed to renew the city's importance as a feature-film production center.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 14-- It took three of the top pitchers in the American League, plus nine innings, before the Minnesota Twins could gain a 1-0 victory and send the New York Mets to their first defeat of the spring today.
Mayor Lindsay disclosed last night a plan to streamline the city's budgeting procedures and bring them into line with his proposals for a sweeping reorganization of the city government.
The managements of the P. Lorillard Company and Schenley Industries, Inc., announced last night an agreement in principle to consolidate their companies.

Hawks Top Bulls, 111-98, With Rally in Last Period CHICAGO, March 14 (UPI) --The St. Louis Hawks scored 11 consecutive points at the start of the final period tonight and went on to post a 111-98 triumph over the Chicago Bulls in a National Basketball Association game.

A fantastic chase is now under way in the Swiss Alps as hundreds of reporters, photographers, publishers' representatives and, presumably, intelligence agents seek to locate the elusive Svetlana Stalin. Already this pursuit has produced scenes worthy of a James Bond farce, but there are serious issues involved.
The American Stock Exchange underwent another late sinking spell yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- The Johnson Administration pressed Congress today for prompt restoration of special tax benefits for business, but also renewed arguments for a general tax increase later this year.
A new stage in Brazil's revolution begins today with the inauguration of President Costa e Silva.

More than 5,000 American men have been cosmetically cured of baldness by submitting to the painstaking and sometimes painful grafting of hairs from the backs of their necks to their scalps, a University of Arkansas dermatologist said yesterday.

The Container Corporation of America was granted a patent yesterday for a process that it says eliminates the pollution of streams from waste "liquor" produced by the manufactures of pulp and paper mills.
The election of Joel J. Pawe as a vice president of E. Rene Frank Associates has been announced by the international real estate concern.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- Bruce Bromley of New York City, a former judge of the New York Court of Appeals, was retained today to defend the House of Representatives against a suit by Adam Clayton Powell.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- President Johnson gave Premier Chung II Kwon of South Korea assurance today that the United States would modernize the military equipment of Korean forces fighting in South Vietnam and defending South Korea at home.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- The Senate decisively rejected today a move by conservative Republicans to attach a restrictive reservation to the consular treaty with the Soviet Union.
MIAMI, March 14 (UPI)-- Gov. Claude Kirk said today that his private police force had smashed a $780,000-a-year narcotics ring and made seven arrests.
Is the machinery for training American surgeons threatened by the Federal programs that seek to make medical treatment available to all?

Controversy and criticism have erupted over the proposed housing maintenance code now before the City Council, but a highly praised companion measure that has been waiting much longer hasn't even seen the light of day. The city's new building code, which was supposed to speed and simplify construction and reduce costs, still is just a blueprint--all 1,400 pages of it.

THE names of the towns where the wines of Alsace are pro duced sound engagingly like something from a Rhineside operetta. There is Ammerschwihr, Goxwiller and Riquewihr; Molsheim, Bergheim and Sigolsheim, not to mention Voegtlinshoffen and Guebwiller.

DANCERS perform on the edge of a precipice. There are times when the dangers they run make the mere spectator feel very humble. Last night at the New York City Center, Nels Jorgensen was dancing, as usual, the central male role in Robert Joffrey's "Pas de Deesses."

The spot rate on the British pound eased yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here, ending its recent sustained rise. The closing quotation of $2.7961 was 5 points below the final rate on Monday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 15--The enemy hit the big American air base at Danang today with his biggest weapon of the war, Soviet-made 140-mm. rockets, and wounded 19 American servicemen, the United States command reported.

In saying that its request for restoration of the 7 per cent investment tax credit was planned all along, the Johnson Administration is coming close to suggesting that it knows just what is happening and what will happen to the economy.
LONGHUU ISLAND, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 15 --Premier Nguyen Cao Ky disclosed today that he would fly to Guam this weekend for a mid-Pacific conference with President Johnson next week.
PARIS, March 14--Premier Georges Pompidou said today that he would not resign despite the closeness of Sunday's election for the National Assembly.
The lawyer for William D. (Bud) Gilmour, the harness racing driver, obtained a recess yesterday until next Monday in his hearing before the State Harness Racing Commission to get new evidence.
A green and yellowish-white library bookmobile is bringing a country touch to mid-Manhattan.

JERUSALEM (Israel), March 14--Two magazine editors who were secretly sentenced to oneyear prison terms for having violated security laws are to be freed next month by order of President Zalman Shazar.

NEW ORLEANS, March 14-- A life insurance agent who previously denied that he had ever met Lee Harvey Oswald prior to the assassination of President Kennedy testified today that he had heard Oswald and two New Orleans men plot to kill the President.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)--President Johnson will address a joint session of the Tennessee legislature tomorrow, visit the homes of two Tennesseans who became President and take part in the dedication of a new college.
PARIS, Ky., March 14 (AP) --Eighteen thoroughbred yearings were killed tonight in a fire that destroyed a 20-stall barn at Claiborne Farm near here.
CHELSEA, Mass., March 14 (UPI)--A wife received a telephone call yesterday from her "dead" husband. The Navy confirmed today that he was alive.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday plans to spend about $285million to increase its capacity to make electric power generlating equipment.

About 1,300 pupils stayed out of Public School 125 in West Harlem yesterday as a boycott by parents went into its second day.

Charles (Bubba) Smith, a 6foot-7-inch giant who looked down upon the athletes he played with and against at Michigan State, was the first college football player selected by the professionals yesterday as the American and National Leagues began their common draft with headquarters in the Gotham Hotel.

DUBLIN, March 14 (UPI)-- Eighty-six farmers, jailed during recent farmers' protests over Government agricultural policies, were released unexpectedly today after their militant National Farmers Association promised to call off demonstrations.

The Bunge Corporation, a large commodity importer and exporter, agreed yesterday to a consent judgment on a complaint filed by the State of New York that charged the company "knew but didn't reveal to proper authorities" that there were huge shortages of soybean oil at storage tanks in New Jersey.

Richard Strauss composed a self portrait in "Ein Heldenleben" (A Hero's Life) but a new biographer does not accept the self-assessment. George R. Marek calls his book, which Simon Schuster will issue on April 3, "Richard Strauss: The Life of a Non-Hero."

WASHINGTON, March 14-- President Johnson is never more impressive than when he is speaking about the poor. He feels their humiliation, and maybe because he is a proud and aggressive man he seems to sense the danger of poverty in the city slums.

CAIRO, March 14--The political split between conservative and radical Arab nations widened abruptly tonight as the Jordanian delegation walked out of the opening session of an Arab League ministers conference.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)--Efforts to obtain freedom for James R. Hoffa were rebuffed today in the United States Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)--President Johnson's appointment of Betty Furness as his consumer affairs adviser has been received coolly by consumer groups and Congressmen active in consumer affairs.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 14 (Reuters)--The Netherlands bank rate will be lowered to 4 per cent from 5 per cent effective tomorrow, the central bank announced today.

Ralph Nader, author and automotive safety critic, filed a $100,000 libel suit in Federal Court here yesterday against Vincent Gillen, a private investigator hired by General Motors to investigate Mr. Nader.

A group of Greenwich Villagers charged yesterday that City Transportation Administrator Arthur E. Palmer Jr. had put forward a plan for two expressways across Lower Manhattan in place of the one that the residents have been objecting to for years.

The Appellate Division upheld yesterday a lower court order directing the arrest of Adam Clayton Powell any time he comes into the state.
The Republican search for someone willing to stand up to Adam Clayton Powell in the special Congressional election in Harlem on April 11 narrowed last night to three persons.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- A former aide to Lyndon B. Johnson altered today the story he had told the Senate ethics committee in an affidavit concerning the purpose of fund-raising affairs for Senator Thomas J. Dodd in October, 1963.

TEN evenings for $10, and the first evening they add a bonus: It could only happen near Orchard Street. The Eleo Pomare Dance Company began the Village Theater Monday Dance Series with an unscheduled solo "Climb" to the music of Miklos Keleman, an addition to an already full evening.
MADRID, March 14 (Reuters)--Representatives of 30,000 airline pilots in 48 countries began a seven-day conference here today centered on flight safety problems in the jet age.
DAYTON, Ohio, March 14 (AP)--"It was a great feeling to get out," exclaimed 21year-old Rick Labuskes as he and 11 other University of Dayton students shed the underwear they wore a month for science.

LONDON, March 14 (Reuters) --A Japanese-Canadian ship building consortium has arranged for a Spanish shipyard to build their new utility "Freedom vessels" it was announced here today.

A leading cancer research institute, reporting yesterday on its analysis of tar and nicotine content of 56 brands of cigarettes, advised smokers who cannot break the habit to switch to brands that contain low quantities of these harmful substances.

EASTCHESTER, N.Y., March 14--Mr. and Mrs. Issa Nakhleh have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mayy Rita Nakhleh to David Arthur Scotto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Scotto of Brooklyn.

IT was the usual scene the other afternoon at Hair Design Associates, a his-and-hers hairdressing establishment at 22 St. Marks Place.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk pleaded today for swift Congressional approval of a resolution backing United States financial and other support for a proposed Latin-American Common Market.

Should Macy's tell Gimbel's? It depends, of course, on what Gimbel's wants to hear and what Macy's would choose to talk about. It depends also on the antitrust laws and the Federal guardians of competition.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 14--One day last season Mayo Smith was in the lobby of the Dodgers' hotel in At lanta, chatting with Walter Alston. Now the manager of the Detroit Tigers, Mayo was then the chief trouble-shooter and general observer of the baseball scene for the Yankees. In the course of the conversation he spoke with the proper reverence of the way Sandy Koufax was mowing down the opposition.

The Board of Education's latest census, showing that Negro and Puerto Rican children now constitute a majority of all public school pupils, underlines the futility of demands to legislate racial "balance" in the schools.

BRASILIA, March 14--President Humberto Castelo Branco, whose military regime ends at noon tomorrow, when Arthur da Costa e Silva is to be inaugurated, held his final Cabinet meeting this afternoon in the Planalto Palace here.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 14--When an Indonesian meets a tiger in the jungle, "he calls him grandfather," Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution explained Sunday after Indonesia's supreme legislature had designated General Suharto as Acting President.
ALBANY, March 14--The Assembly voted 91 to 54 today to impose a two-year moratorium on the number of liquor licenses in the state.
The Consolidated Edison Company has found a way to drill neat street holes without the chatter of jackhammers --the traditional mainstays of the "dig we must" syndrome.
Directors of the Scott Paper Company approved yesterday in Philadelphia the acquisition of the S.D. Warren Company. Directors of S.D. Warren are scheduled to meet today to vote on the merger.
The stock market erased most of its earlier losses in late trading yesterday, but final prices still were slightly down for the session in moderately active dealings.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 14 (UPI)--Gov. Ronald Reagan's administration announced tonight that it would lay off nearly 3,000 state employes in the next 15 months.
Stockholders of the Franklin National Bank and the Federation Bank and Trust Company approved yesterday the proposed merger of the two banks with little dissent and not much more debate.

Eddie Fisher and Buddy Hackett will temporarily restore the Palace to vaudeville for six weeks, beginning Sept. 5, Since January of last year the house has been presenting the musical comedy "Sweet Charity," starring Gwen Verdon.

MIAMI, March 14--Premier Fidel Castro strongly criticized the Soviet-bloc countries today for "rushing" to establish diplomatic and commercial relations with what he termed the "oligarchic" governments of Latin America.
NEW HAVEN, March 14--Dr. Fredrick C. Redlich, chairman of the Yale psychiatry department, was appointed dean of the School of Medicine today.
WASHINGTON, March 14 --The bodies of President Kennedy and his two dead children were quietly moved about 40 feet to their permanent grave in Arlington National Cemetery late tonight.

In an announcement last night that caught the waterfront industry by surprise, Captain William V. Bradley, former president of the International Longshoremen's Association, disclosed that he would again seek to head the union at its quadrennial election in July.
Employes of United Press International have boted to empower the negotiating committee of their Wire Service Guild unit to call a strike, the union announced yesterday.
Capt. Joseph E. Jones, former Commodore of the old Ward Line and first master of the ill-fated Morro Castle, died Friday in Lexington, Mass., where he recently lived. He was 98 years old.

A utility expert has urged the city to press its case against a recent Consolidated Edison electric rate increase because, he says, the company could have saved $58-million in operation and maintenance expenses in 1965 if it had operated more efficiently.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 14-- Towering Joe Adcock took a generous chaw of tobacco and allowed as how the Cleveland Indians' biggest problem this year is the manager.

Democratic and Republican leaders disclosed agreement yesterday on a set of 19 draft rules for the State Constitutional Convention, which opens April 4 in Albany. The rules will be submitted to Democratic delegates tomorrow and to the Republicans next Wednesday.

CLEVELAND, March 14 (UPI)--Leaders of six locals of the United Auto Workers criticized Walter Reuther, the union president, today for proclaiming the guaranteed annual wage as the union's major objective in negotiations in 1967.

WHITE PLAINS, March 14-- The engagement of Miss Martha Frances Kaus to Dr. Joseph Francis Dursi has been announced by her father, Francis J. Kaus, Dr. Dursi is the son of John A. Dursi of Larchmont and the late Mrs. Dursi.
ALBANY, March 14--Republicans and Democrats agreed today to cut $31.1-million from Governor Rockefeller's proposed $4.7-billion budget.
BRUSSELS, March 14--The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions has been unable to agree on a new general secretary to succeed Omer Becu, who resigned early this month because of ill health.

Ken Macker, a former public relations partner of Pete Rozelle, the National Football League Commissioner, was introduced to the owners of the 10 National Professional Soccer League clubs yesterday. Macker is the league Commissioner.

The concert by the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night had an uncommonly bright and tonic quality. Georges Pretre was the guest conductor, and both his program and interpretations had something French about them.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 14--The generals who rule South Vietnam served notice on the Constituent Assembly today that they would not tolerate the Assembly's recent attempts to broaden its powers.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)--The Government established for the first time today tolerances for residues of the pesticide DDT in milk and milk products.
JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, March 12--The hadj--the Moslem world's pilgrimage to Mecca-- is presenting a serious security problem to Saudi Arabia this year.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- A University of Michigan law professor warned today that a computerized national data bank could become a monstrous "Big Brother" with an insatiable appetite for snooping.

Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, denied last night a report by the network that it had suspended free spot announcements for Radio Free Europe because they did not make it clear that the organization was an arm of the Central Intelligence Agency.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)--Twenty-one Republican members of the House called tonight for "a full-scale investigation of the adequacy of the Federal Government's organization to fight crime effectively."

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development sold $250-million of tripleA bonds yesterday at a yield of 5.35 per cent, indicating that this month's slight downward bias in interest rates was still intact.
MOSCOW, March 14 (Reuters)--The Russians have crossed a radish and a cabbage and come up with something with more vitamin C than a lemon.
The Air Transport Association of America, seeking to speed airliner border-crossing formalities on the ground, plans to study whether communication satellites can help break the "paper barriers."

Telephones, cables and the radio are sufficient to carry out routine communications and orders.
A warm and temperate performance of Bach's "The Art of the Fugue" was given by the Stuttgart Chamber Orchestra last night at Philharmonic Hall.
The Federal Government has dropped charges against Harry S. Stonehill, according to court records.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 14 --The Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation announced today that 1,259 students from colleges throughout North America have been awarded one-year scholarships for graduate study to prepare for teaching careers.
MIAMI, March 14--Leaning over the side of a sportsfishing cruiser the other day on the reefs just off Miami, this visitor was looking down at the bottom, beautifully clear below.

WASHINGTON, March 14 --President Johnson promised Congress today that he would hold down costs and tighten the administration of his antipoverty programs, but he pleaded strongly for the funds needed to carry on at a slightly increased pace.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 14 (Reuters)--Manuel Santana of Spain, Mrs. Billie Jean King of the United States and Maria Bueno of Brazil had easy victories in the opening round of the South African tennis championships today.

The proceedings in the United States Supreme Court on March 13, as reported in The New York Times yesterday, erroneously listed some cases under the heading Certiorari Granted that should have been carried under the heading Certiorari Denied.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 14--Delegates and guests had a preview tonight of 100 paintings and sculptures that will go on public exhibition tomorrow for the benefit of the United Nations Children's fund, in its 17th annual art show.

OMAHA, March 14 (UPI) --Bob Devaney, the head football coach at the University of Nebraska, accepted appointment as Nebraska athletic director today. He will continue as football coach of the Huskers.

TEL AVIV, March 14--Rioters protesting growing unemploybent in Israel stoned City Hall tonight, smashing windows, and damaging vehicles in the parking lot. Three policemen were injured and arrests were made.

SEATTLE, March 14--Dorothy Hayden of Hastingson-Hudson, N.Y., teamed with Agnes Gordon of Buffalo, Emma Jean Hawes of Fort Worth, Tex., and Margaret Wagar of Atlanta to capture the Women's Team title in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here this afternoon.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 14 (AP)--Howard Hughes has bought the Desert Inn on the Las Vegas Strip, it was reported today. Mr. Hughes has been living in the hotel's penthouse since December.

The majority opinion was by Justices Bernard Botein, Louis J. Capozzoli, Benjamin J. Rabin and James B. M. McNally. The dissent was by Justice Harold A. Stevens.

The National Professional Soccer League owners reported brisk sales yesterday for opening-day tickets. ALBANY, March 15 Mayor Lindsay spent all day in the snowy state capital today in search of more state aid and new taxes, but the outcome of his talks with Governor Rockefeller and legislative leaders was "not conclusive." More discussions were tentatively scheduled for Saturday.

CORNING, Iowa, March 15 The National Farmers Organization called its long-threatened milk holding action today.

"In the last analysis, it is the sheriff, representing the power of the state, who gives force and vitality to every judgment and order." Deputy Sheriff's Guide.
The Bank of America announced yesterday in San Francisco the appointment of Samuel B. Stewart to the new post of senior administrative officer.
HONG KONG, March 15 The military takeover of Canton and the flare-up of Maoist demonstrations in Peking are regarded here as evidence that there is still vitality left in the Cultural Revolution.
The struggle for civil rights reached into the stockholders' meeting of a major New York City bank yesterday.
SCARSDALE, N.Y. March 15 David L. Rosenberg of 149 Brewster Road, a certified public accountant at 225 Broadway, New York, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. His age was 54.
The nation's electric power production rose 5.6 per cent in the week ended March 11, from the level in the corresponding 1966 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
An attorney representing the owners of the Desert Inn hotel and casino denied yesterday reports that Howard Hughes, the industrialist, had purchased the Las Vegas property or assumed its lease.

NASHVILLE, March 15 President Johnson said tonight that the mid-nineteen-sixties would be remembered as "a dynamic era when American education caught its second wind and raced "forward" toward his goal of offering a good education to every child.

ONE listens desperately all through "Dynamite To nite" for traces of the Arnold Weinstein who had various cockeyed, provocative, and spookily poetic things to say in an Off Broadway success of a few years ago. "The Red Eye of Love." But in this patchy, repetitive, and, halfheartedly whimsical antiwar play, he's hard to catch.
TUNIS, March 15 President Habib Bourguiba had a heart attack last night, the second in two months.

DR. ARIEL MENGARINI of the Bronx won the fourth annual South Jersey Open Chess Championship recently at the President Hotel in Atlantic City. With five victories and one draw in the six-round Swiss system, he tallied 5 - , topping the 68man field from the Eastern states and Canada.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday the formation of a joint committee to explore new communications technology to speed the flow of news to the public.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. March 15 John Malacela, Tan zania's Permanent Represent- ative at the United Nations, said today that his Government is ready to pay for recently expropriated foreign banks and companies, but does not know what the cost will be.
The National Urban League reported yesterday a record expansion of services during 1966, but said one of its important new programs was endangered by cutbacks in Federal antipoverty funds.
WARSAW, March 15 (AP)--Poland and East Germany signed a new 20-year treaty today promising mutual military assistance against any attempt by West Germany to change their borders by force.
PHILADELPHIA, March 15 Gov. Raymond P. Shafer signed a bill today that will allow Pennsylvanians to decide if they want to revise their constitution. He said he hoped they would.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15 (UPI) The Pennsylvania loyalty oath, required of public employes and candidates for office, was challenged as unconstitutional today in a suit filed by Spencer Coxe, local director of the American Civil Liberties Union.
The city has promised to supply funds to continue its experimental program for maintaining heroin addicts on methadone, Dr. Vincent P. Dole, developer of the program, said Tuesday.
ATLANTA, March 15 (AP) Harllee Branch Sr., chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died today in a hospital. He was 87 years old.

BONN, March 15 The United States European Command moved to Stuttgart, West Germany, from France today. At a dawn ceremony, the American flag, which was lowered at Camp des Loges near Paris yesterday, was hoisted over the new headquarters.
MIAMI, Fla., March 15 (AP) Alfredo Hernandez of New York, a Cuban consul under former President Fulgencio Batista, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 54 years old.

MIAMI, Fla., March 15 Bruce Goldsmith of Chicago, a light-air specialist, posted first and second place finishes today in the opening races of the annual midwinter Lightning Class championships on Biscayne Bay.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) The Treasury send to Congress today legislation aimed ultimately at removing all silver backing for paper money.

ATHENS, Ohio, March 15 (UPI) Six hundred nonacademic employes ended their strike tonight at Ohio University when the university agreed to all their demands, including a payroll deduction of union dues.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI) Negotiators for six shopcraft unions indicated today that they would reject most recommendations of a Presidential emergency board trying to head off a nationwide railroad strike April 12.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) Dr. Ellen Winston, the first United States Commissioner of Welfare, is resigning March 31.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 15 (AP) Robert W. Smart of El Segundo, Calif., a lawyer who is a brigadier general in the Air Foree Reserve, was elected today president of the Air Force Association.
Herman Chittison, a jazz pianist, died of cancer last Thursday in Cleveland. He was 58 years old.

The New York Civil Liberties Union filed suit here yesterday challenging the constitutionality of the state's 147-year old vagrancy law, which specifies that any person "not having visable means of support" is subject to six months at hard labor.

When the Rangers finally will be able to think about last night's game again, it will be in some private nightmare. And the bete noir will be a slender, handsome, blond National HockeyLeague referee named John Ashley.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI) Two models of plastic eyeglass frames have been recalled from distribution because they are highly flammable, the Food and Drug Administration said today.
A variety of weather hit the metropolitan area yesterday--and it was all bad.

The Douglas Aircraft Company, which is slated to merge with the McDonnell Company, continued to operate in the red for the first fiscal quarter ended Feb. 28, according to the report issued yesterday.
Two members of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal have been promoted, Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday.
Negotiators for the United Press International and the Wire Service Guild agreed last night to constitute talks on a new contract past an 11:59 P.M. contract expiration deadline.
A Congressional study of military aircraft inventories and production rates has disclosed scarcities of certain types of aircraft and reduced numbers of planes in storage and in reserve.

Indonesia now has an Acting President in General Suharto. It also has someone standing in the wings whom the resolution of the People's Consultative Congress referred to as "Dr. Sukarno" and "Engineer Sukarno." With typical subtlety and caution, he was still referred to as "President Sukarno," but no executive power was left to him, and he has been barred from all political activities until after the next elections.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 15 Italy, Canada and the United States proposed today that the United Nations appoint a representative and a council "to determine the necessary conditions that will enable South-West Africa to achieve self-determination and independence."

Roy M. Cohn, who was chief counsel to the Senate Investigating subcommittee under the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, has been elected chairman of the University National Bank of Chicago, it announced yesterday.

Clarence Taylor, a 57-yearold narcotics suspect charged with killing a detective and wounding two others in an East Harlem basement on Tuesday night, was held without bail yesterday for hearing in Criminal Court on April 13.
Westbury Fashions, Inc., has come back from the brink.

Bird lovers came up with the latest argument yesterday against the twin-towered 110story World Trade Center that the Port of New York Authority plans to build on Manhattan's lower West Side.

David Brodsky, cantor at the Jewish Communal Center of Flatbush for 40 years, died Tuesday, night in St. John's Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 72 years old and lived at 585 East 16th Street, Brooklyn.
LONDON, March 15 (AP) Mrs. Judy Devlin Hashman, formerly of Baltimore, moved into the quarter-finals of the AllEngland badminton championships today, winning two matches.

ALBANY, March 15--The Democrats and the Republicans joined in the Democratic-controlled Assembly tonight in approving with surprising speed three bills, each containing a different proposal for nominating candidates for state offices.

PITTSBURGH, March 15 Thomas J. Gallagher, a former Mayor of Pittsburgh, died last night. He was 83 years old.
Prices advanced in moderate trading yesterday on the London stock exchange. Traders were encouraged by word that Britain had cut her payments deficit almost in half last year.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 15 The Air Force Association said today that the pressures of the war in Vietnam were obscuring long-range American strategic needs.

WASHINGTON, March 15 The first effort to find Federal funds for New York State's ambitious transit reorganization was made today in the House of Representatives.

Silver, former president of the Board of Education of New York, protested against the refusal of Governments, which he did not name, to allow Jews to rejoin relatives in Israel and elsewhere.

Wesleyan University, which acquired 400,000 common shares of Xerox from that company in 1965 in exchange for its American Education Publications and university press, will offer 100,000 of the shares to the public.

Elihu N. Kleinbaum, a stockbroker for 40 years, died of a heart attack at his home, 923 Fifth Avenue, yesterday. He was 78 years old.

The fickleness of the weather still dominates wheat futures trading. On news of rain, the prices tend to decline; on word of dryness, prices rise. Yesterday, the reports spoke of continued lack of moisture, and the deliveries gained up to 3 cents a bushel.

FERNANDO SANCHEZ, who first gained fame designing women's underwear, yesterday showed an audience of 200 at Bergdorf Goodman some of his designs that women can wear in public.

The United Federation of Teachers, as spokesman for the protest action, sought to represent it as a challenge of the Board of Education. Yet, the walkout's effect will be to accentuate divisions between the school and the community it serves.

The Society Corporation, a Cleveland-based bank holding company, plans to acquire the Springfield (Ohio) Bank in a complex transaction announced yesterday. Both the Society National Bank (the Society Corporation's largest unit) and the Springfield Bank were once depositor-owned mutual savings banks. Both have been converted into stockholder-owned commercial banks.

Phaidon Press of London, the publishers of art books, was acquired yesterday by Frederick A. Praeger, Inc., a subsidiary of the Encyclopaedia Britannica.

"The grain market today has been almost entirely wheat," a broker commented yesterday. Bullish enthusiasm again pushed prices to new highs of the recent advance. Yesterday's impetus came from reports of further dry weather in the Southwest.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 16 Billy Martin, the firebrand coach of the Minnesota Twins, was at one end of the dugout, midway through the pennant-winning season of 1965. He was talking quietly to two infielders, explaining the mechanics of the sui cide squeeze.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 16 Mexico and Chile proposed a plan today for the United Nations to assume the administration of South-West Africa to the United Nations.

KHABAROVSK, U.S.S.R., March 15 Communist China is 30 miles from this principal city of the Soviet east. One sees the sparsely populated northeastern tip of Manchuria as the plane approaches Khabarovsk.

A nontheatrical troupe, most of whose members have little stage experience, are putting on an Off Broadway musical. It is intended to raise funds for Edward Orman, a draftsman of Far Rockaway, Queens, who was shot in the spine in December as he walked through a subway arcade.

WASHINGTON, March 16 The Federal Communications Commission today ordered new hearings on the controversial merger of the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., into the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
New Yorkers of Irish extraction and others who join them in the wearing of the green were promised partly cloudy skies and cold weather for the St. Patrick's Day parade on Fifth Avenue today.

The Gillette Company expects first-quarter sales and earnings to reach new records, Stuart K. Hensley, president and chief operating officer, told shareholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Boston.

For the first time in American Telephone and Telegraph Company's history, the proxy statement for the annual meeting on April 19, at the Baltimore Civic Center lists the number of shares held by each director as well as directorships held outside of the Bell System. The Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday that it was creating a division for the production and theatrical distribution of feature-length motion pictures.

WASHINGTON, March 16--The Johnson Administration won speedy House approval today of its request for restoration of tax benefits for business investment in equipment and building. The vote was 386 to 2. Acting on recommendations made by President Johnson just a week ago today, the House passed a bill to restore special incentives that had been suspended last Oct. 10 to relieve inflationary pressures in the capital goods market.

United Press International services to its more than 4,000 newspaper and broadcast subscribers in the United States will be extended and facilitated by means of a new communications system for its news wires, it was announced yesterday.

Delegates representing 100,000 employes of the state and 42,000 county and municipal workers voted unanimously yesterday to end a 19-year-old voluntary no-strike pledge.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 Regents of the University of California voted today to delay, until at least July, final action on Gov. Ronald Reagan's proposal to impose tuition on California residents at the university.

Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. McNicol of 530 Park Avenue and Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elaine Margaret McNicol, to John E. Postley Jr., son of Mrs. Postley of New York and Washington Crossing, N. J., and the late Mr. Postley.
BOSTON, March 16 Richard Cardinal Cushing said today, "I never believed the assassination of President Kennedy was the work of one man."
A group of creators of TV and radio advertising heard their creations boosted and knocked yesterday by a judge of their art. Then they saw and heard some recent prize winners.
During his 16 years in the House of Representatives, Arthur Lewis Miller was a fierce opponent of any legislation that he believed grew out of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal.

ROME, March 16 A group of American Jewish leaders has been urged by a Cardinal to seek discussions with Christians on social as well as on religious questions to further the cause of interfaith understanding.
THAT SUMMER THAT FALL" opened. Last night, Helen Hayes, 46th Street. Contemporary setting, Based on "Ph dre." Author able, Play absent. Not enough words.

W.W. Sebald, former president and vice chairman of the board of the Armco Steel Corporation, Middletown, Ohio, died shortly before midnight Wednesday in Holmes Hospital, Cincinnati. He had been admitted to the hospital on Feb. 7 with emphysema. He was 78 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 16 The Democratic majority on the Joint Economic Committee of Congress called today for a reduction of up to $6-billion in Federal spending during the 1968 fiscal year.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., March 16 Cornell University's precision passing hockey team scored a 1-0 victory over North Dakota tonight to earn its way into the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 20th annual championship tournament in the War Memorial Auditorium.

Governor Rockefeller has ordered an investigation of the operation of the State Commission on Human Rights, following complaints by the commission's own advisory councils and civil rights group of inadequate activity.

WESTBURY, L. I., March 16 --Billy Haughton was about to conclude a telephone conversation with Eddie Arcaro today. Just before he was ready to hang up the phone in Barn CC at Roosevelt Raceway, Haughton asked the ex-jockey if his brokerage firm carried a plan that covered the partial loss of an ear. They both laughed.

Gerald W. Eskow, 44, of Kings Point, L.I., former president of the bankrupt Yale Express System, Inc., pleaded not guilty in Federal Court yesterday to charges of fraud in getting $2.35-million long-term financing for Yale from eight insurance companies.

SAIGON, Friday, March 17 (AP) United States Marines fought an eight-hour battle with Communist forces in the northwestern corner of South Vietnam near the Laotian border yesterday, the United States Command said today.

The State Assembly made itself slightly ridiculous by giving its assent to not one but three direct primary bills. Surely its constitutional responsibility is to choose the measure it considers best for the state rather than to pass on that problem to the Senate and the Governor.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 (UPI) Federal District Judge Albert C. Wollenberg granted the Southern Pacific company today a preliminary injunction to keep railroad switchmen from striking over a promotion dispute.

At Lincoln Center today: "Mourning Becomes Electra," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; "Il Trittico," New York City Opera, New York State Theater, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 2:15, and Buffy Sainte Marie, folk singer, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.

Stock prices surged into new high ground for the year yesterday in active trading in response to favorable economic developments, including the prospects of an early restoration of the investment-tax credit by Congress.

Democratic delegates to the State Constitutional Convention unanimously approved yestera set of rules for the convention. The rules had been suggested by committees representing both the Democratic and the Republican delegates.

Rutgers's basketball team gave Southern Illinois all sorts of fits before yielding to superior talent and losing, 79-70, in the second semi-final of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden last night before a capacity crowd of 18,499.

VAIL, Colo., March 16 France's heavily fortified ski squad began its invasion of the West today in much the way it had blitzed through New Hampshire last weekend. The French dominated the two-run slalom to take an impressive lead in this competition that is labeled the world series of skiing.

Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, warned Latin-American leaders yesterday that a "cavalier" attitude toward President Johnson's aid policy could "sour" bipartisan support for the program.
LONDON, March 16 The French elections are widely believed to be unlikely to have more than a marginal effect on President de Gaulle's prestige in Western Europe or on his policy.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 16 Speculation that President Sukarno might travel abroad this year was revived here today by B.M. Diah, the Information Minister.
PHILADELPHIA, March 16 (UPI) The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania, struck by operators, cafeteria workers and clerical employes, said it was maintaining nearly normal service with some delays.
WASHINGTON, March 15 President Johnson has signed an executive order designed to end the bureaucratic struggle for control of the $7.4-billion Food for Freedom Program.
Two officials of the Turner Construction Company, Herbert D. Conant and Eugene von Wening Jr., each a manager of a branch office, have been elected vice presidents.
LONDON, March 16 Top executives in Britain's nationalized steel industry will have salaries in the $60,000 bracket.
THE rumors that Continental Insurance Company plans to enlarge its position in Diners' Club, Inc., the credit card company, may be exaggerated.
Six persons were arrested yesterday in a series of raids on what the police called the headquarters and key distribution centers for "millions of dollars" in hard-core pornographic movies.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 16 A mood of pronounced rank and file militancy confronted Walter P. Reuther today as skilled trades members of the United Automobile Workers Union opened a conference here.
A ROOM with a view often a spectacular view can be one of the advantages of living on an upper floor in a Manhattan apartment.

The nationally respected Health Department of New York City has always had a special place in government. Established before the State Health Department, it has always been relatively independent of the state agency and has pioneered in many areas of sanitation and health regulation.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Rogosin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Vicki Lee Rogosin, to S. Bruce Lansky, son of Mr. and Mrs. David P. Lansky of Scarsdale, N. Y. The wedding is planned for May 13.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 16 (AP) United States intelligence officers have uncovered what they call graphic proof that a North Vietnamese general directs the Communist side in the war in South Vietnam.

Casslus Clay, the world heavyweight boxing champion, who prefers to be known by his Black Muslim name of Muhammad Ali, implied yesterday that he would go to jail "for what I believe" rather than comply with his United States Army induction date of April 11.
WASHINGTON, March 16 The White House said today that President Johnson would send to Congress a governmental reorganization message that would include a plan for a new department of economic affairs.

A warning that the Government must act to curb textile imports, notably from Japan, if this country is to maintain a healthy domestic textile industry, was sounded yesterday by Robert E. Pomeranz, president of the Roberts Company, textile engineering and machinery manufacturing concern of Sanford, N.C.
WASHINGTON, March 16 Industrial production declined substantially in February for the second straight month, but the drop did not cause any increase in unemployment.
BOSTON, March 16 The Boston Symphony Orchestra embarked today on a campaign to raise $5.5-million to meet household expenses and to refurbish its 67-year-old concert hall.

JERUSALEM (Israel) March 16--Two Arab infiltrators were reported killed today by Israeli soldiers who pursued them across the Jordanian border north of the town of Arad in the northern Negev. Two Israelis were wounded.
DJIBOUTI, March 16 (AP) Ethiopia and Somalia were reported moving troops today to their borders with French Somaliland.

A group of Manhattan Reform Democratic leaders in caucus have banded together to block the election of Assemblyman Frank G. Rossetti as the county leader. Mr. Rossetti became acting leader after the resignation last week of J. Raymond Jones.

DR. TOM MEDLAR'S finicky joy and time-consuming inspiration is neither his wife nor his profession; it is his boat. She is a solid, old-fashioned broadbeamed Maine fishing sloop, lately converted to a yawl, Her name, all too minutely, is Harmony. Puttering about in her, keeping her trim and polished, neatly noting her adventures in a log book,...
OHRBACH'S cup of joy overflowed yesterday, and the brew was potent.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 16 David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said tonight he expected the the deficit in the United States balance of payments to increase by one billion dollars this year because of the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, March 16 A Buffalo scientist reported today evidence suggesting that the "mind-expanding" drug LSD might be damaging the users' chromosomes, the tiny carriers of heredity contained in every human cell.
BOSTON, March 16 (AP) Jack Landau, stage and television producer, director and designer, was found strangled and stabbed to death in his Back Bay apartment today.
NEW ORLEANS, March 16 The state's chief witness in an alleged Kennedy assassination plot testified today that investigators had him placed under hypnosis three times before this week's court hearing.
PARIS, March 16 Michel Bruguier, a lawyer in the Mehdi Ben Barka case, died here today of a cerebral hemorrhage at the age of 45.
The executive director of the Urban League of Greater New York criticized major newspapers and television and radio stations yesterday for not hiring more Negroes for their staffs.
WASHINGTON, March 16 The Senate, in the first legislative endorsement of the Administration's East-West "bridge-building" policy, nar- rowly approved today the consular treaty with the Soviet Union.

The Boeing Company announced yesterday the appointment of H.W. Withington as vice president and branch manager of the Supersonic Transport program, which is now a part of the commercial airplane division.
The Puleo family of the Bronx doubles in Trouble, but no one minds.
"Send me a dollar so I can survive," wrote Andrew Hill, a 29-year-old jazz pianist and composer, in Jazz magazine last August. "Maybe I'll play a public concert for you one day."
PARIS, March 16 Leading members of governments and political parties from six European countries called today for Britain's entry into the Common Market as an equal partner.
MOSCOW, March 16 Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon, fresh from talks with Pope Paul VI on Vietnam, arrived in Moscow tonight and was met by a snub from the Kremlin.

Sir Ian Orr-Ewing, the British Conservative party's spokesman on defense, predicted yesterday that the major airlines would need to buy both the Concorde, the Anglo-French supersonic plane, and the United States' larger and faster supersonic transport, the Boeing 2707.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company announced here yesterday the appointment of Kenneth K. Keene as vice president for pensions on its group insurance staff.
LONDON, March 16 An attempt to remove two directors from the board of Dollar Land Holdings, Ltd., was defeated here today in a poll of stockholders.

CHELTENHAM, England, March 16 (UPI) Woodland Venture, the youngest horse in the race, held on in the stretch run today to win the $22,400 Cheltenham Gold Cup steeple chase by three-quarters of a length.

FORT LAUDERDALE, March 16 In 1961 the Pittsburgh Pirates sent a scout to Elizabeth, Pa., with orders to bring Bill Robinson into the city to sign a contract. Bill's father, a steel worker, roared, "Go to hell," and threw the man out.

The only known unused block of four 1-penny orange 1848 Mauritius stamps part of the British portion of the late Josiah K. Lilly's collection was sold for $64,000 here yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria.
Ireland is expected to reach an important economic milestone this year when for the first time her earnings from exports and tourism will top the $1-billion mark.
WASHINGTON, March 16 President Johnson told educators in Tennessee last night that satellite reconnaissance alone had justified spending 10 times what the nation had already spent on space.
The Motion Picture Association of America is backing a campaign to make moviegoers aware of approval for films from the Production Code Administration.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) President Johnson named former Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California today to head a 12-member commission to review Federal criminal laws.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Caspar Wister of Chestnut Hill of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Carpenter Wister, to William Jackson, Gates, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley R. Gates of Flourtown.
ALBANY, March 16 A measure designed to re-establish a teacher loyalty law in the state was passed by the Senate today after a half-hour of heated debate.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 16 Dan Sikes, a home-town professional, led the $100,000 Greater Jacksonville open golf tournament today with an opening round of 67.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) Gov. Roberto Sanchez Vilella of Puerto Rico said today that he was "disturbed" by demands on the island for his resignation, but declined to comment on whether they were based on recurrent rumors that he and his wife are planning a divorce.
An associate professor of geology has discovered a significant copper deposit in Northwestern Maine, the University of Virginia announced yesterday.
Eighty marked $50 bills led yesterday to the arrest of two city employes on charges of accepting a bribe from a large commercial laundry in Brooklyn in return for reducing the laundry's water bill.
LONDON, March 16 (Reuters) Prime Minister Wilson said tonight that he would have dissociated Britain from United States action in Vietnam if he thought it would hasten the end of the war.
Closing quotations for issues not traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday:
The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. has agreed to play a leading role in an antiwar demonstration scheduled to be held here on April 15 outside United Nations headquarters.
RIDGEFIELD, Conn., March 16 Miss Kathleen Ann Kerrigan and Richard Elmer Gildersleeve plan to be married June 10.

ALBANY, March 16 Despite Democratic charges of "larceny" and "a sellout to the private utility companies," the Republican-controlled Senate pushed through today Governor Rockefeller's plan to aid the expansion of electric power in the state.
PARIS, March 16 President de Gaulle lavished praise today on the commander of the allied armed forces that he had expelled from France.

CLEVELAND, March 16 (UPI) Jerry Lucas and Len Chappell scored three baskets apiece in the final minutes tonight to give Cincinnati a 114111 victory over St. Louis. The triumph enabled the Royals to clinch at least a tie for third place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association.
Industrial issues responded to yesterday's reduction in the British bank rate by registering a strong advance on the London Stock Exchange.

OVIEDO, Spain, March 16 (Reuters) A former Spanish Loyalist soldier emerged whitehaired from a stable here yesterday after spending 29 years in hiding, Jose Fidel Blanco, 54 years old, hid when General Francisco Franco's Nationalist troops overran the north of Spain.

David Ben-Gurion returned last night to the scene of a notable triumph that took place 25 years ago at the Biltmore Hotel. It was there that he formulated the "Biltmore Platform," a document that won the unanimous support of a divided Zionist movement in support of a Jewish Commonwealth in Palestine.
LONDON, March 16 The bank rate, Britain's basic lending rate, was cut a half-point today to 6 per cent.

PARIS, March 16--The missing half of the manuscript of Mozart's "Don Giovanni," which vanished from the Bibliotheque Nationale here in January, was recovered today after an anonymous phone call to police headquarters. The four leatherbound notebooks turned up where the caller said they were hidden--in an empty chamber of the national library's basement.
WASHINGTON, March 16 State Department sources expressed optimism today over the outlook for the meeting of Western Hemisphere presidents scheduled for April 12 to 14 at Punta del Este, Uruguay.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 16 Enemy gunners fired mortar barrages at seven United States and South Vietnamese positions, including a provincial capital, last night and today and shelled an American merchant ship 14 miles from Saigon.

ALBANY, March 16 The counsel to the Speaker of the Assembly said today that he had returned $750 in retainer fees to a public employes un ion after hearing that the union was about to make public a statement saying that he was helping it with its legislative program.
Yakov Zak, the Soviet pianist who made his local debut in 1965, returned to Carnegie Hall last night for his only appearance this season.

SOUTHOLD, L.I., March 16 John Harris Flynn, who retired in 1953 as United States Appraiser of Merchandise in the New York district, and had a long career in and out of Government service, died here today in his home. His age was 87.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 (UPI) Judy Kimball carded a three-under-par 70 today to take a one-stroke lead after the first round of the Orange Blossom golf tournament.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 16 George Walter Baker, designer and manufacturer of electron tubes, died today at St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 1248 Newfield Avenue.

Denver Oldham, the Glen Cove, L.I., pianist who has appeared here several times since his debut in 1961, offered a varied program last night at Philharmonic Hall. The recital was a benefit for the Gospel Association for the Blind, so the sparse attendance must have been a disappointment to the sponsors.

MEMPHIS, March 16 Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Goodman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bobye Louise Goodman, to Lawrence Irving List, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. List of Brooklyn, N. Y.

The spot rate on the British pound showed renewed strength in moderate trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here. The final rate of $2.7969 was 9 points above the closing quotation on Wednesday.

Col. Inju Kay, South Korean Army, retired, and Mrs. Kay of Seoul and Tokyo, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suno Kay, to John Steven Osterweis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Osterweis of New York. The wedding is planned for May 7 in Tokyo.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 100.2 on Wednesday from 100.3 on Tuesday.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 16 (AP) Rich Allen, a third baseman, signed his 1967 baseball contract today with the Philadelphia Phillies.
City Hall, a traditional site for sit-ins and lie-ins, had a formal lunch-in yesterday. But it was not a protest.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 16 Francis P. Sinn, an engineer in zinc smelting for more than half a century, died today at his home, at 129 Orange Road. He was 84 years old.

DES MOINES, March 16 (AP) An attempt by the National Farmers Organization to cut off milk supplies in 25 states met with scattered success today. Dealers said there was no immediate threat of consumer shortages.

By OSCAR GODBOUT Special to The New York Times MIAMI, March 16 Like all of his breed, he had the personality of a time bomb. He would lie motionless beneath a lily pad and then explode in a convulsion of movement if something tasty came by.

ATHENS, March 16 Former President Truman has been awarded an honorary law degree by the University of Salonika, in northern Greece, in gratitude for his decision to send military and economic aid to Greece after World War II.
The city's leading interdenominational Protestant organizations announced a plan yesterday to coordinate their social welfare activities to permit Roman Catholics to participate.
The Small Business Administration denied permission to Edward J. Bermingham yesterday to acquire control of the Small Business Investment Company of New York.
The reduction in the British bank rate yesterday morning and Washington's announcement of a sharp decline in the industrial production index caused bond prices to continue moving higher.
NEWARK, March 16 New Jerseyans were caught unawares today when Governor Rockefeller urged New Jersey to build its own major jetport as New York State intends to do.
The Aspida court-martial and the controversy surrounding it have their roots in a historic Greek conflict the power of the monarchy versus the power of the elected Government.
WASHINGTON, March 16-- Top United States officials forecast today that bombing in North Vietnam and South Vietnam would continue to rise.

Theodore W. Kheel, the lawyer and labor arbitrator, said yesterday that he was "disposed" to accept the request that he mediate in contract negotiations between five of the city's daily newspapers and 10 newspaper unions.
Volume and prices climbed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, but the trading pace and advance failed to match the performance on the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, March 16 Revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended March 11 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of 1966.

WASHINGTON, March 16 A leader of the National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy who has just returned from discussions with North Vietnamese and Vietcong officials in France and Algeria said today that he thought the prospects for a settlement of the Vietnam war were "frozen" until next fall.

FOR 14 years Helen Boatwright has been appearing on New York's concert stages, but it has always been as a guest soloist with an ensemble or as a co-recitalist. Last night, the soprano had a program here all to herself, sharing the stage of Town Hall only with Paul Ulanowsky, her colleague at the piano.
WASHINGTON, March 16 There have been at least three changes in the original design of President Kennedy's permanent grave at Arlington National Cemetery.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., March 16--The engagement of Miss Karen Ann Carlsen, daughter of Capt. H. Kurt Carlsen of the merchant marine and Mrs. Carlsen, to Lieut. (jg.) Laurence Helms Mueller, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Adolf G. Mueller of Clinton, N. Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

Mrs. Constantine A. Tsimenis of 78 Irving Place and Eaton's Neck, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marina Tsimenis, to Philip James Philliou, son of Mrs. James Philliou of Astoria, Queens, and the late Mr. Philliou. The wedding is planned for May.

WASHINGTON, March 16 A House Rules Subcommittee recommended unanimously today the establishment of a permanent select committee to draw up and enforce ethical standards of conduct for all Representatives.
New York (Sunnyside Garden) Angel Oquenda, 175 pounds, Puerto Rico, outpointed Levan Roundtree, 175 , New York, 10 rounds.
Coming after January's decline, the sharp February drop in the Federal Reserve's index of industrial production makes clear that the economy is in a new and precarious phase.

Leopold Stokowski will conduct 25 members of the American Symphony Orchestra in three concerts at Veteran's Administration Hospitals. Mr. Stokowski is donating his service and also paying all other expenses, amounting to $4,000.
Rosalyn Tureck, the pianist and Bach specialist, will direct an advanced Bach study group at the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts in Lincoln Center in July.

WASHINGTON, March 16 Legislation extending the current margin rules covering listed securities to stocks traded over the counter had been introduced in Congress by Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee.
The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday it was discontinuing its magnetic tape business in this country. Present stocks of audio and instrumentation tapes will be sold.

Mrs. Doris Myers Carnot of 37-09 75th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, who served as executive secretary for William P. Rosensohn when he sponsored the first heavyweight championship bout between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson in 1959, died Tuesday at Elmhurst General Hospital in Queens. Her age was 45.

Mrs. Christiana Drummond Councilman Morgan, who was long associated with the Harvard University Psychological Clinic, drowned while bathing off St. John, Virgin Islands, on Tuesday. She was 67 years old and was the widow of Dr. William O.P. Morgan, a physicist.
Mayor Piero Bargellini of Florence, Italy, will be guest of honor at the Botticelli Ball March 29 at the Plaza.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., March 16 American and European bankers meeting here have received a close look at the difficulties that still plague negotiations to create a new international reserve asset to supplement gold, dollars and pounds.
Pepsico, Inc. last year achieved the highest sales and earnings in its 63-year-history the report of Donald M. Kendall, president, disclosed yesterday.

The appointment of Eugene D. Lynch as director of freight traffic sales and assistant general manager for freight and passenger traffic of the United Fruit Company has been announced by Victor Bonnaffee Jr., general manager for freight and passenger traffic.

CHICAGO, March 16 Norman A. Simon is scheduled to be elected president of the Guaranty Bank and Trust Company at a aboard meeting March 28. Mr. Simon, 45 years old, will be the bank's first Negro president.

SEATTLE, March 16--All the New York experts survived the first knockout round of the Vanderbilt Cup contest here this afternoon, although in one case the margin of victory was very small. Mrs. Dorothy Hayden and Alan...

ITHACA, N.Y., March 16 About 150 Cornell University students staged a sit-in in the Administration Building today after five of them were cited for a violation of a ruling banning their solicitation of pledges for destruction of draft cards.
DALLAS, March 16 Concerned over the rise in national stocks of crude petroleum, the Texas Railroad Commission agreed today to reduce permissible oil output in April for the third consecutive month.
Two industrial expansion projects here costing a total of $564,145 have been aided by loans arranged by the New York City Industrial Development Corporation.

Michael De Cicco, an international vice president of the United Furniture Workers of America, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital after several months' illness. He was 58 years old and lived at 1942 West 13th Stret, Brooklyn.
LONDON, March 16--A new weekly newspaper edited for the 90,000 Americans living in Britain and Ireland is scheduled to be published here tomorrow.

Swamp buggies and tractors towing grading apparatus were more important than horses at Aqueduct yesterday morning. Thoroughbreds worked out, all right, on the snow-covered racing strip until 10 o'clock, and immediately afterward the mobile corps went into action, to keep the surface level and fit.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission said today that W.R. Grace Co., Inc., of New York, had agreed not to acquire any more chocolate and cocoa products concerns for 10 years without prior commission approval.
A 20-year-old Barnard junior was formally installed last night as the first woman to serve as an editor of The Columbia Daily Spectator, the Columbia College paper.
BRIELLE, N.J. March 16 (AP)--A 47-year-old Manville, N.J., man, Joseph Chesla, hooked an 81-pound codfish today. It was the largest ever caught.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 15 A revival this autumn on a nationwide scale of mainland China's internal struggle is predicted by Nationalist China's experts.

BIMINI, the Bahamas, March 17--"Adam has had more effect on Bimini in three years than either Ernest Hemingway, prohibition or hurricane Betsy." This view, held by many of Bimini's 1,800 residents, was expressed recently by Arnold Bowlegs, a Biminian Eastern Air Lines agent.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 17--Dr. Howard Biers, a consulting metallurgical engineer in New York, died yesterday of a heart attack in his automobile here. He was 62 years old and lived on Perry Avenue in Silvermine.

A group of faculty members at Long Island University's Brooklyn Center yesterday urged the university chancellor, Dr. R. Gordon Hoxie, to withdraw his acceptance of the resignation of the center's provost, Dr. William M. Birenbaum. Earlier this week Dr. Birenbaum, chief administrative officer of the Brooklyn center, confirmed that he had signed a letter of resignation, but added that the "chancellor requested my resignation."

The Philadelphia Woodwind Quintet shared the stage of the Village Theater last night with the quartet of Ornette Coleman, the avant-garde jazz musician, but each group went its separate way through most of the evening.

Anthony Scotto, a vice president of the International Longshoremen's Association and head of Brooklyn Local 1814, the union's largest local, confirmed reports yesterday that he had been offered the post of executive vice president if Capt. William V. Bradley regains the presidency of the union.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., March 17--Boston University's allAmerica forward, Fred Bassi, scored a pair of goals to lead the Terriers to a 4-2 semi-final victory over Michigan State's defending champions in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's hockey championships tonight.

Four defending champions, Bill Farrell of the New York Athletic Club, Richie Sofman of the United States Army, Dan Direnzo of the New York A.C. and Hassan Makhmultchi of the New York A.C.--advanced last night in early-round competition of the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior wrestling championships at the McBurney Young Men's Christian Association.
WASHINGTON, March 17-- One day last year a 19-yearold soldier sat in his solitary confinement cell in the Fort Dix stockade and wrote to his mother that he was going to kill himself.
Leading issues on the London Stock Exchange closed out a week of progress by easing slightly.

BONN, March 17--Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger said tonight that a formula had been found to solve the problem of financing the foreign exchange costs of stationing American and British troops in West Germany.
WASHINGTON, March 17-- United States officials expressed optimism today that the budgetary problems of maintaining United States and British forces in West Germany were "on the way to a solution."

R. Earle Anderson, a naval architect, director of finance of the United States Maritime Commission from 1938 to 1946, and a writer, died Wednesday in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 86 years old and lived at 162 Washington Avenue, Chatham, N.J.
WASHINGTON, March 17--President Johnson ordered today the release of $791-million in previously frozen Federal funds for highway construction, mortgage assistance, flood control and other projects.
MIAMI, March 17--Adam Clayton Powell said today that he was "reluctantly" canceling plans to return to Harlem on Sunday because of the danger of violence and bloodshed if he were arrested.

It breathes and blinks its eyes. Its heart beats, and its pulse throbs; its muscles twitch and flutter. Its jaw opens to expose a tongue and a set of teeth, vocal cords and a windpipe. Or so it seems.

AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo. March 17 (UPI)--Air Force Academy officials said today that seven junior letter men would be missing from the ine-up April 23 when the Academy's football team started spring training.

OTTAWA, March 17 (Canadian Press)--Air Canada's passenger and freight traffic rose to record levels in 1966 but net income fell to $2,909,878, down more than $1-million from 1965, partly because of a reduction in fares.

THE Metropolitan Opera's new production, "Mourning Becomes Electra," may or may not become a hit. But of one thing there was no doubt at all last night. The new opera by Marvin David Levy received a pulverizing performance, thanks to the effort of two sopranos-Marie Collier from Australia and Evelyn Lear, the American girl who has become one of the European stars in the last decade.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 17--North Carolina delayed for the first minute and 55 seconds of overtime before finding the opening it wanted and then sent Bobby Lewis driving in for a basket. He made it, was fouled, connected on the 3-point play and the Tar Heels kept control to beat Princeton, 78-70, tonight in an Eastern semi-final game of the National Collegiate basketball championship.
The 79 teachers who stayed off the job at Junior High School 98 for three days this week returned to their classrooms yesterday, but only half of the students reported for school.
