Opponents of private efforts to rehabilitate slum property have fresh support for their stand in the report that the Citizens Housing and Planning Council failed to make a profit in two slum buildings on the Lower East Side which it bought and renovated. Roger Starr, the council's executive director, concludes that eliminating the slums calls for huge Government subsidies rather than private investment.
TRENTON, March 17--A state appeals court held today that a property covenant allegedly used by a country club section of Wayne Township to exclude Jews and Negroes was unlawful.

When a Los Angeles art collector sought to authenticate a painting of the Norwich school, an art scholar told him, "Ask Dr. Goldberg." When London's Victoria and Albert Museum and Canada's National Gallery were looking for a lecturer on the Norwich school, the word was: "Call on Dr. Goldberg"

WASHINGTON, March 17-- President Johnson deferred indefinitely today his efforts to merge the Labor and Commerce Departments. He acknowledged widespread opposition, particularly among labor groups, but insisted that he would be proved right eventually.

The secret is out. The two-day weekend is to be the Kremlin's big fiftieth birthday present to the Soviet people. A decree the other day made it official and by next Nov. 7, the anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution, the shift should have gone into effect for most Soviet Workers.

BERLIN, March 17--Walter Ulbricht, the East German Communist leader, and President Antonin Novotny of Czechoslovakia signed today the third of a series of East European "friendship and support" treaties designed to bolster the security of the East German regime.

CHICAGO, March 17 (AP)-- The Chicago Bulls clinched a tie for fourth place in the Western Division playoffs tonight behind the clutch shooting of Erwin Mueller by beating the San Francisco Warriors, 120-117.

DETROIT, March 17 (UPI)-- Passenger car production began a climb upward from weather and labor troubles this week but is still running 26.4 per cent behind 1966 figures, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
Palm Sunday, commemorating the entry of Jesus into Jerusalem to eat the Passover meal with His disciples, will be celebrated tomorrow in thousands of churches.

A charge that the Johnson Administration is using "carrot and stick" tactics on maritime management and labor has been made by Representative William S. Mailliard of California, the ranking. Republican member of the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries.
The Citizens Union proposed yesterday that proportional representation be used in the election of state legislators.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)--The Federal Communications Commission said today that its inspectors had caught more than a score of persons connected with unlicensed and illegally operated citizens band radio stations last night. A spokesman called it the largest coordinated raid in the commission's 33-year history.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. March 17 (UPI)--Clifford Ann Creed picked apart the Sunset Country Club course today for a 65, the lowest round of her career, to take a four-shot lead at 138 in the Orange Blossom golf tournament.

Eight Australians, one New Zealander and three Americans were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury here on charges of having conspired to violate the narcotics laws by smuggling heroin valued at more than $20-million into the United States from Hong Kong
Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., announced yesterday that its executive committee has authorized a merger proposal with Wilson Co., Inc., Chicago meatpackers and athletic-equipment makers.

The other day, in the moments before Cassius Clay had to confront newsmen regarding his draft status, one of This handlers, Drew Brown, told the heavyweight champion: "When they ask you about going into the Army, put your head on my shoulder and cry."
TOKYO, March 17 (AP)-- The wife of ousted President Sukarno of Indonesia said today that she believed her husband was suffering from an old kidney ailment and exhaustion.

DALLAS, March 17 (UPI)-- A: Otis Birch, a 95-year-old millionaire whose marriage last October to his nurse, a, former convict, made headlines throughout the country, died Wednesday in a house trailer here.

AUSTIN, Tex,, March 17 (AP) --Dr. Harry Ransom, chancellor of the University of Texas, said today he had ordered an inquiry into the student newspaper's contention that at least two faculty members had openly berated a Vietnam war veteran in their classes.

GENEVA, March 17--The United Nations Commission on Human Rights unanimously adopted today a resolution noting the concern aroused by "recent manifestations of racial intolerance, including the revival of certain groups and organizations professing totalitarian ideologies such as Nazism."

On Easter Sunday a luncheon, dance and fashion show is to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria to benefit the Postgraduate Center for Mental Health. Mrs. Donald J. Chipman is the general chairman of the March 26 event.
Sidney R. Rabb, chairman of Stop and Shop, Inc., has been elected to the board of the Gillette Company, it was announced yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 17 --Seventeen men were executed in public today in Riyadh, capital of Saudi Arabia. The executions took place in Justice Square in front of the Sharla (Koranic Law) Court, where they were found guilty last Sunday of acts of sabotage.
B'nai B'rith reported yesterday an "acute lack" of Jewish spiritual leaders at American colleges and universities in the face of an increase of 360,000 Jewich students.

SINCE it was St. Patrick's Day, and the dancer at the Henry Street Playhouse was Elizabeth Harris (who could well be Irish, for all I know), I am inclined to be tolerant. But if it were not St. Patrick's Day I would be horrid. Especially if I were not Irish. Which I am not.

DUBLIN, March 17--Thousands of Dubliners celebrated St. Patrick's Day by watching the biggest and most colorful parade ever staged through the streets of downtown Dublin and by attending the Gaelic Games, the biggest dog show of the year and horse racing at Bal doyle.

NEW ORLEANS, March 17, --A panel of three judges ruled today that there was sufficient evidence to try Clay L. Shaw, a retired New Orleans business executive, on charges of conspiring to assassinate President Kennedy.

LYNN FONTANNE registered a triumph of regal power, loneliness and realism last night in her portrayal of the dowager empress in the revival of "Anastasia" on the "Hallmark Hall of Fame." The production was seen on the network of the National Broadcasting Company.

Sent message to Congress on quality of Government; saw, Ambassador-designate of Afghanistan; met with Dr. Ahmed Laraki, Ambassador of Morocco; saw William Fay, Ambassador of Ireland, for annual St. Patrick's Day presentation; saw Civil Service Commission Chairman Macy;

CORVALLIS, Ore., March 17 --The University of California, Los Angeles, romped to its 27th straight victory tonight, drubbing Wyoming, 109-60, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Western regional basketball playoffs.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the three and 12 months ended Feb. 28.
A white-haired Massachusetts veterinarian, here to attend a convention, was found strangled yesterday morning in his room at the Statler Hilton Hotel.

PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., March 17--P. Schuyler Van Bloem, who had been president of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association and Mayor of Lake Success, died yesterday in the St. Charles Hospital here. He was 74 years old and lived at 25 Shawmont Lane in Stony Brook.
EAST LANSING, Mich., March 17 (AP)--Michigan State University's 40,000 students have received a bill of rights guaranteeing their right to disagree with an instructor's views.

Although not the rarity it used to be, a performance of Mahler's "Das Lied von der Erde" is still an event. Yesterday afternoon, the work turned up in a New York Philharmonic concert in Philharmonic Hall, and the occasion had several added points of interest.
Mayor Lindsay delivered a mostly humorous speech last night at the 183d anniversary dinner of the Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick.
Gerald Gutterman, 24 years old, of 46 Schenck Avenue, Great Neck, L.I., was sentenced yesterday to four years in prison on charges of filing false information with his draft board.
LONDON, March 17--W.S. Gilbert, that old assailant of the nobility, would have rubbed his eyes in disbelief.
THAT stunning stock-market coup that produced a $2-million jackpot in Schenley Industries earlier this week continues to titillate Wall Street.
CHICAGO, March 17 (AP)-- There was scattered violence today as the milk holding action by the National Farmers Organization went through its second full day. Thousands of gallons of milk were dumped.

HONITON, England, March 17 (Reuters)--Britain's ruling Labor party suffered a new electoral setback today, coming in third and last in a special election here for a Parliamentary seat kept by the Conservative party.

WASHINGTON, March 17-- Senators J.W. Fulbright and Wayne Morse split sharply today over the extent to which President Johnson's latest bid for Congressional backing on Latin America would "morally" bind legislators to support future Administration requests.

Piano pieces by Italian composers and the Brahms Sonata in F sharp minor (Op. 2) were played by Letea Cifarelli at the Carnegie Recital Hall last night. Since her pianistic and Interpretive abilities were not wellsuited to the Brahms Sonata, it is too bad Miss Cifarelli did not find more Italian works to fill out the evening.
A four-man panel headed by Theodore W. Kheel laid plans yesterday for an intensive mediation effort aimed at settling the newspaper contract dispute.
SCION of 670 years of Grimaldi family rule over the Principality of Monaco, Prince Rainier Louis Henri Maxence Bertrand is a properly peppery potentate.

WASHINGTON, March 17-- Felix Karas, 58-year-old manager of a plastics plant in Los Angeles, entered the West Sculpture Hall of the National Gallery of Art today at an urgent trot and headed for the most expensive painting in the world.

The United States Government continues to observe a double standard on cigarette smoking. By Congressional action, cigarette manufacturers are required to label cigarette packages sold in this country: "Caution: Cigarette smoking may be hazardous to health." But this warning label is not required on cigarettes manufactured for export.

A nation finances its essential institutions in various ways: its corporations and industries through their earnings; governmental agencies through taxes; churches through private donations; universities through endowments, taxes and government contracts.
A snowstorm that reached near-blizzard proportions sneaked into the city while it slept early yesterday, snarling air and highway travel, disrupting subway service and delaying commuters.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 17 --An alert customs officer at Ratmalana Airport here recently noticed a baggage porter open and quickly close an attache case that had already been inspected. When the officer opend the case himself, he found a small envelope full of blue sapphires worth about $200,000.

PARIS, March 17--The Government of Monaco paid $8-million today for Aristotle Onassis' share in the Societe des Bains de Mer--the company that owns the casino at Monte Carlo and most of the tiny principality's luxury establishments. In the process, Mr. Onassis doubled his money.
The Chrysler Corporation continued yesterday its reorganization of Rootes Motors, Ltd., naming Gilbert Hunt as managing director and chief executive officer of the British Automobile manufacturer.
RAINBOW LAKE, Alberta --The "No Vacancy" sign was out the other night as a group of 70-odd trailers huddled together in the subzero weather of northwestern Alberta.

WASHINGTON, March 17-- Nineteen of the nation's Republican Governors decided here tonight that they would not be drawn into an automatic, uncritical endorsement of President Johnson's Vietnam policy when they visit the White House tomorrow as his guests.

NAM BAC, Laos, March 16-- Laotian Government forces and North Vietnamese soldiers are engaged in a struggle for control of the mountaintops overlooking this strategic valley midway between the royal capital, Luang Prabang, and the North Vietnamese border.

A second major Canadian producer of newsprint announced a price increase yesterday. In another pricing development, a supplier of precious metals said increased demand had made higher charges necessary.

LONG BEACH, Calif., March 17 (AP)--Officials of the Pacific Coast Metal Trades Council, representing shipyard workers, hailed today a reunification agreement voted yesterday as "the biggest thing to happen to organized labor in the West in 25 years."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. March 17--Although Dan Sikes held the lead after 36 holes of the $100,000 Greater Jacksonville open golf tournament today, the principal news was that Arnold Palmer failed to survive the cutoff for the concluding two rounds.
Mexico has canceled her order for two American supersonic aircraft because of the mounting costs of the projected 280passenger plane.
The spot rate on the British pound eased silghtly yesterday in moderate trading on foreignexchange markets here. The closing rate of $2.7965 was four points below the final quotation Thursday.
WASHINGTON, March 17--"My conscience is clear," Senator Thomas J. Dodd told the Senate ethics committee today as it concluded five days of public hearings on his tangled financial affairs.

In the four years since Buffy Sainte-Marie first sang at a Macdougal Street cabaret, the 25-year-old Creek Indian girl from Sebago Lake, Me,, has made several recordings, written songs that gave pop hits to Paul Anka and Bobby Darin, and built up a large, devoted, almost cultish following here.
PARIS, March 17--The Government, already shaken by a narrow election victory, was faced today with social unrest in widely separated regions of the country.

KANSAS CITY, March 17-- Frank Litsky, a New York Times sports writer, received the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics Award of Merit today at the N.A.I.A.'s Basketball Hall of Fame luncheon.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)--The Post Office Department, faced with the need to hire about 150,000 workers this year, said today it would end residence requirements for certain postal jobs.

Wheat and potato futures-- the week's most spectacular commodities--remained relatively stable in price yesterday. July wheat closed at $1.85 5/8-7/8, a fraction of a cent stronger than the day before. The May delivery for Maine potatoes closed between $2.75 and $2.77 a hundred pounds, compared with about $2.75 a day earlier.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)--Arrests for the illegal use of marijuana have doubled in two years and now include "age groups and economic levels which were relatively drug-free previously," according to Henry L. Giordano, United States narcotics commissioner.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)--President Johnson's Administration soon will propose special tax incentives for Small Business Investment Companies, Bernard L. Boutin, administrator of the Small Business Administration, said today.
Twenty-one sweet-voiced, peaches-and-cream Vienna Choir Boys went through their paces last night at Town Hall with the usual blend of skill and innocence.

PELHAM, N.Y., March 17 --Frederick W. Greenfield, a member of the board of directors of the Trade Bank Trust Company, Fifth Avenue and 48th Street, New York, died yesterday at Mount Vernon Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived at 200 Boulevard here,

Directors of the Kennecott Copper Corporation and Peabody Coal Company of St. Louis announced yesterday that their boards had agreed to proceed on the estimated $465.5-million purchase of Peabody Coal. The price is intended to produce $47.50 in cash for each Peabody common share, subject to Peabody stockholders.

WASHINGTON, March 17-- A campaign for a constitutional convention to modify the Supreme Court's one-man, onevote rule is nearing success. It would be the first such convention since the Constitution was drafted in Philadelphia in 1787.

More than four decades after the Scopes trial teaching the theory of evolution remains a forbidden subject in some parts of this country. In a recent letter to the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, Nobel Laureate Hermann J. Muller reports that such teaching is still illegal in three states and that many instructors in these and other states fear to discuss the subject.
The Greater New York Chapter of Links, Inc., will hold its annual Easter luncheon next Saturday in the Americana's Imperial Ballroom.

HARTFORD, March 17 (UPI) --The Democratic national chairman, John M. Bailey, denied today that Senator Dodd's financial troubles stemmed from inadequate Democratic party support for his Senatorial campaigns.

WHITE PLAINS, March 17-- Gordon W. Bickert, a senior associate of the law firm of Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside and Wolff, 25 Broadway, Manhattan, died yesterday of a heart attack here. He was 50 years old, and lived at 2 Payne Road, Elmsford, N. Y.

WESTBURY, L. I., March 17 --It was St. Patrick's Day. The snow was falling, the wind was blowing and the odds were "any price" against harness racing at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. By nightfall, though, there was a minimum of white on the scene. Green, most of it in the pockets, however temporarily, of the fans and appropriately-tinted broth, free to the buffs, was the dominant color.
Marvin Cherney, an artist, died yesterday at Mount Sinal Hospital after a long illness, He was 41 years old and lived at 112 East 17th Street.

The marriage of Miss K. Serena Evans, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Gordon Evans of New York and Fishers Island, N.Y., to Robert Rose Carson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carson of Clinton and Geneva, N.Y., took place yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of Notre Dame. The Rev. Joseph F. McGann performed the ceremony.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., March 17 (AP)--A father and son rowing team started out for a 3,000 mile row to England today, but they were back on land after eight hours of rowing in bitter cold and choppy waters.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)--The Civil Aeronautics Board has ordered an airlineby-airline study of customer complaints.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 17--Why did the police release Zoran Sekulic, a 20year-old university student, almost immediately after they had arrested him for hit-andrun driving?

CHICAGO, March 17--Dr. and Mrs. Michael Newton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Lees Newton, to Stephen Conrad Stuntz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurance Fitzhugh Stuntz of Pelham Manor, N.Y.
The Manhattan Democratic organization "is on the brink of bankruptcy, political and financial," Assemblyman Frank A. Rossetti, the organization's new acting leader said yesterday.

A NEW Federal law redefining antiques is causing considerable ferment as collectors reconsider what had been the arbitrary date separating the age of craftsmanship from the era of bad design. Although the law is not likely to affect the market as much as changes in taste will, dealers and collectors have reacted strongly.
NEW DELHI, March 17 (AP)--Prime Minister Indira Gandhi won her first victory in India's new Parliament today.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 17 --The chairman of the Long Is land Bridge Study Committee indicated today that existing plans might be altered so that a proposed span to Connecticut would be aligned more closely with the Long Island jetport proposed yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.

THE delightful practice of mounting temporary ex hibitions of outstanding works of art from small out-of-town museums is one of the most persistently felicitous features of the New York art scene. This week has brought the opening of another of these glorious shows--an anthology of "Treasures" from the Walters Art Gallery in Baltimore.
ALBANY, March 17 (UPI)-- Gov. Rockefeller today named Gabriel Hauge, president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, to the State Banking Board.

INSTEAD of paying to see "Macabro," why not stand outside the theater and wait for a car to run over somebody? The picture offers the same caliber and quota of entertainment. Here is another souped-up parade of human oddities, from the exotic to the sickening, looped together like an international peep Show. The film presented by
Louis Bevilacqua, a civic worker and wholesale liquor salesman, died Thursday in Interboro General Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 51 years old and lived at 87-45 107th Street, Ozone Park, Queens.
MIAMI, March 17--The New York Mets--fresh from their 23-18 debacle against the Boston Red Sox--executed one of their far-fetched turnabouts tonight.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 17 (UPI)--Walter Fulton of Orange, Calif., powered his Harley-Davidson to a record victory today in a 100-mile motorcycle race for amateur riders at the Daytona International Speedway.
VAIL, Colo., March 17--Race officials got Jean-Claude Killy and the rest of the international field competing in skiing's world series out of bed 90 minutes ahead of time this morning.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 17--A single jet fighter-bomber of the United States Navy sliced through soupy skies and violent antiaircraft fire last night in a daring raid on one of North Vietnam's most important power plants.

DANBURY, Conn., March 17 --The engagement of Miss Martha Brandouin Moser to Robert Sloat Rendell, son of Mrs. Jesse Rendell of New York and the late Mr. Rendell, has been announced by her parents, the Rev. and Mrs. Harold J. Moser of Danbury.

The Philips Incandescent Lamp Works--99.98 per centowned by Philips Industries, N.V.--reported yesterday that its earnings declined last year for the first time since 1961. The giant Dutch electronic producer said its profits were down despite a new high in sales for the year.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI)--President Johnson observed St. Patrick's Day today by accepting a cut-glass vase of fresh shamrocks from the Irish Ambassador, William P. Fay.
N.Y. STOCK EXCHANGE Stocks improved in the aft ernoon and closed up in lessactive trading; volume, 10.02 million shares.

In a contest between selfstyled "simple country folk" and "city slickers," Southern Illinois will meet Marquette for the championship of the 30th annual National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden this afternoon.

COLUMBIA, Conn., March 17 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. E. Malcolm Stannard of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Linda Stannard, to John F.X. Warburton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Warburton of Brooklyn, New York.
Plans for the biggest Palm Sunday parade in Harlem's history were thrown awry yesterday by the news that the star attraction, Adam Clayton Powell, had decided not to attend.
Mayor Lindsay vetoed yesterday three bills designed to reduce the price of milk here by about three cents a quart.

HONG KONG, Saturday, March 18 (AP)--Chinese Communist army units loyal to Mao Tse-tung have seized control of farms and factories in three more southeast China provinces, provincial broadcasts said today.
Edgar Bergen, who once advised his daughter, Candice, against a theater career because he thought she couldn't act, will appear with her in a stage comedy.
EVANSTON, Ill., March 17 (UPI)--Virginia Tech upset Indiana, 79-70, and Dayton edged Tennessee, 53-52, last night in the National Collegiate Mideast Regional Playoffs.

WASHINGTON, March 17-- Dental scientists reported today that "an intensive program" was under way to develop a vaccine to immunize people against the bacteria that cause tooth decay, the nation's most widespread disease.

Forty years have passed since the reorganization of New York State's executive branch by Gov. Alfred E. Smith went into effect. He persuaded the voters to approve a constitutional amendment that consolidated 122 separate boards, commissions and offices into eighteen state departments and 47 other agencies.

TORONTO, March 17--Viola R. MacMillan was sentenced today to nine months in jail and fined $10,000 as a result of her conviction for wash trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange during the Windfall Oils and Mines, Ltd., scandal of 1964. Her lawyer said he would appeal the sentence.

D.P. Brother Co., the Detroit advertising agency that handles millions of dollars in billings for the General Motors Corporation, has become a subsidiary of the Leo Burnett Company of Chicago, the nation's fifth largest agency.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 17--Yugoslavia, which prides herself on being the bellwether of the world's Communist-ruled nations--and is regarded by a few of the more doctrinaire as the Judas goat instead--took one more long stride into unorthodoxy this week.

DETROIT, March 17 (UPI) --Recalls were announced today by the Buick Motor Division of General Motors Corporation for nearly 6,000 cars and by the Chrysler Corporation for more than 200 Dodge trucks: Both returns involved possible brake defects in the vehicles.
WASHINGTON, March 17-- A large Soviet spacecraft has separated into two spacecraft in orbit in what may be a test for a manned flight, American space officials said today.
VOTAW, Tex., Saturday, March 18--A 3-year-old girl who fell 28 feet into an abandoned water well last night was rescued early today after being wedged in the narrow space for nine hours.
The Newspaper Reporters Association of New York City yesterday announced its annual awards, which included four to members of The New York Times.

FRANKLIN, Mass., March 17 --Mr. and Mrs. Frederiek Saltman have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Faye Deborah Saltman, to Dr. Elliot S. Gershon, son of Mrs. David Gershon of Brooklyn, New York, and the late Mr. Gershon.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People gave support yesterday to the recommendation of the National Advisory Commission on Selective Service that local draft boards be abolished.
NEWARK, March 17--A jury today acquitted seven men accused of extorting money from a former Hoboken pier operator after deliberating for two hours and forty minutes. The trial lasted a month.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 17--A spokesman said today that Secretary General Thant "is continuing his efforts for a peaceful settlement in Vietnam," but did not wish to give any details at this time.
Fact-finders attempting to resolve a contract dispute between the city and its policemen and firemen have recommended that the employes be given extra pay after 12 and 20 years of service.

Mr. and Mrs. Marco Rosales of 365 West End Avenue and Bogota, Colombia, have announced the approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Victoria Rosales, to Jay Frank Messina. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Messina of Ozone Park, Queens.
Having finished his marathon series of eight concerto programs Sunday in Carnegie Hall, Mstislav Rostropovich turned up at Hunter College last night for his only local recital of the season.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy, surrounded by reporters who turned a St. Patrick's Day party into a news conference on his relations with President Johnson, described Mr. Johnson yesterday as "an outstanding President [whom] I look forward to campaigning for in 1968."

DJIBOUTI, French Somaliland, March. 17--Two hundred French Foreign Legionnaires took up positions today facing the offices of French Somaliland's deputy in the French National Assembly, a farmer bank clerk who has been exhorting the populace to vote for independence from France in a referendum Sunday.
HONG KONG, March 17-- The Chinese Communist press made an unusually heavy attack today against British authorities in Hong Kong.
ROME, March 17--The Italian Chamber of Deputies approved today a plan to put the economic "miracle" of the last ten years on an organized basis for the next five years.

SINCE no group of short stories could posibly carry the distinction or the prestige of a Broadway play, it will be hard to argue that these short stories by Arthur Miller deserve the same attention that is accorded his stage works--the same attention, if not necessarily as much. For in spite of a surprisingly deprecatory introduction in
Mr. Mitchell had over-all responsibility for the million and one functional details that go into the mechanical management of The Times's plant and all its equipment.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 17--Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, South Vietnam's chief of state, sent an ultimatum to the Constituent Assembly today, but the deputies took the message in good humor and said the general didn't really mean it.
Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Eisenhower, warned yesterday that "the possibility of recession has become clearer week by week, day by day."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 17--Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers Union, said today that "we don't want to leave" the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Besides leaving many horse players cold, the white blanket at Aqueduct yesterday cost the State of New York a lot of cool cash--about a quarter of a million dollars worth. Because of the snow and the freezing weather, the nine-race thoroughbred program was canceled by the New York State Racing Commission, on the recommendation of Dick Strickland, the supervisor of racing strips and courses for the New York Racing Association.

SEATTLE, March 17--The North American International team surged back to win its second-round match in the Vanderbilt Cup contest here this afternoon. Alvin Roth, William Root and Edgar Kaplan, all of New York; Norman Kay of Philadelphia, and Eric Murray and Sam Kehela, both of Toronto, trailed Joe Jabon's Seattle team by 15 international match points going into the second half of a 64-deal match, but finally won by 21 points.
MOSCOW, March 17 (AP) --Richard M. Nixon, ignored by Soviet leaders, took a tourist's look at Moscow today and talked with friendly Russians in the streets.

SCULPTURE: NEW YORK SCENE," a bright, concentrated little group show, has settled into the small halls and galleries of the Riverside Museum way up at 103d Street and Riverside Drive. It is well worth the trip.
NEWARK, March 17--One victim of today's snowstorm was Gov. Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey.
The bond market, resting after its workout this week, closed yesterday in undramatic fashion.
LAGOS, Nigeria, March 17-- The military Government of Nigeria issued today a sweeping Constitutional decree restoring considerable autonomy to the federation's four regions.

WASHINGTON, March 17-- ' The Administration moved today to counter reports that it would soft-pedal the nondiscrimination requirements of the new model cities program for rebuilding slum neighborhoods. In a sharply worded speech to a Federal Bar Association meeting here, the Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, H. Ralph Taylor, said discrimination in either the employment or housing phases of the program would not be "tolerated." '

SEATTLE, March 17--The North American International team surged back to win its second-round match in the Vanderbilt Cup contest here this afternoon. Alvin Roth, William Root and Edgar Kaplan, all of New York; Norman Kay of Philadelphia, and Eric Murray and Sam Kehela, both of Toronto, trailed Joe Jabon's Seattle team by 15 international match points going into the second half of a 64-deal match, but finally won by 21 points.
MOSCOW, March 17 (AP) --Richard M. Nixon, ignored by Soviet leaders, took a tourist's look at Moscow today and talked with friendly Russians in the streets.

SCULPTURE: NEW YORK SCENE," a bright, concentrated little group show, has settled into the small halls and galleries of the Riverside Museum way up at 103d Street and Riverside Drive. It is well worth the trip.
NEWARK, March 17--One victim of today's snowstorm was Gov. Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey.
Miss Christine Frances Covey and William Michael O'Neal were married here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Eugene O'Neil performed the ceremony at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church.

LAWRENCE, Kan. March 17 (UPI)--Houston turned back favored but jittery Kansas, 6653, with a pressure zone defense tonight in the second game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association midwest regional basketball tournament.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 6 per cent in production for the week ended March 11, compared with the level in the corresponding 1966 week.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., March 17--The United States hinted for the first time today that it might reluctantly use its economic power to change the world monetary system unless other wealthy countries cooperated in improving the present system.

BALTIMORE, March 17-- John Mitchell, engineering director of The New York Times until his retirement in 1964, died of a heart ailment today at the University of Maryland Hospital. He would have been 65 years old on March 29.
President Johnson's request that Congress approve a resolution authorizing extra funds for economic development in Latin America has gotten a mixed reception.
A firming tendency developed in a less-active stock market yesterday and prices managed to score slight gains.
Tony Pastor's Greenwich Village night spot has lost its liquor license, the State Liquor Authority said yesterday.

ANYONE walking past the 100-year-old brownstone at the corner of Joralemon Street and Garden Place in Brooklyn would have difficulty identifying the savory aromas wafting from the basement. They are likely to be a blend of many foreign cuisines, including those of Argentina, Iran, Greece, China, Peru and France.

When youngsters went to the Countee Cullen public-library branch in the center of Harlem there were so few children's books that they had to line up at the return desk and wait to take one out. But that was two years ago.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 17 (AP)--Cassius Clay is such a heavy favorite these days that bookmakers here aren't getting much business on the heavyweight champion's fights.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March l7--New York University's fencing team, whose goal it is this season to retain its national intercollegiate championship, held a small lead over its foremost challenger, Columbia, at the conclusion of the first day of the two-day Intercollegiate Fencing Association's title event today at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
WASHINGTON, March 17-- United States officials, preparing for the conference at Guam next week on the Vietnam war, report increasing signs of slight cracks in the Vietcong guerrilla structure.

The premiere of Robert Shaughnessy's "The Deer's Cry" and what were said to be the first performances here of Dyorak's. Sextet for Strings (Op. 48) and Louis Haber's Sonatina for Solo Violin were given late yesterday afternoon in a Kohon String, Quartet concert at Town Hall. Also on the program was Dvorak's Terzetto for Two Violins and Viola.
Stocks on the American Stock Exchange turned mixed yesterday on reduced volume.

WASHINGTON, March 17-- Judge George L. Hart Jr. expects to make some ruling before April 11 in the lawsuit brought by former Representative Adam Clayton Powell against Speaker John W. McCormack and other leaders and officers of the House, according to a qualified legal source.
Administrative changes in maritime concerns were announced here yesterday.

LOCK HAVEN, Pa., March 17 (AP)--Lock Haven State College, the defending champion, built a firm lead as the semi-finals of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics wrestling tournament ended tonight.
Football being the season of madness, five inches of snow on the playing field meant nothing to Notre Dame and Fordham, particularly on St. Patrick's Day.
A modern, air-conditioned midtown motel has been acquired as a treatment center for narcotics addicts by the State Department of Mental Hygiene.
JUAREZ, Mexico, March 17 (AP)--Charlotte Ford Niarchos filed a petition in the First Civil Court of Juarez today for divorce from Stavros Niarchos, 58-year-old multimillionaire shipping magnate.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 17--Horace Clarke's first two hits of the exhibition season, both doubles, were wasted tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Yankees, 4-2.
The General Electric Company confirmed here yesterday that it his placed an order with Hitachi, Ltd., of Tokyo, for 12 gas turbines.

TRENTON, March 18--Joseph Comley of the Trenton Club defeated William Bowen of the Princeton University faculty, 15-11, 11-15, 15-11, 5-15, 15-8, in the final of the Central New Jersey Squash Racquets Association championship today.
INDIANAPOLIS, March 18 (UPI)--Greg Weld, of Kansas City, has been named to drive a car entered by J. Frank Harrison, Chattanooga, Tenn., in the 500-mile Indianapolis Motor Speedway race May 30.

The Vassar College Club of New York held its 45th annual opera benefit at the Metropolitan Opera House Saturday night. GENEVA, March 20 The United Nations Human Rights Commission abandoned today its attempt to complete action on a proposed international agreement under which all time limits on the prosecution of war crimes and crimes against humanity would be abolished.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) The Senate approved today an additional appropriation of $12.2-billion to support American forces in Vietnam. The vote was 77 to 3.
The annual luncheon and bridge party for the benefit of the Immaculate Conception Day Nursery, Inc., in Brooklyn, will take place March 30 in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.

HONG KONG, March 20 (AP) The United States Consulate warned seven Americans Monday they would be breaking the law if they sailed to Haiphong with medical supplies for North Vietnam. But the Americans said they would go, despite the warning.
The New York Philharmonic will raise its ticket prices next season for all programs, during the regular subscription series, except those on the Young People's concerts.
The 41st annual New York Golden Gloves finals at Madison Square Garden last night were just what the 17,204 fans who turned out, including Mayor Lindsay, had expected.
ALBANY, March 20 The Democratic-controlled Assembly voted unanimously today to set up a temporary state commission to study the high cost of political campaigns.
HOMESTEAD, Fla., March 20 The New York Mets visited their minor league base here today, giving rise to reports that the whole team was being farmed out.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 21 Outnumbered armor and artillery units of the United States Ninth Infantry Division held off an allnight attack by a Vietcong regiment and by today counted at least 288 enemy dead on the battlefield 31 miles north of Saigon.

BONN, March 20 One week after the leadership of the National Democratic party split on the question of how far to the right the party should go, the leadership of the Free Democratic party is divided on how far left it should go.

A MINK-COATED matron turned around in her seat at the morning showing of Alexander's import collection yesterday and asked Betty Furness, "Are miniskirts still in?" "That's not mini, it's short," said the actress, who was appointed earlier this month as special assistant for consumer affairs...
CHICAGO, March 20 Lloyd Eldon Miller Jr., who was sentenced to death more than 11 years ago in the murder of an 8-year-old girl, was ordered freed today.

TWIGGY, London's mini-bosomed fashion model of the year, looks just like your next door neighbor, if he happens to be a skinny 12-year-old boy, and when she arrived in New York yesterday, she was dressed accordingly in short pants.

WASHINGTON, March 20 President Johnson's ap- pointment of Robert William Komer as, in effect, the No. 2 American official in Saigon has given him a man on the scene whose style and outlook are much in tune with his own. Like the President, Mr. Komer is a man...

The case of Senator Dodd of Connecticut, whose financial affairs have been the subject of public hearings by the Senate Committee on Standards and Conduct, points up the unhealthy ways in which the nation finances its politics and Congress polices its own behavior.

Big-boat skippers who do their sailing on Long Island Sound will get additional options this season in their choice of "qualifying" distance races. But options in the use of life preservers, particularly at small-boat regattas, have been reduced.

Col. Lewis Sanders, a retired Army officer who commanded the 304th Field Artillery in World War I and served in World War II as military consultant to the Senate Military Affairs Committee, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived at 626 East 20th Street.
The short-interest position of shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange rose by 628,877 shares to 14,070,002 in the month ended March 15 from 13,441,125 in mid-February.
LONDON, March 20 Labor and Conservative leaders accused each other today of responsibility for the bloodshed in Aden.

Alfred L. Jaros Jr., a consulting engineer who specialized in mechanical and electrical engineering plans for skyscrapers, hospitals and school buildings, died Friday of a heart attack while vacationing at Las Palmas in the Canary Islands. He was 77 years old.

More than 50 Parks Department employes pushed their way into the office of the city's labor relations director yesterday and kept him trapped behind his desk, screaming that they were not getting raises they won in contract negotiations last year.
The Gulf Oil Corporation said yesterday it planned to spend about a record $1-billion on capital-exploratory projects in 1967.

MONTE CARLO, March 20 (UPI) Gardnar Mulloy, the 52year-old Miamian, put up a hard fight but was eliminated in the opening round of the Monte Carlo international tennis tournament today by Keith Carpenter, the Canadian Davis Cup player, 6-4, 4-6, 7-5.
MOSCOW, March 20 (AP) Richard M. Nixon returned today to Sokolniki Park, where he had his "kitchen debate" with Nikita S. Khrushchev, and was besieged by Russians wanting his autograph.
MELBOURNE, Australia March 20 (AP) The Australian Lawn Tennis Association voted today to urge a two-year trial period for open tennis.
The space problem at Kennedy International Airport is forcing some foreign airlines who are newcomers to New York to seek room in terminals of United States airlines.
NEW DELHI, March 20 The United States Central Intelligence Agency came under severe attack by the Opposition in Parliament today over alleged activities in India.

The spot rate on the British pound firmed yesterday as sterling met brisk commercial demand on foreign-exchange markets here. The final quotation of $2.7967 was two points higher than the closing quotation on Friday.

NIMITZ HILL, Guam, Tuesday, March 21 The United States has just signed a $150miliion economic aid agreement with South Vietnam that will, among other things, involve much larger rice shipments this year to combat shortages and rising prices.

DETROIT, March 20 Current confidential talks between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers Union are believed to include a tentative assessment of what a guaranteed annual income for the wage earners of the nation's second largest car maker would cost.

Early one Saturday morning some weeks ago Mayor Lindsay and an assortment of experts, including Edgar B. Young, who helped to supervise the building of Lincoln Center, and Harold S. Prince, who produces and directs musicals on Broadway, scrambled around the backstage areas of theaters on West 42d Street.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 20 (AP) At least 160 people were known dead today from floods and rain-loosened earth and rock that cascaded down on cities north of Sao Paulo yesterday.

The impact of Truman Capote's "nonfiction novel" has given new life to an old form. Dick Schaap, in the introduction to "Turned On," writes that "this is not a new literary form," explaining: "It is simply reporting." Unfortunately.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) Straybourne Betts is only 10 years old but already is a licensed medical laboratory technician.

CANTON, China, March 20 A picture of production break- downs, struggles between rival groups, factories deprived of leadership and attempted sabotage preceded last week's assumption of power by the Chinese army in Kwangtung Province, of which this city is the capital.

IN an age of specialization and assembly-line produc tion, Armand Ribeiro is a rarity who thrives on variety. He is a cabinetmaker whose tidy, eight-man workshop in Flatbush produces anything from a piece of furniture for the home to built-ins for a large suite of offices.
It was overcoat weather when spring arrived officially at 2:37, A.M. today.

LONDON, March 20 The Grade Organization, Britain's biggest show-business booking agency, agreed today to sell out to Electric and Musical Industries, the worldwide maker and distributor of phonograph records.
Montgomery Ward Co. yesterday released its financial resuits for the fiscal year ended January 31, reporting a 27 per cent decline in earnings and an 8.3 per cent gain in sales.

Diana Sands, one of Broadway's leading Negro performers, will appear as Cleopatra in George Barnard Shaw's "Caesar and Cleopatra" at Theater Atlanta, a resident repertory company in the Georgia capital. She will take over the role tomorrow night from Kathryn Loder, whose right hand is in a cast as the result of a fractured ring finger.

Despite some gains in public understanding and more careful practices by Federal agencies, the grave threat from the widespread use of highly toxic pesticides which the late Rachel Carson exposed in her book, "Silent Spring," still exists.
WESTBURY, L. I., March 20 George Sholty drove three winners at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
Short-term interest rates continued to move down yesterday as outstanding Treasury bills rose in price five to 15 basis points and the regular Monday bill auction drew "very aggressive" bids.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) Farmers plan to increase plantings for 1967 crops about 6 per cent 18 million acres above the 298 million seeded last year.
OLD GREENWICH, Conn., March 20 Walter S. Lemmon, radio engineer and inventor, died Saturday in his home at 9 Quintard Avenue. He was 71 years old.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 20 A group of conservationists here are fighting for the establishment of what would ultimately be the largest state nature preserve in Connecticut.

PEORIA, Ill., March 20 (UPI) The judge presiding over the Richard Speck mass murder trial barred a Chicago newspaper reporter from the courtroom today on the ground that he had violated one of the stringent guidelines for news coverage of the case.
LONDON, March 20 New Yorkers who are tired of ice and snow might consider spending their next winter in London.

Reductions in the Federal Reserve discount rate and in the prime, or minimum, businessloan rate of the commercial banks are "imminent," Robert H. Bethke, executive vice president of the Discount Corporation of New York, said yesterday.
LONDON, Tuesday, March 21 Lieut. Gen. Sir Frederick Morgan, who laid the plans for the Allied invasion of Europe in World War II, died yesterday at his home in Northwood. His age was 73.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) The House Agriculture Committee approved today the Johnson Administration's request for a $195-million authorization to continue the food stamp program for the needy but added a requirement to make the states pay a fifth of the cost.

Charles V. Graham, a senior member of the law firm of Simpson Thacher Bartlett for almost 50 years until his retirement in 1963, died yesterday of a stroke at his home, 169 East 69th Street. Mr. Graham, who also lived at East Gate Road, Huntington, L.I., was 78 years old.
Profit taking reduced industrial prices yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
Dr. Edward S. Elliott, former director of athletics at Columbia University, died in St. Mary Abbotts Hospital in London on March 8, the university announced yesterday. He was 89 years old.

DJIBOUTI, French Somaliland, March 20 At least 11 Somalis were killed today as French troops used submachine guns, grenades and armored cars to crush rioting in the Somali quarter of this shabby East African port.

NOUNS to apply to Gary Graffman: power, sever ity, seriousness, authority, control, technique, logic, One could drum up quite a few more while listening to his piano recital last night in Carnegie Hall. You will note that charm is not among the words. Mr. Graffman is not that kind of pianist.
WASHINGTON, March 20 The Federal Government called for an equal role with the states today in the agency that will control air pollution in the New York metropolitan area.

Three players from Canada, three from Philadelphia and one each from Brooklyn and Pawling, N. Y., reached the quarterfinals of the 23d invitation scholastic squash racquets tournament yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

THE title of Robert Shaw's fourth novel suggests another book on the Eichmann trial and another recital of Nazi cruelties and terrors. To say that the book is and is not what the title implies is to indicate the kind of book he has written. For it is a combination of suspense thriller and political confessional and it is praise for Mr. Shaw's skill that he makes the combination work.
WASHINGTON, March 20 The House Appropriations Committee recommended today that Secret Service protection be continued for Mrs. John F. Kennedy and her two children.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20--Arthur J. Goldberg, the United States delegate, today deplored the showing in New York of a film on Africa as "grossly distorted" and "socially irresponsible."
BALTIMORE, March 20 (UPI) Guy Burt's Royal Fret won her third straight race today when she led all the way in the Guilford Purse at Pimlico.
The inoperative gap at Aqueduct was bridged yesterday and the thoroughbred horses returned to competition after cancelation of Friday's and Saturday's programs.
Six building-material producers have set up a new corporation to increase the supply of low-down-payment financing for home buyers.

Cassius Clay predicted yesterday his heavyweight title defense against Zora Folley tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden "might go 15 rounds, to give the commercials a chance to advertise" although there will be no television in the New York area.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 20 Mickey Mantle, in absentia, and Whitey Ford, very much present, added bloom to a brightening Yankee picture today as the Bombers invaded the training base of the Dodgers and made off with a 7-6 victory.
WASHINGTON, March 20 Discounting predictions of massive mail tie-ups across the nation, the House Appropriations Committee trimmed $99.6-million today from post office money requests.
PARIS, March 20 (Reuters) The possible rigging of the state-run tierce, in which bettors must forecast the first three finishers in a Sunday horse race, was being investigated today.
An indecisive trend prevailed throughout most of yesterday's stock market session, and trading was relatively light.

WASHINGTON, March 20 Personal income showed an unusually small rise in February as payrolls in the private sector declined for the first time in almost two years, the Commerce Department reported today.

IT was the late Logan Pearsall Smith who, I seem to remember, dilated at length upon the possibility of boredom itself becoming a mystical experience. It is a comment of great insight; indeed it is a clue to much of the reasoning behind contemporary avant-garde dance.

Suffolk County Judge Floyd Sarisohn went on trial yesterday charged with helping a prostitute to flout the law, locking up an innocent elderly woman, tampering with court records, fixing a friend's ticket for speeding and other "highly improper" and "grossly illegal" actions.
WASHINGTON, March 20 Senator J.W. Fulbright and other members of the influential Foreign Relations Committee were reported today to be bridling over mounting White House pressure on them.
The tenants at Gracie Mansion have had three nights without a furnace, but the landlords have told them that a new one will be ready for use late today.

Frank Wille, the New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday his approval of a formula designed to reduce the requirement for savings banks in New York to make mandatory contributions to their reserve funds.

CHICAGO, March 20 (AP)-- A circuit court in Michigan, the F.B.I. and Wisconsin's Attorney General were asked today to halt "vandalism and terror" in the National Farmers Organization's drive to force up prices for the dairy farmer's milk.

There are two dangerous legislative attempts in Albany to re-enact all the vestiges of the McCarthy era that were swept away by the Supreme Court decision in January which held the state's Feinberg Law unconstitutional.
WASHINGTON, March 20--The controversial Storm King hydroelectric plant planned by Consolidated Edison was defended today by Dr. Edward Teller, the nuclear physicist.
MIAMI BEACH, March 20 (AP) A pair of California teen-agers took seventh place in regular doubles in the only minor events standings change today at the American Bowling Congress tournament.

ADEN, March 20 The Aden radio announced today a ban on demonstrations protesting the execution in Saudi Arabia Fri day of 17 persons charged with subversive activities.
Prices ended mixed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
A fire during the rush hour in a five-story office building on the southwest corner of Lexington Avenue and 59th Street delayed traffic for nearly an hour last night.
WASHINGTON, March 20 The Treasury bill rate fell substantially at today's auction, with the rate on six-months bills at the lowest point since August, 1965, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

ST. JOHN'S baseball coach, Jack Kaiser, took a look at his baseball field on the Jamaica campus yesterday and said, "I doubt we can play our opening game Wednesday." St. John's diamond, like most front yards and golf courses in the area, was covered with snow.
The former manager of the City College cafeteria at 138th Street and Convent Avenue was arrested yesterday on charges of taking kickbacks from companies that sold food to the cafeteria.

Whatever they may feel obliged to say publicly, nearly all leaders of East African nations will be relieved that a majority of the voters in French Somaliland elected, faute de mieux, temporarily to remain under the control of Paris. This probably includes even Premier Abdirizak of the neighboring Somali Republic.
MIAMI, March 20 Skippers had just what they wanted today a fair wind to Jamaica for the first leg of the 811mile Miami-to-Montego Bay yacht race.
DETROIT, March 20 (AP) The long Easter weekend was slated to cut heavily into United States auto production this week.
The director of Selective Service here said today that although the actor George Hamilton had been reclassified 1-A it was "very unlikely" he would be called for active service because of his age.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, March 21 (UPI)--Buel Ray Wortham, an American tourist who spent nearly three months in solitary confinement in a Soviet jail, boarded a plane for home today.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) Senator John Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, said today that the Senate ethics committee had been left free of any pushing or pulling by Senate colleagues in its investigation of Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.
The Lindsay administration proposed 46 amendments yesterday to a new housing maintenance code the administration itself had introduced to the City Council five weeks ago.

ALBANY, March 20 Proponents of stronger conflict-of-interest laws proposed today that a stringent code of ethics for Legislators, legislative employes and state employes be added to the State Constitution this year.

Miss Barbara Ruth Fahs, daughter of the Rev. Dr. Charles B. Fahs and Mrs. Fahs of Tokyo, was married there yesterday to Nicholas Eby Charles. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Jay Charles of Los Angeles.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 20 It keeps getting more noticeable as the spring training season moves along. Sandy Koufax has retired, but his name constantly creeps into conversations. The one fellow who is more aware than most of the giant void that Sandy's departure left, however, is Chris Short of the Phillies. Short is being labeled as the heir apparent to the Dodger marvel as the best left-handed pitcher in the league.
MOSCOW, March 20 (Reuters) Soviet leaders were reported unyielding today in their opposition to Austria's bid for association with the European Common Market.

WASHINGTON, March 20 The administrator of the National Traffic Safety Agency, Dr. William Haddon Jr., called today for a national debate over whether or not Americans need cars that can exceed 100 miles an hour.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20 A United Nations political mission left today for London, Cairo, Saudi Arabia and Aden in search of an electoral plan for the creation of an independent nation in South Arabia.

Hundreds of shouting students surrounded Chancellor R. Gordon Hoxie yesterday on the Long Island University Brooklyn campus and demanded reinstatement of the school's provost, Dr. William M. Birenbaum.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) A Federal judge refused today to grant a new trial for Robert G. Baker, former Secretary to Senate Democrats, who was convicted on Jan. 29 on charges of income tax evasion, theft and conspiracy.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy said yesterday that Governor Rockefeller's proposals to meet the state's electric power needs would grant "an essentially uncontrollable monopoly to private power interests" and add to the cost of electricity.
A 12-year-old boy will make his Broadway stage debut tonight in "The Impossible Years." He is Joseph K. Levene, son of Sam Levene, star of the comedy.

The N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of James M. Nabrit 3d as associate counsel, the organization's second highest administrative post. The appointment took effect last Jan. 1.
Steel production in the week ended Saturday edged up by one-half of 1 per cent, compared with that of the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

ROCHESTER, March 20 Mr. and Mrs. Fred Hooker Gordon Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda DeVilbiss Gordon, to John Harcourt Hall Jr. of San Francisco, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hall of San Juan, P.R.

Last Friday, wheat futures traders who had owned a July contract for a week could show a worthwhile 10-cents-abushel profit. The price increase had stemmed from the long spell of dry weather over the Southwestern growing areas. Drought could cut the size of the crop, they had reasoned.
Teachers at Public School 194 in Harlem abruptly dismissed classes and walked off their jobs yesterday to protest "inadequate heat" in the building.

Special to The New York Times SEATTLE, March 20 The semifinal round of the Vanderbilt Cup contest began here tonight with the North American international team opposing George Rapee's team in one match and squads headed by Lew Mathe and Kelsey Petterson meeting in the other.
A convention of botanists might suggest a rather placid prospect a hushed assembly of petal gazers.
A meeting of the city's Site Selection Board at City Hall was disrupted yesterday when a group of about 65 Corona, Queens, homeowners staged a protest over the acquisition of a school site.
The National Broadcasting Company plans to increase the number of spot commercials in its Tuesday and Saturday prime time movies next fall from 14 to 16.

LONDON, March 20 (AP) Vanessa and Lynn Redgrave, already rivals for Hollywood's Oscar, have been nominated for the British Film Academy's award to the best British actress of the year. Their chief rival for both is Elizabeth Taylor.

HAMDEN, Conn., March 20 The engagement of Miss Mary Elizabeth Clifford, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Clifford, to Bernard Daniel Colen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Colen of New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents.
PARIS, March 20 Today's rioting in Djibouti is regarded here as putting the Government of President de Gaulle in a dilemma.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) A bill to establish the birthplace of President Kennedy in Brookline, Mass., as a national historic site was approved today by the Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee.
Twelve thousand commuters were delayed up to 40 minutes last night after an electrical fire had flared on a New York Central train at the Spuyten Duyvil station in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, March 20 If someone could explain why Michael Caine is this year's movie idol it would probably do more to illuminate the generation gap than all the prose of Paul Goodman.

WASHINGTON, March 20 The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked the Government today to let it earn a somewhat larger profit than it has in the past. The company said, however, that it would not need rate increases to do this but merely permission to keep more of the earnings realized through increased efficiency.
Engineers from many nations streamed through the doors of the New York Coliseum and New York Hilton Hotel yesterday.
After one month and more than 1,000 pages of often-conflicting testimony, the State Harness Racing Commission hearings on Bud Gilmour's appeal to have his driver's license renewed ended yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 20 Friends of Gov. George Romney of Michigan opened a Romney for President headquarters here today with two employes and leftover campaign literature.
SURABAYA, Indonesia, March 17--The potholed highway from Jogjakarta to Surabaya passes an ancient Hindu temple and then crosses a dry river bed filled with coarse, gray volcanic sand.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) The Weather Bureau said today its forecasts would be issued on standard time this summer despite the Congressional mandate for uniform observance of daylight saving time.
WASHINGTON, March 20 John Kenneth Galbraith has agreed to accept the national chairmanship of Americans for Democratic Action, friends said today.
VIENNA, March 20 (AP) Czechoslovakia beat East Germany, 6-0, in the world amateur hockey championships today and moved into a tie for first place with the Soviet Union and Canada.
WASHINGTON, March 20 If a California court decision on fair housing is upheld, the Supreme Court was told today, all states could pass fair-housing laws that could not subsequently be repealed.

Theodore W. Kheel, the mediator in the newspaper dispute here, resolved a procedural dispute yesterday that had caused what he called a "serious impasse" in bargaining between the deliverers' union and the publishers.

Philip J. Levin, lawyer, realty investor and the largest stockholder in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., has become co-owner with Arlen Properties, Inc., of the 33-story Paramount Building, on the west side of Broadway between 43d and 44th Streets.
TRENTON, March 20--The State Supreme Court ruled today that high school students could experiment with live animals for educational reasons.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 20 (AP) Keith R. Goldsmith, 23year-old son of United States Commissioner Richard S. Goldsmith, went to visit an acquaintance Saturday and ended up facing narcotics charges that resulted from a warrant signed by his own father.
BIMINI, the Bahamas, March 20 Adam Clayton Powell today put off a promised trip to Chicago to campaign for Dick Gregory's mayoral candidacy, saying he must return to his Harlem constituency first.

PARIS, March 20 Harlan Cleveland, United States representative at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, warned Europeans today to worry less about themselves and more about the problems of maintaining order in the world.

About 2,000 detectives and uniformed policemen led by Commissioner Howard R. Leary and the top command of the department attended funeral services yesterday for Detective John D. Pollins, who was fatally wounded last Tuesday by a narcotics peddling suspect.

WASHINGTON, March 20 Senators of both parties suggested today that the fivemonth suspension of the 7 per cent tax credit on business investment be taken off the books and treated as though it had never existed.
Five thousand city firemen shouted down the wage proposal of a fact-finding panel last night and called for an immediate mail ballot on whether to strike.
Five of the largest banks in New York City have agreed to undertake a joint study of the feasibility of a cooperative credit card operation.

A loss suffered by the Douglas Aircraft Corporation in the first quarter of the current fiscal year will affect the stock-dividend terms of a merger agreement with the McDonnell Company, both concerns announced last night.
State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that he could not support Governor Rockefeller's proposed $2.5-billion transportation bond issue in its present form, and wanted more facts about it.
A new 20-volume reference encyclopedia for elementary and junior high school pupils will be published in June by Crowell Collier and Macmillan, Inc.

PUNTA ARENAS, Chile, March 20 (Reuters) A private airline pilot reported here today that Sir Francis Chichester, the British yachtsman who is sailing around the world alone, had rounded Cape Horn and was heading north in the Atlantic toward England.

The film version of "Ulysses," which scored both a critical and box-office success during its three-day, reserved-seat engagements last week in 65 theaters here and around the country, will start an exclusive, unlimited, reserved-seat run at the Trans-Lux 85th Street Theater on Friday.

The American Jewish Congress charged yesterday that the "crude and blatant antiSemitic atmosphere" of a Passion play presented by a Roman Catholic church in Union City, N. J., violated recently announced guidelines for CatholicJewish relations.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 20 (AP) South Vietnamese officials have closed the coastal city of Vungtau to all foreigners except those traveling on official business in an effort to confine an outbreak of plague.
Brandon Tynan, the actor, died on Sunday at the Lynwood Nursing Home, 306 West 102d Street. He would have been 92 years old April 11. He was a resident of The Lambs, the theatrical club.

TOKYO, March 20 (Reuters) --Maria Bieshu, a Soviet soprano, today won the first worldwide Madama Butterfly competition and an award of one million yen (about $2,800). Another Soviet singer, Lamara Chkoniya, was second and Britain's Elizabeth Vaughan was third.
WASHINGTON, March 20 The Supreme Court voided today the conviction of Charles J. O'Brien, a Detroit teamster official, because Federal agents had eavesdropped on him with illegal bugging devices.
AUSTIN, Tex., March 20 The State Senate approved today a proposed amendment to the Texas Constitution that would outlaw discrimination because of race or sex.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., March 20 Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Cook Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Isabelle Kirkpatrick Cook, to Harold G. Pratt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pratt of Concord.
WASHINGTON, March 20 President Johnson met the military rulers of South Vietnam on the island of Guam with just the right words. The question is whether General Thieu and Marshal Ky were listening.

WASHINGTON, March 20 The Inter-American Development Bank announced today completion of a feasibility study that recommends the expenditure of $2.6-billion. over 10 years to raise ground communications in South America to "acceptable" standards.

Mayor Lindsay's warning that "painful and deep cuts" will have to be made in city services must come as a jolt to most citizens. It was just a year ago that the city was saved on the very brink of financial crisis. Yet New York is once again threatened with a yawning gap between the essential needs that must be met and the funds to meet them.

SAIGON, Tuesday, March 21 United States marines landed just south of Vietnam's demilitarized zone yesterday in a new drive, and enemy forces rained heavy mortar and rocket fire on allied forward bases close to the landing area.
Mayor Lindsay will go to Albany this afternoon to seek $180-million in additional state help $70-million less than he asked previously to balance the city's projected $5-billion budget for 1967-68.
MIAMI, March 20 Within a short drive of Miami one of the world's most interesting outdoor scenes stretches for miles. This is the Everglades.

WASHINGTON, March 20 Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, said today that he now supported the play for a draft lottery, after having derided the concept for years. He does so, the general said, because President Johnson overruled his objections.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 21. (AP) The South Vietnamese chief of state, Lieut. Gen Nguyen Van Thieu, returned today from the Guam conference with President Johnson and said his government had proposed a peace meeting to North Vietnam.

Directors of Avnet, Inc., approved yesterday an agreement looking to the possible combination with the Plume Atwood Brass and Copper Corporation. Terms were not disclosed because of the preliminary nature of the transaction, which is estimated to involve about $20-million in stock.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., March 20 (AP) Former President Harry S. Truman said today that the American people should give President Johnson "their full support" on his mission to Guam.

WASHINGTON, March 20-- (UPI)--The House voted 357 to 0 today to give wartime benefits to all servicemen in uniform since the Tonkin Gulf incident in Vietnam in August, 1964, and to increase educational allowances and veteran pension payments.

Dresser Industries, Inc., expects to tender to the FMC Corporation the Link-Belt Company stock it is acquiring through its own tender offer to Link-Belt stockholders, the annual meeting of Dresser was told yesterday in Dallas by John Lawrence, chairman and president.
