WASHINGTON, March 20 The Supreme Court declined today to hear the appeal of David H. Mitchell 3d, a bookstore clerk in Greenwich Village who refused to report for induction into the Army because he said the United States was committing war crimes in Vietnam.
WESTBURY, L. I., March 20 Miss Merrilee Graziano and Allen A. Currier plan to marry in September.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) The Supreme Court upheld today an Interstate Commerce Commission order authorizing low railroad freight rates on grain and grain products from Pittsburgh to nine Eastern destinations.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 20 (UPI) Brig. Gen. Alfred Judson Force Moody, assistant commander of the United States Army First Air Cavalry Division, died yesterday of a heart attack a week after arriving in Vietnam, aides said today. He was 49 years old.

DETROIT, March 20 (AP) The late Jack Ruby's entire estate exclusive of debts consists of the pistol with which he shot Lee Harvey Oswald and four other personal items, the attorney for his estate said today.

ELSAH, Ill., March 20 Mr. and Mrs. Clayton Dudley Ford have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Anne Ford, to Stephen B.L. Penrose 3d, son of Mrs. Penrose of Boston, and the late Mr. Penrose, who was president of the American University in Beirut, Lebanon.

The National Basketball Association's championship playoffs, threatened by a player strike until a week ago, get under way tonight in Philadelphia, Boston, St. Louis and Oakland, Calif. It will take a month or more to produce a champion.
WASHINGTON, March 20--Consumer prices held essentially steady in February for the fourth consecutive month, the Labor Department said today.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) The House voted today to extend the Indian Claims Commission until 1972 and to expand it from three to five members.

Stephen Kramer, formerly with Storey Real Estate, Inc., and the Charles F. Noyes Company, has established a business as a real estate consultant with offices in New York and California. The office here is at 500 Fifth Avenue, at 42d Street.

"An Opening Night at La Scala" is the theme of the ball of the year benefit for the Boys Towns of Italy at the Waldorf-Astoria on April 6. In the Grand Ballroom, heraldic banners will dress the stage, and pink carnations will garland the boxes.
The Conservative party filed suit here yesterday to bar Adam Clayton Powell from running in the special Congressional election April 11 to regain the House seat he had held for 22 years.

NIMITZ HILL, Guam, March 20 Gen. William C. Westmoreland reported today that Vietcong and North Vietnamese units had begun an intensified terrorist campaign against district capitals and pacification teams in South Vietnam.
WTIC-TV in Hartford is being strongly criticized by some of its viewers for its cancellation last week of a Columbia Broadcasting System documentary about the American presence in Vietnam.

IRKUTSK, U.S.S.R., March 17 Irkutsk, the principal city in eastern Siberia, is about 4,000 miles from Azerbaijan, in the sunny south of the Soviet Union. It is a long way to go with seven sacks of dried apricots and four of hazel nuts.

PERTH, Scotland, March 20 (AP) The United States rink from Seattle won its two opening matches today in the Scotch Cup world curling championship bonspiel. The Americans, skipped by Bruce Roberts, defeated France, 17-5, and then triumphed over Scotland, 8-7.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 99.8 on Friday from 100.1 on Thursday.
The City College asked the Board of Education yesterday to let the college operate five public schools in Harlem.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)--The Justice Department has rejected a suggestion by the House antitrust subcommittee that it permit third parties to intervene in court against Government-proposed consent decrees in antitrust cases.
Clutching a green parking ticket in her hand, the errant woman driver walks before the bench in Traffic Court.

The spot rate on the British pound continued to edge up in moderate trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here. The final quotation of $2.7969 was 2 points above the closing rate of the preceding day.

HONG KONG, Wednesday, March 22 (AP)--Defying State Department warnings that they were breaking United States laws, seven American Quakers and a television producer sailed their small yacht out of Hong Kong today with a cargo of medical supplies for North Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- A 50-pound radio backpack that can fix a soldier's position precisely by signals from a satellite has been developed by the Navy and Johns Hopkins University.
SHORT HILLS, N.J., March 21--Mrs. Helen Buchsbaum Dickinson of 167 Hartshorn Drive, wife of George Dickinson, a mortgage banker, died yesterday at Lankenau Hospital, Philadelphia. Her age was 50.
UPPER SADDLE RIVER, N.J., March 21--Samuel J. Davis of 70 Weiss Road, construction superintendent of the Bergen County Park Commission, died on Sunday at the Tuxedo, N.Y., Hospital.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)--The Senate passed by voice vote today a bill to establish the birthplace of President Kennedy in Brookline, Mass., as a national historic site.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 21--Overwhelmingly outnumbered artillerymen and infantrymen today turned an enemy attack into one of the major American victories of the war.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 21--The South Vietnamese Government has replied "not unfavorably" to a peace proposal sponsored by Secretary General Thant, high South Vietnamese sources said today.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)--A huge bill for military procurement, including standby authority to start installing an antiballistic missile defense system, sailed through the Senate today by a vote of 86 to 2. The $20.8-billion authorization measure for the next fiscal year starting July 1 now goes to the House.
SPRINGVALE, Me., March 21 (AP)--Randy Brooks, former jazz trumpeter, died today in an apartment house fire. He was 49 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)--Lieut Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of the Selective Service System, was forced off the stage of Howard University's Cramton Auditorium tonight by a group of students shouting ::America is the black man's battleground."

ALBANY, March 21--A key Republican legislative leader yielded yesterday to intense pressure from Governor Rockefeller and the top Democratic legislative leader on an issue that had threatened to block negotiations for more state aid for New York City.

DJIBOUTI, French Somaliland, March 21--French troops poured through Djibouti's African shantytown today, pressing what they called "the Operation"--a campaign to round up thousands of alien Somali tribesmen and expel them forcibly into the neighboring Republic of Somalia.
ALBANY, March 21--Governor Rockefeller's collection of modern art at the Executive Mansion was criticized by a Democrat and defended by a Republican on the floor of the State Senate today.

PEKING, March 21 (Agence France-Presse)--Premier Chou En-lai has joined with Chen Po-ta, a leader of the Cultural Revolution, in ordering a curtailment of "revolutionary activities" during spring cultivation.
LUSAKA, Zambia, March 21 --Zambia's copper mining companies announced today agreement in principle on the establishment of copper fabricating facilities in Zambia.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- Attorney General Ramsey Clark told a Senate subcommittee today that reform of the Federal jury selection process was overdue.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 21 (UPI)--A resolution calling for a legislative investigation of the relationship between the Big Ten and the University of Illinois was adopted by the Illinois Senate today.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- A member of the Federal Reserve Board opposed today proposals to roll back interest rates paid to savers, and hence probably mortgage interest rates, by the device of lowering the present ceilings on savings rates.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 21--Thomas W. Murphy, a famous harness-racing driver and trainer, died yesterday at his home after a long illness. He was 90 years old.
Gordon E. Crosby Jr. was elected yesterday as chairman of the Uslife Holding Corporation and its subsidiary, the United States Life Insurance Company.

David Oppenheim, a member of the law firm of M.S. I.S. Isaacs, 475 Fifth Avenue, since 1925, died Monday on his way home from his office. He was 72 years old and lived at 95-11 69th Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens.

MANY opera fans discovered Handel's "Julius Caesar" only last fall when the New York City Opera mounted its highly successful production at the New York State Theater. But if they had been keeping up with the American Opera Society about a decade ago, they would have become acquainted with the Handel opera at that time.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) --Airlines and other companies operating twin-engine Convair 580 and Lockheed Electra propjet airliners received warnings yesterday to inspect their propellers.

PITTSBURGH, March 21-- In scenes reminiscent of depression days of the 1930's, dairy farmers in Pennsylvania are voluntarily dumping milk, and masked men have forcibly stopped milk tank trucks and opened valves.

Walter Edward Jenkins Jr., counselor of the United States Embassy in Warsaw, and Mrs. Jenkins have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Elizabeth Jenkins, to Armand George Skol. He is the son of Mrs. Doris K. Skol of Brooklyn and the late Dr. Joseph Skol.

Johnson's Letter Dear Mr. President: I am writing to you in the hope that the conflict in Vietnam can be brought to an end. That conflict has already taken a heavy toll-- in lives lost, in wounds inflicted, in property destroyed and in simple human misery. If we fail to find a just and peaceful solution, history will judge us harshly.

ALBANY, March 21--The Senate, after three hours of attacks and defenses of Senator Robert F. Kennedy and the Surrogates' Courts, voted unanimously today for a bill designed to cut appointments of guardians by the courts.

BALTIMORE, March 21-- Mrs. K. Carrell Slingluff has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Clare Carrell Slingluff, to William Stirling Kenny, son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Kenny of Brockville, Ont.
MONTREAL, March 21--Officials of Quebec have given assurances that Negro visitors to Expo 67, the Montreal world exhibition, will not be the victims of discrimination in housing accommodations.

The provost of the Long Island University Brooklyn center requested yesterday that his resignation be withdrawn, and the university's chancellor, Dr. R. Gordon Hoxie, agreed to consider the plea and make a decision by Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Federal money for buying land to turn into parks and other recreation areas will fall short by at least $2.7-billion in the next 10 years unless Congress acts to close the gap, the Interior Department said today.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 21 (AP)--Dr. Meta Glass, widely known educator and president of Sweet Briar College for 21 years, died here yesterday. Her age was 86.

OAKLAND, Calif., March 21 (UPI)--Guards Jeff Mullins and Jim King set the pace in the first half and Rick Barry picked it up in the second tonight in leading the San Francisco Warriors to a 124-108 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers and a 1-0 lead in their three-of-five-game National Basketball Association Western Division playoff.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)--Legislation that would grant United States asylum to Stalin's daughter, Svetlana Alliluyeva, was introduced today by Representative Paul Findley, Republican of Illinois.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 21--Arthur J. Goldberg denounced South Africa's apartheid policies today as "one of the greatest offenses against human rights still existing in the world."
CLINTON, N.J., March 21 (AP)--The State Police report that snipers have fired on at least four milk trucks in Hunterden and Sussex Counties in the last two days.

A journalism-awards luncheon here yesterday brought men of contrary opinions elbow to elbow and gave the guests a glimpse of old, new and instant antagonisms. They also saw some odd, momentary alliances.

WASHINGTON, March 21 U The Justice Department has assured House members that it will give the case of Adam Clayton Powell "thorough and expeditious attention and will take whatever action is deemed appropriate."

Democratic candidates were elected yesterday in several communities in Westchester County. In Mamaroneck, a slate of Republican-Conservative candidates was beaten by Democrats who were helped by 6,000 phonograph records distributed to townsfolk during the campaign.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 21--Thirty hours after the start of the Miami-Montego Bay yacht race, the fleet was still trying tonight to catch the 67-foot sloop, Chubasco. Chubasco held a lead of approximately four miles over Robert F. Johnson's 72-foot ketch, Ticonderoga, from the New York Yacht Club.

TOKYO, March 21 (AP)-- North Vietnam said today that it had decided to make public President Ho Chi Minh's reply to President Johnson's letter "with a view to exposing to world public opinion the stubbornness and perfidy of the U.S. rulers."
WASHINGTON, March 21-- Following is a chronology of major moves toward negotiations for peace in Vietnam:

GENEVA, March 21--The United Nations Human Rights Commission voted today to refer the problem of halting slavery and the slave trade for study to a subordinate body, the subcommission on prevention of discrimination and protection of minorities.

Gertrude Tiemer - Wille, a painter, photographer and poet, died Monday in University Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived at 155 East 34th Street and at Cundy's Harbor, Me. She was the widow of Frederick Wille, retired manager of the New York office of the Saturday Evening Post, who died in 1953.
The stock market declined sharply, in the final hour of trading yesterday after holding to the upside throughout most of the session.
Fred Waring stepped out on the stage at Philharmonic Hall last night and absorbed the wave of applause that engulfed him.

BONN--When Kurt Georg Kiesinger goes to Washington in May or early June for his first talk with President Johnson, Americans will get a look at a new type of West German Chancellor. We have been familiar with men like Adenauer and Erhard, who worked with the Allied occupying authorities right after the war.

AMENIA, N.Y., March 21-- New York City is relentlessly strangling itself and it is probably too late to do anything about it by simple means, Lewis Mumford, a community-planning pioneer and an authority on urban civilization said yesterday.

The American Motors Corporation will halt production of its large cars for one week beginning next Monday, furloughing 6,500 workers for the week at plants in Milwaukee and Kenosha, Wis. The auto maker has a total employment of 14,100 at its Wisconsin plants.

For the first time since the Korean war, a major producer of sulphur announced yesterday that it was introducing an allocation program. Blaming worldwide shortages, the Freeport Sulphur Company said it was limiting deliveries to domestic customers to 90 per cent of their normal tonnages, effective April 1.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 21 (UPI)--Gov. Roberto S nchez Vilella's wife publicly refused today to give him a divorce following his announcement that they were separated and that he would not seek another term.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- Senator Robert F. Kennedy declared in a statement today that President Johnson had raised the price for any cessation of the bombing of North Vietnam.

LOS ANGELES, March 21 (UPI)--Milton Berle's nephew was killed and another man was injured last night when a sheriff's instructor shot the two trainees with a borrowed pistol he thought contained blanks.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Determined to press for three Model Cities projects--and privately hopeful of winning Federal approval for two--New York City officials sent in today their estimated price tag for the first stage of the program.

A month ago, as he watched a squarely built, chesty man allow a Manhattan lunch-hour crowd to sweep him down the street, Cassius Clay wonderingly said: "That Folley's such a nice, sweet old man, eight little kids, calls me Muhammad Ali, thanks me all the time for giving him a chance. How'm I ever gonna get mad at him and build up this fight?"

WASHINGTON, Mar. 21-In the Supreme Court of the United States today, the following proceedings were had: ORAL ARGUMENT 483-Nell Reltman et al., Petrs., V. Lincoln W. Mulkey et al. 712--Joyce C. Thorpe, Petr., V. Housing Authority of the City at Durham. 831--Francis Eddie Specht, Petr., V. Wayne K. Paterson, Warden et al. Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock. The day call for Wednesday, March 22, 1967, will be as follows: Nos. 240 and 673.
VIENNA, March 21 (AP)-- Czechoslovakia trounced the United States, 8-3, and kept pace with Canada and the Soviet Union in the world amateur ice hockey championship tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- The states of West Virginia and Hawaii told Federal Government regulators today that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company should be allowed to earn no more than a 7 per cent return on its investment.
The only parents a four-yearold girl has ever known spent the day in court here yesterday trying to regain her from the foundling home that took her back because the couple were too old.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- The League of Women Voters charged today that "blitz methods" were being used in state legislatures to win approval of a resolution calling for a Federal constitutional convention to consider the reapportionment of legislatures.
Moslem faithful flocked to a mid-Manhattan hotel for the observance yesterday of the Islamic Festival of Sacrifice, Eidul Adha. The festival honors the memory of Abraham.

LONDON, March 21--A 19thcentury porcelain banquet service of Czar Nicholas I of Russia was sold here today for 65,751 ($184,102) at the first public auction in the West of Russian art treasures since the Bolshevik Revolution 50 years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- The correspondence between President Johnson and President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam merely illustrates how far both sides are from a negotiated settlement of the war or even from an equal basis for negotiation.

AFTER Jim Hall and Hap Sharp of Midland, Tex., had won a 500-mile race at Elkhart Lake, Wis., and a 12hour race at Sebring, Fla., with their Chevrolet-powered Chaparrals, they set their caps for the 24-hour contests at LeMans, France and at Daytona Beach, Fla.
SEATTLE, March 21-- Teams led by George Ra pee of New York and Lew Mathe of Los Angeles met in the final of the Vanderbilt Cup contest here tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. March 21--Representatives of most black African states reacted angrily today to South Africa's offer of self-government to Ovamboland.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Solicitor General Thurgood Marshall said today that California's voters acted unconstitutionally when they approved a state constitutional amendment broad enough to outlaw local efforts to ease racial discrimination in housing.

An organization called the Congress party has filed enough signatures with the Board of Elections to provide Adam Clayton Powell with a second line on the voting machines in the April 11 special election.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 21--The Yankees staged a two-run uprising in the ninth inning today to defeat the Tigers, 5-4, but the big news of the day was made before the game started.
The American Merchant Marine Library Association is again asking for reading material and money for its Public Library of the High Seas, which supplies books and magazines to merchant vessels.
HARRISBURG, Pa., March 21 (UPI)--Gov. Raymond P. Shafer said today Pennsylvania planned to tax Ohio trucks traveling Commonwealth roads beginning April 1.

EVANSTON, Ill., March 21-- The growing inclination of the Federal Government to intervene in collective bargaining threatens to erode the negotiations system almost to the vanishing point, a leading trucking operator said today.
The lower rate of increase in chain-store sales that began last Fall has extended into February.
A fire battalion chief was killed and two firemen were injured yesterday in a two-car collision while the firemen were on a call to East Elmhurst, Queens.
IVANHOE, W. Va., March 21 --Harold Glen Cutright, president of the Glengayle Associates, management consultant engineers at 509 Fifth Avenue, New York, died here today in his home. His age was 66.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 21 --Jackavin, a 3-year-old pacing colt with what his trainerdriver, Del Insko, termed "great potential," was sent away as the 2-to-5 favorite in a Class C-3 one-mile test at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

Preliminary debate on the city's proposed new housing maintenance code has not been really relevant to the fundamental problem. That is to provide a modern, workable law combining all regulations for owners and tenants of all dwellings here.

THE decision of the National Broadcasting Company to increase the number of spot announcements during evening feature-length films represents the first significant crack in the commercial structure of nighttime TV in a long while.

Mayor Lindsay was right to assert that New York City will stand firm against the strike threatened by its uniformed firemen. Such a strike would not only be illegal; it would also be as outrageous a threat to public safety as the celebrated Boston police strike of almost half a century ago.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 21 (AP)--Tommic Agee's sacrifice fly with bases full in the 10th inning gave the Chicago White Sox a 5-4 victory over the Kansas City Athletics today. The Sox are the pacesetters in the grapefruit league with a 9-3 won-lost record.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)--Everett McKinley Dirksen, the Senate Republican leader, prodded party colleagues today to agree on an electoral college amendment and push for action on it in this session of Congress.

With unusual dispatch and against negligible opposition, Congress has given President Johnson the approval he sought for sending an additional three million tons of food grains to hard-pressed India this year on a matching basis.

Female monkeys, normally among the most protective of mothers, can be ordered by radio to reject their young, Dr. Jos M.R. Delgado of Yale's School of Medicine told a convention of electronics engineers here yesterday.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 21 (UPI)--Joe Mullaney, the Providence College basketball coach, signed today a sevenyear contract with the school.
Spring had a lot of trouble yesterday convincing winter that there was a change in seasons.

ALBANY, March 21--The Republican leader of the Assembly, Perry B. Duryea Jr. of Montauk, said today that an "impasse" had developed that might prevent construction of a jetport at Calverton, L.I. The facility would be the metropolitan area's fourth jetport.
Leo C. Bailey was appointed yesterday as vice president and director of research by A.G. Becker Co., investment bankers and members of the New York Stock Exchange.

TOKYO, March 21--Lee Kuan Yew, the Socialist Prime Minister of Singapore, said tonight that Southeast Asian countries "may well prefer a permanent American military presence" to a continued Communist threat.

RACINE, Wis., March 21-- Mrs. Harlow W. Klema of Racine and East Orange, N.J., has announced the enagement of her daughter, Miss. Barbara Ann Klema, to Charles R. Reichert, son of Mrs. W. Rufus Reichert of Greenfield, Mass., and Mendham, N.J., and the late Mr. Reichert.
The special mediation panel in the newspaper negotiations here moved into the dispute yesterday between the New York Newspaper Guild and The Daily News and The World Journal Tribune.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, March 22 (AP)--Two Chinese diplomats left Moscow aboard a Soviet plane for Peking early today after they had been ordered expelled for alleged antiSoviet activity.
Nine debutantes will be presented by their fathers on April 7 at the St. Nicholas Society's Paas (Easter) Festival Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
The Continental Football League gave Andy Robustelli more time yesterday to decide whether to buy the Brooklyn Dodgers franchise. Indications are that he does not want the team, but others do.
The election judges tabulating the votes cast at the annual meeting last month of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., reported yesterday the results of the various proposals.

ST. LOUIS, March 21 (AP) --The St. Louis Hawks pulled away in the fourth quarter and posted a 114-100 victory tonight over the Chicago Bulls in the first game of the Western Division semi-final playoffs of the National Basketball Association.
When a $14.40 number named Dance For Joy took the first race on the first day of spring at Aqueduct yesterday, a frozen horse player remarked, "That kid Pin-kay is gonna be a star."

The revelation by Hanoi of another peace move that failed--the February offer of President Johnson that Ho Chi Minh rejected--means only one thing: this bitter, revolting war, with all of its attendant death and destruction, is apparently going to go on for a long time to come.
BUCHAREST, March 21 (UPI)--Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon, who was ignored by Soviet officials in Moscow, arrived here today and was warmly greeted by Rumanians.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., March 21--The East Hudson Parkway Authority announced today that a $2,350,000 steel fence would be installed along the center of the Taconic State Parkway where head-on collisions have become increasingly numerous in recent years.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 21--Cuba has begun a campaign to regulate population growth despite recent statements by Premier Fidel Castro denouncing birth control as a capitalist error. The island has a population of seven million.
New York City intends to set up a pilot plant to break up lumber, furniture and other large wastes for burning in an incinerator that would generate electricity for at least its own power needs.

ONCE upon a time the horror story was content to deal with things that go shriek in the night, with mad scientists, leering zombies, monsters, ghosts, witches, vampires and damsels in distress. But no more. The ghouls have grown tame. Their fog-enshrouded mansions, hissing laboratories, creaky dungeons and gloomy cemeteries are now more comical than frightening. The girls can take care of themselves. Dracula is what they call their parakeets.

Two Philadelphia schoolboys, Sandy McAdoo of William Penn Charter and Palmer Page of Episcopal Academy, will meet at 12:30 P.M. today in the final round of the 23d invitation scholastic squash racquets tournament at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

If the New York Rangers finish second in the National Hockey League, they will play their first two games of the semi-final Stanley Cup playoff series on Thursday evening, April 6, and Saturday afternoon, April 8, at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- President Johnson, it was disclosed today, sent a letter to President Ho Chi Minh early in February suggesting direct talks between the United States and North Vietnam on ending the war.
STILLWATER, Okla., March 17--Oklahoma State University is the kind of school where the girls are the ones with the long hair.
John P. Warwick, of the Warwick Legler Warwicks, went strongly on the record yesterday against agencies' resigning accounts to get bigger accounts in the same field.
CHICAGO, March 21 (AP)-- Milk from farms and stores alike was given away and tossed away today--the sixth day of the National Farmers Organization's milk-withholding action.

BOSTON, March 21--With as much irresistible inevitability as the arrival of the vernal equinox, which took place a few hours later, the Boston Celtics crushed the New York Knickerbockers tonight, 140-110.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 21--Mr. and Mrs. Barron Collier Jr. have announced the engagement of Mrs. Collier's daughter, Miss Frances Gable, to George Villere, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Caliste Villere of New Orleans.
USHUAIA, Argentina, March 21 (Reuters)--Sir Francis Chichester guided his ketch Gipsy Moth IV through the stormy South Atlantic today, after rounding Cape Horn.

THE most striking achievement of the A.P.A.'s massive and very moving production of "War and Peace" is that, no matter how many scarlet banners scurry across the sky, no matter how wide or how high the mobile stage opens up to display ermined emperors standing astride a blood-red world, Tolstoy's central, simple, essential point is never for a moment lost sight of.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI)--A Senate subcommittee approved today the allocation of $273.6-million for aid to Appalachia and $12.5-million for planning five new regional development commissions.

NEW MILFORD, N.J. March 21--Sandra Shields, TriCentennial Queen of Bergen County in 1965, died yesterday at Bergen Pines Hospital in Paramus. She was 22 years old and lived here at 732 Plympton Street.

Hugh Cullman, president of Philip Morris International, urged his associates in international corporations yesterday to seize present opportunities to invest promptly in the developing countries, even at the cost of temporarily reducing earnings.

Frank D. Gilroy's second Broadway play, "That Summer --That Fall," will end its run at the Helen Hayes Theater on Saturday after its 12th performance. His first one, "The Subject Was Roses," won the Pulitzer, Critics and Tony awards in 1964.
Discrimination, racial imbalance in schools and state aid for nonpublic schools are expected to be major subjects for delegates who convene next month to draft a revised state Constitution.
The National Professional Soccer League, which will make its debut April 16, adopted a weighted point system yesterday to determine the standing. The new system rewards highscoring teams.

The plan recently drafted within the Interior Department for Hudson River Valley development proposes much stronger measures to safeguard scenic and historic values than those New York State has been willing to take. The lasting protection of this magnificent area is clearly a matter of national interest.
SAN FRANCISO, March 21 --The Asia Foundation, a private American philanthropic organization, said today that it had received money indirectly from the Central Intelligence Agency.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- President Johnson led an exhausted and perplexed team of senior officials back from Guam this evening after a conference on the war in Vietnam that they were publicly celebrating as constructive but privately describing as hasty and threadbare.
Industrial issues moved ahead yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

ROYALS TOP 76ERS IN UPSET, 120-116 PHILADELPHIA, March 21 (AP)--The Cincinnati Royals, with Oscar Robertson scoring 33 points and Connie Dierking 29, upset the Philadelphia 76ers 120-116, tonight in the first game of a three-of-five Eastern Division semi-final playoff in the National Basketball Association.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., March 21--Dr. and Mrs. Carl Morse Herbert have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Elisabeth Herbert, to William Ervine Swift. He is the son of the Right Rev. A. Ervine Swift, former Episcopal Bishop of Puerto Rico, and Mrs. Swift of Boca Raton and Philadelphia.
The Wire Service Guild announced yesterday that it had set 12:01 A.M. tomorrow for a strike against United Press International.

WHAT is it about Kurt Jooss's 35-year-old ballet "The Green Table" that makes it so peculiarly effective today? Topicality, of course. Yet this is only part of the issue. Perhaps more important still is the manner in which its very flexible dramatic style seems to make sense in today's theater.
The Wheeling Steel Corporation brought suit yesterday against its former insurance agency, asking damages of $2.4million for alleged excess charges.
FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, March 21--Siaka Stevens, leader of the All-Peoples Congress party, was sworn in as Prime Minister of Sierra Leone today and was immediately taken into custody by the army.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday he would abide by a recent State Supreme Court ruling and would not grant pay increases to welfare and Housing Authority employes who went on strike in January in violation of the Condon-Wadlin Law.

A new opera by Hugo Weisgall, as yet untitled, will be included in the repertory of the New York City Opera during its fall season at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center, Sept. 14 through Nov. 12.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- The House Rules Committee agreed after a heated debate today to clear the controversial joint resolution on the Latin American summit meeting for three hours' debate on the House floor tomorrow.

WOMEN being divorced should not seek alimony from their husbands but rather "severance pay" for their domestic services, according to Clare Boothe Luce. Women who want to avoid the "routine and menial tasks" of the housewife to pursue a career should not marry, advises the wife of the late publisher, Henry R. Luce.
A stockholders' group that plans to solicit proxies to be used at the annual meeting of the Filtrol Corporation has won the right to examine the company's list of stockholders.
Coverdale and Colpitts, a consulting engineering firm, will move from offices at 120 Wall Street it has occupied for 35 years.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 21 (UPI)--The Ripon Society has warned moderate Republicans against making the same mistake with Gov. Ronald Reagan of California that the society says was made with the 1964 Presidential nominee, Barry Goldwater.
The Sleepy Hollow Theater, Inc., a nonprofit group, has been formed to bring American plays to students and to the general public in Westchester.
PORTLAND, Ore., March 21 (UPI)--William T. (Bill) Turner, an assistant at Stanford University for the last 10 years, was named head basketball coach at the University of Portland last night.
Wiretaps in which Suffolk County Judge Floyd Sarisohn was heard advising a convicted prostitute how to avoid further arrests were played back yesterday at his trial on charges of misconduct.
FORT MONROE, Va., March 21--A team of six colonels has begun investigating two recent deaths at Fort Dix, N.J., the Continental Army Command said here today.
NIMITZ HILL, Guam, March 21--Following is the transcript of President Johnson's news conference today at the end of a two-day conference between United States and South Vietnamese officials:
TOKYO, Wednesday, March 22 (AP)--Communist China charged today that a United States warship and military planes had intruded into its territorial waters and air space.

Social, diplomatic, governmental and entertainment personalities attended the benefit world premiere last night of "Thoroughly Modern Millie," at the Criterion Theater. Proceeds went to the Museum of the City of New York.

NOT even Cassius Clay, the creator of instant excitement, could do much in blowing hot air into the ballyhoo bal loon for his heavyweight championship fight with Zora Folley at Madison Square Garden tonight. A publicity artist beyond compare, the resourceful Clay had used an infinite variety of gimmicks in the past to steam up interest in forthcoming bouts.
Two of the nation's largest industrial mergers of the year were proposed yesterday.
West Point-Pepperell, Inc., a textiles producer, announced yesterday in West Point, Ga., that its sales and earnings in the second quarter and first six months declined slightly from year-ago levels.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Ralph Nader, the automotive safety critic, charged today that the National Traffic Safety Agency and its leadership had pursued the goal of safer cars and highways with too much timidity and too little imagination.
OCEANPORT, N. J., March 21 (AP)--Bill Bryan of Armonk, N.Y., has been named director of publicity for Monmouth Park, Philip H. Iselin, the track president, announced today.
DADE CITY, Fla., March 21 (AP)--One of the world's largest concentrators of frozen orange juice cut its price by almost 20 per cent today to the lowest level in 10 years.
Artur Rubinstein will make one of his rare television appearances on the Columbia Broadcasting System next season, probably in early December.

FREETOWN, March 21 (AP) --Sierra Leone, on the southeast corner of the West African bulge between Guinea and Li beria, is a former British colony-protectorate. It became an independent state within the Commonwealth in 1961. The chief of state is Queen Elizabeth II, who is represented here by the Governor General.
THE Communications Satellite Corporation still has more going for it in the banks than in space.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- The Senate Securities subcommittee, after no more than two minutes of deliberation, voted today to approve the nomination of Richard B. Smith as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Senate Banking Committee and the full Senate are expected to vote within a day or two.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., March 21--Mr. and Mrs. Irving Feirstein have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Feirstein, to Richard Blum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Blum of Laurelton, Queens.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 21--Dr. George B. Gallien, who practiced dentistry here for 45 years, died yesterday at his home, 36 Hawthorne Place. He was 80 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Ralph S. Saul, president of the American Stock Exchange, accused the Securities and Exchange Commission tonight of trying to force stock exchanges to change some of the ways they do business to solve a problem mainly affecting mutual fund shareholders.

LONDON, March 21--A Dutch salvage expert died today after an explosion in the engine room of the crippled oil tanker, Torrey Canyon, stuck on a reef at the entrance to the English Channel west of Land's End in southwest England.
"The Greatest Show on Earth" at neighborhood theaters.
CAPETOWN, March 21-- South Africa today offered selfdetermination and the prospect of either complete independence or "some other relationship with other nations" to Ovamboland in Southwest Africa.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 20 --On the side of a highway near San Juan a sign warns motorists to beware of trucks emerging from a side road. "Salida de trucks," the sign says. And its linguistic jumble seems symbolic of a country trying to decide what its political status ought to be.
KIRKENES; Norway--An old photograph shows that when the Sydvaranger company was organized in 1906 to exploit newly discovered iron veins here, Kirkenes was little more than the church place.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI)--The Justice Department said today that it had filed its first suit to force a school system to follow desegregation promises it had made to the Federal Government in order to keep school aid.
Paperboard production rose 2 per cent to 456,000 tons in the week ended March 18 from 447,100 tons in the comparable 1966 week the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

Directors of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., authorized yesterday a 2for-1 split of the common stock and raised the quarterly dividend by 5 cents on the 4,247,822 common shares now outstanding. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, the stock responded with a gain of 2 1/8 points, closing at 52 5/8.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 21 (UPI)--Dr. Carl Coppolino filed notice today to dismiss his $1,275,000 civil suit against Mrs. Marjorie Farber rather than give testimony in a deposition to her attorney.

Three out of five South Vietnamese interviewed by the Columbia Broadcasting System feel that the United States should concentrate more on trying to find a way to negotiate with North Vietnam than on extending American military action against the North. One of seven favors increased military action.
The Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations will meet next Wednesday at the New York Hilton to celebrate its 71st anniversary.

President Johnson is reported to have warned the members of his Cabinet once that if they did not stop issuing premature news releases he would "put a couple of professional politicians in your offices to show you fellows how to do it."
The City Council voted last night to outlaw topless waitresses. The vote, 27 to 5, came at the end of a wearying, though at times lively, sevenhour-and-10-minute session.

GENEVA, March 21--Britain warned today that "a long delay" in reaching agreement on a treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons "may mean no treaty at all." The British appealed to the members of the European Atomic Energy Community, or Euratom, to accept a compromise on the inspection of peaceful nuclear installations.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., March 21--Arthur Dietrich, former vice president of the Baker Castor Oil Company, Bayonne, died yesterday at East Orange Veterans Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 348 Elmwood Avenue here.
PERTH, Scotland, March 21 (UPI)--The United States took the lead in the ninth annual Scotch Cup curling championship tonight with a 12-5 victory over Canada.
The trend toward lower interest rates was interrupted yesterday when bond prices dropped sharply, mainly because of testimony by William McChesney Martin Jr. before the Senate Finance Committee.
NEW DELHI, March 21--A high-ranking Indian official has returned after a meeting with Svetlana Stalin in the Swiss Alps.

The Rev. Henry R. Coleman, rector of Grace Episcopal Church, City Island, the Bronx, died on Monday at the White Plains Hospital of a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived at 104 City Island Avenue.
The Central State Bank of New York announced yesterday the election of Joseph J. Kurtzke as senior vice president.
IN a small room in the otherwise darkened premises of the Charles of the Ritz-Vidal Sassoon salon, a scholar burned the midnight oil all last week.

OAK BROOK, Ill., March 21 --The Rev. Dr. Bryan F. Archibald, president of the Northern Baptist Theological Seminary, and Mrs. Archibald have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Jane Archibald, to Douglas Lawson Hawthorne. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Rowland Hawthorne of Dayton, Ohio.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary of New York said today that he would impose new restrictions soon on the use of guns by his department.
MIAMI, March 21--"It's an entirely different world down there," is the awed response of skin and scuba divers after the first dive.
K.A. Randall, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, warned bankers yesterday to move cautiously in setting up new credit card plans.
A private detective was wounded last night while thwarting an apparent attempt to rob The World Journal Tribune of a $20,000 payroll.

AGANA, Guam, March 21-- President Johnson's hectic 30hour visit to this Pacific outpost raised hopes on Guam and its neighboring islands that Washington will give new attention to their political and economic development.

K.A. Randall, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, warned bankers yesterday to move cautiously in setting up new credit card plans.
A private detective was wounded last night while thwarting an apparent attempt to rob The World Journal Tribune of a $20,000 payroll.
BIMINI, the Bahamas, March 21--Adam Clayton Powell conferred today with a Negro State Senator from California on the formation of a nationwide organization of Negro elected officials.

The stock market has given a surprisingly good account of itself in the face of disappointing economic developments. But Wall Street analysts are wondering whether it can maintain its bright glow if the fading of business activity continues.
The Oberlin College Choir gave its ninth recital in New York last night at Town Hall, as part of the centennial year program of the Oberlin College Conservatory.

Herbert T. Swin, manager on the Brooklyn Academy of Music for 48 years, died yesterday in a Forest Hills, Queens, nursing home after a brief illness. He was 79 years old and lived at 72-81 113th Street, Forest Hills.
Stocks went into full retreat yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

Rick Barry of the San Francisco Warriors topped all scorers in the National Basketball Association this season, wresting the title from Philadelphia's Wilt Chamberlain, who held it the last seven years.
The nation's leading shipping trade association yesterday reversed its course and endorsed the incorporation of the Maritime Administration in the new Department of Transportation.
The Boeing 737, the world's newest jetliner, has reached flight-test status, the manufacturer has announced, and will make its maiden flight early next month at Seattle.
BRUSSELS, March 21--Saul Steinberg, Rumanian-born resident artist of the Smithsonian Institution, cartoonist for The New Yorker magazine and poet of the line, is captivating the youth of Brussels.
Three major maritime unions yesterday threatened a tie-up of indefinite length Tuesday of all American shipping in United States ports.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21--The New York Mets, who haven't been beating anybody but themselves lately, went to the other extreme today and knocked off the world champion Baltimore Orioles-- for the second time in five days.
READERS of The Times of London on Oct. 23, 1964, found a characteristically incisive article by the paper's defense correspondent, Alun Gwynne Jones, on Britain's nuclear strategy.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- After little more than two months in his first elective office, Senator Charles H. Percy has developed a political style that could upstage some of the Republicans in more direct pursuit of their party's Presidential nomination.

COCKEYSVILLE, Md., March 21--Mr. and Mrs. Harry Adair Love have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Colgate Love, to John Rumbarger. He is the son of Mrs. Joseph Rumbarger and the late Mr. Rumbarger.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 21--No details of Secretary General Thant's new initiative toward a peaceful settlement in Vietnam have leaked out here.
The Crompton--Richmond Company, a New York factoring concern, announced yesterday the election of Gabriel E. Romeo as vice president.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 21 (AP)--The chairman of the Nevada Gaming Control Board confirmed today that Howard Hughes, the industrialist, has purchased the Desert Inn HotelCasino on the Las Vegas Strip. Mr. Hughes is staying in a $250-a-day suite in the hotel penthouse.
AGANA, Guam, March 21-- What many American officials considered the most pressing business of the Guam conference was left undone at the meeting's end.

FASHION changes hardly ever happen overnight. They signal themselves months in advance so manufacturers can test them on their first audience--store buyers--and start the production wheels turning. Two concerns, in separate parts of the fashion arena, sent out their signals yesterday, the first day of spring.

A pint-size, automated production of "Die Frau Ohne Schatten" opens an 18-month run today at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, next door to the Metropolitan Opera, where a full-scale version had only nine performances.
MIAMI BEACH, March 21 (AP)--Cecil Stringer of Hattiesburg, Miss., rolled a 677 series today and took fifth place in the regular singles division of the American Bowling Congress tournament.

CYNTHIA, a cherub-faced brunette in a shocking pink sweater, smiled wanly as she talked about the straight A's she used to get as a grade school pupil. Now 17 years old and a junior in a respected East Side high school, her grades have slipped to C's and D's.

WASHINGTON, March 21--Senator J. W. Fulbright, supported by other members of the Foreign Relations Committee, severely criticized the United States Information Agency today for actions "doubly subversive" of the American system.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 99.6 on Monday from 99.8 on Friday.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Extensive new regulations to protect "the unwary public" during periods of "industrial warfare," When a group of outsiders tries to take over a corporation, were advocated today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LONDON, March 21 (AP)-- Karl Mildenberger of Germany successfully defended his European heavyweight championship tonight by stopping Billy Walker of Britain in the eighth round of their scheduled 15round bout.
TNRIN, Italy, March 21-- Three Italians, one of them a noted parachutist, have been detained on suspicion of spying for the Soviet Union.

PASCO, Wash., March 21 (UPI)--Mark Twain's "Huckleberry Finn," considered by many the greatest American novel, was under attack from a local civil rights leader today because it contains the word "nigger." The leader has never read the book through.

Marvin D. Barkan has been appointed a vice president of the Blitman Construction Company in charge of the estimating department. Mr. Barkan, a graduate engineer, joined the civil engineering contracting concern in 1959.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said today that youths who failed to meet educational or physical standards for the draft ought to be compelled to remedy their defects, in the interest of fairness to other young men who were drafted.

The Seven Arts Associated Corporation, which has many interests in the entertainment industry, announced here yesterday the appointment of M. Kenneth Hyman as executive vice president in charge of production.

Senator Jacob K. Javits proposed last night that the United States revise its "not very successful" policy of containment and isolation of Communist China.
LISBON, March 21--The Portuguese political police announced today the breaking up of a clandestine emigration ring.
Mayor Lindsay announced a reversal of plans yesterday that will keep the seven-member tax commission as an independent city agency outside the new Finance Administration.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- The Justice Department asked the Federal Communications Commission today to postpone for two weeks new hearings the commission had ordered on the proposed merger of International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc.
Dorothy Maynor has been given the 1967 Louise Waterman Wise Award for her services to young people by means of the performing arts.

ROME, March 22--An Italian accused as a spy was reported to have told investigators today that 300 persons connected with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization were involved in an espionage ring that helped the Communists.
DETROIT, March 22--A buzzer will remind drivers of 1968 General Motors model cars to pull the key out of the ignition switch when they get out.
John Bigelow Marsh, a senior member of the law firm of Turk, Marsh, Kelly Hoare, died yesterday at his Oyster Bay, L.I., home after a short illness. He was 80 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- Mr. and Mrs. Norman Armour Jr. have announced the engagement of Mrs. Armour's daughter, Miss Abby Deering Paine, to Lane Taylor Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor of Miquon, Pa.

WASHINGTON, March 22 --Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin and Senator Joseph D. Tydings of Maryland urged Congress today to reject 26 of the 32 state legislative petitions calling for a constitutional convention to modify the Supreme Court's reapportionment rule.

PARIS, March 22--Maurice Couve de Murville will continue to be Foreign Minister despite his defeat in the National Assembly election 10 days ago, authoritative sources said tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)--The House stayed late tonight to adopt President Johnson's plea for an endorsement of more aid to Latin America.

WASHINGTON, March 22-- "More of the same" is what responsible American officials predicted today for the war in Vietnam in the wake of the publication of the letters exchanged by President Johnson and President Ho Chi Minh.

Gov. George Romney of Michigan would be a stronger Republican candidate against President Johnson than former Vice President Richard M. Nixon, according to the results of the latest Gallup poll, published yesterday in The New York World Journal Tribune.

PARIS, March 22--Organizers of Earl Russell's private "war-crimes" court on Vietnam have rented a large hall here as of April 10, it was announced tonight.
Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, disagreed strongly yesterday with Senator J. W. Fulbright on the United States Information Agency's overseas book program.

THE additional income resulting from an explosion of pure-bred dog activity to record heights during the last three years has not been sufficient to prevent the American Kennel Club from increasing some of its basic fees.
While many of the 77 million automobile owners in the United States may doubt that spring has arrived, few will question the fact that they will be spending more time behind the wheel in the next;

NANTUCKET, Mass., March 22--Mr. and Mrs. Allen Ramsdell Congdon of Nantucket, formerly of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Tobie Congdon, to Robert Kennedy Quinby. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert William Quinby of Long Beach, L.I.
MOSCOW, March 22 (AP)-- Adding to an unusual burst of space activity, the Soviet Union launched today its seventh unmanned earth satellite of this month and the 11th in the last two months.

LESS than a year ago, William F. Russell became coach of the Boston Celtics, perennial champions of the National Basketball Association. When Red Auerbach announced that Russell was to be his successor, much attention was focused on Russell's role as "the first. Negro to coach or manage a fully accepted major league team."
For three rounds, Cassius Clay danced a sedate minuet against Zora Folley at the Garden last night. The he switched to a thunderous rock 'n' roll, with Folley doing the rolling.

ALBANY, March 22--New York City and state officials were reported today to be considering a compromise fiscal package for the city that would include some form of new tax on liquor, increased lottery drawings and a realignment of the state school aid.

Cassius Clay retained his heavyweight boxing championship last night by knocking out Zora Folley, the 34-year-old challenger from Chandler, Ariz., in 1 minute 48 seconds of the seventh round of their scheduled 15-round fight at Madison Sqaure Garden.
A newspaperman was named executive director or Harlem's Uptown Chamber of Commerce yesterday, and will head a drive to give "a more accurate view of Harlem and its business activities."

THE Sicilian Defense, 1 P-K4, P-QB4, is growing more popular these days. Its many involved positions, which occur early, are overly sharp. One offbeat way, however, to avoid the known routines is 1 P-K4, P-QB4: 2 P-QB3.

NEW ORLEANS, March 22-- A New Orleans grand jury returned an indictment today against Clay L. Shaw, a 54year-old retired businessman and New Orleans socialite, on a charge of conspiring to assassinate President Kennedy.
ALBANY, March 22 -- Not long ago, the telephone rang in the office of Mrs. Kit Currie, a saleswoman at Dawson's Book Shop, dealers in rare books and Oriental art in Los Angeles.

OTTAWA, March 22--The House of Commons, after a stormy argument, modified last night the Government's plan to give the First National City Bank of New York a five-year period of grace in which to "Canadianize" its Mercantile Bank in Montreal.
NEW DELHI, March 22-- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress party lost power today in still another state.
TORONTO, March 22 (AP)-- The Montreal Canadiens tied the Toronto Maple Leafs for third place in the National Hockey League tonight by beating the Leafs, 5-3.
LONG BEACH, Calif., March 22--S.C. Thompson, co-author of "The Official Encyclopedia of Baseball," died of cancer on Monday at Long Beach Memorial Hospital. He was 69 years old.
When a night worker at the Red Cross awoke Lloyd G. of Flushing, Queens, early on a ...

TWO years ago, Roy Lichtenstein, the artist, wanted to do some ceramic sculpture and secured the help of a traditionalist potter, Hui Ka Kwong. Mr. Lichtenstein did his sculpture and Mr. Hui, under the artist's influence, changed his style. The results can be seen through May 14 ...

WASHINGTON, March 22-- Leaders of major securities industry organizations endorsed today--with reservations-- supported legislation designed to give ordinary stockholders greater protection when attempts are made by outside groups to take over control of a company.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 22--Mr. and Mrs. William F. Colton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Ann Colton, to Charles P. Abbott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard C. Abbott of Berrigan, New South Wales, Australia.
The pace of the newspaper negotiations here quickened yesterday, but Theodore W. Kheel, the chief mediator, said he was not pleased with the way they were going.

LONDON, March 22 (AP) --Princess Margaret, her family and her household staff slept through a burglary at her London home today. Officials said the burglar was captured soon after with gold coins and other property he had stolen.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- House Republican leaders asked Congress today to send the budget for fiscal year 1968 to the President for "substantial reductions."
The city's 24,000 organized policemen, who have threatened to picket City Hall and other key municipal buildings while in civilian clothes, may have their lines crossed by members of labor unions.
The 50-year-old grandmother running against Adam Clayton Powell said yesterday that Harlem's image would be a major issue in her campaign.
CHICAGO, March 22 (UPI) --Three railroad shopcraft unions rejected today the recommendations of a Presidential emergency board in a wage dispute after a meeting with the carriers' chief negotiator.

BONN, March 22--The Hamburg-Atlantic Line announced today in Hamburg the purchase of the 25,000-ton Israeli ship Shalom. The company said the ship would be renamed Hanseatic and assigned to the North Atlantic and cruises.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 22--In dying winds, Chubasco continued to lead the fourth biennial Miami-to-Montego Bay yacht race tonight, but several smaller boats had moved into challenging positions.

Marie. Collier's impersonation of Musetta in last night's Metropolitan Opera performance of Puccini's "La Boheme" could not be faulted dramatically, but her singing lacked the important brilliant high notes. This was Miss Collier's first Musetta with the company after having made an impressive debut in the premiere last Friday of Marvin David Levy's "Mourning Becomes Electra."

HANOVER, Germany, March 22 (Reuters)--The National Democratic party's executive committee appealed tonight to Fritz Thielen, the chairman it ousted 10 days ago, to call a national congress to choose his successor.
"NOT A WAY OF LIFE," which opened last night at the Sheridan Square Playhouse, calls itself a "controversial play." Where's the controversy?

MOSCOW, March 22 (Reuters)--The Soviet Communist party newspaper Pravda said today that President Johnson's Guam conference on Vietnam proved that the United States had no interest in ending the conflict.
PERTH, Scotland, March 22 (Reuters)--The United States topped the league stage of the world curling championships today with victories in all their seven matches for a maximum 14 points.
SAN JUAN, P.R., March 22 (UPI)--A petition signed by near 1,000 Puerto Rican women demanded today that Gov. Roberto Sanchez Vilella resign because of his marital troubles.

SAIGON, Thursday, March 23 (AP)--About 10,000 South Korean troops pushed from north and south along the South Vietnamese Coast today in the biggest Korean operation of the war. They sought to close a 40-mile coastal gap and crush a North Vietnamese and Vietcong force.
Industrial issues turned mixed yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

To honor the memory of Theodore Roethke, the poet, a cash award for poetry is being established in Saginaw, Mich. Women of the Friday Book Club brought about establishment of the Theodore Roethke Memorial Foundation.

WASHINGTON, March 22-- The Federal Communications Commission agreed today to postpone until April 10 its new hearings on the controversial merger of the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
Stocks recovered sharply in afternoon trading and closed on the upside after being depressed in early dealings. Activity was light.

TOKYO, March 22--The Fuji Iron and Steel Company, Ltd., of Tokyo, and the Tokai Iron and Steel Company, Ltd., of Nagoya, announced today that they would merge on Aug. 1 to form a single concern under the Fuji name.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- United States officials announced plans today to base B-52 bombers in Thailand beginning four to eight weeks from now.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 22 (UPI)--The South African Olympic Games Association announced today new conditions for the country's athletic teams touring aboard, obviously aimed at getting the racially segregated republic readmitted to the Olympic Games.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- Air pollution from sulphur oxides often exceeds safe levels in virtually all major American cities and many smaller ones, according to a Government report published today.
Dolphins have been trained to attach wires to torpedoes and missiles lying on the ocean floor, thus greatly simplifying undersea recovery operations.

The spot rate on the British pound continued to gain in quiet trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. The final quotation of $2.7972 was three points higher than the closing rate for the preceding day.

Mrs. Ann Lynch Cooper and Maurice J. Holland Jr. will be married in July. Their engagement has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Lynch of Rota, Spain. Mr. Holland is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Holland of East Greenwich, R.I.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)--The Chief of Naval Operations and the Secretary of the Navy have disagreed under Congressional guestioning whether United States airpower is being used effectively against North Vietnam.

STANFORD, Calif., March 22 (AP)--The Stanford University news bureau announced that Dr. Victor C. Twitty, 65 years old, head of the biological sciences department, died today in his campus laboratory "of self-inflicted cyanide poisoning."
GENEVA, March 22--The United Nations Commission on Human Rights urged today that the General Assembly establish a high commissioner's office for human rights.

RICHMOND, Va., March 21-- Big shippers and big truckers got together here last night at the annual dinner of the Richmond Traffic Club. And since regulated industries of this kind always have their pipelines into politics (and vice versa) not a few of those present were men who know more than a little about votes and voters in Virginia.

The Rev. Dr. James Archibald Mitchell, who retired five years ago as rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Englewood, N.J., died yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. His age was 74.

Bonsai, the Japanese art of growing dwarf trees in small containers, will be demonstrated by the Greenwich House Pottery School from April 7 through 9 at its flower and ceramics show at Greenwich House.

ALBANY, March 22--Republican delegates to the Constitutional Convention declared today that major proposals on which the convention is narrowly divided should be submitted to the voters separately--not lumped with other proposals that have widespread support.

For the second of their three current lieder recitals in Carnegie Hall, Dietrich FischerDieskau, baritone, and Gerald Moore, pianist, last night turned their attention to the greatest of song cycles; Schubert's "Die Winterreise."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 22--Most of the members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee conferred for more than three hours today with Secretary General Thant, principally on the war in Vietnam.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 22--Mickey Mantle suffered his first injury of 1967 today as the Yankees bowed to the Red Sox, 5-2, in the opener of a seven-game road trip against the Western-based Florida teams.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, March 22 (AP)--Eddie Cotton of Seattle, the second-ranked light-heavyweight, scored a technical knockout victory over Bobby Stininato of San Francisco in the ninth round of their scheduled 10-round fight here last night.
Two of the nation's top ad agencies yesterday announced major executive changes aimed toward the same goal: client happiness. Kenyon Eckhardt and Benton Bowles are the agencies.
ALBANY, March 22--The appointment of Dr. Joseph B. Robinson to the new post of Assistant for Special Problems to the State Health Commissioner was announced today by Governor Rockefeller.

ALBANY, March 22--Governor Rockefeller recommended today that a bridge be built across Long Island Sound, connecting the Oyster Bay-Bayville area in Nassau County with the Rye-Port Chester area in Westchester.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.

A 40-year-old importer was arrested in his lower Manhattan office yesterday by Federal agents who said they found 12 pounds of pure heroin hidden in electronics equipment that had just been delivered from Paris, In Paris, meanwhile, French police disclosed that they had arrested five men and seized another 12 pounds of heroin that was to be shipped--also in eletronics equipment--to New York.
The Tuskegee Institute Choir, led by Relford Patterson, its director since 1956, sang at Town Hall last night.
A Bronx grand jury investigating city-supported Youth Houses, detention homes for boys and girls, has found brutality, aggressive homosexuality, overcrowding and poor care.

FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, March 22 (Reuters)--Sierra Leone's army chief, Brig. David Larisana, imposed a curfew on the capital today and announced that all efforts were being made to form a constitutional government and end political confusion.

STEAMBOAT SPRINGS, Colo., March 22--"That man I just clipped is a rancher with a 1,000-acre spread up in the Sydney section," George the barber said today. "But he ain't selling. He's waiting for the ski boom."
James McVickar, a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 1150 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 22-- A new type of closed-end investment trust--with one set of shares that will receive all the trust's dividend income and another set that will receive all its capital gains--was cleared for sale to the public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
If the likely prospect of a white Easter weren't a bit ludicrous, merchants would be crying.

WASHINGTON, March 22-- A new type of closed-end investment trust--with one set of shares that will receive all the trust's dividend income and another set that will receive all its capital gains--was cleared for sale to the public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
If the likely prospect of a white Easter weren't a bit ludicrous, merchants would be crying.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 22 --The Rev. Dr. Robert M. Skinner, vice president of Princeton Theological Seminary, died today while visiting friends in Westfield, N.J. He was 64 years old.

Richard Adler, collaborator on the songs of "The Pajama Game" and "Damn Yankees," is negotiating to produce the musical version of Bruce Jay Friedman's best-seller, "A Mother's Kisses," next season. Jerome Chodorov has done the adaptation.
COCOA, Fla., March 22-- Norman Miller hit a home run with two out in the last of the ninth inning today to give the Houston Astros a 4-3 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

SEATTLE, March 22--Lew Mathe of Los Angeles, Ron Von Der Porten, Michael Lawrence and Lew Stansby, all of San Francisco, Jim Jacoby of Dallas and G. Robert Nail of Houston won the Vanderbilt Cup final here this afternoon by a margin of 16 international match points.

DJIBOUTI, French Somaliland, March 22--Somalia has refused to permit a group of Somali tribesmen who were expelled from French Somaliland to take refuge on her territory, a French Government spokesman said tonight.
Trading in a new cotton contract, called No. 2, opened quietly yesterday in terms of activity but loudly in terms of brokers' shouts as they made their bids and offers.
GENEVA, March 22--A tentative agreement reached on a three-year extension of a pact regulating world trade in cotton textiles marked a major breakthrough today in the Kennedy round of tariff talks.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)--A Senate investigator charged today that an international cartel had sought to control the quinine market by purchasing Unit States stockpiles.
Benjamin W. Rosenblum, tion, textile converters at 119 West 40th Street, died on Tuesday at Palm Beach, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived at 605 Park Avenue.
CAMERON, Wis., March 22-- Milk is money to a dairy farmer. When he dumps milk and watches it seep into the earth or flow down a creek, he is watching dollars disappear.

WASHINGTON, March 22-- Two little-noticed changes in the antipoverty program are subjecting Sargent Shriver and his Office of Economic Opportunity to the close supervision of the advisory council Mr. Shriver used to head.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 22 (UPI)-- Manuel Santana of Spain and Jan Leschly of Denmark scored straight-set victories today to enter the final of the South African tennis championship.
LONDON, March 22--The House of Commons voted tonight to change Britain's currency system to a decimal $2.80 pound.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 22--The Alabama State Board of Education was ordered by a Federal Court today to begin desegregation of all public schools in the state by next fall.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI)--Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that half the nation's doctors were refusig to treat Medicare patients.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 22 (AP)--The Philadelphia Phillies extended Manager Gene Mauch's contract today through 1968.

CAMAU, South Vietnam, March 19--At dusk Maj. Theodore Cline taxies his plane from the dirt airstrip that runs through this provincial capital, avoids end-of-the-day traffic at an intersection and parks his 0-1E Bird Dog in the Government headquarters compound.

Nix was the word for the thoroughbreds at Aqueduct yesterday. Nix, the Latin word for snow and the good old American slang term for no go. For the third time since last Friday, the racing card at the Big A was canceled because of the surprising and super-abundant downfall that made the track look like part of a huge meadow in a midwinter setting.

GENEVA, March 22 (AP) --The World Health Organization warned today that the world was in the throes of a cholera epidemic that could reach Western Europe, and that fear was helping to spread the disease.
A huge volume of new debt securities reached the market yesterday, headed by the largest underwritten public offering on record.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)--The Federal Home Loan Bank Board published tonight a policy statement on mergers of savings and loan associations insured by the Federal Government.
George F. Keenan, professor of law at St. John's University, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 85-15 Forest Parkway, Woodhaven, Queens. His age was 65.

PAWLING, N.Y., March 22 --Mrs. Owen Kildare, radio broadcaster, lecturer and author, died yesterday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Elliot Christman, on Pleasant Ridge Road in Poughquag, near here. She was 78 years old.

EAST LANSING, Mich., March 22--Don Schollander will make his long-awaited debut in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's swimming championships, which start tomorrow at Michigan State University. But he may be overshadowed by Greg Buckingham, his summertime buddy.

JOHN BROWNING is the kind of pianist who is at his best in elegant music Thus it was no surprise that Ravel's "Gaspard de la Nuit" should have received the best performance of all the music on his Philharmonic Hall program last night. Mr. Browning has agile fingers, a good sonorous tone and an ability to handle any kind of pianistic figuration in stride.

JUNEAU, Alaskan March 22 (AP)--The Coast Guard reported tonight that the cutter Storis had seized a 178-foot Russian fishing vessel for violating the United States 12-mile exclusive fisheries zone off the Alaska Peninsula.
Orders for machine tools, depressed in recent months, made a sharp recovery in February.
WESTBURY, L.I., March 22 --Precisely nine hours after this morning's announcement of the snow-out at Aqueduct, the word was flashed officially that there would be action tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Tuesday the level it reached on Monday, which was 99.7.

The candidate of the Government's National Conciliation party, Col. Fidel Sanchez, has won his expected election in El Salvador for a five-year presidential term. Fears that the left-wing candidate, Fabio Castillo, might win or make a strong showing proved wide of the mark; he was a very poor third.

Almost gently, it seemed, in deference to the man's age, his eight children, his downcasteyed humility, Cassius Clay knocked out Zora Folley last night with one short, chopping, right-hand punch to the chin.
