SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 22--Nearly 900 enemy soldiers died in fighting that raged throughout South Vietnam yesterday. At least 60 American soldiers were killed ...
SUBURBAN radio, a major public convenience that has tended to be overshadowed by the glamour of television, comes into its own when there is a sudden snowstorm. Yesterday morning was no exception.

LONDON, March 22 (UPI) --A 16-year-old boy said in court today that he had stolen 26 snakes from London Zoo, including one of the most poisonous species in the world, simply because he was "very interested in snakes."

The city plans to use most of the money it hopes to receive from the Model Cities program to improve educational opportunities for young children, to provide training and job opportunities for welfare clients, and to enable property owners to rehabilitate their buildings.

HONG KONG, March 22-- Across the Shumchun River on the plain at the foot of the mistshrouded mountain lies Communist China. The figures in the rice paddies are workers of the People's Republic. They look no different from those grubbing in the paddies on this side of the placid river.

HANOI, North Vietnam, March 22 (Agence FrancePresse)--A definite hardening of Hanoi's position in the Vietnamese war is the interpretation put by observers, here on yesterday's publication of President Johnson's letter to President Ho Chi Minh and the reply of the North Vietnamese leader.

The president of Jubilee Records said yesterday that if Adam Clayton Powell showed "a little bit more humility" it might help the lagging sales of the former Harlem Representative's record, "Keep the Faith, Baby."
WASHINGTON, March 22-- A group of air traffic controllers charged today that flight was reaching "a point of public peril" because of shortages of trained men and modern equipment.

A five-year program for the United States merchant marine that has the Secretary of Transportation, Alan S. Boyd as its chief salesman ran into its first major obstacle from a management group yesterday.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 23 Ticonderoga, one of the world's fastest sailing yachts, fell 30 miles behind the pacemaking Chubasco today in the Miami-Montego Bay race, after a frustrating night of drifting on windless seas.
Group Securities, Inc., a mutual-fund investment company, announced yesterday in Jersey City the election of John R. Tappan as a director.
The Occidental Petroleum Corporation last year had the highest sales and earnings in its 47-year history, Dr. Armand Hammer, president, reported yesterday.

HONG KONG, March 23 A fondness for bridge that virtually amounted to an addiction was a cause of the downfall of Teng Hsiao-ping, general secretary of the Chinese Communist party, in the purges of Mao Tse-tung's Cultural Revolution, according to a Red Guard newspaper.

The Union Electric Company reported yesterday 1966 operating revenues of $229,670,000, against $209,862,000 a year earlier. Net income rose to 39,800,000, equal to $1.53 a share, from $37,051,000, or $1.42 a share, in 1965.

CHICAGO, March 23 (UPI) The St. Louis Hawks rallied in the last quarter last night to beat the Chicago Bulls 113-107, and take a 2-0 lead in their best-of-five semi-final National Basketball Association playoff. Lou Hudson led the victor's scoring with 29 points.

NEWARK, March 23 (AP) A Federal judge approved today a petition for bankruptcy filed by the Jersey Central Railroad. He scheduled a hearing April 11 to choose trustees to operate the debt-ridden commuter line.
WEST HARTFORD, Conn., March 23 David R. Daniel, retired publisher of The Hartford Times, died today in Hartford Hospital at the age of 64.

Verdi's "Il Trovatore" was given for the seventh time this season by the Metropolitan Opera last night, but it was only the first time of the season for three of the cast members: Gabriella Tucci as Leonora: James McCracken as Manrico and Louis Sgarro as Ferrando.
Suffolk County Judge Floyd Sarisohn refused 35 times yesterday to answer questions on his dealings with a convicted prostitute.
WASHINGTON, March 23 Representative Herbert Tenzer said today that an urban renewal project near Kennedy International Airport, which had been held up because of jet noise, had been reactivated.
Delos A. Blodgett 2d, a former director of several corporations, died Wednesday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 66 East 79th Street, a cooperative of which he was president.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 23 J. Edward Johnson, retired vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died in the Good Samaritan Hospital here yesterday. He was 65 years old and had come here from Glen Ridge, N.J., after his retirement in September.
NEW DELHI, March 23 Foreign Minister M.C. Chagla told Parliament today that the Government would conduct a "thorough inquiry" into the activities of the Central Intelligence Agency in India.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 23 ?Loredo Hanover finished first in the featured Class A-3 one mile pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, but it failed to avail those among the 17,022 fans who had wagered on the 7-2 horse. Loredo Hanover was disqualified because of interference and dropped to eighth place.
FLANDERS, N.J., March 23 Miss Marcia Phyliss Kevitz and Jonathan E. Avirom will be married this spring.
Yesterday, it was the turn of Needham, Harper Steers to announce changes at the top.
PARIS, March 23 (Reuters) The French Horse Racing Federation announced today the cancellation of a payoff of 7,000,000 francs (about $1.4-million) to a mystery bettor.

SAN FRANCISCO City of Paris, a department store here, has one thing in common with another big store, G. Fox Co. of Hartford: both are run by granddaughters of the founders, who are now septuagenarians.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 For what it's worth, the Yankees can lay claim today to the baseball championship of New York.

An attempt by underworld figures to take over a plush suburban nightclub by intimidation and violence resulted yesterday in the indictment of three alleged Mafia members on charges of violating the Federal antiracketeering laws.

WASHINGTON, March 23 Charges that the news broadcasts of the American Broadcasting Company might be subject to interference and censorship if the company is taken over by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation will be fully explored in the Government's forthcoming hearings.
BUENOS AIRES, March 23 (AF) Oscar Bonavena accepted a $75,000 offer today to flight Cassius Clay, the heavyweight champion, in Tokyo May 27.

WASHINGTON, March 23 The Johnson Administration's new slogan for the Vietnam war is "More of the Same." This has a cool and almost casual sound, but the nation should be very clear about what it means.
WASHINGTON, March 23 The United States Government was studying today the possibility and cost of providing "live" television coverage via satellite of the forthcoming Latin-American summit meeting.
VIENTIANE, March 23 The national radio announced today the dismissal of General Kong Le as commander in chief of the neutralist element in Laos.

The snow swirled down again at Aqueduct yesterday afternoon, as machinery rolled over the empty track. Dick Strickland, the supervisor of racing strips for the New York Racing Association, had his crew working hard to get the track into working order, on the chance that there would be racing today.
GENEVA, March 23 Switzerland and Sweden, both traditionally neutral powers, propose to conclude an accord for cooperation in the development of nuclear power for peaceful uses.

The Belgian Village, an entertainment success but a financial loser at the 1964-65 World's Fair, owes the state and the city $20,000 because of unpaid sales taxes, the State Division of Taxation said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 23 An Administration-supported bill to create a 43,434-acre Redwood National Park in northern California was introduced in the Senate today with a warning that further delays might "spell final doom" to park proposals.

Angry owners of illegally parked autos that had been towed away to the city's car pound on Pier 74, at 34th Street, became further incensed yesterday when the pound was suddenly moved to Piers 95 and 96.

NEW ORLEANS, March 23 A New Orleans judge ordered today the arrest of Gordon Novel, a 29-year-old former bar owner in the New Orleans French Quarter, as a material witness in the investigation by District Attorney Jim Garrison into the assassination of President Kennedy.
BUFFALO, March 23 (AP) Pete Johnson, a jazz pianist once known as the "Boss of the Blues," died tonight in Meyer Memorial Hospital after suffering a stroke at his home here Sunday.
HURRY SUNDOWN" is sheer pulp fiction as Otto Preminger has put it on the screen.
THE new one-man evening at the Off Broadway Or pheum, adapted from Gogol's "Diary of a Madman," is a lonesome business on two counts.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 23 The initial reaction of economic observers here to Colombia's massive new economic statute is that it consolidates existing measures rather than reaches out in adventurous new directions.

ALBANY, March 23 The counsel to the Speaker of the Assembly said today that he was severing his relationship with a public employes union he had represented for seven years because of news stories that had "misrepresented" the work he did for the union.
Industrial issues closed with moderate gains yesterday in quiet trading on the London Stock Exchange.

PARIS, March 23 French authorities today indicated that Bertrand Russell and his supporters would not be permitted to hold an "international war crimes tribunal" in a public place in Paris next month as they had planned. It was not clear whether the organizers would go on to hold the "tribunal" in private.
TOKYO, March 23 (AP) North Vietnam said today that its disclosure of secret letters between President Johnson and President Ho Chi Minh was "legitimate and necessary."

Tenants of the 17-story apartment building at 180 East 79th Street will take title to the 37-year-old structure in an $8-million transaction on April 10, the renting and managing agents said yesterday.
Samuel D. Shwitzer, a New York lawyer for 64 years, died Monday at his home in Harrison. N.Y. He was 85 years old.
MIAMI, March 23 He was a big lobster. His an tennae delicately tested the water around him.
A rare twentieth-century United States postage stamp sold here yesterday for $6,750.

WASHINGTON, March 23 Government sources said today that there were no plans for a meeting between President Johnson or his senior officials there and Maj. Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle, Presidentelect of Nicaragua. General Somoza is in New York on a "private" visit.

CHICAGO, March 23 (AP) Negotiators representing 12,000 railroad switchmen across the nation have accepted a 5 per cent pay rise offered by 26 railroads, a union official said today.
Robert Coover has won the 1966 award of the William Faulkner Foundation for the "best first novel of the year."
Zim Lines announced yesterday that its 25,300-ton flagship, the Shalom, would carry out all sailings scheduled for the rest of the year.
BRUSSELS, March 23 European interest rates are falling like a row of dominoes as central bankers, acting with unparalleled coordination, attempt to revive their sluggish economies.

The election of Neville Stone as chairman of the board of the American Waterways Operators, Inc., by the directors of the national trade association of the towboat, tugboat and barge industry has been announced.

DETROIT, March 23 The Rangers, looking like so many fallen angels, were kicked out of second place in the National Hockey League tonight by a band of Detroit Red Wings that had nothing to gain except salve for injured pride.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 23 (UPI) Mrs. Billie Jean King and Maria Bueno justified their top seeding at the South African championships today by blasting their way into the singles final.

IF a ringsider watches Cassius Clay often enough, he sometimes will find himself doing a double take. It is almost as if the observer has glanced at a trick mirror in a fun house and is startled by the distorted image that confronts him. Maybe that's why it's so difficult to get a proper focus on the champion of the world.

Mrs. Margaret M. Kerr of Easton, Conn., and Harold B. Kerr of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Kerr, to John E. Stenson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Stenson of Wautoma, Wis.
City Councilman Mario Merola has submitted a bill that would permit fans of the New York football Giants to resell previously purchased tickets for any reason, including a poor won-lost record.
WASHINGTON, March 23 Senator Daniel B. Brewster, Democrat of Maryland, has separated from his wife, Carol, and lawyers are Working out divorce terms.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) Congress was asked today to ban the sale of airline trip insurance at airport counters, or by vending machines, in an effort to curb airliner sabotage.
An advertising executive suggested yesterday that networks should refund some of the cost of sponsorship if the number of viewers of a television program is less than expected.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 23 William Marion Nygren, 22 years old, a junior at Portland State College, was convicted yesterday of failure to report for induction into the armed forces. He was sentenced to 18 months in prison.
Nine prominent Roman Catholic scholars have become advisers to a new unofficial Catholic organization seeking a change in canon law to permit priests to marry.
Prof. Clyde C. Whipple, who retired in 1962 from the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, died Wednesday night at his home, 25 Cushman Road in Scardale, N.Y. He was 75 years old.
Luther Lassiter wasn't in his best form yesterday as he started the defense of his world pocket billiards championship in the Terrace Ballroom of the Hotel Statler-Hilton.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) France plans to boycott a meeting of the foreign ministers of the nations in the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization scheduled here April 1820, it was learned tonight.

The regular passenger steamship link between New York and Bermuda, interrupted since last November when Furness Lines withdrew from the run, was reopened yesterday with the sailing of the 22,636-ton Cunard liner Franconia yesterday.
BIRCHWOOD, Wis., March 23 Eugene George, a 39-yearold dairy farmer here, is on strike.
WASHINGTON, March 23 Three of the four representatives from Queens called today for a medical school and hospital at Fort Totten, a scenic waterfront site at the northeastern tip of Queens.
Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., is extending to April 21 its tender offer to purchase shares of Austin, Nichols Co., a liquor importer, at $27.50 a share.
Federal Reserve credit policy eased further during the week ended Wednesday, figures issued yesterday by the monetary authorities indicated.

ROME, March 23 The Italian Defense Ministry said today that there was "no foundation whatever" for reports that officers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization had been implicated in a Soviet spy ring uncovered in Turin.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 23 The number of American and enemy combat casualties in Vietnam set records last week, a United States military spokesman reported tonight.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 23 The Arkansas Supreme Court ordered the release tonight of two newsmen who were jailed here yesterday.
The New York-Tulane Educational Conference, a series of panel discussions led by Tulane University faculty members, will be held at the Biltmore Hotel next Thursday.

The offer by Buell G. Gallagher, president of the City College, to have that institution assume operational responsibility for a cluster of schools in Harlem should be welcomed by all parties to the growing controversy over the management of the city's schools.
PARIS, March 23 Two new books have set off debate and soul-searching among Roman Catholic intellectuals in France.
WHEN a philosopher appears to turn against all the body of thought that his disciples have come to hold dear, there is bound to be dispute and despair.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) The Federal Reserve Board said today net income after taxes of the more than 6,000 banks in its system increased about 5 per cent last year. It said earnings rose by $100-million to $2.2-billion.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 The days are growing longer for Wes Westrum, the manager of the New York Mets, and today was one of the longest.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 23 Buoyed by visions of beer, beach and bikinis, thousands of college students swarmed this week to their three favorite Easter vacation spas Nassau, Fort Lauderdale and this 23-mile-long stop of sand to participate in what they call "the annual spring rites."

Active training of astronaut crews for the nation's space program has been suspended until the full impact of the Apollo spacecraft fire last January can be assessed, space agency officials said yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 23 A dramatic increase in Vietcong defections was the central reason for assertions by key officials at the Guam conference that enemy morale was beginning to crumble, American sources indicated today.

A three-alarm fire, feeding on 4,000 bales of crude rubber, destroyed nearly three quarters of an 850-foot pier at Clifton, S.I., yesterday afternoon. The owners estimated the total loss at more than $1-million. The flames and fiery debris from the...
The president of Youth House, Inc., said yesterday that she hoped recent disclosures of overcrowding and maltreatment would force the city to held improve its four detention homes.
WASHINGTON, March 23 President Johnson won a prize convert today in the Congressional debate on the Vietnam war.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 23 The United Arab Republic's Permanent Representative said today that his Government was supporting "the people" against the local governments in the British-protected Federation of South Arabia.
In show business top billing goes to the most popular star. It's the same way in the threering show at the Chicago Board of Trade.
VENICE, Fla., March 23 (UPI) Gloria Ehret and Kathy Whitworth carded two-under par 70's today to tie for the first-round lead in the $11,500 Venice open women's golf tournament.
Directors of the General Aniline and Film Corporation and the Ruberoid Company signed yesterday formal agreements to merge, as approved in principle on March 1.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) The House Education and Labor Committee today recommended continuing the Teacher Corps for two more years and urged Congress to finance aid to school districts in poverty areas for two years.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) The Federal Aviation Agency has agreed to withhold the birth date and sex of pilots and aircraft owners in selling listings of such persons, Representative Cornelius E. Gallagher, Democrat of New Jersey, said today.
A technique that some believe will open new paths for studying the nature of atoms and molecules, the chemistry of life and many other mysteries was described here yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, March 23 The 11th Yale Festival of Undergraduate Drama ended today. More than 500 visitors from 38 colleges attended 12 performances of one-act works and excerpts from longer plays, including some by student playwrights.
WASHINGTON, March 23 American individuals and businesses, taken together, are taxed less than their counterparts in any other major industrial country in the Atlantic world.

The city's new Commissioner of Parks and Administrator of Recreation and Cultural Affairs predicted yesterday that Mayor Lindsay's Cultural Council, now being formed, would be the "most gutsy art council in the world."

KNOWLTON, N.J., March 23 (UPI) An alleged milk saboteur was shot and a truck driver was kidnapped while his milk tanker was hijacked and wrecked today in eruptions of violence growing out of the National Farmers Organization's milk strike.
HERMOSILLO, Mexico, March 23 (AP) Eleven people were killed and at least 35 were injured as students and teachers fought the police, informed but unofficial sources said today.
Theodore W. Kheel, chief mediator in the newspaper dispute, announced yesterday he had intervened in the dispute between the publishers and Printing Pressmen's Local No. 2.

ALBANY, March 23 (AP) A resolution that would have let voters decide in November whether to permit the state to build and operate a ski resort in the Adirondack Preserve was defeated today in the Assembly.
United States military officers think that the Soviet leaders have everything to gain and nothing to lose by discussing the possible curtailment of the nuclear missile race.

EAST LANSING, Mich., March 23 Greg Buckingham and Dick Roth of Stanford smashed American records tonight as the National Collegiate swimming championships began at Michigan State University. How fast they swam depends on how much you believe in modern technology.

The Investment Company Institute, the trade association for mutual funds, reported yesterday that investors purchased $298,313,000 of new fund shares last month, down from $391,340,000 in January and down from $395,849,000 in February, 1966.

WASHINGTON, March 23 "Parkinson's Second Law" has been working with a vengeance in the less-developed countries a major reason for their failure to show much economic advance. Such is the pessimistic conclusion of an economist of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
SEA SCAPE, Andromeda and Horizons won't be going into the water today at the Norwalk Cove Marina, as scheduled.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 99.4 on Wednesday from 99.7 on Tuesday.

SEATTLE, Wash, March 23 The final of the Vander bilt Cup contest, which ended here last night, was a close match between two well-balanced teams. Two factors accounted for the slender 16point margin of victory for Lew Mathe of Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, March 23 Imports fell more than exports in February, marking the second consecutive month of improvement in the nation's trade surplus, the Commerce Department reported today.
Two plainclothes patrolmen stopped a performance in the New Dramatists Workshop, 83 East Fourth Street, late last night and arrested four performers on charges of desecrating the flag.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) South Africa has denied Ralph McGill, noted publishercolumnist, a visa to visit that country on a United States Government-sponsored lecture tour, it was disclosed today.
ALBANY, March 23 The Senate passed today a bill that would mandate higher minimum car insurance coverage for about three-million motorists in the state.

Vice President Humphrey's tour of Europe next week, though hardly an adequate substitute for President Johnson's long-overdue visit there, is an essential holding operation at a time of deepening malaise in relations with America's most vital allies.
THOSE silent partners of the New York Philharmonic, the three young assistant conductors, took over the orchestra last night in Philharmonic Hall.
POUND RIDGE, N.Y., March 23 Miss Linda Wirt Lewis and Frank Winston Tooni have made plans to be married May 20 in South Salem.
An exhibition of oil sketches from the 17th and 18th centuries will assist graduate students in art history at Columbia University to study abroad.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, March 23 The 105's were still firing when the helicopter touched down at Fire Base Jullet, which has been hacked out of the jungle in the hills three or four miles from the Cambodian frontier.
GLASGOW, Scotland, March 23 (AP) Duncan Macrae, a character actor on stage and screen, died here today in the Victoria Infirmary, where he had been a patient since November. He was 61 years old.

DETROIT, March 23 (AP) Automobile production in the United States fell off to an estimated 134,735 cars this week because of the Easter holidays. Assembly plants will be closed from Good Friday until Monday.

Mayor Lindsay urged the State Legislature yesterday to approve a pending Hospitals Department reorganization measure, which he called "the first essential step in rebuilding the troubled municipal hospitals of New York City."

POTSDAM, N.Y., March 23 The engagement of Miss Barbara Jean McHugh to Robert Davis Bethke has been announced by Prof. and Mrs. Edward McHugh, parents of the future bride. Mr. Bethke is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Bethke of Armonk.

WESTON, Vt., March 23 Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Christoffers, formerly of Darien, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Christoffers, to Krov Nicholas Menuhin. He is the son of Yehudi Menuhin, the violinist, of London and Mrs. Nola Hawthorne of Nassau, the Bahamas.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had ordered the recall of 26,000 cases of dog candy contaminated with Salmonella bacteria.
ALBANY, March 23 Governor Rockefeller and the legislative leaders failed tonight to reach agreement on a fiscal package for New York City.
Columbia University took a major step yesterday toward withholding the class standings of its students from draft boards.

Miss Suzanne Elizabeth Leaf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Leaf of Mount Vernon, N.Y., was married last evening to Harold Jerome Greenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Greenberg, also of Mount Vernon. Rabbi Henry L. Kagan and Rabbi Aaron H. Blumenthal performed the ceremony at the Regency.
WASHINGTON, March 23 Release of United States stockpiles of quinine was suggested today as a weapon against high drug prices, which have allegedly been inflated by an international cartel.
MOSCOW, March 23 (AP) The United States and the Soviet Union began today to arrange for negotiations to limit the arms race in offensive and defensive nuclear missiles.
The eyes of the two regal lions that have guarded the main entrance to the New York Public Library for 56 years were ringed yesterday with four-inch-wide bands of bright orange and blue paint.

VIENNA, March 23 Morris Mott scored two third-period goals tonight to lift heavilyfavored Canada past the United States, 2-1, and into a tie with the Soviet Union for first place in the world amateur hockey championship.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) President Johnson asked Congress today for an additional appropriation of $479-million to cover added costs of the 1967 pay increase for Federal employes and military personnel.
Israeli rioters who recently protested rising unemployment by stoning the Tel Aviv city hall were reflecting the political tensions generated by the Government's deflationary policies.
A laborer charged with hitting and threatening a woman with an air rifle hanged himself last night in his cell at the Wilson Avenue precinct in Brooklyn, the police said.

OAKHURST, N.J., March 23 Dr. and Mrs. Harrison J. Merrill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda June Merrill, to Peter Nelson Upton of the Navy. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson K. Upton of Buffalo.
The Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad reported yesterday a net income of $1.9million for 1966, compared with a $1,450,669 loss in 1965.

WASHINGTON, March 23 The United States is preparing an offer to open all its civilian atomic power plants to international inspection. The intention is to set an example for worldwide acceptance of international controls over such plants.

HONG KONG, March 23 Jenmin Jih Pao, official publication of the Chinese Communist party, said today that the difficulties of "U.S. imperialism" in the Vietnam war were "enormous, insoluble and fatal."

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) The Senate Republican leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen, today predicted intensified bombing of North Vietnam as the Washington attitude toward peace talks took a pessimistic turn.
General Motors accused yesterday Ralph Nader, the author and auto safety critic, and Vincent Gillen, a former investigator for the company, of being "allies in an attempt to mulet General Motors."
The Columbia Broadcasting System broadcast yesterday a report from Peking, the network's first from mainland China in 17 years.

The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation reported yesterday that the Warren Petroleum Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Gulf Oil Corporation, had indicated its intention of tendering the 1.92 million shares of the Transwestern Pipeline Company that it owns in response to Texas Eastern's tender offer.
The stock market responded to lower interest rates for business yesterday and moved sharply higher in active dealings.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 23 (AP) Ten of the best handicap horses from the East and the West were entered today for Saturday's 22d running of the $137,600 Gulfstream Park Handicap, with a record $97,600 awaiting the winner.
ATLANTA, March 23 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. says the war in Vietnam has become the major obstacle to the civil rights movement and that he plans to take "a much stronger stand" against it.
The election of David F. Shaw as president, chief executive officer and a director was announced here yesterday by the United Nuclear Corporation.

KIRKENES, Norway, March 10 Because the Norwegian Government feels it cannot find a good reason to say no to Moscow, Kirkenes is again scheduled to become a departure point for visaless visits to a couner of the Soviet Union.

ALBANY, March 23 "Bill Ronan is going to have so much power under Rockefeller's transportation plan that Bob Moses will look like a schoolboy with a small allowance," a politician commented here recently.
PERTH, Scotland, March 23 (UPI) Scotland won the Scotch Cup, symbolic of world curling supremacy, for the first time when it defeated Sweden, 11 to 5, tonight.

The Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania presented its 79th annual production, "Quick! Before It's Written," subtitled "An Absolutely True Account of Everything That's Ever Happened in the Entire World, Including Newark, New Jersey," at The Lambs, 128 West 44th Street, last night.
Directors of Wilson Co. voted yesterday a quarterly dividend of 42 cents a share on the company's common stock, payable April 26 to stockholders of record April 3.

The Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference selected Princeton, Long Island University and Massachusetts Institute of Technology yesterday as the outstanding basketball teams in their respective divisions for the 1966-67 seasons.
RYE, N.Y., March 23 H. Earle Thompson, a retired vice president of the Union Carbide Corporation, died of a stroke today at his home on Griswold Road. He would have been 75 years old on Saturday.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 23 Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. has won the support of two members of his Cabinet in his campaign against crime, provided it can be financed entirely from state funds.
Interest rates resumed their downward course yesterday as the credit market digested Wednesday's announcements of cuts in the basic business lending rate.

The small Storm King Art Center, at Mountainville, N.Y., has just brought off a coup that a major art museum might crow over. In one swoop, it has bagged 13 works by the late David Smith, considered by many critics the most important sculptor this country has produced.

BONN In their mood of increasing political awareness, the Germans hope to learn from us where Washington's interests are the same as those of Bonn and where they aren't. This is the real point Chancellor Kiesinger wants explored when he is received this spring by President Johnson. He is unlikely to be satisfied with vagaries or slogans.
OTTAWA, March 23 (AP) Canada's new Bank Act, after eight months in the House of Commons, won Senate approval in a matter of hours yesterday and early today it became the law of Canada.

LOYADA, French Somaliland, March 23 Border officials of Somalia charged today that French soldiers in French Somaliland had tortured Somali tribesmen by clubbing them with rifle butts and making them lie, half naked, on desert sand in the sun.
The coffee is free at the Compleat Works of Charles Dickens, a student-run coffeehouse across the street from Fordham University. And so is everything else.

Elie Siegmeister has written more than 100 songs since his 1930 student days in Paris, and 25 of them were on display last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The retrospective concert was presented by Herbert Beattle, bass, and Maxine Makas, soprano. Both artists served the composer and his music eloquently.
PENSACOLA, Fla., March 23 (UPI) Homero Blancas, Bob Kelley and Tom Weiskopf shot seven-under-par 65's today and shared a one-stroke lead after the opening round of the $75,000 Pensacola open.

The possibility that the elevated section of the West Side Highway between Canal Street and the Battery Park underpass might be replaced by a depressed roadway was held out yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
Consumption of newsprint set records in February and for the first two months of 1967.

Mayor Lindsay's impressive plea on behalf of the Rockefeller program for mass transportation unification in the New York metropolitan area should have convinced any doubters. He correctly described it as a sensible, progressive step that would provide a modern transportation system for ten million New Yorkers.

LOS ANGELES, March 23, (AP) The San Francisco Warriors whipped the Los Angeles Lakers 113-102 tonight to take a 2-0 lead in the best-of-five semi-final Western Division play-offs of the National Basketball Association.

The marriage of Miss Geri Wahrman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Wahrman of Brooklyn, to Daniel Richter Raichel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Israel Raichel of Fair Lawn, N.J., took place last night. Rabbi Leon B. Fink performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Shalom in Brooklyn.

The spot rate on the British pound rose to its highest level since last March in moderate trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here. The final quotation of $2.7977 was five points above the closing rate on Wednesday.

DAKAR, Senegal March 23 (Reuters) Supporters of former Premier Mamadou Dia were accused today of having plotted to assosinate President Leopold Senghor yesterday, according to an announcement from the President's Office.

GARDNER, Mass., March 23 Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Nichols Jr. of Gardner and Rindge, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara W. Nichols, to Pfc. John E. Bennett, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Bennett of Kabul, Afghanistan, and Tokyo. The wedding is planned for May.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company of New York avoided capital gain taxes on $4.9-million in two transactions involving transfers of property to a charitable trust. Representative Wright Patman said today.

Billy's, 948 First Avenue (near 52d Street), 355-8920. The wrecker's ball wrecked Billy's, the wonderful Sutton Place landmark, in 1966, and now it has reopened at a new location with many of the sentimentally remembered trappings intact.

Operating earnings of the Monsanto Company in the first quarter are expected to be better than those of the previous quarter, but will still be below the $1.13 a share earned a year ago, Edward A. O'Neal, chairman, told shareholders at the annual meeting in St. Louis yesterday.

Dr. Bernard B. Alperstein, an allergy specialist in Brooklyn for more than 30 years, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. His age was 65 and he lived at 160 Parkside Avenue. His office was at 1319 50th Street.
Five Jewish Orthodox rabbinical groups voiced strong objections yesterday to the participation of Orthodox religious persons or organizations in any "religious dialogue" with other faiths.

WASHINGTON, March 23 Farmer "unrest and dissatisfaction is at the highest point in years," the president of the country's largest and most conservative general farm organization, the American Farm Bureau Federation, said today.

THERE is a small town in New York just a wharf away from Manhattan. Its inhabitants are the year-round residents of the Hudson Harbor-79th Street Boat Basin, a salty lot whose seagoing homes normally sway gently back and forth at their moorings.
HOW does a woman celebrate the arrival of spring when it's still too cold to doff her mink? Emeric Partos, custom fur designer for Bergdorf Goodman, offered a solution yesterday beflowered mink.
PARIS, March 23 The case of the heroin in the oscilloscopes turns out to have a curious link to the Ben Barka affair.
FORT DIX, N.J., March 23 The Army attacked today what it termed "outrageous charges" of medical neglect of trainees here, but said that a medical procedure had been added as a result of the furor.

GENEVA, March 23 The Disarmament Conference began today a six-week recess to give the United States more time to persuade West Germany and Italy to accept inspection arrangements for a treaty panning the spread of nuclear weapons.

The restrictions placed by Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary on the use of guns by policemen show an enlightened willingness on his part to cooperate with the state's revised Penal Law, which goes into effect Sept. 1. ROME, March 23 In a homily following a Holy Thursday rite today, Pope Paul VI reaffirmed Roman Catholic doctrine on the Eucharist as the sacrament of Christ's "living, real and substantial presence."

SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, March 23 At the end of the third round of the 10th chess tournament commemorating the liberation of Sarajevo in World War II, the Soviet champion, Leonid Stein led with two and a half points.
The streets of New York were turned into a morass of slush yesterday as moderating temperatures melted the 10inch snowfall that had blanketed the city on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, March 23 Three major maritime unions called off today a work stoppage scheduled for Tuesday that would have affected all United States-flag shipping in American ports. The strike had been called as a protest against the use of alien crews on American ships.
The Wire Service Guild agreed yesterday to submit to a membership vote a proposal from United Press International for a new two-year contract covering 1,000 employes in 98 bureaus across the nation.
Prices rose yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in advance of the Good Friday closing.

A 4,000-year-old love letter written on a clay tablet; jewelry more than 2,000 years old, and forgeries of British stamps smuggled into Britain in World War II for use as anti-Jewish propaganda can be seen here in an exhibition called, "Four Thousand Years of Jewish History."

Federal narcotics agents seized 230 pounds of marijuana in an apartment at 130 West 74th Street yesterday and arrested three men.
BRUSSELS, March 23 The Johnson Administration is considering backing down on its Kennedy Round request for common financing by the developed countries of food aid to the hungry nations.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 23 The University of California, Los Angeles, is expected to take its last two giant steps to an undefeated season and the National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball championship tomorrow and Saturday nights.

JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., March 23 If Europe's rep resentatives fail to do well in the concluding phases of the World Cup ski races starting tomorrow morning, their coaches may justifiably put the blame on irresistible distractions.

President Johnson was given the first annual Franklin D. Roosevelt Birthday memorial Award last night by the National Foundation March of Dimes "for keeping alight in word and deed the ideals and spirit" of the last President.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) Interest rates on conventional home mortgages dropped moderately during February for the second straight month, reflecting a general casing of credit, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

LAND'S END, England, Saturday, March 25--Driven by stormy winds, the first oil from the crippled Liberian tanker Torrey Canyon washed ashore today at the Lizard, a promontory on the Southern coast of Cornwall, coast guards reported.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 24--A horde of sunburned college students, here for the Easter holidays, went on a rampage today. They looted delivery trucks, attacked a crowded bus and battled the police with a barrage of stolen fruit.
BIMINI, the Bahamas, March 24--Adam Clayton Powell conferred today with three officials of his Harlem Democratic Club on strategy aimed at assuring his re-election on April 11.

Britain's Royal Ballet opens its ninth New York season at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 18. During the sixweek series (the longest season ever undertaken by a visiting national ballet) it will have to gross more than $1-million at the box office before the impresario. Sol Hurok, can break even.
CONCORD, N.H., March 24 --Gov. John W. King will sign a bill next week that will expand sweepstakes sales outlets in New Hampshire from 62 to more than 150.
CHICAGO, March 23 (AP)-- Gail Deborah Percy, aged 13, will be maid of honor when her half-sister, Miss Sharon Lee Percy, will have nine bridesfeller 4th on April 1.

HONG KONG, March 24 (AP)--Guy Wolstenholme of England surged into first place by a stroke today with a threeunder-par 67 for a 135 total after two rounds in the $12,000 Hong Kong open golf tournament.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 24 --No longer the "only wheel in town" since action was resumed at Aqueduct in the afternoon, Roosevelt Raceway attracted 22,465 punters tonight. The cofeatures, a pair of $10,000 consolation tests in the Early Bird pacing series, provided better than average entertainment as both winners rallied to take the one-mile events.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 24 (AP)--Charles B. Lord, advertising director of The Indianapolis News and The Indianapolis Star, died yesterday at Robert Long Hospital, where he had been taken Wednesday for heart surgery. His age was 64. He leaves his wife, Frances, and two sons, William and Richard.
NORFOLK, Va., March 24 (UPI)--The Navy said today that the aircraft carrier Wasp collided with the fleet oiler Salamonie 45 miles east of San Juan, P.R., while refueling.

DJIBOUTI, French Somaliland, March 24--France plans to increase her aid to this barren territory, focusing it on the backward Afar nomads, Gov. Louis Saget said yesterday. It was the votes of the Afars in the referendum last Sunday that gave France her mandate for continued rule here.
Mayor Lindsay has given raises totaling more than $200,000 in recent months, most of them to high-ranking city officials. The increases were bipartisan, Democrats sharing with Republicans.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)--The Justice Department announced today that it had agreed to settle for $1.6-million a $4.9-million damage suit against builders of a Veterans Administration hospital in Boston.
Miss Marjorie M. Eckmann and Stephen M. Cahn were married here yesterday afternoon in the White and Gold Suite of the Plaza by Rabbi Robert Rothman.

Superintendent Bernard E. Donovan warned yesterday that the public schools might be forced to trim services and drop proposed improvements next year for lack of funds unless the city received more state aid.
CONCORD, N.H., March 24 --The New Hampshire Supreme Court ruled unconstitutional today the loyalty oath and relating statutes affecting justices of the peace and notaries public.
BELGRADE, March 24--"Do you know how much it cost to put this country together, and how little it would take to wreck it?"

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 --The Rev. Cornelius J. Ryan, treasurer of the Eastern Province of the Vincentian Fathers, and a trustee of St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens, died here yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage. His age was 51 He resided here at the Central House of the Congregation of the Mission.

THREE boutiques, early blooms in the spring crop of new shops have recently opened in Manhattan. Abra cadabra, 243 East 60th Street, arrived dressed up like an old-fashioned carnival with clothing, accessories and decorative furnishings for men, women and children.
The American Export Isbrandtsen Company, ship line operator, announced here yesterday the election of John R. Gosnell as a director.
PRAGUE, March 24 (UPI)-- Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon completed his tour of European capitals tonight with an informal meeting with Czechoslovakia's Second Deputy ...

PANMUNJOM, Korea, March 24 (AP)--A strapping United States Army captain said today he threw a football block at two Communist guards and opened a hole for a North Korean newsman to escape from this neutral village.
WASHINGTON, March 24-- Wholesale prices remained stable in March as increases in the prices of industrial commodities were offset by further declines in food prices.

An investigation of a consumer complaint that quart containers of milk sold here have been short-filled was ordered yesterday by the Markets Commissioner, Gerard M. Weisberg. He said his department would check retail stores and bottling plants.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)--New York State asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to stop all action--at least for now--on the proposed railroad merger of the Chesapeake OhioBaltimore Ohio system and Norfolk Western.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 24--S.A. (Huey) Long's Ondine of the Larchmont Yacht Club surged up today to challenge Chubasco for the lead in the Miami-Montego Bay yacht race.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 24--Borobudur is falling down. It is also sagging inward, tilting outward and being eaten by moisture.
In his years at Albany Governor Rockefeller has made many excellent appointments to public office. His talent for picking good men, however, has never been applied to the Public Service Commission.
NEW DELHI, March 24-- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress party became the opposition party in a seventh state today as a coalition took over the Government in the northwestern state of Hariana.

NEDROW, N.Y., March 24-- The chief of the Iroquois League, a federation of five Indian tribes, is demanding that the state of New York return to Indian custody ceremonial wampum belts that go back, the Indians say, to the time of Hiawatha.
Mayor Lindsay called yesterday for intensified negotiations and mediation efforts to avert "a last-minute cliffhanger" next Thursday in the newspaper dispute.

JACKSON TOWNSHIP, N.J., March 24--Federal Bureau of Investigation agents dug up two bodies last night in a sparsely settled area here and said today they might have discovered a burial ground for victims of the Mafia, which is also known as the Cosa Nostra.

WEST ISLIP, L.I., March 24 --Frederick W. Bradt, who retired in 1960 as superintendent of terminals of the Luckenbach Steamship Company, died yesterday in Redlands, Calif., where he was vacationing. He was 70 years old and lived at 256 Sequams Lane here.
MOSCOW, March 24 (Reuters)--Tikhon S. Pryakhin, a deputy to the Supreme Soviet, the Soviet Parliament, and a leading Moscow region party official, has died at the age of 55, it was reported today.

A group of adjoining, architecturally harmonious town houses in Central Harlem that date from the eighteen-nineties has been officially designated the St. Nicholas Historic Distract by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. The commission proposed the designation at a public hearing last July.
Peggy Fleming, who successfully defended her women's world figure-skating crown in Vienna earlier this month, arrived here yesterday from Zurich en route to her home in Colorado Springs, Colo.

The nation's drug manufacturers warned yesterday that state legislation that requires written "informed" consent from patients given experimental drugs "will seriously impede medical research in New York." The music man has played for his last movie at the Museum of Modern Art. After 28 years of piano accompaniment to the vast silent-film cavalcade on the museum's auditorium screen, Arthur Kleiner is exchanging his Baldwin for a house near Minneapolis.

BOSTON, March 24-A political consultant company fashioned from a group that captured the 1964 New Hampshire Presidential primary for Henry Cabot Lodge has completed its first mission for Gov. George Romney of Michigan.

JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., March 24--A rumor began making the rounds earlier this week that Robert Killy, father of the sensational Jean-Claude, was coming here to prove to himself that the reports of his 23-year-old son's ski achievements were true.

JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., March 24--A puzzled representative of the Evian Mineral Water Company of France, the donor of the World Cup trophies, arrived at the Wild West Classic ski races today. He is Andre Redon, who was forced to land in Baltimore instead of New York because of poor flying conditions.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)--The United States should recognize that the Soviet Union, not Communist China, makes the Vietnam war possible and should use United States-Soviet trade relations as a lever to end the war, Representative Melvin R. Laird said today.
MOSCOW, March 24 (AP)-- The Soviet Union announced the launching today of the l51st satellite in its Cosmos series, the eighth this month.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., March 24--Howard D. Crane, who retired in 1950 as head of the actuarial department for New Jersey of the Federal Housing Administration, died yesterday in Bergen Pines County Hospital, Paramus, after a long illness. He was 85 years old and lived at 28 Ethelbert Place here.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 24-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk was heckled today as he defended United States policy in Vietnam before 2,200 persons at Cornell University. But he also received standing ovations from the great majority of the audience at the beginning and end of his address.
A Columbia University scientist reported yesterday that he had crystallized the human enzyme lysozyme, one of the body's defenses against bacteria.
CINCINNATI, March 24 (AP)--The Federal Government contended today that Cassius Clay's appeals to avoid the draft should come after his scheduled induction into the Army April 11.

Moody's Investors Service, Inc., which runs an investment-advisory service for client portfolios worth more than $4billion, is negotiating to acquire the investment management of Lazard Fund, Inc., with total assets exceeding $84-million.

Jack Breit of Houston defeated Kazuo Fujimi of Japan, 15063, last night to gain his fourth consecutive victory in the world pocket billiard championship at the Statler-Hilton Hotel. The victory enabled Breit to hold onto first place after four rounds.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 24--Houston, with its height and weight, boxed in Lew Alcindor, but the other members of the undefeated University of California, Los Angeles, took up the slack as the Bruins defeated the Cougars, 73-58, in a semi-final game of the National Collegiate championship tournament tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)--The Supreme Court temporarily barred Texas today from allowing private companies to bid for oil drilling in submerged lands claimed by the Federal Government.

MOSCOW, March 24 (UPI) --The liner Independence will call at Odessa next month, the first Stop by an American cruise ship at that Soviet port since World War II. The ship will head north into the Black Sea from a Mediterranean cruise, call at Odessa April 3-4 and then go on to Constanta in Rumania, a United States Embassy spokesman here said.
The Rev. John C. Taylor, assistant professor of philosophy at Fordham University for 20 years, died Thursday in his residence at Loyola Hall. He was 55 years old.

A group of American scientists, including some concerned with the planning of planetary exploration, has concluded that Soviet spacecraft have probably landed living organisms inadvertently on Mars and Venus.
CHICAGO, March 24 (AP)-- The United Soccer Association, looking ahead to the 1968 season, established player limits at a one-day meeting today.
Montgomery Ward Co. the retailer and mail-order company, announced yesterday in Chicago the election of Richard L. Abbott as a vice president.
CHIHUAHUA, Mexico, March 24 (UPI)--A measles outbreak has taken more than 50 lives recently among the Tarahumare Indians of Chihuahua, a state legislator said today.
Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc. had the highest sales and earnings in its 118-year history, the 1966 annual report disclosed yesterday.

The colorful Jewish festival of Purim will be observed beginning at sundown today and lasting through tomorrow with ceremonies both in synagogues and homes.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 24--Ambrose Pat rick Genda woke up this morning as the fifth man of Sierra Leone's six-man delegation to the United Nations. In a few hours he learned from broadcasts that he had been named to head the military junta ruling his country.

ROME, March 24--Francesco Cardinal Bracci, a Vatican expert on canon law and a member of a commission to implement the Lateran Pacts with Italy, died here today after a long illness. He was 87 years old.
JERUSALEM (Jordan), March 24--Light showers followed thousands of pilgrims as they trudged and sang their traditional route along the Way of the Cross today--Good Friday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 24--For the first time since 1947, the United Nation's has received a report from South Africa on administration of the Territory of South-West Africa.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., March 24--Extra patrols of New Jersey state policemen were as signed today to the state's major milk producing counties --Warren, Sussex and Hunterdon--to guard against renewed violence in a dispute over raising milk prices.

LONDON, March 24 (UPI)-- A surprising feature of the annual university boat race between Oxford and Cambridge tomorrow is that only two foreigners, both Americans, are among the 16 young men who will indulge in their "March madness" on the River Thames.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 (AP)--Wilt Chamberlain tied the National Basketball Association playoff-assist record of 19 tonight as he led the Philadelphia 76ers to a 121-106 victory over the Cincinnati Royals. The triumph gave the 76ers a 2-1 edge in the three-of-five-game Eastern semi-final playoff.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)--The Navy plans to pull out of a New Jersey shipyard an unfinished nuclear attack submarine that has been under construction since 1964.

Almost no one expects the New York Knickerbockers to have any basketball games to play after tomorrow, but Cazzie Russell is more certain than most that the playoff games against the Boston Celtics tonight at 8:30 o'clock at Madison Square Garden and tomorrow night in Boston will be his last of the season.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)--Two members of the House Armed Services Committee announced today that they were mobilizing opposition to an Administration proposal to build five fast deployment logistic ships.

Philip Manker, a florist for 58 years, who retired in 1965 from his shop at 3127 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, died yesterday at Lutheran Medical Center, Brooklyn. He was 74 years old and lived at 9108 Colonial Road, Brooklyn. Surviving are his widow, the former Katherine Krauss; a son, Alfred W.; a brother, Charles, and two sisters, Mrs. Elizabeth Krauss and Mrs. Lillian Podlesney.

The contemporary reality of evil and death was a dominant theme yesterday as Christians observed Good Friday, the most solemn day of the liturgical year.
Orville R. Mertz was elected president of the Koehring Company yesterday at a board meeting that followed the annual stockholders' meeting of the Milwaukee-based construction-equipment concern.

Thoroughbred horse racing returned to Aqueduct yesterday and a crowd of 42,157 attended the action. The sport was canceled at the Big A on Wednesday and Thursday because of the heavy snowfall and the consequent uncertain state of the racing surface.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., in a surprise move, has chosen Charles F. Luce, Under Secretary of the Interior, as chairman and chief executive officer.

BOSTON, March 24 (UPI)-- Senator Edward W. Brooke, saying he was neither a hawk nor a dove but "an owl" in regard to the Administration's Vietnam policy, called today for the gradual elimination of the draft and creation of a volunteer career Army.
The semi-final round of the women's Eastern indoor singles tennis championship will be held today at 5 P.M. at the Vanderbilt Athletic Club, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)--The Hi-Life Packing Company of Chicago has begun a voluntary recall of 26,000 cases of dog candy after discovery of Salmonella contamination in samples, a Food and Drug Administration spokesman said today.

PARIS, March 24--Election results in more than 100 of France's 486 National Assembly districts are being contested in appeals to the Constitutional Council. In the 1962 elections, when fewer results were contested, the council invalidated seven of them and ordered new voting.
WASHINGTON, March 24-- The Office of Economic Opportunity said today it expected to receive next month a report on the first of a series of objective, in-depth studies of community action programs.

NEAR THE DEMILITARIZED ZONE, South Vietnam, March 23--The Marine sergeant was worried. Six half-naked Vietnamese, suspected of being Vietcong, lay huddled nearby, blindfolded, army bound with cloth strips, faces pressed to the ground.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 24 (AP)--Gov. Spiro T. Agnew, Republican, signed bills today calling a constitutional convention to rewrite the state's 100year-old charter and ending the state's 306-year-old ban on interracial marriages.

The New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange were closed yesterday for Good Friday. So were commodity markets in the United States, Canada and England. The Chicago Livestock Exchange was the only major market open. Banks remained open in New York City, but were closed in New Jersey, Connecticut and some other parts of the nation.
Major commercial banks in Kansas City, Mo., reduced their prime, or minimum, interest rates on business loans to 5 per cent yesterday from 5 per cent.
The three television networks indicated yesterday that they would not provide live coverage of President Johnson's conference with hemisphere chiefs of state at Punta del Este, Uruguay, next month.
Fifteen months after the close of the 1964-65 World's Fair, the fair corporation still is embroiled in a $200,000 suit brought by the designer of the fair's largest attraction, the Belgian Village.

Richard G. Keyes, general credit manager of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation, died Wednesday on a train en route from his office at 460 Park Avenue to his home at 12 Overhill Road, Scarsdale, N. Y. His age was 62.
WASHINGTON, March 24-- The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee has withdrawn from membership in the civil rights movement's principal lobbying organization, it was learned tonight.
FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, March 24--After nearly a week of post-election political paralysis, Sierra Leone bowed to military rule last night in a bloodless coup.

MESA, Ariz., March 24-- Wiley Butler, who retired two years ago as chairman of the board of the Coastal Oil Company of Newark, a subsidiary of the Continental Oil Company, died Wednesday at Mesa General Hospital. He was 66 years old and had lived recently in Scottsdale.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 24 --The Rev. Billy Graham, whose week-long religious crusade closes here Easter Sunday, denied knowledge yesterday of Central Intelligence Agency financial support for his recent trip to Latin America.

PARIS, March 24--The natural name for a French credit card would be "carte blanche," if the Americans had not gotten to it first. Pre-empted in their own language, the French will call theirs "Carte Bleue."

THOUSANDS of children, sprung from school for Easter vacation, swarmed over New York, yesterday with their parents, soaking up culture in museums, sights at the United Nations and views of New York from the Empire State Building.

LONDON, March 24--The Labor Government's pragmatic brand of limited socialism will soon be put to a new test: Can government ownership of a large part of the steel industry be as profitable as private ownership?

PARIS--American soldiers are quitting France this month but American lettuce, frozen T-bone steaks at $1.25 a pound and cleansing solution for contact lenses will still be on sale for their wives and children.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)--A hearing examiner for the Federal Trade Commission reported today that a Chicago mail-order house, Spiegel, Inc., had made fictitious pricing and savings claims for some of its merchandise.
The 79-year-old Israeli winner of the 1966 Nobel Prize for Literature, S.Y. Agnon, will make his first visit to the United States in May, it was announced here yesterday.
MONTREAL, March 23-- Box-office specialists from New York and Toronto are being pressed into Easter weekend service to clear up a backlog of orders for the Montreal World Festival.
WASHINGTON, March 24, (UPI)--Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy gave birth early today to the couple's seventh son and 10th child.

The Navy E-2A Hawkeye, an electronics-laden aircraft once believed to be too complex fore steady and reliable use in combat, is reported to be compiling such an impressive record in Vietnam that a more advanced model is now on the drawing boards.

KENT, Ohio, March 24, (UPI)--Two defending champions, Mike Caruso of Lehigh and Rich Sanders of Portland State, moved to within a victory of retaining their titles by winning semi-final matches tonight in the 37th National Collegiate wrestling championships.

WASHINGTON, March 24-- President Johnson announced today a long-range study of the nation's foreign trade policy. This all but ruled out any major legislation this year to replace the expiring Trade Expansion Act.
A small, narrow, pink stucco house with a tiny courtyard in Parma will become a national shrine today, the 100th anniversary of Arturo Toscanini's birth.

NORFOLK, Va., March 24 (UPI)--A shipbuilders' union ratified a new pact with the Norfolk Shipbuilding and Drydock Company today, ending an eight-day work stoppage that had held up repairs on six naval vessels.
Steel cables have been wrapped tightly around a 75year-old building in Manhattan to help ward off possible danger of collapse when blasting begins in an adjoining excavation.

The chisel and pneumatic hammer, normally associated with the digging up of city streets, replaced the spade and the hoe as gardeners hacked away at frozen ground to prepare it for the city's Easter flowers.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 24 (AP)--The Constituent Assembly today formally presented South Vietnam's new Constitution to the military regime charged with putting it into effect.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)--The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today the application for construction of a new railroad line in Texas, the first such action in years.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)--The House Republican leader, Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, called on President Johnson today to withdraw immediately his request for an income tax increase.

Two state legislative leaders charged yesterday that the emotional problems of thousands of New York City children, especially in ghetto areas, were being "misdiagnosed as mentally retarded or simply ignored" by the Board of Education.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 24 --Dr. J.E. Wallace Sterling, president of Stanford University since 1949, announced today his prospective retirement to become lifetime chancellor.
A 26-year-old plainclothes man on vice-squad duty in a West side tavern, shot and killed a woman yesterday who allegedly attacked him with a knife and a derringer that turned out to be a toy pistol.
LONDON, March 24 (AP)-- Chelsea lost to Blackpool, 2-0, today and missed an opportunity of keeping up with the First Division leaders in the English Soccer League.
The spot and forward rates on the British pound were unchanged in extremely quiet trading yesterday on foreignexchange markets here.

Sierra Leone had a chance to be the first new nation in its part of the world to transfer government power constitutionally and peacefully after an election. Instead it has only the dubious distinction of being the tenth African country taken over by military coup in two years.

HANOI, North Vietnam, March 24 (Agence France-Presse)-- North Vietnam's official daily newspaper, Nhan Dan, said today that the decision to base American B-52 bombers in Thailand was part of a plan to extend the Vietnam war toward Cambodia.
SAN ANGELO, Tex., March 24 (AP)--Hugh Lamar Stone, former executive vice president and general counsel of the Gulf Oil Corporation, died here last night at the age of 82.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24--In a move calculated to stiffen their defense and provide what Manager Wes Westrum described as "greater maneuverability," the Mets today obtained Santos (Sandy) Alomar from the Astros.

ROME, March 24--The Italian Government may soon end the ban on distribution of birth control information and material that is held to be a major cause of about a million illegal abortions here annually.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., March 24--Mrs. Clara Foster Treat, widow of Edwin M. Treat, a former vice president of the National Surety Corporation, died at her home here yesterday at the age of 95.
MIAMI, March 24 (AP)-- Three Pittsburgh pitchers held Baltimore to two hits tonight as the Pirates defeated the Orioles, 1-0, in an exhibition baseball game.

MANHASSET, L. I., March 24--Dr. William C. Meagher, former clinical professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the State University of New York, died last night at the Huntington, L. I., Hospital. He was 71 years old.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 24-- Violence in Mexico's Sonora State over the Governorship nomination there was reported to have eased today.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 24 --Wide concern in official circles and in the public about possible infiltration by gangsters into the gambling casinos here has led to demands for tighter supervision.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, March 24 (AP) --Juan Marichal, still a holdout from the San Francisco Giants, said today he would fly to the United States tomorrow and report to the Giants' training camp at Phoenix, Ariz.

The placing of orders last year for 13 modern tramp ships in a program designed eventually to replace the 800-vessel fleet of war-built Liberty Ships still afloat has been called an encouraging development by the American Bureau of Shipping.

WHITE PLAINS, March 25 The engagement of Miss Jane Andrea Gevertz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Gevertz, to Harris Joel Maslansky, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Maslansky, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

KITWE, Zambia, March 25 In the Braaivleis bar in the center of Kitwe last night a white copper miner with a Yorkshire accent and a bit too much beer inside him tried with a few crude insults to provoke a black man sitting at the opposite end of the bar.

FALLS VILLAGE, Conn., March 25 Mr. and Mrs. Albert Bennett Moore of Falls Village and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Elizabeth Moore, to David Craig Meade. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Craig Meade of Levittown, Pa.

Damascus found the road to victory for the fifth straight time in his career as he scampered to a 2 -length success over Disciplinarian in the $28,600 Bay Shore at Aqueduct yesterday. WASHINGTON, March 25 The Defense Department is withholding a new Senate report that charges that ammunition shortages have forced field commanders in Vietnam on some occasions to change the planning or execution of their military operations, Congressional sources said today.

Laws governing mergers among railroads, truckers, forwarders and other carriers were described last week as "unfair, discriminatory, confusing and absurd," by G. Russell Moir, chairman and chief executive of the United States Freight Company.

PARIS, March 25 The French authorities have invoked a statement by Secretary of State Dean Rusk as a major reason for their decision to boycott next month's ministerial meeting of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.

The dominant fact about the business outlook as the end of the first quarter nears is that no one is completely sure whether the economy is about to slip into its fifth postwar recession.

But some of them, under the guidance of the local antipoverty agency, have been making a movie about how it is to be a boy and live in a ghetto.

Boots, red hunting cap, big furry windbreaker, and soft, silvery hair falling boyishly over his forehead.

A LARGE question is being asked in a small gallery this week. At the cozy Museum of Contemporary Crafts, 29 West 53 Street, is a tiny, tidy selection of models, photographs and sculpture called "Monuments, Tombstones and Trophies," scheduled to run through May 14. Set neatly among primly potted chrysanthemums, it deals with a huge, unsettling theme: the validity of memorial construction for our time.

When McGeorge Bundy left his White House post as Presidential adviser last year to become president of the Ford Foundation, it was generally assumed that his assertive personality would have a strong impact on the image and actions of the nation's largest foundation. An early Easter doesn't mean an early spring any more than a late Easter means a late spring. Spring is a matter dictated by the sun, and Easter's dates are dictated by the moon, whose phases are unrelated to the seasons. PRINCETON, N.J., March 25 Mrs. Wright Almgren has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Linda Joyce Almgren, to Milford Burton Kime, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Milford Kime of Glen Ridge, N.J.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 25 Enemy troops ambushed and shattered a South Vietnamese Army convoy of 121 heavy trucks last night.

SPRING? Winter is not giving up this year without a fight. Who can forget that a week ago this morning, thermometers were showing numbers like 8 and 10. Then, midweek, on the second day of spring, a junior-sized blizzard delivered about eight inches of snow.

PARIS, March 25 The Army band played "Auld Lang Syne." The Stars and Stripes came down. The base a U.S. military establishment for the past 12 or 15 or 20 years was turned over to a representative of the French Government. An elderly French woman, a sweet young fille, and even a few men wept. The Yanks, as they had been told to do many times in many lands, were leaving.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 25 Miss Leslie Curtis Heinkel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Boulton Heinkel of Short Hills, N.J., was married here this afternoon to Ens. Peter Grantham Engler, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Geoffrey Engler of short Hills and Hague, N.Y.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 25--At its best, traffic in this sprawling capital city is bad. Lately it has become even worse, but the authorities say this is part of a plan that they hope will soon make conditions at least tolerable.

A little-known group of experts the Committee of International Port Development, a part of the International Association of Ports and Harbors is doing valuable work to help in the expansion of world trade by seeking to further develop ports and harbors.

PITTSBURGH, March 25 Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Parshall of Pittsburgh and Hyannis Port, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Worthington Parshall, to Robert Wayne Stewart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Claude H. Stewart of Wilmington, Del.
With new Coast Guard regulations set to take effect June 1, an increasingly popular program for boat owners these days is the ventilation seminar.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 25 (AP) A three-run homer by Jim Wynn and an inside-the-park home run by Chuck Harris today helped the Houston Astros gain 6-5 victory over the Washington Senators in an exhibition baseball game.

ALBANY, Calif., March 25 (UPI) Pagan Gem moved smartly between horses in the stretch run to win the Eastbay Handicap at Golden Gate Fields today and become a strong candidate for the $95,000 California Derby April 22.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 25 Dame Pattie, a new contender for the right to represent Australia in September's America's Cup, outsailed Gretel today in the first of a new series of selection trial races off Sydney Head.

Max Elbin, president of the Professional Golfers Association, has been named winner of the William D. Richardson award. This is an honor voted annually by the Golf Writers Association of America to an individual who has made an "outstanding contribution" to golf. It is named for the late sports writer of The New York Times.

The 13th anniversary Symphony Ball, sponsored by the board of directors and the women's committee of the Brooklyn Philharmonic, will be held on April 8 in the Promenade at the New York State Theater. It will follow a concert in Philharmonic Hall by the orchestra under the baton of Siegfried Landau, with Malcolm Frager as guest piano soloist.

ROCHESTER, March 25 Miss Holly Eugenia Hungerford Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Fergus Smith of Woodstock, Vt., and Pompano Beach, Fla., was married this afternoon to Henry Mowat Clarendon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarendon of Darien, Conn.

TUCSON, Ariz. The only urban renewed project in Arizona is well under way here. It involves 80 blighted acres in the downtown area where city services were costing about $250,000 more annually than tax revenues were producing.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI) A Republican group said today that Senator Robert F. Kennedy's "long-range Presidential plans will not be helped by his running on a platform of 'I can do more for the good of Hanoi.'"
ATLANTA, March 25 Public utilities are accounting for an increasing bulk of the annual volume of securities filings and sales by corporations with headquarters in the Sixth Federal Reserve District.
BIAMI BEACH, March 25 (AP) Bob Mangus of Largo, Fla., rolled a 674 series today and took sixth place in the regular singles section of the American Bowling Congress tournament.

WASHINGTON Because of a change in State Department travel restrictions, American tourists are now free to visit Albania, one of the five Communist nations that have been generally off limits to United States citizens.

"We could build the towers with paper if we had all the study drawings, all the plans and all the working drawings that have gone into this thing," said Joseph Solomon, standing over a sheaf of architectural studies, opened on a conference table.

MIAMI, Fla., March 25 (AP)--A wall-like breakwater nearly a mile long and containing rocks "bigger than a car" has been uncovered under the Mediterranean Sea at one of the ancient harbors of North Africa, an English archeologist said yesterday.

Engineering studies of the fire that destroyed a major portion of the McCormick Place exhibition center in Chicago last January suggest that fire-protection requirements for such structures should be changed.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., March 25 The price of 15 processed radioisotopes will go up April 21, including doubling the prices of 13. The isotopes development center at Oak Ridge National Laboratory said the prices were being increased by the Atomic Energy Commission to recover the full costs of production and distribution.
LOS ANGELES, March 25 (AP) Epileptic seizures apparently induced by the drug LSD were so violent for one man, psychiatrists report, that he fractured two vertebrae while under the drug's spell.
WASHINGTON, March 25 Police informers have been a law enforcement mainstay for centuries, but the law perhaps out of distaste has until recently kept them in constitutional limbo.
TASHKENT, U.S.S.R., March 25 Residents of this central Asian city, accustomed to hundreds of tremors in the last 11 months, took another severe earthquake in stride yesterday.

IN one of its most potent aspects, poetry is the art of observation. The senses are mined deliberately to yield the ore of feeling. This kind of writing is the opposite of self expression, for the focus falls sharply upon the objective world. The personal insight and the universal image are the sparks struck from a bare confrontation.
ROANOKE, Va., March 25 (AP) Dr. H. Sherman Oberly, retired president of Roanoke College, died yesterday in a Richmond hospital. He was 68 years old.

LAS VEGAS, Nev. Unlike fabled Xanadu, where Khublai Khan decreed a single, stately pleasure palace and garnered poetic fame thereby, this strangest of desert cities now has more than two dozen temples devoted to plush living and free spending.
MOSCOW, March 25 (UPI) A Soviet scientist said today that the Russians had succeeded in producing the "strongest substance" ever made on earth.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI) The Justice Department said today that Federal voting examiners would be appointed in nine counties in Georgia, Louisiana and Mississippi.
A mild Easter, but a partly cloudy one, with the temperatures rising into the middle 50's was predicted yesterday by the Weather Bureau for snow-weary New Yorkers.
JACKSON TOWNSHIP, N.J., March 25 Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation dug through a field all day today before calling off their search for more victims of gangland slayings.

DJIBOUTI, French Somaliland, March 25 This week's bloodshed and turmoil have left Djibouti's economy dangerously enfeebled, with half its bank deposits withdrawn by anxious depositors, the future of its port in doubt and hopes for outside investment even slimmer than before.

WASHINGTON, March 25 The position of front runner in the race for a party's Presidential nomination can be a perilous one, but the traditional patterns of conduct for such a leader are fairly well established and easy to follow even if not always with success.

WILMINGTON, N.C., March 25 The marriage of Miss Rosslyn Troth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Ross Troth of Wilmington, to Phillip Gregg Zook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Elbert Zook of Scarsdale, N.Y., took place this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church of Wilmington.
Greater Boston came the nearest to getting its stadium this week that in has in three years of controversy.

The third annual John F. Kennedy memorial regatta will be held at the United States Naval Academy on Saturday and Sunday, April 8 and 9. The event is sponsored by the Naval Academy on Saturday and the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association of North America.

MANHASSET, L.I., March 25 Mr. and Mrs. Walter Burton Fisk Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Gove Fisk, to Robert Fisher Gibson 3d. He is the son of the Right Rev. Robert Fisher Gibson Jr., Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Virginia, and Mrs. Gibson of Richmond.

MUSKOGEE, Okla., March 25 (AP) Two accidents some 20 miles apart on highways in eastern Oklahoma claimed nine lives in a span of about four hours today.

A champagne reception and preview of the Catharine Lorillard Wolfe Art Club's 70th annual exhibition at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South, next Sunday afternoon will benefit a fund for travel and research in this country by staff members of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Mrs. Arthur Howe is chairman for the exhibition, which will be on public view April 3 through April 16.

ANNA Sokolow looks at the world with cool eyes. She is honest, yet compassionate. She no more draws conclusions than she pulls punches among all our choreographers Miss Sok- olow is our sad mistress of the documentary. If Truman Capote could ever envisage a nonfiction, ballet, Sokolow would have to choreograph it. With a terrifying, at times simply painful, literalness, Sokolow is concerned with truth.

The second phase of a $4-million program to modernize the Grand Concourse in the Bronx will begin soon between 172d and 182d Streets, Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff, Commissioner of Highways, said last week. He announced a low bid of $1,158,046 for the 1.6-mile improvement by the Columbia Asphalt Corporation of Flushing, Queens.
