CHICAGO, March 25 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. led 5,000 peace demonstrators today in a 12-oclock march through throngs of Easter shoppers, then told all who could crowd into the Coliseum that the Vietnam war was "a blasphemy against all that America stands for."

The State Investigation Commission again urged Congress yesterday to enact a law to permit court-ordered wiretapping for law enforcement purposes. Easter retail business across the nation wound up last week with a moderate gain above the 1966 level.

ONE of the most beautiful landstapes that architect Paul. Rudolph says he has ever seen lies along the Potomac River in Stafford County, Virginia. The Iand climbs and dips, in one place subtly and in another ostentatiously; it is clustered with some of the tallest trees found in the eastern United States. In this environment Rudolph will build his town.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 25 (UPI) Manuel Santana of Spain, benefiting from a 10-minute break after the third set, rallied to beat Jan Leschly of Denmark, 2-6, 6-2, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, in the men's final of the South African international tennis tournament today.

The Canadian rugby fraternity made its annual Easter pilgrimage to New York yesterday and found the city unhospitable. The visitors lost all four matches.

LOS ANGELES, March 25 (AP) Jim Ryun of Kansas toyed with the opposition today in winning the mile in 4 minutes 5.1 seconds and the 880 in 1:48.1. MIDDLETOWN, N.J., March 25 Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Huston, Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Mary Huston, to Lieut. Paul F. Schultz Jr., U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Schultz of Foley, Ala.

NEW JERSEY'S first state-wide Flower and Garden Show will be staged April 8-12 at the West Orange Armory. Exhibitors and nurserymen have planned 80 educational and informational displays and exhibits, as well as the two standard flower shows presented by the Garden Club of New Jersey. Show theme is "Keep the Garden State in Bloom." It will be open daily from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. Admission is $1.50 for adults, 75 cents for children.

MONTREAL, March 25 (AP) The Montreal Canadiens stretched their unbeaten string to seven games with a 4-1 National Hockey League victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 25. American children have always had measles. It has been an almost invariable accompaniment of childhood. But now the disease may be virtually ended this year, at least in the United States.

THE Virgin Islands has been thrown into an uproar by the announce ment that Caribair, the major local airline, has been allowed to increase its fares from San Juan, P.R., to St. Thomas and St., Croix by 75 cents each way. The roundtrip fares are now $20 for St. Thomas and $26.50 for St. Croix.

WASHINGTON, March 25 The marriage of Miss Sally Hill Hooker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gay Hooker, to Roger Richardson Sullivan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene R. Sullivan of Milton, Mass., took place this afternoon.

Michael Burke, chairman of the board and president of the New York Yankees, will be honored at the Sports World dinner dance for the benefit of the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, at the Waldorf-Astoria Friday, April 14.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 25 Miss Ellen Lenore O'Donnell, daughter of Patrick J. O'Donnell and the late Mrs. O'Donnell, plans to be married in May to John Kenneth Moynahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Moynahan of Garden City, L.I. The father of the bride-to-be has announced the engagement.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25--There was a ringing note of scorn in Mike Shannon's voice when his teammates dragged themselves back into the football huddle. They had been taking a physical beating throughout the first half and were behind, 6-0. Then strong-armed Mike threw a spectacular 50-yard touchdown pass--only to have it disallowed by a holding penalty. Mike took one look at those dejected faces and called a time out.

Evidence that a third victim of gangland slayings was buried in what may be a secret Mafia graveyard in New Jersey has been dug up by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, sources close to the case disclosed yesterday.
VENICE, Fla., March 25 (UPI) Kathy Whitworth went around the Venice Country Club in 71 today and took a commanding four-stroke lead in the $10,000 Venice Open tournament with 141.

Progress in clearing up minor differences between five New York dailies and the newspaper unions was reported last night, and the chief mediator in the negotiations said he hoped to move on to major issues today.

SENLIS, France The flags go down at SHAPE headquarters outside Paris this week, marking not only the disappearance of U.S. forces and allied installations from France but the end of a historic era. The piece of Rocquencourt where General Eisenhower first installed SHAPE sixteen years ago was once a farming area locally known as the trou d'enfer. Now it returns to civilian life. One may hope it will never again be called a hellhole.

One way to minimize this problem is to keep the inside of the chute lubricated by spraying regularily with a silicone spray. This type of lubricant is widely sold in paint and hardware stores for lubrication of windows, doors and similiar surfaces where a non-greasy, long-lasting lubricant is desired.

A RATHER deflating incident happened the other day. While on my way to purchase a potted plant, I stopped momentarily in front of the florist's to sit on a rock set in a softly lighted garden of lush plant material. The sounds of tropical birds filled the air; a small pool sparkled in the sun. Suddenly, I found myself falling backward into the greenery. My "rock" had collapsed. It was made of rubber.

The New York City Opera ended its 1967 winter season at the New York State Theater yesterday with performances of Puccini's "Il Trittico" in the afternoon and Verdi's "La Traviata" at night.
The fourth annual outdoor New York Flea Market will open on April 16 with a collection of attic wares that range from beaded bags to underwear mannequins.

BERLIN, March 28--Youthful German demonstrators protesting the war in Vietnam today defaced Amerika Haus, the United States cultural institute in West Berlin, by hurling plastic bags filled with red paint against the building's glass facade.
Bernice Fitz-Gibbon, the Wisconsin farm girl who found happiness and fame in the big city, has just been elevated to the Copywriters Hall of Fame.
Combined tax collections by Federal, state and local governments for fiscal 1967 will cross the $200-billion mark for the first time, according to Tax Foundation, Inc.
The chancellor of Long Island University has decided to replace Dr. William M. Birenbaum, the vice president and provost of the college's Brooklyn Center.
Four young boys, three of them brothers, set out Saturday afternoon for adventure on Lower New York Bay on two wooden rafts.
The Senate Commerce subcommittee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries has rescheduled full-scale hearings on merchant marine needs and Federal Shipping policy proposals.
VIENNA, March 26 (AP) A bruised and weary United States hockey team scored a 2-0 victory over Finland today in the 1967 world championships and assured itself of a spot in the 1968 Winter Olympics.
Andrew Heiskell, chairman of the board of directors of Time, Inc., has been named 1967 chairman of the Greater. New York Committee of the United Negro College Fund.

WASHINGTON, March 26 Kermit Gordon, the former Director of the Bureau of the Budget, was named today as president of the Brookings Institution, succeeding Robert D. Calkins, who has headed the independent research and educational organization for 15 years.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., March 26--Miss Caroline Elizabeth L. Schaefer was married this afternoon to Howard S. Cooper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Ely Cooper of Jersey City. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Abraham H. Schaefer of Hartford and the late Dr. Schaefer.

CAIRO, March 26 (UPI) Foreign Minister Mahmoud Riad told United Nations fact finders today that the only solution to the explosive Aden problem who for Britain to negotiate directly with an Arab nationalist organization backed by Cairo.
Victor Brown, founder and former president of the women's underwear concern of his name, died yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla., where he lived. He was 70 years old and also had a home here.
"Cabaret" was voted the best musical of the 1966-67 Broadway season and "The Homecoming" the best dramatic play at last night's Tony Awards ceremonies in the Shubert Theater.
The Carnation Company, the $380-million canner of evaporated milk and producer of other dairy and food items, achieved record sales and earnings in 1966, it reported over the weekend.

DANANG, South Vietnam, March 25 While artillery duels and sweeps by Marine battalions near the demilitarized zone attract the most attention, the planners for the Third Marine Amphibious Force here are also worrying about the "other war."

ACAPULCO, Mexico, March 26 (UPI) Mrs. Jacqueline Kennedy, her daughter, Caroline, and a niece were dumped into the Pacific Ocean today. Their sailboat was tipped over by waves churned up by a speedboat manned by Mexican security guards who were chasing away two boatloads of photographers.
HONG KONG, March 26 (UPI) Peter Thomson of Australia won the Hong Kong open golf championship today by defeating Brian Huggett of Britain on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff.

The Cerro Corporation and Pickands Mather Co. jointly announced over the weekend a proposal for the consolidation of the businesses and resources of the two companies as a "basis for seeking and developing new opportunities in the ...

Goals and Ed Giacomin, the combination that lifted the New York Rangers into first place in the National Hockey League at midseason, rekindled their hopes for a second-place finish last night at Madison Square Garden.

NASHVILLE, March 26 (AP) Armed with a court order against two labor unions that joined the farmers' milk boycott, at least two major processors planned today to resume normal milk deliveries tomorrow.
FOR the first time, a computer has played chess against humans under regular tournament conditions time-limit, touch-move and so on. It did poorly, but wasn't completely shut out.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation learned yesterday that one of two bodies dug up in what may be a secret Mafia graveyard in New Jersey was not that of the man they had thought it was.

TAMPA, Fla., March 26 The memory of the trip is still sharp in the mind of Dave Bristol of the Reds, at 33 years old the youngest manager in the big leagues. It is etched so deeply that it nearly solidifies his iron determination not to return to it or anything like it.
CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) A few hard pressed dairy processors began yielding today to pressure of the National Farmers Organization's milk withholding in Minnesota.

A champagne reception on the stage of the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center will open festivities the evening of April 17 for the fourth annual benefit of the New York City Ballet Fund. A dinner party in the theater's grand promenade will close the event.

A slowdown in the frenzied race to put a man on the moon seems to be taking place. No Soviet astronaut has gone into space for more than two years, while no Americans are to be sent into orbit until early next year, or even later.
The New York Community Trust has elected Herbert B. West as director. The election was announced yesterday by Ralph Hayes, the director of the organization since its opening in 1923.
Breakfast in London, lunch in New York and baggage in San Francisco that is the way some people have summed up the wonders and frustrations of air travel.
At Lincoln Center today: George Bela Kehler, pianist, Library-Museum, 6:30 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 7:30; "La Gioconda," Metropolitan Opera, 8.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Monday, March 27 (Reuters) The Danish newspaper B.T. described today an underwater confrontation in which Soviet divers were reported to have captured Danish frogmen during a visit here by a Soviet cruiser in 1964.

The enactment of a bill now before the House of Representatives that would make it illegal for American companies to cooperate with the Arab boycott of Israel was called for yesterday by the American Jewish Congress.

THE City Center Joffrey Ballet closed its third season at the New York City Center last night with a superb and authoritative performance of Kurt Jooss's "The Green Table," which became something of a family affair.

Many factors were conspiring against an effective performance by Mahalia Jackson, the gospel singer, at Philharmonic Hall yesterday afternoon. But the great singer, who has been a stranger hereabouts for two years, again proved why she is such a highly regarded artist.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) The billion-dollar electronics computer industry, already the target of an investigation by the Justice Department's Antitrust Division, is coming under the scrutiny of the House antitrust subcommittee.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., March 26 William S. Borland Jr., who retired last year after 35 years as an advertising salesman for Harper's Bazaar magazine, died of cancer today in his home at 920 Pelhamdale Avenue. He was 65 Years old.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 26 Collegiate basketball is clearly split into two divisions:
PITTSBURGH, March 26 Steel makers watched anxiously last week for some sign that economic stimulants were beginning to take effect in their markets.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 26 (UPI) Bert Shankland and Chris Rothwell of Tanzania, took the lead in the East African Safari motor rally when the pace-setting Swedish pair of Bengt Soderstrom and Gunnar Palm crashed into a bridge early today.
EAST LANSING, Mich., March 26 The world's newest swimming sensation is a shy, 21-year-old Californian who, until now, has been hidden in the shadows of more celebrated teammates.
PARIS, March 26 The 25year-old American de signer Mia Fonssagrives, who lives in Paris, was married yesterday to the French couturier, Louis Feraud.

There is more than a routine political spark in the regeneration of the once familiar fight between private and public electric, power in New York State, now explosively set off by Governor Rockefeller and Senator Robert Kennedy.

MIAMI, March 26 For the last three months Cuba has been conducting an extensive "political, economic and sociological survey" of Latin America. The scope and intelligence connotations of it, according to experienced United States observers, could lead to the establishment of Havana as a Communist intelligence center for Latin America.
Gorilla Monsoon, a 385-pound wrestler from Manchuria, will try to gain his second consecutive victory over Bruno Sammartino of Abruzzi, Italy, tonight at Madison Square Garden.

ROCKVILLE, Md., March 26 Tom Osler of the South Jersey Track Club, a 26-year-old mathematics teacher at St. Joseph's College, won the Amateur Athletic Union national senior 30,000-meter running championship today. He scored by 800 yards over Lou Castagnola of the Washington (D.C.) Sports Club.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) A new financing system for rural electric cooperatives is necessary to assure a stable source of loan funds for cooperatives during the next 15 years, Senator Gaylord Nelson, Democrat of Wisconsin, said over the weekend.

THE weather, as though repenting its recent per versities, beamed on the women who made the Easter charity lunch circuit in midtown Manhattan yesterday. It didn't beam broadly enough for most of them to give up fur coats, but at least it didn't blow their hats off.

LONDON, Monday, March 27 (AP)Abolition of the private educational system, which includes such famed training grounds for British statesmen as Eton, Harrow and Winchester, was called for today by the general council of the Trades Union Congress.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., March 26 (UPI) The University of Southern California led by the record-smashing pole vaulter Bob Seagren and Earl McCulloch, a sprinter, dominated the Santa Barbara Easter Relays yesterday.
Joseph Jacobs, president and founder of a merchandising and advertising concern at 342 Madison Avenue that bears his name, died in Sarasota, Fla., yesterday, while on vacation. He was 75 years old.

The Red Cross is many things to many people. One definition might be that it is a resource in emergency--the first aid knowledge when seconds count, the blood for rush surgery, the volunteer companionship... a resource in emergency--the first aid knowledge when seconds count, the blood for rush surgery, the volunteer companionship ...
A shortage of low-cost electricity has forced several mayor companies to cancel plans for expansion in the state and move elsewhere, the New York State Power Authority said yesterday.
Like other great religious festivals, Easter expresses the great contrasts and ambiguities of human experience.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 26 (AP) Collegians had their final, fling on the beach today, but some 200 of their fellow students who had been arrested during a vacation marked by clashes with the police spent Easter Sunday in jail.

GOOD satire of television is seemingly impossible to come by on television, and yesterday afternoon's "We Interrupt This Season" made the point again. A company of attractive young people tried very earnestly to apply ...
The marriage of Miss Natalie Agnes Sheridan to Michael Edgar Ford took place yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Family.

With T-Day only three weeks away, the Internal Revenue Service reports it is seeing fewer old friends so far. In fact, 1966 tax returns are said to be running several hundred thousand behind the pace of past years.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, March 26 (AP) Luis Ruiz Trujillo, nephew of the late dictator, was held by the police today in the investigation of the attempted murder of Gen. Antonio Imbert Barrera.

PEKING, March 25 (Agence France-Presse) The Red Guard publication Tung Fang Hung (The East Is Red) reported today that "Revolutionary rebels, in accord with the spirit of the Cultural Revolution," had recently completed the production of their first motion picture.
MOSCOW, March 26 (AP) The Communist party warned the Indonesian leaders today that their anti-Communism could harm relations with Moscow and possibly the chances of economic aid.
NEW ORLEANS, March 26 (AP)--Renato Cellini, conductor and general director of the New Orleans Opera House Association, died in his home yesterday. His age was 54.
WASHINGTON, March 26 The Job Corps, beset for two years by friction between some of its training centers and the people next door, started a "Salute the Communities Week" today.
BOSTON, March 26 They all laughed when Coach Dick McGuire declared his New York Knickerbockers would finally beat the Boston Celtics tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 26--Gov. Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey was assigned today the sensitive political task of drafting a plan to insure fair Negro representation at the Democratic National Convention in 1968.

The head of the Uniformed Firemen's Association served notice yesterday that beginning Thursday or Friday firemen would refuse to perform any duties other than responding to fires and to emergencies such as gas leaks.

Some high-ranking officials within the Federal Reserve System believe that economic expansion will resume in the United States before the end of 1967, a well-informed New York banker said over the weekend.

Manhattan south of Central Park will gain 300,000 to 700,000 more office jobs in the next 33 years, an increase of 37 to 87 per cent. But this will require better transportation, cleaner air, noise controls and pleasantness of environment.
CHARLESTON, S.C., March 26 Miss Jennie Levkoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Levkoff, was married this evening to Richard Kaltman DeScherer, son of Mr. and Bernard DeScherer of Englewood, N.J.

New in bookstores is "American Antique Furniture," a profusely illustrated, two-volume paperback work intended for readers who have not made a serious study of American antiques, but who would like to be able to recognize principal periods and styles. Originally written by Edgard G. Miller, Jr., in 1937, the work is a guide to the periods prior to 1840.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, March 26 Grand Master Bent Larsen of Denmark took the lead in the second round of the 1967 Grand Prix International Chess Tournament by defeating Guy Mazzoni of France at Monaco last night. Larsen thus became the first of the 11-man field to post an outright win, for a score of 1 out of 2 points.

WASHINGTON, March 26 Vice President Humphrey left today on a diplomatic mission for President Johnson in which he will seek to mend relations between the United States and its Western European allies.
New Yorkers and visitors celebrated Easter yesterday with a Fifth Avenue parade notable for its lack of frilly bonnets and at joyous church services that combined the traditional and the offbeat.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 26 Many Latin-American union leaders are disturbed at the apparent absence of labor matters from the agenda for next month's conference of American Presidents.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 27 United States pilots shot down their 38th MIG jet over North Vietnam yesterday in fighting off defenders during a raid on the Sontay army supply area 23 miles west of Hanoi.

The largest free electorate in the world proved last month that it still put its faith in democracy. While the disaster to the Congress party, which has ruled all of India for twenty years, may have had a temporarily destabilizing effect, it also showed that despite poverty, illiteracy and inexperience, the Indian voter is willing to take to the ballot box instead of the streets to express his freedom of choice.
The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, which last year spent an estimated $14-million for advertising, is parting company with Tatham-Laird Kudner, according to a reliable source.
WASHINGTON, March 26 Mr. and Mrs. C. Tracy Barnes have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Barnes, to John Michael Dudley Casey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Casey.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 26 (UPI) Jim Kaat, the American League's leading pitcher last year with 25 victories, gave up five hits in seven innings today as the Minnesota Twins beat the Boston Red Sox, 7-1.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 26 (AP) Dame Pattie, handled in a masterly fashion by her skipper, Jock Sturrock, scored her second victory in two days over the Gretel in the America's Cup trials off Sydney Head today.
The value of construction contracts signed in February increased 13 per cent from the January level, according to a national survey.
KINGSTON, R.I., March 23--The University of Rhode Island, a relative latecomer in the field of oceanography, is making a strong bid to become the first sea-grant university in the nation.

BALTIMORE, March 26 Mayor Theodore R. McKeldin has moved to prevent the eviction of a downtown bookshop specializing in left-wing and civil rights literature. The shop has been the recent target of repeated harassment and acts of vandalism.

BOSTON, March 26 (AP) Senator Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, said President Johnson told him today that he had performed "a great service to the country and to the American people" in presenting his views on the Vietnam war.
Financial support to 50 leading colleges and universities declined last year, it was reported yesterday, but the drop was not considered indicative of a significant reduction in contributions.
PENZANCE, England, March 27--Oil gushed tonight from the broken hull of the tanker Torrey Canyon, and Government officials conceded that they could not prevent massive pollution of Britain's coasts.

WHEN I went to Washington as Ambassa dor," India's Foreign Minister once recalled, "the first question I was asked was, 'Are you a Moslem?' I said, 'I don't ask whether you're a Catholic, Protestant or Jew.

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, March 27 While slavery is a dying institution in Saudi Arabia, it is by no means dead. In Muscat and Oman, the Trucial States, Yemen, and parts of the Federation of South Arabia, it is still very much alive.
WASHINGTON, March 27 The Supreme Court refused today to hear a challenge to a New York law that makes it illegal for a man to masquerade as a woman in public.
Assemblyman Bertram L. Podell called yesterday for an immediate review of the cases of 7-to-12-year-old children who he said did not belong in the "prison-like" Youth House in the Bronx.

Dr. Heyrovsky described his polarograph on a visit here in 1933 under the auspices of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. It registers on paper in four or five minutes the kind and amount of chemical substances present in liquids for solids.
CHESHIRE, Conn., March 27 Senator Thomas J. Dodd has returned, uncashed, a money order for $70 sent to him as a gesture of reproach for complaining about the cost of taking a war hero to lunch.
Stock prices drifted down yesterday in moderate trading on the American Stock Exchange.
The Feather Ball, the major fund-raising event for Just One Break, will be given Way 2 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom. Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller, wife of the Governor, is honorary chairman.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) The Defense Department identified today 101 United States servicemen killed in action in the Vietnam war. The list includes the names of men who died of wounds. Those from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut follow:

The prime, or minimum, interest rate on business loans dropped to 5 per cent yesterday at practically all of the nation's major banks exactly two months after the Chase Manhattan Bank first reduced its prime rate to that level.

The Allied Stores Corporation which operates 114 retail units in 27 states, including Stern Brothers and Gertz in the New York and New Jersey metropolitan areas had the highest annual and quarterly results in its 38-year history in the periods ended Jan. 31.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI) Governments at all levels will collect a record $203-billion in taxes from the American people during the current fiscal year of 1967, the Tax Foundation estimated today.
NASSAU, Bahamas, March 27 Holy Cross captured the annual Nassau rugby tournament today by defeating Dartmouth 8-6, in the final.
VIENNA, March 27 (AP)--The Soviet Union won its fifth straight world hockey title today by defeating Canada, 2-1. Vyacheslav Starshinov scored the decisive goal midway through the final period.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 28 (AP)--A life sentence imposed on Pfc. Charles W. Keenan of Nitro, W. Va., for having killed two Vietnamese civilians has been reduced to 25 years at hard labor.

JERUSALEM, Jordan, March 27 (AP) Jordan has accused two bishops and a layman of the theft in 1959 of 28 historic Biblical manuscripts from the Armenian Catholic cathedral here, but the district attorney has suspended prosecution under a two-Year amnesty decree.

LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga., March 27 (AP) Scientists working with mice, guinea pigs and other animals report having obtained promising results in their search for better and safer vaccines to treat rabies in human beings.

FLAMINGO, Fla., March 27 Visitors to the Ever glades National Park here are entranced by the varied and beautiful displays of birdlife. Some of the birds have been holding the attention of this fan in recent days.

Agreed to review three cases concerning the proper standard that should be used by the Tennessee Valley Authority in determining the area within which it can legally sell power (No. 962, Hardin V. Kentucky Utilities Co.; No. 1056, Powell Valley Electric Cooperative v. Kentucky Utilities Co.; No. 1063, Tennessee Valley Authority v. Kentucky Utilities Co.).
BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., March 27 Chester J. Gerkin, a retired lawyer, died Saturday in the Foothill Acres Nursing Home in Neshanic. He was 83 years old and lived on Claremont Road here.
PRAGUE, Tuesday, March 28 (Reuters) Prof. Jaroslav Heyrovsky, a Nobel Prize winner in chemistry, died here yesterday, the Ceteka press agency reported today. He was 76 years, old.
The bond market discounted yesterday the news that more major banks had cut their prime lending rate.
The stock market was pretty much of a scrambled affair yesterday in active dealings. A few more stocks advanced than declined, but the leading market average weakened.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 27 (AP) President Rend Barrientos Ortuno decreed a state of emergency today in the Bolivian southeast and announced they Government's determination to crush a guerrilla movement. He announced that the air force was using napalm in attacks on the guerrillas.

Choppy waters and overcast skies slowed the search yesterday for three Staten Island youngsters, missing since Saturday and believed to have been drowned while on an adventure trip in Lower New York Bay.
Steel production in the week ended Saturday edged down 2/10 of 1 per cent from the level of the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Simon Wiesenthal, who has tracked down 1,000 Nazi war criminals, including Adolf Eichmann, said yesterday that Martin Bormann, Hitler's deputy, was still at large and utilized "a double."

A State Supreme Court justice yesterday blocked any payment of $600,000 in insurance benefits to the widow of a 46year-old lawyer who allegedly embezzled $482,000 from his clients before he committed suicide last August.
A program to promote the employment and advancement of Negroes in New York City retail stores was outlined yesterday by William H. Booth, chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights.
JERUSALEM (Israeli) March 27 (AP) Arab and Israeli radio stations spoke to each other yesterday for what was said to be the first time since Israel was established 19 years ago.
Mario F. Narizzano, a retired food executive, died Sunday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street and in Sands Point, L.I.,

First the first time, Previews, Inc., the international real estate marketing concern, will deal in Manhattan properties. For that purpose it has opened a branch office at 263 West 12th Street, between Fourth and Bleecker Streets in Greenwich Village. Previews' headquarters are at 49 East 53d Street.

TRENTON, March 27 (AP) President Johnson personally chose God. Richard J. Hughes for the task of drafting a plan to insure integrated Southern delegations at the 1968 Democratic Convention, a New Jersey official said today.
The J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation and the Schroder Trust Company announced here yesterday the election of Hermann C. Schwab as senior vice president in charge of the investment department.
Bruno Sammartino of Abruzzi, Italy, and Gorilla Monsoon of Manchuria via St. Louis, threw each other across the ring at Madison Square Garden Last night to no conclusion.
MARAZION BEACH, England, March 27 It was low tide this afternoon, and in a freezing wind dozens of children wandered about the broad stretch of beach at this Cornish village.
