The city has allowed its shores to become shabby with rotting piers, noisy highways and decayed buildings, and at least one idyllic plan for improvement will only worsen the situation, the Park Association of New York City declared yesterday.
Two persons died in a fire early today in a sixth-floor room of the Times Square Hotel at 43d Street and Eighth Avenue.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 27 (UPI) Cassius Clay, the heavyweight champion, won another round today in his fight to postpone his scheduled April 11 induction into the Army. His draft-board director called it a "delaying tactic."

Arthur Ashe, Mrs. Billie Jean King and Chuck McKinley will play on a new type of court, to be used for the first time in the Long Island indoor tennis tournament at C.W. Post College in Brookville Friday evening and Saturday afternoon and evening.
What would happen if the city budget were cut by $100million?

COME September, a woman will be able to step right from the tub into an Emilio Pucci print. The Florentine fashion designer's first collection of bathroom linens, for Springmaid, will be in stores in early fall.
If you are a newlywed, your name and address are worth 1.25 cents. If you are a wealthy widow, they are worth 4 cents.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, March 27 (UP) President Joaquin Balaguer said today that the Government would hire a private investigation agency to aid the police in clearing up a wave of political violence in and around Santo Domingo.

The Lindsay administration has completed engineering plans for a four-lane Lower Manhattan Expressway that would cross the borough in the bustling downtown area partly by tunnel and depressed highway and partly by surface road.
A highly controversial plan to construct another transmountain highway through the Great Smoky Mountains National Park is still under consideration by Secretary of the Interior Stewart Udall.
WASHINGTON, March 27 The Supreme Court delayed today the merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads until the fate of three smaller lines has been decided.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 (UPI) Mrs. Dolly Fritz MacMasters of San Francisco was married yesterday to Newton Cope of Sacramento by Judge Gordon Schaber of the Superior Court.
ALBANY, March 27 Earl Warren, Chief Justice of the United States, today accepted an invitation to address the opening session of the state's Constitutional Convention next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, March 27 Infectious mononucleosis, a disease of young adults thought often to be transmitted by kissing, seems to be on the increase.

NEW DELHI, March 27 (AP) India will sign a treaty forbidding nuclear proliferation only after she is satisfied that her security is guaranteed against "nuclear attack or nuclear blackmail," Foreign Minister M. C. Chagla told Parliament today.

FREEPORT, L.I., March 27 Robert L. Doxsee, '69-year-old former Mayor of Freeport, was killed today when his automobile ran off Meadowbrook Parkway and plunged into the water near the Jones Beach toll booth.
Industrial issues led an advance yesterday on the Toronto Stock Exchange. The industrial index was up 0.95, to a new 1967 high of 163.71, in light trading.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) Jack Molinas, a former college and National Basketball Association star, who was convicted on a game-fixing scandal, was denied a hearing by the Supreme Court, by an 8-1 vote, today on his claim that he was unconstitutionally trapped with a listening device.

MOSCOW, March 27 The Soviet Government will extend its profit-oriented economic reform to many of the country's huge state farms this year to stimulate efficient production, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today.

William V. Schwarting, senior vice president and director of Albert Frank-Guenther Law, Inc., an advertising and public relations agency, died yesterday in Arlington Manor Nursing Home, Oceanside, L.I. He was 75 years old.

The boycott committee of Public School 125 in West Harlem last night accepted an invitation from the Board of Education to meet with it and the Superintendent of Schools to discuss the community's demands for participation in the school's management.
ALBANY, March 27 Goverror Rockefeller and the legislative leaders said tonight that they were still in disagreement on how much additional finan- cial aid New York City needed.
Ann Watkins, a leading literary agent here from 1910 until her retirement 10 years ago, died Sunday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital at the age of 81. She lived in West Redding, Conn.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 27 (AP)--Gov. Ronald Reagan called today for record state spending of $5.08-billion during the coming year--an increase of $440-million over his original budget sent to the Legislature on Jan. 31.
ANCHORAGE, March 27 (AP) A Russian trawler captain convicted of violating United States fishing waters was released from fail here today after the Soviet Government had paid his $10,000 fine.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI) The Supreme Court validated today a 1966 realignment of Mississippi's Congressional districts despite claims that they were gerrymandered to assure an all-white delegation.
Widespread milk dumping by disgruntled dairy farmers has caused neither shortages nor higher prices in the nation's grocery stores.

Dr. William M. Birenbaum was formally removed yesterday as provost of Long Island University's Brooklyn Center. He charged afterward that the university's central administration tended "to equate local dissent with disloyalty."
The ranking Democrat in the State Senate characterized the the State Power Authority and Public Service Commission yesterday as "spineless" and proposed that the two bodies be made bipartisan.

WASHINGTON, March 27 Senator Robert F. Kennedy made known today, through an aide, that he had "no plans" to enter any Presidential primary next year and would take all necessary steps to keep his name off primary ballots in New Hampshire, Oregon and Nebraska.

PITTSBURGH, March 27 (AP) The National Professional Soccer League and the United Soccer Association have been discussing a possible merger. In a statement issued here today, the commissioners of the new leagues said they had been conducting "a dialogue on mutual problems" for some time.
Banks are the logical outlets for selling tickets in the state lottery with adequate safeguards for the purchasers, for the state and for the public.
HOUSTON, March 27 (UPI) Mrs. Candace Mossler and her nephew, Melvin Lane Powers, filed suit today against Percy Foreman, a lawyer, asking that he return a land deed and some $84,000 in jewels.

NEW DELHI, March 27 The Government warned today that a "serious" food situation "may develop" in coming months because of the uncertainty of further imports and the failure of state administrations to procure adequate stocks from farmers.
MAIN dishes that combine potatoes with fish or shellfish take advantage of the currently heavy supplies of the budget-priced vegetable and provide a change of pace for a family lunch or supper.

WASHINGTON, March 27 The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today some changes in personnel assignments in its New York regional office aimed at strengthening enforcement and regulalatory activities in that office.

Willie Shoemaker demonstrated at Aqueduct yesterday that he was still willing to learn, The leading money-winning jockey now active, Shoemaker guided Bold Tale of the Jaclyn Stable to victory by a neck over Itsago in the feature race of seven furlongs, an accomplishment that rested well with the favorite-players in the crowd of 33,180.

THE traditional fisherman's sweater has evolved into the knitted baby dress, and the tailored shirt has become a minidress, but what really marks Irish fashion designers' giant step into the mainstream of fashion is the prevalence of pants.

NASHVILLE, March 27 A severe milk shortage in middle Tennessee was extended today for at least 24 hours as a Federal judge studied an appeal to set aside a state court injunction barring interference with milk deliveries.

GENEVA, March 27--Vice President Humphrey began his two-week tour of Western Europe today by emphasizing the Johnson Administration's desire to achieve agreements here on a treaty prohibiting she spread of nuclear weapons and on a general reduction of tariffs.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., March 27 (AP)--Owners of a Hereford bull are excited about what they contend is a new development in the cattle-raising industry.

WASHINGTON, March 27 Senator Albert Gore of Tennessee is nothing if not dauntless, a fellow who is accustomed to disappearing under this or that steamroller, then arising only slightly flattened to fight again.

Mayor Lindsay met at City Hall yesterday morning with a group of judges, the five District Attorneys, law enforcement officers, top legislative leaders and others in the opening of a coordinated attack on crime in the city.
Mr. and Mrs. Nunzio Joseph Marchese lost their court fight yesterday to keep the 4-year-old foundling that they have cared for since she was 2 weeks old.
DETROIT, March 27 The American Motors Corporation will offer a small personal or sporty car for sale by this fall. This new automobile is called the Javelin.

The proposed Patent Reform Act of 1967, the first major attempt to change United States, patent law in more than 130 years, will meet some opposition from lawyers and inventors, a conference on the bill held by the American Management Association indicated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 27 The Supreme Court upheld today the Justice Department's authority to block anticompetitive bank mergers as it handed down its first interpretation of the Bank Merger Act of 1966.

Robert S. Malaga, the 35year-old dynamo who organized the Davis Cup challenge round in Cleveland in 1964, is negotiating with the United States Lawn Tennis Association for the newly created post of "executive assistant" to Robert J. Kelleher, the association's president, it was learned yesterday.
Lincoln Center today: Philadelphia Orchestra, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30 P.M., and "Il Trovatore," Metropolitan Opera, 8.
WASHINGTON, March 27 Julian Theodore Copper, aged 4, was asked by his Head Start teacher if he knew what place he was in.
A university press, an impresario and a dancer were honored yesterday for best keeping in step with the dance.
TRENTON, March 27 The Governors of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania announced plans today to establish a new interstate agency to fight air pollution.

That "Music in Our Time" can be as frustrating as it is absorbing was demonstrated in a concert in the series of that name at Town Hall last night. Six works were given first performances. Taken as a whole, the best that can be said for the evening is that it was highly varied.

Department store ticket sales for Lincoln Center presentations, not counting the Metropolitan Opera, went up $207,879 last year, to a total of $701,300. The box offices maintained in department stores by the Shuberts, however, recorded $23,516 less this year, for a total $1,541,434 for the fiscal year that ended Feb. 26.

In a surprise development, the Draper Corporation's board of directors approved yesterday in principle an improved merger bid made by the RockwellStandard Corporation, which is now involved in a proposed merger with North American Aviation, Inc.
ROME, March 27--Pope Paul VI, in an appeal for unity, said today that Easter is an "ecumenical feast" that invites all Christians to a single faith.

MOSCOW, March 27 (Reuters) The Soviet Union charged today that a "raging mob" of Red Guards had attacked a Soviet Embassy car in Peking and held diplomats, including one woman, captive for six and one-half hours.

A chubby 15-year-old, his red face covered with sweat, stormed out of Madison Square Garden yesterday, tripped over a collection of beach chairs, blankets, ther mos bottles and newspapers, and squealed: "I got 'em!"

SARASOTA, Fla., March 27 The Chicago White Sox, the weakest hitting team in the American league, overpowered Al Downing and Mel Stottlemyre with a pair of five-run innings today and defeated the New York Yankees, 12-7.
BERKELEY, Calif., March 27 (UPI) The world's largest optical mirror, which has taken more than 4,000 man-hours to make, was completed today for space research.

New York State now has an executive budget submitted annually to the Legislature by the Governor, but it has no agency for long-range fiscal planning. This is a serious omission which helps explain the recurring crises in the state's financial affairs. It can and should be remedied by the Constitutional Convention.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 27 (AP) Milovan Djilas, the controversial writer who was released from prison three months ago, said today here he did not want to travel abroad.

CHATTANOOGA, March 27 (AP) United States District Judge Frank Wilson today set May 8 as the date for a hearing on James R. Hoffa's fourth motion for a new trial and ordered that the teamster leader be brought here from the Federal penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pa., to take part in it.
Louis w. Menk, president of the Northern Pacific Railway Company, was elected yesterday as a director of General Mills, Inc., a food producer.

The Federal Maritime Commission asked the United States District Court in New York yesterday to find three foreign steamship lines in contempt for failing to provide information the agency had requested.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 27 (UPI) Juan Marichal, the San Francisco Giants' star right-handed pitcher, signed his 1967 contract today for $100,000. He said he was ready to pitch the opening game of the season and was sure he could win 20 games again.

SALEM, Ore., March 27 Gov. Tom McCall has proposed an Oregon Greenway along the Willamette River a 200-milelong corridor that would convert the riverside into protected lands for hiking, horseback riding and nature walks.
PEKING, March 27 Red Guards have stepped up a campaign aimed at keeping Premier Chou En-lai above criticism white directing their fire at some of his deputies.

Sol M. Linowitz, United States representative at the Organization of American States, said yesterday that the United States should make clear its preference for progressive, democratic governments over military regimes in Latin America through acts of "special friendship."

WHITE PLAINS, March 27 Westchester County welfare workers dissatisfied with pay and working conditions began picketing the County Office Building here around the clock today. Groups of 10 to 50 took part.

Broadway's latest attempt to lure people to the theater got under way last night as Mayor Lindsay, the all-girl band from "Cabaret" and stage celebrities shared a bumpy, hilarious bus ride from East 96th Street to Times Square.
PHILADELPHIA, March 27 (AP)--William Kincaid, considered one of the finest flute players, died today at his home in South Philadelphia. He was 71 years old.

The election of Mrs. Adelaide M. Brice as president, and of Mrs. Shirley de Lima as executive vice president has been announced by Homerica, Inc., a real estate concern that specializes in finding homes for transferred businessmen.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., March 27 (AP) Broward County's top prosecutor said today that the City of Fort Lauderdale should end the "college crud invasion."
Senator Albert Gore has launched a campaign to repeal the law for financing Presidential campaigns that was passed last November. The Senator is on solid ground.

Japanese art treasures that have never left Japan before will be shown today at the Brooklyn Museum. The show has been mounted behind closed doors, but the construction of an entrance to it out in the open has attracted curious passersby in the museum's main hall.

WASHINGTON, March 27 A Senate report made public today asserts that restrictions placed on American pilots by the Johnson Administration have contributed significantly to losses in the air war against North Vietnam.

CHICAGO, March 27 (AP) The Mobile Homes Manufacturers Association has re-elected Earl W. Swett of Marquette, Mich., as president. Mr. Swett, head of Marlette Homes, Inc., of Marquette, became the first

WASHINGTON, March 27--Leading Democrats here expect Arthur J. Goldberg to resign as United States representative at the United Nations this summer, so that he can run for the Senate from New York in 1968.
Negotiations for the sale of the Carlyle Hotel, home of presidents, prime ministers and princes, are expected to be completed today.
WASHINGTON, March 27 President Johnson has indicated that he would favor legislation over an executive order as a means of blocking defense contracts of chronie violators of the nation's labor laws.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) Only 2 per cent, roughly 9 million ounces, of the known United States unmined gold resources of more than 400 million ounces are economically minable under today's technology, the Secretary of the Interior, Stewart L. Udall, reported tonight.
COLUMBIA, S.C., March 27 (AP)--The South Carolina Supreme Court ruled today that the State Senate cannot have more than 46 members.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 27 James H. W. Thompson, the American "silk king" who built a fortune in beautiful Thai cloth, has disappeared in the jungles of northwestern Malaysia.
ALBANY, March 27--Two of Governor Rockefeller's key proposals in an attack on crime breezed through the Senate today without debate.
ATHENS, March 27 Greece's Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Constantine Tsolakas, was unexpectedly retired by the Government today.
The appointment of Dr. Norman E. Frimer as dean of Yeshiva University's Stern College for Women was announced yesterday.

ORSON WELLES' long-awaited "Chimes at Midnight" has arrived under the title of "Falstaff," a title change that pays fitting tribute to the actor-director's superb portrait of Shakespeare's mountainous rogue.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 27 The Armed Forces Congress approved the new South Vietnamese Constitution today and ordered that it be put into effect Saturday.

LONDON There is something odd and uncoopera tive about their faces. They look young but not boyish. They do not grin. When posing for photographs, they never poke pipes in their mouths, stand up straight, stick out their chins or bother to look hopeful.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that outstanding commercial paper declined $600-million, or 4 per cent, in February, to $15,135,000,000. This was the first decline since last September.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27 Going into the final two weeks of spring training, the Mets, it must be said, are still very much in the formative stage.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 27 The world's roughest, toughest production-car rally the 3,200-mile East African Safari ended in clouds of dust today as tired, red-eyed drivers roared up to the Nairobi finish line after four days and nights of lighting all that Africa's terrain and some of its populace could throw at them.
SEOUL, South Korea, March 27 (AP) -- A North Korean defector has said that life, except for top party officials, is "hellish."
The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists said yesterday that it is set to call a strike against the three major television and radio networks anytime after 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.
SINCLAIR Oil Corporation shareholders are ponder ing whether to convert or not to convert.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 27 In a major move toward bringing fuller integration to Roman Catholic parochial schools, the United States Catholic Conference, composed of all American Bishops, has called a nationwide conference on "racial isolation," it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 27 Dear Groucho, "The Groucho Letters" is (are?) a delight for all us F.B.I. types who like to read other people's mail, but you're probably going to find, next time you face a piece of stationery, that publication was a mistake.
Retail inventories of men's apparel are currently "a little high," John D. Gray, president of Hart Schaffner Mark, a leading clothing manufacturer and retailer, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) The Supreme Court agreed today to hear a second challeage to New York's "stop and frisk" law.

A secondary offering of 335,133 shares of Household Finance Corporation common stock reached the market yesterday through an underwriting group led by Dean Witter Co., White, Weld Co., and William Blair Co.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) The nation's 41st and last planned Polaris submarine will be commissioned into service Saturday, the Navy said today.

TORONTO, March 27 -- The Bank of Montreal, Canada's third largest bank, encountered opposition today when it announced a reduction in its prime lending rate to 5 per cent from 6 per cent, effective April 1.

THE turbulent history of the architecturally majes tic city of Leningrad was reviewed in broad and quick strokes last night in the George Vicas color production on the National Broadcasting Company network. The program was an interesting chronicle of the city's existence from Peter the Great to the present.

Charlton Ogburn Jr. will receive the John Burroughs Medal for 1967 for "The Winter Beach," published last October by Morrow. The award is given by the John Burroughs Memorial Association, which, in the name of the great naturalist, annually selects an outstanding book on natural history issued in the previous 12 months.

Charles T. Ross, a coin broker, has been playing a waiting game and an unhappy one at that. In January, he became a member of the New York Mercantile Exchange, center for potato futures, because the exchange, as announced last fall, planned to start trading in silver dollars.

THE period that Daniel Stern is writing about in his fifth novel ought to be familiar to unnumbered servicemen and, by extension, to all those who were enmeshed in their lives. It was the time immediately ...

The United States now has more shipping tonnage under its "effective control" flying foreign flags than it has flying the nation's own merchant marine pennant, a Maritime Administration report disclosed yesterday.

Three dozen participants in the Cathedral Conference on Business Ethics yesterday pondered the dilemma of a stockbroker who finds his associates artificially reducing the share price of a client company.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 27 (AP) Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., defeated Maria Bueno of Brazil today and took the women's singles title in the South African tennis championships.
DETROIT, March 27 (AP)--The United States auto industry will close out a disappointing first quarter on Friday. Output ran nearly 15 per cent below that of a year ago.

In a broad interpretation of the fraud section of the Securities Exchange Act, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit held yesterday for the first time that Federal courts have jurisdiction in cases where investors defraud brokers.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) State Department officials said today that a reply was being prepared to a Philippine request for the return of the Sangley Point naval air station in Manila Bay.

FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, March 27 Sierra Leone, where a military junta set aside the resuits of elections last week, had another head of government today, but citizens of the West African state had not yet been told about it.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) More than 500 law enforcement officials, judges, professors and state legislators will confer tomorrow and Wednesday on how to implement more than 200 recommendations made by the National Crime Commission.
THE Jets and Giants made progress reports yester day on their quarterbacks. So far, there are no problems.

Luther Lassiter defeated Cicero Murphy, 150-53, last night and tied Walter McGown for the lead in the world pocket billiards tournament at the Statler-Hilton hotel. Each is undefeated in eight matches.
JACKSON, Miss., March 27 (AP) The Mississippi Supreme Court ruled today that the death of a highway patrolman while searching a Congressman's son had resulted, at least in part, from heart disease.
BANGKOK, Thailand, March 27 The first B-52 bombers to be based on Thai soil will arrive here next week, Premier Thanom Kittikacharn said today.

The McDonnell Company is arranging a $300-million revolving credit with a group of 10 banks to provide the ailing Douglas Aircraft Company with working capital should the proposed merger of the two companies go through.
The Bronx Republican organization last night selected State Senator John Calandra to run for District Attorney next fall.
DENVER, March 27 An Air Force Academy officer, a psychology teacher until last January, filed suit in Federal Court here today for classification as a conscientious objector to the Vietnam war.
TOKYO, March 27 (AP) North Vietnam in effect rejected today proposals by U Thant, Secretary General of the United Nations, for settling the Vietnam war.

Special transactions by foreign governments, including changes in the way they invest their dollar reserves, improved the United States payments balance by almost $1.7-billion last year, final figures for 1966 disclosed today.
RICHMOND, March 27 (UPI) A naturalized Canadian asked a Federal court today to order the Central Intelligence Agency to open its secret files.
Performing a selection of familiar repertory works, Yuriko and company gave the third of the Monday Night Dance Series at the Village Theater last night.

John Gary brought more than his voice to his Carnegie Hall concert last night. His voice, in itself, is something unique for a pop singer. It ranges from a sonorous baritone right up to a smoothly articulated falsetto. The general texture is light, but it's a real voice, and when Mr. Gary wants to unleash some power he has it at his command.
Miss Melissa Hattersley and William Schnirring plan to marry June 13 in Locust Valley, L.I.
Average weekly earnings of factory workers in the New Yor factory workers in the New York-northeastern New Jersey metropolitan area rose in January to a record high for the fourth consecutive month.
Mayor Lindsay thinks the subways may be used to carry United States mail as well as people.

BISMARCK, N. D., March 27 (UPI) A lawyer on trial in a $3-million insurance fraud case told a Federal judge he was forced off a highway at gunpoint today as he drove here with documents that "prove" President Kennedy was assassinated by persons other than Lee Harvey Oswald.
SYDNEY, Australia, March 27 (Reuters) The skipper of Gretel, an Australian contender for the America's Cup, stepped down today after his third successive loss to Dame Pattie.

Harry Nelson, one of the last of the colorful game operators of old Coney Island, died yesterday at Coney Island Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 2914 West 15th Street, in the "island" area.

Unexpectedly successful in Boston on Sunday but once again weakened by external circumstances just when further success is possible, the New York Knickerbockers face the Boston Celtics at Madison Square Garden tonight at 8:30 in the fourth game of the first round of the National BasketBall Association Eastern Division playoffs.
The strong flow of funds into savings institutions so far this year picked up steam during February, the United States Savings and Loan League said yesterday.

A 10-year decline in TransAtlantic passenger travel by ship may be reversing itself. In the last decade, the travel volume has gone from one million passengers in 1956 and 1957 to slightly more than 600,000 last year.

Robert Garcia, who has the support of the regular and Reform wings of the Bronx Democratic party, is virtually assured victory today in the special election to fill the State Senate seat from the 29th District.
MADISON, Wis., March 27 (AP)--The creation of a committee to campaign for former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama in Wisconsin's Presidential primary next year was announced today.

DETROIT, March 27 (AP) Detroit school officials plan to review the case of a junior high school teacher who was suspended after using a play in his classroom in which a 15-yearold girl was cast as a prostitute.

The Plaza's Grand Ballroom will be the setting April 13 for a luncheon and fashion show benefiting the Girls Club of New York. The club's thrift shop is sponsor of the luncheon, and Lord Taylor will present a "Caravan of Fashion."
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 27 Vamoose, a new 40foot sloop skippered by Ted Turner of Atlanta, was officially declared the winner today of the 811-mile Miami-toMontego Bay yacht race.
LOS ANGELES, March 27 (AP) Two stars of the Los Angeles Lakers were wearing casts today.

Renewed pressure from Senator Symington and the Senate Preparedness subcommittee to extend the bombing of North Vietnam to military airfields and Haiphong harbor is a case of exasperation overwhelming reason. Despite the natural desire to hit the enemy in so seemingly logical a place as its airfields, the risks of expanding the war and strengthening China's influence militate against such raids even if they offered important military advantages. But the military advantages are few.
The volatile wheat futures market climbed yesterday on news of too little moisture in wheat-growing areas.
The Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads said they were disappointed but not disheartened by the Supreme Court ruling yesterday.

FORT MEYERS, Fla., March 27 The Pittsburgh Pirates have just broken a record with 215 double plays last sea son and the player bus bubbled with bright badinage on the way back from the ball park. Most of the needling was directed at Bill Mazeroski, the team captain and a chief architect in the setting of the mark.
Markets Commissioner George M. Welssberg said yesterday that inspections over the past weekend had shown two companies were supplying shortfilled quart containers of milk to consumers.

Jonathan Ogden Bulkley, president of Bulkley Dunton Co., Inc., 295 Madison Avenue, paper dealers, died on Saturday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at Southport and Washington Depot, Conn.
Theodore W. Kheel, chief mediator in the newspaper dispute, said last night that he was pushing for a quick settlement between the publishers and the printers.
ATHENS, March 27 Two Soviet diplomats were given 48 hours to leave Greece today for activities "incompatible with their duties."
Willard Connely, American biographer of English literary figures of the 17-18th centuries, died on Sunday in his home at Godalming, England. His age was 78.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 28 United States Navy attack bombers from the nuclear-powered aircraft carrier Enterprise pounded a fuel depot and a missile site within five miles of the North Vietnamese port of Haiphong yesterday, the United States military command announced today.

It wasn't quite 9:30 yesterday morning and Perry Harten, berry-brown from a skiing weekend, was up to his ears in the commercial production problems of Sullivan, Stauffer, Caldwell Bayles. It's his job.
WASHINGTON, March 27 Treasury-bill rates rose at today's auction after their sharp decline last week, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

Harold (Kayo) Konigsberg, the convicted extortionist, gave Federal agents the information leading to the discovery of bodies buried in what may be a secret Mafia graveyard in New Jersey, it was learned from Government officials yesterday.
DETROIT, March 27 Gov. George Romney spurned Democratic help as he pressed for a showdown today over his controversial Michigan tax reform plan.
A man brandishing a knife in Harlem yesterday was shot and wounded fatally by a police lieutenant.

The American Film Institute, which will get under way later this year, is expected to operate through offices in several locations, most likely in New York, Los Angeles and Washington, Gregory Peck, chairman of the Film Advisory Council, reported yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, March 27 The Westchester County Board of Supervisors petitioned the Legislature today to postpone authorization for the Long Island Sound bridge until the details of the plan were submitted to county officials for scrutiny.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 27--South Vietnamese Army troops killed 142 of the enemy in sharp fighting yesterday in the Mekong Delta, a Government military spokesman said today.

The New York City Central Labor Council, which represents 1.2 million union members here, was understood to have pledged "full support" yesterday to city policemen and firemen in their contract disputes with the city.
NEW DELHI, March 27 A letter from Stalin's daughter, Svetlana Alliluyeva, indicates that she was discouraged from trying to remain in India by a member of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's inner circle.

HOUSTON, March 28 About 400 students blocked doors and disrupted classes today at Texas Southern University here to protest the school administration's refusal to recognize Friends of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee as an on-campus organization.
FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, March 28 The puzzle over who would head Sierra Leone's military junta was solved at Government Wharf today with a red carpet reception for Lieut. Col. Andrew Juxon-Smith.
A fire in a New Haven Railroad electric locomotive sent dense clouds of smoke rolling through much of Grand Central Terminal early yesterday afternoon, causing the evacuation of the main concourse.

Four college professors and a housing expert associated with a civic group were named yesterday as the first senior staff members for the Constitutional Convention, which opens in Albany next Tuesday.
One hundred and eight East Side playgoers took advantage of the League of New York Theaters' new chartered bus service to the theater district last night.
Plans to use Western Union branches for the sale of state lottery tickets ran into opposition yesterday from the Communications Workers of America.

WASHINGTON, March 28 Although "more zip" in the economic indicators would be welcome, the economy is performing "only slightly below the level that was anticipated early this year," a high Government economic official said today.

STRANGE, but true; there was a note in the Phil harmonic Hall program saying "First performance at these concerts." The performance in question was Beethoven's "Missa Solemnis," and it seems inconceivable that the Philadelphia Orchestra had never before presented the score in New York. But apparently it hadn't.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 29 South Vietnam made known today its acceptance in principle of peace efforts sponsored by Secretary General Thant, but with conditions that were described as "counterproposals."
Mortimer Lahm, chairman and a founder of the M.H. Lamston variet,Y store chain, died Monday in New York Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 1040 Park Avenue, at 86th Street.

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that it would continue operating trains under a tristate demonstration project after the April 30 deadline. In addition, the line said it was merging two long-run trains in their operations within New York State.

Paperboard production rose 1.8 per cent to 453,800 tons in the week ended March 25 from 448,500 tons in the comparable 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.
Emile Griffith signed yesterday to defend his middleweight boxing championship, for the third time, against Nino Benvenuti of Italy, the European titleholder, on April 17 at Madison Square Garden.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 28 After Billy Herman, the manager of the Boston Red Sox, had installed the rookie shortstop, Rico Petrocelli, as his varsity regular in 1965, the skipper was lavish with his praise. In no time at all he was comparing the 21-year-old with his old double-play partner on the Cubs, Billy Jurges.

The owners of a chicken farm on which Government agents believe they found a Mafia graveyard will be questioned today by a Federal grand jury in Newark that is investigating how the Mafia disposes of its unwanted members and enemies.
LAND'S END, England, March 28 Jet planes bombed the wrecked tanker Torrey Canyon today, setting fire to the crude oil in her hull and on the surface of the ocean for a mile around.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 28 (AP) The National Basketball Committee acted today to curb stalling tactics in collegiate and high school games. It also barred "dunking," a shot utilized mostly by tall players.

JACKSON, Miss., March 28 (AP)--A three-judge Federal panel has ordered its plan for apportioning the Mississippi Legislature into immediate effect after throwing out proposed changes as "without merit."
The New York Rangers, in a three-way battle with Toronto and Montreal for second place in the National Hockey League, will meet the Detroit Red Wings tonight at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, March 28 Congress was told today that its methods of appropriating funds had blunted the effectiveness of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 a major pillar of President Johnson's Great Society.

A complicated virus a microscopic agent that lies biologically on the border between life and nonlife has been assembled in the laboratory, a geneticist from the California Institute of Technology reported here yesterday.

Rutgers University suggested yesterday that a series of saucer-shaped floating airfields, made of concrete and anchored in the Hudson and East Rivers, could provide bases for mass short-haul aerial transportation to and from Manhattan.

ALBANY, March 28--Mayor Lindsay, Governor Rockefeller and the leaders of the Legislature announced agreement tonight on a compromise fiscal package to give New York City about $126-million in additional state aid.

THE HAGUE, March 28 Vice President Humphrey sought today to enlist Dutch support for efforts toward successful conclusion of the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting negotiations and a compromise on a treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.
Charles H. Kline, a well-known correspondent and magazine editor, was found dead Monday in his apartment in Washington. He was 67 years old.

The spot rate on the British pound resumed a strongly buoyant trend yesterday in moderate trading on foreignexchange markets here. The final quotation of $2.7988 was 11 points higher than the closing rate on Monday.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 28 Long Island University announced today that it would open a law school and law center on its Merriweather campus at Brookville, L.I., in September, 1969.

TOKYO, March 28 Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore has expressed a view on Vietnam that is seldom heard in public from other leaders of non-Communist Asia. There have been indications that many agree in private with what the vigorous young Socialist politician said here but withhold a similar open expression because of domestic considerations.
The annual dinner dance benefiting the Kips Bay Boys Club will be held on April 20 at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof.
The election of Frank P. Rossi as president was announced here yesterday by the Sperry Hutchinson Company, distributor of S. H. Green Stamps.

Mary B. Kirkbride, who retired in 1946 as acting director of the New York State Health Department's division of laboratories and research, died Monday night at her home in Albany. She was 92 years old.
STUART, Fla., March 28 The trout is often referred to as Florida's most popular game fish, although many partisans of the snook might argue the point.
WASHINGTON, March 28 President Johnson termed "monstrous" tonight the fact that the crime rate was so high that far more Americans were dying of homicide than were perishing in the Vietnam war.
NASHVILLE, March 28 (AP) The National Farmers Organization and the Nashville Milk Producers, Inc., signed an agreement tonight to end the middle Tennessee milk strike.

TRENTON, March 28 (AP) Dan Wettlin Jr., vice president of the New Jersey Milk Industry Association, said today of the milk holding action: "It looks like it's all over." But Charles Barbay Sr., a regional supervisor for the National Farmers Organization, said: "That's not true. The farmers are still holding out."

WASHINGTON, March 28 A Senate document has reported a serious shortage of Air Force munitions in Vietnam last spring. Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara denied last spring that any such shortage existed.

Two bootleggers who operated a large still on the Lower East Side received severe prison sentences yesterday in Federal Court for defrauding the Government of $390,000 in taxes on the illegal alcohol they produced.
WASHINGTON. March 28 (AP) Trucking industry negotiators reportedly made some progress today in the face of strike preparations by the teamsters union.
Richard S. Lane, Reform district leader of the 66th Assembly District since 1961, was designated for re-election to that post by members of the Lexington Democratic Club last night.
"You can kid the customer only once and you'd better not," three executives yesterday counseled the Cathedral Conference on Business Ethics.

WASHINGTON, March 28 A Federal advisory commission said today that state governments "are on the verge of losing control" over the mounting problems of central city decay and the rapid growth of metropolitan areas.
Industrial prices drifted down yesterday in quiet trading on the London Stock Exchange.

KEITH DOUGLAS was killed in Normandy on June 9, 1944, at the age of 24. Before that he had fought with the British Eighth Army from Alamein to Wadi Zem Zem and had been wounded and hospitalized. For a young man he left a considerable body of work as his "Collected Poems" shows.

Only the fantastic marksmanship of Sam Jones saved the Boston Celtics from another upset at the hands of the New York Knickerbockers last night, and moved the National Basketball Association champions into the next round of the playoffs against the Philadelphia 76ers.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 28 (AP) A Toledo, Ohio, cement finisher Charles Gregory, moved into fifth place in the regular all-events division today at the American Bowling Congress tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)--Stuart G. Tipton, president of the Air Transport Association, said today that the Government would receive in royalties more than the estimated total of $1.3-billion it is contributing to the development of the supersonic transport plane.
PARIS, March 28 Bernard Frechtman, long the official English translator of Jean Genet, died in an accident at his country home near Paris on March 2. He was 52 years old.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 28 James Kelly Foster of 119 Wellington Road, a reared lawyer who practiced for nearly 40 years at 50 Court Street, Brooklyn, died here Sunday at the age of 82. His firm in later years was Underhill Foster.
Ted Bates Co. has a computer that's a name dropper. It clackity-clacks out such gems as Exirel, Nenlen, Paphon, Sasist, Cecol and Rorgen.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 28 (AP) Dame Pattie defeated Gretel by 3 minutes, 7 seconds today in the fourth of the preliminary trials to select Australia's challenger for the America's Cup yachting classic.
Mead Johnson Co. announced yesterday that it was recalling the eight-ounce size of an infant milk formula, Enfamil Nursette.

PEKING, March 28 (Agence France-Presse) Chinese Communist officials intervened discreetly Sunday to halt a "siege" of a carload of Soviet diplomats by furious Red Guards, East European sources said today.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation joined the $2-billion club yesterday as it announced record sales and earnings for 1966. The concern reported earnings for last year of $89.91-million or $4.07 a share, on sales of $2,121,272,000. In 1965 the company cleared $78,515,000, or $3.59 a share, on revenues of $1,856,330,000.

GENEVA, March 28 The leading trade officials of the United States and the Common Market opened today a series of high-level meetings that could make or break the nearly fouryear-old Kennedy round negotiations on expanding world trade.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., March 28 (AP) The names of three jockeys and six horses, three of them fillies, have been submitted to the voting committee of the Hall of Fame in the National Museum of Racing.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)--Negotiators for six unions and 138 railroads, facing a strike deadline April 12, met briefly today to get bargaining talks started again.

According to William ManChester, the assassination of President Kennedy caught Lyndon B. Johnson so poorly briefed on his responsibilities as Commander in Chief that if a Russian nuclear attack had been launched that afternoon it could have crippled this country's power to retaliate.

Argentina has received a "strongly favorable" response from financial institutions in the United States and Europe to a request for loans totaling $400-million to support the stability of the Argentine peso, banking sources said yesterday.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 28 (AP) More than 300 policemen, soldiers and trackers with dogs searched the jungles of the Cameron Highlands without success today for James H. W. Thompson, the "silk king" of Thailand.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 28 State Senator Robert O. Tiernan, Democrat of Warwick, held a razor-thin lead over James DiPrete, Republican Mayor of suburban Cranston, tonight in a special election in the Second Congressional District.
Declines outnumbered advances again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

BONN, March 28 In more ways than one, East Germany and West Germany have exchanged roles on the world stage during the last 12 months and the Easter holiday has provided the most telling examples of how they have done so. A year ago the East Berlin Communist regime was wearing ...

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, March 28 (AP) A 12-man private expedition traveled about 35 miles today on the first leg of a trek over the polar icecap to the North Pole, according to radio reports received here tonight.
CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) Quentin P. Gore, managing editor of The Chicago Sun-Times, died yesterday in PresbyterianSt. Luke's Hospital where he had been a patient since Saturday. He was 58 years old.
CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) The Chicago Black Hawks defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 7-2 tonight in a National Hockey League game but lost Matt Ravlich, a defenseman, for the remander of the season.

Of all the controversial subjects at the New York State Constitutional Convention that we have discussed in these columns, the most controversial will probably be the relationship of church and state in the school system.
WASHINGTON, March 28 Arthur J. Goldberg, United States representative at the United Nations, said today he was "not a candidate" for Senator from New York.
The Columbia Broadcasting System will present four new comedy-variety series this summer in prime time as replacements for regularly scheduled shows.

WASHINGTON, March 28 President Johnson announced today that the United States had aceepted a three-step Vietnam peace proposal by Secretary General Thant of the United Nations but that Washington "learned regretfully" of North Vietnam's apparent rejection of the proposal.
Barbara Harris, winner of a Tony as the best actress in a musical, was unable to complete Monday night's performance in "The Apple Tree" because of a sudden attack of laryngitis.
Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan said last night that the Lindsay administration's proposal for a Lower Manhattan Expressway was a "marked improvement" over earlier plans.

HOLLYWOOD, March 28 (AP) "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" won honors tonight as the best-written American film drama of 1966 at the awards dinner of the Writers Guild of America. Ernest Lehman adapted the Edward Albee play for the screen.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 28 Albert O. Hirschman, an authority on Latin-American economics, was named today Lucius N. Littauer Professor of Political Economy at Harvard University.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 28--The National Catholic Educational Association today was asked to conduct a study of the future of Catholic education in the United States.
CLEVELAND, March 28 Authorities here are investigating suspected outside financing of white and black hate groups that are terriorizing city neighborhoods.

Wintery winds have been blowing enough topsoil from fields of winter wheat because of dryness to worry Middle Western farmers and Department of Agriculture officials. Wheat futures traders have been trying to figure out how far the crop has deteriorated, culling their information from a variety of reports.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 28 Alabama legislators who conferred with former Gov. George C. Wallace Jr. said today that they had been told that Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace would call for resistance to a Federal court mandate to desegregate all Alabama schools.

The D.W.G. Corporation, a cigar manufacturer, and the N.V.F. Company, a producer of vulcanized fiber and related products, announced last night that an agreement in principle for a merger of the two concerns had been reached.

Silver continues to be used in United States 50-cent coins only to placate producers of the scarce metal, and not, as the Government says, to provide a "prestige" coin and a link with tradition, it was charged here yesterday.
The printers began what they called separate negotiations with The New York Times last night in a new effort to reach an agreement before midnight tomorrow when newspaper contracts expire.

The National Institute of Arts and Letters named four composers yesterday to receive $2,500 grants on May 24 at the annual joint ceremonial of the institute and its affiliate, the American Academy of Arts and Letters.
The Madison Fund, a New York-based closed-end investment company, withdrew yesterday its offer of Dec. 27 to purchase the assets of the Consolidated Investment Trust of Boston.
In a brief City Hall ceremony, Mayor Lindsay yesterday swore in William T. Golden to the nonsalaried post of chairman of the $500million City University Construction Fund.

When William Schuman became president of the Juilliard School of Music in 1945, one of the items he had written in a little black book of projects was, simply, "a resident quartet." Last night the Juilliard String Quartet celebrated its 20th anniversary by presenting a concert of typical repertory in typical performances.
Mrs. Lucille Pickett Williams opened her campaign against Adam Clayton Powell yesterday.

HONGAY, North Vietnam, March 27 (Agence FrancePresse)--This industrial center and commerical port northeast of Haiphong is one of the world's loveliest sites, but also an incomparable reference point. It is a fly-over point and occasional target for United States fighter-bombers taking off from aircraft carriers cruising some 120 miles away.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, March 28 Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the United States chess champion, took the lead of the 1967 Grand Prix International Tournament here last night by defeating Dr. Wolf Bergrasser of France in the fourth round. Fischer has won in all four rounds.
PEKING, March 28 (Agence France-Presse) The Peking radio reported tonight that an "acute disease" was gripping the South China provinces of Kwangtung and Hunan.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 28 Secretary General Thant disclosed today that on March 14 he appealed for a "standstill truce" in Vietnam as a first step toward peace negotiations.

INASMUCH as "Sherry!", which opened at the Alvin last evening, is a newly minted musical comedy version of "The Man Who Came to Dinner," it is quite naturally full of old jokes and new jokes. The trouble with the old jokes is that you remember them. The trouble with the new ones is that no one ever will.

ON the cold and sleety feastday of Epiphany in January, 1955, Giovanni Battista Montini entered Milan, where he had just been named Roman Catholic Archbishop, knelt before thousands of its shivering citizens and kissed the wet earth on which they stood.

VIENNA, March 28 (AP) A battered United States hockey team routed West Germany, 8-3, tonight, clinching fifth place in its final game of the world championships. The triumph qualified the Americans automatically for next year's Winter Olympic Games.
WHEN a mutual fund buys or sells a major block of stock in New York Stock Exchange trading, the transaction often creates quite a stir.

Mayor Lindsay personally entered the city's contract dispute with the police and firemen yesterday, but it was learned that he was determined not to increase an offer previously made even if that meant a strike.
WASHINGTON, March 28 Twenty nations of Latin America, representing a combined population of 230 million, have agreed in principle to create a fully functioning common market no later than 1985.

Robert Garcia, a 34-year-old Reform Democrat, won an overwhelming victory in the special election yesterday for the State Senate in the heavily Democratic 29th District, which covers parts of the Bronx and Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) Seven persons cured of cancer from a Pittsburgh teen-ager to an actor met President Johnson today to help open the American Cancer Society's campaign in April to raise $40.77-million to fight cancer.
WASHINGTON, March 28 Premier Mohammad Hashim Maiwandwal of Afghanistan greeted President Johnson today with a warm handshake and a restatement of his country's neutrality.
Trainers put blinkers on their horses to wake them up, cure bad habits, coax more speed out of them and get their minds on the business at hand.

WASHINGTON, March 28 President Johnson seems to have liberated Vice President Hubert Humphrey from his opulent doghouse. After years of secondrate assignments, odd political and ceremonial chores, the Happy Shouter from Minnesota has been turned loose in Europe on what promises to be the start of a much more active political and policy role.
Eddie Taylor of Knoxville, Tenn., won two matches yesterday in the world pocket billiards championship tournament at the Statler-Hilton.

It was a welcome circumstance last night at the McMillin Theater of Columbia University to be able to apply Anton Webern's name to his own music rather than to that of the flood of younger composers who have been influenced by him.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes disclosed yesterday that the first equipment delivered for the city's $100-million electronic traffic-control system had proved totally unworkable.

I am glad to be able to meet with you again. In the interval since my last press conference there have been several developments. As you know, I was able to pay a brief visit to Burma during the interval.

PRACTICE will begin today at Sebring, Fla., for the season's second trans-American sedan championship race and for the annual 12-hour world championship endurance contest. The sedans will compete in a four-hour race Friday afternoon and the longer event, for sports, sports prototype ...
A squabble between Mayor Lindsay and Representattive Paul A. Fino surfaced yesterday to complicate the Republican side of the already complex campaign for Bronx District Attorney.
Scheduled domestic trunk airline passenger operations this year are expected to reach the 70 billion passenger-mile level, the Civil Aeronautics Board said last week.
Prof. Eugene Avallone has been named to the newly created post of dean of campus planning and development at City College, it was announced yesterday.

Yields on new bond issues continued to move down yesterday. New York State sold $75million of highway bonds that were priced, generally, to give yields one-tenth of a percentage point below yields on similarly rated bonds marketed last week.

PRESIDENTS of major corporations seldom have the time and energy to be serious bridge players. Perhaps the only exception is Dr. George Rosenkranz of Mexico City, who is president of Syntex and was closely concerned in the development of birth-control pills.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 28 The Florida Republican party today made its greatest legislative gains in 100 years in the state, electing at least 19 State Senators and 40 members of the House.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 28 (AP) The State Senate concurred in House amendments tonight and enacted an open housing bill.
In a surprise action yesterday that brought applause in a packed courtroom the city endorsed a lawsuit seeking the redistricting of the BedfordStuyvesant area in Brooklyn where 370,000 Negroes live.

Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, called last night for an "escalation toward peace" in Vietnam and suggested that President Johnson halt the bombing of North Vietnam to "show we're sincere."

A 74-year-old Bronx man was found stabbed to death yesterday morning in a cleaning and tailor shop that he had operated for 40 years at 1012 East 163d Street. The police said that Isidore Young, who lived at 960 Grand Concourse, apparently was the victim of a robbery.

Pinkerton's, Inc., the security and investigation concern, made its first public offering of common stock yesterday, a move that will subject the company to the scrutiny of Wall Street's analysts and its new stockholders. The transaction amounted to $6.9-million.

The new chief executive officer of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., said yesterday that there weren't "any quick solutions to the company's problems." But he pledged to work hard to make the giant utility "the cleanest, most reliable, best looking and most efficient electric system that can be designed."

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 28 Legislators began hearings today on a record California budget exceeding $5-billion. Some Assembly Republicans as well as Democrats predicted that it would be increased, not reduced.

OMAHA, March 28 (AP) The Omaha police took into custody late this afternoon Mrs. Lillie-Mae McMaines for New Orleans authorities. She is wanted there as a material witness in the investigation by District Attorney Jim Garrison into the assassination of President Kennedy.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 28 Dr. Clark Kerr, former president of the University of California, declared today that "confrontation politics" was the essence of the new student activism sweeping America's campuses.

ROME, March 27 "Populorum Progressio," meaning "on the Development of Peoples," is the opening of the Latin text of Pope Paul VI's encyclical. By tradition this Papal document will bear these two words as its title.
The stock market managed to make a modest advance yesterday in quiet dealings, with the glamour issues showing the best gains.

Edward P. Gilleran, consultant to the development office of Fordham University and formerly secretary to three presidents of the university, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 33-43 83d Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.
WASHINGTON, March 28 "Con Ed won't be much different for Chuck Luce," a friend said recently. "He's really a trouble shooter and if he doesn't know Con Ed has troubles he'll soon find out."
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) Statistics of the Job Corps showed today that it has a 70 per cent efficiency rating on its job getting school dropouts to become active.
ALBANY, March 28 The Assembly defeated today, for the third time in three years, an attempt to authorize parimutuel betting on quarterhorse racing in New York.

KINSHASA, the Congo, March 28--After 16 months of military rule, the Congo is about to enter a new phase. President Joseph D. Mobutu is ready to begin a revolutionary program, a radical departure from present administrative, political and economic practices.
NEW HAVEN, March 28 The government here and the International Business Machines Corporation are planning to put the city's files on computers to obtain a statistical profile of everyone in town.
ROME, March 28 Pope Paul VI declared today that "the world is sick" and prescribed urgent, unselfish, nonpolitical action for economic and social justice as the cure.

ALBANY, March 28--Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia introduced a bill today to require full disclosure of the names and fees of the special guardians, receivers and trustees appointed by the Surrogates' Courts.

The annual Bal des Berceaux, sponsored by the Committee of French American wives, will be held on April 15 in the Pierre's Grand Ballroom. Ambassador Charles Lucet of France and Mrs. Lucet, patrons of the event, will be among the guests of honor.

TRENTON, March 28 Gov. Richard J. Hughes backed down today and announced that he would allow a public legislative hearing on his controversial proposal to provide publicly financed, free bus transportation for New Jersey's parochial and private school students.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 28 The Kansas City Athletics used to be famous as a baseball team with golden uniforms and a traveling mule. Now they also have a pitching staff, and they used it to good advantage today in defeating the New York Yankees, 5-4.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 28 (AP)--Robben Wright Fleming, chancellor of the University of Wisconsin, was named today as president of the University of Michigan, one of the nation's oldest and largest universities.

WASHINGTON, March 28 The Treasury auctioned ninemonth and one-year bills today at discount rates very close to each other and close to yesterday's rate for six-month bills. Both rates today were down substantially from last month's issue of these bills.
Mrs. Flora Feder Freedman, a former lawyer and the wife of Max Freedman, a stockbroker, died yesterday in her home at 1701 Albemarle Road, Brooklyn.
The Rev. Paul D. Collins, chaplain to the Episcopal Community of St. Mary at Peekskill, N.Y., died Monday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 55 years old.

The appointment of Dr. J. Frederick Eagle as dean and executive vice president of the New York Medical College was announced yesterday. Dr. Eagle, assistant dean of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, will take his new post July 1.

LANESVILLE, N.Y., March 28 Eugene F. Martin, who retired in 1965 as a vice president and member of the plans board of Carl Byoir Associates, Inc., New York City public relations concern, died here today at his home. He was 61 years old and formerly lived in Scarsdale.

CONTRASTING studies of how Texas looks to an Englishman and how England looks to a Texan were offered last night on a news special of the Columbia Broadcasting System. The conceit of trying to cover two societies in one hour took its toll: the oversimplifications were onerous and the insights seldom more than animated postcards.
NEW LONDON, Conn., March 28 (UPI) Mrs. Antoinette Foster, a church organist and mother of three children, pleaded guilty today of manslaughter in the gun slaying of her Navy officer husband.

The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen announced yesterday it would strike the Long Island Rail Road on April 13. However the Federal mediation procedures customary in railroad labor disputes are expected to delay the strike for at least 60 days.
WHITE PLAINS, March 28 Daniel F. McMahon, Public Safety Commissioner of Yonkers, was designated by the Westchester Republican County Commitee tonight as its candidate for Sheriff.
PITTSBURGH, March 28 (UPI) Department stores here reported only moderate counter sales today of Mr. Manchester's book.

The huge water pollution danger created by the stranding of the tanker Torrey Canyon off the coast of Cornwall calls attamination problem that no one, tention to a kind of ocean concertainly not the world's oil industry, seems prepared to control.

Stokely Carmichael, advocate of black power and chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, has accepted an invitation to participate in a peace protest in New York on Saturday April 15.
A series of 10 weekly art tours for children 6 to 16 years old will begin this Saturday. The first trip will be to the Egyptian collection at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

The oil-borne ecological and economic disaster now devastating the coast of Cornwall is severe enough, but it might have been even worse. The bombed and broken tanker, the Torrey Canyon, now pouring the last of its almost 120,000 tons of petroleum into the ocean, is by no means the largest such vessel on the seas.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 28 The Mets again made altogether too many mistakes today to suit Manager Wes Westrum. But, with the help of some positive accomplishments and rival malfeasances, they survived them to beat the Phillies, 9-7, in 10 innings.
R.H. Macy Co., Inc., reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the 26-week period ended Jan. 28.
Dina Melicov ofw 351 West 24th Street, a sculptor, died Monday in St. Vincent's Hospital at the age of 62. She was the wife of Samuel Gould, a furniture designer and importer.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 29 (AP) Phan Khac Suu, speaker of the Constituent Assembly, announced today his candidacy for President in South Vietnam's first election under the new constitution.

NEW DELHI, India, March 28 28 Foreign Minister M.C. Chagla said today that the United States had been warned that "Indo-American relations were bound to suffer" if there were further stagings in New York of a play that portrays Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and other Indian leaders.
The United States is producing in Latin America television soap operas that are commercially sponsored, often by American concerns.
WANT an entire English pub, complete with tankards and a "Penny a Pint" sign for the bar?

There is an informal air of formality about a New Yorker Magazine, Inc., annual meeting. Shortly after 10:45 A.M. yesterday, R. Hawley Truax, chairman, called the roomful of about 75 well-dressed stockholders to order.

MOSCOW, March 28--The Soviet Union is preparing to open its Northern Sea Route, linking Europe and Asia along the north coast of Siberia, to vessels of all foreign countries, the head of the Soviet Union's swiftly growing merchant fleet said today.
A City Council committee was told yesterday, on the one hand, that New York City needed more home rule and, on the other, that it already had enough.
Sidney L. Feibleman, a retired lawyer and a former member of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 360 East 55th Street.
CHEVY CHASE, Md., March 28 The marriage of Miss Mary Jean Sinclair, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Duree Sinclair of Washington, to Frederick Dent Sharp took place this evening.
ALBANY, March 28 Governor Rockefeller has agreed not to press for the immediate building of a bridge across Long Island Sound to connect Nassau and Westchester Counties.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 28 (UPI) United States marines battling North Vietnamese forces for control of the northern frontier reported today that they had killed at least 100 enemy soldiers, some of them strapped to sandbags so they could not run away.
Harvey Rothenberg, a 42year-old administrative assistant to Mayor Lindsay, received his first pay check yesterday. It was for 30 cents.
MOUSEHOLE, England, March 28 In a tiny shelter, just a few tumbledown rooms and wire coops, the main battle to save Cornwall's sea birds from oil is fought.
ANCHORAGE, March 28 (AP) The punishment a Russian trawler captain faces from his Government will include repayment of a $10,000 United States fine and loss of his master's license for a year.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 28 A raging fire, with flames 300 feet high, destroyed the Laurel in the Pines Hotel here tonight.

PALMA, Spain, March 28 The shadow of the Vietnam war hung over the annual spring meeting here of the Inter-Parliamentary Union as the Communist delegations quickly opened a barrage of charges against the United States for "aggression" and "brutal bombings" in North Vietnam.

Pvt. Pete Gogolak, the soccerstyle place-kicker for the New York Giants last season, has been in Walson Army Hospital at Fort Dix, N.J., for the last two weeks with "low back pains" following a fall down a six-step flight of stairs, the player's father disclosed yesterday.
Work on Hellinic Lines pier at the foot of 57th Street, Brooklyn, was slowed yesterday as a result of longshoremen's resentment of managament's shifting of pier supervisory personnel.

The initial reaction of Roman Catholic churchmen in this country who were canvassed yesterday about Pope Paul's new encyclical was calm and noncommittal. None had yet read the text, and the few who did comment emphasized that their remarks were necessarily tentative and probably superficial.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 28 The all-important program that seeks to stabilize the fragile South Vietnamese economy could be undermined by continuing inflation.

Edward Heath, who became the leader of Britain's opposition Conservative party in 1965, told an American audience last week that the idea of a special relationship between Britain and the United States was a myth.

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, March 27 High-ranking Saudis say they have no fear of subversion by adherents of President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic. They are confident they have the answers to this problem and are eager to pass them on to the British in Aden.
WASHINGTON, March 28 The last generation of Americans "made the greatest mess in the world" of its cities and "loathsome towns," a distinguished architect charged today.

HAWTHORNE, N.Y., March 28 A motorist involved in a series of crashes in the metropolitan area in the last two years, including one that resulted in the death of a young woman, was jailed for 30 days and fined $50 here tonight for driving without a legal license.
David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, defended yesterday his bank's involvement in loans to the South African Government.

Supreme Court Justice Jacob Markowitz ruled yesterday that the American Express Company could proceed with its plan to make a $60.2-million settlement with creditors of its American Express Warehousing, Ltd. subsidiary.

ROME, March 28 Miss Jane Stuart Vander Poel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Halsted Billings Vander Poel, was married today in All Saints Anglican Church to Eric Richards Rippel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Alexander Rippel of Madison, N.J.
Hy Resnick was nervous. The frankfurters were broiling too slowly, the lines outside were growing too fast, the soft-drink machine had just broken down and the store was set to open.

More than 600 apartment house owners and managers paid $1 each yesterday to take a look at an exhibition of airpollution control devices that will soon be mandatory additions to incinerators at costs of at least $5,000.
PITTSBURGH, March 28 (AP) Gregory I. Zatkovich, a lawyer here whose career included service as Governor of Carpathian Russia, died Sunday in Shadyside Hospital. He was 80 years old.
Lincoln Center today: "Mourning Becomes Electra," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Chamber Symphony of Philadelphia, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation filed a registration statement yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington for a possible secondary offering of 112,510 outstanding common shares owned by Spyros P. Skouras and family interests.
