Negotiations between the three television and radio networks and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists broke off last night and the union announced that it would strike the networks at 5 o'clock this morning.
AGE OF ILLUSIONS, a Hungarian-made drama directed by Istvan Szabo and presented by Brandon Films, at the Fifth Avenue Cinema at 12th Street.

The United States has reiterated its desire for peace in Vietnam by accepting the proposals made by Secretary General Thant. These call for a general standstill truce, preliminary talks and the reconvening of the Geneva Conference of 1954.
In war-torn South Vietnam nearly one-and-a-half million men, women and children have been forced to flee their farms ...
NORMAL, Ill., March 28 The Earl of Avon, the former Sir Anthony Eden, warned tonight against the "dangers" of further escalation of the war in Vietnam.
MEDFORD, Ore., March 28 (AP) Mrs. Helen Hedrick, widow of an Oregon educator, has announced her engagement to Alfred A. Knopf, the publisher.
WASHINGTON, March 29 The Order of Railway Conductors and Brakemen threatened today a major railroad strike for midnight Friday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 29 The third conference of African and Asian writers concluded a four-day meeting here today with a resolution condemning United States policy in Vietnam.

THE pear-shaped tones and familiar faces of many network announcers and newsmen were missing from the airwaves yesterday, but from the viewer's standpoint the first day of the first national strike by the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists hardly altered the nonelectronic maxim regarding man's dispensability.
GENOA, Italy, March 29 (UPT) The captain cried out as in pain.

TAMPA, Fla., March 29 On this moody afternoon of sun, shadow and occasional spots of rain, the Mets turned in one of their brighter performances of this spring training season in downing the formidable Cincinnati Reds, 5 to 3, today.
PHILADELPHIA, March 29 (AP) Philadelphia's four-year. old Police Advisory Board, a civilian panel created to hear citizen complaints against the police, was declared "illegal and void" today.

An attempt to settle the boycott at P.S. 125 in Manhattan failed yesterday when the Board of Education and boycott leaders disagreed over the number of people who would participate in a joint meeting planned for 5 P.M.
The third proxy fight in three years for control of the Boston Maine Railroad Corporation appeared likely yesterday.

ARLINGTON, Tex., March 29 (UPI) Don Dunfield of Santa Clara, Calif., led the qualifiers in one-meter diving and Jim Henry of Dallas led the three-meter competition today in a prequalifying round for the Amateur Athletic Union diving championships, to be held here this weekend.
Industrial issues declined yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

A number of readers have challenged The New York Times this week, and with good reason. The definition in the crossword puzzle for leap year was incorrect. No. 21 down in Monday's puzzle had the years 1800 and 1900 as leap years. They were not.
Seven singers have been chosen to represent the Eastern Region in the Metropolitan Opera National Council's semifinal auditions, to be held on Friday, April 7, in the Metropolitan Opera House.
The stock market fluctuated erratically throughout most of yesterday's session and ended slightly off in the quietest trading since mid-February.

Sears, Roebuck Co., continued to register record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31. However, fourthquarter profits dropped $36million from the level of the preceding year despite a moderate sales increase, the 80th annual report disclosed yesterday.
Edward Gordon Hooker, a stockbroker formerly with E.F. Hutton Co., died yesterday in his home at 1160 Park Avenue, apparently of a heart attack. He was 43 years old.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 29 (AP) Jack McMahon was appointed today general manager and coach of San Diego, the new National Basketball Association entry.

WASHINGTON, March 29 The answer to the question Why is the world such a mess? lies right before our eyes in the personality sketches of the world's shakers and movers which the newspapers and magazines are so fond of drawing.
LONDON, March 29 (AP) Dr. Herbert John Davis, a former president of Smith College and a professor at Cornell University, died yesterday in Oxford at the age of 73.
Exports of cotton fabric from Japan to the United States fell sharply in January, according to Textiles Imports, Inc.
Distraught parents filled a Queens courtroom yesterday afternoon as 22 young men, were arraigned on charges of selling or possessing marijuana, LSD, barbiturates, amphetamines and hashish.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 29 (UPI) Jimmy Clark of Scotland followed Parnelli Jones behind the wheel of Andy Granatelli's turbine car today and breezed around the Indianapolis motor speedway at speeds over 160 miles an hour.

PITTSBURGH, March 29 (UPI) Department stores and major bookstores here, where copies of William Manchester's "The Death of a President" were put on sale prematurely Monday, took the book off their counters today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 29 Secretary General Thant has received written replies from North and South Vietnam as well as from the United Stales to his latest peace proposals.

BOSTON, March 29 (UPI) Bill Russell, the first Negro head coach of a major professional team, has been rehired as player-coach of the Boston Celtics for what was reported to be "substantially" more than $125,000.

The National Institute of Arts and Letters and its affiliate, the American Academy of Arts and Letters, held a special meeting yesterday to mark the 50th anniversary of United States entry into World War I.
The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States announced here yesterday the election of William R. Cowie as vice president in charge of the securities investment division.
AKRON, Ohio, March 29 (AP) Jim Stefanich of Chicago averaged 245 for 16 games to take the lead in the $100,000 Firestone Professional Bowlers' Association Tournament of Champions after two rounds.

BENTRE, South Vietnam, March 28 No bricks or cement are to be found in this Mekong Delta town, the capital of Kienhoa Province, known for the beauty of its women and for its prominent sons in Government and Vietcong ranks.
A Supreme Court jury in the Bronx convicted a 28-year-old man yesterday of the killing and rape of a 9-year-old crippled girl last September.
FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, March 29--When Lieut. Col. Andrew Juxon-Smith arrived here from London yesterday he drove to army headquarters through silent streets.
ABOUT 40 children descended on the offices of a New York publishing company yesterday to learn what their fathers or mothers did between the morning coffee and the evening cocktail.
WASHINGTON, March 29--The Senate ethics committee has tentatively decided to recommend that Senator Thomas J. Dodd be punished for misconduct, but that he not be expelled.

APRIL skiing seems assured for New England, New York and even New Jersey points. Some major centers such as Whiteface and Gore Mountain in the Adirondacks have closed, but several dozen remain open at least through this weekend.
DANANG, South Vietnam, March 29 Few United States marines in South Vietnam question the thesis that booby traps and mines are the guerrilla's most valuable weapons.
WASHINGTON, March 29 Mutual funds engaged in recordbreaking trading activity in stocks last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
From Rochester comes word that Irwin Ress, president of Norrito, Ress, Inc., is joining Mathison Advertising, which will become Mathison-Ress.

WASHINGTON, March 29 The White House has been quietly asking the hat size of each of the 35 Latin-American envoys who, with their wives, will be guests of President and Mrs. Johnson in Texas this weekend.

THE big, black limousine pulled up in front of an old, gray, five-story building on East Fourth Street owned by Universal Pictures. A film unit manager, supplied by Universal with the car, pointed to its upper stories. "That's the location of the two pads where your principals live in the film," he said to the chic, elderly woman in the back seat.

Chet Huntley went on the air last night with his 7 o'clock news report despite a strike by the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, whose members set up picket lines against the three television networks at 5 A.M. yesterday.

The Burroughs Corporation announced yesterday that it had received a $32-million contract from Barclays Bank, Ltd., for a computer system to connect most of the bank's 2,500 branches in Britain with its London headquarters.

BALTIMORE, March 29 Twenty-six states objected before a three-judge Federal court here today to the Congressional extension of Federal minimum wage and hour provisions to millions of low-salaried state public hospital and public school employes.
The city has refused to give certificates of occupancy to two tenements involved in a highly publicized experiment in "instant" slum rehabilitation.

The appointment of a threeman board of investigators to determine the causes leading to the stranding of the Liberianflag tanker Torrey Canyon off the Cornwall coast of England on March 18 was announced here yesterday by Albert J. Rudick, deputy commissioner of maritime affairs for Liberia.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 29--President Tito is using a recent dispute over the Serbo-Croatian language as an occasion to criticize liberal elements within the Communist party.

A group of enthusiastic oarsmen at Notre Dame have not received intercollegiate team status, but the Fighting Irish heavyweight oarsmen made a lasting impression on Fordham yesterday. The Notre Dame freshman and varsity club crews defeated the Rams on the Olympic course off Orchard Beach.

A Canadian psychiatrist said yesterday that social and personal pressures produced by the accelerating pace of Western society were either causing or aggravating many physical as well as mental illnesses.

PAGET, Bermuda "I am a typical government employe's wife," Mrs. George W. Renchard said as she glanced through a picture window of her home to a view that swept beyond a Bermuda moongate and onto the Atlantic. "The paintings and portraits on the walls are ours, but everything else belongs to the house."
ATHENS, March 29 Greece faced another political crisis tonight. A disagreement between the country's two main political parties imperiled the caretaker Cabinet.
The proposed Gimbels store at Lexington Avenue and 86th Street will be built by the department store chain rather than constructed by a developer and leased to Gimbels as originally planned.

All local governments within New York State are creatures of the state. Their boundaries, their fiscal powers, their governmental powers are all fixed by the state. Yet the local government provisions of the present State Constitution are so complex that relatively few specialists understand them. Local officials are constantly seeking the advice of the Controller and the Attorney General as to what they can and cannot do.

The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday it would build a $20-million, automated plant at Oyster Creek, Tex., to produce vinyl chloride, which is used in the manufacture of several plastics. The plant is scheduled for completion early in 1969.

Gasoline supplies in the nation in the week ended last Friday fell to 221,441,000 barrels from 222,369,000 barrels a week earlier and 215,908,000 barrels in the corresponding week a year ago, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, March 29 (UPI) A grand jury investigating an alleged conspiracy to assassinate President Kennedy questioned today the former roommate of the late David W. Ferrie.

Washington, March 29 Following are the texts of a statement by President Johnson today and of a report to him by a panel headed by Under Secretary of State Nicholas deB. Katzenbach on the Central Intelligence Agency and private American voluntary organizations:
MIAMI BEACH, March 29 (AP) A pair of bowlers from Muskegon, Mich., jumped into first place in the Classic doubles division today at the American Bowling Congress tournament.

ALBANY, March 29 A bill that would allow policemen to moonlight, passed by the Legislature and sent to Governor Rockefeller a week ago, has been recalled from the Governor's desk by the sponsor, amended and reintroduced.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 29 South Vietnamese militiamen are holding several civilians prisoners until the Vietcong release 15 persons they kidnapped last Sunday, a United States mission spokesman said tonight.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 29 (AP) Illinois appointed two of its former athletic stars, Jim Vlek and Harv Schmidt, as head football and basketball coaches, respectively, today.
WASHINGTON, March 29 The world's total stock of monetary gold declined last year for the first time on record, the International Monetary Fund reported today.
SANDUSKY, Ohio, March 29 Dr. Frank J. Prout, retired president of Bowling Green State University, died late last night in Good Samaritan Hospital here at the age of 84.
The Rangers burned the candle at both ends last night, but produced a lovely glow for 14,121 impressionable fans at Madison Square Garden.

The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered an investigation yesterday into charges made by its staff that two Philadelphia-based mutual funds had incurred "un necessary brokerage costs" in order to favor a securities concern that retails their shares.
CHERBOURG, France, March 29 France launched her first nuclear-powered submarine, the 7,900-ton Redoutable, today and took a long stride toward becoming the world's fourth nuclear naval power.
Bob Cassidy of Levittown, L.I., scored a close unanimous decision over Carmelo Hernandez of Puerto Rico in a 10-round middleweight fight last night.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI) Secretary of State Dean Rusk today accepted on behalf of former President Harry S. Truman an ancient bronze Athenian helmet from Greece to mark the 20th anniversary of the Truman Doctrine.

PORTH NAVAS, England March 29 Cornish oystermen and engineers pitted their ingenuity against the water today in a race to save four million oysters from contamination by oil from the wrecked tanker Torrey Canyon.

The city's budget director said yesterday he believed that Albany's estimate of the revenue the city would get from an expanded state lottery was $20million too high. But he did not feel there would be a serious threat to present city programs.
An 800-page book compiled by computer will sell for $225 on its publication this year by The New York Times.
GREENSBORO, N.C., March 29 Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus have similar goals, but they have chosen different fairways to reach their objective.

ALBANY, March 29--Governor Rockefeller and the legislative leaders were reported today to be pressing nearer to a compromise agreement on overhauling the antistrike statute for public employes--the Condon-Wadlin Law.
When the 350-passenger jumbo jets take to the air in January, 1970, they will have many of the comforts of luxury cruise ships, if Trans World Airlines' present thinking is carried out.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 29 The last three paragraphs of the United States' communication to Secretary General Thant, commenting on his revised peace proposals for Vietnam, were omitted inadvertently from the text published in The New York Times this morning. The paragraphs follow:
PARIS, March 29 It is springtime in Paris, couples embrace at cafe tables and the Prefecture of Police is trying to turn people's minds to thoughts of rats.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI) The Justice Department told the Supreme Court today that the full thrust of the oneman, one-vote principle would be lost unless it was extended to local governing bodies.

A longtime member of the Lexington Democratic Club, the city's oldest Reform organization, charged yesterday that its vote for district leader was a "farce" because many who voted did not live in the district.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 29 (UPI) A Federal judge rejected today three draft appeals by Cassius Clay, paving the way for the heavyweight champpion's induction into the Army April 28.
Eight awards for achievement were presented yesterday as part of a "Salute to the Jews in the Arts" by the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations.

The Savings Banks Association of New York State urged Governor Rockefeller and the leaders of the State Legislature yesterday to give their "personal attention" to a pending bill that would allow savings banks here to make unsecured personal loans a type of credit extension currently barred to the savings banks.

NEW ORLEANS, March 29 The full United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed today a farreaching decision that six Southern states must integrate their public schools from kindergarten up at the start of the fall term this year.
BUDAPEST, March 29 (AP) Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty observed his 73th birthday in the United States Embassy today.

The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service yesterday awarded Sea-Land Service, Inc., one of the nation's major operators of containerships, a two-year, $70-million contract for the transport of Department of Defense cargoes between the West Coast and South Vietnam.
Bertrand Russell wrote his memoirs of the first 42 years, of his life 10 years ago. The work, called, "The Autobioggraphy of Bertrand Russell," will be released by Little-Brown on April 17.

Luther Lassiter of Elizabeth City, N.C., remained unbeaten in the world pocket billiards championship at the Statler Hilton yesterday by beating Lou Butera of West Pittston, Pa., 150-118. Lassiter has won 10 matches.
SEOUL, South Korea, March 29--A South Korean prosecutor formally indicted today Sgt. Billy J. Cox of the United States Air Force for trial by a Korean court on charges of arson and assault.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 29 (UPI) The Oklahoma House of Representatives passed by a one-vote margin today a bill legalizing therapeutic abortion. One lawmaker said it was aimed at halting "roadside abortions," and another said it could make the state "the abortion center of the Southwest."
The American Stock Exchange drifted down yesterday for the third consecutive session.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation sold $200-million of debentures yesterday that were priced to give investors a yield of 5.375 per cent.

BERLIN, March 29 The East German Communists, involved in a drive to break away from identity with West Germany, have renewed pressure against the churches to make them cut ties across the EastWest border.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 29 (AP) Gov. Spiro T. Agnew said last night that he had withdrawn from negotiations in the 168-day-old Baltimore tugboat strike.
DENVER, March 29 (UPI) For eight days, Mrs. Pearl Pratt mourned the death of her son in Vietnam. She and her 11 other children sadly awaited the funeral.
Jeremiah T. Ford 2d was discharged yesterday as athletic director of the University of Pennsylvania, a post he had held for 14 years.
ATLANTA, March 29 Gov Lester G. Maddox, who rose to power on a platform of militant segregation, said today that he definitely would hire Negroes for responsible positions in the state government.
Roland Maycock, vice president and formerly associate general counsel of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, was appointed general counsel yesterday.

"I can't find my stock certificate. Get me another one." The many brokers who receive such calls each week usually respond by advising the caller to notify the bank that acts as transfer agent for the shares that are lost.
MUNICH, Germany, March 29 (Reuters) Fritz Schaeffer, West German Finance Minister from 1949 to 1957, died in a hospital near Berchtesgaden tonight. He was 79 years old.
DETROIT, March 29 (UPI) The General Motors Chevrolet Division called back today 12,602 new Corvairs to correct a possible defect that might cause the steering shaft to snap.

William Maidman, executive vice president of the Central Foundry Company, told shareholders in a proxy statement yesterday that he would seek to replace Sidney Gondelman, chairman and president of the company.

NEW ORLEANS, Thursday, March 30 A Delta Air Lines DC-8 with six persons aboard crashed about a mile south of New Orleans International Airport early today. All six persons on the training flight were presumed killed.
Isaac Dov Berkowitz, a sonin-law of Sholem Aleichem and a distinguished author, playwright and translator in his own right, died yesterday in a Tel Aviv hospital at the age of 81.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 29 When Buzzie Bavasi, the wheelerdealer of the Dodgers, included Pete Richert in the six-player trade with the Washington Senators before the 1965 season, he did it with reluctance. It was part of the price he had to pay in order to get Claude Osteen to round out the Dodger staff.
A suit to prevent Adam Clayton Powell from running in the special Congressonal election April 11 was dismissed yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich.
VIENNA, March 29 (AP) The Soviet Union hockey team defeated Czechoslovakia, 4-2, amid stormy scenes tonight and finished the world tournament unbeaten for its fifth consecutive title.
Under banner headlines in the world press, editorialists and churchmen of many countries and faiths welcomed yesterday the encyclical "On the Development of Peoples" issued by Pope Paul VI.
President Johnson has done the expected in reappointing William McChesney Martin Jr. to another four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 29 (UPI) Don Larsen and Art Mahaffey, pitchers, were cut from the San Francisco Giants' roster today along with two young players. However, Bill Henry, a left-handed pitcher, gained a second chance.

BONN, March 29 The United States has given written assurances to West Germany that the proposed treaty to forbid the spread of nuclear weapons would not prevent the establishment of a European nuclear force in the event of the political unification of Western Europe.
A bill prefiled in the City Council yesterday would virtually assure detectives of life tenure in their jobs, barring misbehavior.

WHITE PLAINS, March 29 The Westchester Board of Supervisors was asked today by County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian to buy 802 acres of rolling woodland at Muscoot in the town of Somers for the county's open-space land bank.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 29 (AP) Cologne scored a major upset today as she won the $32,200 Suwannee River Handicap at Gulfstream Park over a turf course made soft and slow by heavy rains.

The head of the printers local said yesterday that his union did not plan to strike tonight against five of the city's major newspapers, even if no agreement has been reached by midnight when the current contracts expire.

Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting Corporation, is opposed to a proposed amendment by Senator J. W. Fulbright that would restrict the use within the United States of books and other materials of the United States Information Agency's overseas program.

Mrs. Robert Rehm of Asheville, N. C., and Milton M. Ferrell of Miami have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Ferrell, to John William Cronin Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cronin of Warwick, R. I. A spring wedding at the Plaza is planned.

Roy L. Reierson, senior vice president and chief economist of the Bankers Trust Company, said yesterday that there is a better than even chance that the economy can avoid a "fullfledged" recession in 1967.
PHILADELPHIA, March 29 (AP) The Philadelphia Yearly Meeting of Friends (Quakers) said today it would defy an official American ban and send medical supplies directly to North Vietnam.
ONLY one undefeated team survives in the New York Double Elimination Knockout Championship.

DEMAREST, N. J., March 29 Mr. and Mrs. Clarence J. Cook have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Cecelia Cook, to David William Benfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Benfield of Savannah, Ga.
MOSCOW, March 29 Novy Mir, the liberal literary journal, came under a new volley of criticism today and was warned to halt its ideological transgressions.

WASHINGTON, March 29 The Department of Labor has warned the supervisors of about 500 apprentice programs that apprentices will be barred from Federal projects unless the programs comply with the department's antidiscrimination policy by April 10.

Federated Mortgage Investors, one of two concerns that resulted last year when the former Kirkeby-Natus Corporation divided its business into two parts, reported yesterday in its annual report that it had sustained an operating loss of $971,234 during the period from June 25 through Dec. 31, 1966.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 29 A Roman Catholic Bishop from Jerusalem said here today that while the church was seeking an answer to world poverty, "the poor are not in the church we are not the church of the poor."
PARIS, March 29 Charles Flammarion, a prominent Paris book publisher, died here today. He was 83 years old.

Harold (Kayo) Konigsberg, who led Federal agents to what they have called a Mafia graveyard in New Jersey, will be asked if he knows the whereabouts of the killer of Arnold Schuster, the Brooklyn man who was slain after he had told the police where they could tioning in the slaying of Mr. find Willie Sutton, the bank robber.
The nation's drug manufacturers yesterday withdrew their objections to legislation that would require "informed" written consent from patients who are given experimental drugs.

WASHINGTON, March 29 A Senate report said today that shortages of merchant seamen and junior merchant marine officers had caused some difficulty in shipping for Vietnam but that there was a marked over-all improvement in the movement of war supplies and troops by sea and air.
Free tickets are available for the Festival of New York films, to be held Monday to Wednesday at the Regency Theater, Broadway at 67th Street.

DENVER, March 29 (AP) Federal District Judge William E. Doyle granted a temporary injunction today suspending the proposed transfer of an Air Force captain from the Air Force from the Air Force Academy.
Roy Wilkins, a onetime red cap and stockyard cleanup man, received the Freedom Award of 1967 here last night, and acclaim from President Johnson.
Directors of White Cross Stores, Inc., proposed yesterday in Pittsburgh a 2-for-1 split of the common shares.
R. Minor Eager, a vice president of the Fiduciary Trust Company of New York since 1963, was elected yesterday to the additional post of secretary.

WALL STREET handicappers are guessing that the president of Mack Trucks, Zenon C.R. Hansen, is looking for a merger partner that will pay a big price for consolidation and will let Mr. Hansen run the company his own way, fortified with lots of new cash.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 29 Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. led Florida Republicans to new heights yesterday and enhanced his own reputation as a vote getter as the party won more than 35 per cent of the seats in the State Legislature.
Mrs. David B. Caminez of 201 East 79th Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Bette Louise Caminez, to David Laurence Klein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Klein of Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, March 29 The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust suit today against the National Farmers Organization, charging that it had sought to monopolize the sale of milk in a 19-state area.
The city's nine television stations will ask the Board of Estimate today to hold up approval of the controversial World Trade Center for 60 days.
GENEVA, March 29 Senior government officials decided today to allow themselves more time to deal with the two crucial issues at the Kennedy round of trade negotiations.

YONKERS, March 29 Mrs. Marjorie Semple Rogers, who retired in 1965 as director of the Needlework and Pattern Design Studio of the McCall Corporation, New York magazine and pattern publishers, died yesterday in her home at 1 Sherwood Terrace.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 29 Radio Baghdad announced tonight that the Iraq Petroleum Company had made an initial payment of 22-million ($60.6million) to the Iraqi Government for oil production royalties for the first quarter of 1967.
LONDON, March 29--Miss Corinna Dixon, younger daughter of Lady Dixon and the late Sir Pierson Dixon, was married today to James Leslie Hamilton, elder son of Lord and Lady Hamilton of Dalzell.
The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has called off its threat to picket City Hall today.
MASS-PRODUCED interpretations of modern classics in furniture go on view today in two rooms and a gallery on the ninth floor at Gimbels.
WASHINGTON, March 29 President Johnson renamed William McChesney Martin Jr. today as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, ending months of argument and speculation.
TeenSet, with a dinky national monthly circulation of 200,000, is preparing for a special edition with a 2.25-million run.
The Continental Football League crashed into the line yesterday that says a professional sport cannot successfully exist without a New York franchise.
CHATEAU MADRID, 42 West 58th Street, Andy Russell, singer, Held over: Joaquin Robles's Flamenco Ballet.

WASHINGTON, March 29 President Johnson directed the Central Intelligence Agency today to end covert financing of private voluntary organizations and ordered a study to find new ways of supporting such groups openly.
The spot rate on the British pound eased somewhat in moderate trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 29 The New York Yankees ended a week's tour of Florida's west coast today, leaving behind a poor record and persistent reports that they were trying to negotiate two sizable trades.

LONDON, March 29 Ralph Schoenman, secretary of the socalled International War Crimes Tribunal sponsored by the Bertrand Russell Peace Foundation, said today that if the proposed trial could not be held in Paris it would be moved to Stockholm.
ALBANY, March 29 (UPI) The Senate approved by 54-2 today an Administration bill to enlarge purses for thoroughbred racing in New York State.
WASHINGTON, March 29--In Washington social and intellectual circles, Cord Meyer Jr. has been well known for many years. To the liberals of this college generation, his name means nothing.
Jean Xceron, one of the pioneers of nonobjective painting in this country, died yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital. His age was 77 and he lived at 47 West 74th Street.

LOS ANGELES, March 29 "Stuff and nonsense," was the general reaction at the University of California, Los Angeles, today to the new rule, adopted yesterday by the Natuonal Basketball Committee, that bans "basket-stuffing" in the college game.

The Southern Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday that 1966 sales of electric energy rose by 10.8 per cent, while operating revenues were up 9 per cent and net income were up 4.6 per cent. Harllee Branch Jr., president, put operating revenues at $486,934,000, against $446,833,000 a year earlier.

The American News Company has signed an agreement to purchase the operating assets of Nemrow Brothers, a leading tobacco wholesaler in New England, Henry Garfinkle, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, March 29 Mr. and Mrs. Horace Reynolds Moorhead have made known the engagement of Mrs. Moorhead's daughter, Miss Virginia B. Morris, to John Parker Hoffman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Parker MacDowell Hoffman of Corning, N. Y.
Molly Picon has agreed to act in two shows, the tryout of "The Rubiyat of Howard Klein" and "Funny Girl," both on the summer circuit.
CHATHAM, N.J., March 29--William W. Goddard, a former real estate broker in Elizabeth, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital, Summit, on his 84th birthday.
A suit seeking to enjoin the Legal Aid Society from representing defendants in the city's criminal courts has been dismissed by State Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich.
A 17-year-old youth who came here seven months ago from South Carolina was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder on Tuesday of a 74-year-old Bronx tailor.

Officials of three railroads opposed to the inclusion of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad in the proposed Pennsylvania-New York Central Railroad merger concluded their case yesterday before an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner in New York.

ONE of the marks of a grand master is his ability to snatch victory from a deadeven position. In the recent international tournament in Majorca, a former world champion, Mikhail Tal of the Soviet Union, upset the Span ish star Antonio Medina.
Key leaders of the Democratic Reform movement sought yesterday to undercut a proposal assertedly designed to unify the Manhattan Democratic organization.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 30 (AP) An armed United States Army helicopter accidentally hit a South Vietnamese village with two rockets, killing three Victnamese civilians and wounding 20, the United States command said today.

NORTHRIDGE, Calif., March 29 Fencers from 36 colleges begin competition tomorrow in the 23d annual National Collegiate Athletic Association championships here. New York University is the defending champion.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 29 The Democratic candidate clung to a thin but probably decisive lead today in a special Congressional election that was closely watched for clues to continued national Republican resurgence in 1968.
CLEVELAND, March 29 Dr. Elizabeth G. Meier, professor of special work at the School of Applied Social Sciences at Western Reserve University, died today at University Hospital here. Her age was 54.

A specialist in cooperative housing, Hyman Goodman, has joined Mark Rafalsky Co. as a vice president. He will be in charge of acquiring and supervising cooperative and condominium developments for the real estate company.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 29 Dr. Phan Khac Suu, Speaker of the Constituent Assembly, predicted today that "some sort of settlement" of the war would be sought by "all parties concerned" after the elections next fall.

The Botticelli Ball, a dinner dance sponsored by Orphans of Italy, was held last night at the Plaza for the benefit of the St. Philip Youth Center in Florence, Italy. The center was damaged by the floods last fall.
Alex Webster, who holds three club records as a ball carrier for the New York Giants, was signed as a fulltime assistant coach by the National Football League club yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 29 The Federal Government has taken another step to reduce racial discrimination in its 30year-old public housing program. The program has been a target of civil rights groups in recent years.
The appointment of Richard G. Davis as executive vice president was announced yesterday in Los Angeles by the Rexall Chemical Company.

A new communications center designed to withstand nuclear blasts is being built in a 47-foot-deep hole in the ground in Netcong, N.J., for the Long Lines Department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
THE first 90-minute documentary about a record ing, "The Golden Ring," was shown over WNDT, Channel 13, last night, and the story it told was engrossing on several levels.
Vice President Humphrey will help the New York Stock Exchange celebrate its 175th anniversary as the main speaker at a public ceremony May 17 on the steps of Federal Hall.

PARIS, March 29 Prevailing winds and currents will almost certainly carry oil across the English Channel from the Torrey Canyon to the beaches and oyster beds of Normandy and Brittany, French authorities said today.
THE National Ballet of Washington, now at the City Center for a first brief Broadway season, had two new things and two old things to offer last night.

Two labor relations consultants, one of whom was a former union official who allegedly dominated a number of locals, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to violate the Taft-Hartley and Landrum-Griffin Laws.

Dr. Samuel W. Boorstein, an orthopedic surgeon who for many years was affiliated with Fordham Hospital and with the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, died Tuesday in Tel Aviv, where he had lived since retiring in 1964. He was 82 years old.
Landlords who install equipment to reduce air pollution, in compliance with the city's new Air Pollution Control Law, are going to have to pay the city for the water used in the installations.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., March 29 Mrs. Joseph S. Lamborghini has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Janet Edith Lamborghini, to Nicholas Canaday Spitzer. He is the son of Prof. and Mrs. Lyman Spitzer Jr. of Princeton, N. J.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) Seiho Matsuoka, the chief executive of Okinawa, told President Johnson today that the people of the Ryukyu Islands want to return to Japanese rule as soon as possible.
WASHINGTON, March 29 Educators and doctors should spend less time cursing LSD and more time telling students the facts about it, a physician from California said here today.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 29 (AP) Bolivia's army commander reported today that the army was tightening its ring around a large band of leftist guerrillas in southeastern Bolivia and the air force continued to attack the insurgents with napalm and machine guns.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 29 (AP) H.A. (Bud) Millikan resigned today as coach of the University of Maryland basketball team and his assistant, Frank Fellows, was named to succeed him.
MEXICO CITY, March 29 (AP) Charlie Pasarell, America's fourth-ranking player, was upset by Jose Gisbert of Spain, 6-4, 6-4, in the first round of Mexico City's international tennis tournament today.
POLITICS is the art of the voluble. It flourishes on such controversial talk as John H. Bunzel showers through "AntiPolitics in America."

CASPER, Wyo., March 29 (UPI) A United Air Lines 720 jet carrying 49 persons plunged 8,000 feet in air turbulence over Wyoming today but landed safely here. One man was killed when he released his seat belt to protect his month-old grandson.

LONDON, Thursday, March 30 Eighty-eight members of Parliament were among the 334 sponsors of an advertisement in The Times of London today that called on the British Government "to dissociate itself from the bombing of North Vietnam by explicitly endorsing the peace proposals" recently made by Secretary General Thant of the United Nations.
Mr. and Mrs. Irving L. Welsher have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Annette Welsher, to Jeremy M. Grossman, son of Dr, and Mrs. Jonathan Grossman of Bethesda, Md.

MONTREAL, March 29 (UPI) The Montreal Canadiens took over sole possession of second place in the National Hockey League tonight when they defeated Toronto, 5-3, to drop the Maple Leafs into fourth place.

Another cliff-hanger is over. At the very last minute Governor Rockefeller and the leaders of the Legislature have managed to find a formula that will give Mayor Lindsay just enough funds to keep New York City from financial disaster. The trouble is that this new reprieve also insures that the city will face another financial crisis a year from now.
STUART, Fla. There's fishing water almost every where in this part of the country from the sea west to Lake Okeechobee. Much of it consists of drainage ditches and canals.

THERE was no need for exhibitors, whose dogs had gained awards, to express more than the conventional "thank you" to show judges who had made the selections, said William L. Kendrick of Devon, Pa., at a recent meeting of the Dog Fanciers Club at the Overseas Press Club.
CAIRO, March 29 (AP)--Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union arrived in Cairo today for suddenly announced talks with leaders of the United Arab Republic.
NEW DELHI, March 29--Six persons were killed and 100 were injured today during a clash between Hindus and Sikhs in Calcutta.

Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner yesterday blocked efforts to split the New York City school system into five school districts, each with its own borough school board.

The Papal encyclical "On the Development of Peoples" is remarkably advanced in its economic philosophy. It is sophisticated, comprehensive and penetrating, and it shows a profound grasp of the problems of developed versus underdeveloped countries in their technical as well as moral and religious aspects.

WASHINGTON, March 29 An increase of seven million acres in land planted to corn and other feed grains was urged today by the president of the Corn Refiners Association "to avoid very high prices for meats, poultry and other foods."
Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Sweeney died last night in a fire that broke out in the Gordian Knot Nautical Restaurant, just below their second-floor apartment at 1584 York Avenue between 83d and 84th Streets.
A flurry of liquidation marked the opening of trading in wheat futures yesterday as traders responded to a five-day Government weather forecast.
A cocktail preview of paintings by Jean Venitien at the Frank Partridge Gallery, 6 West 56th Street, will be held on April 12.
Best Co., which operates a specialty store here with 15 branch outlets, announced yesterday the election of Ronald Ruskin to the new post of merchandising vice president.

WASHINGTON, March 29 It is at least possible that the Katzenbach committee, in its study of the Central Intelligence Agency's involvement with private voluntary organizations, has raised at last the fundamental question of how a free society ought to represent itself abroad.

WASHINGTON, March 29 The chief of the Federal Government's organized crime unit charged today that the teamsters' union and the East Coast longshoremen's union were linked with each other and the Cosa Nostra.
LAND'S END, England, March 29 The wreck of the Torrey Canyon was hit anew today with bombs, napalm, rockets and kerosene in a further effort to destroy the tanker and her remaining oil cargo.

The American Electric Power Company sold 1.2 million shares of common stock at competitive bidding yesterday to an investment banking syndicate managed by the First Boston Corporation and Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co.

WASHINGTON, March 29 After being on the defensive for weeks, the United States believes it has been handed a diplomatic windfall in the maneuvering over Vietnam peace proposals.

Robert Moses said yesterday that construction activities of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority would absorb "most, if not all" of the agency's surpluses "for at least the next three years."

Curtis Cokes, a world champion with only regional celebrity, and Gypsy Joe Harris, who has rarely fought outside his native Philadelphia, will make their first appearances at Madison Square Garden tonight.

PEKING, March 30 (Agence France-Presse)--China's army moved into another field today, taking control of the Cantral Trade Bureau, as Peking announced that "eddies of counterrevolutionary restoration" threatened Maoist groups throughout the country.

VIENNA, March 30--Fiftysix Czechoslovaks who had come here to attend the ice hockey world championships, which ended yesterday, have decided not to return home and have asked for asylum in Austria, the Ministry of the Interior said today.

EVER since James Jones's new mammoth novel was first announced I have been misreading its title as "Go to the Window-Maker." How intriguing, I thought-- Mr. Jones has gone and written my very own story, all about the volcanic emotions that beset a do-it-yourselfer at the moment of truth.
ST. IVES, England, March 30 --Infantrymen sprayed detergent to try to break up oil puddles on Porthmeor Beach today.
Doyle, Dane, Bernbach picked up 18 awards at the third annual Andy Awards black-tie dinner of the Advertising Club of New York, held last night in the New York Hilton.

The Rev. John Courtney Murray, the prominent Jesuit theologian, described Pope Paul's newest encyclical yesterday as "the church's definitive answer to Marxism."

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 30 (UPI)--Judge William J. Kirby of the Pulaski County Circuit Court released today two newsmen jailed for refusing to answer questions of a grand jury investigating a reported attempt to bribe a state legislator.
NEW DELHI, March 30 (AP) --Morarji Desai, Indian Deputy Prime Minister, rejected demands from Communist members of Parliament today that American Peace Corps volunteers be expelled from India.

GENEVA, March 30. A Brazilian representative said today that his Government intended to produce its own nuclear explosions "as soon as possible" for suoh peaceful purposes as creating waterways to link the basins of the Amazon and the Rio de la, Plata.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 30--The New York Yankees made some significant gains today despite a 4-3 loss to the Minnesota Twins, the third straight Yankee defeat and fifth in the last six games.

Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he considered the Arthur J. Goldberg-for-Senate boom among some leading Democrats an indication that President Johnson was worried about winning New York's electoral votes in the 1968 election.

A picture of a dog with drooping ears and a forlorn face is posted on a management bulletin board in the composing room of The Daily News. Surrounding the dog are the words, "We're mighty sad when we don't hear from you. How about some suggestions?"
The stock market declined slightly yesterday in relatively quiet trading. Price changes were small for the most part, with the glamour stocks showing the largest declines.
The 11th International Automobile show will open today in the Coliseum on Columbus Circle.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., March 31--Miss Barbara Ann Newhouse and Harold Martin Reiss plan to be married in August.

BATRI, South Vietnam, March 28--A recently captured Vietcong document instructing Communist guerrillas on how to counter the Government's pacification plan says: "The leader of the program is very determined to succeed."
Members of the Board of Education met with Mayor Lindsay yesterday to protest a legislative plan that would require the Mayor to chart a decentralization of the city's school system.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)--Key features of the Uniform Time Act go into effect tomorrow with prospects that virtually the entire continental United States will switch to daylight saving time for six months at 2 A.M. April 30.
CORNING, Iowa, March 31 (UPI)--The leader of the milk holding action said today that his followers would begin selling dairy cows for slaughter in a move to force milk prices higher.
PALMA, Majorca, March 31 --The prospect of a mediation effort in Vietnam by the InterParliamentary Union was raised today at its conference here.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporatibn signed a $26-million contract yesterday to develop and install automatic-train, control-and-communications equipment for the Bay Area Rapid Transit District in San Francisco.

ROME, March 31--A total of $1.5-million worth of medical aid for North Vietnam has been donated by Roman Catholics and distributed by the International Red Cross, Msgr. Fausto Vallainc, the Vatican press officer, said in a news conference today. He indicated that this aid started recently.
Small price cuts on steel plate will result for some customers because of a new billing formula announced yesterday by the United States Steel Corporation.
ALBANY, March 31--Negotiations on a new antistrike law for public employes that had been reported "within a hair" of agreement this afternoon appeared to have deteriorated abruptly late tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 31-- Trucking industry negotiators threatened today to halt twothirds of the nation's, truck operations if the teamsters' union tried to "whipsaw" them with a selective strike.

THE American Contract Eridge League bids fare well to New York City today after 30 years of residence. In its early years, under the guidance of William E. McKenney, the league's central offices were in the Park Central Hotel, but for almost two decades they have been ,at 33 West 60th Street in space that has been progressively less adequate to the needs of an expanding organization.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 31--Mihajlo Mihajlov, a writer and political activist who is serving a jail term for persistent criticism of Yugoslavia's Communist party and Government, will be tried on new charges April 17.

Miss Roberta Buchan O'Connell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. O'Connell of New York and New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Mark DeWolf Gibson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Langhorne Gibson of Greenwood, Va.

The Mutual Broadcasting System, Inc., and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists reached agreement last night. The union said that newsmen and staff announcers would go back to work immediately.
ALBANY, March 31--A bill to eliminate half the special guardians now appointed by Surrogates' Courts won unanimous and final legislative approval in the State Senate today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 1 (AP)--Four Vietcong battalions--totaling 2,000 men--were repulsed today in an attempt to smash a big United States force pushing toward a vital enemy hideout in the jungle.

PARIS, March 31--A number of French housewives have stopped buying fish because they are afraid it will taste like fuel oil, it was reported today. New evidence indicates that their fear has some foundation.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 31 (AP)--Kansas University set a world record of 3 minutes 15.2 seconds in the sprint medley relay tonight as Jim Ryun ran a 1:46.1 half-mile anchor leg at the 40th Texas Relays. The previous record of 3:15.5 was set by the Santa Clara Youth VillaGe in 1961.
Adam Clayton Powell's plan to organize a Negro "third force" In national politics drew a qualified endorsement yesterday from William H. Booth, chairman of the city's Human Rights Commission.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 31 (AP)--Gretel won her first race against Dame Pattie today in their America's Cup preliminary trials as rough seas damaged both yachts, swept two crewmen overboard and injured another.
The Religious Society of Friends (Quakers) is developing the first fully accredited seminary in its 312-year history.

Mayor Lindsay sent the first draft of his 1967-68 executive budget to the printers last night, saying that it would not cause a cut in essential services despite his failure to win all the state help he had sought.
The doors on a speeding crowded subway car slid open without warning yesterday morning, but thanks to two quick-reacting passengers no one was hurt.
WASHINGTON, March 31-- Two Illinois physicists have patented a method of keeping the occupants of offices, cars and aircraft from getting tired and sleepy.

Mr. O'Brlen, a tough, hardfisted former prize fighter who was born in the back of the yards district near Chicago's stockyards, started his teamster career as a helper on a horse-drawn beer wagon when he was 15 years old. He earned $8 a week rolling beer barrels onto and off the wagon.
Andrei Voznesensky, one of the Soviet Union's leading poets, is scheduled to arrive April 10 or 11 to begin a coast-tocoast poetry-reading tour of universities and colleges.

BOSTON, March 31--Philip Elman, Commissioner of the Federal Trade Commission, strongly urged today that his agency concentrate on fulfilling its intended regulatory role and leave the policing of antitrust laws to the Department of Justice.

The Houston Natural Gas Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday sizable gains in operating revenues and net income for the 12-month period ended Jan. 31, John H. Wimberly, president, confirmed that negotiations are in progress for his company to acquire Rio Grande Valley Gas Company of Brownsville, Tex. Tentative
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31--A study of nearly 1,000 high school students has indicated that youngsters have decided whether they will become smokers by the time they are 15 years old.
Although her chances did not appear very good when she left the gate slowly, Arrangement of the Tartan Stable proved to be the best in the field of eight in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Habana 2d of Quezon City, Luzon, and Davao City, Mindanao, the Philippines, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Salud Teresita Habana, to Kingsley Wood. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Meredith Wood of Scarsdale, N.Y.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., March 31--The head of the Chesapeake Ohio and Baltimore Ohio Railroads said today that if the Pennsylvania and New York Central merger plan "gets caught in the switches and dissolves, I do not think there is any chance" of the C. O. being able to complete its merger with the Norfolk Western Railway.
PHILADELPHIA, March 31 --Circus fans with good memories are getting an unexpected treat during the Ringling Bros. and Barnum Bailey six-day run here.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31 (AP)--Rico Carty drove in two runs with a double and a triple today and led the Atlanta Braves to a 4-2 exhibition game victory over the Minnesota Twins.

Gypsy Joe Harris, jiggling and squirming and lurching to a mad music inside his shaven skull, won a unanimous 10round decision last night at Madison Square Garden from Curbs Cokes, the welterweight champion.

TOKYO--How fares the classical kimono in mod ern, tradition-breaking Japan? Better than ever for formal wear, not only among fashion-conscious women but also, in the distinctive male version, for status-minded men, according to a consensus of experts interviewed here and in Kyoto, a center of the kimono trade.
"I may have made some mistakes. The same may be true for my former partners. But I do not want to engage in recriminations because I have never believed that anyone is infallible"

MOST of the ingredients in Erico Verissimo's new novel will be familiar to anyone who has read at all in Latin American affairs or simply read the newspapers. Incidents like the Galindez case, the kidnapping of a Dominican exile who was also a professor the public trials in Havana ...
Lincoln Center today: Mourning Becomes Electra," 2 P.M., and "Kie Zauberfloete," 8, Metropolitan Opera; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.
NEWPORT furniture of the 18th century continues to be the most expensive Americana and also the most in demand, despite new trends evident at antique shows.
The career of Rodion Yakovlcvich Malinovsky and the fortunes of the Communist party of the Soviet Union were closely intertwined through 50 years of Soviet power.
LONDON, March 31--The British Government decided today to go ahead with its purchase of the American F-111, the controversial swing-wing attack plane. Officials signed an order for 40 of the planes.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 31--George Archer, who lives on a ranch but roams fairways for a livelihood, led the $125,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament today. The 6-foot-6inch former cowboy from Gilroy, Calif., tied the course record with a 64 that gave him a 36-hole aggregate of 131.

A 24-year-old electronics expert, who had $15,000 worth of Bell Telephone System equipment, was arraigned yesterday on charges of illegal electronic eavesdropping and criminal possession of the telephone equipment. He is Robert L. Mion of 2019 Arthur Avenue.

The immediate threat of a newspaper strike eased somewhat yesterday, but the printers' union exerted new pressures for contract concessions by holding three meetings in the composing room of The Daily News.

GENEVA, March 31--Eric Wyndham White, the International trade official who guides the Kennedy round of tariffcutting negotiations, made a major bid today to break the deadlock in the key chemical sector.
Gordon Hilker is probably the only impressario in the world Who can lecture about politics and pigeons whose whistles don't whistle properly.

MOGADISCIO, Somalia, March 27--Mogadiscio looks best at night when the sun's glare is gone and when moonlight spills over Moorish domes and the patchwork of roofs, blotting out the eyesores of the city's daytime countenance.
Operations of the Gulf American Corporation in the six months ended February 28 resulted in reduced sales and earnings from the levels of the corresponding period a year ago.

Three detectives investigating a stolen-car ring were shot down on a Brooklyn Street yesterday by a man who escaped on foot, armed with a police revolver. The gun belonged to one of the three detectives.

LAS VEGAS, Nev.,, March 31 (AP)--Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said they had found today $67,000 of the $500,000 that disappeared from a California bank when Roger Lee Williams, a bank official, vanished last July 15 with his two young daughters.

Consolidation of the David Taylor Model Basin in Carderock, Md., and the Navy Marine Engineering Laboratory in Annapolis into the Naval Ship Research and Development Center was announced yesterday by Vice Admiral I.J. Galantin, Chief of Naval Material.

Consumers have become more optimistic in the last few months in their attitudes toward purchases and the state of the economy, the Survey Research Center of the University of Michigan reported yesterday.
BY a kind of consciousnessexpanding coincidence, not one but two uptown galleries are turned on this week--or, to put it another way, have become psychedelicatessens.

TEANECK, N.J., March 31 --Dr. Herbert J. Stack, the founder and retired director of the Center for Safety Education at New York University, died here today in Holy Name Hospital. He lived at 519 Windham Road.
Three more paper companies announced yesterday they were increasing their newsprint prices by $3 a ton effective July 1.
THE collection of 102 paintings, "Masterpieces From Montreal," that opened Tuesday at the Gallery of Modern Art on Columbus Circle is well enough named.
Still on a roller coaster, wheat futures dropped yesterday after a sharp rise the day before.
NEW DELHI, March 31 (AP)--Foreign Minister M.C. Chagla said today that Stalin's daughter, Mrs. Svetlana Alliluyeva, would be "most welcome" if she wanted to return to India from Switzerland.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 31 --The New York Mets lost to the Chicago White Sox today, 6-4, but a far more significant loss was recorded 30 miles north in a hand-written sign on the Mets' bulletin board that read: "Good Luck, fellows. Mac."

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., March 31--The American Textile Manufacturers Institute heard a warning today about the nation's growing balance of payments deficit, and a new call for restrictions on textile imports.
OAKLAND, Calif., March 31 (UPI)--A Protestant minister presided in a Roman Catholic Church tonight at the wedding of his son and a Catholic woman.

TOKYO, March 31--Concerned over dangers such as the spread of floating oil from a stranded tanker off the coast of Britain, the Japanese Cabinet approved today a move to limit dumping of oil in waters around Japan.
The leaders of a boycott at Public School 125 in West Harlem announced an end to the boycott yesterday, even though their aims had not been realized.

Helen C. Adams, a leader for more than 30 years in the care of the aging, died Thursday at the Miriam Osborn Memorial Home in Rye, N.Y., at the age of 87. She had been disabled by a broken hip in 1960.
Miss Catherine Coholan and F. Richard Mansfield were married here yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour by the bridegroom's cousin, the Rev. James O'Dea.

The Sprague Electric Company's first-quarter profits will be somewhat less than the $1,907,475, or $1.17 a share, earned in the period a year earlier, Robert C. Sprague, president, told shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday in North Adams, Mass.

Mrs. Nina Laura Nathanson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Nathanson, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Michael Birnbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Birnbaum. Both families are of Brooklyn. Judge Nathaniel Kaplan of the Family Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.
THE high fashion specialty stores that have been thinking color when it comes to clothes have now extended the philosophy to letter paper.
Even when he was an 8year-old caddie in WinstonSalem, N.C., Harold bunovant wanted to be a golf teacher. Today, after several false starts, he gets his big chance.

PANAMA, March 31 (AP)-- Leaders of the Inter-American Federation of Working Newspapermen's Organizations say they are convinced that the American Newspaper Guild accepted in good faith funds from foundations later disclosed as supported by the Central Intelligence Agency.
Treasury bill rates declined yesterday to the lowest levels since September, 1965, as the money market ended the week with a spurt in prices.
The election of George J. Grabner as a director of the Lamson Sessions Company was announced yesterday at the annual meeting in Cleveland.

NEW ORLEANS, March 31 (AP)--District Attorney Jim Garrison obtained warrants today for the arrest of Gordon Novel and a Cuban exile leader on charges of conspiring to burglarize a munitions bunker in 1961.
WASHINGTON, March 31-- The rate of accumulation of inventories by manufacturers slowed sharply in February, the Commerce Department reported today. Government economists welcomed the news.
Dr. Uriel Weinreich, a leading linguistic and Yiddish scholar, died Thursday of cancer in Montefiore Hospital. He was 40 years old and lived at 80 La Salle Street.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 31 --The next time local harness racing fans get to see Cardigan Bay it most likely will be in a distance handicap race, in which the great, 11-year-old New Zealand-bred pacer will be weighted down by yardage, rather than by cost position.

The prospect of continued free movies on domestic airlines has dimmed in recent days, but leaders of the airborne movie industry--a multimillion dollar business--are bringing up their big guns to prevent the imposition of a viewing charge.

WASHINGTON, March 31-- A challenge to the authority of the Federal Maritime Commission to issue rules and regulations it deems necessary to administer the Shipping Act of 1916 was turned down today by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
New York State's narcotics addiction control program, the most massive ever tried in the nation, goes into effect today after months of controversy.
Jennifer Tilston, a 20-yearold actress, has made the leap from dramatic school to the Broadway stage in less than two hours.

WASHINGTON, March 31-- Almost a third of the blood collected by American blood banks becomes outdated and must be discrarded before use, according to the head of a Government program organized to reduce the wastage.
The election of David E.A. Carson as a vice president and actuary was announced yesterday by the Hartford Fire Insurance Company and the Hartford Accident and Indemnity Company.

THEY shop together, lunch together, visit Seventh Avenue together. In the evenings they play bridge, go to the theater, visit friends and, occasionally, attend a charity ball. They recently returned from a vacation to Haiti together. They are the fashion inseparables.

WASHINGTON, March 31-- Administration officials said today that Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace's threat to seize the Alabama public schools could lead to another showdown between state and Federal power reminiscent of past confrontations in Arkansas, Mississippi and Alabama.

CASTEAU, Belgium, March 31--The Atlantic alliance formally opened its supreme military headquarters in Belgium today with one minor mishap--the pulley came off the NATO flagpole at a crucial point in the flag-raising ceremonies.
The Automatic Sprinkler Corporation of America, acquisition of Baifield Industries has been approved in principle by Baifield's directors.
A $35-million long-range development plan for the Puerto Rico International Airport at San Juan was announced yesterday by Ruben Sanchez, executive director of the Puerto Rico Ports Authority.
The Waldorf-Astoria's Starlight Roof will be glowing with pink and silver Saturday, and guests at the Pink aad Silver Ball are expected to match their gowns to the decor.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31--South Vietnam's observer at the United Nations made public today Saigon's "agreement in principle" with the main points of SecretaryGeneral Thant's peace proposals. Saigon also added some suggestions of its own.
LANSING, Mich., March 31-- Gov. George Romney asked leading Democrats in the State Legislature today to help save his tax reform program that was defeated in the eSnate last night.

MONACO, Monte Carlo, March 31--The United States chess champion, Eobby Flscher of BrooKlyn, Kept the lead in the Grand Prix International, even though he did not play the seventh round, scheduled for this morning.
WASHINGTON, March 31-- The nation's Democratic state chairmen, unaccustomed as they are to joint public meetings, were overwhelmed with political hospitality today.
ALBANY, March 31--The Assembly gave final approval tonight to Governor Rockefeller's mass transportation plan.
ALBANY, March 31--Former Justice of the New York State Supreme Court Joseph Rosch died today in Albany Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 87 years old.

PEKING, March 31--The supporters of Chairman Mao Tsetung's Cultural Revolution used their heaviest artillery today in opening what appears to be a showdown battle in the struggle to strip all authority from Liu Shao-chi, the chief of state, and two other leaders accused of opposing the Mao line.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday swore in Eugene E. Hult, the Board of Education's top construction man, as the Commissioner of Public Works. The Mayor directed him to reorganize his new department and speed city construction.
The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday it would lay off 21,000 production workers for five days during April because of a sharp decline in the company's auto assembly schedule for the month.
Mayor and Mrs. Lindsay gave a luncheon at City Hall yesterday for Lord and Lady Avon and for the Lindsays' house guests, Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, and Mrs. Hatfield.

Beginning today, the name of the game will be trout. For the hundreds of thousands of New York State fishing license buyers the law proclaims that on All Fool's day with the first glimmering of light, a hardy soul may stand in freezing water and catch brook, brown, rainbow, lake and splake.

BUENOS AIRES, March 31-- The Bolivian Government has asked the United States to provide its army with machine guns and bombs to help wipe out guerrilla forces in the jungle-covered mountains along the country's southeast border.
SOME seasoned Wall Streeters have watched with a mixture of satisfaction and regret as disappointing earnings results cause stock price drops.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)--J. Edgar Hoover, the F.B.I. Director, has assailed organizers of campus filthyspeech movements and the author of the play "MacBird!", asserting that they were "determined to destroy all acceptable standards of personal conduct and sane behavior."
WITH equal amounts of venom, cajolery pie-inthe-sky and the elusive factor called desire, Emile Percy Francis has created the New York Rangers in his own image.
BONN, March 31--A state court in Bavaria has ruled that the labor of the average German hausfrau is worth 1,180 marks ($295) a month, which comes to $3,540 a year.

Rio Algom Mines, Ltd., a diversified metals and mining company based in Toronto, expects higher earnings in the first quarter of 1967 than in the corresponding period a year before, the company's annual meeting was told in Toronto yesterday.

NORTHRIDGE, Calif., March 31--The performance of Mike Gaylor in foil catapulted New York University into a sizable lead today after the second day's competition in the 23d National Collegiate fencing championships.

Irving Friedlander, assistant counsel of the administrative review bureau, State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, died Wednesday of a heart attack here. He was 53 years old and lived at 2220 Wallace Avenue, the Bronx.

SEBRING, Fla., March 31-- Jerry Titus of Sherman Oaks, Calif., drove a Shelby Mustang to a front-running victory in the second of the season's Trans-American sedan races today. He averaged 94,824 miles an hour over Sebring's 5.2-mile road course.

New York's present Constitution has been amended 162 times since it was adopted in 1894. One of the ' most frequent criticisms leveled against it is that its rigidity and excessive detail require cumbersome constitutional amendments for even minor changes. For example, the voters of the state had to approve a constitutional amendment to correct the misspelling in the Constitution of the names of the city of Plattsburg and the village of Keeseville.

A musical setting of the Roman Catholic Mass in the vernacular English text approved by the Ecumenical Council, Vatican II, was given its premiere at Philharmonic Hall last night under the sponsorship of Fordham University.

ALBANY, March 31--A State Senator promises the Iroquois Indians today that "everything possible" would be done to give them greater access to ceremonial wampum belts they say belong to them and date from the time of Hiawatha.
The election of John N. Thurman as assistant vice president of Grace Line was announced yesterday by Wilfred J. McNeil, president of the steamship company.

The operators of curbside hotdog stands and other itinerant venders, who on Thursday were told they could remain in one spot for more than 10 minutes, yesterday learned they were being banned from a section of the Bronx.

LUSAKA, Zambia, March 31 --The authorities in Portuguese Angola have suspended all Zambian import and export freight traffic on the Benguela Railway following guerrilla attacks on the line, a railway spokesman in Benguela confirmed tonight tonight.
Motor vehicle accidents in this country killed 52,500 persons last year, disabled 1.9 million others, and cost the nation almost $10 billion.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 --After threatening to crush the Boston Celtics in memorable fashion, the Philadelphia 76ers had to settle for a decisive but hard-earned 127-113 victory tonight in the first game of their four-out-of-seven series.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., March 31--Mayor Walter Zirpolo and Council President Robert E. Jacks of Woodbridge Township, who have been accusen of bribery, resigned today saying they wanted to avoid creating an atmosphere "extremely detrimantal to the community."

WASHINGTON, March 31-- The House of Representatives asked the Federal District Court here today to throw out Adam Clayton Powell's suit to regain his seat. It contended the court lacked power to interfere in the actions of a coordinate branch of government.

DARIEN, Conn., March 31-- Two Canadian and two Massachusetts curling club rinks today reached the semi-final round of the Nutmeg Curling Club's international mixed bonspiel for the Golden Handle Trophy at the Country Club of Darien.
The American Stock Exchange closed yesterday with a modest decline.
Industrial issues moved up on a wide front yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
Sir Solly Zuckerman, chief scientific adviser to the British Government, has written a book, "Scientists and War," which Harper Row will put out on April 12.

WASHINGTON, March 31-- Without comment or ceremony, President Johnson ratified today a consular convention with the Soviet Union. It is the first bilateral treaty with Moscow since the Bolshevik revolution 50 years ago.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday he sympathized with students and faculty at the Bernard M. Baruch School of Business who oppose a Board of Higher Education committee plan to strip it of liberal arts courses and convert it into a specialized professional school Juniors, seniors and graduate students would attend the school.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan is investigating charges that housewives as well as city and state agencies have been paying millions of dollars extra yearly for milk, butter, cream and orange juice as a result of price-rigging among local milk companies.

WASHINGTON, March 31-- Protests against the draft and the war in Vietnam disrupted Selective Service headquarters here today and half-filled the auditorium of a large church with antiwar demonstrators.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. The problems that affect Catholic Education from grade school through college were brought into focus here last week as the National Catholic Educational Association held its 64th annual convention attended by 19,000 persons. THE nation's highway toll could be cut in half, saving 25,000 lives a year, if three kind of drivers were ruled of the road, according to a prominent automotive medical expert.
CALCUTTA, India, April 1 (AP) Hindus facing starvation in drought-stricken areas of Bihar state are slaughtering cows and eating the meat, though the animals are sacred in the Hindu religion.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 1 One of the most widely reapportioned state legislatures in the country, with an 8-to-1 majority of new members from urban and suburban areas, completed a session here this week that even the remaining rural conservatives hailed as the most productive in Maryland's history.

BROOKLINE, Mass., April 1 Mrs. Henry Andrew Birnbaum has announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Ellen Birnbaum, to Jean Russotto, son of Mr. and Mrs. J rome Russotto of Montreux, Switzerland.

ALBANY, April 1 Enrolled Democrats hold a lead of 824,080 over Republicans in the state, the Secretary of State, John P. Lomenzo reported yesterday. Enrollment totals tabulated from the election of last Nov. 8 list 3,615,806. Democrats and 2,791,726 Republicans.

WHILE an attempt to revive two famed classic car nameplates, the Cord and the Duesenberg, has ended in failure, one old-time favorite, the Mercedes SSK, is making a successful comeback under the nom de radiateur of Excalibur SSK.
NEW DELHI, April 1 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress party lost control today of the government in the country's most populous state.

IN Europe, more and more motorists, including some of the tens of thousands of American tourists, are expected this summer to take the easy and pleasant detours away from traffic jams afforded by car ferries.

WASHINGTON The Republicans have come up with a party slogan for the Presidential campaign. They call it "the Eleventh Commandment" and it may be even harder to keep than all the other ten: "Then shalt not speak ill of another Republican."

The football Giants have signed a Negro quarterback who had been passed up by every club in the recent professional draft because he was reported to have been "too cocky."
ALBANY, April 1 Governor Rockefeller reported today that the state completed the 1966-67 fiscal year, which ended at midnight last night, with a surplus of $4-million.

SANDS POINT, L.I., April 1 The engagement of Miss Susan Ward Bergman to Lieut. Robert Smith Meehan, U.S.A., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. George S. Bergman, Lieutenant Meehan is the son of Mrs. John R. Meehan of Stamford, Conn., and the late Mr. Meehan.
Home construction in the Southeast declined appreciably less during 1966 than in the rest of the nation and most other business indexes showed substantial gains.
LOS ANGELES, April 1--The administration of Gov. Ronald Reagan is reasonably pleased with the results of its first three months in office, although not overjoyed with its press notices.

Lightweight jackets for a man's leisure hours take a dressy turn this season. Herewith, examples of the new outerwear for meeting the variables of spring.

ESTATE WHIM, St. Croix, V.I. Work men restoring his old Danish sugar plantation have spent these first few days of spring putting final touches on a wind-driven sugar mill. Their goal was to have the majestic wooden sails turning in time to help celebrate the 50th anniversary this week of the purchase of the Virgin Islands by the United States.

LAND'S END, England, April 1 (UPI) British officials today accepted an offer by the United States Third Air force to send equipment and 115 men into the fight against oil washing ashore from the stranded tanker Torrey Canyon.

MOSCOW, April 1 (AP) The body of Marshal Rodion Y. Malinovsky, the Soviet Defense Minister, lay in state today in the white-columned Central Hall of the Red Army, and mourners lined up for more than a mile to pass his bier.

FIRE fighting experts generally agree that time is their most valuable weapon when fighting a fire-time in which to help occupants of the house to escape safely, and time in which to keep the fire from spreading so rapidly that it burns out of control before fire fighting apparatus can be brought into full play.

MONTREAL, April 1 (UPI) John Ferguson scored twice in the third period tonight to lead the Canadiens to a 5-4 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks, leaving Montreal in sole possession of second place in the National Hockey League.

TORONTO, April 1 Absorbing a 5-1 beating from the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight, the New York Rangers fell to fourth place in the National Hockey League while their last chance to finish second evaporated 375 miles away in Montreal.

A musical setting of the Roman Catholic Mass in the vernacular English text approved by the Ecumenical Council, Vatican II, was given its premiere at Philharmonic Hall Friday under the sponsorship of Fordham University.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 1 Miss Amy Gershovitz and Peter Ellis Schwartz were married this evening by Rabbi Morris N. Kertzer in the Larchmont Temple.

DJIBOUTI, French Somaliland, March 26 Hundreds of Samali tribesmen lolled glumly beside De Gaulle Boulevard today, waiting for their daily supply of kat, a mild narcotic on which the average tribesman spends more than half his pay.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 1 A 36-page booklet, with a color map, issued by the Tennessee Valley Authority, outlines industrial development in the seven-state Tennessee Valley region during 1966. The annual tabulation, listing all the private industries by names, products and districts, says the growth involved more projects, providing more new jobs and greater power demands than ever before.
The easing of the money market is reflected in the opening of three new developments of homes by one New Jersey builder.
Mrs. Marion Mill Preminger will be the hostess April 18 for a luncheon at her home benefiting the women's division of the Anti-Defamation League Appeal of B'nai B'rith.

A Tony Lema memorial celebrity pro-am tournament, which will feature some of golf's top players, plus a roster of celebrities, will be played at the Stardust Golf Club in Las Vegas, Nev., on April 18.
WASHINGTON, April 1 How far and how fast can the less developed countries be pushed toward helping themselves under United States foreign aid programs without raising demands of "Yankee, go home"?

MIAMI When James Kern tells his wife he is going out for a walk, chances are he will be away for a week. As president of the Florida Trail Association, Mr. Kern is helping to blaze a 550-mile-long footpath through Florida.
