QUINCY, Mass., April 2 (AP)--The police recovered today $94,577 in cash and checks of the $400,000 loot taken last night when hijackers slipped into the cab of an armored truck while its guards were outside and sped off in a hail of bullets.
The city's Superintendent of Schools charged yesterday that Mayor Lindsay was trying to bypass the Board of Education to "get more power to control the city's schools."
Bill Bilderback, Navy's lacrosse coach, was a satisfied man yesterday, partly because of a little fellow who made a big start in the middies' opener.

ARLINGTON, Tex., April 2 (AP)--Sue Gossick of Tarzania, Calif., became the first defending champion to triumph in the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor diving meet today as she took the women's three-meter final with 416.40 points.
WASHINGTON, April 2--A Presidential advisory group has recommended major changes in the controversial campaign financing law that Congress enacted last fall.

Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau seems to have a knack for acquiring very special accompanists for his solo appearances here this season. He gave three recitals at Carnegie Hall with Gerald Moore, the famous English pianist who has announced his impending retirement as accompanist.

MADISON, Wis., April 2-- Residents of Wisconsin will vote Tuesday on whether tax money should be used to transport parochial and private school children, but apparently the ecumenical spirit has pervaded what has traditionally been a divisive battle.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 2 (AP)--Sixteen per cent of the three million Negro students in the South are now attending desegregated schools, the Southern Education Reporting Service said today.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) --Federal spending under President Johnson's proposed budget will increase by $38-billion or 27 per cent in the 1966-68 period, the American Enterprise Institute said tonight.

ALBANY, April 2--When the 186 delegates to the Constitutional Convention gather here Tuesday, one of their biggest problems, oddly enough, will be deciding just how much work they should do on the Constitution.
PITTSBURGH, April 2-- Steel officials faced decisions on production cutbacks last week.
JERUSALEM (Israel), April 2--The Israeli artist who designed murals for the Shalom wants them back now that the liner is to sold to a West Germany company.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) --Senator Lee Metcalf, Democrat of Montana, said today that he had asked the Attorney General to find out whether private utility companies had violated antitrust laws.

Lynn Redgrave, the actress who has been nominated for an Oscar for her performance in "Georgy Girl" and who is a star in Broadway's "Black Comedy," was married yesterday to John Clark, once a top child star in Britain.

Greece is mired in a new political crisis that could put its democratic system under its greatest strain since the end of the civil war eighteen years ago. A bitter deadlock between the two biggest parties has brought to an end the nonpolitical Government of Ioannis Paraskevopoulos, formed last December to prepare Greece for parliamentary elections in May.

UNEASY lies the pretty head that wears the crown! The reign of the women's world chess champion, Nona Gaprindashvilli, is threatened by none other than a fellowtownswoman, Nana Alexandria, a 17-year-old Tiflis schoolgirl.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 2 --President Cevdet Sunay, accompanied by his Foreign Minister, Ihsan Sabri Caglayangil, left Ankara today for an official 12-day visit to the United States, including talks in Washington with President Johnson.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Monday, April 3 (Reuters)--A United States general who spent three days in the jungle in a search for James Thompson, the American "silk king" who has been missing since last Sunday, gave up the search today.
OLDHAM, England, April 2 (AP)--The police rescued a 3year-old girl yesterday who they they said had spent four days alone in her home with her dead mother.

The city's Department of Real Estate is scheduled to sell 205 mortages today to four pension funds administered for city employes. The value of the mortgages, to be purchased as investments, is more than $10million.

ATLANTA, April 2 (AP)-- Cale Yarborough fought off challenges by Richard Petty and Mario Andretti today in driving his 1967 Ford to victory in the Atlanta 500 before a record crowd of 80,000.

WASHINGTON, April 2-- John Kenneth Galbraith attacked the Johnson Administration's policy in Vietnam today and said that a prolonged conflict could "mean the death and burial of the Democratic party."

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 2--George Archer, a former cowboy, rode through a storm of birdies by Doug Sanders and Arnold Palmer to win the Greater Greensboro open golf tournament today by two strokes. The 6-foot ex-ranch hand cracked the tourney record with a closing 68 for a 14-under par aggregate of 267.

Serge Jaroff first brought his Don Cossack Chorus to Carnegie Hall 37 years ago, rousing the audience to enthusiastic applause. Saturday night, as part of the choir's annual North American tour, he did so again, with the same results.

Secretary General Thant of the United Nations has now clarified his position following his proposal a week ago for a peaceful settlement of the Vietnam war. He did so in his latest statement praising Senator Joseph Clark's suggestion that the United States "make the first move" and put Mr. Thant's cease-fire plan into effect.

TOKYO, Monday, April 3 (AP)--North Vietnam's official newspaper rejected today Secretary General Thant's threestage Vietnam peace proposal, saying the plan did not "proceed from the realities of the present situation in Vietnam."

TANHIEP, South Vietnam, April 2--The citizens of Tanhiep voted today in village council elections. There were no apparent irregularities and no Vietcong violence. But a sampling of voters indicated that only a minority understood the complexities of the voting procedure or the significance of the election despite a week-long campaign to explain issues and candidates.
CARACAS, Venezuela, April 2--The American chiefs of state conference at Punta del Este, Uruguay, next week is running into the old conflict between international ideals and national politics.

Pan American World Airways has paid half the cost of its future fleet of Boeing 747 jets in advance of delivery of the first aircraft in 1969, according to the company's 1966 annual report.

PEORIA, Ill., April 2 (UPI) --The murder trial of Richard Franklin Speck, accused slayer of eight nurses in Chicago, will resume tomorrow with opening arguments scheduled following the swearing in of the newly empaneled jury.
Awards totaling $2,196,100 have been granted to 294 scholars, scientists and artists, the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation announced last night.

Two scientists at Northern Illinois University have found that chicken eggs exposed to continuous beeps of a particular sound later hatched chicks that responded to that sound in preference to others.

GENEVA, April 3--The owners of the 1.3 million motor vehicles in Switzerland got bad news today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3--The Government reported today that 80.5 per cent of qualified voters participated in yesterday's first round of village council elections.

Guests at the New Yorker Hotel plodded up long flights of stairs to rooms with unmade beds yesterday while members of the hotel's 10 unions sat under the crystal chandeliers of the Grand Ballroom in a four-hour work stoppage.

WASHINGTON, April 3-- President Johnson's first major legislative proposal to the 90th Congress, a two-year extension of the Appalachian Regional Development Act, cleared the Senate Public Works Committee today. It is expected to receive Senate approval within a week.

MONACO, Monte Carlo, April 3--Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the United States chess champion, retained the lead of the Grand Prix International after completion of the 10th and penultimate round here last night.
NEWARK, April 3--Dr. David Weingast, assistant superintendent of Newark's public school system, was named today as Superintendent of Schools for the rural Fairfield County town of Ridgefield, Conn.

HAMDEN, Conn., April 3-- Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd George Reynolds have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Reynolds, to Kermit Roosevelt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Roosevelt of Washington and Nantucket, Mass. A May wedding is planned.

The New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden, N.J., disclaimed all responsibility yesterday for delays in the completion of the nuclear submarine Pogy or for increases in the cost of her construction.

The Harvard Business School Association will sponsor a conference April 14 at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel where Federal officials, businessmen and educators will discuss the relationship between Government and the business community.

Mrs. Evelyn A. Hemmingson Herrick, a lawyer, a, lieutenant commander in the Coast Guard Reserve and the wife of Capt. H. Scott Herrick, U.S.N., died of cancer March 23 in her home in High Wycombe, Buckinghamshire, England. She was 49 years old and had retired recently.
NAPLES, Fla., April 3--The selection of a jury for Dr. Carl A. Coppolino's second murder krial in four months was begun today.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 3--Desperate for a dependable shortstop, the New York Yankees obtained John Kennedy tonight from the Los Angeles Dodgers in a trade involving three Yankee players and an undisclosed amount of cash.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI)--The Secretary of Agriculture, Orville L. Freeman, told the Congress today that European countries were not budging on their barriers to American farm exports in the trade negotiations in Geneva.
The typographical union put further pressure on The Daily News yesterday for a wageand-hour settlement by continuing to hold chapel meetings in the composing room of the paper.
WASHINGTON, April 3-- Three and one-half years of musical research and writing culminated last night in the premiere of Edward Boatner's "Freedom Suite."
WASHINGTON, April 3-- Senator Robert F. Kennedy urged Governor Rockefeller today to authorize the State Power Authority to build a nuclear reactor.
The duties of chief executive officer of the Budd Company have been transferred to Philip W. Scott, the president, from Edward G. Budd Jr., the chairman, it was announced yesterday.
It was a warm spring day on Wall Street yesterday but the stock market continued to show a wintry chill.
TORONTO, April 3 (Canadian Press)--G.R. McGregor, president of Air Canada, said today he doubted that the United States' proposed supersonic jetliner will ever get off the ground.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3-- H.J. Grinsfelder, executive head of Gimbels-Philadelphia, died this evening at the Ravdin Pavilion of the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 1900 Rittenhouse Square.

GENEVA, April 3--The text of an agreement extending an accord regulating international trade in cotton for three years was approved today at a meeting of a 29-nation committee of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
A widow whom a jury had awarded $32,000 won a reversal yesterday on the ground that the award was inadequate for the death of her husband, who was killed in an automobile accident.
LOS ANGELES, April 3 (AP)--One of the last vestiges of the World War 2 evacuation of Japanese-Americans, Nisei, to relocation camps looms as an issue in a municipal election tomorrow.
Every Ranger road game during the National Hockey League Stanley Cup playoffs will be telecast, and the home contests at Madison Square Garden will be on radio (WHN).

Yesterday was a warm and lovely day, until nightfall, at least. At 10:05 A.M., the temperature was 76 degrees, but by 6 P.M. it was 53 degrees and by midnight it had plummeted to a shivery 36 degrees.

TORONTO, April 3--The National Ballet of Canada, only 14 years old, is still busy building up its basic repertory. Last week it produced a new "Swan Lake." Tonight at Toronto's O'Keefe Center it gave the 19th-century Russian classic, "Bayderka," reproduced for the company by the Bolshoi ballet-master Eugen Valukin. It was a modest triumph.
MOSCOW, April 3--Marshal Rodion Y. Malinovsky was buried in the Kremlin Wall today in a military funeral attended by the top Soviet leaders.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 3 (UPI)--A national Roman Catholic weekly called on "all religious publications" today to reject prejudice when considering the possible Presidential candidacy of Gov. George Romney of Michigan.

GENEVA, April 3--Dr. Alf Nyberg, director of the Swedish Meteorological Institute, today urged members of the Fifth World Meteorological Congress to show "the high level of mutual understanding" that he said would be required to operate the proposed global weather forecasting system.

Smith, Barney Co., New York investment bankers, announced yesterday the election as executive vice presidents of Hugh Knowlton Jr., Andrew J. Melton Jr., and Robert A. Powers. They had been senior vice presidents.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)--President Johnson received a medal today from the farmer-owned land banks, which are observing their 50th anniversary. In a ceremony in the White House rose garden, Fred A. Kneutsen, president of the Federal Land Bank of Spokane, Wash., declared:
Like old soldiers, antiques dealers--old in point of service--never die; they just fade away into their carefully restored saltboxes, answering the bugle call of the doorbell by appointment only.
The election of Ellison L. Hazard as a director of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company was announced yesterday at the annual stockholders meeting in Akron, Ohio.

WASHINGTON, April 3--The Justice Department disclosed today that a man who has served two years in Atlanta Penitentiary was convicted after Federal agents spied on him with an illegal listening device.

WASHINGTON, April 3-- Consumer installment credit showed its smallest rise in more than five years in February. Repayments of automobile loans exceeded new auto loans for the first time in more than six years.
Stocks declined along a broad front yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
The Police Department yesterday began testing a program of tape-recording interrogations.
Dr. Irving London, a general medical practitioner and internist, died yesterday in the Roosevelt Hospital. He was 62 years old, lived at 25 Central Park West and had an office at 700 Park Avenue.
WASHINGTON, April 3-- The Justice Department conceded tonight that the American Communist party could not be punished for refusing to register with the Government as an agent of the Soviet Union.
DETROIT, April 3--Auto makers contend they see signs of a spring sales upturn, although sales reports continue to show sharp declines from last year's levels.
Certified Grocers of Illinois, Inc., a grocery cooperative, to Geyer, Morey, Ballard, Inc., Chicago.

ODESSA, U.S.S.R., April 3 (UPI)--The arrival today of the first United States cruise ship to visit a Soviet Black Sea port since World War II was supposed to be an important event, but the 535 Americans aboard went on eating breakfast.
NEW ORLEANS, April 3 (UPI)--Judge Edward A. Haggerty Jr. today banned all persons officially connected with the assassination conspiracy trial of Clay L. Shaw from talking about the case.

CLOVIS, N.M., April 3 (UPI) --Air Force Capt. Dale Noyd, who is making the first court test of the Government's refusal to allow conscientious objection "to a particular war," received a 30-day leave today.

American Book-Stratford Press, Inc., opened its second printing-binding facility, yesterday at Saddle Brook, N.J. covering 140,000 sq. ft., Frank Satenstein, president, disclosed in the 1966 annual report.

ADEN, April 3--British troops let nationalist rioters rampage through Aden's narrow streets for a while today. Some of the screaming Arabs carried flags of the United Arab Republic and portraits of of its President, Gamal Abdel Nasser.

ATLANTA, April 3--A Federal District Court here has reversed a 1963 administrative ruling by former Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon that authorized any national bank to act as an insurance agent.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 3--State Sentor Robert O. Tiernan of Warwick, Democrat, was declared the winner today by 316 votes over Mayor James DiPrete Jr. of Cranston, a Republican, in a special Congressional election.

NEW DELHI, April 3--Michael von Schenck of Switzerland was elected today as secretary general of the International Secretariat for Volunteer Service, an organization that seeks to promote consultation among nations using volunteer workers in development programs.
LONDON, April 3 (Reuters) --Sir Francis Chichester said in a radio message today he was sailing his yacht Gypsy Moth IV away from Cape Horn and the "roaring forties" winds into calmer seas.

An automated intensive-care unit that completely takes over the chore of monitoring and recording a critically ill patient's pulse, temperature, respiration and blood pressure will go into operation at Lenox Hill Hospital today.

Norman Walker's choreography is much like something that occurs when you are waiting for something to happen, but it's so well put together that you don't mind. Last night at the Village Theater, Norman Walker and Dance Company presented "Eloges," "The Prussian Officer" and "Trionfo Di Aphrodite."
Industrial issues edged up yesterday in brisk trading on the London Stock Exchange.
Gottfried Heindl has been named president of the Austrian Institute in New York City.
The First National City Bank, the second-largest bank in New York, said yesterday that it had lowered the interest rate that it pays on some of its consumer-type, time deposits ...

A false report from Kansas City that former President Harry S. Truman had been taken by amulance to a hospital reached television and radio listeners here shortly after 11 o'clock last night. It was denied a few minutes later by Mrs. Truman as "ridiculous."
A four-story apartment house at 444 East 86th Street, near York Avenue, has been sold in a transaction that completed assemblage of a site for another tall East Side apartment building.

Shareholders of the Home Insurance Company approved yesterday a two-for-one stock split at the annual meeting held here. In other actions, they voted to increase the number of shares outstanding to 9,862,820; fixed the par value of these shares at $2.50, and reduced the authorized capital to $24,657,050.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 3-- Although only a month has passed since Roosevelt Raceway's officials began using exacta wagering on a broader scale, they are already giving the move a broad vote of confidence.

Dr. George A. Koenig of 7 Peter Cooper Road, a surgeon, who served in both World Wars, died Sunday in the Veterans Administration Hospital here. His age was 80.
The election of Thomas A. Murphy as controller was announced yesterday by the General Motors Corporation following a board meeting here.
The assets of philanthropic foundations in the United States have reached a record high estimated at $20.3-billion, the annual report of the Foundation Library Center disclosed yesterday.
The architectural firm of Moore Hutchins has admitted two new members and changed its name to Moore Hutchins Partnership.
Despite President Johnson's gala weekend for LatinAmerican Ambassadors at his Texas ranch, they didn't have too much to cheer about when they returned to Washington.

The Securities and Exchange Commission and Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey have joined forces to propose new regulations for protecting shareholders against corporate raiders. Mr. Williams has called for full disclosure in all corporate proxy contests, while the S.E.C. also wants additional safeguards that will benefit individual investors when insurgents make a tender offer for shares.

Fran Tarkentan ("I've got 18 million things on my mind") sat through a 15-minute film of the football Giants, 1966 lowlights yesterday and was constantly startled whenever he saw a quarterback scramble.
TRENTON, April 3--The Assembly gave final, unanimous approval tonight to a measure setting up a divorce study commission.
Directors of Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., approved yesterday an agreement in principle to acquire the assets of the Collyer Insulated Wire Company for stock valued at about $15-million.
ATHENS, April 3--King Constantine took bold action today to end Greece's four-day political deadlock by nominating Panayotis Kanellopous, the conservative leader, as Premier.

The dissident group of stockholders of the Boston Maine corporation led by Jordan Eskin, a New York lawyer, sought yesterday to block the election of the railroad's slate of 16 directors at the annual meeting April 12.
A panel truck crashed through the wooden doorway of New York University's phi Epsilon Pi Fraternity house yesterday, coming to a halt about 10 feet from a group of students having lunch.

ATLANTA, April 3--Birth control researchers predicted today that tests of an entirely new kind of long-acting contraceptive drug that can be implanted within women would start before the end of the year.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 3--Fourteen Florida Negroes, several of whom have been acting as their own attorneys while on Death Row at the Florida State Prison, have been ordered to prepare, for final clemency hearings before the State Pardon Board.
Unions of governmental employes here predicted yesterday that a bill passed by the Legislature to penalize the unions if they strike would mean more strikes rather than fewer.
CHICAGO, April 3--Chet Huntley and David Brinkley, who haven't said good night to each other in nearly a week, said good morning to each other today.
Interest rates declined again yesterday in the face of a continued build-up in volume of new fixed-income securities scheduled for sale.

MOSCOW, April 3 (UPI)--A British sailor convicted of breaking up a Russian wedding party by getting drunk and punching the bridegroom has been sent to a Soviet labor camp to serve an 18-month sentence, British officials said today.
THE increased stock-transfer tax poured record revenues into New York City coffers during the first three months of 1967.

The roller coaster in wheat prices was still running, and yesterday the downswing and the upward thrust took place in one active day on the Chicago Board of Trade. Futures prices dropped almost four cents in the case of nearby May wheat and a little less for the other deliveries. Then, all made a strong recovery to close at about the same levels as last Friday.

In a move that could shut down thoroughbred racing here and deny New York State al- most $2-million a week in tax revenue, horsemen decided last night not to enter their horses in races at Aqueduct. The boycott will start tomorrow.

New York State's ninth Constitutional Convention, which opens in Albany today, has the opportunity to provide the state with a modern Constitution strong enough to protect the basic rights of its citizens and establish a sound structure of government, and yet flexible enough to cope with changing social and economic conditions.
PEORIA, Ill., April 3 (AP)-- A jury heard the state demand the death penalty today for Richard F. Speck in the slaying of eight student nurses.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) --Senator James B. Pearson, Republican of Kansas, introduced legislation today that was designed, he said, to settle the running battle between the Amateur Athletic Union and the United States Track and Field Federation.
WASHINGTON, April 3-- George Meany said today that a new farm labor contract with a big California grower would point the way to new gains for farm workers throughout the country.
Studebaker Corporation will acquire almost all the assets of the Wagner Electric Corporation under an agreement signed yesterday.
JUDGING by the number of New Jersey cars seen at southern New York state trout waters over the opening weekend, Garden State anglers just could not wait for the opening of their own season.

CHICAGO, April 3 (AP)-- Negotiators for 66 railroads and the Order of Railway Conductors and Brakemen signed today an agreement that a union spokesman said ruled out a strike in the near future.

Lincoln Center today: Music by Canadian composers, Library-Museum, 2:30; "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera, 8, and National Catholic Music Educators concert, with Phyllis Curtin, William Walker, William Masselos and an orchestra conducted by Walter Gillessen, Philharmonic Hall, 8.
GEORGE R. MAREK, a recording executive and author of a biography of Puccini and other books, has subtitled his study of Richard Strauss, "The Life of a Non-Hero."

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI)--The pilot of an airliner that crashed and killed 83 persons last year apparently suffered a heart attack about six seconds before striking the ground, the Civil Aeronautics Board said today.

The Rangers will hold their first pre-Stanley Cup workout today, a nonpublic scrimmage at Iceland, atop Madison Square Garden, with no new strategy planned by Coach Emile Francis.

THE HAGUE, April 3--Petrus J.S. deJong, a former professional naval officer who became a junior defense official eight years ago, formed a rightof-center coalition Government today, 47 days after the general election.
At two of its major centers the Welfare Department discontinued yesterday its long-time practice of investigating applicants before granting public assistance.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3 (AP)--Mike Shannon raised his spring batting average to .364 today with three singles as the St. Louis Cardinals whipped Dean Chance and the Minnesota Twins, 6-1.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI) --Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz urged today passage of a bill to expand picketing rights at construction sites.
WASHINGTON, April 3-- President and Mrs. Johnson extended the nation's greetings today to President Cevdet Sunay of Turkey and his wife, who arrived here for a three-day state visit.

PURCHASE, N.Y., April 3 --A meeting of 200 Purchase residents overwhelmingly endorsed a suggestion tonight to make Purchase an incorporated village to prevent commercial enterprises from building in this area of wealthy and wooded estates.

WASHINGTON, April 3--The- Senate Foreign Relations Committee adopted today a watereddown version of the resolution of support that President Johnson hopes to take to a Western Hemisphere summit meeting next week. Administration officials immediately denounced the new language as "worse than useless" and pressed for its revision.

Wyllys Rosseter Betts, who was formerly associated with Harris, Upham Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, or more than 12 years, died Sunday in Good Samaritan Hospital, Phoenix, Ariz. He was 68 years old and lived in nearby Scottsdale, Ariz.
Eight men who have been getting state treatment for heroin addiction gave their own help yesterday to the new State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., April 3 --The New York Generals, who are training at C. W. Post College for their National Professional Soccer League opener in Los Angeles on April 16, reported today that four players on the 15-man squad were sidelined with injuries.

BACKGROUND--New York State's ninth Constitutional Convention opens today at noon in Albany. The convention call was approved by the voters in November, 1965. The last meeting like it was held in 1938.
The General Aniline and Film Corporation announced yesterday its entry into the electrostatic copier field with the introduction of a new copying machine called the Gafax 500.

Mr. Owsley was born in Denton, Tex. He graduated in 1909 from Virginia Military Institute. After studying law at the University of Texas he was admitted to the bar in 1912. He served two years in the Texas House of Representatives. In 1915 he became county and district attorney of Denton County.

Storm signals are blowing for the National Endowment of the Humanities. Mayor Lindsay returned last night to the scene of his first crisis for a festive "happening" organized to erase his $260,000 campaign deficit.

SARASOTA, Fla., April 3-- Jack Hamilton and Bill Denehy --two baseball players in search of regular employment-- pitched the New York Mets to a 4-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox today and allowed only two hits in doing so.

A City Hall spokesman said yesterday that Mayor Lindsay was "confident" that he and Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan could work out an administrative decentralization program for city schools that would be "in the city's best interests."
Piero Bargellini, the Mayor of Florence, received an unusual book here yesterday.

The General Public Utilities Corporation expects the "whole Middle Atlantic states area" to experience power-supply problems this year because of construction delays on two power plants, William G. Kuhns, vice president, said at the company's annual meeting here yesterday at One Chase Manhattan Plaza.
QUINCY, Mass., April 3 (UPI)--The police were seeking four men in the theft of an armored truck carrying close to $400,000 in cash and checks.

Persons who have been tripping and falling on the four shallow steps in front of the Metropolitan Opera House at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts will soon have something more functional and steady to hold on to than wooden horses.

WASHINGTON, April 3-- Gov. George Romney has postponed until later this year any statement supporting or criticizing the bombing of North Vietnam and other actions there he regards as military tactics.
The spot rate on the British pound advanced in moderate trading yesterday on foreignexchange markets here.
City school officials reported yesterday that there had been an "encouraging" increase in the number of Negro teachers, supervisors and administrative employers in recent years.
WASHINGTON, April 3-- Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien urged today that the Post Office Department be replaced by a nonprofit Government corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 3-- News item: Secretary of State Dean Rusk refuses to appear on "Meet the Press" to discuss United States foreign policy because of the strike by television newsmen. The Secretary, says the State Department, will not be caught "crossing a picket line."
Three cancer research laboratories, including the SloanKettering Institute in New York, have begun clinical tests of the enzyme L-asparaginase on human leukemia patients.

Corning Glass Works, the first industrial company to issue first-quarter results, reported yesterday record sales and earnings. The year-to-year increase, however, was the smallest for the initial quarter since 1961.
E.F. Hutton Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange, has announced the appointment of Robert H. Stovall as chairman of the investment policy committee.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 3--The acting chief of the Cuban mission at the United Nations was injured today by the explosion of a bomb packaged in a book sent to him through the mail.

More than 1,000 students boycotted classes at the Brooklyn center of Long Island University yesterday and demanded the reinstatement of Dr. William M. Birenbaum, who was ousted as provost of the center last week.
PEKING, April 3 (Agence France-Presse)--For the third day, demonstrators here attacked President Liu Shao-chi today. Some wall posters even suggested that the head of state be "shot."

WASHINGTON, April 3-- Counsel for Adam Clayton Powell contended today that his exclusion from the House of Representatives was an act of Congress in substancce, if not in form, and was therefore subject to review by a special threejudge Federal court.
CONCORD, N.H., April 3-- Mrs. Elba Chase Nelson, for many years secretary of the Communist party in New Hampshire, died last night at Concord Hospital. She was 76 years old.

DALLAS, April 3 (AP)-- The Dallas police today arrest ed Sergio Arcacha Smith, selfidentified as a former anti-Castro Cuban leader, on a warrant issued by District Attorney Jim Garrison of New Orleans.
The six-day-old strike against the three major television and radion networks by the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists became a battle of statements yesterday.

THERE should be a direct, succinct way of explaining in an introductory sentence just why "Masters of the Loaded Brush," which opens tonight at Knoedler, 14 East 57th Street, is such a good exhibition, but the way is difficult to find. The show's virtues make too long a list for an opener, and are so intertwined that none can be picked out by itself.

BEIRUT, April 3--The Iraqi Cabinet and the Higher Defense Council, acting in a joint session as the nation's highest authority, have in effect extended the term of office of President Abdul Rahman Arif indefinitely, the Baghdad radio announced today.

LONDON, April 3--Vice President Humphrey is telling European leaders that they could advance the cause of peace in Vietnam if they directed some of their criticism at North Vietnam as well as at the United States.

TRENTON, April 3--Dr. Carl L. Marburger, a leading figure in urban education for the poor and the assistant commissioner for education in the Federal Bureau of Indian Affairs, was named the new State Commissioner of Education here today.
WEST PALM BEACH Fla., April 3 (UPI)--Rico Carty's bases-loaded double in the sixth inning drove in two runs today and gave the Atlanta Braves a 2-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 3 (AP)--Secretary General Thant suggested today that developing countries would find hovercraft, or air-cushion vehicles, handy for transport because they could get around "without expensive roads and bridges, over swamps, shallows, marshes, snow and ice, rivers and seas."

KINSHASA, the Congo, April 3--A "desperate" shortage of doctors and health workers is blocking the development and progress of African countries, according to Dr. Alfred Quenum, African regional director of the World Health Organization.
PARIS, April 3--President de Gautle's followers, who went to the brink of defeat in last month's legislative election, won the first important test in the new National Assembly today.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla, April 3 (AP)--Scientists are designing a device that may some day put oceans to work generating electricity for coastal cities such as New York or Miami.
SAIGON, Tuesday, April 4 (AP)--In the air war today, a formation of B-52's attacked an enemy base camp before dawn in War Zone C near Cambodia.
JERUSALEM; (Israel); April 3--Syrian and Israeli border units exchanged fire near the Sea of Galilee today in a renewal of the kind of shooting that led to United Nations talks last January.

HAMILTON, N.Y., April 3 (UPI)--Edward J. Ashnault was named head basketball coach today at Colgate University.

Officials of the New York team in the projected American Basketball Association explained yesterday some of the hitherto vague details of its operation, and reported on the results of the league meeting held in Oakland, Calif., over the weekend.

Montgomery Ward Co. will reduce its capital outlays in 1967 to $35-million from $57.8million last year, after the completion of major expenditures to modernize old facilities and open new market areas, the company's financial report disclosed yesterday.

The returns of the nationwide municipal elections in Chile come as an especially sharp disappointment because the poor showing of President Frei's party, the Christian Democrats, was so unexpected. The party won only 36.5 per cent of the votes compared to 42.3 in the 1965 elections. The Communists, the Radicals in the center and the Nationalists on the right all gained.
The Columbia baseball team beat Manhattan, 8-4, yesterday at Baker Field for its second straight victory of the season.

A Marine Corps sergeant who had earned the Purple Heart and five battle stars in Vietnam was shot to death in Greenwich Village early yesterday morning after breaking up a street fight.
Columbia University yesterday became one of the first major institutions in the country to discontinue the practice of ranking its students.
The eighth annual art show of the Park Avenue Synagogue will be held for three days starting Sunday.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 3-- Chile's sizable middle class all but abandoned President Eduardo Frei Montalva and his Christian Democratic party in yesterday's municipal elections.

One of the city's largest leather-goods manufacturers, who was on the verge of moving from the city, has decided to relocate in Manhattan instead, because his skilled workers would not have followed him out of town.

WASHINGTON, April 3--If there is any one thing that has been established in the years of controversy following the Supreme Court's school desegregation decision in 1954, it is that the Federal Government intends to enforce Federal court orders.

Earnings reports from some of the nation's major banks for the first quarter of 1967 started to come in yesterday. In general they showed higher profits, but in some cases the rate of improvement lagged behind that of last year.

DALLAS, April 3 (AP)-- Braniff Airways, Inc., has tripled its profits and doubled both its revenue passenger miles and cargo ton miles in its two years under new management, Harding L. Lawrence, president, said today.
LOOKOUT MOUNTATN, Tenn., April 3--Miss Laura Ames Durand and Robert Scott Doolittle plan to marry here Aug. 19.
At 8:15 A.M. yesterday, a green button was pressed activating the television transmitter that will carry the Board of Education's new Channel 25 educational programs into 50,000 city classrooms.

Dr. Clarence Mark Hebbert, who retired in 1961 as professor of mathematics at Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, died yesterday at Putnam Memorial Hospital, Bennington, Vt. His age was 76.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI)--Earl Kintner, a former chairman of the Federal Trade Commission complained today that hospitals were getting price breaks when they bought drugs and resold them. He said they were driving drugstores out of business.

DALLAS, April 3 (AP)--Alvin M. Owsley, a former diplomat and an early national commander of the American Legion, died today at his Dallas home. He was 78 years old.
Cassius Clay will defend his heavyweight boxing title against Floyd Patterson, the two-time former champion, in Las Vegas, Nev., April 25, The Associated Press reported last night.

BOSTON, April 3--Gov. John A. Volpe made one of his rare appearances at a legislative hearing last week when he urged the Joint Committee on Insurance to repeal the Massachusetts Automobile Compulsory Insurance Law.
LONDON, April 3 (AP)--A boom in construction of larger and faster ships has increased the surplus of cargo-shipping space, Lloyd's annual register for 1966 reported today.

St. John's University set a Metropolitan Baseball Conference record by blasting four home runs yesterday in beating Fordham, 11-5, at Jack Coffey Field, the Bronx. More remarkable, the feat was accomplished in seven innings. The game was called because of darkness.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) --The Navy is planning to buy 40 to 50 electronics-laden reconnaissance planes costing well over $150-million.

NO ONE familiar with the singing and acting talents of Jon Vickers will be surprised to learn that his first appearance in the title role of Verdi's "Otello" with the Metropolitan Opera was successful. The Canadian tenor...

Less than three weeks after taking office, Parks Commissioner August Heckscher has started fence mending--6,000 feet of it that courses along automobile, bicycle and bridle paths from 59th to 72d Street in Central Park.

ALBANY, April 4--Governor Rockefeller suggested today that "a lot of pressure" from harness racing interests had killed his bill to give an extra $3.5-million to thoroughbred racing tracks for increasing purses.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 4 --Mr. and Mrs. Lindley Edward Eberstadt of Montclair and Mantoloking have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Claire Eberstadt, to William Morrow Weiant 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Monroe Alden Weiant of Westfield.
The Girls' Clubs of America will give their annual Career Key Awards at a banquet on Tuesday in the Statler-Hilton.
JACKSON POLLOCK, the American abstract paint er who died in 1956 at the age of 44, is the subject of a large retrospective exhibition opening today at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street.

With an eye to improving its operations, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has begun a permanent, high-level review of its organization and management. The agency, one of the largest in the Federal Government, hopes thereby to head off criticism of its way of doing business and to prepare for even more ambitious space projects involving missions to Venus and Mars and the outer reaches of the solar system.

ALBANY, April 3--The high heels of the delegates' wives click-clacked over the marble floor. The women turned toward the Assembly parlor and stepped inside. They raised their eyes and said "Ooh!" at the oak-beamed ceiling, and Aah!" at the panelled oak walls, and they glided across the green-gray car pet toward a table.

MORLEY SAFER, correspondent in Vietnam for the Columbia, Broadcasting System, gave his impression of the war in an hour-long film last night. It was an understandably bitter and caustic account of the ugliness of death mixed with the smells of cheap perfume, beer and sweat.

Dr. George Himler, coordinator of the city's five county medical societies, said yesterday that under no circumstances would he allow the city to inspect the medical records of office patients he had treated under the Medicaid program.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 4--Hal Reniff, who never works as a starting pitcher, and Fritz Peterson, who no longer plays with minor leaguers, were completely out of character today as the Yankees helped the Atlanta Braves close their spring training camp.
The Paradise Ball, the 11th annual benefit for the Sheltering Arms Children's Service, will be held at the Plaza on April 14. Mayor and Mrs. Lindsay are honorary chairmen.

The Camera Corporation of America yesterday introduced and demonstrated its new "instant" camera. The device, called the Chrislin Insta-Camera, takes and develops finished prints inside the camera within a minute.
OTTAWA, April 4--Roland Michener, a leading figure in Canadian politics and diplomatic service, was named Governor General of Canada today. He succeeds Georges P. Vanier, who died March 5.
With Mayor Lindsay as honorary chairman, a new privately sponsored program was set up yesterday to protect New Yorkers with special medical problems from incorrect treatment in the event of accident.

NEW ORLEANS, April 4-- Clay L. Shaw, the man accused by the District Attorney's office of having conspired to kill President Kennedy, described himself as an "old-fashioned liberal of the Wilson-Franklin Roosevelt persuasion."

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 4 (UPI)--The Alabama Legislature voted unanimously today to work as a committee of the whole to take testimony and map ways for sidestepping two Federal court orders demanding complete school integration by next fall.

CLEVELAND, April 4--Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schoonhaven Carey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Feather Carey, to Douglas Osborn Kyle Felt, son of Mrs. Jack Osborn Felt of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Felt.
ROME, April 4--A high Vatican prelate rejected today the idea of letting Roman Catholic priests marry to make clerical life easier and to meet the threatening and growing shortage of diocesan clergy.
The Reform Democrats of Greenwich Village began priming yesterday for their biennial battle against the neighborhood's remnants of Tammany Hall.

CINCINNATI, April 4 (AP) --A temporary injunction against the National Farmers Organization was dissolved yesterday by Federal Judge Timothy S. Hogan, who said he had found no evidence connecting alleged violence with the organization in its milk withholding drive.

The Automatic Sprinkler Corporation of America renewed its offer yesterday to purchase substantially all the assets of the Interstate Engineering Corporation of Anaheim, Calif., involving stock worth about $50million.

WASHINGTON, April 4--A tape-recorded plea for peace by former President Dwight D. Eisenhower was used tonight in a performance of Aaron Copland's "Preamble for a Solemn Occasion" by the National Symphony.

MIAMI BEACH, April 4 (AP)--Dale Remley of Pontiac, Mich., celebrated his first appearance in an American Bowling Congress tournament today by rolling a 717 series that gave him first place in regular singles.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)--The Food and Drug Administration proposed today guidelines that would require accurate labelling for analgesic drugs sold over the counter without prescription.
The decision by the trustees of Columbia University to abolish the practice of ranking students according to their standing in their class represents a fundamental, long-overdue educational reform.

There is wide agreement that the Senate made a mistake last November when it wrote into a miscellaneous tax bill a new plan for Federal subsidies for the two major political parties. Such a far-reaching proposal requires more careful safeguards and more thoughtful consideration than it received.

The Paul Revere Life Insurance Company of Worcester, Mass., said yesterday it had withdrawn its suit charging the All-State Credit Corporation of Lynbrook, L.I., and its officers with making "untrue, misleading and deceptive" statements about All-State's financial condition.

If you can't find a race in the book--the condition book --then stage one yourself. Johnny Nerud, one of America's premier trainers, followed this unusual formula at Aqueduct yesterday. Between the first and second scheduled races, he sent three outstanding members of his barn--Tartan's Dr. Fager and Aforethought and Joseph M. Roebling's Gaylord's Feather into a six-furlong sprint.
Edward Dale Toland, vice president for finance of the American Maize-Products Company, 250 Park Avenue, fell to his death from the Yale Club early yesterday morning.
LONDON, April 4--Britain has decided to sue the Union Oil Company of California, owner of the Torrey Canyon, for damage done by the grounded tanker's cargo of crude oil.
Leading economists presented three contrasting views yesterday on whether a recession in the economy is likely during 1967.

NEW DELHI, April 4--In an effort to outmaneuver and embarrass Prime Minister Indi ra Ghandi, the seven opposition parties in Parliament announced today that they had agreed on candidates for the offices of President and Vice President of India.
CHICAGO, April 4--Mayor Richard J. Daley was re-elected overwhelmingly today to a fourth four-year term.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)--Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, voiced support today for President Johnson's proposed reforms of draft policy and rejected the concept of compelling youths to work for the Government in nonmilitary capacities.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., April 4--Msgr. Richard H.J. Hanley, founding editor of The Long Island Catholic, official weekly newspaper of the Rockville Centre Diocese, died yesterday in Mercy Hospital, after a week's illness. He would have been 51 years old Saturday.

Angered by the Legislature's failure to increase purses, horsemen at Aqueduct race track are shutting down New York State's biggest revenue-producing corporation with what they described as a "very serious" boycott.
John V. Hagan, who retired on Jan. 26 as a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday in Brooklyn Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 70 Prospect Park Southwest, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)--Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman announced today that he would hold four hearings around the country next week on milk prices.

JACKIE STEWART of Scotland may drive in the 150 mile big car race at Trenton on Sunday, April 23, if he can get a release from a Formula Two commitment in Europe. Stewart already has been designated as the No. 1 driver for John Mecom Jr. of Houston in the forthcoming 500 mile test at Indianapolis, Mecom owned the LolaFord racers that finished first and sixth in the 500 mile race last year.
HIGH POINT, N.C., April 4 (UPI)--The Imperial Wizard ousted the Kludd from the Ku Klux Klan today.
The Rangers went through such an extraordinarily rough workout yesterday that Coach Emile Francis cut off the scrimmage after only 55 minutes.
James F. McArdle, a 48-yearold trial lawyer, has been chosen as the Republican candidate for District Attorney of Queens. He will oppose the incumbent Democrat, Thomas Mackell, in November.
John Perry, an excellent pianist who has not played here previously, gave a recital at Town Hall last night in the Oberlin College Conservatory of Music Centennial Concert Series.
NEW DELHI, April 4--"We in the Congress party have learned much from our past lapses and I feel that everyone in the party has grown wiser from the past."
Johnny Carson, who receives $780,000 a year as the star of the "Tonight"' show, has notified the National Broadcasting Company that he does not plan to return to the program.

Secretary General Thant left yesterday for Geneva and visits to five Asian countries. He plans to return April 21, the opening day of a special session of the General Assembly on peace-keeping and the future administration of South-West Africa.
Mayor Lindsay learned yesterday that he faced an almost certain move by the Board of Estimate and the City Council to override some or all of his 20 capital-budget vetoes.

The 22d sprint championships of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges will surpass any of the previous regattas held on Lake Quinsigamond at Worcester, Mass., in the arrangements that are being made and the size of the entry.
The head of the Publishers Association of New York City expressed the hope yesterday that the printers would end their daily round of meetings in the composing room of The Daily News.
A car with an 11-monthold girl on the front seat was stolen in Brooklyn last night.

Stocks pursued an irregular course yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. The list was off at the start, continuing Monday's decline. But then some bargain hunters came into the market and prices began a morning-long recovery.

LAKELAND, Fla., April 4-- When the New York Mets yielded 10 runs in one inning a couple of weeks ago, close students of Met behavior warned that as bad things were they could grow worse. Today they did.

Edward T. Shean, a partner in the Wall Street investment banking firm of Lazard Freres, called his office on the morning of March 10 to say that he would be late for work. He has not been seen since, the police said yesterday.

ALBANY, April 4--With a call from Chief Justice Earl Warren for stronger leadership by the states, in partnership with the Federal Government, New York's first Constitutional Convention in 29 years began today the task of rewriting the state's basic charter.

MADRID, April 4--The Cortes (Parliament) voted today without discussion to revise three articles of the Penal Code to provide severe prison sentences for editors and writers who violate the legal limitations on freedom of the press or who "insult" the Government.

NAPLES, Fla., April 4--A prospective juror in the second murder trial of Dr. Carl Coppolino was disqualified today after he said he could not accept the acquittal verdict won by Dr. Coppolino in his first trial in New Jersey last December.

WASHINGTON, April 14-- The House Foreign Affairs committee was told today that "The disillusionment cating away at Vietcong morale" had increased defections of Vietcong troops and civil cadres to a thousand a week.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 4 (AP)--Stokely Carmichael said today that Negroes were not bound to obey laws legislated by white people.
ATLANTA, April 4--A Federal investigation is under way into the possible hallucinogenic effects of banana peels, Dr. James L. Goddard, Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, said today.
WASHINGTON, April 4-- President Johnson complained today that Congress was unduly interfering with his flexibility as Commander in Chief to determine the organization of the armed forces.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)--Two college editors from Howard University argued at a Senate hearing today that there should be special draft deferments for Negroes.

A $100,000 award of punitive damages against the manufacturer of the anticholesterol drug Mer/29 was overturned yesterday on the ground that there was "insufficient evidence of management misconduct."

WASHINGTON, April 4-- Senator Robert F. Kennedy, disagreeing once again with the Johnson Administration, enlisted today in a drive for repeal of the Presidential campaign financing law that Congress passed last fall.
The election of Frank M. Thompson as vice president in charge of personnel was announced here yesterday by the American Express Company, the travel service organization.
LONDON, April 4--Vice President Humphrey sat in the gallery of the House of Commons today and listened to expressions of discontent over United States policy in Vietnam.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 4 --A 24-year-old graduate student at Princeton University was found dead in his dormitory room today. The death was called an apparent suicide by the police here.
More than $17-million has been pledged to the $35-million building and endowment expansion program of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.
HOUSTON, April 4--A chanting, hand-clapping crowd of students from Texas Southern University marched on the Harris County Courthouse here today.
HONG KONG, April 4 (UPI) --The eldest daughter of President Liu has said that her father invited her to renounce the family and leave home last year when she criticized him for opposing Chairman Mao.

The sales and profits of the P. Lorillard Company should be higher in the first quarter and could possibly set records for the entire year, Manuel Yellen, chairman and chief executive, told the annual meeting yesterday.
LAGOS, Nigeria, April 4-- The Federal authorities took a major step toward isolating Nigeria's Eastern Region today when Nigerian Airways suspended all flights to and from the region's airfields.

GENEVA, April 4--The International Committee of the Red Cross announced today that 44 women and children of the Yemeni royal family, who had been under house arrest in Sana for the last four years, had been released by the republican regime and had joined other members of the royal family in Saudi Arabia.

"IT'S time we began to make some noise," said William Thomas. Mr. Thomas is head of Susan Thomas, the sportswear concern that is sometimes described in the fashion business as an enigma wrapped in a mystery.

The Rev. Henry P. Fisher, former pastor of the Roman Catholic Paulist Fathers' Church of the Good Shepherd, Broadway and 207th Street, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 70 years old.
For the final work in its season, the American Opera Society presented Gluck's "Orfeo ed Euridice" at Carnegie Hall last night.

A new disease is reported to have broken out among business forecasters. It is called "currentitus," and it has been described as a "virus characterized by excessive atten- tion to the current behavior of individual statistical series and by debilitating weakness of perspective."

While announcing the rehiring of Dick McGuire as coach as his reward for leading the team out of the cellar for the first time in eight years, the New York Knickerbockers disclosed all sorts of uncertainties yesterday.
A couple of the boys from D'Arcy's Chicago office were in town the other day to see about network time for their client, the McDonald's Corporation.

Federal Bureau of Investigation agents arrested 14 men in the metropolitan area yesterday on charges of illegally arranging draft deferments on the basis of fake documents that had caused unwitting draft boards to issue improper classifications.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) --The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a bill to permit court review of Federal grants to church-related institutions.
The Boeing Company announced yesterday the award of a contract to the Sperry Phoenix Division of the Sperry Rand Corporation for production of flight control systems for the company's 747 airliners.
WHEN Lucy Gallo was 7 years old she was taught how to embroider "by the sisters in the convent in the little town in the mountains, Calitri, where I was born."

WASHINGTON, April 4--A prominent Methodist clergyman sharply deplored today what he called the "strongest pressure" by the Roman Catholic Church on both a state and national level to gain public support for aid to parochial schools.
PARIS, April 4--An officially sponsored committee of financial experts has proposed greater "internationalization" of the world's financial markets to make them bigger and more efficient.
CHICAGO, April 4--The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission strongly urged the nation's commercial broadcasters today to support a system of public television.

A general strike and incessant bloody rioting by rival Arab nationalist forces in Aden have given the newly arrived United Nations mission a grim indication of the difficulties it faces. The three-man team has the responsibility of making recommendations to Secretary General Thant on means of resolving the crisis in South Arabia and promoting viable, democratic government.
The election of C. Charles Marran as president of the Volume Footwear Retailers Association was announced here yesterday during the association's annual meeting at the Americana Hotel.

Prices advanced on a broad front yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. The major factor in the upturn was investors' response to the Treasury announcement of an $89-million increase in Britain's gold and foreign currency reserves in March.

The Library of Congress has acquired several manuscripts and letters of the late Robert Frost who was the institution's consultant in poetry. One letter to Robert S. Newdick in 1935 indicated the poet's playful attitude toward Newdick's studies ...

WESTFIELD, N.J., April 4 --Mr. and Mrs. Arthur C. Kammerman have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julie Madeleine Kammerman, to Daniel Owsley Hogenauer. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Hogenauer of Westtown, Pa.

WASHINGTON, April 4--A State Department official told Congress today that prospects for moving toward a settlement of the war in Vietnam "appear bleak" in the wake of North Vietnam's reaction to peace proposals.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall announced today a partial reorganization of the Bureau of Mines to emphasize further the health and safety of miners and to strengthen research.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4--The United States has lost its 500th warplane over North Vietnam since the bombing raids began 32 months ago.
The Export-Import Bank of Washington announced yesterday it was planning a public offering of $400-million of participation certificates on April 19.

Met with Cabinet under secretaries; met with directors and managers of Veterans Administration's districts; saw President Cedvet Sunay of Turkey; met with Secretary of State Rusk, Defense Secretary McNamara,....
A committee that contends it represents a majority of the faculty at the Brooklyn center of Long Island University called last night for the resignation of R. Gordon Hoxie, the university chancellor.

The 1967 gold medal award of the U.S.O. of New York City was presented last night to Harvey S. Firestone Jr., national chairman of the U.S.O. The presentation was made in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) --The United States has the highest per capita death rate from fires of any of the world's major nations, Congress was told today.
The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, the second-largest commercial bank in Canada, reduced yesterday its prime, or minimum, interest rate on business loans to 5 per cent from 6 per cent.
DETROIT, April 4--The American Motors Corporation is attempting to sell its financing subsidiary, Redisco, Inc., and its Kelvinator appliance division.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 4 --Oral contraceptives not only seem not to cause cancer but they also apparently prevent at least one type of cancer from developing, a Harvard gynecologist reported here today.
Creditors of American Express Warehousing, Ltd., will vote May 9 on a repayment plan--3 years after the company was driven into bankruptcy by a $136-million foodoil fraud.
Miss Penelope Ann Makin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John William Makin of Kuwait, has become affianced to Thomas William Hamilton Phelps, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ward Phelps of Greenwich, Conn.
HONG KONG, Aprii 4--Adherents of Mao Tse-tung accused the Chinese Communist chief of state, Liu Shao-chi, today of the serious charge of counter revolutionary activity.
A 260-pound Army veteran-- once rejected for a city job because of his weight--has won his right to his $8,050-a-year job as a Traffic Department civil engineer.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 4-- Robert Shuttleworth, a harnessracing driver, pleaded not guilty to a charge of first-degree perjury in Nassau County Court today.
ALBANY, April 4--Following are the text of the invocation by Cardinal Spellman and excerpts from the addresses at the opening session of the Constitutional Convention:

Wild beasts strolled in Central Park yesterday along asphalt roads lined by thousands of cheering children. It was a day of precedent. This was the first time that animals and performers of the Ringling Bros. and Barnum...

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 4-- A smaller starting field, reduced galleries and the possibility that Jack Nicklaus would develop a case of mumps provided the gossip today in advance of the Masters golf tournament.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 4-- Communist influence in Latin America is said to be very much on the decline. Presidents, Foreign Ministers and U.S. diplomats all seem determined to emphasize the point, but there is something about the way ...

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) --An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended today that three railroads purchase the Alton Southern Railroad. This line provides switching services for 17 major railroads in the St. Louis area.

WASHINGTON, April 4-- Prospects have brightened for the enactment of an antidiscrimination law for Federal juries in the wake of an endorsement of the Johnson Administration's basic position by the Federal judicial heirarchy.
WITH the hockey players taking time off to enjoy the benefits of their major medical plans, Madison Square Garden welcomed the circus last night.
Herbert Abraham, a chemist and inventor, former chairman of the board of the Ruberoid Company, died Monday at his apartment, 1100 Park Avenue. He was 83 years old.
Rabbi Harry J. Brevis, originator of the International Hebrew Braille Code, will leave today for Israel to test his new shorthand Braille at the Jerusalem Institute for the Blind.

SERQUIGNY, France--An entire generation has matured since the idea of evolving some kind of "Europe" between America and Russia was originally promulgated. Communist, neutralist and anti-Communist leaders were already speaking ...
The St. Lawrence Seaway will open to navigation on Friday, a week ahead of schedule, it was announced yesterday, and expectations are high for another good year.

ALBANY, April 4--Nearly 2,000 persons ate crackers and cheese, danced foxtrots and waltzes and sipped champagne tonight at a gala party for the delegates of the Constitutional Convention that convened today.
BUENOS AIRES, April 4 (Reuters)--An Argentine rugby team decided not to identify itself on the field in a United States tour starting tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) --The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has barred a lower court judge from hearing a multimillion-dollar damage suit against a union in connection with a railroad strike that ended a year ago today.

MIAMI BEACH, April 4-- Miss Karen Lee Baum and Henry Crowell Alexander Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander of Miami, plan to be married here in June at the home of the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Cyril Baum.

ASKED what the city provided in fresh-water fishing recreation for New York children, Mrs. Mary Nichols, a Parks Department public relations functionary, shouted yesterday to an assistant holding the phone, "Tell him kids often bring their own goldfish to Conservatory Lake [in Central Park] to catch!"

"This is all Italian inside this area," said Rev. Mario Zicarelli, marking a small rectangle on a map of the Bronx with his thin forefinger. "We're not the kind who move," he said, "the Irish left when the Negroes came, but Italians don't move."

TEANECK, N.J., April 4-- The Rev. Peter Hess, oldest member of the American Province of the Roman Catholic Society of African Missions, died here Saturday at the American Headquarters of the society. He was 95 years old and had been a priest for 72 years.

Wilbur Franklin Howell, a former executive in the paper container industry, died Sunday in Cuernavaca, Mexico, where he was vacationing. He was 77 years old and lived at 39-43 47th Street, Long Island Cit, Queens.
SOME Wall Street brokers hunt big game or pilot their private planes for recreation. Others prefer the more mundane pursuits of stamp collecting, model trains or photography.

WASHINGTON, Ppril 4--A Senate subcommittee heard testimony today about a tax agent's electronic bug that was supposed to transmit a bribe attempt but tuned in, instead, on a lawyer's private conversation with his client.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) --The Federal Communications Commission said today it had been advised that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company plans to postpone until Aug. 1 the effective date for revised rates on its Telpak service.
PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., April 4 (AP)--The American seniors golf tournament medalist, Alan Howard, was upset today in a first-round match.

ADEN, April 4--The Arab Mayor of Aden said today "the British authorities are cowards" and charged that they had lost control of the Crater district, which was shaken by rioting for the third consecutive day.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 4--Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. asked the Florida Legislature tonight to create a State Department of Justice under the Governor's office to drive crime and criminals out of Florida.
The students of the Bernard M. Baruch School of Business and Public Administration carried picket signs instead of attache cases yesterday in an almost complete boycott of classes at their school.
The Canadian police have voiced concern to enforcement officials in New York over an influx of American Mafia figures to Montreal and Toronto.
