PEORIA, Ill., April 4 (AP)-- A jury trying Richard Speck on charges of murdering eight nurses heard testimony today that he had been drinking and had a gun and a knife shortly before the girls were strangled and stabbed.
BOSTON, April 4--The Unitarian Universalist Association set its sights today on new goals for liberal religion with the unveiling of a candid twoyear survey of its membership.

COLORADO SPRINGS, April 4--Col. Louis C. Kossuth, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Kossuth have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Louise Kossuth, to Ens. Joseph W. Sandford Jr., U.S.N.R. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Webster Sandford of Plainfield, N.J., and Wolfeboro, N.H.

THE words were brave but hardly believable when Emile (The Cat) Francis, the manager-coach of the New York Rangers, offered the somewhat extravagant preseason forecast that his Broadway Blues would gain the Stanley Cup playoffs. At the time it seemed about as unreal a prediction as envisioning those other sad sacks, the New York Mets, as World Series contenders.
WASHINGTON, April 4-- The judge who is hearing Adam Clayton Powell's appeal to be reseated in the House questioned today whether the court had the power to act in the case.

LOS ANGELES, April 4-- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation joined the growing list of entrants in the electric runabout sweepstakes today when it announced the start of production of a snubnosed two-passenger vehicle.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Monday the level it reached on Friday, which was 98.6.
WASHINGTON, April 4-- Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien will go before a Senate subcommittee on Monday to make another plea for more money for his deficitridden department.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) --The American Medical Association urged Congress today not to expand Medicare, as President Johnson has suggested.
BONN, April 4--"What happened to Krupp could happen to a lot of other companies in this country," a West German economist said the other day. "Krupp is on shaky financial legs."

FASHION'S obsession with youth is over, a Paris couturier declared unequivocally yesterday. "Charm will be back," promised Gerard Pipart, the 33-year-old designer for the house of Nina Ricci who is starting a threeweek visit to New York. "Color is going to disappear-- there will be a more uniform look from top to toe," said the designer, ...

DEAL, N.J., April 4--Joseph D. Bannon, former circulation director of the Hearst newspapers in New York City and for 27 years the president of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, died Monday in the Jersey Shore Medical Center, Neptune Township. He was 86 years old and lived at 73 Roosevelt Avenue here.
LONDON, April 4--Britain repaid her remaining shortterm debts to foreign central banks in March and scooped an additional $89.6-million into her reserves of gold and dollars.

The Cunard Line yesterday unveiled for the first time here a five-foot scale model of the Q4, its $85-million superliner now under construction. The model was displayed aboard the Queen Mary at Pier 92, on West 52d Street.

CORNING, Iowa, April 4 (AP)--Oren Lee Staley, head of the National Farmers Organization, gave credit today to the group's milk holding action for causing the Government to call hearings on Federal milk marketing orders.

FARMINGTON, Conn., April 4--Robert Porter Keep, a trustee and former principal of Miss Porter's School, a preparatory school for girls, died Sunday in Hartford Hospital. He would have been 85 years old Friday. His home was at 47 Main Street.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 4-- Senator Mark O. Hatfield told a biennial convention of dock workers today that the Johnson Administration "has lost the capacity to solve" the Vietnam war problem.

The traditional construction slowdown during the winter months is "too costly, illogical and unnecessary" to be allowed to continue because technology makes construction feasible during cold weather, a union official declared.

Class rankings came under attack by graduate school administrators yesterday. On Monday, Columbia Univer ended the practice of ranking students. In the past many law schools and medical schools have considered class rank in selecting students.
A. Philip Randolph, the labor and civil-rights leader, warned yesterday that barring Adam Clayton Powell from Congress a second time would lead to "trouble in the black ghettos all over the country."
Ground will be broken next week for construction of the Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy Center for Research in Mental Retardation and Human Development, an $8-million building at the Bronx Hospital Center.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI)--Manuel F. Cohen, chairman of the Securities and Exchange commission, urged Federal controls today for regulating corporate take-overs through purchases of stock above the market price.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)--The world's only known flock of wild whooping cranes has started its annual northward migration--a 2,500 mile trip to remote nesting grounds near Canada's Great Slave Lake.
PARIS, April 4--The first official analysis of party strength in the French National Assembly today showed that, on paper, the Gaullist coalition falls two seats short of having a majority.
WASHINGTON, April 4-- President Cevdet Sunay of Turkey said today that his country hoped to achieve virtual economic self-sufficiency by the middle of the nineteen-seventies.
The winners of Silurian awards for journalistic achievement in 1966 were announced yesterday by Henry Senber, president of the Society of the Silurians.

The leadership of the National Rifle Association showed something less than robust confidence in its position on gun control when it refused the other day to permit Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts to address the delegates to its annual convention. He was only allowed to speak to a closed meeting of the association's board of directors.

A tender offer for up to 250,000 shares of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., was made yesterday morning by "undisclosed principals" and Wall Street immediately began a guessing game to determine their identity.
The Prudential Insurance Company of America announced yesterday in Newark the election as directors of Paul A. Gorman, Gordon Grand and Fairleigh S. Dickinson Jr.

Dr. Herman Taller, author of the controversial health book, "Calories Don't Count," went on trial in Brooklyn Federal District Court yesterday on charges of mail fraud, conspiracy and violation of the Food, Drug and Cosmetics Act.

The seeds of Cassius Clay's rematch with Floyd Patterson, which was officially announced yesterday for April 25 in Las Vegas, Nev., were sown minutes after the heavyweight champion carefully punished and humiliated the challenger in their first meeting, on Nov. 22, 1965.

WASHINGTON, April 4-- President Johnson was reported today to be resigned to abandoning his drive for Senate approval of a resolution to strengthen his hand for the Western Hemisphere summit meeting next week.
Dr. Albert B. Sabin, developer of the oral polio vaccine, has appealed for public support of a campaign to bring war-disfigured Vietnamese to the United States for treatment.
International House, a residence at 500 Riverside Drive for graduate students from 84 countries, will hold its annual Festival of the Arts from next Wednesday through April 16 and again on April 22.

The United Artists Corporation achieved record net earnings of $13,616,000 last year, despite a drop in gross income, according to the report yesterday of Robert S. Benjamin, chairman and Arthur B. Krim, president of the film company.

James E. Reardon, onetime partner in Harry Gross's $20million-a-year bookmaking combine, won a directed verdict of acquittal yesterday in Federal Court after the Government refused to disclose an informer's home address.

TRENTON, April 4--The Hughes administration has tentatively decided that Solberg Airport in Hunterdon County is the best possible site in northern New Jersey for the metropolitan area's fourth major jetport.
MOSCOW, April 4--The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia commented in an ironic tone tonight on reaction in the United States to Moscow's offer to sell giant hydroelectric turbines and generators.
ROME, April 4--A 24-year fight by an Italian shipowner to recover more than $3-million taken from him by the Japanese in World War II has brought about the attachment of Japanese assets in Italy.
Major banks in Chicago, Los Angeles and New York reported yesterday that their net operating earnings for the first quarter rise above the yearearlier level, in some cases sharply.
An organization of civil rights, labor and religious groups has called for the United States to urge the use of force to topple the Rhodesian government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith.

Thomas F. Lennon, an investment counselor and former amateur sports official and timer, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital of bronchial pneumonia and a brain hemorrhage. He was 71 years old, and lived on Turkey Hill Road, Montville, N.J.

The Composers' Showcase has as its theme this season, "A Sampling of American Music of This Century," and a sampling is exactly what was heard last night in the group's third concert at the Eisner and Lubin Auditorium of New York University's Loeb Student Center.
Airborne devices that will enable airline pilots in effect to make multilane highways in the sky out of the present single lane routes will be tested in the Northeast this summer.

MONTE CARLO, April 4-- Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the United States chess champion, won the Grand Prix International today with a total of 7 points out of nine games, despite losing his last-round game to Evfim Geller of the Soviet Union.

Confusion among traders still dominated wheat futures yesterday. In a down-and-up market, prices sold off sharply during the day only to show small gains by the end of the session. The weather was responsible for much of the indecision. Had drought hurt the crop badly or not?

The Brooklyn College Chorale last night opened a fiveyear series of concerts that will bring forth obscure musical settings of the Passion of Jesus Christ. This marathon undertaking combines research and performance of neglected...

The National Basketball Association will hold its "pro draft" on May 1 and its college draft on May 3, in New York, the league office announced yesterday, and a coin-tossing ceremony to determine first pick in the college draft will be held today.
A $330,067 program to help Puerto Ricans in New York City find jobs, or better jobs than they have now, will begin next week, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, Agril 4--The charge that American bombardment of North Vietnam is deliberately not being confined to military targets was made today by five members of a delegation that returned from Hanoi last week.

The first visit to Washington by the locally elected Chief Executive of the Ryukyus, Seiho Matsuoka, calls attention to the fact that, 22 years after the war, the United States is still administering a chain of Japanese island with a population of almost a million.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 4 (AP)--Gordon Novel walked out of jail today on $10,000 bond and cast fresh mystery on his role in the New Orleans investigation of the assassination of President Kennedy.
NEW DELHI, April 4--Stalin's daughter, Svetlana Alliluyeva, has disclosed that she defected to the West only after having been told that the Indian Government would not grant her asylum.

The recent loss of the 118,825ton Liberian tanker Torrey Canyon, laden with crude oil, off the coast of Cornwall, has focused attention on one of the world's oldest commercial practices--marine insurance.
SAIGON, April 4 (Reuters)-- Two companies of Vietcong-- about 300 guerrillas attacked a police station tonight five miles from the center of Saigon.
Two copper and brass fabricators yesterday followed earlier price cuts on some products by competitors.
MOSCOW, April 4 (AP)-- Soviet political and military leaders met in private today, presumably to discuss the selection of a new Defense Minister or discuss matters of wider international importance.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. called yesterday on Negroes and "all white people of goodwill" to boycott the Vietnam war by becoming conscientious objectors to military service.
BALBOA, C.Z., April 4--The Panama Canal's monthly traffic record for transits of oceangoing ships was broken during March.
The Riegel Paper Corporation stated yesterday it had filed suit in Federal District Court here to prevent the Brown Company from acquiring additional Riegel shares.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) --Stewart L. Udall, Secretary of the Interior, said today that Under Secretary Charles F. Luce would not participate in policy discussions or decisions relating to electric power matters during his remaining months in office.
Stock prices seesawed in indecisive trading yesterday and closed with an almost even distribution of gains and losses.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 4--The stoppage of thoroughbred racing is not expected to spread to Roosevelt Raceway, where the trotters and pacers currently are in action.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. called yesterday on Negroes and "all white people of goodwill" to boycott the Vietnam war by becoming conscientious objectors to military service.
BALBOA, C.Z., April 4--The Panama Canal's monthly traffic record for transits of oceangoing ships was broken during March.
The Riegel Paper Corporation stated yesterday it had filed suit in Federal District Court here to prevent the Brown Company from acquiring additional Riegel shares.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) --Stewart L. Udall, Secretary of the Interior, said today that Under Secretary Charles F. Luce would not participate in policy discussions or decisions relating to electric power matters during his remaining months in office.
Stock prices seesawed in indecisive trading yesterday and closed with an almost even distribution of gains and losses.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 4--The stoppage of thoroughbred racing is not expected to spread to Roosevelt Raceway, where the trotters and pacers currently are in action.

THERE is a lad in Manhattan named Tim (for Thomas) Moore. He is 12 years old, in the sixth grade at Collegiate School, and he holds, like Samuel Johnson, that he who does not mind his belly will hardly mind anything else.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 5 --Mrs. Betty Powers Smith has announced the engagement of her daughter, Second Licut. Kathleen Power Smith, U.S.A.F., to Capt. Wallace L. Morse, U.S.A.F. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Shired Morse of Modesto, Calif.
A 20-story marble-clad tower at the southwest corner of Broadway and 58th Street is undergoing a $20-million renovation.
WASHINGTON, April 5--Mayor Lindsay urged Congress today to triple the proposed $50-million in Federal aid for local crime-control programs. The Mayor also asked...

An air of bafflement and expectation hung yesterday over Aqueduct race track, which was closed because of a horsemen's boycott. The executive personnel sat around waiting for some word from Albany about a possible way to solve the dispute.

The "Terrible Williamsons" are headed this way from their winter retreat in Canada. And, if past experience holds, this itinerant gang of confidence men and women will gull many homeowners of more than $1-million before they return home this autumn, the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York warns.

GENEVA, April 5--Secretary General Thant of the United Nations said today that prospects for peace in Vietnam "are as distant today as they were a year ago." He warned anew that "because of the increasing intensification of the war there are more prospects of the war widening into a larger war and spilling over the frontiers."

CLEVELAND, April 5 (AP) --An official of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers said tonight that a system-wide strike against the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad had been called for 3 P.M. Friday in a dispute over a change in working conditions at Meadville, Pa.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 5-- It was business as usual at Roosevelt Raceway today. While the status was quo at Aqueduct, where thoroughbreds once sped and mutuel machines whirred, standardbreds were being entered at Roosevelt and post positions were being drawn for races three days in advance.
The bond-market tug of war between investors and investment bankers heated up yesterday, but the results of the contest still appear far from settled.
Robert B. Walker, president and chairman of the American Tobacco Company, criticized yesterday various studies that contend that cigarette smoking causes many diseases.

ANKHE, South Vietnam, April 5 (AP)--A soldier of the United States First Cavalry Division (Airborne) fought his way out of Vietcong captivity three weeks ago, according to reliable sources, but the Department of Defense has ordered official silence on the incident.

WASHINGTON, April 5-- Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said today that the House leadership was studying possible courses of action if Adam Clayton Powell is reelected, as expected, next Tuesday and presents himself again for admission.

WASHINGTON, April 5-- The Agency for International Development, in a major policy shift, plans to finance the manufacture and distribution of contraceptive pills for developing countries that have voluntary family planning programs.
CHICAGO, April 5--The chairman of the Communications Satellite Corporation today labeled as "nonsense" a Ford Foundation charge that the corporation threatened to become a "baleful monopoly."

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 5 --Mr. and Mrs. Edward Ross Aranow have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Vicki Anne Aranow, to Donald Mark Klcin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Klein of North Caldwell, N.J.
Stock prices moved upward yesterday in a moderate but sustained advance.

PARIS, April 5 (Reuters)-- A secret agreement to merge French left-wing non-Communist parties into a single Social Democratic party at the end of this year was disclosed here today by Guy Mollet, the Socialist leader.
Two more building inspectors have been dismissed, Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler said yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 5--A United States Air Force wing commander who flew his 100th mission over North Vietnam today has discounted the idea of bombing MIG bases, which is favored by other pilots.
BURWINKEL, Germany-- The dairy farmers of the moorland here are caught in a wet dilemma: too much water on the one hand, and too much milk on the other.

Renato Fasano is conducting his Virtuosi di Roma in four Vivaldi programs in Philharmonic Hall this week. Last night, for the second concert, he had a vocal group at his disposal as well, the Coro da Camera di Roma. The group, a chamber chorus of 26 voices directed by Nino Antonellini, proved to be as technically proficient and suave in sound as the instrumental group.

PETERBOROUGH, Ont., April 5 (AP)--Johnny Bower, the Toronto goalie, suffered al split finger on his right hand during a practice session today and will miss the opening Stanley Cup playoff game against the Hawks.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Thursday, April 6 (AP)--An Agena rocket misfired in orbi early today, tossing a $9-million satellite out of control in the wrong orbit.

WASHINGTON, April 5-- The dollar outflow from the United States to pay for direct investment in Europe and other developed countries will decline about $400-million this year, according to projections given the Commerce Department by 612 large companies.
Joan Conway's playing last night at Carnegie Recital Hall showed her to be a musical pianist whose best efforts were frustrated by an insensitive approach to the piano.

Free Society Association Scores Romney on War WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) --The Free Society Association, of which former Senator Barry Goldwater is honorary chairman, rebuked Gov. George Romney of Michigan today for not, as it put it, taking a firm stand on Vietnam.
OSLO, Norway, April 5-- The mink farmers of Telemark, 100 miles north of Oslo, lost half of their 30,000 animals to food poisoning yesterday.
Fifteen theatrical unions voted overwhelmingly yesterday to give full support to the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists in its strike against the three television and radio networks.
The Manhattan Savings Bank announced here yesterday the appointment of E. Virgil Conway to the new post of executive vice president.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., April 5-- Mr. and Mrs. John Tyson of Bryn Mawr and Northeast Harbor, Me., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Tyson's daughter, Miss Elise Biddle Paumgarten, daughter also of the late Harald Paumgarten, to Thomas Tew Benson. He is the son of Mrs. John Howard Benson of Newport, R.I., and the late Mr. Benson.

PEORIA, Ill., April 5--The only survivor of a night of ter ror last July when an intruder killed eight nurses in Chicago walked across a courtroom here today, pointed at Richard Speck and declared: "This is the man."
The city's firemen voted last night to perform only emergency duties beginning at 9 A.M. today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 5--Significant increases in financial and technical support for population-control programs in the developing countries are being made by United States and United Nations agencies.

WASHINGTON, April 5-- A Democratic Senator accused President Johnson and Senate leaders today of resorting to delay and "wheel-deal' tactics in opposing repeal of the new law on financing Presidential campaigns.
TULSA, Okla., April 5 (UPI) --Dick Stuart quit the Los Angeles Dodgers today for a chance "to be a somebody again playing baseball in Japan.
"There are just too many potatoes," a commodities broker commented yesterday. In that statement was the crux of the potato problem.

The Franklin National Bank of Mineola, L.I., which has grown into an institution with almost $2-billion in assets by aggressively merchandising retail services for consumers, plans to take a new step to enhance its credit services for business.

BONN, April 5--The United States is proposing to redeploy two-thirds of one of its six divisions in West Germany, the first major withdrawal since American forces were committed to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization 16 years ago.

HANOVER, Germany, April 5 (AP)--The Opposition Free Democrats ended a controversypacked national convention here today with proposals for increased contacts with East Germany and a demand that West Germany renounce nuclear weapons even in case of war.

The Detroit Pistons won the right yesterday to pick first in the National Basketball Association draft May 3. Presumably they will go after Jimmy Walker of Providence as a backcourt partner for Dave Bing, their rookie of the year.

CONVICTS and butterflies in some quite outrageous and improbable confrontation lie at the creaking heart of John Taras's "Piege de Lumiere." The title implies "a light trap," and the ballet concerns the efforts of a band of runaway convicts to entrap butterflies. One of these delinquent lepidopterists becomes more interested in a butterfly than perhaps anyone should, and this leads to disaster.

TRENTON, April 5--The president of the state chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said here today that a proposal to provide free bus transportation to private and parochial schools would precipitate a "mass exodus" of white pupils from New Jersey cities.
Raina Kabaivanska sang the title role in "Madama Butterfly" for the first time with the Metropolitan Opera last night, and she gave a fresh account of herself.

A new impasse developed yesterday in the dispute over dismissed faculty members at St. John's University when the United Federation of College Teaehers insisted that proposed arbitration also include those who went on strike.
Fourteen civic organizations joined yesterday in charging that pupils are often wrongly accused of unruly behavior and suspended from public schools without fair hearings.

SEIJI OZAWA, slim, steelspring, intense, conducted his own orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. It is thee Toronto Symphony, which appeared as part of the International Festival of Visiting Orchestra. The 30-year-old Japanese conductor took it over in 1965.
ADEN, April 5--Imprisoned Arabs jeered and snubbed a visiting United Nations factfinding mission today while terrorist mortar and machine-gun fire erupted outside the prison walls.
HAVERFORD, Pa., April 5 --The Board of Managers of Haverford College announced today the appointment of Dr. John R. Coleman to be the 16th president of the 134-year-old school.
ANDERSON, Ind., April 5 (AP)--Ike W. Duffey, former meat packer, railroad president and sports promoter, died yes- terday at his home. His age was 56.
LEW ALCINDOR and all the other 7-foot-tall college basketball players as well as those not so tall won't be allowed to stuff, dunk or drop the ball through the nets anymore because of a new ruling.
A boycott by horsemen who are seeking higher purses shut down Aqueduct Race Track yesterday, and there were no indications of an early end to the dispute.

Mischa Elman, short, somewhat round, bald, energetic, would come bustling out on stage in that indescribably cocky walk of his. He would look over the audience with wise eyes that had seen audiences of all kinds for 30, 40, 50 years. Then he would tuck his Stradivarius under his chin.

In one of the most momentous steps in its history, the United States Lawn Tennis Association has embarked on a program designed to raise vastly increased revenues for carrying out an organization and development expansion that could add millions to the number of players throughout the country.

ALBANY, April 5--The State Tax Commissioner disclosed today that lottery tickets would sell for $1 and that many of the ticket outlets, which now include hotels and motels, would be paid 2 or 3 cents a ticket, or possibly more, for their handling costs.
Prices turned around yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and recovered some of the ground lost in Monday's decline.

THE growing enthusiasm for bridge among college students has led to an increased number of intercollegiate contests. Columbia University held the first of an annual series of intercollegiate team of four events last month, and the winners were Margaret Gwozdzinsky, David Smith, Lewis Finkel and Steve Goldstein, all of City College, and Louis Rowen of Columbia.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI)--The United States has rejected a Philippine demand for the return of Sangley Point Naval Air Station to the Philip pine Navy.
Mayor Lindsay has decided to give a $700-a-year raise to registered staff nurses who work the evening and night shifts, in an effort to alleviate the acute shortage of nurses during these hours.

OF all the changes that have been made in the coaching staff of the New York Football Giants, the one that unquestionably brought the warmest glow to the vast army of faithful followers was the appointment of Alex Webster as the director of the offensive backfield. For one glorious decade Big Red served as a symbol of the Giants.

WASHINGTON, April 5-- The dollar outflow from the United States to pay for direct investment in Europe and other developed countries will decline about S400-million this year, according to projections given the Commerce Department by 612 large companies.

NAPLES, Fla., April 5--The exhausting procedure to find an impartial jury for the second murder trial of Dr. Carl A. Coppolino seemed near an end today with Judge Lynn Silvertooth and the defense counsel, F. Lee Bailey, hopeful that a jury could be sworn in tomorrow.
Five hundred New York Port Authority policemen picketed the midtown bus terminal here yesterday for a parity in pay with city policemen. They are now getting $8,372 a year, and want $1,000 more.

WASHINGTON, April 5--The arrival of the baseball season need not be a terror to women. Despite many women's suspicions, baseball is such a simple game that even children can understand it. Let us outline its principles in all their simplicity for the benefit of all those women who want to get more out of their summers.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 5--A harness racing driver and a material witness in Nassau County's investigation into the sport pleaded not guilty today to perjury charges.

ALTHOUGH the leprechaun with the voice of a cricket and the eyes of a bluebottle fly candidly acknowledges-- in "Finian's Rainbow"--that there are such things as fourwish crocks of gold, he carefully explains that the crock on the premises is strictly a three-wish job and nobody had better clamor for more.
ROTTERDAM, April 5 (AP) --The district court of Rotterdam consented today to the public sale of two American ships of the Sapphire Steamship Lines of 230 Fifth Avenue in New York City.

Louis Fess Taylor, the key prosecution witness in the Bronx trial that resulted in former State Senator Eugene Rodriguez being convicted of extortion, pleaded guilty yesterday in Supreme Court to attempted felonious possession of narcotics and to criminally pos sessing a pistol, a misdemeanor.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) --The Post Office Department has fined nine railroads $127,500 since Jan. 1, charging them with delaying the mails.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI)--Harold Howe 2d, United States Commissioner of Education, told the Senate today that he felt draft deferments for college students were "no longer justified."
The appointment of Michael F. Bloch as staff vice president was announced here yesterday by the American Machine and Foundry Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 5-- The State Department announced today a relaxation of American visa requirements for foreigners. It is designed to stimulate travel to the United States in 1967--designated International Tourist Year by the United Nations.
BERLIN, April 5--The West Berlin police said tonight that they had arrested 11 persons on charges of having plotted to assassinate Vice President Humphrey.
WASHINGTON, April 5-- Former Ambassador Edwin O. Reischauer criticized today the United States embargo on trade with Communist China as ineffective and recommended that it be relaxed.
Undefeated New York University scored 10 runs in the sixth inning yesterday to break a 2-2 tie and overwhelm Bates College, 16-2.

TWO iconoclastic American designers, a generation apart, were honored last night by a retrospective showing of their clothes at the Fashion Institute of Technology (F.I.T.), 227 West 27th Street. Elizabeth Hawes, who shook up the fashion world in the nineteen-thirties with her custom-made designs, and Rudi Gernreich, who has done the same thing in the sixties with ready-to-wear, were selected as examples of "Two Modern Artists of Dress" at work.
ODESSA, U.S.S.R., April 5 (AP)--Soviet aid shipped from this Black Sea port to North Vietnam apparently has increased sharply over the last two months.
WASHINGTON, April 5--A number of proposals were offered by Senate Republicans today in an effort to give President Johnson full Congressional backing for the Western Hemisphere summit meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 5-- In June of 1754 Commissioners from New York, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, New Hampshire and Maryland met at Albany. In view of increasing difficulties with the Indians and the war with France, they adopted Benjamin Franklin's "Albany Plan."

MASSAPEQUA PARK, L.I., April 5--Thomas P. Swift, retired president of Thomas P. Swift Associates, a public relations and advertising company in New York, died today in Massapequa General Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived here at 129 Thornwood Road.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 5 (UPI)--A wealthy rubber planter threw his hat into the South Vietnamese presidential ring today.
Charity-ball trotters, an ambivalent lot who find the idea enjoyable but the sameness somewhat painful, dropped two words from their usual description of such events last night.

BEGINNING freshwater an glers are most fortunate because all the best is ahead of them. It is as if they can afford to suffer through the minor pains of making a beginning. None needs a $200 rod, a $100 reel, a $25 line, $40 waders and a $20 creel.
DETROIT, April 5--Byers A. Burlingame, president and chief executive of the Studebaker Corporation, will retire sometime this year, the company's annual report said.

The Ford Foundation and Communications Satellite Corporation are at odds about how best to set up a domestic satellite system that would carry educational television. Neither side, it appears, has all the answers.
The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) yesterday acquired Ankney Food Service, Inc., an in dustrial catering and vending company of Dayton, Ohio. The terms were not disclosed.
DETROIT, April 5--Automobile safety publicity is costing the industry more than one million units in car sales this year and is spurring sales of small imported models, a market analyst said today.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., April 5--"We expect continued improvement for both sales and income for all of 1967," D.C. Burnham, president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, told about 750 stockholders here today at their annual meeting at the Beverly Hilton Hotel.
Union printers lifted a road block yesterday to direct negotiations on key economic issues in the city's newspaper dispute.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5-- When Jack Nicklaus tees off tomorrow at 12:30 P.M. in the Masters golf tournament, he will have an opportunity no other golfer has had. The husky 27-year-old from Columbus, Ohio, has a chance to win the coveted title for the third year in succession.

WASHINGTON, April 5-- Senator Robert F. Kennedy has recommended to President Johnson the appointment of Milton Pollack, a Manhattan lawyer, as a Federal judge for the Southern District of New York. Mr. Kennedy's office said the recommendation was expected to be approved by the President and sent to the Senate for confirmation. Mr. Pollack, who is 60 years old, lives at 480 Park Avenue.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 5--The Dutch have had commercials on television for three months, and by all accounts they find it innocuous, largely ineffectual and frequently funny.

Special to The New York Times ALBANY, April 15--Moses M. Weinstein has been called a "cherry bomb" who explodes with references to the Bible and to Confucius and uses sharp wit to score telling points during political debate.
Little Jimmy Patton, a fearless safetyman who played 12 distinguished seasons with the New York Giants, announced yesterday his retirement from professional football.

A GREAT lure of faraway beaches are the unusual clothes available in resortarea boutiques. For its newly opened beach shop on the fifth floor, Lord Taylor has imported some of these sprightly designs from resorts as far apart as Puerto Vallarta on the Mexican Pacific coast and ...

THIS is an enjoyable escapade. In a solemn time, when vicarious cares make the whole world a "be-in" of trouble, I recommend Ved Mehta's gift of laughter. Chacha means uncle in Hindustani. The delinquent bit is self-bestowed--like this one's other titles. He is an engaging fraud. And although his habitat is contemporary India ...
HOLLYWOOD, April 5-- The Oscar presentations of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences will go on as scheduled Monday night, whether they can be televised or not.
WASHINGTON, April 5--The Government's top labor mediator sought tonight to head off what would be the nation's biggest trucking strike.
Stocks finished up with glamour issues strongest in moderately active trading; volume, 8.81 million shares. Corporate bonds were steady in brisk trading; transactions, $14.72 million.
NEW DELHI, April 5-- Foreign Minister M.C. Chagla denied today that he had misled Parliament by telling it that Sta- lin's daughter, Mrs. Svetlana Alliluyeva, had never sought asylum in India.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 5-- Dr. Hermann J. Muller, winner of the Nobel Prize in 1946 for his discoveries of the hereditary effects of radiation, died today at Robert W. Long Hospital. He had been hospitalized last month with a heart condition.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- President Johnson asked Congress today to increase the pay of Federal employes, both civilian and military, by an average of 4.5 per cent. He also gave the details of a requested increase in postal rates.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) --Mrs. Ona G. Cooper, a former regent of the Army-Navy Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, died yes- terday at her home in this area. She was 83 years old.

MADRID, April 5--United States and Spanish airborne troops are to "assault" the northern city of Saragossa next month in combined aerial maneuvers that for the first time will work Spain into the Western European defense pattern.
The Federal Government is seeking medical data from physicians on the health of airplane pilots in the interest of aviation safety.

Faculty members of nine Roman Catholic colleges and seminaries in Westchester County will consider "The Making and Identity of the American Jew" at a three-day institute beginning April 16 at the College of New Rochelle.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 5 --Thousands of chemicals, among them extracts from trees that grow in mainland China and insects that inhabit Taiwan, are being sifted through a screen at the National Cancer Institute, Bethesda, Md., to sort out those that show anti-cancer activity.

The International Milling Company, Minneapolis-based food processor, realized a 64 percent increase in earnings for the six-month period ended Feb. 28 on a sales gain of 9.5 per cent, the mid-year report disclosed yesterday.
OTTAWA, April 5--Canada converted today an additional $50-million of her gold reserves into interest-bearing United States investments.

ST. LOUIS, April 5 (AP)-- Bill Bridges scored 25 points and pulled down a career high of 32 rebounds to lead the St. Louis Hawks to a 115-109 victory over San Francisco tonight in the final round of the Western Division playoffs of the National Basketball Association.

ARLINGTON, Tex., April 5 (UPI)--Keith Russell of Phoenix, Ariz., added the 10-meter platform diving championship today to the 3-meter springboard title he had won earlier in the national Amateur Athletic Union indoor diving championships.
WASHINGTON, April 5--A new wide door to the world of life without oxygen is being opened at the National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Md.

SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, April 6--United States soldiers Shot and killed three North Koreans yesterday in a brief exchange of fire 50 yards south of the demarcation line separating North and South Korea, it was announced today.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., April 5 --Supporters of a 1968 Presidential campaign by former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama have opened a headquarters in this suburb of Washington "to encourage him to run on a third-party ticket."
WHITE PLAINS, April 5-- A State Supreme Court justice refused today to grant Westchester County's request for an immediate end to picketing by welfare caseworkers.
VALHALLA, N.Y., April 5 --Air pollution has become serious in Westchester County and soon will be dangerous unless controls are imposed, public health officials argued today.

ALBANY, April 5--The State Constitutioanl Conven tion rounded out its leadership today with the appointment of four vice presidents, top committee chairmen and the designation of Moses M. Weinstein as majority leader, or Democratic floor manager.

BUFFALO, April 5--The National Conference of New Politics, a coalition of peace, civil rights and antipoverty activists, announced today a program to oppose actively the renomination of President Johnson in 1968.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5-- Another overwhelming performance by Wilt Chamberlain, who set a playoff record by hauling in 41 rebounds, brought the Philadelphia 76ers a 115-104 victory tonight and brought the Boston Celtics to the brink of dethronement after eight years as champions of the National Basketball Association.
Two burglars were surprised by the wife of a broadcasting company executive yesterday as she returned to her East Side apartment while they were ransacking her home.

LISBON, April 5--About 300 Portuguese royalists shouted "Long live the King, Long live the monarchy," today in a majo rmonarchist demonstration. The demonstration followed an elaborate ceremony organized by the Government of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar on the occasion of the return of the remains of Dom Miguel, Portuguese pretender, who died in exile in 1866.
Two men were named yesterday as acting provosts of Long Island University's turbulent Brooklyn center, for succeeding terms.

Irving Seidman, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, said yesterday that some underworld figures who flourished during Prohibition had moved into bootleg cigarette rackets that have cost the city and state more than $50-million in taxes in the last nine months.
ROME, April 5 (UPI)--Angelo Piero Sereni, Bologna University professor of international law, who taught for many years at Columbia University, died yesterday. He was 59 years old.
Sent message on Federal pay rises and postal rates to Congress; presented Boy of the Year Award to Gerald Simile of Dennison, Tex.; saw Postmaster General O'Brien; met with Cabinet.

Mrs. Ruth Houghton Axe, a woman of finance, who is president of E.W. Axe Co., investment adviser and underwriter of the several AxeHoughton mutual funds, has been invited to join the Board of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad (the Katy).

Patrick Francis Meagher, a 95-year-old retired printer who was responsible for the establishment of the Police Department bagpipe band, died yester- day in his home at 1977 Morris Avenue, the Bronx. He was believed to have been the oldest member of the International Typographical Union, which he joined when he was 18.

The chief financial officer of a textile consulting concern pleaded not guilty in Federal Court yesterday to charges he attempted to give a $200 bribe to an Internal Revenue Service agent for a favorable audit of his employer's return.

Richard S. Giovine, advertising manager since 1964 for the Commercial Solvents Corporation, manufacturers of chemicals, died of a heart attack Tuesday afternoon at a photographic studio at 570 Fifth Avenue. He was 52 years old and lived at 35-63 161st Street, Flushing, Queens.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 5--Two hundred Dutch sailors and roamed the streets of Amster dam tonight hunting for beatniks, who were said to have molested the servicemen's girl friends.
The Nederlander family, operators of a chain of legitimate theaters, is planning to enter the Broadway producing field.
The Rutgers baseball team defeated Columbia, 7-5, at Baker Field yesterday, scoring six of its runs on homers. It was Columbia's first loss of the season. The Lions had won their first two games.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) --Racketeers use more sophisticated electronic devices, or bugs, than Government agents do, an official of the Internal Revenue Service testified today.

The format is the next best thing to printing money yet its operation seemingly generates a trauma peculiar to electronics: restlessness de luxe.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)--Sales of United States manufacturers totaled $145.6billion during the last three months of 1966, up 10 per cent from a year earlier, the Federal Trade Commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
JEFFREY GETWELL, an unsung hero with a high forehead and a diffident smile, can afford to feel slightly smug today.
LAITHIEU, South Vietnam, April 6 (AP)--Powerful air blowers that sweep Vietcong guerrillas with 1,000-degree blasts are being used north of Saigon.

ADEN, Friday, April 7--A United Nations mission cut short its visit to the violence- racked British Protectorate of South Arabia today, charging that the British had refused to cooperate with it.
The Federal Reserve's policy of aggressive credit ease was manifest beyond any possible doubt yesterday.

DALLAS, April 6 (AP)-- Mike Burton of the University of California, Los Angeles, broke the listed American record for the 500-yard free-style event in the finals of the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor swimming meet tonight and also tied the pending record of 4 minutes 37 seconds set by Greg Buckingham of the Santa Clara Swim Club, the defending champion, two weeks ago in the National Collegiates.
WASHINGTON, April 6-- The Government struggled today to settle two major labor disputes threatening to snarl the nation's transportation system.

The Women's League for Israel will hold its 39th anniversary luncheon Monday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Proceeds will be used for the Vocational Training Center for Girls in Nathanya, Israel, and for maintenance of four other "Y"-style homes the organization maintains in Israel.

WASHINGTON, April 6-- The Governor of the Bank of Italy said today that he "repudiated out of hand" the view widely held in Europe that American capital investment there must be limited to prevent economic "domination."

GENEVA, April 6--The poorer countries presented today a four-point list of trade concessions that they hope to obtain from the industrialized nations at the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting negotiations in order to speed their economic development.
ALBANY, April 6 (AP)-- Former Assemblyman Orin S. Wileox of Theresa, Jefferson County, will head the new State Lottery Commission, Governor Rockefeller announced today.
LONDON, April 6--Sir William Connor, who as Cassandra in London's Daily Mirror was the most widely read columnist in Britain, died in St. Bartholomew's Hospital today. His age was 57.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 6--Joint committees of American and Vietnamese experts are being established in an effort to come to grips with the country's most pressing economic problems.

OTTAWA, April 6 (AP)-- The effect of new lockage charges on the Welland Canal will be almost 15 times greater on Canadian shipping than on American, the Dominion Marine Association's annual meeting was told yesterday.

These sketches of nine noted--or notorious leaders of Tammany Hall provide also a once-over-lightly political history of New York City and, in lesser measure, of New York State. The book covers the activities of the political bosses from the earliest days of this nation when the political club house was the service agency for the newly arrived immigrant--in return for votes--to the present ...

MONTECITO, Calif., April 6 --Mrs. Eleanor Wilson McAdoo, a daughter of President Wilson and the former wife of William Gibbs McAdoo, Mr. Wilson's Treasury Secretary, died last night at her home here. She was 77 years old.
For the fourth day this week, potato futures set new lifetime lows yesterday as they continued their slide.
Anne Ayer, a mezzo-soprano, brought a program of seldomheard songs to Town Hall last night. It was the mature singer's first local appearance, but she has toured abroad.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., April 6--Linden H. Morehouse, retired board chairman of the Morehouse-Barlow Company, publishers of Episcopal books at 14 East 41st Street in New York, died of a kidney ailment today in the United Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 336 Carol Avenue in Mamaroneck.

Clifford B. Mandell, manager of press relations for WCBS-TV, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, after collapsing at Pochari's restaurant, 8 East 52d Street. He was pronounced dead on arrival at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived in Syosset, L.I.

New York State has put up its first money--$37.5-million --toward construction of the East 63d Street subway-rail tunnel to Queens. In a related move, the Transit Authority is seeking city approval of an en- gineering study for a new East Side subway.

ROME, April 6--President Edward Ochab of Poland arrived today on a state visit to Italy that may also produce discussion with Pope Paul VI of long embittered but recently improving church-state relations in Poland.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6-- An Arnold Palmer golf ball was declared illegal for play in the Masters tournament today, but Palmer wasn't worried.
AINTREE, England, April 6 (AP)--Two American-owned horses, one last year's winner and the other owned by a movie star, Gregory Peck, are heavily backed to win Saturday's Grand National Steeplechase.

ALBANY, April 6--The State Court of Appeals ruled today that 16 ferryboat officers who were not rehired by New York City after they walked off their jobs in 1965 had never been given a fair hearing to determine whether they had been discriminated against.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) --Endicott Peabody, former Governor of Massachusetts, said today, at a hearing on his nomination for a Federal job, that funds raised at a testimonial dinner for him next June 12 would be used solely to pay off campaign deficits.

BUENOS AIRES, April 6--A good reporter even on a short trip should be able to find a big place like Latin America, but it is not easy and in actual fact Latin America may not even exist except in name. There are twenty sovereign states reaching from the Rio Grande to the South Pole ten thousand miles away.
PARIS, April 6--French production of the highly enriched uranium needed for hydrogen bombs and nuclear submarine propulsion began last week, the Government announced today.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 6--The New York Yankees finished the Florida portion of their preseason schedule in a blaze of errors today as they lost to the Washington Senators, 5-2. The Yankees made three misplays, including Mickey Mantle's first error as a first baseman, and the Senators contributed five.

BROOKFIELD CENTER Conn., April 6--Mr. and Mrs. E.H. Lewis have announced the engagement of their daughter Miss Diane Lewis, to Gerald H. Majer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Majer of St. Charles Ill. The wedding is planned for next month.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6 (UPI)--There are two fancy scoreboards at the plush golf course where they play the Masters golf tournament.
PITTSBURGH, April 6 (UPI) --Six policemen and two former members of the force were harged today with bribery and extortion in permitting racketeers to operate unimpeded.
"The Sound of Music," generally regarded as the biggest money-making film ever, did so badly in West Germany that it has been withdravrn there until further notice.
GLEN COVE, L.I., April 6-- Dr. Elvis L. Eckles, associate dean and a professor of economics at the City University of New York, died of a heart attack in his home this morning. He was 50 years old.

Rudolph A. Peterson, president of the Bank of America, the world's largest privately owned bank, called yesterday for a reappraisal of United States policy for combating the deficit in its international payments, and for a relaxation of Government controls over foreign lending and investing by American business.

The Commercial Solvents Corporation told stockholders yesterday that the company was making progress in developing a new class of chemicals said to be capable of inhibiting fertility and accelerating animal growth.
HYDERABAD, India, April 6 (AP)--His Exalted Highness Nawab Mir Barkat Ali Khan Bahadur was installed today as the eighth Nizam (ruler) of Hyderabad.

BERLIN, April 6--Heinrich Albertz, a 52-year-old Protestant pastor, was confirmed as Mayor of West Berlin today after having filled that post since last December, when his predecessor, Willy Brandt, left Berlin to become West German ...
Aqueduct plans to resume racing tomorrow, even if only one horse is entered, and George D. Widener indicated last night he would enter that horse.
CARSON CITY, Nev., April 6 (AP)--A bill making it easier to obtain a Nevada divorce was signed today by Gov. Paul Laxalt.
ALBANY, April 6--A proposal for mandatory free college education in New York was submitted to the Constitutional Convention today.

DETROIT, April 6 (AP)-- United States auto production reached 2 million for the year to date today--22 days later than the production date of the Cumillionth car of 1966. The lag reflects production cuts in the face of slow sales.

WASHINGTON, April 6-- The White House announced today that President Johnson would leave Andrews Air Force Base Monday night on a nonstop flight to Montevideo, Uruguay. From there he will fly 80 miles by helicopter to the beach resort of Punta del Este.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 6-- Dr. Roger W. Heyns, chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley, said today that "the bewilderment, criticism and even anger" sometimes expressed about the school was diminishing.

The men of Hook and Ladder Company 44 gathered around their big red American LaFrance truck after Capt. Howard Borden had completed the 9 A.M. roll-call in the old firehouse at 1261 Morris Avenue. the Bronx.

Determination among the members of the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association to continue its boycott against thoroughbred horse racing at Aqueduct remained firm yesterday. The statement that there would be racing at the track tomorrow failed to create a break in the solidarity of the group's members.

An opponent of the present proposal for Interstate Highway 87 in Westchester County testified yesterday that Governor Rockefeller had told him that he, too, was opposed to the plan, but had been "forced" by the Federal Government to accept it.
BY the time he was 30 years old, Creighton Williams Abrams Jr. was a man of legendary exploits.
The Meadow Brook National Bank and the Bank of North American announced yesterday that their proposed merger had been approved by the Controller of the Currency.
LONDON, April 6--Just to the right of the entrance to the premises of the Anti-Slavery Society in London stands a seven-foot Y-shaped piece of wood.

WASHINGTON, April 6-- Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, has introduced a bill that would make unlawful the sending of a pandering advertisement through the mail. The proposal is aimed at curbing the sale of erotic literature and devices.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 6-- Teamsters and dockers pledged today to win substantial gains in the California warehousing industry this year, either at the negotiating table or on the picket line.

WASHINGTON, April 6(AP) --The House of Representatives debated a complex overhaul of the copyright laws for nine hours today but failed to resolve the chief controversies over jukeboxes and communityantenna television (CATV) systems.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., April 6 (AP)--Walter A. Dowell of Walnut Ridge, Ark., the defender, defeated William Holt of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., 1 up, in the quarter-finals of the American Senators golf championship today.

ROME, April 6 (Reuters)-- An appeals court here lifted tonight an obscenity conviction and two-month suspended sentence against Gina Lollobrigida for seduction scenes in the film "Le Bambole" ("The Dolls").

BERLIN, April 6--The lawyer for eight German students held on suspicion of plotting an attack on Vice President Humphrey with explosives said today that they had planned to throw only smoke bombs and plastic bags containing flour, pudding powder and buttermilk.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John S. Brittain of the engagement of Mrs. Brittain's daughter, Miss Hope Brewster Bromley, to Christopher Runyon Jennings, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malbon Hollis Jennings of New York.

At Lincoln Center today: New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 2:15 P.M.; "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Gabriel Banat, violinist; Joan Dorneman, harpsichordist, and Anita Gelber, pianist, Library and Museum of the Performing Arts, 6:30.

WASHINGTON, April 6--A national vice president of the American Jewish Congress sharply criticized Senator Jacob K. Javits today for the Senator's assertion that New York should liberalize its restrictions on state aid to parochial schools.
The slowdown by firemen, accompanied by definite threats of strike, confronts the city with a dangerous emergency.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) --Elijah Mays, a former employe of the Detroit Police Department, declined today to answer detailed questions by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee on wiretapping. He said he feared for his safety.

The Lorraine Building, once a fashionable Fifth Avenue hotel and now an office tower, has been sold by the estate of Matthew Byrnes to Chatham Associates, one of the real estate investing companies of Sod Goldman and Alexander DiLorenzo Jr., for about $4million.
The city's 10,500 unionized firemen began a partial work stoppage yesterday in a pay dispute with the city by suspending such routine duties as inspecting buildings and fire hydrants.
A Lindsay administrationsponsored application to the Federal Government for $400,000 to plan a Model Cities program here won unanimous approval by the Board of Estimate yesterday.
"Ice Capades," which for the last 13 years has set up shop here indoors at Madison Square Garden, will be performed outdoors this year in its annual New York appearance.
The City Council's Committee on Buildings killed a bill yesterday that would have created a commission to study the new building code now awaiting city action.

The Enjay Chemical Company, a subsidiary of Standard Oil (New Jersey), said yesterday it planned two major multimillion-dollar expansions to increase production capacity for two additives and one solvent at its Bayway manufacturing complex in Linden, N.J.

S. Klein Department Stores, Inc., the chain whose main store is the bargain-lure at Union Square, will bear the thrust of future expansion of its parent company, the McCrory Corporation, Meshulam RikliS, chairman of McCrory, said yesterday.
Mrs. Lucille Pickett Williams is winding up her political campaign the same way that it began: with a tiny budget, no hoopla and no hope.

WASHINGTON, April 6-- Donald F. Turner, head of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division, indicated to Congress today that he would probably not attempt to bar a merger of the American Motors Corporation with a nonautomotive company.

More than 800 residents of Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant area demanded at a turbulent meeting last night that they be permitted to vote for the board of directors of any corporation set up to stimulate the redevelopment of the community.
Horse-drawn carriages brought many of the 1,200 guests to the Waldorf-Astoria last night for a ball in behalf of Boys' Towns of Italy.

Net operating earnings of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in the March quarter climbed to a record first-quarter figure of $14,785,419, or $1.18 a share, up 18.02 per cent from the $12,527,792, or $1 a share earned in the like 1966 period.
Social leaders have lots of playthings. All the playthings have funny names. The merrygo-round is fashion, the seesaw is art; there is a swing called decorating and a sandpile known as charity.

Alexander Mikhailovich Nikolaieff, a former colonel to the general staff of the Imperial Russian Army and the czarist regime's last military attache in Washington, died on Tuesday at Metropolitan Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived at 2029 Second Avenue.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad asked a Federal Court in New Haven yesterday whether the line "can and should be continued in operation" two or three more years, in view of the recent Supreme Court decision delaying the Pennsylvania-New York Central railroad merger.

The political problems now facing the Gaullists in France were masked in the 261-to-214 victory of Jacques Chaban-Delmas over the left bloc candidate, Gaston Defferre, in the contest for President of the National Assembly.

SYRACUSE, April 6--Paul Shipman Andrews, dean emeritus of the Syracuse University College of Law, died today at the Veterans Administration Hospital here. He was 79 years old.
A picture of a blue vase full of large, blossomed flowers, painted by Renoir in 1881, was sold last night to an unidentified Chicago collector for $100,000.
Franke Wille, New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced the appointment yesterday of John K. Lundberg as First Deputy Superintendent of Banks.

The body of an unidentified man was found in a parked automobile, six blocks from Manhattan police headquarters just before midnight last night. The police said the man was the "apparent victim of a gangland-type ride."
The stock market held on to a narrow gain yesterday after a late afternoon retreat pared an earlier advance.
Michael Kroll, the 21-year-old Marine Corps sergeant who was shot to death in Greenwich Village on Monday while he was on leave from Vietnam, was buried with military honors yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 6--An enemy force estimated at 1,500 soldiers was reported today to have carried out a series of daring attacks on Quangtri, the capital of South Vietnam's northernmost province, and to have freed 200 to 300 prisoners.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 5-- The Laotian Government cannot control and cannot halt the movement of North Vietnamese troops through its territory to South Vietnamese battlefields, the Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, said today.
WESTBURY, L.I., April 6-- Cardigan Bay's next start here will be Tuesday night, April 18, John Cashman Jr., the racing secretary at Roosevelt Raceway, announced today.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Fridays. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) --A Senate report today praised the combat operations of the Navy and the Marine Corps in Vietnam, but found shortages of pilots and experienced non-commissioned officers.
CHICAGO, April 6--Parsons College in Fairfield, Iowa, lost its accreditation today.

WASHINGTON, April 6-- A double agent who pretended to spy for the Soviet Union while working for the Federal Bureau of Investigation told Congress today that the Russians had frequently warned him of danger by sticking chewing gum on his mailbox.
The appointment of Sal Nuccio as a vice president of the Continental Insurance Companies was announced here yesterday by J. Victor Herd, chairman.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6-- Bruce Devlin brought his father here from Australia to watch him play in the Masters golf tournament today. In the first round. Devlin gave his father an added treat by shooting a double eagle 2 on a par-5 hole. An eagle is 2 under par on one hole, a double eagle 3 under par.
DENVER, April 6 (UPI)-- The Colorado Senate approved today a bill that would liberalize the state's abortion law.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6-- Bert Yancey, who obtained his first glimpse of the Augusta National Golf Club course four days ago, solved its intricacies today. The 28-year-old professional from Philadelphia, a former cadet at the United States Military Academy, outplayed a field of 82 rivals with a five under-par 67.
J. Frank Forster, president of the Sperry Rand Corporation, will begin wearing two new corporate hats, those of chairman and chief executive officer, on July 25.

SYRACUSE, April 6--A crop of barnyard art is growing here, nourished by its originator, George Vander Sluis, and by what he calls "seed money" --a $5,000 grant from the New York State Council on the Arts.
The London Stock Exchange edged up yesterday after overcoming a mid-session round of profit taking.

WASHINGTON, April 6-- The National Association of Letter Carriers attacked today President Johnson's proposal for a 4.5 per cent pay increase for postal workers this year as "inadequate" and a demonstration of "shocking disregard" for the postal service.

The body of a man identified by the police as John W. Smith of North Bergen, N.J., was found at 11:50 P.M. Thursday, slumped in the front seat of a car near Canal Street. There were three bullet wounds in his head.
PARIS, April 7--Premier Georges Pompidou announced tonight the formation of a new Gaullist Government in which most of the key Ministers remain the same as in his former Cabinet.

MOSCOW, April 7--A sweeping revision of wholesale prices in industry, crucial to the implementation of the Soviet Union's profit-oriented economic reform is expected to be put into effect on schedule July 1 despite serious lags in preparation.

HOUSTON, April 7--While the other members of the New York Yankees merely marveled tonight at the synthetic Astroturf that has replaced grass in the Astrodome. Tom Tresh inspected it cautiously. Tresh did not want to risk reinjuring his right knee.
An acquisition in the women's foundation industry that looked sour at the time, has turned sweet according to Garson Reiner, chairman and president of Exquisite Form Industries, Inc.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., April 7 (UPI)--Eleven-yearold Kenneth Young, safely home after being held for three days by a kidnapper, turned today to helping the police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation track down his captors. He told his father the record $250,000 ransom should not have been paid.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Enright Butler of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Butler's daughter, Miss Judith Ann Olan, to Bernard Marie Jacques Boullet, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Roger Boullet of Paris.
BONN, April 7--Dr. Heinz Nordhoff, head of the Volkswagen Motor Company, announced today in Berlin that Kurt Lotz would succeed him at the end of 1968.
BONN, April 7--The West German Cabinet presented to Parliament today the draft of a law to make possible the curtailment of the right of postal and telephone privacy in time of national emergency.

MANILA, April 7 (AP)-- About 300 Philippine and American war veterans, some of them on crutches, stood silently at attention today during a ceremony opening a four-day observance of the 25th anniversary of the World War II battles at Bataan and Corregidor.
LEO ROSTEN, known best for his warm and sweet-tempered sketches of H*Y*M*A*N K*A*P*L*A*N, has writ- ten in his new book a dilly of a thriller.
TRENTON, April 7--A move to draft a "uniform interpretation" of New Jersey's abortion law was announced here tonight by the State Attorney General, Arthur J. Sills.
Stocks slipped again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

NEW ORLEANS, April 7 (UPI)--The president of the Shipbuilders Council of America said today the United States merchant fleet could be improved with modern automated ships while Government subsidies were reduced 50 per cent. The president, Edwin M. Hood, addressed Tulane University's 18th annual Institute of Foreign Transportation and Port Operations.
Three youths of Brooklyn's Bedford--Stuyvesant section were arrested yesterday and charged with the knife-slaying last Monday of a 58-year-old
WASHINGTON, April 7-- Some of the world's biggest bombers will begin operations in the next few days from the largest airfield in Southeast Asia.

THE stock market sagged a bit yesterday, But the consensus of Wall Street analysts seems to be that the major movement still points upward. For the record, the Dow-Jones industrial average fell 7.91 points yesterday, to close at 853.34.

WASHINGTON April 7 (AP)--"The jingle, the rumble and the roar" of the old Wabash Cannonball may soon fade forever. The Norfolk Western Railway wants to discontinue the famous old train, effective May 10.
A COLLECTION of 45 designs in natural Russian sable, commis sioned by the Soviet Union for display at its pavilion at Canada's Expo 67, has just been completed by a wholesale fur manufacturer here.
The credit markets continued yesterday to react to the Federal Reserve's discount rate reduction.

BERLIN, April 7--Authorities said today they had found no evidence of a conspiracy to kill Vice President Humphrey and released eight Berlin students who were arrested two days ago in what the police said was a plot to attack Mr. Humphrey with explosives.
A 3-foot bronze statue called the "Prince of Peace" will be dedicated this month at a special ceremony in the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations, 777 United Nations Plaza.

LONG BEACH, L. I., April 7 --Morris Kramer, who retired in 1965 as head of Kramer Brothers and Schorr, a real estate concern formerly at 1440 Broadway, New York, died yesterday at Long Beach Memorial Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived here at 450 Shore Road.

ROCHESTER, April 7--The marriage of Miss Anne Ramaker Trainor, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George McCague Trainor, to Michael Anthony Ralph, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Ralph, took place here this afternoon in Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church. Msgr. Leslie G. Whalen, the pastor, and the Rev. David Moody, of the Third Presbyterian Church, officiated.

KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, April 7 (AP)--St. Vincent's British administrator, Hywel George, today revoked the appointment of Chief Minister E.T. Joshua, dissolved the Legislature Council and assumed complete control of the country.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, April 8--A major trucking shutdown was at least temporarily averted early this morning when industry negotiations decided to keep bargaining with the teamsters' union despite scattered work stoppages.

The Association for Women's Committees for Symphony Orchestras will hold its biennial meeting at Lincoln Center beginning April 25. More than 80 delegates from orchestras in 32 cities of the United States and Canada will attend four days of panel discussions, lunch eons, dinners and concerts.
MONTREAL, April 7 (AP)-- The eastern section of the St. Lawrence Seaway, swept by a snow squall, opened today for what is expected to be a record shipping season.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 7--The 138th vessel built for the Navy by the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, the nuclear submarine Ray, will be commissioned next Wednesday.

As the International Automobile Show neared the end of its nine-day stand at the Coliseum yesterday, the mood among United States exhibitors was one of cautious optimism. In contrast, importers were frankly in ecstasy, for the biggest retail showcase in the city was proving a sales bonanza for the overseas makers.

Four Stradivarius instruments valued at $500,000 have been lent to the Iowa String Quartet by the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington. The two violins, viola and cello were made by Stradivari between 1692 and 1736 and all were in the collection of the 19th-century virtuoso. Nicolo Paganini.

PORTMOUTH, Va., April 7 (AP)--Johnny Briggs hit his second home run of the game with two men on in the ninth inning today to give the Philadelphia Phillies an 8-7 exhibition victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
The resumption of commercial cargo bookings for Saigon has been announced by Solon B. Turman, chairman of Lykes Brothers Steamship Company of New Orleans.

The Carnegie Corporation of New York announced yesterday that it would give $400,000 to Harvard. Yale and Columbia Universities to help students, mainly Negroes, go on to graduate school after college.

The Board of Missions of the Methodist Church moved yesterday to withhold proxies on 10,500 shares of Eastman Kodak Company stock it owns to question the company's repudiation of a job-training program for Negroes.

OSLO, Norway, April 7--The Norwegian Government, in an apparent shift, has decided to reject a Soviet proposal to let tourists cross the border this summer for brief visits to the Soviet town of Boris Gleb.
CAMDEN, N.J., April 7 (AP)--Coit Hendley Jr. will become editor of The CourierPost on April 17, William A. Stretch, publisher, announced today.
TOKYO, April 7 (UPI)--Lu Liang Huan of Taiwan posted a three-under-par 69 today to take a one-stroke lead at 140 after 36 holes in the Yomiuri international open golf championship.
The Allegheny Power System, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday "substantial progress" in 1966.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) --Representative Lucien N. Nedzi, Democrat of Michigan, who charged there was apparent immunity of professional athletes from the military draft, announced today a finding that there were 360 such athletes in military reserve units.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI)--President Johnson today proclaimed April as Cancer Control Month.
Nine young singers were named winners of the semifinals of the 1966-67 Metropolitan Opera Regionals Auditions, which were held at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon.

"Masters of the Loaded Brush," at Knoedler, 14 East 57th Street, is a benefit for Columbia University's department of art history and archeology, and a collection of paintings by masters of the 17th and 18th centuries who (to explain the title) filled their brushes richly with oil pigment and had a great time capitalizing on its fluidity and texture. BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 7--A campaign of public denunciation and a party purge, traditional instruments of repression in a Communist country, are serving to show the vigor of democratic tendencies as well as the limits of democracy in Yugoslavia.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 98.3 on Thursday from 98.5 on Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 (UPI)--The Philadelphia 76ers' star center, Wilt Chamberlain, who has sparked his team to three consecutive play-off victories over the Boston Celtics, did not practice today because of severe pain in both knee joints.

NAPLES, Fla., April 7--A jury for the second murder trial of Dr. Carl A. Coppolino was completed today. Testimony on the charge that he killed his first wife with an injection of a little-known drug will probably begin Monday after the selection of two alternate jurors.
The city government has become overcentralized and remote from the communities under the Lindsay administration, the Manhattan Borough President, Percy E. Sutton, asserted yesterday.

The driver of a stolen car abandoned it on the Madison Avenue Bridge, linking Manhattan and East 138th Street in the Bronx, and then jumped 40 feet into the Harlem River. Members of the Police Department's Tactical Patrol Force who had been chasing him for a mile at 65 miles an hour, picked him out of the water five minutes after his jump and booked him for grand larceny.

A request for a 4.46 per cent rate increase by the Jamaica Water Supply Company was opposed by the city yesterday partly on the ground that the utility had offered no proof that its chief officer performed the work of an executive.
SAN JUAN, P.R., April 7 (UPI)--Mrs. Yvette Diago Powell has filed a support suit against her husband, Adam Clayton Powell, but is not "at this moment" seeking a divorce, her lawyer said today.

The elections of John F. Burditt as chairman of the board of ACF Industries, Inc. and Henry A. Correa as president, effective May 1, were announced yesterday by William T. Taylor, the present chairman. Mr. Taylor, 67 years old, will become chairman of the executive commit tee.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7 (UPI)--A Superior Court judge enjoined the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists today from picketing the Augusta National Golf Club, where the Masters tournament is scheduled to be televised tomorrow and Sunday by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
NEW DELHI, April 7--Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is trying to assert her leadership of the Congress party by insisting that it support the candidate of her choice for the presidency of India.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday the city would move soon to change some taxicab regulations.
