DENVER, April 7--The Colorado Legislature today all but completed passage of a bitterly contested bill to liberalize abortion laws.

NATCHEZ, Miss., April 7 (AP)--A racially integrated jury heard a Mississippi sheriff today tell how the fatal shooting of an elderly Negro was designed to lure the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. into an assassination ambush.
PARIS, April 7--Vice President Humphrey heaped warm words of praise on President de Gaulle today. He called the French leader a great man of courage, held in high esteem by President Johnson.
JERUSALEM (Israel), April 7--Israel reported that six MIG-21's of the Syrian Air Force were shot down today by Israeli Mirage fighter planes in a series of air battles east of the Sea of Galilee.

MIAMI, April 7--During the October, 1962, missile crisis, Maj. Ernesto Che Guevara was preparing resistance against an expected United States invasion of Cuba, Granma, the Cuban Communist party's newspaper, disclosed yesterday.

SCRANTON, Pa., April 7-- Sister M. Eugenia, a member of the Sisters Servants of the Immaculate Heart of Mary order for 65 years, and former president of Marywood College here, died last night in St. Joseph's Hospital. She was 83 nears old.

SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N. J., April 7--F. Miller Fargo Jr., from 1939 to 1953 a vice president and a director in New York for the American Cyanamid Company, died today in his home here on Woodland Avenue. He was 80 years old and also had a home on Nantucket Island.

Jerrold R. Golding, president of the Essex House and vice chairman of the board of directors of the Sterling National Bank and Trust Company, died of a heart attack yesterday in the hotel. He was 50 years old at lived at 778 Park Avenue.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and former Representative Eugene J. Keogh testified yesterday in United States District Court here that they knew of no improper influence that had led the United States Department of Commerce to select the route of a Westchester County section of Interstate Highway 87.

The Japan Fund, Inc., a closed-end investment company, has elected Jonathan Mason to the new post of chairman of the board. Harry G.A. Seggermen was elected president to succeed Robert L. Garner, who will remain a director.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) --Termination of Federal aid for 21 southern school districts and one college for failure to comply with the nondiscrimination provisions of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 was announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 7--The United States has told six Atlantic allies that it sees "only a fair chance at best" of winning agreement from the Soviet Union to halt the deployment of antiballistic missile defense systems, authoritative sources said today.
Sales and earnings of Consolidated Foods Corporation registered new records in the 36 weeks ending March 11, Willam Howlett, president, reported yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. C.B. Tsien of Jesselton, Sabah, Malaysia, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Vickie Mei-Yue Tsien, to T'ing Chung Pei of Medford, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ieoh Ming Pei of New York.
Miss Joy Deborah Javits, the 18-year-old daughter of Senator and Mrs. Jacob K. Javits, had a nondebut last night.

FEW sculptors at work today can equal the technical mastery that Isamu Noguchi brings to the carving of stone. In the hands of this exquisite craftsman, stone is given an amazing delicacy, precision and gemlike strength. Nature--the nature of stone--and artifice are joined in an elegant harmony.
The Watertown (N.Y.) Savings Bank announced yesterday that it planned to reduce the dividend rate that it pays on savings accounts to 4 per cent from 5 per cent, effective May 1.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 7-- When the crystal night falls on this timeless place, the watcher on high ground notices a peculiar thing: There appear to be two star-filled skies, one overhead and the other in the valley.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 7 --Miss Loraine Kelly and Dale E. Seborg plan to marry in August.

ADEN, April 7--South Arabia's Prime Minister, Mohammed Hassan Obali, charged tonight that the United Nations fact-finding mission, which left abruptly this morning, had snubbed the Arab populace and decided to "communicate through the colonialist power only."
During the first week of operation of the new state law covering narcotics addicts, 23 persons have volunteered for treatment and six of them have been committed, it was announced yesterday.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7-- Jack Nicklaus set another golfing record in the Masters tournament today, but it was the one he wanted to avoid.

SAN DIEGO, April 7 (AP)-- Clay Hodges of Los Angeles, the Golden Gloves champion, gained the semi-finals of the heavyweight division today in the national Amateur Athletic Union boxing championships by outpointing Mike Boswell of Youngstown, Ohio.

Or would the elimination of present requirements and tests in the licensing of teachers lead to a lowering of standards--and poorer teachers for the city's children? Those are the basic questions that have
HOT SPRINGS, Ark., April 3--The century-old gambling tradition continues in this resort town, despite the efforts of a new Governor to wipe it out.

The National and American Football League owners will vote next month on the 1968 site of the Super Bowl game, which this year was played at Los Angeles. There have been indications that there is strong backing to have the contest shifted to Miami's Orange Bowl.
THE light flooding a living room when a switch is turned on may one day come not from table lamps or built-in panels but from "light paintings."

Supporters of the Communist newspaper The Worker, published here twice a week, voiced hopes yesterday that a will now under probate would yield a million dollars toward enabling the paper to resume daily publication.
BOYNTON BEACH, Fla., April 7-John O. Sirot, a former registrar and field representative for Point Park College in Pittsburgh, died here Wednesday. His age was 67.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 (AP)--A white junior high school teacher was suspended today for three days without pay and ordered transferred to another school for allegedly reciting a racially insulting rhyme during a classroom session.

William Manchester, author of "The Death of a President," will make "three or four hundred thousand dollars" from his history of the assassination of John F. Kennedy. The memorial library named for the President will receive "five to 10 million dollars."

AINTREE, England, April 7 (AP)--Different Class, owned by the film star, Gregory Peck, and two other thoroughbreds in the field of 44 are the 9-1 favorites to win tomorrow's Grand National steeplechase.
WASHINGTON, April 7--A United States District Court judge ruled today that the courts had no right to order the House of Representatives to seat Adam Clayton Powell.

LIVINGSTON, N.J., April 7 --Miss Jeraldine Doris Dickson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Dickson, was married this afternoon to David Morris Kozloff, son of Mrs. Samuel Kozloff of Wyomissing, Pa., and the late Mr. Kozloff. Rabbi Barry Green performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.
James F. Hackett, first deputy fire commissioner, died last night at Bronx Lebanon Hospital. He was 54 years old.

CHICAGO, April 7 (AP)--A plan to extend school operating hours by 1 to 2 hours daily and step up voluntary shifting of pupils was proposed to the Chicago school board today by Superintendent of Schools James F. Redmond.

Libraries are for dancing, or was that a Broadway show some seasons ago? In any case, Larry Richardson and Dance Company flashed through a short early evening recital of three works last night at the Donnell Library Center of the New York Public Library at 20 West 53d Street.

WASHINGTON, April 7-- The United States has offered the World Bank a contribution of up to $960-million over the next three years--with certain conditions--as its share of a major increase in funds for loans to poor nations.
Efforts are under way in Bedford-Stuyvesant to close the split between two corporations who want to direct the redevelopment of the largely Negro ghetto in central Brooklyn.

Secret bargaining talks between the printers and The Daily News continued yesterday, but the stereotypers broke off their negotiations with the Publishers Association and threatened to strike at midnight tomorrow against The Long Island Press.

The United Nations mission to South Arabia had planned to stay three weeks and visit all seventeen states making up the Federation that is to become independent next year. Instead, it has packed up and left Aden after less than five days, charging the British authorities with failure to cooperate.
LOS ANGELES, April 7-- Show business must wait until Monday for its awards but local business is already reaping its rewards from the annual rite of the Oscar.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 8--South Vietnam proposed today a 24-hour truce on May 23 to celebrate Buddha's birth.

Austin N. Heller, the city's Commissioner of Air Pollution Control, called yesterday for the use of minicabs and electrically powered taxis to reduce the witch's brew of gas fumes enveloping New York.

The Automobile Competition Committee of the United States announced yesterday some changes in its 1967 schedule and the tentative racing dates for 1968. The United States Grand Prix and two long endurance races for prototype sports cars were involved.

POETS should always have poetic names like Rim- baud. It should be in their contract with God. They should perhaps always have poetic ballets created about them, such as Frederick Ashton's "Illuminations" seen for the first time in many years at the New York State Theater last night. "Illuminations" was the first work the New York City Ballet ever commissioned from a foreign choreographer; it was also almost the last and always the best.
LONDON, April 7 (Reuters) --Prime Minister Donald Sangster of Jamaica, critically ill in a Montreal hospital, was knighted today by Queen Elizabeth, it was announced from Buckingham Palace.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Levine of Far Rockaway, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Marsha Levine, to Mark Arthur Wallace. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton J. Wallace of Brooklyn.

TORONTO, April 7--The Newfoundland government is planning to guarantee more than $50-million in debt securities and take voting control of Canadian Javelin, Ltd., to consummate a $120-million Javelinpromoted pulp and paper venture. Javelin, a Canadian mining and development company, has been continually embroiled in controversy.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 7-The New York Mets pulled up stakes and headed north today after winning 11 games and losing 13 in spring training here.
DETROIT, April 7--A plastic camper, designed to fit on the back of a pick-up truck, has been shown by the Ford Motor Company. Traditional camper units are made of wood or aluminum.

Mrs. Katherine Iselin O'Donnell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Iselin of New York and Oceanport, N.J., was married yesterday to Frederick Martin Gilman, son of Mrs. Frederick Gilman of Oakhurst, N.J., and the late Mr. Gilman. Rabbi Aaron Lefkowitz performed the ceremony in the home of the bride's parents at 785 Fifth Avenue.
SHERRILL, N.Y., April 7-- This is the smallest city in the state and, appropriately it has a very small mayor. The population is 2,922. The mayor stands 5 feet 2 in high heels.
WASHINGTON, April 7-- The White House thanked Gov. George Romney of Michigan today for a "strong endorsement of the fundamentals of the Administration's position on Vietnam."
The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company of Milwaukee has agreed to sell its controlling interest of 1,700,000 shares of common stock of John Labatt, Ltd.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) --President Johnson announced, today that there would be a fourth annual Presidential program to place the stamp of excellence on about 120 boy and girl scholars.
The case for and against Monteverdi was ably put forth last night at Town Hall as Johannes Somary led the Amor Artis Chorale and Orchestra in some rarely heard works.

ROME, April 7--Pope Paul VI expressed grave concern today over the growth within the Roman Catholic Church of a spirit of challenge to sacrosanct doctrines and even to the authority of the Magisterium-- the hierarchy he heads.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7-- To many a suburbanite who spends his summer fighting weeds, bugs and dry spells, grass is grass as long as it's green. To a golfer who earns his living hitting a ball hopefully from one patch of brass to another, the least difference in the length or texture of the grass can be earth- shaking.
GENEVA, April 7--Evidence that the diplomatic gloves are coming off in the final phase of the Kennedy Round was provided today by the Nordic delegations.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 (AP)--Robin Roberts, a star right-hander with the Philadelphia Phillies for several years, will return to the club's minor league system.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., April 7 --Gordon I. Donovan, director of sales of the Triangle Conduit Cable Company, Inc., of New Brunswick, died today in his home at 747 Dixie Lane. His age was 65.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)--Government and industry officials today urged the selling of 60 million pounds of nickel from the national stockpile to help meet a domestic shortage.

An ethnic, racial and economic survey of families with children in the Roman Catholic elementary and high schools of the city will be undertaken next week by the New York Archdiocese and the Brooklyn Diocese.
DALLAS, April 7 (UPI)-- Don Schollander of Yale and Mark Spitz, a Santa Clara, Calif., schoolboy, posted American records tonight in the men's national amateur athletic union swimming championships.

DARES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 7--Four East German secondary school teachers were to arrive in Tanzania, this weekend under a bilateral agreement signed in Dar es Salaam. They will be assigned to schools here and in Mbeya.
A major battle appears to be shaping up between the city's Health Services Administration and some physicians.
CARSON CITY, Nev., April 7 --A bill increasing the state's gambling tax by an average of 20 per cent cleared the Nevada Legislature last night. Gov. Paul Laxalt is expected to sign it.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) --The State Department announced today that seven countries had been added to the list of those whose citizens will be eligible, beginning April 15, for indefinite, multiple entry visas to the United States.
North American Aviation, Inc., announced yesterday the election of William B. Bergen as vice president in charge of the space and propulsion group.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7--Arnold Palmer, an emotional golfer who plays emotional golf with peaks and valleys, is unhappy. He is in a par rut.
SOCHI, U.S.S.R.--This somnolent, subtropical resort on the Black Sea, sheltered from the Siberian winds by the snowcapped Caucasian Mountains, has hopes of becoming an international vacation center.
ATHENS, April 7--Twentyseven students were injured and 10 persons were arrested in Athens tonight in the latest of a week-long series of political demonstrations.

The Columbia Pictures Corporation is extending through April 14 its offer to exchange common shares of the film company for the 36,690 outstanding shares of its $4.25 cumulative preferred stock, Abraham Schneider, president, announced yesterday. The offer had been scheduled to expire Monday.

It may be talking prosperity, but it is behaving as if it fears recession.

The chairman of the Long Island University Board of Trustees said yesterday that he would request suspension of all classes at the Brooklyn center on Tuesday if a week-old student boycott continued on Monday.
The 1964-65 New York World's Fair, which lost $20million in its first fiscal year, increased its total deficit by about $1-million in 1965, it was indicated yesterday.

The Excelsior Savings Bank and the Empire City Savings Bank, both based in Manhattan, announced yesterday that Frank Wille, the New York State Superintendent of Banks, had approved their proposed merger.
ST. LOUIS, April 7 (AP)-- Emil Frei Jr., a designer of stained-glass windows died yesterday of a heart attack in Kirkwood, a suburb. He was 71 years old.

HARRISON, N.Y., April 17 7--Pepsico, Inc., filed plans with town officials here today for the multimillion--dollar corporate headquarters that it proposes to build on 112 acres in Purchase that had been the home of the Blind Brook Polo Club.

Negotiations in the strike against the television and radio networks resumed last night in an effort to settle the 10-dayold dispute. The meeting, at the Barclay Hotel broke up at 12:15 this morning and will resume there at 10 A.M.

In the first day of the twoday Intercollegiate Women's Fencing Association national championships held at Hunter College Park Avenue last night, Paterson, Fairleigh DickinsonTeaneck, Cornell and Montclair finished undefeated and became eligible for the finals today.
WASHINGTON, April 7-- One of the principal tourist attractions on Capitol Hill moved upstairs today.
CAMIRI, Bolivia, April 7-- The bodies of seven Bolivian soldiers officially described as ambushed by "Castro Communist guerrillas" were brought to this dusty jungle town today.

Perley L. Thorne, professor emeritus and former chairman of the mathematics department of New York University, died yesterday in Augusta Ga., where he was visiting relatives. He was 83 year; old and lived In Ponte Vedra Beach Fla.

FAIRFIELD, Iowa, April 7 (AP)--Millard G. Roberts president of Parsons College said today the school would appeal its exclusion from the approved list of the North Central Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools.
THE knitted dress is the closest thing to a panacea the fashion business has developed for the woman who doesn't know what to wear.

A man sought in the fatal stabbing of a Swedish seaman on March 9 in front of the Swedish Seamen's Center, 150 South Portland Avenue, in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, turned himself in yesterday at the Bergen Street station. He was charged with homicide.
Patsy Cantore, former president of the Bleecker Manufacturing Company, 33 Bleecker Street, died yesterday at the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 74 years old.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 7 (AP)--State Senator Robert O. Tiernan of Warwick, a Democrat who supports President Johnson's policy in Vietnam, is the official winner of a special Rhode Island Congressional election.
The city reached contract agreements last night with the firemen's and policemen's unions after months of negotiations, threats of strikes and a work slowdown.
A pair of red brick buildings in Greenwich Village that once served as an ironworks warehouse will soon become the first low-income housing co-operative for artists in the city.
LANSING, Mich., April 7 (AP)--James P. Hoffa, 25 years old, son of James R. Hoffa, imprisoned teamsters union president, says he will be a Democratic candidate for the Michigan Legislature.

AMES, Iowa, April 7 (AP)--, A movement erupted on the campus of Iowa State University today to impeach the president of the student body after the student newspaper said he admitted attending a marijuana smoking party.

The Hat Corporation of America, the country's largest hat manufacturer, signed a consent decree yesterday with the Federal Government agreeing not to acquire any men's fur-felt hat producer in the next five years.

TOKYO, April 7--Richard M. Nixon said today that "if the credibility of the United States is destroyed in Vietnam, it will be destroyed in Europe as well." Deploring the attitude of some Europeans who feel that the United States commitment in Vietnam is a mistake, the former Vice President said these Europeans would quickly realize the meaning for Europe if the United States refused to fulfill its commitment in Asia.
The rowing season begins today for major college eights of the East with a particularly attractive race between Princeton and Rutgers on Carnegie Lake at Princeton.
PEORIA, Ill., April 7--A seaman testified today that Richard F. Speek, accused of murdering eight nurses, told a Chicago bartender a few hours after the killing that a "sex maniac must have done it."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 7-- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman made a public appeal tonight to the Kennecott Copper Corporation to abstain from developing a rich copper deposit in a Washington State wilderness area.
ELIZABETHTOWN, Pa., April 7 (AP)--A police officer was shot to death today in a bank robbery in nearby Maytown, the authorities reported.

NEW ORLEANS, April 7 (UPI)--District Attorney Jim Garrison's office refused today to accept conditions for the voluntary return of Gordon Novel for questioning in an alleged plot that led to the assassination of President Kennedy.
EACH Saturday, thousands of students in 215 colleges across the nation sit down to dinners of broiled steak or lobster tail.
TORONTO, April 7--The half-point reduction in the Canadian central bank rate to 4 per cent is being interpreted here as a removal of unrealistic restraints on the economy rather than as a stimulus.

Miss Molly D. Gerard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sumner Gerard of Ennis, Mont., was married here yesterday to Thomas G.B. Wheelock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Wheelock of Lloyd's Neck, L.I. The Rev. Benjamin Minifie performed the ceremony in Grace Episcopal Church.
WASHINGTON, April 7-- Washington lawyers generally, including those who are his friends, say that George Luzerne Hart Jr. is a conservative, but the judge will not accept any easy characterization.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)--Pamela Jean Rudden, representing New Jersey, was selected tonight as Queen of the 1967 National Cherry Blossom Festival.

BOSTON, Aril 7 (AP)-- Frank Hogan, a colorful majorleague catcher who was known as Shanty when he played for the New York Giants baseball team 35 years ago, died today in the Faulkner Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Somerville.
Out-of-work horsemen at Aqueduct are eligible for "substantial" help if they need it, their secretary-treasurer said yesterday.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 10.6 per cent in production for the week ended April 1, compared with the level in the corresponding 1966 week.
HARTFORD, April 7--Gov. George Romney of Michigan announced tonight a policy position on Vietnam coinciding almost precisely with that being followed by President Johnson.

The Computer Sciences Corporation of El Segundo, Calif., announced yesterday the de- velopment of a computer-based ticketing service for the sale of sports or theater tickets at local banks or shopping centers.

Jack Cohen, 60-year-old former president of Local 2 of the Plumbers Union, was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court to six months in prison and fined $5,000 for accepting $1,200 from a contractor in violation of the Taft-Hartley Act. He was free in $2,500 bail pending appeal.
CONCORD, N.H., April 7-- Senator Charles H. Percy declined tonight to remove himself from possible contention in the New Hampshire Presidential primary of 1968.
MONTREAL, April 7--Over- confidence wasn't one of the Rangers' problems today.
JERSEY CITY, April 7 (UPI)--The Post Office Department announced yesterday that 16 men had been arrested on charges of stealing from the mails. More arrests were expected.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 7--The destroyer Waddell was hit nine times yesterday as a North Vietnamese shore battery fired 100 salvos 65 miles southwest of Haiphong. The destroyer finally silenced the enemy guns.

Three hours after a sniper slaying yesterday morning on West 85th Street detectives traced the path of a bullet to a sixth-floor room occupied by an unemployed laborer, who told them that he had been shooting at birds.

ROME, April 1--Secretary General Thant of the United Nations gave a pessimistic assessment of the situation in Vietnam tonight and got an equally dark report from the Special United Nations Mission to seek solution of troubles in Aden.

HOUSTON, April 7 (AP)-- A sheriff's deputy rammed his automobile into a getaway car today, ending a chase of a bandit holding a bank president at gunpoint. Curiosity seekers, photographers and the police converged on the smashed automobile to find the banker grappling with the bandit for his life.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 7--The faculty and students of Cornell University paused today to honor the memory of the nine persons who died Wednesday in a residence-hall fire.
LOS ANGELES, April 7-- The curtain will rise on a new era in theater here next week when two theaters open, completing the city's $33.5-million Music Center.
Potato futures set some sort of record yesterday--and a depressing one for many traders. For the fifth day this week, lifetime lows were set.
CHICAGO, April 7 (AP)-- The Masonite Corporation announced today it has contracted to sell all marketable timber on most of its Mississippi woodlands to the St. Regis Paper Company.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 7-- Roosevelt Raceway, the only wheel in town, attracted only 22,106 persons tonight to its nine-race program, which was featured by a $15,000 junior free-for-all one-mile pace. Some felt this turnout, 401 short of last Friday night's attendance, when Cardigan Bay was the magnet, was somewhat on the disappointing side. The cloudy, occasionally rainy weather, however, might have held down the gate.

KINSHASA, the Congo, April 7--President Joseph D. Mobutu announced today over radio and television the details of the constitutional changes that his regime was about to make.

NEW DELHI--On Feb. 10 the Government of India made the following announcement: "1971 is the 'cut-off date,' after which no further concessional imports of wheat will be sought. AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, April 7--The driver exploring the flat, canal-striped lowlands a few miles southwest of Amsterdam does a double take when he gets to Schiphol Airport. He is certain that he has seen not one, but two airports so close together they are using the same runways.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., April 8 An unassuming Negro who left the drab slums of this Southern tobacco town to win the Medal of Honor for bravery in Vietnam came home to an elaborate welcome today.

HEPATICAS are among spring's daintiest flowers. In early springs, blooms appear in March. In cold northern areas, April is the usual time. Initially the white, pinkish, blue or lavender flowers appear as small fuzzy buds that are likely to be half hidden among the previous year's foliage. As they uncurl, the flowers emerge on three-to-six-inch stems.

ANEMONE, the very name sings of spring woods, when April winds sway budding boughs. Then the tremulous little native wood anemone (A quinquefolia) carpets the ground with beauty. The flowers are borne above low clumps of compound leaves that have deeply cut, wedge-shaped leaflets.

MIAMI BEACH, April 8 (AP)--Aided by the best twoman game of the tournament, a 504, Bernard Mandalla and Gene Harchelroad of Pittsburgh took fifth place today in the classic doubles division of the American Bowling Congress championships. The classic is limited to professionals.

BRUSSELS, April 9--Vice President Humphrey is said to feel that his diplomatic mission to Europe has succeeded in stemming the tide of discontent among the European allies and in opening the door to a resolution of disarmament and economic issues dividing the alliance.

Practical problems, such as not knowing whom to ask for information, are more of a barrier to a Negro or Puerto Rican trying to get a mortgage than discrimination is, a study conducted for the City Commission on Human Rights indicates.
PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 9--Washington is expected to relax the requirement that virtually all of its aid to Latin America be tied to the purchase of United States exports.
The Philadelphia Port Corporation is planning to expand a 4-berth pier project into an 11-to 14-berth container complex.

HELP WANTED: Potential judge. Must have practiced law 10 years. Manhattan resident, preferably from East Side. To join 95-member court. Salary $25,000. Job is yours until age 70--if you win. Apply for interviews, and submit resume no later than April 11.

The fourth and last concert in the Virtuosi di Roma's Vivaldi Festival at Philarmonic Hall last night was a benefit for the Toscanini Memorial Archives in the music division of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center.

THE modernization of a musical comedy is always fair game for an enterprising producer, but Kirk Browning's pop surgery on "Damn Yankees" appeared to be the product of a bent scalpel. The Saturday night program on the network of the National Broadcasting Company was so busy trying to graf together multiple staging forms that no one seemed to notice that the show's pulse beat had stopped early in the operation.

NEW HAVEN, April 9-- Wendell R. Garner, a professor and former chairman of the psychology department at Johns Hopkins University, has been appointed James Rowland Angell Professor of Psychology at Yale University, it was announced at Yale today.
WILL Sucess kill the pants suit?

The continuing debate on Federal maritime policy will move into a high-level forum on Wednesday when Senator E. L. Bartlett opens his committee's long-delayed series of hearings into the merchant marine.

STILLWATER, Okla., April 9 (AP)--Dave Porter of Michigan pinned Curly Culp of Arizona State in the final match last night, giving the East a 19-17 victory over the West in the first East-West National Collegiate Athletic Association all-star wrestling meet.

PARIS, April 9--"It's not Hubert's fault that the Atlantic is wider than ever." That remark by a senior European diplomat today summed up the reaction in Europe to the two-week visit by Vice President Humphrey.

THIS season's orange crop is the largest on record and now, at the height of the harvest, is the best time to enjoy the bright golden fruit, either by itself or in salads, sauces, baking or marmalade.
WASHINGTON, April 9-- Barry Goldwater applauded President Johnson today on issues of the Vietnam war.
At 11:22 yesterday morning, Mayor Lindsay swung his leg over a shiny black English bicycle and, to the cheers of onlookers, whizzed away from Gracie Mansion to the faraway borough of Brooklyn.
NEW DELHI, April 8-- The largest display of American paintings India has ever seen is being shown here, and is provoking indignation, bewilderment and excitement.

HARTFORD, April 9--In Emanuel Synagogue here this afternoon, Miss Lois Gersten Rome, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Aron Rome of West Hartford, became the bride of Stephen Toby Kunian of Boston. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Saul Kunian of Swampscott, Mass.

Almost four Democrats in 10, or twice as many as a year ago, disapprove of the way President Johnson is handling the situation in Vietnam, George Gallup, the poll taker, said yesterday in an article in The World Journal Tribune.
Larry Dinardo of St. Francis Prep won the shot-put and set a meet record in the discus yesterday in the 11th annual All Hallows Games at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
WASHINGTON, April 9-- Senator Thruston B. Morton, in a change of attitude, suggested today that members of the Senate be required to publish an annual financial statement of assets and liabilities.

Ten families will be moved from their 72-year-old tenement at 633 East Fifth Street this morning, and, if all goes well, move back in to rehabilitated apartments in the same building on Thursday morning.
SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., April 9--James Prigoff of the City A.C. retained his National Squash Tennis Association championship at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.
New York City is investigating the feasibility of using two pioneering medical systems introduced by the Kaiser Foundation in California.
TEL AVIV, April 9--Mrs. Violet Elliot, the wife of an American businessman, was sentenced to one year in prison here today in connection with a plot to blow up a railway bridge in Zambia.

John V. Lindsay withstood Some difficult competition again last night: he didn't shoot as fast as the cowboys on "Bonanza," didn't sing like the Smothers Brothers and didn't emote like Richard Burton.
The tail of the earth's magnetosphere wags.
A merger of the Lazard Fund with Moody's Capital Fund, subject to the approval of Lazard Fund stockholders, was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 9-- Different designations have been used to identify the Apollo spacecraft involved in last January's fatal accident.

SEOUL, South Korea, April 9--As a key project in South Korea's program to increase exports, this nation is waging a drive to expand its sales to the United States drastically. This year's goal is $200-million, double last year's record of $100million.

PEKING, April 9 (Reuters)-- Chairman Mao has ordered the army, now wielding wide powers across the country in the Cultural Revolution, to curb its heavy-handed treatment of the population, it was disclosed here today.
FLEMINGTON, N.J., April 9 --Leaders of a fight to prevent construction of a jetport in Hunterdon County prepared today lead a march on Trenton.
Alcan Aluminium, Ltd., has joined the lengthening list of corporate image seekers and will have some high-class help.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 9--A pall of smoke rises over this beleaguered city. A rat-tat-tat never ceases. There are hundreds of explosions, shrieks of anger, the sounds of tearing metal.
WASHINGTON, April 9--A major trucking shutdown spread across the nation today as the Government searched for a key to unlock the labor dispute that caused it.

JAKARTA, Indonesia--Former President Sukarno often used his considerable capacity for scorn against advocates of birth control and family planning. Touring villages in Java, he would proudly single out, as community exemplars, mothers who had borne a dozen or more children.

DURHAM, N.C., April 9--In a spectacular finish to a successful spring, the New York Mets rallied for five runs in the bottom half of the ninth inning today to down the Baltimore Orioles, 5-4. Larry Stahl's threerun homer was the big blow of the inning and Tommy Davis decided the game with a pinchhit single that broke a 4-4 tie.
COHOES, N.Y.--The parade that came throbbing down the main street of this turn-ofthe-century mill city Saturday would not have looked thin on Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) --The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, said tonight that "some unnamed source somewhere in the executive department" blocked Senate action on a resolution for President Johnson to take to a meeting of hemispheric chiefs of state.

CHICAGO, April 9 (UPI)-- The Toronto Maple Leafs outplayed the Chicago Black Hawks from the opening second tonight to earn a 3-1 triumph and even their Stanley Cup playoff semi-final series at one victory apiece.
Donald R. Lee, a Buffalo antipoverty official, was elected state president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in a special election yesterday.

Publication of a new edition of "U.S. Coast Pilot 2," a 230page book describing the 267mile Stretch of Atlantic coast from Cape Cod, Mass., to Sandy Hook, N.J., was announced yesterday by the Coast and Geodetis Survey of the Department of Commerce's Environmental Science Services Administration. The last edition of the publication came out in 1960.

WARM-WEATHER fashions from California are the star attractions of Martin's of Brooklyn's expanded fifth-floor sportswear departments. Sportswear Elegante and the Town and Country Shop have beachwear, travel, daytime and play clothes by both old and new California designers.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 9 (AP)--Tony Roche of Australia defeated Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico, 6-2, 6-4, in the singles final, then gained a share of the doubles championship in the Caribe Hilton hardcourt tennis tournament today.
MANILA, April 9 (AP)-- More than 100 American veterans, many of whom were prodded through the streets of Manila by the Japanese in 1942, marched there again today.
PITTSBURGH, April 9-- Chances for a quick recovery of the steel market appear slim.
A 15-year-old boy, troubled over low marks at school, stole a car to run away from home last night. The stolen car, the police said, crashed into another car, killing a woman.

An epidemic of guerrilla fighting is sweeping over Latin America. When their numbers are added, their arms and finances estimated, and their present ineffectiveness considered, the temptation is to brush the guerrillas aside as mere irritations.

RENNES, France, April 9 (AP)--The first bits of oil from the battered tanker Torrey Canyon reached the French coast today. Inhabitants of Lingreville, a village 15 miles north of Granville in the Manche Department (County), said the oil appeared in small spongy bits along 200 yards of the beach.
LOOKING at it on television, a viewer would never have guessed that the man who sank the putt had just won one of golf's most coveted prizes.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 9--Sue Cullman, a 17-year-old senior at Rosemary Hall in Greenwich, rode Fancy Me to the regular working hunter championship at the New Canaan Mounted Trop horse show today.
Tradition will be served today when the major league baseball season opens with the customary first games at Washington and Cincinnati. The other 16 teams will be in action tomorrow.
The Farr-Harris Central Park Sunday Cycling Society had its first Bicycle Bash yesterday. The participants agreed they might never be the same again.
BUENOS AIRES, April 9-- Argentina has reached final agreements with the two outstanding United States oil companies whose contracts were annulled in November, 1963.

THE Westchester Knockout Team Championship began last fall with an entry of 24 teams. The final match played recently resulted in a victory for Mr. and Mrs. Richard Hewitt and Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Lobell, all of Scarsdale.
"No question--we wereon sweating it out," Bob Scott, the lacrosse coach at Johns Hopkins, said yesterday in commenting about his team's 10-6 triumph over Washington in Baltimore Saturday.

The Brooklyn Philharmonia journeyed to Manhattan on Saturday night to play its fourth annual concert at Philharmonic Hall. Accompanying the orchestra to Lincoln Center was a sizable contingent of Brooklyn patrons, many elaborately dressed for the annual Philharmonia Symphony Ball, which followed in the Grand Promenade of the New York State Theater.

WASHINGTON, April 9--The Ripon Society, an organization of moderate and liberal Republicans drawn largely from the academic world, urged today that a negative income tax be adopted to replace many public welfare and antipoverty programs.

DALLAS, April 9 (AP)--A 26-man swimming and diving squad, with two contestants to be added, was named today by the National Amateur Athletic Union to represent the United States in the Pan-American Games at Winnipeg, Can., July 23 to Aug. 6.
President Johnson will be off tonight to Punta del Este, Uruguay, and the summit meeting of hemispheric heads of state. The conference begins Wednes day and ends on Friday.
VADUZ, Liechtenstein, April 9 (UPI)--The Government of Liechtenstein has agreed to increase its armed forces by 33 per cent, from 21 to 28 men, and add two police dogs, it was reported today.
ALBANY, April 9 (AP)--A growing number of trucking companies in New York State were reported tonight to be joining the lockout.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) --Attorney General Ramsey Clark announced tonight that this year's Young American Medals for Bravery will be awarded to Gloria Cassidy, 14 years old, of New York, and 17-year-old Nathaniel Curry of Opa Locka, Fla.

WASHINGTON, April 9--Offers by other leading trading nations to reduce tariffs in the Kennedy round of trade negotiations covered almost $2-billion less in total trade than United States offers, a member of the House of Representatives disclosed today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 9--United States infantrymen, advanced behind rumbling tanks late this afternoon into a heavily fortified village from which enemy troops had been fighting for more than a day.

WASHINGTON, April 9--Seeking to soothe Congressional critics, the Administration will ask tomorrow that the antipoverty law be sharply revised to prevent future abuses.

A riding stable in Connecticut offered yesterday to send its fastest thoroughbreds here to help Aqueduct get back into business.

The United States Office of Education has granted $2million to Teachers College, Columbia University, to build a research and demonstration center for the education of the handicapped, John H. Fischer, president of the college, announced yesterday.

Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello appealed yesterday for citizens to report on the "effectiveness and integrity" of city inspection services to back up the Lindsay administration's program for detecting graft.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 9--The inquiry into the fire on the Apollo spacecraft has been called by a consultant to the board "the most monumental detective story of all time." WOLVERHAMPTON, England, April 9 (Reuters)--The Toastmaster at a Labor party dinner toasted Prime Minister Wilson--instead of Queen Elizabeth--and stirred up a minor storm among Conservatives today.

INDIAN dance, like Indian food, is an acquired taste, and once the average westerner has acquired it he is still likely to be in the position of the man who knows what he likes but is less certain why he likes it. These musings are prompted by the recital of Indian dance given by Bhaskar and his comapany Saturday night at the 92d Street young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.

WEST Virginia is assured of a place in fishing his tory because the centennial golden trout originated there. This fishing season, New Jersey and Pennsylvania anglers will have a chance to catch these beautiful butter-colored trout.

JAMES EDWIN WEBB, head of the National Aero nautics and Space Administration, is a blue-eyed stocky man of 5 feet 9 inches who was born in a small North Carolina town with the improbable name of Tally Ho.
Gustave L. Levy, a senior partner in Goldman, Sachs Co., was nominated yesterday for a one-year term as the next chairman of the New York Stock Exchange's board of governors.

Lucky Stores, Inc., of San Leandro, Calif., has agreed to buy the Consolidated Foods Corporation's Eagle Supermarket operation for $50-million in cash and securities, it was announced yesterday following board approval of both companies.

WASHINGTON, April 10 How much longer will everyone have to go on struggling to maintain his cool? It was amusing enough back in the early Kennedy days when a beautifully maintained display of cool made its exhibitor feel part of the New Frontier, the new generation, the artsy-insy-toughsy set with the temperature so low ice wouldn't melt in its mouth. But six years of day-in, dayout cool maintenance !

WESTBURY, L.I., April 10 The news that Aqueduct's shutdown had ended was met with almost indifference by Roosevelt Raceway officials tonight. They seemed to agree that the five-day hiatus at the Big A had not made much of an impact on their business.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 10 (UPI) The Michigan Daily reported yesterday that Senator Robert F. Kennedy had told an interviewer that even though the "doves" represented a minority viewpoint, protests against the Vietnam war had restrained President Johnson's handling of it.
Late buying spurred prices on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

Vandals destroyed a huge electric switchboard panel over the weekend at Junior High School 59 in Springfield Gardens, Queens, cutting off the lights and heat and forcing a delay of two hours in the beginning of classes yesterday.

Directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York have elected John J. Clarke as vice president and special legal adviser and Edward G. Guy as vice president and general counsel, Alfred Hayes, president, announced over the weekend.

The new Norwegian motorship Stav Viking, the latest addition to the Viking Line fleet, will be given the usual harbor welcome as she passes the Statue of Liberty at 10 A.M. today on her maiden arrival here.
BERNE, Switzerland, April 10 (UPI) Henri Kunz, the president of the Swiss Ice Hockey Federation, and its entire Central Committee resigned today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 (AP) The Philadelphia Phillies, without a reliable first baseman since Bill White injured his foot during the winter, purchased Tito Francona today from the St. Louis Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, April 10 Following are excerpts from the text of a statement today by James E. Webb, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, before the House Subcommittee on NASA Oversight, a unit of the Committee on Science and Astronautics:
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 11 Units of the United States Ninth Infantry Division have killed 166 Vietcong soldiers in fighting 20 miles from Saigon that entered its third day today.

Capt. Sydney Blackledge, vice president of American Export Isbrandsten Lines, Inc., was reelected president yesterday of the National Cargo Bureau at the 16th annual meeting of members and directors at 99 John Street.
DAYTON, Ohio, April 10 (AP) Dwight Edwin Young, publisher and Former editor of The Dayton Journal Herald, died early today at his home in Kettering. He was 83 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The Supreme Court made it easier today for poor convicts in state prisons to try to win their freedom in Federal courts.

WASHINGTON, April 10 Officials of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation were accused by a Government hearing examiner today of "clearly improper" be havior at hearings on the concern's plan to take over the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc.

Mrs. Rhea Glance Grubart, founder and former secretary of Branch 520 of the Farband Labor Zionist Order, died at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals Sunday night. She and her husband, Harold, lived at 1520 Sheridan Avenue in the Bronx. She was 54 years old.

SATTAHIP, Thailand, April 10--The three B-52 bombers that landed at U Taphao airfield this morning, the first to be based in Thailand, loosed their payloads of 500-pound and 750-pound bombs on an enemy base camp and storage center 30 miles nothwest of Saigon on their way from Guam.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 10--Ceylon proposed today a meeting between the National Liberation Front and the Governments of North Vietnam and South Vietnam to discuss the conditions for a cease-fire.
George S. Moore was elected president of the Metropolitan Opera Association yesterday, replacing Anthony A. Bliss.

BRUSSELS, April 10 The West German Foreign Minister, Willy Brandt, declared today that Britain was sincere in her desire to join the Common Market and that the problems of British membership "can be solved in a businesslike fashion."

NASHVILLE, April 10 A new outbreak of rioting by Negro students tonight prompted the Tennessee House of Representatives to demand that Stokely Carmichael, the "black power" advocate, be deported to Trinidad.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The Pentagon issued today its biggest draft call of the year, asking for the induction of 19,800 men in June. All will go to the Army.
The city's water supply has improved enough to mean few, if any, real restrictions on the use of water this summer.

NAPLES, Fla., April 10 Dr. Carl A. Coppolino, on trial on a charge of having murdered his first wife, heard a woman doctor testify today that she no longer believed his statement that he awoke to find his wife lying in her bed dead of a heart attack.

CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) A brown spider, called the "brown recluse," whose bite probably is more toxic than that of the black widow spider, now is found in more than a dozen Midwestern and Southern states, a team of medical investigators reported today.
A one-club opening bid with a three-card suit is not the easy route to bidding success that some players suppose.

Arthur V. Williams, an elected trustee of Local 1233 of the International Longshoremen's Association of Newark, was indicted by a grand jury yesterday for allegedly misappropriating union funds, according to the Waterfront Commission of New York, Harbor.

The bill that would establish a modified direct primary system for nominating candidates for statewide offices such as Governor and United States Senator is now one of 945 left by the Legislature for Governor Rockefeller to sign into law or to veto. We hope that he will approve this much-needed reform.

WASHINGTON, Apri1 10 (AP) A round of hearings on whether the Government should participate actively in the development of an electric car for commercial markets ended today with Federal agencies in disagreement on the issue.

WASHINGTON, April 10 The flow of economic aid to Latin America, from major United States Government and international financing agencies reached a record, $1.3-billion, during 1966, according to statistics announced today by the InterAmerican Committee for the Alliance for Progress.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 10 Yemeni royalists in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, strongly discounted reports from Cairo and Sana today of the assassination of Prince Abdulla ben Hassan, son of the royalist Premier and military commander.
Preston Martin, the California savings-and-loan commissioner, predicted yesterday that Federal authorities would act by July 1 to roll back interest and dividend rates on savings accounts.

WASHINGTON, April 10 Government officials have reacted with keen interest to unexpected statements last week by the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Bank of Amer ica, to the effect that, in a showdown, the dollar is superior to gold and that the United States need not be so "defensive" about the deficit in its balance of payments.

Mrs. Frances Magid Sneider, who was active for many years in Jewish philanthropies, died yesterday in Presbyterian Hospital. Her age was 71, and she was the wife of Leopold James Sneider, retired head of the Magid Company, handbag manufacturers. They resided at 19 East 88th Street.

CHICAGO, April 10 Church officials disclosed today that the international Synod of Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church would concentrate on matters of doctrinal orthodoxy and avoid issues such as clerical celibacy and peace.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 (UPI)--Rick Barry, still performing well despite an injured left ankle, scored 25 points tonight to pace the San Francisco Warriors to a 123-102 victory over the St. Louis Hawks and a 3-2 lead in the National Basketball Association Western Division playoff.
The midtown Manhattan towaway program will be extended to new areas before the end of summer, Mayor Lindsay's representative on a parking study team said yesterday.
SUCCESSOR was caught off base, but the settlement of the horsemen's boycott here last night left other top Kentucky Derby candidates in a position to do their tuning-up at Aqueduct.

ATLANTA, April 10 Gov. Lester G. Maddox halted the electrocution of a convicted rapist today and said he was considering delaying all executions until Georgia could vote in a referendum on capital punishment.

Lincoln Center tonight: "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera, 8, and Strauss's "Die Aegyptische Helena," presented in concert form by the Little Orchestra Society with Ingrid Bjoner, William Olvis and others, Philharmonic Hall, 8.

Donald F. Shaughnessy, president of the New York City Public Development Corporation, announced yesterday that agreement had been reached to build a multimillion-dollar Graphic Arts Center on Manhattan's Lower West Side.
PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Aprll 10 The United States and the other American republics differed sharply in private today over the future of trade policies in the Western Hemisphere.
LISBON, Tuesday, April 11 Portugal's political police announced early today that the Roman Catholic-led society Pragma had been closed for "spreading ideas of subversive political indoctrination."

Members of the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association signified their intention last night of resuming racing in a meeting at the Americana Hotel, and Tommy Trotter immediately became the center of attention.
Harlan J. Swift, president of the Erie County Savings Bank of Buffalo, was nominated yesterday as president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

JACKSON, Miss., April 10 A battle scarred Head Start program, accused by critics of misusing hundreds of thousands of Federal dollars, has won an auditor's finding that "the amount of disallowance, if any, will be relatively minor in amount."

HOLLYWOOD, April 10 "A Man for All Seasons," the movie version of Robert Bolt's stage drama, was voted the best feature film of 1966 tonight at the 39th annual awards presentation of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. The ceremony was held at the Santa Monica Civic Auditorium.
WASHINGTON, April 10 President Johnson left tonight for Punta del Este, Uruguay, for a three-day conference with 17 other American heads of government, the first such meeting since 1956.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 The medical doctor was ad vised today by a New York internist to master the techniques of the computer age or lose his place as "the keystone to medical care."
